headline: In Brooklyn, Challenging the Party Establishment
abstract: The New Kings Democrats, formed in 2008, continue to lobby for reform with the Democratic Party and to engage more of the community.
lead_paragraph: When their excitement of watching Barack Obama win the presidency began to fade and the reality of the local political machine — something they wanted to be a part of — had set in, Rachel Lauter and Matt Cowherd founded New Kings Democrats, the Brooklyn-based, grass-roots political organization.

headline: Storm’s Impact on Oil Industry Is Felt at Gasoline Pumps
abstract: Fuel prices are up sharply nationwide in Hurricane Harvey’s aftermath, and may be so for months, given the blows to refining, production and shipping.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ports along the Gulf of Mexico are closed to fuel barges. Part of the biggest pipeline between Texas and New York has stopped flowing. Refineries and gas stations are flooded. Drilling rigs in the biggest shale field in Texas are running low on diesel supplies.

headline: South of the Border, Migrants Eye a Storm-Torn Texas
abstract: The powerful storm that struck Texas created opportunities in the eyes of some border crossers, but many fearing new immigration policies stayed put.
lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — When a group of migrants staying in a shelter in this border city heard last weekend that Hurricane Harvey was barreling down on Texas, they did not wait. They saw an opportunity to ford the Rio Grande and slip into the United States, using the storm as cover.

headline: Mattis Insists He and Trump Are on the Same Page on North Korea
abstract: Asked if he had considered resigning over policy differences with the president, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he was committed to serving as secretary of defense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Jim Mattis insisted on Thursday that he was not at odds with President Trump over North Korea and asserted that the media had misinterpreted his recent remarks on how to deal with Pyongyang.

headline: Officials Eye Euphrates River Valley as Last Stand for ISIS
abstract: Even with the Islamic State on the run, U.S. advisers grapple with political and military problems in wresting Iraqi and Syrian towns from extremists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Islamic State fighters are expected to make their last stand in a series of Euphrates River Valley towns and villages that American-backed Syrian and Iraqi forces are not expected to attack for months, American officials said Thursday.

headline: How Shelley Worrell, Creator of CaribBeing, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The creator of the Brooklyn-based Caribbean culture hub likes to garden, buy Caribbean produce and check out neighbors’ West Indian Day Parade costumes.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Shelley Vidia Worrell saw her Caribbean roots reflected everywhere. So as an adult, in an effort to celebrate and preserve them, she created CaribBeing, which hosts film series and art exhibitions, and which just completed a monthlong residency in a shipping container at the Brooklyn Museum. When not at the museum or working with the mayor’s office to designate an official Little Caribbean in Flatbush, Ms. Worrell, 40, has been checking out her neighbors’ preparations for the West Indian American Day Parade, which will be held on Sept. 4 in Crown Heights. She lives in a brownstone with her husband, Janluk Stanislas, a filmmaker.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Metropolis Awash in Stagnant Brew of Chemicals, Sewage and Garbage
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 1, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no need to test it. It’s contaminated. There’s millions of contaminants.”

headline: Stephon Marbury Stops at N.Y.U., as His Story Continues
abstract: After a contentious N.B.A. career, the basketball standout from Brooklyn became a star in China; he spoke to students Wednesday about his odyssey.
lead_paragraph: Stephon Marbury walked into a secluded courtyard off East 12th Street in Lower Manhattan Wednesday afternoon and settled into a chair between two tables stacked with boxes of shoes.

headline: What Sandy Can Teach Harvey About Recovery
abstract: Five years after the storm that wreaked havoc in New York, some victims are still rebuilding their homes. What can Houston learn from the city’s mistakes?
lead_paragraph: Disasters are meant to inform each other, the mistakes of one recovery observed and presumably avoided in the next. Those tasked with remaking Houston in the wake of the current devastation, will have a thick playbook of error on which to reflect.

headline: Drag Racing for Any Car: 12 Seconds of Pure Adrenaline
abstract: A photographer captured the rush of “Race Your Own Ride” night at Raceway Park in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: You really think a Prius can blow the doors off a Hyundai Elantra? On Wednesday nights, the place to settle such a question is Englishtown, N.J., where $20 can buy drivers three runs on the quarter-mile drag strip at Raceway Park.

headline: What North Korea’s Missile Tests Look Like to a South Korean Reporter
abstract: A conversation with Choe Sang-Hun, the New York Times’s Seoul correspondent, about where the standoff might be headed.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — North Korea fired a ballistic missile over northern Japan this week, prompting the government in Tokyo to warn residents in its path to take cover, and leading to another round of questions about whether war will soon strike the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Discussing North Korea
abstract: This week’s Australia newsletter features a conversation with our correspondent in Seoul, South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Though Federer Survives 2nd 5-Set Match, His Play Invites Questions
abstract: Something appears to be amiss with Federer’s game, casting some doubt on his status as a favorite at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: The signs were there before the United States Open began, even if many devoted fans refused to recognize them. Roger Federer had injured his 36-year-old back during a tournament in Montreal two weeks ago, then had withdrawn from the next tournament in Cincinnati to rest it.

headline: Texas Abortion Restriction Is Temporarily Blocked
abstract: A federal judge ruled that opponents of the law, which would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion, were likely to succeed in court.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a Texas law that would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion.

headline: Dave Dombrowski, Ever the Tinkerer, Readies the Red Sox for October
abstract: The Boston executive Dombrowski has won just one World Series in his 40-year career, with the Marlins. But that’s never stopped him from pursuing more.
lead_paragraph: The doors are now locked to all newcomers hoping to play past Oct. 1. Once September arrives, baseball executives cannot add pieces to help in the postseason. Everyone eligible for a playoff roster must be in his organization before Sept. 1. The gang’s all there now, for some lucky franchise. We just don’t know which.

headline: How Federal Flood Insurance Puts Homes at Risk
abstract: The underfunded program encourages development in flood-prone areas.
lead_paragraph: It was clear long before Hurricane Harvey slammed into Texas that the National Flood Insurance Program, the government’s most important means of recovering from such disasters, needed to be overhauled. It fails to account for the full extent of flood risk, encourages development in areas known to be flood-prone and is not realistically funded.

headline: Without Wasting a Word
abstract: A Patrick Berry Friday is a very good Friday indeed.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Don’t tell anyone, but this is a rough week for me. I took The Boy to college for his first semester, and I’m incredibly proud of how much he’s grown up in the past few years. I love the young man he’s become. He’s outgrown whatever teenage quirks he had, and he’s really nice to be around. And now he’s leaving. By the way, today’s puzzle is a really nice one by Patrick Berry.

headline: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend
abstract: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.
lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky enough to have time off this Labor Day weekend, put in a few extra hours with a movie or two about the workplace. Whether they are set in cube farms or factories, the stories of workers’ struggles and triumphs will always have a place in the movies. Here are 7 to start with. Get to work.

headline: For 18 Hours, 3 Men in Houston Fought for Survival in Hurricane Harvey
abstract: The men, including two journalists for The Daily Mail chronicling a rescue attempt, jumped out of a boat shortly before it crashed into power lines.
lead_paragraph: Clinging to a tree branch in torrential rain and howling winds, Ruaridh Connellan fought against the ferocious current of Houston’s Greens Bayou. His body was weak and under water. Are we going to die, he said over and over again to a colleague hugging the trunk of the tree.

headline: Soccer Star Kylian Mbappe’s Move to Paris St.-Germain Is Completed
abstract: It was widely reportedly that P.S.G. will pay 180 million euros ($216 million) for the 18-year-old Monaco forward.
lead_paragraph: Forward Kylian Mbappe’s expected move to Paris St.-Germain finally went through Thursday evening, as Monaco loaned him until the end of the season along with an option to make the move permanent. No financial details were given by P.S.G. in its statement, but the permanent deal would be from 2018 to 2022.

headline: Corrections: September 1, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, September 1, 2017.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Who’s Allowed to Hold Hands?
abstract: A Jamaican woman chafes at the reality that expressing affection for her wife can lead to confrontations with her fellow immigrants in New York.
lead_paragraph: On our first date, I dared to give her a lingering hug on a crowded subway platform on West Fourth Street, an unusual display of physical affection on my part, which I blamed on the wine. It was the start of spring, the city in bloom.

headline: Inside One of Houston’s Improvised Shelters
abstract: One family describes how they lost everything in the flooding before being taken to one of the many shelters in Houston.
lead_paragraph: One family describes how they lost everything in the flooding before being taken to one of the many shelters in Houston.

headline: Word + Quiz: flippant
abstract: This word has appeared in 42 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Texas, ‘Brexit,’ Emmanuel Macron: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: With Aaron Judge Struggling at the Plate, Greg Bird Steps Up for the Yankees
abstract: Bird, after a miserable start and an ankle injury, homered for the second game in a row as the Yankees survived the ninth to thump the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: A couple of days off, a demotion in the batting order and the presence of a real judge — Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the United States Supreme Court — in the Judge’s Chambers at Yankee Stadium did little to spur Aaron Judge out of his second-half funk on Thursday.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Narcos’ and ‘Diana, 7 Days’
abstract: “Narcos” returns on Netflix without its main character. And a new documentary on Diana, Princess of Wales, focuses on the week after her death.
lead_paragraph: “Narcos” returns on Netflix without its main character. And a new documentary on Diana, Princess of Wales, focuses on the week after her death.

headline: Plastic Bags
abstract: Is the use of plastic bags limited where you live? Should it be?

headline: Boats Carrying Rohingya Fleeing Myanmar Sink, Killing 46
abstract: The victims were trying to escape renewed violence in western Myanmar, where the predominantly Muslim group faces oppression.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At least 46 people believed to be Rohingya fleeing violence in western Myanmar have been found dead on the banks of a river along the boundary with Bangladesh, Bangladeshi officials said on Friday.

headline: The 1990s Gave Us the Trump Teens
abstract: Had America not absorbed the sheer skeeviness of that decade, we wouldn’t be where we are today.
lead_paragraph: It began on the slopes in Aspen the last week of 1989. A real estate mogul and his paramour, a model named Marla Maples, had the misfortune to walk straight into the path of the mogul’s wife, Ivana Trump. There was a confrontation. And a short time later the gossip columns were consumed with the first juicy scandal of the 1990s. One tabloid headline went so far as to declare “Best Sex I Ever Had,” a reference (some say apocryphal) to how Ms. Maples rated Donald Trump.

headline: The Urban Revival Is Over
abstract: People are no longer pouring into America’s cities. And that’s bad news for everyone.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For all the concern about the gentrification, rising housing prices and the growing gap between the rich and poor in our leading cities, an even bigger threat lies on the horizon: The urban revival that swept across America over the past decade or two may be in danger. As it turns out, the much-ballyhooed new age of the city might be giving way to a great urban stall-out.

headline: Make Pot Legal for Veterans With Traumatic Brain Injury
abstract: An explosion in Afghanistan left me with daily migraines. The best solution is illegal: marijuana.
lead_paragraph: The explosion that wounded me during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in 2010 left me with a traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress. In 2012 I was medically retired from the Marine Corps because of debilitating migraines, vertigo and crippling depression. After a nine-year career, I sought care from the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: In Praise of Equipoise
abstract: We all have many identities, and we do best when we’re able to move through them gracefully.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese-born writer Amin Maalouf made an interesting point about identity: Other people often pick ours for us. The anti-Semite elevates the Jewish consciousness in the Jew. The Sunni radical elevates Shiite consciousness in the Shiite.

headline: The Week the Earth Stood Still
abstract: When normally stoic scientists start draining the barrel of awful superlatives, it’s time to pay attention.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, most of us were still trying to fathom what nine trillion gallons of water would feel like — that hydraulic cube over downtown Houston, four miles square and two miles high. And then the cube doubled to become the most extreme rain event in American history.

headline: Blocking a Bad Immigration Law in Texas
abstract: A judge has temporarily blocked an attempt to force localities to cooperate with harsh federal policies, but the legal struggle will continue.
lead_paragraph: Anyone watching the storm devastation in Texas had to be stirred by the mix of resilient victims and valiant rescuers — a mix of people from all backgrounds united in a struggle for survival. The heroic images of community resolve could not have been a more apt backdrop for the decision by a federal judge in Texas in midstorm to block the Republican-controlled state government’s attempt to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities and make them enforce federal immigration laws.

headline: Red Sox’s Gentle Bunt Draws a Furious Response From C. C. Sabathia
abstract: “I just feel like they try to take the weak road,” Sabathia, the Yankees’ starter, said after Eduardo Nunez bunted on Boston’s second at-bat of the night Thursday.
lead_paragraph: It was a delicately hit ball, a bunt placed by Eduardo Nunez just in front of the pitcher’s mound in the first inning on Thursday. But for C. C. Sabathia, who came down off the hill to field it, the bunt came saddled with a gesture, one that seemed bold enough to awaken a bear in winter.

headline: In ‘House of Z,’ the Jagged Arc of Zac Posen
abstract: A documentary available on Vogue’s website chronicles the rocky path of a comet of the fashion world.
lead_paragraph: Zac Posen’s mythic ascent to fashion superstardom is retold in “House of Z,” a documentary by Sandy Chronopoulos available for streaming on Wednesday, Sept. 6, at Vogue.com/houseofz. The son of an artist and a lawyer living in SoHo, Mr. Posen first draped fabric on dolls as a toddler. As a teen at Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, he turned the actresses Paz de la Huerta, Jemima Kirke and Lola Schnabel into muses. While a student at Central St. Martin’s in London, he designed a pink silk dress for Naomi Campbell that was passed from woman to woman before catching the eye of a reporter for The New York Times. Buyers came calling and Mr. Posen set up a studio with the help of his mother and sister. A star was born. He was 20.

headline: Quad Cinema’s Nicolas Roeg Retrospective Highlights a Director’s Lens Work
abstract: The program features several of Roeg’s films from his time as a cinematographer, as well as his signature non-linear approach to directing.
lead_paragraph: The great British filmmaker Nicolas Roeg was a cinematographer before he was a director, and the partial retrospective of his work now underway at the Quad Cinema is wisely including two classic films highlighting his lens work.

headline: ‘Company’ Helps Take Those Dog Days of Summer for a Walk
abstract: The busy summer theater season in the Berkshires is almost over, but Barrington Stage Company extended its production of “Company” through Sept. 10.
lead_paragraph: The official last day of summer is not until Sept. 22, but let’s face it: It’s essentially over after Labor Day, and we’re all going to gripe about how it went by faster than ever this year and we didn’t do enough.

headline: Resonant Bodies Festival: Witness the Process at Roulette
abstract: Since 2013, this wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music has had the intimate feel of witnessing works in progress.
lead_paragraph: The art making feels unusually personal during the Resonant Bodies Festival, which began in 2013 and has swiftly become something to look forward to each year. A wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music, lately hosted at Roulette in Brooklyn, it follows a simple formula: Three nights (Tuesday through Thursday, Sept. 5-7), three singers per night, one 45-minute set per singer. The vocalists are the curators.

headline: A Century of Jacob Lawrence
abstract: A new exhibition illuminates Lawrence’s inspiration and his enduring influence.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Lawrence may be best known for his Great Migration series of paintings, depicting the movement northward of millions of black Americans from the South in the early 20th century. But the artist himself was born in Atlantic City, after his own parents made the journey. And this week, the SCAD Museum of Art in Savannah, Ga., will mark Lawrence’s 100th birthday on Thursday, Sept. 7, with the opening of “Lines of Influence,” an exhibition that traces both the sources of his inspiration and his enduring resonance with contemporary artists.

headline: Alexandra Pirici Installs a ‘Threshold’ at the High Line
abstract: Ms. Pirici, who lives and works in Bucharest and Berlin, will create a moving barrier of performers at the top of Manhattan’s verdant pedestrian highway.
lead_paragraph: Anyone strolling the High Line between Tuesday, Sept. 5, and Thursday may encounter traffic in the Rail Yards, the park’s northernmost section. At 30th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues, performers will create a moving barrier for pedestrians to pass through. The event, from 4 to 7 p.m., is Alexandra Pirici’s “Threshold,” a work that the artist describes not as a performance but as an “ongoing action.”

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Putting Art on Wheels and Taking It Back to the Street’
abstract: What do artists, truck drivers and customers think about Spain’s Truck Art Project?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Nora Ephron on the advantages of revision.
lead_paragraph: This week Lisa Schwarzbaum reviews a new book about Nora Ephron and her romantic comedies. Ephron was a regular contributor to the Book Review, and in this essay from 1986, she ruminates on the unexpected advantages of revision. Below is an excerpt.

headline: Letter to the Editor
abstract: Mark Lilla responds to Beverly Gage’s review of his new book, “The Once and Future Liberal.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Write a Love Letter
abstract: Give it at least an hour. Strike a balance between poesy and mundane description.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘You need a minimum of one hour,’’ says Sonia Cancian, an assistant professor of history at Zayed University in Dubai. Find a quiet place away from distractions and spend time just thinking about what you want to communicate. ‘‘A letter has a remarkable way of transpiring feelings, emotions, honesty, sincerity and authenticity,’’ says Cancian, who insists on the singular power of a love letter even in the era of more immediate communication methods like video chat or texting.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Coercing Your Wife Into Writing a Memoir
abstract: Can a spouse with an interesting childhood be compelled to turn it into a book?
lead_paragraph: Nicholas writes: My wife had an insane childhood. Her father made her sneak into other people’s gardens to steal orchids so he could sell them. A family friend would come and go, with tales of faking Scud missile launches in Iraq. Not to mention long-ago connections with the Crowninshields, the money long run out. She doesn’t want to embarrass her relatives. But I think she should write a book.

headline: Poem: The Widows’ Neighborhood
abstract: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Terrance Hayes

headline: Behind the Cover: 9.3.17
abstract: For this issue, the new business in Washington of selling a Trump bump.
lead_paragraph: Gail Bichler, design director: “This week’s cover story is about a new cast of characters in Washington who are using their relationships to Donald Trump’s 2016 campaign as a ticket into the capital’s clubby influence industry. To underscore their outsider status —and their sometimes unorthodox methods — we hit on the idea of a D.I.Y. flier.”

headline: New Sentences: From ‘Autumn,’ by Karl Ove Knausgaard
abstract: Is aging a form of surrender to fate?
lead_paragraph: “To turn 40 is to realize that one’s limitations will last one’s whole life through, but also to know that all the time, whether one likes it or not, and whether one is aware of it or not, new layers are being added to one’s character, a type of knowledge and insight that isn’t directed towards the future, towards what will come to pass or one day be accomplished, but towards the here and now, in the things you do every day, in what you think about them and what you understand of them.”

headline: Don’t Mess With Pepe
abstract: The stoner comic character co-opted by the alt-right has joined the ranks of hand-drawn characters who lawyered up and fought back.
lead_paragraph: If Dr. Seuss’ Cat in the Hat emerged victorious from a property rights battle, and so did Maurice Sendak’s Max, why not Pepe the comic zine frog?

headline: On the Road: Two Children Brave the Irish Famine
abstract: Paul Lynch’s novel “Grace” asks timeless questions about suffering and survival through the story of a sister and brother in the Irish famine.
lead_paragraph: GRACE By Paul Lynch 354 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Feminist Fiction From the Philippines, Written 50 Years Ago
abstract: In Nick Joaquin’s “The Woman Who Had Two Navels and Tales of the Tropical Gothic,” women are granted powers that are both uncanny and real.
lead_paragraph: To enter the world of “The Woman Who Had Two Navels and Tales of the Tropical Gothic,” your faith must bend to the following: Time travel exists. Shapeshifting is possible. And a woman could be in power.

headline: Epic Stories That Expand the Universal Family Plot
abstract: Julian Lucas considers how family stories go beyond genealogy to discover those “who became ‘our’ ancestors” and those who didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Family sagas write history through microcosm, tracing a clan’s rise, survival and, more often than not, ultimate dissolution. Thomas Mann’s healthy bourgeois Buddenbrooks succumb to decadent sterility; Gabriel García Márquez’s Buendías are erased by a hurricane; the Starks of Winterfell are massacred in the Riverlands. A family is sacrificed to time, and in their entrails readers find auguries of larger motions. The critic Frank Kermode believed that novels developed alongside a loss of faith in biblical chronology, as substitutes for Adam and Eve’s universal family plot. He is borne out by recent years’ fruitful crop of epics rooted in the familiar soil of fathers and daughters, mothers and sons, blood, sex, bastardy and inheritance.

headline: Suspense Fiction That Mines the Terrain of Female Guilt
abstract: New novels by Deborah Moggach, Nuala Ellwood, Hallie Ephron and Ruth Ware explore the complex ethics, traumas and loyalties that define women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: FINAL DEMAND By Deborah Moggach 225 pp. Overlook, $27.

headline: Fall in Italy: Lovely Weather, Lower Prices
abstract: Sicily, Lake Como and the Amalfi Coast are among the destinations where hotel packages are available (some include airfare).
lead_paragraph: Italy is always in style as a vacation destination for travelers from the United States, and this year is no exception. The country is a best-seller within the travel networks Virtuoso and Signature Travel Network, the latter of which has a double-digit growth in sales in 2017 for Italy trips. Flight searches are also up, but, fortunately, airfare prices are down: between May 1 and July 10, Cheapflights.com saw flight searches to Milan and Rome from the United States for travel for this September and October increase 43 percent, compared with the same period last year while ticket prices dropped by 18 percent to Milan and by 17 percent to Rome. Misty Ewing, the global head of public relations for Virtuoso, encourages value-seekers to consider a fall Italian getaway. “Prices drop significantly, but the weather is still beautiful,” she said.

headline: Mythic Revenge, a Mythic Film and Possibly Mythic Memories
abstract: This week’s crime novels delve into the Spanish past and into film history, then grapple with two present-day children tormented by dangerous visions.
lead_paragraph: Louise Penny wrote the book on escapist mysteries — a dozen of them, in fact, almost all set in the sheltered Canadian village of Three Pines. “It was a haven, a buffer, from the cares and cruelty of the world,” she tells us in GLASS HOUSES (Minotaur, $28.99), a place seemingly so free of malice and discord that Armand Gamache, chief superintendent of the Sûreté du Québec, and his wife, Reine-Marie, have made it their sanctuary. One of the pleasures of returning to this series is visiting old friends in the village like Gabri and Olivier, who run the convivial B&B; the artist Clara Morrow, whose startling portraits will haunt you; and (a personal favorite) Ruth Zardo, a poet who accurately describes herself as “a crazy old woman who prays for Satan and has a duck.”

headline: A Decades-old Detective Series Is Still on Top
abstract: “Y is for Yesterday,” the penultimate installment of Sue Grafton’s Alphabet Series, premieres on the Best-Seller list at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: THE ABCS OF MYSTERY: Back in 1982, when Sue Grafton wrote the first novel in what was to become her career-making Alphabet series, she knew she was taking a risk. “It was a crapshoot,” she told NPR’s Dwayne Brown. “I wasn’t even sure I could sell ‘A Is for Alibi.’” But she wanted to get back into solo writing after a career in Hollywood, and detective fiction called. The risk paid off: The Alphabet books, which star the Southern California-based private investigator Kinsey Millhone, have been steadily enthralling readers with heists, betrayals and murders for the last 35 years.

headline: Unesco World Heritage Sites 2017 Picks Range From Eritrea to England
abstract: A couple of the 21 new inductees, spread among 18 cultural sites and three natural ones, are controversial choices.
lead_paragraph: Unesco annually expands its list of World Heritage Sites, and this year’s class of inductees, announced in July, offers both stimulation for travelers, with a rich and varied group of intriguing sites, and a reminder, especially with its remote and more vulnerable picks, that the list itself is not about tourism.

headline: Manufacturing Is a Bright Spot in a Subdued Jobs Report
abstract: Employers added 156,000 jobs in August, fewer than expected. But Mack Trucks’ turn from layoffs to hiring typifies a revival at factories this year.
lead_paragraph: MACUNGIE, Pa. — At the sprawling Mack Trucks factory here, the last of the workers laid off in 2016 after sales slowed down are back on the line, and for the first time in years, the company is hiring new employees.

headline: Looking for a London Vacation Rental? We Tried the Plum Guide
abstract: Four levels, three bedrooms, chic neighborhood, close to the subway, one plumbing problem (fixed). The verdict: positive.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of vacation home rentals in London has surged following last summer’s Brexit referendum: Existing companies with an international presence, such as Airbnb, Onefinestay and Oasis have all reported a significant jump in rentals, while a handful of new players offering rentals only in London, such as the Plum Guide and Cuckooz, have seen their businesses grow rapidly.

headline: Floodwaters Inundate Beaumont as Houston Assesses Damage
abstract: Across coastal Texas, millions of residents grappled with the devastating effects of storm Harvey while millions of others returned home to take in the damage.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As Southeast Texas residents emerged by the thousands from shelters, motels and friends’ houses to return to flood-damaged homes, others remained in the grip of the crisis on Friday, cut off by still-rising floodwaters and living without running water for a second day.

headline: Ken Burns and Lynn Novick Tackle the Vietnam War
abstract: Americans are still divided over the legacy of the Vietnam War. Can Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s 18-hour documentary help put the demons of that era — and of our own — to rest?
lead_paragraph: Ken Burns shot to fame in 1990 with “The Civil War,” which drew record audiences for PBS and jump-started a revival of popular interest in the subject. Nearly three decades and more than 20 documentaries later, he is perhaps the nation’s most trusted historical brand, as much an icon of American-ness as baseball (the subject of his nine-part 1994 documentary) and apple pie (one of the few classic American themes he hasn’t taken on).

headline: My Liberia: A Vacation Paradise
abstract: Can Liberia be a place that people consider a dream destination? Depends on the dreamer.
lead_paragraph: On the last day of my family’s big trip home to Liberia, the staff of Mamba Point Hotel threw an impromptu going away party for my 6-year-old nephew, Cooper.

headline: Inside New York City’s Priciest Rentals
abstract: Some New Yorkers could afford to buy multimillion-dollar properties, but they’d rather rent a place for upward of $20,000 a month.
lead_paragraph: When Allan Rothstein decided to rent his NoHo loft on Crosby Street a few years ago, the $22,000-a-month price tag wasn’t a major concern.

headline: The Little Theater That Could
abstract: The survival of 13th Street Repertory Company, a relic from Greenwich Village’s bohemian past, depends on the survival of its 100-year-old doyenne.
lead_paragraph: The wilting three-story building in Greenwich Village that houses the 13th Street Repertory Company creaked and groaned as its artistic director, Joe Battista, gave a tour of its theater one afternoon in July. The Repertory opened in 1972 and is one of the oldest Off Off Broadway theaters in New York. Mr. Battista walked past its 65 tattered seats and onto its stage.

headline: Shot by Shot: Building a Scene in Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s Vietnam Epic
abstract: The filmmakers look at all sides of a battle, and a war, that many Americans, as Mr. Burns put it, “would basically prefer to be about themselves.”
lead_paragraph: “The Vietnam War,” Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s panoramic 18-hour television documentary, includes 10 set-piece battle scenes documenting the action from multiple perspectives. Among them is the battle of Binh Gia, which took place in late December 1964, 40 miles southeast of Saigon.

headline: Kenya Supreme Court Nullifies Presidential Election
abstract: The justices threw out last month’s re-election of President Uhuru Kenyatta, calling the result “null and void” and ordering a new vote.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a historic ruling and a first in Africa, Kenya’s Supreme Court nullified on Friday the re-election of a sitting president, ordering a new vote to be held within 60 days after finding that the outcome last month had been tainted by irregularities.

headline: Harvey, Kenya, Harriet Tubman: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In City of Ruins, Philippines’ Battle Against ISIS Rages On
abstract: Times journalists went to a newly captured part of Marawi, finding profound destruction in the Philippine city and despair among the civilians forced out of it.
lead_paragraph: MARAWI, Philippines — The houses still standing after more than three months of fierce urban combat in Marawi are barely holding on — pocked with bullet holes on the outside and blackened by fire from within.

headline: Tending to the Rituals of My Lost and Found Father
abstract: I used to see his idiosyncrasies as a way to bully me. Now, I find his routines a godsend. A boat we can climb into and row together.
lead_paragraph: He says it’s his lucky bottle and not to touch it.

headline: New York Today: A Labor Day Staycation
abstract: Friday: Activities for the final days of summer, long weekend weather, and a lesson on Labor Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this fabulous Friday.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Biting Midges, Coffee and Stronger Brains
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Does Cooking Boost Nutrients in Tomatoes and Spinach?
abstract: Levels of some nutrients may go up with cooking. But levels of others go down.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it true tomatoes and spinach release more of their nutrients when they’ve been cooked?

headline: From Guerrilla Fighter to Myanmar Peace Negotiator
abstract: Min Zaw Oo left the jungle to pursue a Ph.D. in the United States. Two decades later, the government invited him back to try to end the war he once fought in.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar

headline: Work, Work, Work. Love, Love, Love.
abstract: Stephanie Horbaczewski, a founder of the beauty and fashion network StyleHaul, had no time for a relationship until Gordon Clemons came along.
lead_paragraph: When Stephanie Horbaczewski met Gordon Clemons, romance was the last thing on her mind.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Next Big Battle for Business Is Immigration
abstract: Business leaders posted an open letter to President Trump asking him not to end a popular immigration policy, but it isn’t clear whether he’ll listen.
lead_paragraph: The next potential battle between the Trump administration and business leaders is near, and it’s on immigration.

headline: Jason Fried of Basecamp on the Importance of Writing Skills
abstract: The chief executive of a project-management software firm says that a priority in his hiring process is determining whether a candidate can write well.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jason Fried, chief executive of Basecamp, a web-based project management tool, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Green Light for Art Criminals?
abstract: The scrapping of the specialist art crime squad in London’s police force could affect the international art market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The horrific Grenfell Tower fire, which claimed the lives of about 80 residents of an apartment block here in June, has had a number of unforeseen consequences.

headline: When Colleagues Won’t Stop Talking Politics
abstract: What to do when political chatter at the office stresses you out.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Willie Nelson, Roky Erickson, Eric Clapton: Twang, Psychedelia and Blues
abstract: Mr. Nelson headlines the Outlaw Music Festival; Mr. Erickson hits Brooklyn and Jersey City; and Mr. Clapton brings some Austin six-stringers to the Garden.
lead_paragraph: With all eyes on a hurricane-torn Texas, its perpetually touring musicians carry a spirit of resilience. Willie Nelson, despite recent respiratory problems, has been barnstorming across America with his encompassing repertoire of Americana. This weekend he headlines the Outlaw Music Festival of roots-rock and country in amphitheaters: Friday, Sept. 8, at PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., and Saturday at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y. The lineup includes his son’s band, Lukas Nelson and Promise of the Real, along with Sheryl Crow, the Avett Brothers and Margo Price. The paladin of Texas psychedelia, Roky Erickson — who led the 13th Floor Elevators in the 1960s and returned, after some difficult years personally, with garage-rock visions of aliens, demons and redemption — performs in Brooklyn on Wednesday and Thursday at Rough Trade and Jersey City on Friday at White Eagle Hall. Meanwhile, Eric Clapton is bringing Austin bluesmen as openers — and rivals — when he plays Madison Square Garden on Thursday and Friday, sharing the bill with the incendiary guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and with Jimmie Vaughan, a founder of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.

headline: What Do Harrison Ford and a Homicidal Clown Have in Common?
abstract: The trailers for “It” and “Blade Runner 2049” use central characters to bring in new audiences, build suspense and keep old fans wanting more.
lead_paragraph: It only took a day for a sinister 31-year-old clown to outpace the combined powers of Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson, a.k.a The Rock.

headline: David Litt, an Obama Speechwriter Who Wants No Credit
abstract: David Litt’s book about his time in the Obama White House is different than most books by political operatives: He writes about his lack of influence.
lead_paragraph: Washington is filled with political operatives who inflate their importance and take credit, oftentimes where it might not be due.

headline: Amanda Seales of ‘Insecure’ Revisits Her Harlem Haunts
abstract: The 36-year-old actress, comedian, hip-hop artist and producer returns to the neighborhood where she first tried to make her name.
lead_paragraph: As Amanda Seales strode into Ginny’s Supper Club, the nightspot under the Red Rooster in Harlem on a recent Thursday, a young woman pulled her aside, saying, “You are fabulous, honey.” At the fan’s request, the two took a pout-perfect selfie.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: August 2017
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: After a summer break, we present the first edition of Teenagers in The Times of the new school year. On the first Friday of each month, you’ll find a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.

headline: Michael Dell, Tech Billionaire, Pledges $36 Million in Harvey Relief
abstract: Mr. Dell, a Texan, said a gift from the Michael and Susan Dell Foundation would seed the Rebuild Texas Fund, which aims to raise $100 million.
lead_paragraph: Michael Dell, the billionaire Texan who founded Dell Technologies, has pledged $36 million of his foundation’s money to help disaster relief efforts in the wake of Hurricane Harvey.

headline: California Today: Firefighters, at Less Than $2 an Hour
abstract: Friday: The inmates who battle California’s wildfires, workaholism in Silicon Valley, and Eureka’s Victorian architecture.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Deporting Dreamers
abstract: Subjecting the Dreamers to deportation is not actually consistent with American legal values.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Harvey Updates: Fire and Smoke Again Engulf Chemical Plant Near Houston
abstract: The plant was the same facility where, on Thursday, a chemical storage trailer exploded, setting off a fire, after flooding from Harvey had knocked out equipment needed to keep the chemicals stable.
lead_paragraph: Fire engulfed part of a chemical plant northeast of Houston on Friday evening, sending thick black smoke high into the sky, a statement from Arkema, the owner of the plant, confirmed. It was the same facility where, on Thursday, a chemical storage trailer exploded, setting off a fire. Flooding from Harvey, once a Category 4 hurricane that hit southeast Texas last week, had knocked out the refrigeration system needed to keep the chemicals stable.

headline: Capturing Action Just Off the Court at the U.S. Open
abstract: A photographer finds beauty in the margins of action and light at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: I am always attracted to the edges because they define shape and give context. And I always seek a spark of photographic magic on the edges of light and shadow. So when I was tasked to cover the opening days of the United States Open this year, I found myself looking to the margins of both the action and the light as the world’s premier players performed an exquisitely elegant dance of athleticism and grace with the assistance of an army of support: ball boys and ball girls, line judges and members of the security staff, working in view of a sea of awe-inspired fans, myself included. I worked the courtside edges, from Arthur Ashe Stadium to the practice courts, to incorporate some of those people into photographs that usually strive to be free of distractions, and I allowed myself the pleasure of finding beauty as the players tried to gain their own edge.

headline: Trump Again Lashes Out at Comey’s Handling of Clinton Investigation
abstract: President Trump charged that James B. Comey had “exonerated” his opponent Hillary Clinton before completing an investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday lashed out anew at the F.B.I. director he fired in May, charging that James B. Comey had “exonerated” Hillary Clinton before fully completing the investigation into her use of a private email server.

headline: Switching Between Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android
abstract: Whether jumping from Android to iOS or vice versa, Apple and Google have tried to ease the process for their newcomers.
lead_paragraph: Q. How hard is it to switch smartphone systems from Android to the new iPhone that is coming out this fall? Do I have to buy all new apps? And if I ever want to change back to Android, how much of a hassle is it?

headline: Farhad’s and Nick’s Week in Review: Uber’s New Boss and Amazon’s New Supermarket
abstract: Two tech reporters analyze the week’s big tech news, including Uber’s surprising new C.E.O. and how Amazon might change Whole Foods.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is out this week so Nick Wingfield, a Times technology reporter based in Seattle, filled in.

headline: A 16-Room Penthouse at the Pierre Sells for $44 Million
abstract: A triplex perched atop the Pierre Hotel has finally sold after more than four years on and off the market and an original list price of $125 million.
lead_paragraph: One of the city’s most expensive apartment listings — a rambling triplex perched atop the venerable Pierre Hotel overlooking Central Park — has finally sold after more than four years on and off the market.

headline: Football Favoritism at F.S.U.: The Price One Teacher Paid
abstract: As its team marched toward a national title, Florida State investigated charges of academic favoritism for top players. The teacher who reported the favoritism lost her job.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — As the Florida State University football team was marching to a national title in the fall of 2013, the school was investigating allegations of academic favoritism involving a half-dozen of its leading players, including one who scored the winning touchdown in the championship game.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Alex Trebek
abstract: The "Jeopardy!" host sketched his answers at his desk with both a regular and an Extra Fine Point Sharpie while sipping a glass of chardonnay.
lead_paragraph: The “Jeopardy!” host sketched his answers at his desk with both a regular and an Extra Fine Point Sharpie while sipping a glass of chardonnay.

headline: Nafta Negotiations: What’s at Stake in the Second Round
abstract: Trade representatives from Canada, Mexico and the United States will resume discussions after a tense first round of talks.
lead_paragraph: Trade negotiators from Canada, Mexico and the United States resume discussions on Friday over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: As Season Opens, a Fresh Set of Eyes and the Usual Suspects
abstract: The College Football Playoff selection committee took a chance with its final four last season. Should it do that more often?
lead_paragraph: In December, the “human element” in selecting a national champion, so longed for during the 16 years of the Bowl Championship Series’ automatonic algorithm, finally showed up in the College Football Playoff’s third season.

headline: The 10 Games That Will Determine College Football’s Playoff
abstract: The season is full of forgettable games, but fans shouldn’t miss the ones most likely to determine the four playoff teams.
lead_paragraph: By the end of the season, most of the College Football Playoff contenders’ 12 or 13 games will seem, in retrospect, like insignificant and anonymous blowouts of weaker opposition. But a few games will prove defining for who was beaten, and where and how. These games will be crucial in deciding who gets in and who is left out of the four-team postseason.

headline: A Well-Choreographed Apartment
abstract: For Kelly Devine, the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” furnishing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: For Kelly Devine, the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” furnishing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.

headline: In Kelly Devine’s Apartment, Even the Furniture Has to Audition
abstract: For the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” designing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Kelly Devine grew up in Los Angeles, and stuck around for the first two decades of her career to stage dances for film, television, videos and commercials. She moved east a dozen years ago to focus on Broadway musicals, and has since worked on “Rock of Ages,” “Rocky,” “Doctor Zhivago” and “Come From Away,” in the process picking up two Tony Award nominations. Next up: “Escape to Margaritaville.”

headline: A Clam Chowder That Tastes Like Summer
abstract: The building blocks for a classic version are salt pork (or bacon), potatoes and milk, but what about adding a bit of polenta and zucchini?
lead_paragraph: A traditional chowder of corn, potatoes and clams is like a clambake in a bowl, minus the lobster. Everything bobs about in a delicious broth, highlighting the sweetness of each ingredient.

headline: The August Jobs Numbers Are Weak. Don’t Blame Trump.
abstract: The numbers highlight a widely made mistake in how we have been talking about the economy since Inauguration Day.
lead_paragraph: The details of the August jobs numbers are disappointing, though hardly catastrophic.

headline: When Office Meetings Leave the Office Behind
abstract: Some entrepreneurs have instituted activities — outdoor planning sessions, meetings in a salt room, deal talks on a surfboard — that sound relaxing but are meant to be productive.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs have a reputation for working long hours to get their businesses up and running, leading some of their employees to a quick burnout.

headline: A Whirlwind Year for a Workaholic, Mindy Kaling
abstract: The writer and actress talks about the end of an era, some unexpected tears and why her alter ego doesn’t get to ride off into the sunset.
lead_paragraph: When we last saw “The Mindy Project,” a newly married Mindy Lahiri was gazing out a subway window when a shadow of doubt crossed her face. Which was crazy, because wasn’t this what she’d always wanted?

headline: Russian Election Hacking Efforts, Wider Than Previously Known, Draw Little Scrutiny
abstract: A Times investigation has found that infiltration efforts were broader than previously disclosed and that state and federal agencies have conducted few forensic inquiries.
lead_paragraph: The calls started flooding in from hundreds of irate North Carolina voters just after 7 a.m. on Election Day last November.

headline: Lasting Merit Found in a Tuberculosis Vaccine Invented a Century Ago
abstract: BCG vaccine, used in many countries, protects for nearly twice as long as previously thought, scientists find.
lead_paragraph: Tuberculosis kills almost two million people a year. A perfect vaccine could save many of them, but the one now in use — invented in the 1920s and known as BCG, for Bacillus Calmette-Guérin — has so many flaws that some countries, including the United States, have never adopted it.

headline: Agreement on Construction Workers’ Safety, but Not So Much on Bill
abstract: There seemed to be a consensus that workers should be better trained, but a bill requiring that has been blocked in the City Council by real estate interests.
lead_paragraph: When thousands of union workers gathered for a raucous rally near City Hall in late 2015, after a spate of deaths and injuries in construction accidents, they urged local officials to adopt stronger safety measures.

headline: Lattice to Seek Trump’s Approval for Chinese-Backed Buyout
abstract: The move by the semiconductor maker follows resistance to the deal from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration will soon face a test of its China economic policy, as a chipmaker plans to appeal to the White House for approval of its proposed sale to a Chinese-backed buyer.

headline: Summer Was Not So Hellish for Commuters at Penn Station
abstract: After eight weeks of emergency track repairs at the nation’s busiest transit hub, service is set to revert to a “new normal” next week.
lead_paragraph: After the recent reviews, Amtrak may want to consider producing a sequel to the “summer of hell.”

headline: Under ‘Observation,’ Some Hospital Patients Face Big Bills
abstract: A judge has cleared the way for a lawsuit against Medicare by patients who were never officially admitted to hospitals.
lead_paragraph: In April, Nancy Niemi entered Vidant Medical Center in Greenville, N.C., with cardiac problems. She stayed four nights, at one point receiving a coronary stent.

headline: Shelley Berman, Stand-Up Comic Who Skewered Modern Life, Dies at 92
abstract: Along with Mort Sahl, Lenny Bruce and others, Mr. Berman redefined comedy in the mid-20th century while also carving out a notable acting career.
lead_paragraph: Shelley Berman, whose brittle persona and anxiety-ridden observations helped redefine stand-up comedy in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died early Friday morning at his home in Bell Canyon, Calif. He was 92.

headline: ‘Pink Panther’ and ‘Decoy’ Return on Disc
abstract: They’re back. All six of the Inspector Clouseau films starring Peter Sellers on Blu-ray, and a 1950s TV series about a New York City policewoman on DVD.
lead_paragraph: It’s a case of good cop, bad cop: The 1957-58 series “Decoy,” an obscure gem from the golden age of network television, has been issued in its entirety on a three-disc set from Film Chest Media Group. And all six movies about the blundering Inspector Clouseau, starring Peter Sellers and directed by Blake Edwards (who also did much of the writing), are out from Shout! Factory as the six-Blu-ray “Pink Panther Film Collection.”

headline: Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor, Living Out Loud (and Quietly)
abstract: The actors, who go way back as college roommates, recall cherished VHS tapes, the glory days of gay night life, and apartments with curtains for doors.
lead_paragraph: Madonna’s 1998 album, “Ray of Light,” bore many gifts, not least of which was the friendship between Billy Eichner and Robin Lord Taylor.

headline: Library Cards Unlock Film Vaults
abstract: Kanopy, a movie-streaming service that is free for New York Public Library members, is a garden of cinematic delights. Here’s how to use it.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, back when video rental stores were still around but clearly an endangered species (Tower Records had shut down, Blockbuster was in trouble and Netflix was still dealing in DVDs), I was chatting with a friend, a fellow cinephile experiencing an economic downturn. (As it happened, he had worked for Tower.) It was difficult to keep up with classic releases on home video, particularly stuff from the Criterion Collection, he said, but fortunately for him titles would eventually turn up at his local public library. And he didn’t have to wait long for them either, since few people in his New Jersey town (which had once been mine) were keen on art or foreign films.

headline: Harvey, Part II
abstract: A new state motto?
lead_paragraph: A new state motto?

headline: Shania Twain Walked Out on Top. Now She Wants Back In.
abstract: Ms. Twain is set to release “Now,” her first album in 15 years, on Sept. 29.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The last time Shania Twain released an album — the experimental country-but-not-quite opus “Up!” — it sold 874,000 copies in its first week, and went on to receive the Recording Industry Association of America’s diamond certification for 10 million copies sold, her third album in a row to reach that milestone.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Try a new recipe for chicken-fried steak with queso, maybe paired with corn and Julia Moskin’s classic mashed potatoes.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Will Return for a Third Season on HBO
abstract: Mahershala Ali will star in a new round of the series, which will take place in the Ozarks. Nic Pizzolatto is once again writing nearly all of the episodes.
lead_paragraph: It’s actually coming back.

headline: Your Everyday Makeup Questions, Answered
abstract: Advice from experts on the best ways to apply your daily makeup and, along the way, clear up a few confounding makeup questions.
lead_paragraph: Advice from experts on the best ways to apply your daily makeup and, along the way, clear up a few confounding makeup questions.

headline: Women’s Hockey League Will Pay Players for First Time
abstract: Players in the Canadian Women’s Hockey League will receive a stipend ranging from $2,000 to $10,000.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Women’s Hockey League will pay players for the first time in its 11-year history beginning this season, the league announced Friday.

headline: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend
abstract: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.
lead_paragraph: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.

headline: A Tasting Menu of Yelps and Hums at the Resonant Bodies Festival
abstract: This immersion in experimental vocal music, on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at Roulette in Brooklyn, gives nine artists the freedom to program 45-minute sets.
lead_paragraph: For a city obsessed with tasting menus and small-plate smorgasbords, there is a fitting festival of experimental vocal music.

headline: U.S. Open Results: Marin Cilic Loses; New Aunt Venus Williams Wins
abstract: Marin Cilic, the No. 5 seed, fell to Diego Schwartzman. Denis Shapovalov, Venus Williams and Garbiñe Muguruza advanced to the fourth round.
lead_paragraph: Stay here for live results and analysis from Day 5 of the U.S. Open.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in December
abstract: New movies and TV shows are added to streaming platforms each month. Here are the titles we think are most interesting in December.
lead_paragraph: New movies and TV shows are added to streaming platforms each month. Here are the titles we think are most interesting in December.

headline: Cecilia Bartoli, Last Seen With a Beard, May Return to New York
abstract: Ms. Bartoli, the star mezzo-soprano, hints in an interview that she may return to the city, where she last performed nearly 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — It has been nearly a decade since the beloved Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli last sang in New York. David Letterman, Jon Stewart and others have been known to grow beards when they’ve left the city’s limelight. But the whiskers Ms. Bartoli was sporting recently weren’t quite of that variety.

headline: Why a 24-Year-Old Chipmaker Is One of Tech’s Hot Prospects
abstract: Nvidia, a maker of graphics processing units, is riding an artificial intelligence boom to put its chips in drones, robots and self-driving cars.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Engineers at CTA.ai, an imaging-technology start-up in Poland, are trying to popularize a more comfortable alternative to the colonoscopy. To do so, they are using computer chips that are best known to video game fans.

headline: Singing and Chattering: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
abstract: A Ravel reinterpretation, Rameau on keyboard and Julius Eastman are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what's delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: How Low-Cost Airlines Alter the Economics of Flying
abstract: Even as mergers have significantly reduced competition, airlines like Spirit and Frontier continue to play a role in moderating ticket costs.
lead_paragraph: For more than three years, the average one-way fare between Detroit and Philadelphia never dipped below $308, and sometimes moved higher, topping $385 at one point.

headline: After Harvey, Houston Showed Up
abstract: I asked a guy who was driving his boat downtown what brought him out to help. He told me it was because his family had been spared.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Houston is sprawling, made of dozens of little Houstons. Bellaire is not Montrose is not the Heights is not Sugar Land, and it’s possible to go years without stepping foot in one community or the other. Each one vibrates on its own frequency.

headline: A Life’s Many Acts Culminate in the Kitchen at NA/NA in Paris
abstract: The chef Nathaly Nicolas-Ianniello, a former ecological journalist, serves dishes like ganache with black sesame miso to adventurous Parisians.
lead_paragraph: When Nathaly Nicolas-Ianniello opened NA/NA in Paris in 2015, not only was it the first time she had ever worked as a chef, but it was her first job in a restaurant. A daring thing for anyone to do, but she was 52, and many of her friends thought she was nuts.

headline: A Controversial Restoration That Wipes Away the Past
abstract: The restoration of Chartres Cathedral asks questions about how we preserve the past — and which past we preserve.
lead_paragraph: CHARTRES, France — The pilgrim did not find what he was searching for. As a child, Patrice Bertrand heard his mother recount details of her visit to the shrine of the famous Black Madonna of Chartres Cathedral, 60 miles southwest of Paris. Now Mr. Bertrand, 41, of Nantes, was following in her footsteps. But he was perplexed by what he discovered: “The statue I came to see is not here anymore,” he said. The Black Madonna had become white.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in September
abstract: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here’s what we like for September.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: Mueller Has Early Draft of Trump Letter Giving Reasons for Firing Comey
abstract: The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has a copy of a letter President Trump wanted to send to James B. Comey explaining the rationale for firing him. The White House counsel blocked the president from sending it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has obtained a letter drafted by President Trump and a top political aide that offered an unvarnished view of Mr. Trump’s thinking in the days before the president fired the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey.

headline: Amy Beach, a Pioneering American Composer, Turns 150
abstract: Prolific and acclaimed, Beach fought against sexism throughout her career, and her work still struggles to be performed.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Antonin Dvorak arrived in the United States in 1892, for a historic visit that resulted in the creation of his “New World” Symphony, he made a cursory remark to a Boston newspaper about gender and the field of music.

headline: Janine Charrat, Ballerina and Choreographer, Dies at 93
abstract: A child star as a dancer, Ms. Charrat went on to create important dances at a time when few women were doing so and survived an accident that left her burned.
lead_paragraph: Janine Charrat, a noted French ballerina who became a major choreographer at a time when few women were engaged in that pursuit and survived a midcareer accident that left her badly burned, died on Tuesday in Paris. She was 93.

headline: Is There a Date-Stamp on the Moving Body?
abstract: The aging body — for athletes and dancers — is the subject of Monica Bill Barnes and Anna Bass’s play “One Night Only (Running as long as we can).”
lead_paragraph: A work by Monica Bill Barnes warrants certain expectations. It will be humorous, it will be fun and, despite your cynical self, you will laugh.

headline: Blunting the Far Right, Merkel Gains as German Election Nears
abstract: Once vulnerable, the chancellor has opened a big lead in polls by taking away from her opponents the issue that had animated them: immigration.
lead_paragraph: ANNABERG-BUCHHOLZ, Germany — Taking the stage, Chancellor Angela Merkel thanked the thousands of Germans who had turned out at a recent campaign rally, and then leveled her gaze at a small but noisy knot of right-wing protesters yelling and blowing whistles at the back of the square.

headline: Review: ‘Tulip Fever’ Delivers a Wilted Period Piece
abstract: Alicia Vikander, Dane DeHaan and Christoph Waltz star in this much-delayed film about an overripe love triangle in 17th-century Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way around reviewing “Tulip Fever” without noting that the movie has been buried deeper than a tulip bulb. The Vulture writer Kyle Buchanan has already provided a rundown of the substantial delays in the film’s release, which — for a project once regarded as an Oscar contender — might be taken as a sign of an odor other than floral. This week, Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of the Weinstein Company, the film’s distributor, took the extraordinary step of defending the movie in advance with a column for Deadline Hollywood, though it is laced with passive-aggressive barbs like “I know this film’s not perfect, very few are, but it’s a perfectly good time in a movie theater.”

headline: My Son, Off to College
abstract: A father describes the feeling of seeing his son leave home for college.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio Says Donors Were Denied Favors. How Many? Hard to Say.
abstract: The mayor had long vowed to detail how campaign donors who sought city business were rejected, but his essay, released on Friday, gave few examples.
lead_paragraph: Dogged by investigations into his political fund-raising, Mayor Bill de Blasio promised last year to prove his integrity to New Yorkers by providing concrete examples of campaign contributors who did not get favors from his administration.

headline: Hurricane Irma Looms, but It’s Too Early to Predict Landfall
abstract: The thought of a Category 3 hurricane approaching, as thousands reel from Harvey, is daunting. But experts are days away from understanding its impact.
lead_paragraph: A week after Hurricane Harvey made landfall in Texas, another powerful storm system is looming. But forecasters say it is too early to determine where Hurricane Irma, a Category 3 storm with 115-mile-per-hour winds that was moving west in the Atlantic Ocean early on Friday, would have any impact on land, if at all.

headline: Chinese Firm With Big Stake in Lenovo to Buy Control of Luxembourg Bank
abstract: Legend Holdings would acquire a controlling stake in the Banque Internationale à Luxembourg from an investment vehicle of the Qatar royal family.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Legend Holdings, the Chinese company that is the computer manufacturer Lenovo Group’s largest shareholder, said on Friday that it had agreed to buy a 90 percent stake in Banque Internationale à Luxembourg for 1.48 billion euros, or about $1.75 billion.

headline: The Looming Uncertainty for Dreamers Like Me
abstract: It’s hard to overstate how much DACA changed everyday life for almost 800,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday was my first day back at school at Baruch College for my senior year. I had been looking forward to starting class again, but it was impossible to pay attention. I was completely distracted by the whiplash of news about whether Donald Trump would end the executive order Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, — the policy President Barack Obama announced in 2012 that allowed almost 800,000 immigrant youths like me to step out of the shadows of society.

headline: In Election Interference, It’s What Reporters Didn’t Find That Matters
abstract: When Nicole Perlroth, Michael Wines and Matthew Rosenberg set out to understand Russian hacking in the last election, the absence of good data was conspicuous.
lead_paragraph: The story started, as many do, with our own confusion.

headline: What to Read About Hurricane Harvey
abstract: As people begin to plot a path forward from the storm’s destruction, we collected some of the best coverage from The Times and around the internet.
lead_paragraph: As people begin to comprehend the scope of Hurricane Harvey’s destruction and to plot a path forward, we collected some of the best coverage from around the internet.

headline: An American Abroad
abstract: Suzy Hansen discusses “Notes on a Foreign Country,” and David Thomson talks about “Warner Bros: The Making of an American Movie Studio.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: What’s Driving Job Growth in Industrial America?
abstract: President Trump campaigned on reviving the kinds of jobs done in factories, coal mines and oil fields. Since he took office, hiring has indeed ticked upward in these sectors, but is there any connection?
lead_paragraph: President Trump campaigned on reviving the kinds of jobs done in factories, coal mines and oil fields. Since he took office, hiring has indeed ticked upward in these sectors, but is there any connection?

headline: Lil Uzi Vert and a Generation of Rap Stars Looking Beyond Hip-Hop
abstract: A fun-house sort of rap movement is led by Lil Uzi Vert with his “Luv Is Rage 2,” who is joined in this vein by Lil Peep and XXXTentacion.
lead_paragraph: Listen to hip-hop in 2017 and hear the darnedest things. There are rappers who rap in only occasional, seemingly random bursts. There are rappers who mainline the aesthetic and vibrating energy of punk. And there are surrealists who stretch out words and melodies like taffy.

headline: The Yankees’ Judge’s Chambers: A Promotion to Dismiss?
abstract: Aaron Judge’s slump has made his special seating section in right field seem even more out of step for the Yankees, who were never known for trumpeting individual players.
lead_paragraph: There was a game Thursday night when the Yankees’ marketing ploy suddenly was golden; when a real Supreme Court justice, Sonia Sotomayor, donned a black robe and sat in the Judge’s Chambers at the Bronx stadium to cheer on Aaron Judge.

headline: Better Planning for Inevitable Disasters
abstract: Readers call for more responsible growth and question whether all taxpayers should bear the burden of “the negligence of Texans.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Cost of Hurricane Harvey: Only One Recent Storm Comes Close
abstract: Comparing more than 200 billion-dollar natural disasters since 1980.
lead_paragraph: Comparing more than 200 billion-dollar natural disasters since 1980.

headline: Rock’s Not Dead, It’s Ruled by Women: The Round-Table Conversation
abstract: Guitars may seem to matter less than ever. But just beneath the mainstream, dozens of female bands are making some of the most urgent, politically relevant music around.
lead_paragraph: For years now, we, the pop music team of The New York Times — Jon Caramanica, Joe Coscarelli, Caryn Ganz and Jon Pareles — have wondered where exactly the guitars went. While there’s never been a shortage of quote-unquote traditional rock bands — say, a mostly male, mostly white four-piece — their cultural impact has continued to wane in the face of increasingly diverse musical tactics, distribution networks and messengers.

headline: Vanguard Speaks Softly but Carries a Big Stick
abstract: The fund goliath is engaging more with companies, and in the past year voted against management at Exxon Mobil, Viacom and Wells Fargo.
lead_paragraph: The activist hedge-fund manager Paul Singer recently warned that the rise of so-called passive investing risked distorting markets and “devouring capitalism.”

headline: If Not for ‘The Jinx,’ Robert Durst May Have Avoided Murder Charges
abstract: Mr. Durst’s “obsession” with being unfairly suspected of murder led him to pursue the documentary film that led to new charges, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Durst’s Los Angeles trial for the murder of his friend Susan Berman is still a year away. But for the last seven months, testimony in a series of “conditional hearings” has battered Mr. Durst, the eccentric scion of a New York real estate family. Despite his frail demeanor, witnesses have testified, over the years he has had episodes of violence, and often a revolver in his possession.

headline: Amid Allegations, a Call for Essex County College’s Board to Resign
abstract: A two-year college in Newark facing financial and academic challenges must change course, according to clergy members who attended a raucous board meeting.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A group of New Jersey religious leaders called for the resignation of the entire board of Essex County College Thursday and for federal and state investigations into allegations of financial malfeasance and undue political influence at the institution, which is in danger of losing its accreditation after years of mismanagement.

headline: Pope Francis Sought Psychoanalysis at 42, According to Book
abstract: The pontiff is quoted in a series of interviews as saying he had weekly sessions for about six months while in Argentina “to clarify some things.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — At 42, Pope Francis had weekly sessions with a psychoanalyst for about six months “to clarify some things,” according to excerpts from a new book by a French sociologist scheduled to be published next week.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: The latest side project from the popular American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin involves real-time motion sensors; costumes by Dior; and projections by his father, Dmitrij, also an accomplished ballet dancer. A commission by the Works & Process Rotunda Project, this 30-minute work — scheduled to be performed twice nightly, at 8 and 9:30 p.m., on Monday and Tuesday — features Mr. Simkin, the Ballet Theater soloist Cassandra Trenary, the Hubbard Street dancer Ana Lopez and Brett Conway in juicy choreography by the Hubbard Street house choreographer, Alejandro Cerrudo. With observers watching from above, standing along the Guggenheim’s spiraling ramps, the dancers will tangle with each other and their own shadows, which, thanks to technology, will seem to have developed minds of their own. BRIAN SCHAEFER

headline: Helping Women Over 50 Face Their Financial Fears
abstract: After hearing too many stories of women who had ignored their finances until they became widows, a publicist and an insurance executive decided to get them talking about it.
lead_paragraph: Ronni Ginott was at a New Year’s Day party in 2003 when her husband, David, had a heart attack and died on the spot, at 58.

headline: Rome Survived Caligula. Will America Survive Trump?
abstract: Readers discuss Nicholas Kristof’s column about ancient Rome’s resilience in the face of unstable rulers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Nashville Statement Is an Attack on L.G.B.T. Christians
abstract: It’s not just symbolic. Bigoted religious views cause real harm.
lead_paragraph: This week, an influential group of evangelical Christians publicly doubled down on intolerance in a message about lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people that represents a renewed commitment to open bigotry.

headline: What if I Bombed at My Own Wedding?
abstract: We were writing our own vows. I needed to make sure I got some laughs.
lead_paragraph: Any nerves I had leading up to my wedding manifested less as a case of cold feet than as a flare-up of preshow jitters. There were, of course, the predictable stresses: Did everyone receive their invitations? Will my mother’s elderly cousins dance to “The Thong Song”?

headline: Matchesfashion.com Sells Majority Stake to Apax After Fierce Bidding War
abstract: The private equity firm beat out rivals that included Bain Capital, KKR and Permira to take a controlling interest in the fast-growing British luxury e-commerce group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Matchesfashion.com, the British luxury e-commerce group that began life as a single bricks-and-mortar boutique before growing into one of the most powerful online players in the global high-fashion market, has a new majority shareholder after a fierce bidding war.

headline: Michael Cromartie, Who Guided Journalists on Religion, Dies at 67
abstract: A former conscientious objector to the Vietnam War, he became an influential evangelical thinker in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cromartie, who shepherded a generation of journalists toward more informed coverage of religion’s evolving junction with politics and public policy, died on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 67.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 3 Premiere: Life Without Pablo
abstract: As the Netflix series enters its third season, a question hangs in the air: Can it survive without its main antagonist?
lead_paragraph: Welcome back, everyone. The last time we checked in on “Narcos,” Pablo Escobar was bleeding out on a Colombian rooftop. It was the logical (and historically accurate) end to two seasons of drama and violence.

headline: Trump Says Decision on ‘Dreamers’ Program Will Come Soon
abstract: President Trump said he would announce a decision by Tuesday on whether he will end the Obama-era program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday said he would announce a decision by Tuesday on whether he will end the Obama-era program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation, declaring, “We love the Dreamers” even as his White House grappled with how to wind down their legal status.

headline: Dakota Plan to Bury, Not Burn, ‘Scaffold’ Sculpture
abstract: A Dakota representative said the remains of Sam Durant’s sculpture would be taken to an undisclosed location in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The remains of “Scaffold,” a sculpture that prompted outrage among Native Americans this summer when it was placed in the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden, will be buried in a secret location in Minnesota, according to Ron Leith, a Dakota representative.

headline: Retrieving Gold, and More, From Wastewater
abstract: Scientists are eager to find better ways to extract heavy metals from industrial wastewater.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are the heavy metals removed from wastewater valuable?

headline: Led by a Vietnam War Opus, a Rich Season of Documentaries
abstract: The fall season’s documentaries show the form’s strengths and versatility, with the Ken Burns opus on Vietnam dominating the schedule.
lead_paragraph: Watch a lot of television documentaries and docu-series, as I do, and you might have started to feel over the last few years as if a handful of subjects were monopolizing filmmakers’ attention. Syria. Shootings of black people by police officers. Prison conditions and the plight of ex-convicts. Stress and suicide among military veterans.

headline: Polarizing Former New York Detective Will Be Honored by His Peers
abstract: Some have criticized a plan by retired detectives to celebrate the career of Louis Scarcella, who has seen convictions overturned in eight of his cases.
lead_paragraph: If they know him at all, most New Yorkers know Louis Scarcella as the once-renowned and now retired detective whose reputation for solving murders has been battered in recent years by serial allegations of misconduct.

headline: Turkey’s President Calls U.S. Indictments of His Guards a ‘Scandal’
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan denounced the charges after three more bodyguards were indicted by a federal grand jury over a brawl in Washington.
