lead_paragraph: Turkey’s president denounced what he called the “scandalous” American judicial system on Friday, responding to new indictments of his bodyguards over a brawl during his visit to Washington in May.

headline: For Car Buyers, Larger Inventories May Mean Good Deals
abstract: Labor Day weekend, typically a prime time for consumers to make new car purchases, may be even better for buyers this year given stagnant auto sales.
lead_paragraph: The end of summer is often a good time to find deals on new car purchases — and that is especially true this year, given that car sales have slowed and dealers are eager to make sales.

headline: New America, a Google-Funded Think Tank, Faces Backlash for Firing a Google Critic
abstract: The president of the New America Foundation promises staff there will be “deep internal discussion” about its donors’ influence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of an influential think tank funded by Google is grappling with a mounting backlash — including from her own scholars and donors — over the firing of a leading critic of the tech giant.

headline: What 8 Art Fans Wore to a Hamptons Opening
abstract: The artist collective Auto Body unveiled its new exhibit, which is made up of cheeky road signs, to a group of stylish visitors.
lead_paragraph: Auto Body, a scrappy artist collective in Bellport, N.Y., unveiled a new exhibition this summer. Commissioned by the Parrish Art Museum, the works include cheeky road signs like “Hold Your Horses” and “Takes Two to Canoe,” erected along the traffic-clogged stretch of Montauk Highway between Bellport and Water Mill. To celebrate the project, artists, weekenders and others gathered on Aug. 12 at Bush Farms and Museum.

headline: Louise Hay, Widely Read Self-Help Author, Dies at 90
abstract: From a 1984 best seller, Ms. Hay built a publishing empire emphasizing the power of positive thoughts.
lead_paragraph: Louise Hay, who from a 1984 best seller built a self-help publishing empire that has attracted millions of devotees with its messages about the power of thought and attitude, died on Wednesday at her home in San Diego. She was 90.

headline: Cowboys’ Elliott and Players’ Union Sue to Void Any Suspension
abstract: Ezekiel Elliott is facing the possibility of a six-game suspension by the N.F.L. in connection with what has been called a domestic violence incident.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week before the N.F.L. season begins, the league and one its most prominent players, Ezekiel Elliott of the Dallas Cowboys, have set the stage for a down-to-the-wire court battle over his six-game suspension related to a domestic violence incident.

headline: The Playlist: U2 Dances Into Darkness and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear the week's 12 most important new songs from Bully, Robert Plant, N.O.R.E. and Pharrell Williams, and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, N.O.R.E. and Pharrell Williams team up again, tributes to Thelonious Monk start to pour in, and Robert Plant unleashes a dark vision.

headline: Juicero, Start-Up With a $700 Juicer and Top Investors, Shuts Down
abstract: Juicero stood out — even in Silicon Valley — for raising enormous sums of money despite an unproven business plan.
lead_paragraph: MONTEREY, Calif. — From the moment it started, Juicero stood out as a symbol of Silicon Valley’s insular excess.

headline: White House to Ask for $14.5 Billion Down Payment for Harvey Relief
abstract: The White House will seek quick passage of a $7.8 billion Harvey relief package, followed by another $6.7 billion by the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is asking Congress for more than $14 billion as a down payment on Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts, sending Republican leaders a request late Friday for $7.8 billion in immediate aid that will be quickly followed by a request for another $6.7 billion, officials said.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Anna Dubenko, Sam Roberts and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: A Taste of Indian Nostalgia Finds an Eager Audience
abstract: A take on Kwality, a beloved brand, in the United States is inspiring childlike elation among those who missed its wide-ranging flavors.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — For anyone who grew up in India during the second half of the 20th century, ice cream is inseparable from the name Kwality.

headline: Canada Letter: Debating Sir John A. and a Remote Town Stranded
abstract: A roundup of news for and about Canada
lead_paragraph: The legacy of Sir John A. Macdonald, the first prime minister of Canada, has become the subject of debate in light of his attitudes and policies toward indigenous people. Kingston, Ontario, seemed like the obvious place to go to explore the issue. Macdonald grew up there, represented it in Parliament until his death in 1891 and is buried there.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
abstract: Melania Trump’s stilettos, Teen Vogue’s Refashionista and more.Melania Trump’s stilettos, Teen Vogue’s Refashionista and more.
lead_paragraph: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Alexandr Dolgopolov Wins, but Is Grilled About a Suspicious Loss
abstract: Dolgopolov lost a match 10 days ago at the Winston-Salem Open that attracted an enormous number of bets, raising suspicions.
lead_paragraph: A dozen reporters crowded around a small table Wednesday afternoon to talk to Alexandr Dolgopolov after his five-set victory over Jan-Lennard Struff in the first round of the United States Open.

headline: Astros, Best in A.L., Bulk Up Pitching by Acquiring Verlander
abstract: Houston traded three prospects to the Detroit Tigers for Justin Verlander on Thursday — “with seconds to spare,” said Jeff Luhnow, the team’s general manager.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Astros reported to spring training believing they were the best team in the American League. They have proved it ever since, arriving in September with the A.L.’s best record, at 80-53. But even in March, their starting rotation seemed thin. Jeff Luhnow, their general manager, had been unwilling — not unable — to trade for an ace last winter.

headline: See Harvey’s Path From a Helicopter
abstract: Get a 360-degree view of the flooding and damage caused by Tropical Storm Harvey in and around Houston and Port Arthur, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Get a 360-degree view of the flooding and damage caused by Tropical Storm Harvey in and around Houston and Port Arthur, Tex.

headline: Texas, Russia, Uhuru Kenyatta: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Karoly Makk, Acclaimed Hungarian Filmmaker, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Makk’s “Love” won a prize at the Cannes Film Festival. His “Cats’ Play” was nominated for an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: Karoly Makk, a leading Hungarian director who was honored at the Cannes Film Festival in 1971 for “Love,” the story of one family’s survival under his country’s repressive Stalinist rule, then nominated four years later for an Academy Award for best foreign-language film, for  “Cats’ Play,” died on Aug. 30. He was 91.

headline: Handling of Police Killing Spurs Grand Jury Inquiry Into Prosecutor
abstract: State Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman is to investigate the way the Rensselaer County district attorney dealt with a 2016 shooting.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, intends to impanel a grand jury this month to investigate a district attorney in relation to the fatal police shooting in Troy, N.Y., of an unarmed motorist in 2016.

headline: Serena Williams Gives Birth to a Baby Girl
abstract: The tennis star has not played a match since winning her 23rd Grand Slam singles title at the Australian Open on Jan. 28.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams has given birth to a girl, according to the United States Open’s official Twitter account and her coach.

headline: Judge Throws Out Most Serious Charges in Penn State Hazing Case
abstract: The judge made his ruling after a pretrial hearing, dismissing a number of felony charges. Lesser charges were left intact.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania judge on Friday dismissed the most serious charges against eight Penn State fraternity members indicted in the hazing death of a 19-year-old student, sharply and suddenly defanging prosecutors and setting the stage for a new legal battle in the high-profile case.

headline: Data Shows Mayweather-McGregor Was a Pay-Per-View Juggernaut
abstract: Final numbers are pending, but Showtime says it looks as if the blockbuster match could become history’s top-grossing fighting event.
lead_paragraph: The blockbuster fight between the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. and the mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor last Saturday has a “very good shot” at being the top-grossing fighting event of all time, the Showtime Sports executive in charge of it said Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: Sylvan Esso, “Die Young”
abstract: A bit of beauty and solace.
lead_paragraph: No column today, and radio silence, because I’m traveling (forum at Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon, talking Trump and NAFTA). But I have time for a quick entry — this live version (with a Mountain Man reunion!) has been going around my brain for days.

headline: A Long-Pursued ISIS Preacher Is Finally Charged in New York
abstract: Abdullah el-Faisal’s teaching has influenced many terrorists. Now he’s charged in the first international terror case brought by New York prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two decades, Abdullah el-Faisal has preached jihad, on the streets and online, first promoting the grim theology of Al Qaeda and then endorsing the Islamic State. Imprisoned in England and later deported from Kenya to his native Jamaica, he has in recent years kept up his internet proselytizing from his home near Kingston. His influence has turned up repeatedly in major terrorism cases.

headline: Forceful Chief of Staff Grates on Trump, and the Feeling Is Mutual
abstract: John Kelly is fully aware of the president’s resentment about being managed, and his appeal has gradually dimmed. But Mr. Trump needs Mr. Kelly more than Mr. Kelly needs him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was in an especially ornery mood after staff members gently suggested he refrain from injecting politics into day-to-day issues of governing after last month’s raucous rally in Arizona, and he responded by lashing out at the most senior aide in his presence.

headline: Jim Rice Weighs In on C.C. Sabathia-Eduardo Nunez Feud
abstract: Rice, a Red Sox Hall of Famer, said Sabathia, who was angry after Nunez tried to bunt in the first inning on Thursday, would field better if he lost weight.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of the sometimes ferocious Yankees-Boston Red Sox rivalry, there have been some memorable matchups and more than a few brawls.

headline: Stranded ISIS Convoy Symbolizes Militants’ Stalled Campaign
abstract: The Islamic State’s convoy, chased around Syria for five days with nowhere to go, has become emblematic of the militants’ declining fortunes.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Islamic State militant, his AK-47 cradled between his legs, crouched next to the driver in the front of the bus, near a placard in the windshield that read B-9, which stood for bus No. 9 out of 17. The flash of a camera in the early dawn light showed him to be smiling broadly.

headline: Tal Afar After Liberation From ISIS: Battered but Still Standing
abstract: Iraqi commanders attributed the comparatively light damage to an escape corridor they had purposely left so the fighters would flee into the desert.
lead_paragraph: TAL AFAR, Iraq — An airstrike left a crater the size of a tennis court in one neighborhood. Artillery punched a gaping hole in the minaret of the city’s main mosque. Some buildings were leveled.

headline: A Turning Point for South Vietnam?
abstract: The elections of 1967, long ignored, could have saved the country. Instead, they doomed it.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow marks the 50th anniversary of Vietnam’s most democratic election.

headline: The Older the Better in Professional Tennis These Days
abstract: Winners of Grand Slam tennis events are skewing older these days — Venus Williams is 37 and Roger Federer is 36 — as the younger players take longer to reach their primes.
lead_paragraph: The future of men’s tennis has appeared to be previewing itself during the first week at the United States Open. Just how far into the future is anyone’s guess.

headline: For Vulnerable Older Adults, a Harrowing Sense of Being Trapped
abstract: Thousands of people were evacuated from Texas nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Many still need medicine, medical help and a return home.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A Holocaust survivor waded waist-deep in flood water. Dozens of people were trapped in a 14-story residence for seniors. A disabled man sat alone at home, without the aide who usually helps him, watching the water rise and unsure if anyone would come.

headline: Waiting for a Perfect Protest?
abstract: Well-intended moderates have used unrealistic standards to judge anti-racism activism. But this is nothing new — just ask Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: Media outlets and commentators representing a range of political persuasions have called attention to recent outbreaks of violence in Berkeley, Calif., Boston and other locations where anti-racist and anti-fascist demonstrators have gathered. Intentionally or not, they have often promoted a false equivalency between groups that advocate white supremacy and those that seek to eliminate it.

headline: Venus Williams, a Newly Minted Aunt, Keeps Her Focus on the Business at Hand
abstract: Williams advanced to the fourth round at the U.S. Open on a day in which her sister gave birth to a baby girl and in which her usual support network was lacking.
lead_paragraph: The news came before Venus Williams stepped onto the court for her third-round match Friday afternoon at the United States Open. Big news, about her sister Serena.

headline: Where Harvey Hit Hardest Up and Down the Texas Coast
abstract: Over 150,000 properties in Texas have been affected by Hurricane Harvey, based on preliminary estimates by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
lead_paragraph: Over 150,000 properties in Texas have been affected by Hurricane Harvey, based on preliminary estimates by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Little Effort to Investigate in States Targeted by Election Hacking
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 2, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t know if any of the problems were an accident, or the random problems you get with computer systems, or whether it was a local hacker, or actual malfeasance by a sovereign nation-state.”

headline: Water Damage From Hurricane Harvey Extended Far Beyond Flood Zones
abstract: About 40 percent of flooded buildings were in areas considered a “minimal flood hazard.”
lead_paragraph: About 40 percent of flooded buildings were in areas considered a “minimal flood hazard.”

headline: Denis Shapovalov, 18, Advances to Fourth Round at U.S. Open
abstract: Shapovalov, of Canada, is the youngest player to reach the fourth round of the U.S. Open since Michael Chang in 1989. With the draw wide-open, he could go further.
lead_paragraph: Denis Shapovalov’s high-flying and improbable run at the United States Open continued Friday as he advanced to the fourth round of only his second Grand Slam main-draw event.

headline: How to Regulate Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Three rules for ensuring that A.I. systems don’t run roughshod over humans.
lead_paragraph: The technology entrepreneur Elon Musk recently urged the nation’s governors to regulate artificial intelligence “before it’s too late.” Mr. Musk insists that artificial intelligence represents an “existential threat to humanity,” an alarmist view that confuses A.I. science with science fiction. Nevertheless, even A.I. researchers like me recognize that there are valid concerns about its impact on weapons, jobs and privacy. It’s natural to ask whether we should develop A.I. at all.

headline: If You Want to MAGA, Save DACA
abstract: Great nations know the value of human potential.
lead_paragraph: What is it, really, that makes a country great?

headline: Corrections: September 2, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 2, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Where There’s Smoke, There’s a Conspiracy Theory at a Russian Consulate
abstract: Just what the Russians had set afire at their consulate in San Francisco, a day after the State Department ordered it shuttered, remains a burning question.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amid rare extreme heat in San Francisco, it was unusual to see black smoke billowing from a chimney on Friday — not to mention that it was coming from the Russian Consulate, the day after the Trump administration ordered it closed.

headline: Utah Nurse Handcuffed After Refusing to Draw Patient’s Blood
abstract: A video of the episode showed an extended confrontation between the nurse and a police officer during which she screamed, “Somebody help me!”
lead_paragraph: The body camera video from a Salt Lake City police officer in an emergency room at University of Utah Hospital was rife with tension.

headline: In Beaumont, Tex., Hopscotching for Food, Water and Shelter
abstract: For many residents of southeast Texas, the last few days have been spent on a series of roads to nowhere.
lead_paragraph: BEAUMONT, Tex. — Carrie Chambliss climbed into her husband’s truck on Friday and drove a winding route some 70 miles, plowing through deep water, to get from her home in Mauriceville to a grocery store in Beaumont that had “barely anything” left.

headline: The Second Video Ever Shown on MTV
abstract: A very crunchy weekend challenge from Erik Agard.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Well, this was a lot of fun. Erik Agard is back with a puzzle that not only debuts a whopping 11 entries, but also contains a lot of really good stuff and devious cluing.

headline: U.S. Stumbles in Qualifying on Night Mexico Clinches Place in World Cup
abstract: A 2-0 defeat against Costa Rica complicates the Americans’ road to next year’s World Cup in Russia. They have three qualifiers left.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — If a sense of inevitability about qualifying for next year’s World Cup had begun to take hold for the United States national team under Bruce Arena, a feeling that he had reset the team’s course since replacing the team’s previous coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, that aura vanished Friday night.

headline: A Tennis Player Rises in the Rankings After a Terrible Fall
abstract: In 2011, Stefano Travaglia, who reached the second round of the U.S. Open, slipped on the stairs and fell through a window, an accident that nearly his career.
lead_paragraph: On a summer evening six years ago, the Italian tennis player Stefano Travaglia walked from his family’s sixth-floor apartment in the town of Ascoli Piceno near the Adriatic coast to the floor below. He needed to pick up some tennis shirts onto which an elderly neighbor had sewn sponsor patches for him. He bypassed the building’s elevator for the short trip, taking the stairs.

headline: The Summer of Love’s Dispiriting Fall
abstract: Even the Beatles began to sense that their utopia was, in fact, nowhere.
lead_paragraph: THE Summer of Love began with a burst of flower power. On June 1, 1967, the Beatles released “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” and the horticulture was nearly as impressive as the music. In the foreground of the album cover, the flowers spelled out the band’s name, and formed other shapes nearby — a guitar here, a star there. A daisy grew from John’s shoulder, a natural epaulet.

headline: Catcher Derek Norris Suspended for Season Under Domestic Violence Policy
abstract: Norris was released by the Rays in June, several weeks after his former fiancée Kristen Eck wrote in an Instagram post that Norris had abused her in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The free-agent catcher Derek Norris was suspended Friday for the rest of the season for violating Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy.

headline: Eduardo Nunez, Once a Friend to the Yankees, Is Now a Thorn in Their Side
abstract: Nunez, who drew C.C. Sabathia’s ire on Thursday after dropping a first-inning bunt, launched a two-run homer in the third Friday in a Boston victory.
lead_paragraph: During Eduardo Nunez’s four seasons as a Yankee, he was part team mascot, part punch line.

headline: Maybe Colin Kaepernick Is Just Not That Good
abstract: Limited skills rather than persecution could explain why he doesn’t have a job.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not Colin Kaepernick plays another down in the N.F.L., I’m going to say that he can achieve more off a football field than he — or anyone else in the sport — can achieve on one.

headline: Primary Choices for the New York City Council
abstract: Here are endorsements in five competitive races.
lead_paragraph: Here are endorsements in five competitive races.

headline: Seahawks Acquire Sheldon Richardson From the Jets
abstract: Seattle will also send a 2018 second-round pick to the Jets, and the clubs will swap seventh-round picks in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks acquired defensive tackle Sheldon Richardson from the Jets on Friday in exchange for wide receiver Jermaine Kearse and a second-round draft pick, bolstering a defense that was already considered among the best in the N.F.L.

headline: A Polished Hotel in Asbury Park Is New Center of Gravity
abstract: In a seaside New Jersey town celebrating a rebound, The Asbury, a modern, 110-room hotel, is as welcoming to spirited children as it is to carousing adults.
lead_paragraph: From $125.

headline: Man Barred From Open Last Year Is Arrested After Returning
abstract: The man, Ranier Piirimets, was ejected for what is known as courtsiding, a term for collecting immediate data about the scores of tennis matches and then using it to make wagers.
lead_paragraph: The United States Tennis Association announced on Friday the arrest of an Estonian man who violated a no-trespassing order by returning to the United States Open after having been ejected from the tournament last year.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Humans of New York’ and ‘A Monster Calls’
abstract: Brandon Stanton’s popular photography project comes to Facebook’s new streaming platform, and a family drama about a boy and a monstrous tree arrives on HBO.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Stanton’s popular photography project comes to Facebook’s new streaming platform. And a family drama about a 12-year-old boy and a monstrous tree arrives on HBO.

headline: The First Count of Fentanyl Deaths in 2016: Up 540% in Three Years
abstract: The first governmental account of nationwide drug deaths in 2016 shows overdose deaths growing even faster than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: The first governmental account of nationwide drug deaths in 2016 shows overdose deaths growing even faster than previously thought.

headline: In Indonesia, 3 Muslim Girls Fight for Their Right to Play Heavy Metal
abstract: Voice of Baceprot, a rising metal band made up of three teenage girls, is challenging entrenched stereotypes about gender and religious norms in the country.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The three teenage girls — shy and even seeming slightly embarrassed as they peer out from their Islamic head scarves — do not look much like a heavy metal band.

headline: Town After Town Under Water in the 100 Miles From Houston to Beaumont
abstract: Hurricane Harvey left residents of many small towns stranded.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Harvey left residents of many small towns stranded.

headline: 'Today We Should Not Be Blue- or Red-State People’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate the devastation of Hurricane Harvey, President Trump’s pardon of Joe Arpaio and pumpkin spice flavor.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: In Venezuela, Cooking With Firewood as Currency Collapses
abstract: Across every sector the nation relies on, production is falling and prices are skyrocketing. One family cooks over an open-air fire because propane gas is so scarce.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Food shortages were already common in Venezuela, so Tabata Soler knew painfully well how to navigate the country’s black market stalls to get basics like eggs and sugar.

headline: Rosa Parks House in Berlin Has a Ticket Home to America
abstract: The house that was a haven to the civil rights pioneer in the 1950s was turned into an art exhibit. It still needs a permanent home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a backyard in Berlin, a ramshackle house that was once a haven for the civil rights pioneer Rosa Parks is preparing for its third life — back in the United States.

headline: Silicon Valley Courts Brand-Name Teachers, Raising Ethics Issues
abstract: As teachers launch personal brands and cast themselves as influencers, start-ups and tech giants alike are racing to cultivate them to spread their wares.
lead_paragraph: MAPLETON, N.D. — One of the tech-savviest teachers in the United States teaches third grade here at Mapleton Elementary, a public school with about 100 students in the sparsely populated plains west of Fargo.

headline: ‘Dear Sugars’: In the Shadow of Damaged Parents
abstract: Steve Almond and Cheryl Strayed, joined by Steve’s father, discuss letters from people coping with the traumas they inherited from their parents.
lead_paragraph: Her father had cheated, and her mother blamed herself and the children for his infidelities. “She said if we were better behaved and he’d had a better home life, he would have never cheated on us,” this week’s letter writer recalls. "She told my sister and me that we were not attractive enough to keep a man.”

headline: Celine Dion Loves You. And You. And You.
abstract: After a hiatus and her husband’s death, the Canadian singer has gone from icon to legend. She’s given her fans everything else, so now she’s giving them a handbag.
lead_paragraph: Annick Chenard, 38, has seen Celine Dion in concert 21 times and also has a large tattoo of Ms. Dion’s face and flowing hair on her right shoulder. She recently spent a whole day out on a Montreal street with a fold-up chair and a poncho, waiting for a slim chance to meet her queen.

headline: EJ Johnson Is ‘Not Just Some Other Rich Girl’
abstract: Magic Johnson’s son was outed as gay by TMZ, then became a reality show star. All of 25, he is now embracing his role as a gender-flouting role model.
lead_paragraph: “Today we are talking about breaking boundaries,” EJ Johnson declared from the stage of Beautycon, a two-day cosmetics festival held in August at the Los Angeles Convention Center. The 25-year-old son of Magic Johnson was moderating a panel called “The Gender Revolution,” and he was dressed for the part: black silk pants, crop top, sleeveless duster.

headline: Want to Have a Good Day? Try Making the Bed First
abstract: In a time of chaos, tucking your sheets in tightly each morning can give you a sense of control. Here are some best practices for making the bed.
lead_paragraph: When Adm. William H. McRaven, retired, was stationed in Afghanistan, his days were filled with chaos and unpredictability. “We could have soldiers dying and the horror of civilian casualties,” he said.

headline: New York City Parks in the Summer: Romance, Games and a Performance for a Dying Tree
abstract: Daniel Arnold spent the last two months photographing parks in all five boroughs. The experience showed him “a very different pulse of the city.”
lead_paragraph: Parks in New York offer one of the city’s most coveted and valuable amenities: space. “You very rarely have room to spread out and not think about getting in somebody’s way,” said Daniel Arnold, a photographer who spent two months capturing moments in New York City’s open spaces. “There’s this psychological relief to them.”

headline: Get Ready for Technological Upheaval by Expecting the Unimagined
abstract: Rather than planning for economic changes we imagine, it is better to prepare for change itself with smarter social, educational and employment policies.
lead_paragraph: Self-driving vehicles could upend the transportation sector and eliminate a million or more jobs. Algorithms that decode M.R.I.s put a whole medical subfield at risk. And the list of professions and sectors soon to be obsolete grows steadily by the day.

headline: Give Up Prosecco to Save Your Teeth? British Claim Riles Italy
abstract: A storm in a wineglass has erupted between Italy and Britain when some British dentists claimed that prosecco causes chronic tooth decay.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A storm in a wineglass has erupted between Italy and Britain after some British dentists claimed this past week that prosecco, the bubbly North Italian wine, causes chronic tooth decay.

headline: Eid al-Adha: Muslims Around the World Celebrate Holy Festival
abstract: The Feast of Sacrifice, or “big Eid,” is one of the two major religious festivals of Islam.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Muslims across the globe — including in countries like India, Indonesia, Turkey, Russia and Pakistan — are celebrating Eid al-Adha, Islam’s most revered observance.

headline: L’Oréal Drops Transgender Model Over Comments on Race
abstract: Munroe Bergdorf posted on social media about “the racial violence of white people” and was dropped from a makeup advertising campaign.
lead_paragraph: A transgender activist and model was dropped from a L’Oréal ad campaign because of comments she made on social media about race, the company said on Friday.

headline: Video of Police Officer Knocking Down Woman and Child Incenses China
abstract: A street altercation in Shanghai has renewed a national discussion about the powers of the police to push back against irate residents.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Twenty-two seconds of real-life police drama have riveted and divided many in China over officers’ powers to use force against irate residents — including a woman clutching an infant.

headline: After Harvey, a Return Home in High Water
abstract: Days after a storm battered Houston, a family made an emotional return through waist-high water to see their flooded home and collect their belongings.
lead_paragraph: Days after a storm battered Houston, a family made an emotional return through waist-high water to see their flooded home and collect their belongings.

headline: He Had Her at ‘We the People’
abstract: Melissa Alpert and Trevor Mills (who was then deployed to Afghanistan) became pen pals in 2013 after she found his email in her spam folder.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Rose Alpert and Trevor Douglas Mills are to be married Sept. 3 at Rock Island Lake Club, an events space in Sparta, N.J. Mike Schellhammer, a friend of the groom who is affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, is to officiate.

headline: Finding Comfort in Each Other, and the Unknown
abstract: When Kelly Love and Hristos Karavoulias first met, his childhood cancer was nonactive. Now the couple is making the most of their time together.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Anthoula Love and Hristos George Karavoulias were married Sept. 2 in Lowell, Mass. Rev. Gregory Christakos performed the ceremony at the Transfiguration Greek Orthodox Church.

headline: Stranger Than Fiction: What Happened After the Bookstore
abstract: What do you do after prolonged eye exchanges while browsing in the aisles and then during a subway ride? Turn to Craigslist’s Missed Connections.
lead_paragraph: Molly Higgins Fischer married Samuel Chandler MacLaughlin Sept. 2 in South Dartmouth, Mass. Nina MacLaughlin, the groom’s sister, who received a one-day marriage designation from the state of Massachusetts, officiated at the home of the groom’s father and his partner, Pamela A. Murray.

headline: Human Toll of Harvey Comes Into View as Waters Recede
abstract: Among the dead were volunteers, people who ventured out to check on relatives, and “loner-type folks” who died in their homes.
lead_paragraph: One couple had just another stop or two in their pickup truck, a check on an elderly uncle. A 60-year-old woman had just lain down for a much-needed nap. An 8-year-old boy was riding in a van with his extended family in search of higher ground.

headline: One Week After Harvey, Texas Residents Exhausted, Still Stranded
abstract: As residents of Houston tackled the long process of repair after “a trying week,” others near Beaumont were still under water or without tap water.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A week after Texas was slammed by Hurricane Harvey, this region was still engulfed in crisis on Saturday, with weary residents of Houston searching for ways to repair swamped homes and salvage possessions even as others faced new orders to evacuate. In cities and small towns to the east, thousands of others remained stranded by rising waters and were still without dry shelter.

headline: The Popcast Answers Your Questions About Beyoncé, Music Videos and More
abstract: On this week’s episode, our readers picked the topics of conversation, which include Lil Wayne, merchandise and Camila Cabello.
lead_paragraph: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: For One Family in Houston, an Overwhelming Start to Recovery
abstract: With no preparation and few road maps to guide them, hurricane survivors like the Amofas are stumbling through their first bewildering days after Harvey.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — She couldn’t sleep. Not now.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Like our constructors, I no longer own a Magic 8 Ball, but I had one when I was a child. When you are young and innocent and hope against hope for something to come true, you will go to extraordinary lengths to confirm that hope.

headline: Police and Protesters Clash Over Disappearance of Argentine Activist
abstract: Santiago Maldonado’s disappearance has transfixed Argentines and emerged as a flash point in the coming legislative election.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The disappearance of an indigenous rights activist in Argentina spurred violent clashes between demonstrators and the police on Friday and has raised dark memories of forced disappearances during the country’s dictatorship.

headline: ISIS Is on Its Heels, but Fighting to the Death
abstract: American officials say the pace of the fight against the Islamic State is not slowing, even as the militants’ territory continues to shrink.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NIMITZ, in the Persian Gulf — A few days ago, Capt. Mike Spencer of the Navy rocketed off the flight deck of an aircraft carrier in his F-18 to provide air support for Iraqi troops advancing on the dusty city of Tal Afar, one of the Islamic State’s last strongholds.

headline: Minnesota Finds a Way to Slow Soaring Health Premiums
abstract: A new state program is holding down health insurance costs in Minnesota, and it’s a possible model for other states and for Congress.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Last fall, as consumers in Minnesota were facing health insurance rate increases of 50 percent or more, Gov. Mark Dayton, a Democrat, said the Affordable Care Act was “no longer affordable to increasing numbers of people.” The state’s top insurance regulator said the Minnesota market was “on the verge of collapse.”

headline: Trump Returns to Texas, With Words of Encouragement and Triumph
abstract: “There’s a lot of love,” the president said on his second trip to the region this week. “As tough as it’s been, it’s been a wonderful thing to watch.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump urged onlookers at a Houston shelter to “have a good time” on Saturday — and appeared to take his own advice during a daylong Gulf Coast tour that blurred the line between bucking up a battered region and taking an early victory lap.

headline: Ivan Lendl, Open Champion, Pushes the Benefits of Group Training
abstract: Lendl is supervising an experimental program for junior players backed by the United States Tennis Association, and progress is starting to show.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Kypson knows the precise punishment — including how many steps on the VersaClimber, an extreme aerobic exercise machine — he must endure for every transgression he commits during a practice session with Ivan Lendl, the three-time United States Open champion who helps oversee Kypson’s development as a tennis player.

headline: ‘Endless Stream’ of Rohingya Flee Military Offensive
abstract: “By far the worst thing that I've ever seen.” The New York Times reporter Hannah Beech describes a huge exodus of civilians into Bangladesh after a new military offensive against Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: “By far the worst thing that I've ever seen.” The New York Times reporter Hannah Beech describes a huge exodus of civilians into Bangladesh after a new military offensive against Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.

headline: Desperate Rohingya Flee Myanmar on Trail of Suffering: ‘It Is All Gone’
abstract: Tens of thousands escaped into Bangladesh, where they told New York Times journalists accounts of massacres by security forces. Hunger and hardship await them across the border.
lead_paragraph: REZU AMTALI, Bangladesh — They stumble down muddy ravines and flooded creeks through miles of hills and jungle in Bangladesh, and thousands more come each day, in a line stretching to the monsoon-darkened horizon.

headline: We Don’t Deny Harvey, So Why Deny Climate Change?
abstract: We know there’s a link, and there are things we can do to combat global warming.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that after the 9/11 attacks, the conversation had been limited to the tragedy in Lower Manhattan, the heroism of rescuers and the high heels of the visiting first lady — without addressing the risks of future terrorism.

headline: The Real Battle Begins: Mr. Macron vs. the Labor Code
abstract: The president has had a rocky few months. Now comes his first true test: reforming labor rules.
lead_paragraph: Since his spectacular victory in France’s presidential race in May on a promise of a new kind of politics, Emmanuel Macron has had a rocky ride. The military chief of staff quit in anger over budget cuts; the president endured ridicule over how much he spent on his makeup; he has been accused of being aloof; his popularity ratings have plummeted. All that, however, is just a prelude to the real battle.

headline: The Best Era for Working Women Was 20 Years Ago
abstract: Were the 1990s a peak never to be seen again?
lead_paragraph: The working woman was everywhere in 1980s and 1990s pop culture: The tough single gal Murphy Brown ran the news on TV every week. Dolly Parton in “9 to 5,” Melanie Griffith in “Working Girl,” and the ominously coldhearted mother in “Mrs. Doubtfire.”

headline: The Real Campus Scourge
abstract: No safe space or trigger warning lifts the sting of a cold new world.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, college freshmen are settling into their new lives and grappling with something that doesn’t compete with protests and political correctness for the media’s attention, something that no one prepared them for, something that has nothing to do with being “snowflakes” and everything to do with being human.

headline: The False Promises in President Trump’s Tax Plan
abstract: Mr. Trump says that all Americans will win big from tax cuts on businesses and the wealthy. It’s a tough sell because it’s not true.
lead_paragraph: As they return to Washington this week from their August recess, House Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee have their work cut out for them. Their job is to draft a major tax-cut bill for Congress to pass, ideally by year-end, to avoid closing out 2017 without a single big legislative win. The policy objective is to steeply cut tax rates for businesses and wealthy individuals. The political aim, and the point of President Trump’s speech last Wednesday, is to persuade the men and women in the Trump working-class base that a tax cut for the wealthy would be good for them, too.

headline: Don’t Suspend Students. Empathize.
abstract: Discipline can be a lose-lose proposition. Here’s a different method.
lead_paragraph: To his teachers at Ridgeway High School in Memphis, Jason Okonofua was a handful. During class, his mind drifted and he would lose the thread of the lesson. He slouched at his desk and dozed off.

headline: Can Melania Trump Rise Above It All?
abstract: Stiletto heels won’t help, but she could bring some grace to the chaos.
lead_paragraph: We are not going to dwell on Melania Trump’s flying to flood-ravaged Texas in stilettos, or sneakers, here. But nature abhors a vacuum, and the first lady’s fans and critics focus on her costumes in part because, so far, that’s about all they see of Melania Trump. In the back-to-work spirit of Labor Day, let’s reflect on Mrs. Trump’s plans as first lady now that she’s settled in the White House and Barron, her only child, heads back to school.

headline: Right-Wing Books, Wrong Answers
abstract: A professional deceiver and a high-minded conservative reach the same dead end.
lead_paragraph: Normal human beings read thrillers or romances on vacation; newspaper columnists assign themselves political polemics.

headline: Kenyans Celebrate Court’s Ruling to Nullify Election
abstract: Many are calling Chief Justice David Maraga a national hero after the Supreme Court said the presidential vote was tainted by “irregularities and illegalities.”
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The chief justice of Kenya’s Supreme Court, David Maraga, is a Seventh-day Adventist who refuses to preside over a court case on a Saturday. Once accused of corruption, he went on live television and swore on the Bible that he had never taken a bribe.

headline: Houston Needs a Hand
abstract: An anti-government stance made Hurricane Harvey’s impact worse. Can big government now make things better?
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — I am sure that by now many of you have seen the heartening pictures of the countless volunteers here in Houston, lining up to help out in the wake of Hurricane Harvey, kayaking to the rescue, opening their homes to strangers, feeding the hungry from their own kitchens. The scenes are even more moving in person, when you see the pickup trucks piled high with plastic bags of donations causing traffic jams around the George R. Brown Convention Center, and still more people coming in on foot, bearing boxes of diapers, dog food, bar soap, pillows, blankets and virtually anything else a human in an emergency could use.

headline: Upsets and Injuries Leave the U.S. Open Men’s Bracket Wide Open
abstract: Fifth-seeded Marin Cilic’s defeat at the hands of Diego Schwartzman, the No. 29 seed, added to the confusion in a competition already turned upside down.
lead_paragraph: When fifth-seeded Marin Cilic lost Friday afternoon to 29th-seeded Diego Schwartzman, players took notice of who was — and who was not — left around them in the draw.

headline: Stephen Miller Is the Enemy of My Dreams
abstract: Sometimes what you’re looking for has been right there all along, shouting over women on cable news shows.
lead_paragraph: I am a peaceable person. By that I mean I avoid conflict and also I’m quite lazy. People generally appeal to me. I can see their good side. I sometimes have fleeting antagonisms: toward a waitress I feel is being too performative in her friendship with a coffee shop regular, or that woman on the subway eating a plum really loudly. But in general, I have a smiley face and at the risk of sounding bonkers, I make friends with almost everyone I come across. What I’m missing, I’ve come to realize after a summer of cookouts and heart-to-hearts and hiking trips, is an enemy.

headline: ‘The New Washington’: Roger Stone
abstract: Michael Barbaro interviewed Roger Stone, one of President Trump’s oldest advisers. Maggie Haberman joins Mr. Barbaro for an analysis of the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Note from January 25, 2019: Roger Stone was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday in connection to the special counsel’s investigation and was charged with seven counts, including obstruction of an official proceeding, making false statements and witness tampering. Read the latest here.

headline: Jim Bridenstine to Be Nominated by Trump to Lead NASA
abstract: The former Navy pilot is in his third term in Congress and would be the first elected official to serve as NASA administrator if confirmed by the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jim Bridenstine, Republican of Oklahoma, will be nominated by President Trump to serve as NASA’s next administrator, the White House said on Friday night.

headline: What Climate Scientists Want You to See in the Floodwaters
abstract: Hurricane Harvey offers an opportunity to understand what’s happening to the climate and how we can mitigate future disasters.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — Like most Americans this week, we have been transfixed by the still unfolding disaster in Houston and coastal Texas, described on the airwaves as “unprecedented” and “beyond anything experienced.”

headline: Yankees Beat Red Sox as Matt Holliday Returns From the D.L. With a Blast
abstract: Holliday delivered three runs with his 17th homer of the season. The Yankees also got a solid start from Masahiro Tanaka and three hits, including a solo home run, from Chase Headley.
lead_paragraph: On July 15, Matt Holliday hit a home run off Boston Red Sox closer Craig Kimbrel in the ninth inning at Fenway Park, sending the game into extra innings. It wound up lasting 16, and Holliday played every one of them.

headline: As Bike-Sharing Brings Out Bad Manners, China Asks, What’s Wrong With Us?
abstract: The popularity of shared-use bikes has brought a wave of misbehavior, raising questions about social decay and the decline of decorum.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Lijing, a mechanic in Beijing, does not usually pay much attention to manners. He does not mind when people blast loud music, and he strolls the alleyways near his home in a tank top stained with grease. But when a stranger recently ditched a bicycle in the bushes outside his door, Mr. Liu was irate.

headline: Goodbye, Yosemite. Hello, What?
abstract: Confederate statues are not our only monuments to self-delusion.
lead_paragraph: HOTELS generally don’t figure prominently in my imagination, but Yosemite Valley does, and so does the glamorous Ahwahnee Hotel. When my father took me on Yosemite climbing trips in the 1980s, we never stayed at the Ahwahnee — it costs a fortune — but Dad always brought clean dress shirts so that we could hang out in the Ahwahnee’s kitschy Indian Room Bar before we slept illegally under the evergreens.

headline: Is Trump Really Pro-Worker?
abstract: He talks about his love for miners and factory workers. So far, he hasn’t done much to show it.
lead_paragraph: Even though Donald Trump is a flamboyant billionaire, many blue-collar voters embraced him as the presidential candidate who would lift them out of their economic rut. “I will bring jobs back and get wages up,” Mr. Trump said last summer, vowing to get tough on trade, Mexico and China.

headline: In El Salvador, ‘Girls Are a Problem’
abstract: Salvadoran women are facing an epidemic of violence fueled by impunity and a culture that normalizes machismo.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — I don’t want to go back to El Salvador. I felt afraid as a woman there more than in any other country in Latin America. I realized I had entered hostile territory while chatting with the taxi driver who picked me up at the airport, the first Salvadoran man I met. He told me he had a baby, a little darling called J. J., and showed me a photo.

headline: Long List of Top Democrats Have 2020, and Money, on Their Minds
abstract: Well before most of them will announce they are running, prospective Democratic candidates for president are taking steps to lay the financial foundation for a campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aides to Senator Kamala Harris of California say that her fund-raisers in Martha’s Vineyard and the Hamptons this summer have been all about helping Democrats in 2018. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies say his new political group is building an email list so he can communicate directly with his supporters about the future of the party and the country. And Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio says he has been traveling to Iowa and New Hampshire in part because “I like being out around the country.”

headline: Outlawing War? It Actually Worked
abstract: A 1928 pact brought an end to the right of conquest and changed the way states behave.
lead_paragraph: If you were to ask historians to name the most foolish treaty ever signed, odds are good that they would name the  Kellogg-Briand Pact of 1928. The pact, which was joined by 63 nations, outlawed war. Ending war is an absurdly ambitious goal. To think it could be done by treaty? Not just absurd but dangerously naïve.

headline: Instagram Your Leftovers: History Depends on It
abstract: A food historian says everyday, forgettable meals are where the real stories are.
lead_paragraph: I am a culinary historian, and scrolling through the endless food on Instagram makes me hungry. No, not for the fresh-baked sourdough rolls nestled so prettily in a linen napkin or that jaunty tumbler of strawberry mousse sporting its shiny green sprigs of mint. They look delicious, but what really makes my mouth water is the thought of all the stories behind them — everything that happened in the kitchen before you picked up your phone and clicked.

headline: The Moral Debate Over Statues
abstract: Readers disagree on the standards that should be used to decide whether monuments should remain, discussing Columbus, Robert E. Lee and others.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: United Kingdom
abstract: In which Andrew Zhou puts things together, two by two.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — For about a month, my dog, Jade — known to most as The Extremely Spunky Border terrier, or ESBT — enjoyed an unusual friendship. Border terriers were bred to rid their Scottish ancestors’ households of rodents, and they still “go to ground,” as it is called, but Jade has never shown any particular interest in her genetic lot. She’s a lover, not a fighter, so when the rabbit came knocking, Jade’s reaction was: “Cool! Another four-legged friend to play with!”

headline: Amid Nuclear Tensions, Trump Mulls Exit From South Korea Trade Deal
abstract: The president’s advisers are deeply divided over the idea, as negotiators from both countries struggle to rewrite the five-year-old deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is considering pulling out of a major trade agreement with South Korea as he tries to fulfill get-tough campaign pledges on international trade. But he has not yet made a final decision, two senior administration officials said Saturday.

headline: A Crude Rant Gets Fognini Booted From the Open — and Good Riddance
abstract: It may take awhile for officials to decide the long-term fate of this foul-mouthed player. Based on his past behavior, though, it should be a no-brainer.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest victories at the United States Open on Saturday didn’t happen on a tennis court. It was even sweeter than a great sports performance, and much more satisfying, too.

headline: No Madonna. No Geena Davis. But Still in a League of Their Own.
abstract: The latest Rockford Peaches are another tribute to the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League, which was also re-created on film 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ELGIN, Ill. — Strike one. “You swing like a girl!” the pitcher barked, heckling yet another player at the plate. Sonja Bushnick of the Rockford Peaches lifted her wooden bat again. She passed on one ball and fouled off another. On the next pitch she hit a short pop-up that the pitcher caught with ease. He laughed at her.

headline: North Korea Claims to Have Developed a Missile-Ready Hydrogen Bomb
abstract: North Korea’s state news agency offered no evidence for the claim, other than a photo of what it said was a hydrogen bomb ready to be loaded onto an ICBM.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Sunday that it has developed a hydrogen bomb “with super explosive power” to be mounted on its intercontinental ballistic missile.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Venezuela, That Empty Feeling
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 3, 2017
lead_paragraph: “Bolívars are like ice cubes now. If you’re going to go to the fridge and take one, it’s something you have to use right now, because soon it’s going to be gone.”

headline: Canadian Teenager, Headed to the Fourth Round, Gives U.S. Open a Jolt
abstract: Denis Shapovalov, 18, on Friday became the youngest male player to reach the round of 16 since 1989, and some say he could make it to the final.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning, Denis Shapovalov and two of his childhood friends, Jan Alafriz and Jonathan Soriano, drank tea in a dimly lit lounge at their hotel in Manhattan. A woman and her daughter approached the table and asked Shapovalov to autograph the cast on the daughter’s forearm.

headline: Uneven Pliskova Battles Back to Advance to 4th Round Against Brady
abstract: The world’s No. 1 player survives a hard one against Zhang Shuai, but is dogged by questions about inconsistent play. What does it all mean for the women’s draw?
lead_paragraph: As Zhang Shuai stepped to the baseline, needing one good serve to knock off Karolina Pliskova, the world’s No. 1 player, she did so with experience.

headline: Astros Make Return to Houston, Looking to Help in Hurricane’s Wake
abstract: The Houston Astros’ doubleheader against the New York Mets on Saturday was the first time the team had played at Minute Maid Park since Hurricane Harvey hit.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ten minutes before the start of a day-night doubleheader at Minute Maid Park on Saturday, Houston Astros Manager A. J. Hinch grabbed a microphone and stood in front of home plate.

headline: Mets’ Michael Conforto Will Have Shoulder Surgery
abstract: Conforto, 24, dislocated his left shoulder during a swing on Aug. 24 and will undergo the procedure soon. Meanwhile, the Mets were swept in a doubleheader in Houston.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Michael Conforto, the Mets’ lone All-Star this season, will have shoulder surgery in the coming week, John Ricco, the team’s assistant general manager, said Saturday before the Mets’ doubleheader against the Astros. Conforto dislocated his left shoulder on a swing in an Aug. 24 game.

headline: Cambodia Arrests Opposition Leader, Accusing Him of Treason
abstract: A rights advocate called Kem Sokha’s arrest a “disastrous setback” for human rights in Cambodia as Prime Minister Hun Sen consolidates power.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — The leader of Cambodia’s main opposition party, Kem Sokha, was arrested early Sunday at his home and accused of treason for participating in what the government said was a Washington-backed plot to undermine the country’s leadership.

headline: Corrections: September 3, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 3, 2017
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: North Korean Nuclear Test Draws U.S. Warning of ‘Massive Military Response’
abstract: The North’s sixth nuclear test, on Sunday, was its most powerful yet, but it was unclear whether it had in fact detonated a hydrogen bomb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea’s detonation of a sixth nuclear bomb on Sunday prompted the Trump administration to warn that even the threat to use such a weapon against the United States and its allies “will be met with a massive military response.’’

headline: In Phillies’ Gloomy Season, Rookie Rhys Hoskins Is a Beacon
abstract: Hoskins, who hit 11 home runs in 18 games and rewrote major league history, has leaned on routine and preparation to allow his talent to shine through.
lead_paragraph: Each day last weekend, Rhys Hoskins of the Philadelphia Phillies reached a home run total faster than any player ever had before. He hit his ninth homer that Friday in his 16th career game. He launched his 10th homer the next day, and his 11th the next. No other major leaguer had ever arrived at those mileposts in so few games.

headline: Don Shewey, Andrew Willett
abstract: Don Shewey, a psychotherapist and writer, and Andrew Willett, an editor for The New York Times Magazine, met in New York in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Don Shewey and Andrew Willett are to be married Sept. 3 in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. Michael Cohen, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at Longwood Cabin, a home of friends of the couple.

headline: Jennifer Cole, David Feldstein
abstract: The couple both attended Cornell, but they didn’t begin dating until well after graduation.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Heather Cole and David Harris Feldstein are to be married Sept. 3 at Temple Judea in Manhasset, N.Y. Rabbi Gerald Sussman is to officiate.

headline: Robin Wright, Richard Cleary Jr.
abstract: The couple, both 30, met at Washington & Lee University, from which they graduated, the bride magna cum laude and the groom summa cum laude.
lead_paragraph: Robin Elizabeth Wright, the daughter of Federal Judge Susan Webber Wright Carter of Little Rock, Ark., and the late Robert R. Wright III, was married Sept. 2 to Richard Simon Cleary Jr., a son of Helen Bragg C. Cleary and Richard S. Cleary of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Leo J. O’Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Andrew in Little Rock.

headline: Nancy Gunzenhauser, Benjamin Popper

lead_paragraph: Nancy Leigh Gunzenhauser and Benjamin Adam Popper were married Sept. 2 in New Rochelle, N.Y. Judith Wank, an adjunct leader for the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, N.Y., officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club.

abstract: She works in advertising, and he started a food truck and shops selling bagels with custom spreads. They met as freshmen at Penn.
lead_paragraph: Brittany Wallis Bell and David Alexander Fine are to be married Sept. 3 in Philadelphia. Rabbi David-Seth Kirshner is to officiate at the Rittenhouse with assistance from Cantor Israel Singer.

lead_paragraph: Jamie Hannah Garfinkel and Jonathan Adam Levy are to be married Sept. 3 at Milston Well Farm in Boulder, Colo. Rabbi Jamie Korngold is to officiate.

lead_paragraph: Richa Bhasin and Dr. Sridhar Padala Reddy are to be married Sept. 3 at the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan. William Miller, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, is to officiate. Earlier in the day, Pandit Ashwartha Narayan, a Hindu priest, is to lead a Hindu ceremony at the New York Ganesh Temple in Flushing, Queens.

Agler of Needham, Mass. Aaron G. Zucker, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister in order to preside at this event, is to officiate at Fremont Foundry, an events space in Seattle.

lead_paragraph: Matthew Benjamin Mittelman-Freeman and Adam Jay Rosen are to be married Sept. 3 at the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. William J. Hibsher, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, is to officiate, with Richard Orient, his husband, taking part in the ceremony

headline: Christina Cordeiro, Stuart Mitchell
abstract: The couple, both now doctors, met when they were medical residents.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Christina Nicole Cordeiro and Dr. Stuart Leighton Mitchell are to be married Sept. 3 in Baltimore. The Rev. Andrew Foster Connors is to officiate at Brown Memorial Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor, with Fritz Bauerschmidt, a Roman Catholic deacon, taking part.

headline: Glennda Testone, Jama Shelton
abstract: The couple met in 2006 while advocating for L.G.B.T. rights. When same-sex marriage was legalized, Ms. Testone proposed to Ms. Shelton.
lead_paragraph: Glennda Lyn Testone and Jama Renee Shelton were married Sept. 2 at the Conventional Hall on the boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J. Rick Weber, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, with his husband, Peter Schwartz, also a Universal Life minister, taking part in the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Mara Daile Sloan and Benjamin Bryan Boroughs were married Sept. 2. The Rev. Danny R. Reed performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church in Charleston, which is in Charleston, S.C.

headline: Gregory Schweizer, Jordan Rice
abstract: The couple shares a love of the law: They met at Stanford, from which they both received law degrees.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Michael Schweizer and Jordan Andrew Rice were married Sept. 2 in Chicago. Judge Cheryl Ann Krause of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, officiated at the Bridgeport Art Center.

abstract: The bride is a lifestyle blogger and the great-great-great granddaughter of President James A. Garfield. The groom is a senior financial analyst in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mackenzie Elizabeth Horan and Rudolf William Beuttenmuller IV were married Sept. 2 at the Siasconset Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass., on Nantucket. The Rev. Gregory Schweers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Marcel Bouchard, also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Lauren Block, Stephen Pack
abstract: The bride and groom grew up in neighboring New Jersey towns,and knew many of the same people but not each other until 2013.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Cary Block and Stephen Brian Pack were married Sept. 2. Rabbi Ellie L. Miller officiated at Stonehouse at Stirling Ridge, an events space in Warren, N.J.

headline: Lizzy Divine, Jesse Bordiuk
abstract: The couple met at Brookline High School in Brookline, Mass., from which they both graduated
lead_paragraph: Lizzy Ann Divine and Jesse Hellman Bordiuk were married Sept. 2 in Manchester, Vt. Bill Ewall, a friend of the bride’s family, received permission from the Vermont secretary of state to officiate at the Inn at Manchester.

headline: Alexandra Thomas, Eric Kathrein
abstract: The couple met in a San Francisco bar in 2013. “I really think I fell in love that first night,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Elise Thomas and Eric Reed Kathrein were married Sept. 2. The Rev. Jesús Rivera, a former Roman Catholic priest now affiliated with American Marriage Ministries, officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Baltimore.

headline: Caroline Stern, Thomas Burnett
abstract: The couple met at Amherst College, from which they graduated, both magna cum laude.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Brodie Stern and Thomas Somerset Burnett are to be married Sept. 3 at the Water Club in New York. Rabbi Howard L. Jaffe is to officiate.

headline: Emily Hughes, Amit Mukherjee
abstract: She was an Olympic skater and he is with a venture capital firm. They met through a mutual friend, and hit it off on their first date.
lead_paragraph: Emily Anne Hughes and Amit Mukherjee were married Sept. 2. Acting Justice Michael J. Obus of the New York State Supreme Court in New York, a friend of the bride’s family, officiated at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

headline: Global News Quiz: Trump Rebuked, Diana’s Death, Myanmar Exodus, Kenya Court
abstract: Did you stay on top of the most important stories last week? Test your knowledge of international events with our quick quiz, recapping major news headlines and featured articles from across the globe. To take the quiz, click on an answer, and the correct response will be revealed after you choose.
lead_paragraph: Did you stay on top of the most important stories last week? Test your knowledge of international events with our quick quiz, recapping major news headlines and featured articles from across the globe. To take the quiz, click on an answer, and the correct response will be revealed after you choose.

headline: Alana Frankfort, Dovid Spector
abstract: The couple met through the dating app Happn.
lead_paragraph: Alana Michele Frankfort, a daughter of Bobbie Frankfort and Lew Frankfort of New York, is to be married Sept. 3 to Dovid M. Spector, a son of Marsha Spector and S. Jan Spector of Atlanta. Rabbi Bruce S. Block will officiate at the bride’s family home in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

headline: Amelia Brown, Jaser Faruq
abstract: The couple met in 2011 at Cornell, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Amelia Huidekoper Brown and Jaser Faruq were married Sept. 2 at the Washington National Cathedral in Washington. Jim Ehrenhaft, an American Marriage minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Charity Jackson, Philip Greene III
abstract: The bride works for Uber and the groom is a second-year M.B.A. student at the University of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Charity Nichole Jackson and Philip Hilliard Greene III were married Sept. 2 at the Anderson House, a museum in Washington. The Rev. Kym Lucas, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Sara Danitz, Noah Steinhardt
abstract: The couple met at Camp Ramah in New England, where they spent six summers together as campers and counselors.
lead_paragraph: Sara Beth Danitz and Noah Mark Steinhardt are to be married Sept. 3 in Palmer, Mass. Rabbi David M. Steinhardt, the groom’s father, is to officiate at Camp Ramah in New England, with assistance from Rabbi James Rosen and Cantor Joseph Ness.

headline: Mary Montgomery, Jessie Brain
abstract: The couple met while working in the medical intensive care unit at Brigham and Women’s Hospital
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mary Watson Montgomery and Jessie Margaret Brain were married Sept. 2 at Belle Mer, an event space in Newport, R.I. Susan Larrabee, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Aditi Ahlawat, Vinay Rathi
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a charity auction in Worcester, Mass.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Aditi Ahlawat and Dr. Vinay Kumar Rathi are to be married Sept. 3 at Belle Mer, an event space in Newport, R.I. Pandit Jayant N. Sane, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

headline: Lara Tong, Jesse Hou
abstract: Lara Tong and Jesse Hou were married Sept. 2 at Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Lara Sophie Tong and Jesse Hou were married Sept. 2 at Terranea Resort in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. Sam Wong, an uncle of the bride, who received a one-day appointment as a deputy commissioner of civil marriages from the County of Los Angeles, officiated.

headline: Gabrielle Phillip, Jeff Dumont
abstract: The bride is a pediatric resident at Yale New Haven Children’s Hospital, and the groom is a financial officer in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Gabrielle Simone Phillip and Jeff Dumont are to be married Sept. 3 at St. Mary’s Catholic Church in Roslyn, N.Y. The Rev. Jean-Pierre Seon, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony.

headline: Joshua Hunold, Michael Beyman
abstract: The couple met on OkCupid while living in different cities.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Robert Hunold and Michael Joshua Beyman are to be married Sept. 3 at Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. Shobhit Singla, a friend of the couple ordained by the Universal Life Church for the event, will officiate.

headline: Bhavna Changrani, Sameer Punyani
abstract: The couple met on the eve of the huge snowstorm in 2016 that shut down Washington for days.
lead_paragraph: Bhavna Changrani and Sameer Paul Punyani are to be married Sept. 3 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Pandit Vijay Raghavan, a Hindu priest, is to officiate at the Westin Fort Lauderdale Beach Resort.

headline: Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer Steady the Course Toward a Historic Meeting
abstract: Nadal and Federer notched their most convincing wins of the tournament Saturday, raising hopes that the two could meet in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: After a shaky first week, the stumbles of Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer suddenly smoothed Saturday. Each turned in his most convincing performance of the tournament, buoying hopes that they might finally face off at the United States Open for the first time in their careers.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: Season Finales of ‘Power’ and ‘Twin Peaks’
abstract: “Power” and “Twin Peaks” offer plenty of drama for your Labor Day weekend. And the sensual “Dirty Dancing” arrives on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: “Power” and “Twin Peaks” offer plenty of drama for your Labor Day weekend. And the sensual “Dirty Dancing” is on Amazon.

headline: Blind Football Player Snaps for Extra Point in a U.S.C. Win
abstract: The long-snapper, Jake Olson, had both of his eyes removed before he was a teenager because of retinoblastoma, a cancer of the retina.
lead_paragraph: A blind football player for the University of Southern California participated in his first college regular-season game on Saturday, snapping the ball on the final extra point in the fourth-ranked Trojans’ 49-31 home victory over Western Michigan.

headline: ‘Great Comet’ in 360: Goodbye, My Gypsy Lovers
abstract: “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” closes on Broadway today. In 360, here is an onstage perspective of “Balaga,” one of the most rousing numbers in the show.
lead_paragraph: “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” closes on Broadway today. In 360, here is an onstage perspective of “Balaga,” one of the most rousing numbers in the show.

headline: To Understand Rising Inequality, Consider the Janitors at Two Top Companies, Then and Now
abstract: Focusing on core competence and outsourcing the rest has made U.S. companies lean, nimble and productive. It has also left lots of people worse off.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — Gail Evans and Marta Ramos have one thing in common: They have each cleaned offices for one of the most innovative, profitable and all-around successful companies in the United States.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: 57 Cross River Road, Pound Ridge

headline: A Mosque Was Bombed. What to Do With the Shoes Left Behind?
abstract: A pile of shoes remains at a Kabul mosque after a deadly suicide attack, the blood-flecked flats and bent bows a haunting reminder.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nobody really knew what to do with the pile of shoes left outside a Kabul mosque targeted by a suicide bombing a few days earlier.

headline: When the TV Heroine Is Less Than Perfect
abstract: Prestige television has been dominated by antiheroes. Now it’s making more room for women with issues (as long as they include motherhood and guilt).
lead_paragraph: We’ve been living in the age of the television antihero for a while now. Tony Soprano, Vic Mackey, Walter White, Frank Underwood, Don Draper — male murderousness and deception wrapped in charisma has been a dominant trope of the TV revolution.

headline: A West Coast Spotlight on Latino Artists Leads the Fall Art Season
abstract: “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA” with some 70 museum exhibitions, is a must-see in a season of old masters, overdue solos and big surveys.
lead_paragraph: Size-wise, the biggest deal of the new art season comes right at the start with “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA,” a roundup of some 70 museum exhibitions in Los Angeles and throughout Southern California devoted to Latin American and Latino art. The chronological arc is wide, from pre-Columbian gold to contemporary performance. So is the ethnic spectrum, with surveys of Afro-Brazilian and Chinese Caribbean art, and work by artists of Japanese descent living in Lima, Peru, and Mexico City.

headline: Retrofitting a Long Island Lighthouse for a Second Act
abstract: Groups are trying to turn the Suffolk County-owned Cedar Island Lighthouse, decommissioned in 1934, into a bed-and-breakfast.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The Cedar Island Lighthouse, a quaint, cubic structure of notably large granite blocks in Suffolk County’s Cedar Point Park, once appeared a fortress. From atop its stone tower, built in 1868, the lantern light led whaling ships and fishing boats home.

headline: A Toronto Restaurant Both Simple and Iconoclastic
abstract: The food at Brothers Food & Wine, which opened last October in a slim, plain space just above the Bay Street subway station, is richly complex and utterly satisfying.
lead_paragraph: You might not know it by appearances, but Brothers Food & Wine in Toronto is run by a couple of young iconoclasts: co-owners Chris White, 30, and Jonathan Nicolaou, 33, who shares chef duties with Keenan McVey, 29. The two met in Toronto culinary circles, then rose up through boundary-pushing London kitchens — Dandelyan for Mr. White; St. John for Mr. Nicolaou.

headline: Why Trump, After North Korea’s Test, Aimed His Sharpest Fire at the South
abstract: The nuclear crisis lays bare how the president’s trade agenda — the bedrock of his economic populist campaign — is increasingly at odds with his security agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the world agonized over the huge nuclear test in North Korea this weekend, President Trump aimed his most pointed rhetorical fire not at the renegade regime in Pyongyang, but at America’s closest partner in confronting the crisis: South Korea.

headline: Walter Becker, Guitarist, Songwriter and Co-Founder of Steely Dan, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Becker and Donald Fagen developed a sophisticated, adventurous sound, producing hits like “Do It Again” and “Rikki Don’t Lose That Number” and a raft of acclaimed albums.
lead_paragraph: Walter Becker, the guitarist and songwriter who made suavely subversive pop hits out of slippery jazz harmonies and verbal enigmas in Steely Dan, his partnership with Donald Fagen, died on Sunday. He was 67.

headline: Surf’s Up in the Rockaways? Let’s Meditate on That
abstract: A Buddhist meditation center has opened on the outskirts of New York City, where it is more peaceful but also accessible by subway. And there’s surfing.
lead_paragraph: The Rockaway Summer House is not your typical Buddhist retreat center.

headline: When Gentrification Knocks on the Wrong Door
abstract: Would-be buyers want Monxo Lopez’s South Bronx home, where an overheated real estate market seeks to remake — or erase — the past. He’s not selling.
lead_paragraph: Monxo Lopez is a popular man. He wishes he were not.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: You have one last hurrah before the end of summer: Make Melissa Clark’s mashed potato salad, some grilled corn, or fried chicken.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: In Her Family’s Footsteps, a Reporter Takes to the Classroom
abstract: While covering Silicon Valley’s influence on schools, Natasha Singer, who comes from a long line of teachers, found that students had mixed feelings about classroom technology.
lead_paragraph: To spend a day in Kayla Delzer’s colorful classroom at Mapleton Elementary School in North Dakota is to behold a bold experiment in next-generation learning unfolding in front of your eyes.

headline: What’s the Difference Between a Hydrogen Bomb and a Regular Atomic Bomb?
abstract: North Korea claimed it successfully detonated a hydrogen bomb on Sunday. Some experts suspect it had tested a “boosted” atomic bomb.
lead_paragraph: North Korea claimed that a nuclear blast on Sunday was a big advance from its previous five tests because it had successfully detonated a hydrogen bomb. But some experts suspect the North may have tested a “boosted” atomic bomb.

headline: Dating 6 Men at 68: The Woman Behind the Musical ‘Curvy Widow’
abstract: Bobby Goldman, who wrote the book for the new show, is having a ball talking about sex.
lead_paragraph: At 68, Bobby Goldman has found herself in the unexpected position of recommending adult toys to strangers.

headline: For Italians With Disabilities, a Place in the Sun
abstract: A beach near Rome is accessible to everyone, a rarity in a country where people with disabilities often feel excluded.
lead_paragraph: FOCENE, Italy — On a recent summer morning, one lido on the beach at Focene, west of Rome, was bustling. Italians of all ages and sizes sizzled on sun-bleached chairs. Children splashed happily among the waves, and a group of senior citizens exercised (gently) to a mambo beat.

headline: The Cambodia Daily to Close (After Chasing One Last Big Story)
abstract: The government says The Daily owes a tax bill of $6.3 million and must pay up or “pack up and go.” Its last print issue will be published on Monday.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — For the reporters and editors of The Cambodia Daily, an independent newspaper, Sunday was the end of an era as they prepared its final edition after 24 years in operation.

headline: Obama’s Letter to President Trump on Inauguration Day
abstract: Mr. Obama’s letter, obtained by CNN, urged the incoming president to guard democratic institutions and traditions.
lead_paragraph: In a letter left on Inauguration Day for President Trump that was both congratulatory and cautionary, Barack Obama urged the incoming president to guard democratic institutions and traditions, and “sustain the international order.”

headline: Damien Chazelle Is Producing a Musical Series for Netflix
abstract: The “La La Land” creator is executive producing and directing a new Netflix series set in France called “The Eddy.”
lead_paragraph: From the City of Stars to the City of Lights: Damien Chazelle, the filmmaker behind “La La Land,” is making his first foray into television with a new musical drama series for Netflix set in Paris. Netflix has ordered eight episodes of the show, which is called “The Eddy.”

headline: Reese Witherspoon Knows Rom-Coms Need an Image Makeover
abstract: With her focus now in projects like “Big Little Lies,” the “Home Again” star says you should think of the genre as stories about women’s experience.
lead_paragraph: Romantic-comedy heroines can seldom have it all. They’re either professionally successful and unlucky in love, or great with the kids and unfulfilled at work or in the bedroom.

headline: Frankfurt Evacuates 60,000 People to Defuse World War II Bomb
abstract: The discovery of a 4,000-pound bomb thought to have been dropped by the British Royal Air Force prompted the biggest postwar evacuation in Germany.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A relic of the relentless pummeling that flattened much of Germany more than 70 years ago forced tens of thousands of people to temporarily abandon their homes on Sunday in Frankfurt.

headline: As a Weary Texas Seeks Solace, Governor Says Property Damage May Exceed Katrina
