abstract: The Treasury secretary urged a link between the distribution of emergency funds and a debt ceiling bill, while Texans gathered for prayer.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As people throughout this flooded region sought solace in places of worship on Sunday, some of them makeshift, the governor of Texas predicted that Hurricane Harvey’s economic toll would exceed Hurricane Katrina as the federal government’s costliest natural disaster.

headline: Making the Women’s Serve a Bigger Weapon
abstract: Many in women’s tennis believe that the standard of serving can improve. Here are nine components of good serving technique.
lead_paragraph: Many in women’s tennis believe that the standard of serving can improve. Here are nine components of good serving technique.

headline: Filling a Weak Spot in Women’s Tennis: The Serve
abstract: Serena Williams has a powerful one, but she is an outlier. There is growing insistence in women’s tennis that the standard of serving needs to improve.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Davenport, a Hall of Famer who now works as a tennis coach and commentator, does not mince words about where she sees continuing deficiencies in women’s tennis, the sport in which she was ranked No. 1 in singles and doubles.

headline: Vacation Rentals Turn Into Shelters in Harvey’s Wake
abstract: Airbnb and HomeAway have asked hosts to give away space that they usually rent out to people displaced by the hurricane.
lead_paragraph: The six-bedroom home in an affluent neighborhood of New Orleans has everything a vacationer would want in a rental: tasteful décor with old-world touches like a clawfoot tub, a saltwater pool and a deck that would tempt even an inexperienced griller to try to char a nice dry-aged rib-eye. It goes for $750 a night this time of year on Airbnb.

headline: Calhoun Who? Yale Drops Name of Slavery Advocate for Computer Pioneer
abstract: A residential college named for a proponent of white supremacy will be rededicated to Rear Adm. Grace Hopper, a pioneer in computing.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — In a dining hall at Yale University, the portrait of an avid proponent of slavery has been replaced with a shield depicting a heraldic dolphin.

headline: After Dismal Summer, Hollywood Pins Hopes on Fall Ticket Sales
abstract: Despite hits like “Wonder Woman,” studios struggled badly at the domestic box office this summer, as a parade of expensive sequels disappointed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jeff Bock, a senior analyst at Exhibitor Relations, an entertainment research firm, summed up Hollywood’s dismal summer at the domestic box office — estimated ticket sales fell to a 22-year low — by going on an “I’m mad as hell and I’m not going to take this anymore” rant.

headline: Your Best Tips for Saving a Few Extra Bucks
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: He Aimed to Fight in Syria. ISIS Had a Broader Plan: Southeast Asia
abstract: The Islamic State sent a young Indonesian to fight in the Philippines. His shocked family now reckons with his role.
lead_paragraph: PURWOREJO KLAMPOK, Indonesia — The quiet young Indonesian aircraft mechanic dashed out of his relatives’ home in a hurry in February and disappeared. The next time his anxious family would get word of him would be three months later, on the television news.

headline: Now on Stage: The Countdown to a New Taylor Swift Album
abstract: The release of a new Taylor Swift album is always an instructive lesson in marketing. But with streaming dominant, the playbook is being rewritten.
lead_paragraph: For the music industry, the rollout of a new Taylor Swift album is always a master class in marketing, and the release of “Look What You Made Me Do,” the first single, is a case in point.

headline: Reggaeton, Bachata, Latin Trap? Ozuna Does It All
abstract: The Latin pop singer had almost one billion YouTube views before releasing his debut album “Odisea.”
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — One evening in late July, the day after the Puerto Rican singer Ozuna’s second straight sold-out concert at Manhattan’s United Palace Theater, he was sitting by the waterfront here, discussing the number of YouTube views his videos receive. “I put on YouTube one single and, in 20 hours, have five million, six million people,” he said. The totals overwhelm him: “In one month, I have 100 million. In one year, one billion. It’s too much.”

headline: Shaken by Harvey, Congress May Try Something New: Bipartisanship
abstract: Lawmakers return from recess with priorities reshuffled and glimmers of cooperation emerging on hurricane aid. The question is whether it will last.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress returns to Washington on Tuesday after a monthlong summer recess, Americans may witness something rare and strange on Capitol Hill: a glimmer, ever so faint, of bipartisanship.

headline: Body Tied to Cinder Block Is Found Near a Brooklyn Dock
abstract: The police said a passer-by on Saturday noticed the body of a man wrapped in a tarp floating in the Mill Basin inlet.
lead_paragraph: The police on Sunday were still trying to identify the body of a man found floating off the docks of a southeast Brooklyn neighborhood, an eerie reminder of an old-fashioned organized crime story.

headline: A Flying Cowboy Rides to Rescue Cattle Stranded in Harvey’s Floods
abstract: The devastating rain put thousands of animals at risk of drowning, but a cowpoke in a helicopter is helping drive them to higher ground.
lead_paragraph: BAY CITY, Tex. — “I’m gonna mash ’em out.”

headline: North Korea Nuclear Test Puts Pressure on China and Undercuts Xi
abstract: The confluence of the latest North Korean detonation with a major appearance by President Xi Jinping of China was a message to Mr. Xi, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was supposed to be Xi Jinping’s moment to bask in global prestige, as the Chinese president hosted the leaders of some of the world’s most dynamic economies at a summit meeting just weeks before a Communist Party leadership conference.

headline: North Korea, Myanmar, Princess Mako: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Frank Gehry to Design Museum for Architectural Gems (and Model Trains)
abstract: A few blocks away from Mass MoCA, the new museum will feature models of famous buildings and trains.
lead_paragraph: Frank Gehry has signed on to design a new museum in North Adams, Mass., that will feature models of trains running around famous buildings from the last 150 years — including six of his own.

headline: Wildfires Scorch Los Angeles in the Midst of a Heat Wave
abstract: More than 1,000 firefighters battled a stubborn fire that destroyed three homes and scorched thousands of acres of land.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than 1,000 firefighters battled wildfires burning through the Verdugo Mountains on the north edge of Los Angeles on Sunday, in the midst of a scorching heat wave. The fire destroyed three homes and forced mandatory evacuations in several neighborhoods.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Threatens Subsidies for U.K.’s Landed Gentry, and Queen
abstract: Millions in European Union farm subsidies that go to Britain’s rich and famous — including Queen Elizabeth II — could be excised after the country leaves the bloc.
lead_paragraph: SANDRINGHAM, England — It is a club that includes some of the world’s richest people. There are dukes, sheikhs, flamboyant entrepreneurs — even Queen Elizabeth II and other members of the royal family.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 4
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills rescheduled to Tuesday, and an auction of four-week bills also on Tuesday.

headline: Actors in a World Series Drama Are Now Gracing a New Stage
abstract: Rajai Davis and Aroldis Chapman, who faced each other in an epic at-bat in Game 7 of the Indians-Cubs showdown, are now with the Red Sox and the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: When Jordan Michael Davis, the 2-year-old son of Rajai Davis, is not minding his p’s and q’s at the dinner table, his father knows a sure way to get his attention.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Sequel to ‘The War of the Worlds’
abstract: In Stephen Baxter’s authorized follow-up to H. G. Wells’s science-fiction classic, the Martians return, and this time they know what they’re doing.
lead_paragraph: It was 120 years ago that H. G. Wells’s “The War of the Worlds,” about a Martian invasion of Earth, appeared as a magazine serial. (In the United States, the story was rolled out in Cosmopolitan.) Nearly 80 years ago, a radio dramatization of the novel caused “a wave of mass hysteria,” according to The New York Times, among some listeners who didn’t know the terrifying scenario was fiction. Now, Stephen Baxter has written a sequel, “The Massacre of Mankind,” authorized by Wells’s estate. (Baxter is the author of dozens of science-fiction books, and, even more pertinently, a vice president of the H.G. Wells Society.) His book was published in Britain earlier this year, where The Guardian said: “It’s Baxter’s best novel in a long time, and this may be because it reads like a genuine labor of love.” Below, Baxter talks about the evolution of Wells’s original story, his own childhood love of science fiction and more.

headline: Trump Shifts Labor Policy Focus From Worker to Entrepreneur
abstract: The administration’s approach fits with the president’s often-stated view of what drives economic success.
lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of the Trump era, one of the more unusual departures from recent Washington practice came in June, in a case before the Supreme Court involving worker rights.

headline: John Ashbery Is Dead at 90; a Poetic Voice Often Echoed, Never Matched
abstract: Among his many honors, Mr. Ashbery was the first poet to win the Pulitzer, the National Book Award and the National Book Critics Circle Award.
lead_paragraph: John Ashbery, a poet whose teasing, delicate, soulful lines made him one of the most influential figures of late-20th and early-21st-century American literature, died on Sunday at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: A Giant Nuclear Blast, but a Hydrogen Bomb? Too Soon to Say
abstract: Unusually large test explosions like Sunday’s North Korean blast can be achieved in many ways, making the field of atomic forensics difficult for distant experts.
lead_paragraph: Not all nuclear arms are created equal. They have four main designs that progressively raise the destructive power of the weapons and their ability to obliterate large targets. The biggest are known as city busters.

headline: Markets Are Closed for Labor Day, and the European Central Bank Will Meet
abstract: Expectations are building that Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, will soon announce a tapering of the bank’s stimulus program.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: Heng on Japan’s Constitution
abstract: The increasing threat from North Korea may jeopardize Japan’s pacifist Constitution.
lead_paragraph: The threat from North Korea has bolstered Shinzo Abe, the prime minister of Japan’s desire to strengthen Japan’s military, which has long been limited by the country’s pacifist Constitution.

headline: When the Welcome Wagon Won’t Budge
abstract: The 10 minutes required to steady a new mailbox as the bond sets around the post may not be a great time to meet new neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Ready for One’s Star Turn
abstract: Tracy Gray fires things up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Labor Day is a day to commemorate the workers in our country and to remember the growth of trade unions and labor movements in the 19th century. Blood was shed to protect the rights of these workers, and it is a contemplative day.

headline: Friends Recall Selflessness That Embodied Queens Assemblyman
abstract: Michael Simanowitz, who was elected to the New York State Assembly in 2011, was described as a “gentle giant.” He died at age 46.
lead_paragraph: Michael Simanowitz, a member of the New York State Assembly from Queens, died on Saturday at age 46, according to an Assembly spokesman. He had been battling cancer, friends said.

headline: Guinot, the French Cosmetics Company, Bets on Tennis Underdogs
abstract: In order to maximize exposure at major tournaments, Guinot makes short-term endorsement deals with players scheduled to face the sport’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: Sweden’s Robin Soderling, who was ranked 25th in 2009, stuns No. 1 Rafael Nadal at that year’s French Open, where he had been undefeated. At the same tournament three years later, the 111th-ranked Virginie Razzano of France beats Serena Williams in the first round. At this year’s Australian Open, the 117th-ranked Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan defeats Novak Djokovic.

headline: What to Do With Confederate Statues
abstract: A descendant of Robert E. Lee’s cousin says they should be moved “somewhere for a cooling-off period,” then perhaps be display in a museum.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tired of Technology
abstract: Readers discuss the benefits and drawbacks of ever-present technology.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Educating Inmates Benefits All
abstract: A teacher of prison courses, a former inmate and a criminology professor offer their views.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Clinton’s Choices When Trump Stalked Her at Debate
abstract: Readers discuss Mrs. Clinton’s regrets over not confronting Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Houston Neighborhood Under Water
abstract: While people in parts of Houston are gutting their houses and beginning to rebuild after hurricane Harvey flooded the city, residents of the neighborhood of Memorial may have to wait weeks for the water to drain.
lead_paragraph: While people in parts of Houston are gutting their houses and beginning to rebuild after hurricane Harvey flooded the city, residents of the neighborhood of Memorial may have to wait weeks for the water to drain.

headline: Chechnya’s Persecuted Gays Find Refuge in Canada
abstract: The Canadian government has quietly allowed gay men and lesbians from the Russian republic to seek safety in Canada over the past three months.
lead_paragraph: HONEY HARBOUR, Ontario — The Canadian government, working with a Toronto-based nonprofit, has quietly allowed gay men and lesbians from the Russian republic of Chechnya to seek safety in Canada over the past three months.

headline: Angela Merkel Declared Winner of German Election Debate
abstract: The German chancellor and her main rival, Martin Schulz, clashed over Turkey and refugee policies in their only TV debate before this month’s election.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The only televised debate between Chancellor Angela Merkel and her main challenger, Martin Schulz, before German elections later this month appeared not to sway many undecided voters on Sunday about who should be their next leader.

headline: Over 21 Miles of Highway, Snapshots of a Resilient Houston
abstract: The stretch of I-45 that leads downtown from near George Bush Intercontinental Airport captures some of the essence of what has often been a misunderstood city.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — This city sprawls over 600 square miles, an area so big that Chicago, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Detroit could all fit within it simultaneously. The nine-county Houston metropolitan region, covering more than 10,000 square miles, is almost as large as the entire state of Massachusetts.

headline: Kenya’s Giant Step for Fair Elections
abstract: In accepting a challenger’s accusation of fraud and ordering a new election, the Supreme Court has set a milestone for Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Kenyan Supreme Court’s courageous decision to nullify the re-election of President Uhuru Kenyatta is a critical first for Kenya and Africa, demonstrating that democratic institutions are capable of acting independently and resolving disputes that in the past have often spilled over into violence.

headline: For India, Toilets Are a (Mostly) Serious Issue
abstract: A new movie, “Toilet, a Love Story,” has charmed audiences at a time when the government is trying to bring plumbing to the half a billion Indians without it.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The most popular movie in India this summer is about a toilet. It nearly causes a divorce. It makes a father slap his adult son. It splits a village in half. But, ultimately, it’s about a romance.

headline: Eager to Create Blue-Collar Jobs, a Small Business Struggles
abstract: A Michigan auto parts company has transformed itself and made money. But its chief finds herself caught between demands to lower costs and lift wages.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Mich. — Anita-Maria Quillen blended a strawberry-banana shake, tucked high heels into a Louis Vuitton bag and fired off last-minute requests at her little boys and their sitter.

headline: Motives of North Korea’s Leader Baffle Americans and Allies
abstract: With the country again conducting a nuclear test, no issue confounds analysts more than what Kim Jong-un, its dictator, really wants.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — What does Kim Jong-un want?

headline: Old Soldiers’ Homes, Left to Just Fade Away
abstract: The veterans agency has 430 vacant buildings, including 200 that are more than 90 years old. Now it is trying to get rid of many of them.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — When the towers of the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers began rising after the Civil War, they were seen as soaring monuments to the nation’s benevolence. But after more than a century of use, they became more of an albatross.

headline: Lessons Learned on Frosty Roads Help Estonian Kaia Kanepi Gain Traction at U.S. Open
abstract: Kanepi, who was unsure whether she wanted to continue to play tennis, realized she missed it while taking a driving course. Now she’s a win away from the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Sometime between driving on an icy road in Finland and throwing a medicine ball with an Olympic champion discus thrower in Estonia, Kaia Kanepi realized that she missed tennis.

headline: Reinvigorated Astros Complete Sweep of Mets
abstract: Justin Verlander, acquired by Houston on Thursday, held his introductory news conference with the team, which also welcomed back some key players who had been injured.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Carlos Correa, the Houston Astros’ All-Star shortstop, was playing video games on a PlayStation 4 console late Thursday when he found out that his team had acquired Justin Verlander, one of baseball’s most decorated pitchers, in a trade with the Detroit Tigers. He threw his controller into the air.

headline: Maria Sharapova Is Ousted, but Star Power Is Big Loser at U.S. Open
abstract: Anastasija Sevastova of Latvia denied the Russian a spot in the quarterfinals. Denis Shapovalov, a breakout star with Russian roots, also lost.
lead_paragraph: It was not a good day for blond players with Russian family roots at the United States Open, or for those attracted to the sizzle of celebrity tennis.

headline: Read John Ashbery’s Poetry
abstract: Here is a selection of work by John Ashbery, the influential American poet who died Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Here is a selection of poems by John Ashbery, who died Sunday. They were chosen by Gregory Cowles, The New York Times’s poetry editor, and Andrew Epstein, an Ashbery expert at Florida State University.

headline: Did You Watch the ‘Power’ Season 4 Finale? Let’s Chat
abstract: The series showrunner, Courtney Kemp, and star, Omari Hardwick, help break down the episode and what it might mean for Season 5.
lead_paragraph: The billboards for Season 4 of “Power” showed James “Ghost” St. Patrick (Omari Hardwick) sitting in a jail cell, arrested for a murder he didn’t commit. Three words, “his darkest hour,” seemed to hint at the looming legal fight for the former drug dealer turned semi-legit businessman.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Scenes Along a Houston Highway Show a City Determined to Recover
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 4, 2017
lead_paragraph: “The thing that Lanier used to say about Houston that I loved, and is so true, is that Houston is one place where nobody cares who your daddy is, and that’s why people flock here.”

headline: Trump Seriously Considering Ending DACA, With 6-Month Delay
abstract: The plan, which officials said could still be changed, would give Congress time to come up with a legislative solution.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on the Supreme Court’s decision on President Trump and DACA.]

headline: No Corrections: September 4, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, September 4, 2017.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, September 4, 2017.

headline: Diego Schwartzman Reaches U.S. Open Quarterfinal by Beating No. 16 Seed
abstract: Argentina’s Schwartzman, at 5 feet 7 one of the shortest players in the top 100 of the ATP Tour, overcame leg pain to defeat Pouille of France.
lead_paragraph: Diego Schwartzman did not allow himself to think his tennis career could be blunted because he is 5 feet 7.

headline: Arizona Extends Its Streak and Its Wild-Card Edge
abstract: The Diamondbacks defeated the Rockies for a 10th straight victory and increased their lead over Colorado for the top N.L. wild-card spot.
lead_paragraph: Ketel Marte and Brandon Drury homered in a three-run sixth inning to bolster a strong outing by Zack Godley, and the Arizona Diamondbacks extended their winning streak to 10 games with a 5-1 victory on Sunday over the Colorado Rockies in Denver.

headline: Venus Williams and Petra Kvitova Continue Remarkable Runs to U.S. Open Showdown
abstract: Venus Williams reached the quarterfinals for the 12th time, and Petra Kvitova, returning from an attack, defeated third-seeded Garbiñe Muguruza.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after making her breakthrough at the United States Open, Venus Williams continues to thrive on the sport’s biggest stages.

headline: North Korea, Angela Merkel, U.S. Open: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Yankees Pound the Red Sox and Win a Four-Game Series
abstract: The Yankees rode a barrage of homers to an easy victory on Sunday night and moved within three and a half games of first-place Boston in the American League East.
lead_paragraph: In their final regular-season game against the Boston Red Sox this year, the Yankees sent a malicious parting gift on Sunday night at Yankee Stadium, a lasting impression just in case these rivals cross paths again come October.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: A Jerry Lewis Tribute and ‘Strangers’
abstract: TCM commemorates Jerry Lewis in a Labor Day marathon. And a newly single woman has questions about her orientation in Facebook Watch’s new dramedy.
lead_paragraph: Turner Classic Movies commemorates Jerry Lewis’s Labor Day telethon with a night of some of his best work. And a newly single bisexual woman has plenty of questions in Facebook Watch’s new dramedy.

headline: Land, Loss and Rebirth in Standing Rock
abstract: Photos taken by Larry Towell at Standing Rock over a period of six months are being exhibited at the Visa Pour l’Image photo festival in Perpignan, France, this month.
lead_paragraph: Photos taken by Larry Towell at Standing Rock over a period of six months are being exhibited at the Visa Pour l’Image photo festival in Perpignan, France, this month.

headline: Why Can’t We Get Cities Right?
abstract: Caught between rampant development and NIMBYism.
lead_paragraph: The waters are receding in Houston, and so, inevitably, is national interest. But Harvey will leave a huge amount of wreckage behind, some of it invisible. In particular, we don’t yet know just how much poison has been released by flooding of chemical plants, waste dumps, and more. But it’s a good bet that more people will eventually die from the toxins Harvey leaves behind than were killed during the storm itself.

headline: In Defense of the Truth
abstract: How can a liar negotiate treaties or navigate international disputes?
lead_paragraph: Once again: Donald Trump is a liar.

headline: Taking On Chicago’s Police
abstract: Illinois tries to do what Washington won’t: establish court oversight of a scandalous department.
lead_paragraph: The wrenching shift in the Justice Department’s approach to criminal justice under President Trump is playing out painfully as Chicago tries to rein in a scandalous police culture that tolerated officers routinely abusing and killing residents, particularly African-Americans and Latinos.

headline: Why We Should Put Women on Pedestals
abstract: Since statues tell us whom society deems important, more female figures are in order.
lead_paragraph: It’s a perilous time to be a statue.

headline: Showdown in Guatemala
abstract: In a nation soaked in corruption, a president who ran as a reformer is under the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Morales was elected president of Guatemala in 2015 on a promise of stopping the country’s fabled corruption and restoring conservative values. A former television personality widely known for his comic role in the series Moralejas (Morals), Mr. Morales rode popular anger to victory in 2015 as an outsider whose slogan was “not corrupt, nor a thief.”

headline: A New Type of Labor Law for a New Type of Worker
abstract: If unions are going to return to their old strength, they need rules tailored to modern workplaces.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day was born in the late 19th century, during a time of raw fear about the path of economic development. Opportunities for decent, middle-class livelihoods seemed to be shrinking, and the “laboring classes” confronted a grim future of what many called wage slavery. Conservatives held most of the seats of power, but reform-minded politicians, activists and policy mavens were thinking big about labor’s rights and wrongs.

headline: Eric Gonzalez for Brooklyn District Attorney
abstract: In a key city race with national implications, the acting D.A. makes a good case for building on the progressive policies of the recent past.
lead_paragraph: In a key city race with national implications, the acting D.A. makes a good case for building on the progressive policies of the recent past.

headline: You’ll Never Be Famous — And That’s O.K.
abstract: Social media make it seem as if meaningful lives are the extraordinary and attention-grabbing ones. That’s rarely the case.
lead_paragraph: Today’s college students desperately want to change the world, but too many think that living a meaningful life requires doing something extraordinary and attention-grabbing like becoming an Instagram celebrity, starting a wildly successful company or ending a humanitarian crisis.

headline: How a Crackdown on Leaks Threatens Confidential Sources
abstract: It seems all but certain that the Justice Department will try to chip away at the guidelines that limit when federal prosecutors can serve subpoenas on the news media.
lead_paragraph: It was just four years ago that roughly two dozen representatives of major news organizations crowded around a conference table at the Justice Department for a meeting with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. Our agenda? Strengthening the Justice Department’s guidelines that limit when federal prosecutors can serve subpoenas on the news media.

headline: Land, Loss and Rebirth in Standing Rock
abstract: Photos taken by Larry Towell at Standing Rock over a period of six months are being exhibited at the Visa Pour l’Image photo festival in Perpignan, France, this month.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Larry Towell watched as the remains of the main protest campsite at Standing Rock, N.D., burned around him in February. The structures, many of them considered sacred by the Native Americans who began the protests against the Dakota Access Pipeline, had been set on fire so the authorities preparing to enter the encampment would not be the people who destroyed them.

headline: U.S. Urges Fuel Cutoff for North Korea, Saying It’s ‘Begging for War’
abstract: Trump administration officials said a cutoff was a last best chance to resolve the standoff with the North using sanctions rather than military means.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump Administration, warning that North Korea is “begging for war,” is pressing China and other members of the United Nations Security Council to cut off all oil and other fuels to the country.

headline: Test Your Knowledge of Historical Events, as Seen in Our Pages
abstract: Many of the dominant news issues of our era were just as important decades, even centuries ago. We went through the New York Times archive to quiz you on your knowledge of major issues.
lead_paragraph: Many of the dominant news issues of our era were just as important decades, even centuries ago. We went through the New York Times archive to quiz you on your knowledge of major issues.

headline: The Same Agency That Runs Obamacare Is Using Taxpayer Money to Undermine It
abstract: Three ways the Department of Health and Human Services has campaigned against the current health law.
lead_paragraph: Three ways the Department of Health and Human Services has campaigned against the current health law.

headline: Chelsea Manning Headlines New Yorker Festival
abstract: The event, from Oct. 6 to 8, will also include interviews with Preet Bharara, Seth Meyers and Glenn Close.
lead_paragraph: In previous years, The New Yorker Festival has centered on pop culture luminaries, from David Letterman to Stephen Sondheim. But this year’s festival, from Oct. 6 to 8 in Manhattan, will skew political, with interviews with Chelsea Manning, Preet Bharara, and Senator Al Franken of Minnesota.

headline: Houston Family Returns to a Flooded Home
abstract: The Hendrix family returns to their still-flooded house in West Houston to witness the destruction left by Hurricane Harvey.
lead_paragraph: The Hendrix family returns to their still-flooded house in West Houston to witness the destruction left by Hurricane Harvey.

headline: In ‘Careers for Women,’ the Plot Twists Around the World Trade Center
abstract: Joanna Scott’s “Careers for Women,” featuring a Port Authority publicist in midcentury Manhattan, serves up a vice-ridden narrative with white-glove service.
lead_paragraph: CAREERS FOR WOMENBy Joanna Scott 295 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $26.

headline: Backyard Chickens Carry a Hidden Risk: Salmonella
abstract: More than 900 people have contracted it from backyard poultry this year — the highest number ever — and the trend is expected to continue.
lead_paragraph: Pet chicks and ducklings seem unlikely culprits in a serious public health problem. But they’re responsible for infecting more than 900 people with salmonella this year — the highest number to date, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: On the Road in Germany, Accompanied by Troubling Memories
abstract: Alison Moore’s novel “The Lighthouse” follows a lonely British hiker on an increasingly precarious trek through the German countryside.
lead_paragraph: THE LIGHTHOUSEBy Alison Moore 203 pp. Biblioasis. Paper, $14.95

headline: Where Your Mercedes-Benz and Porsche Were Born
abstract: Two museums in Germany’s motor city, Stuttgart, supply automotive history, test drives and the awe of seeing cars being created.
lead_paragraph: When I stepped off the S-Bahn at the Neckarpark station in Stuttgart on my way to the Mercedes-Benz Museum, I ran into a gaggle of Idaho high school students who nicely summed up the two automotive museums they had just visited.

headline: Ruined ‘Apartments’ May Hold Clues to Native American History
abstract: In Colorado, archaeologists have begun excavating two “great houses” in what once was a northern settlement of the ancient Chaco civilization.
lead_paragraph: NEAR MANCOS, Colo. — On the site of a former auto-repair shop here, broken stone walls mark the site of a 900-year-old village that may yield new insights into an ancient desert culture.

headline: Among the Masters at the Ferrari and Lamborghini Museums
abstract: The designs are dazzling at three automobile museums in Italy. And then you get to drive.
lead_paragraph: When I started planning our vacation to Italy my teenage sons worried about being trapped for hours in museums. I promised that wouldn’t happen, since I still have flashbacks to my parents dragging my sisters and me on exhaustive and exhausting visits to museums and places like the landscape painter Frederic Church’s house at Olana in Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Is Houston Still a Model City? Its Supporters Aren’t Backing Down
abstract: Houston embodies wildly different lessons on how to build a city. And everyone is doubling down.
lead_paragraph: Houston is a prime example — of what depends on your point of view.

headline: Art That Isn’t Pretty, in Pictures
abstract: The rebirth — and importance — of ugly painting.
lead_paragraph: The rebirth — and importance — of ugly painting.

headline: The Beauty of Ugly Painting
abstract: The art world is obsessed with unpretty pictures. But why?
lead_paragraph: Lost in the fun house of Laura Owens’s unstoppably inventive show at the gallery Sadie Coles HQ in London last year, I spent a whole afternoon eyeballing a painting of Garfield. The L.A.-based Owens transforms elements that could be too swiftly called ‘‘zany’’ or ‘‘lurid’’ — rainbow sprinkles as a psychedelic garland on wallpaper; stoned, Crayola-like squiggles; swirls of oil paint thick as cake frosting — into something ravishing. In a 2013 interview, the artist said she had no intention of making ‘‘good’’ art, art that fulfills some fussy criteria of taste or beauty; the opposite impulse, she suggested, is always more fruitful.

headline: Opioids Aren’t the Only Pain Drugs to Fear
abstract: They are only one of many drug-related problems associated with pain management.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a White House panel declared the nation’s epidemic of opioid abuse and deaths “a national public health emergency,” a designation usually assigned to natural disasters.

headline: Prince William and Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, Expecting Third Child
abstract: The child will be fifth in line to the British throne; the couple already has two children: George, 4, and Charlotte, 2.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince William and Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge, are expecting a third child, who would be fifth in line to the British throne, Kensington Palace announced Monday.

headline: Trump Can’t Stop Trade With North Korea. But He Does Have Options.
abstract: With about $650 billion in U.S.-China trade on the line, Washington must tread carefully if it wants to pressure Beijing to take a tougher line on Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — President Trump said on Sunday that the United States could consider stopping all trade with countries doing business in North Korea, in a move that could spell economic catastrophe for the pugnacious country.

headline: Why Aung San Suu Kyi’s Nobel Peace Prize Won’t Be Revoked
abstract: Some fellow laureates have confronted the de facto leader of Myanmar over its treatment of the Rohingya, but a Nobel Prize has never been rescinded.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the de facto leader of Myanmar and a Nobel Peace Prize laureate who once embodied her country’s fight for democracy, came under increased pressure on Monday to denounce a military operation that has caused thousands of Muslim refugees to flee across the border to Bangladesh.

headline: The Fall’s Most Fascinating Art Show? The Met Trying to Fix Itself
abstract: The museum is searching for a director. Maybe it’s time for a woman to assume control.
lead_paragraph: There are many exciting museum shows to see across the country in coming months. But of particular interest to me will be the one unfolding in real time at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as this august institution tries to right itself after several years of staff unrest, financial mismanagement and overreach. A lot has happened since Thomas P. Campbell, its director of eight years, resigned under pressure in late February, but it’s not over. The most obvious questions are: Who will be the next director, and when will he — or, better yet, she — be appointed?

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3 Finale: The Curtain Call
abstract: Does it even matter that so many questions were left unanswered?
lead_paragraph: In May of 1990, ABC aired the “Twin Peaks” Season 1 finale, and frustrated viewers who’d expected the show’s creators David Lynch and Mark Frost to resolve the “Who killed Laura Palmer?” mystery. In June of 1991, “Twin Peaks” Season 2 also ended with more questions than answers, and stuck fans with a cruel twist, revealing that heroic FBI Agent Dale Cooper had been replaced by an evil twin. So if you were confounded by the way the third (and perhaps last-ever) “Twin Peaks” season wrapped up last night ... well, call it tradition. Whether by circumstance or intent, this has always been a TV drama that eschews tidy resolutions.

headline: A Baby Wails, and the Adult World Comes Running
abstract: In almost every mammal species, an infant’s cry has a primal impact on nearby adults. Scientists are beginning to figure out why.
lead_paragraph: A normal human baby, according to psychologists, will cry about two hours over the course of a day.

headline: Review: ‘American Horror Story: Cult’ Feeds Off Trump-Era Fears
abstract: The new season portrays today’s politics as a joke gone horrifyingly wrong, but doesn’t quite make “Horror Story” great again.
lead_paragraph: In the summer and fall of 2016, America was under clown attack. First in South Carolina, then across the country, residents reported sightings of menacing clowns, in the woods, on the streets and on social media.

headline: N.F.L. Win Projections Follow Form, With One Exception
abstract: In professional sports, good teams tend to slip and bad teams tend to improve from one season to the next.
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Browns and the Jacksonville Jaguars are two N.F.L. teams few expect to see at the top of any league ranking. Yet those two misbegotten outfits stand together as the teams expected to improve the most this season.

headline: Jockey Robbie Davis Now Welcomes Offspring Into the Saddle
abstract: He admits he was devastated when his daughter decided to be a jockey, but now he is proud that she and two of her siblings followed in his footsteps.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Robbie Davis raised his six children in the thoroughbred racing business. In fact, he did it right here, in the sport’s beating heart. He was a jockey, one of New York’s best for more than two decades.

headline: Happy Labor Day
abstract: Today is for cookouts and barbecue, hot dogs and watermelon lemonade. Dig in!
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Gender War, Aisle 3: Unisex Kids’ Clothes Stir British Backlash
abstract: John Lewis, the British retailer, has sparked a spirited discussion by eliminating boys and girls signs and using gender-neutral clothing tags at its stores.
lead_paragraph: In the gender wars recently, British retailers have had trouble striking the right balance in the children’s aisle, either perpetuating stereotypes or going too far in the opposite direction.

headline: Film Forum to Have a New Screen and More
abstract: The downtown nonprofit repertory and art-house cinema is set to add a fourth screen and renovate its other three.
lead_paragraph: Film Forum is getting a makeover. The popular downtown art house and repertory cinema will be adding a fourth screen along with buildingwide improvements, the theater announced Monday.

headline: Twice Beaten, Thrice Shy? Not for Sal Albanese, Mayoral Hopeful. Again.
abstract: In 2013, Sal Albanese got 0.9 percent of the Democratic mayoral primary vote, finishing eighth out of nine. This year, the worst he can do is second.
lead_paragraph: The candidate sat in a dark suit and yellow monogrammed tie on an R train headed to Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to campaign with an old friend. Little gave away that the man was nearly at the end of another quixotic campaign to become mayor of New York, except for a small navy button with his first name: Sal.

headline: Salman Rushdie’s Prose Joins the Circus in ‘The Golden House’
abstract: Rushdie’s 13th novel is exhausting, but it’s a treat when focused on a villain who resembles Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: When Salman Rushdie began work on his second novel, “Midnight’s Children” (1981), the one that would make his name, he realized, he has written, that he could not write his book “in cool Forsterian English. India was not cool. It was hot. It was hot and overcrowded and vulgar and loud and it needed a language to match that,” and he would try to find that language.

headline: Listen to 13 Essential Walter Becker Songs
abstract: With Steely Dan, he produced some of the most artistically and commercially potent music of the 1970s and early ’80s.
lead_paragraph: When you think of Steely Dan, you probably hear Donald Fagen’s brackish snarl in the front of your mind. But Walter Becker, the group’s other half, played an equal role in defining its sound and direction. Mr. Becker, who died on Sunday at 67, founded Steely Dan — which was more of a protean studio project than a band with any set personnel — with Mr. Fagen, his perennial musical partner, in 1972. They sculpted a literary, restlessly inventive brand of jazz-rock, producing some of the most artistically and commercially potent music of that era. The group returned to touring in the 1990s, and released two warmly received albums in the new millennium. Here are 13 essential tracks that showcase Mr. Becker’s talents, including two from his low-profile solo career.

headline: Susan Vreeland, Novelist With a Passion for Art, Dies at 71
abstract: A former high school teacher, Ms. Vreeland was best known for her novel “Girl in Hyacinth Blue,” which traces the history of a fictional painting.
lead_paragraph: Susan Vreeland, who drew on her love of art to fashion well-regarded novels about paintings and those who paint or own them, died on Aug. 23 in San Diego. She was 71.

headline: A Persistent Case in Ferguson Raises Doubts About Reform
abstract: Five years after the arrest of Fred Watson, the city prosecutor continues to pursue minor charges despite what appear to be numerous problems.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When the Justice Department issued a scathing report that detailed routine civil rights violations by the police and courts here after an officer fatally shot Michael Brown in 2014, one anecdote generated particular outrage.

headline: Stodgy No More? The Shaw Festival is Full of Surprises
abstract: Under a new artistic director, one of the biggest stage festivals in North America is experimenting with pop-up shows and audience interaction. Of course, “Saint Joan” is on the bill, too.
lead_paragraph: NIAGARA ON THE LAKE, CANADA — The slip of paper lodged in Shaw Festival programs at a recent Saturday matinee didn’t beg for donations or warn about an understudy. Instead, it had a $5 offer for a bonus play — one that would begin at 11:30 that very evening.

headline: Menendez Trial Set to Begin With Tensions High and Washington Watching
abstract: For the first time in 36 years, a sitting United States senator, Robert Menendez of New Jersey, is facing a federal bribery trial, one that could alter both the makeup of the Senate and the future of money and politics.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The senator paused in a corridor of the federal courthouse here last month to oblige a beckoning courtroom sketch artist.

headline: David Wright to Have Rotator Cuff Surgery
abstract: A Mets legend is hit with still more bad news. Three other Mets will also undergo surgery this week.
lead_paragraph: The once-illustrious career of Mets third baseman and captain David Wright sustained yet another blow on Monday when the Mets announced he would undergo surgery to repair a torn rotator cuff in his right shoulder on Tuesday in New York.

headline: Lil Uzi Vert Debuts at No. 1, Leading a SoundCloud Wave
abstract: The Billboard album chart this week again showed the power of streaming, as Lil Uzi Vert’s “Luv Is Rage 2” and XXXTentacion’s “17” took the top two spots.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of rappers with anarchic approaches to social media and free digital distribution on platforms like SoundCloud is riding the streaming wave into the mainstream. On the Billboard album chart this week, two auspicious debuts from leading figures of that movement — Lil Uzi Vert, 23, and XXXTentacion, 19 — marked their commercial arrival by outpacing an array of more traditional releases.

headline: Muslims on 2 Continents Protest Persecution in Myanmar
abstract: Widespread demonstrations have raised pressure on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the de facto leader of Myanmar, over the treatment of the Rohingya minority.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Protests erupted Monday among Muslims in Asia, Australia and Russia over a military campaign in Myanmar that has forced tens of thousands of fellow Muslims to flee across the border to Bangladesh.

headline: Merkel, Vulnerable on Diesel in Germany, Moves to Address Issue
abstract: While expressing opposition to banning the use of diesel-powered vehicles, the German chancellor pledged Monday to increase financial aid to cities trying to fight air pollution.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has been hailed as the “climate chancellor” for her efforts to help the country shift toward renewable energy. But she has faced criticism from consumers angered by her refusal to come down harder on German automakers over a widening diesel emissions scandal.

headline: Allies for 67 Years, U.S. and South Korea Split Over North Korea
abstract: The uneasy relationship between President Trump and South Korea’s leader is testing a seven-decade alliance at a critical time.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For seven decades, the United States and South Korea have been the closest of allies. Their soldiers have served together not just on the Korean Peninsula but in Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq. And under America’s protective umbrella, the South Korean economy has soared.

headline: Review: ‘As You Like It’ Creates a Sanctuary City in Central Park
abstract: This free production from Public Works includes more than 200 amateur performers and looks as diverse, busy and vital as New York City itself.
lead_paragraph: “All are welcome here.”

headline: Best Pictures, Maybe, but Telluride Is Not About Oscars
abstract: The film festival has become a showcase for ambitious mainstream filmmaking, like new work from Guillermo del Toro and Greta Gerwig.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Spending time at a film festival is like living inside an accordion. Time expands and contracts — months are compressed into a few hours of screen time, and a day of screenings lasts a week — and you can’t always extract the music from the noise. The Telluride Film Festival, which spans each Labor Day weekend in this high-altitude former mining town, is an old-time squeeze box wired up to a Dolby sound system.

headline: China’s Reformist Central Banker Could Be a Tough Act to Follow
abstract: As Zhou Xiaochuan nears retirement, potential successors may lack the desire or political heft to shake up the country’s troubled financial system.
lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — Throughout much of China’s economic rise over the past three decades, one Chinese official quietly played a pivotal role in pushing an embrace of free markets.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Sets Scares in Postelection America
abstract: Killer clowns provide some mayhem, but this season, titled “Cult,” finds its terror in the fear and anger of a fragmented citizenry.
lead_paragraph: There have been haunted mansions, sinister hotels and mental institutions. There have been ghosts, aliens and witches.

headline: The Russian Company That Is a Danger to Our Security
abstract: Kaspersky Lab, the cybersecurity company, is close to Putin’s government. So why is the U.S. government using its software?
lead_paragraph: MADBURY, N.H. — The Kremlin hacked our presidential election, is waging a cyberwar against our NATO allies and is probing opportunities to use similar tactics against democracies worldwide. Why then are federal agencies, local and state governments and millions of Americans unwittingly inviting this threat into their cyber networks and secure spaces?

headline: J.J. Watt Appealed for Donations. Then His Mom Got to Work.
abstract: When J.J. Watt’s call for donations to aid Hurricane Harvey victims went viral, his mother, Connie, who runs his foundation, got a quick education in disaster philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: PEWAUKEE, Wis. — Connie Watt, a former vice president at a home inspection company, sat at her kitchen table on Saturday morning and counted out nearly $20,000 in crumpled $1 bills, hastily signed checks, crisp $100 bills and loose change that schoolchildren had delivered to Pewaukee High School in plastic bags.

headline: North Korea, Rohingya, Narendra Modi: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: In Rome, Violent Eviction of Migrants ‘Touched a Nerve’
abstract: With more than 10,000 Romans waiting for public housing, some sympathize with the now-homeless migrants. Others argue for a policy of “Italians first.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — The gardens by Piazza Venezia in the middle of Rome are normally used as a rest stop by tired tourists. In recent weeks, they have instead become home to weary asylum seekers, evicted from a building in Rome that they had illegally occupied for years.

headline: What Do Dreamers Do Now?
abstract: The expansive cruelty of the executive branch may yet be tempered by the powers and wisdom of America’s legal system.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: U.N. Group Accuses Burundi Leaders of Crimes Against Humanity
abstract: A panel of investigators set up by the agency’s Human Rights Council said it had delivered a list of suspects to the United Nations High Commissioner for human rights.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — For more than two years, critics of President Pierre Nkurunziza of Burundi and independent activists have fallen victim to homicide, have disappeared into secret detention centers or escaped to neighboring countries, recounting torture and rape at the hands of the military and the police.

headline: For Kurdish Independence
abstract: The Kurdistan Regional Government’s representative in Washington takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Increasing Diversity on Campuses
abstract: Readers offer their ideas, from making applications less onerous to eliminating the SAT.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Memorizing Poetry Pays Dividends
abstract: Readers recall how favorite poems helped them and others in life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Pence Would Be No Relief’
abstract: An Indiana resident says Mr. Pence was divisive as that state’s governor and would be no better than President Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Allison and Katie Crutchfield, D.I.Y. Punk’s Twin Elders
abstract: The sisters, who both have new music out this year, talk about male condescension they faced on their way up.
lead_paragraph: Washington — For over a decade, Allison and Katie Crutchfield have been making music together, on terms of their own making. As teenagers, the twin sisters formed the cheery, poppy punk outfit the Ackleys, and later the more controlled and lyrically ambitious P.S. Eliot. Beginning around five years ago, they began working on their own projects — the confessional Waxahatchee for Katie, the swaggering, now-defunct Swearin’ for Allison — which elevated them from D.I.Y. stalwarts to indie-rock flagbearers.

headline: More Business Travelers Go ‘Rogue,’ Booking on Their Own
abstract: When employees look for lower rates or chase reward points, companies have policies for keeping tabs on their whereabouts and safety.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Diederich, who traveled more than 68,000 miles last year and spent 192 nights in hotels, books his hotel rooms on Priceline.com, on Kayak.com or directly on hotel websites. He tends to book his airline seats on American Airlines’ site.

headline: New Study Offers Support for Prostate Testing
abstract: A new analysis of earlier studies found prostate screening can reduce cancer deaths, but routine screening carries risks.
lead_paragraph: For men who are weighing the pros and cons of prostate cancer screening, a new study strengthens the evidence that testing can reduce deaths from this cancer, something two earlier large landmark clinical trials appeared to reach different conclusions about.

headline: Battered by Harvey, Immigrants in Houston Brace for a DACA Decision
abstract: Some families said their choices about whether to rebuild wrecked homes may depend on whether President Trump ends a program for “Dreamers.”
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Aracely Martinez-Ramirez sat on the driveway by her rotting home, next to most of the family’s possessions, now slated for the trash: Her sisters’ flowered dresses, their baby dolls, a mud-caked Virgin Mary.

headline: Abundant Afghan Harvest Wilts Amid Violence and Extortion
abstract: As bountiful as the fruit is this season, the Taliban and militias defending the government against it have taken a toll on farmers and traders.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Outside the Kabul fruit market, with its roughly 800 shops and stalls, a crowd of sellers and buyers is arriving for another day of activity. This time of year is the peak of the country’s fruit season, and this harvest has been impressive.

headline: Private University in North Korea Reopens Despite Travel Ban
abstract: Pyongyang University of Science and Technology, financed by evangelical Christians abroad, began a new semester without American professors.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The only foreign-funded private university in North Korea started a new semester on Monday, but without its usual American professors because of Washington’s ban on travel to the country, university officials said.

headline: In Flood-Ravaged Houston, Lawmakers Promise Federal Help
abstract: Politicians from both parties stressed urgency in passing relief legislation for areas of Texas and Louisiana hit by Hurricane Harvey.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — At a sprawling convention center-turned-shelter where evacuees from Hurricane Harvey have sought refuge, lawmakers pledged on Monday that Congress would begin voting on disaster relief legislation by midweek.

headline: New Arrests in Israel’s Submarine Scandal, and New Questions on Netanyahu
abstract: The arrest of another once-close associate of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu prompted questions about what he knew, or should have known.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is not a suspect in the so-called  submarine affair, one of the corruption scandals rocking Israel. But with his personal lawyer, the man he appointed as national security adviser, and now his former chief of staff among the expanding parade of suspects, analysts and critics assert that if Mr. Netanyahu did not know what was going on, he should have.

headline: ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label May Shrink for Some Firms Under Trump
abstract: The Trump administration is examining the use of the designation for large non-bank financial institutions, with a closely anticipated Treasury report on the matter expected next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is examining the labeling of large non-bank financial institutions as “too big to fail,” with a closely anticipated Treasury Department report on the initiative expected next month.

headline: The Dastardly Double U
abstract: A rumination in rhyme about a certain subway line.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Traces of Crime: How New York’s DNA Techniques Became Tainted
abstract: The city’s medical examiner has been a pioneer in analyzing complex DNA samples. But two methods were recently discontinued, raising questions about thousands of cases.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the DNA laboratory in the office of New York City’s chief medical examiner emerged as a pioneer in analyzing the most complicated evidence from crime scenes. It developed two techniques, which went beyond standard practice at the F.B.I. and other public labs, for making identifications from DNA samples that were tiny or that contained a mix of more than one person’s genetic material.

headline: How I Keep the Topic of Aging Fresh
abstract: The Times’s New Old Age columnist explains how she approaches writing about the elderly — and the effects her columns have had.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, when I took over as primary writer of a New York Times blog called The New Old Age, I figured I could probably keep it going for three years or so. Then, I’d run out of things to say about aging and caregiving.

headline: J’ouvert Spared Violence Amid Heightened Security Effort
abstract: The police implemented similar security measures used for New Year’s Eve in Times Square, but some attendees groaned that something was lost.
lead_paragraph: J’ouvert has long been a jubilant exclamation of Caribbean identity and pride.

headline: Former C.I.A. Chief John Brennan to Become a Fellow at Fordham
abstract: Mr. Brennan, who received his undergraduate degree from Fordham in 1977, will be a part of the law school’s nonpartisan Center on National Security.
lead_paragraph: John O. Brennan, the former director of the C.I.A., has been named a distinguished fellow for global security at the Fordham University School of Law’s Center on National Security.

headline: In Texas, Distrust of Washington Collides With Need for Federal Aid
abstract: Despite state Republican leaders’ anti-Washington rhetoric, the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey is prompting huge demands for federal flood and relief aid.
lead_paragraph: Few places need the federal government right now more than Texas does, as it begins to recover from Hurricane Harvey. Yet there are few states where the federal government is viewed with more resentment, suspicion and scorn.

headline: Yankees Surge Past Orioles to Remain in the Thick of the Playoff Hunt
abstract: Starlin Castro homered and drove in three runs to lead the Yankees over Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The ruling the Yankees had been bracing for was finally handed down Monday morning — and it was a reprieve of sorts. Gary Sanchez, their starting catcher, had his four-game suspension reduced to three, and although he would have to miss the entire series here against the Baltimore Orioles, the timing could hardly have been better.

headline: The Daily News, a Distinctive Voice in New York, Is Sold
abstract: The paper’s owner, Mortimer Zuckerman, is selling it to Tronc, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune.
lead_paragraph: Tronc, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, announced on Monday that it had acquired The Daily News, the nearly 100-year-old tabloid that for decades set the city’s agenda with its gossip, sports and city coverage.

headline: For U.S., a Tough Spot With Little Room for Error
abstract: After a loss at home in World Cup qualifying, the United States faces a challenging match in Honduras, with the team with which it is tied for third in its group.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — A raucous crowd, encouraged by the declaration of a national holiday and the not-so-remote possibility of a World Cup berth, will not be all that greets the United States soccer team when it steps into Estadio Olímpico for a World Cup qualifying match on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Dreamers’ Find Allies in Trump’s Business World
abstract: Some executives, even if they like the president’s economic policies, are drawing the line at efforts to end a program that shields young immigrants from deportation.
lead_paragraph: As the president of a steel company, David Zalesne said some of the Trump administration’s economic policies are probably going to be good for his industry. President Trump has vowed to bolster American manufacturing — and domestic steel production in particular.

headline: On DACA, President Trump Has No Easy Path
abstract: Delaying a decision on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program would buy the president some breathing room but displease nearly everyone else.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, an anxious and uncertain President Trump was caught between opposing camps in the West Wing prodding him to either scrap or salvage an Obama-era program allowing undocumented immigrants brought to the country as minors to remain in the United States.

headline: No Corrections: September 5, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 5, 2017
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, September 6, 2017.

headline: Bridgewater’s Ray Dalio Dives Deeper Into the ‘Principles’ of Tough Love
abstract: The 68-year-old chairman’s deeply personal new book, “Principles: Life & Work,” explores a workplace culture that he has embraced as “radical transparency.”
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Ray Dalio, the chairman of what is today the largest hedge fund in the world, Bridgewater Associates, received a memo signed by his top three lieutenants that was startlingly honest in its assessment of him.

headline: Trump Faces Deal-Making Challenges as Congress Returns
abstract: As lawmakers return to town, the president faces weeks of hard bargaining on the debt ceiling, his border wall, the tax code, Harvey relief and more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump the deal maker heads into the autumn of his first year in as weak a negotiating position as any president in modern times — desperate for a victory yet hardly near consensus on any major priority, still able to dominate the national conversation but so far incapable of translating that into action.

headline: Even an Early Exit at the U.S. Junior Open Doesn’t Dampen a Burundian’s Trip
abstract: Sada Nahimana, 16, had to take to the road early to find worthy competition. After her visit to New York, she was struck by the shade provided by its buildings.
lead_paragraph: When Sada Nahimana first left her hometown as a young girl to visit her grandmother, she knew immediately that she wanted to see more.

headline: CoCo Vandeweghe’s Hard Work Is Taking Her Further
abstract: Vandeweghe beat Lucie Safarova to make the quarterfinals, her best showing at the U.S. Open. Now 25, she has learned to manage the grind of the tour.
lead_paragraph: CoCo Vandeweghe hopes it is over: the exhausting routine of entering every tournament, of scrambling for qualifying wins, of scrounging for points as she clambered up the slippery rungs of the professional tennis ladder. So many matches. So much potential for burnout.

headline: Hurricane Irma, Now a Category 5 Storm, Threatens the Caribbean and Florida
abstract: The “potentially catastrophic” storm recorded maximum winds near 185 m.p.h. just hours ahead of its expected landfall in the Caribbean on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: For the latest on Hurricane Irma, read this article.

headline: Relationship Problems? Try Getting More Sleep
abstract: Sleep problems not only create relationship problems, they can also make fighting with your partner particularly toxic to your health.
lead_paragraph: It started as a simple conversation about a child’s birthday party. But it quickly escalated into a full-blown marital rift. She accused him of neglecting the family. He said she was yelling.

headline: Amid New York’s Tennis Fusillade, Hope for a Nadal-Federer Showdown
abstract: Rafael Nadal, a grinder, and Roger Federer, a gifted competitor, have never met at the U.S. Open. After Nadal’s fourth-round rout, a potential semifinal looms.
lead_paragraph: To experience a live-action viewing of Rafael Nadal is to be in awe of his sheer effort, the startling expenditure of unbridled energy, even as he fidgets in routinized preparation between points.

headline: United Technologies to Buy Rockwell Collins in $30 Billion Deal
abstract: United Technologies, the corporate parent of Pratt & Whitney, will pay $140 a share in cash and stock in one of the largest deals in aerospace history.
lead_paragraph: United Technologies has agreed to buy the airplane parts maker Rockwell Collins for $30 billion, including debt, establishing an industrial giant and cementing one of the largest deals ever in the aerospace industry.

headline: New Zealand’s Election Had Been Predictable. Then ‘Jacindamania’ Hit.
abstract: After becoming the Labour Party’s youngest leader last month, Jacinda Ardern is disrupting New Zealand’s status quo — and may be the next prime minister.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — No one had expected New Zealand’s Sept. 23 election to be much of a contest. The conservatives were expected to win, again.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Is Pressing for Oil Embargo on North Korea
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 5, 2017
lead_paragraph: “We have kicked the can down the road long enough. There is no more road left.”

headline: On a Break
abstract: Michelle Kenney goes out a chorus girl and comes back a star, ably assisted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of the great joys of living in the New York City area is its proximity to live theater of all kinds, especially Broadway. As the parent of a child in college, the joy of proximity is pretty much all I can afford right now, but I have seen some amazing shows in my time.

headline: Ailing Juan Martín del Potro Makes a Recovery, on the Court
abstract: After being pummeled in the first two sets of his fourth-round match against Dominic Thiem, del Potro, who has been battling illness, advanced to the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: Early in his fourth-round match against Dominic Thiem at the United States Open on Monday, it looked as though Juan Martín del Potro should have been in quarantine instead of on a tennis court.

headline: Models Talk: Racism, Abuse and Feeling Old at 25
abstract: For decades, modeling was the silent profession. But not any longer. In interviews with The New York Times, young women discuss racism, sexual abuse and the fashion industry’s obsession with extreme youth.
lead_paragraph: For decades, modeling was the silent profession. But not any longer. In interviews with The New York Times, young women discuss racism, sexual abuse and the fashion industry’s obsession with extreme youth.

headline: What It’s Truly Like to Be a Fashion Model
abstract: “Every day that you’re working as a model, you’re objectified somehow.” Twelve models, in their own words, on issues like racism, body shaming and financial problems.
lead_paragraph: For decades, modeling was a silent profession, where women were supposed to be seen and never heard.

headline: Lilium, a Flying Car Start-Up, Raises $90 Million
abstract: The fund-raising round for the two-year-old company was led by Tencent Holdings, the Chinese internet giant, and will go toward developing a five-seat vehicle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As interest in flying cars continues to swell, one of the most prominent start-ups working on the technology has gained a big new backer.

headline: Power Station, Storied Manhattan Recording Studio, to Be Revived
abstract: The 33,000-square-foot complex will operate as a commercial studio and as a hub of educational programs for the Boston-based Berklee.
lead_paragraph: New York’s most storied recording studios have been vanishing, victims of more accessible digital recording techniques and escalating real estate prices in Manhattan. First went the Hit Factory, in 2005. Last year, both the Magic Shop — a favorite of David Bowie, who recorded his final album there — and Manhattan Sound Recordings were shuttered.

headline: North Korea, Rohingya, Angela Merkel: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: anemia
abstract: This word has appeared in 50 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘American Horror Story’ and ‘Like Crazy’
abstract: Menacing clowns descend after the 2016 election in “American Horror Story: Cult.” And the romance drama “Like Crazy” arrives on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: Menacing clowns descend on Michigan after the 2016 presidential election in the new season of “American Horror Story.” And the romance drama “Like Crazy” arrives on Netflix.

headline: Tornado Black, Tennis Prodigy, Sidelined by an Operation’s High Cost
abstract: A once-promising star is giving tennis lessons instead of playing professionally because she can’t afford a hip operation.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Four years after she reached the junior singles final at the United States Open, Tornado Alicia Black, once the most promising young female player in the country, moved gingerly on a quiet tennis court behind a set of condominiums, coaching a 10-year-old girl.

headline: Back to School
abstract: How do you feel at the start of the 2017-18 school year? Why?
lead_paragraph: Maybe your school started back in mid-August, or maybe you’re just returning to the classroom this week. But regardless of when it began, how do you feel at the start of the 2017-18 school year? Why?

headline: How to Recognize Burnout Before You’re Burned Out
abstract: Being tired, ambivalent, stressed, cynical and overextended has become a normal part of a working professional life.
lead_paragraph: Emma Seppala was working as an intern at The International Herald Tribune (the past iteration of The International New York Times) one summer in college in Paris, shuttling between the newsroom writers and editors on the second floor and the workers at printing presses in the basement.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Trump Seriously Considering Ending DACA, With 6-Month Delay’
abstract: What is the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program and how many people will be affected if it is discontinued?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: They Worked For America. Now These Afghans Face Violence and Poverty Here.
abstract: Afghans who risked their lives working for the U.S. military were granted safe haven in California. Danger awaited them there as well.
lead_paragraph: Afghans who risked their lives working for the U.S. military were granted safe haven in California. Danger awaited them there as well.

headline: Bill de Blasio, the Best Democratic Choice for Mayor
abstract: With the economy humming and crime way down, the mayor deserves his party’s nomination.
lead_paragraph: With the economy humming and crime way down, the mayor deserves his party’s nomination.

headline: When the Rich Said No to Getting Richer
abstract: With President Trump and Congress turning to tax policy, it’s worth revisiting a story about wealth from another era.
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, a top automobile executive named George Romney — yes, Mitt’s father — turned down several big annual bonuses. He did so, he told his company’s board, because he believed that no executive should make more than $225,000 a year (which translates into almost $2 million today).

headline: Nicole Malliotakis, a Gutsy G.O.P. Challenger
abstract: Whether her message can resonate is in question. But we’re pleased that she is prepared to give her Democratic opponent a lively challenge.
lead_paragraph: As the daughter of a father from Crete (and of a Cuban-born mother), Nicole Malliotakis may be familiar with the Greek myth of Sisyphus, doomed for eternity to push a boulder up a hill, only to have it roll back on him every time. Running as a Republican for citywide office in New York is kind of like that — only maybe more frustrating.

headline: Pondering Voyagers’ Interstellar Journeys, and Our Own
abstract: Forty years ago, we sent two Voyager spacecraft into the cosmos. Will we continue our own journey of discovery?
lead_paragraph: Tempe, Ariz. — Tuesday is the 40th anniversary of the launch of Voyager 1, which, paradoxically, was shot into space two weeks after its partner spacecraft, Voyager 2. With all of the turbulent terrestrial news of late, it may seem like humanity is stuck in the past, dominated by religious wars and racial violence. But pondering the journey of these two small space explorers reminds us of just how far humanity has traveled in just a few decades.

headline: They Worked for America. Now These Afghans Face Violence and Poverty Here.
abstract: Afghans who risked their lives working for the U.S. military were granted safe haven in California. Danger awaited them there as well.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Mustafa Rafi, an Afghan electrical engineer, risked his life working with the U.S. military in his homeland. Because he faced a grave threat from the Taliban, he and his family were relocated to Sacramento in June 2015 thanks to a special immigrant visa.

headline: What Did This Summer Teach You?

lead_paragraph: As this is our first Student Opinion Question of the new school year, the moment is apt to reflect on the summer that just passed.

headline: An Angry Birds Empire: Games, Toys, Movies and Now an I.P.O.
abstract: The listing by the Finnish game maker Rovio would consist of stock from its main shareholder and others, as well as a $36 million share offering.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The digital world is littered with one-hit wonders — companies that tried to turn a single successful brand into a big-time business only to be eclipsed by changing technology and consumer tastes.

headline: The First Time I Met Americans
abstract: Before becoming a novelist, I spent six years at war. Years later, I came to America and finally met my old enemies.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — I first visited the United States in the summer of 1998, when I was invited to attend a literary conference in Montana with four other Vietnamese writers. We flew from Hanoi to Taiwan to Los Angeles. As we crossed the Pacific Ocean, passing through many time zones, I buried myself in sleep and woke up only when the plane hit the tarmac. At passport control, we found ourselves in a huge hall, and I was abruptly taken aback: There were Americans all around us, lots of them! I will never forget that strange feeling. It was bizarre, unbelievable, surreal, that I, a veteran of the Vietnamese People’s Army, was in the United States, surrounded by Americans.

headline: Americans Are Confronting an Alarming Question: Are Many of Our Fellow Citizens ‘Nazis’?
abstract: For decades, we talked about Nazis mostly in analogies, jokes and caricatures. Now we’re debating whether it’s a fair word for describing a good number of our neighbors.
lead_paragraph: One morning in mid-August, Americans woke up in what felt, to some, like an altered country. The week’s most notable political event had begun with hundreds of Americans carrying torches while chanting “Sieg heil” and “Jews will not replace us.” White supremacist radicals like these had been active and energized throughout the presidential campaign, but much of their energy had been restricted to the internet. The rally in Charlottesville was markedly different. It confronted America with an unlikely question: Was it possible the nation was seeing a burgeoning political faction of ... actual Nazis? People we should actually call Nazis?

headline: A Panorama of Steel Drums

lead_paragraph: The rhythm of steel drums signals the approach of the West Indian American Day Parade in central Brooklyn. But rising rents and increasing noise complaints have made it difficult to continue the tradition.

headline: Michigan Gambled on Charter Schools. Its Children Lost.
abstract: Free-market boosters, including Betsy DeVos, promised that a radical expansion of charter schools would fix the stark inequalities in the state’s education system. The results in the classrooms are far more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Toss a dart at a map of Detroit, and the bull’s-eye, more or less, would be a tiny city called Highland Park. Only three square miles, Highland Park is surrounded by Detroit on nearly all sides, but it remains its own sovereign municipality thanks largely to Henry Ford, who started building Model Ts there in 1910. Ford didn’t care for the idea of paying Detroit taxes, so he pressured Highland Park to resist annexation by the larger city. By the end of the decade, his Albert Kahn-designed factory had revolutionized mass production. Five years later, Walter Chrysler started his own car company a few blocks away.

headline: David Hockney, Contrarian, Shifts Perspectives
abstract: Mr. Hockney’s new paintings are riveting in their spatial distortions. A born colorist, he’d rather be a Cubist.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When David Hockney began his career, figurative painting was considered old hat and even retrogressive. The assumption, in advanced circles, was that abstraction was wholly superior, raising large, lofty questions about the essence of painting instead of getting bogged down in the picayune details of postwar life. What possible wisdom could be gleaned from a painting that depicts a palm tree, for instance, or the glistening turquoise of a backyard swimming pool?

headline: Patisserie Chanson’s Dessert Bar Opens in Flatiron District
abstract: The latest from Ravi DeRossi, dim-sum-style Italian in the West Village, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: THE DESSERT BAR AT PATISSERIE CHANSON When the pastry chef Rory Macdonald opened his bakery and cafe last spring, he planned to develop the lower level of the spacious store as a tasting room for desserts and cocktails. It took longer than expected — what doesn’t in the restaurant world? Finally, it’s ready, and just in time for the fall season. The underground space was discovered during the construction of the pastry shop upstairs, and it turns out that it was once a speakeasy, a bit of history that seems to be turning up often these days. It was also a gambling school, and Chanson’s cocktail menu nods to that with drinks like Poker Alice, named for a gambler and mixed with assorted liqueurs. There’s a 16-seat dessert bar, as well as booths and tables, and playing-card motifs on the walls. The six-course dessert tasting, which includes some more savory items, like olive oil gelato with sea salt and eucalyptus to clear the palate, is $68, by reservation for people of drinking age. (Opens Thursday): 20 West 23rd Street, lower level, 929-423-8880, patisseriechanson.com.
