headline: The Very Bad Economics of Killing DACA
abstract: Bad fiscal impact, higher chance of depressions. What’s not to like?
lead_paragraph: Trump’s decision to kill DACA — never mind the attempt to obscure things with that meaningless delay — is, first and foremost, a moral obscenity: throwing out 800,000 young people who are Americans in every way that matters, who have done nothing wrong, basically for racial reasons. But it’s also worth noting that Jeff Sessions just tried to sell it with junk economics, claiming that the Dreamers are taking American jobs. No, they aren’t, even if we leave aside the question of who’s an American. DACA is very much a boon to the rest of the U.S. population, and killing it will make everyone worse off.

headline: Why Onions Make You Cry

lead_paragraph: Trying to figure out why humans cry is exhausting. We cry about death, violence, breakups, abandoned puppies, sweet kisses and words charged with all kinds of meanings. We don’t cry when we should, and we cry for no reason. But let’s take a moment to appreciate the clarity of crying while cutting onions.

headline: Will the Trump Era Transform the School Lunch?

headline: Review: In ‘Spettacolo,’ a Tuscan Town Where All the World’s a Stage
abstract: A documentary about Monticchiello in Italy, where each year the residents put on a play about their most urgent concerns.
lead_paragraph: Some tell their stories in kitchens, warming hands and souls over coffee; others write confessions. For decades, the residents of the tiny Tuscan town of Monticchiello have turned their lives into theater. Each year, they gather to discuss art and their world until they land on a topic that reflects their most recent, urgent concerns. Word by word, they push and pull, challenging one another as they shape a production. All the world’s a stage, but in Monticchiello that truism is movingly real, especially because these days its aging resident-players have more exits than entrances.

headline: Crisis Is Over at Texas Plant, but Chemical Safety Flaws Remain
abstract: Explosions at a chemical plant near Houston have revealed gaps in emergency response and disclosure rules for the chemical industry nationwide.
lead_paragraph: CROSBY, Tex. — Residents have returned to their homes here in the shadow of the Arkema chemical plant now that the fires at the plant are out and the immediate safety hazard has passed.

headline: City Hospital System Is Expanding Children’s Mental Health Programs
abstract: The programs will follow an “integrated care” model, which brings physical health doctors, psychiatrists and community resources together.
lead_paragraph: Recognizing that negative childhood experiences can affect a person’s health long into adulthood, New York City’s public hospital system is expanding its mental health programs for children and adolescents.

headline: Secret Hitler, a Game That Simulates Fascism’s Rise, Becomes a Hit
abstract: A new board game got a boost from a sudden surge of interest in fascism after the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: I was house-sitting for my brother this summer when I saw something suspicious: a box in his living room emblazoned with the words “Secret Hitler.”

headline: Faulkner and Other Ghosts Sing Through Jesmyn Ward’s New Novel
abstract: Ward’s third novel, “Sing, Unburied, Sing,” follows a tender teenager and his drug-addicted mother on a road trip.
lead_paragraph: In his wonderfully cranky Nobel Prize acceptance speech, William Faulkner exhorted his fellow writers to create from the heart, not “the glands.” Address the immortal truths, he instructed: “love and honor and pity and pride and compassion and sacrifice.”

headline: Honoring Harriet Tubman and Other Abolitionists
abstract: A reader decries the Trump administration’s reluctance to put Tubman on the $20. Another urges that statues of abolitionists be erected.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why I’m Resigning From Trump’s Diversity Coalition
abstract: A president who doesn’t believe in the value of America’s Dreamers is not one I can continue to support.
lead_paragraph: Right now in the United States there are some 800,000 law-abiding young people without proper immigration papers who nevertheless proudly call America home. Today President Trump sent them a clear message: They are not welcome here. With its decision to terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which has protected these “Dreamers” since 2012, the administration claims that it is merely insisting that Congress take responsibility for the program. That is a dodge, and a cowardly one. This cruel new policy is also a direct contradiction of the promise that President Trump made to the Hispanic community only months ago.

headline: To Understand It Is to Own It: Sean Scully on Collecting
abstract: The artist isn’t heartbroken by the works he can’t afford; instead, he lines the walls of his inner sanctum with works he simply likes to “feed off.”
lead_paragraph: TAPPAN, N.Y. — The walls of Sean Scully’s art studio in this quiet hamlet are lined with paintings for which he is famous — bars and blocks in muscular, vibrating hues — and others for which he is not: portraits of his son Oisín, now 8, at play on a beach in Eleuthera, the Bahamas.

headline: President Trump, Don’t Forsake the ‘Dreamers’
abstract: Readers praise the children of illegal immigrants who have qualified for DACA. To abolish the program would be cruel and misguided, they say.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Does the Hamptons Garden Grow? With a Lot of Paid Help
abstract: On the East End of Long Island, the professionally planted and tended vegetable garden requires a different kind of green.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The rigors of vegetable gardening, for most people, are humble and gritty: planting, weeding, dirtying knees, working up a sweat and maybe straining a back muscle or two.

headline: The ‘Bright Tomorrow’: Growing Up in the Brezhnev Era
abstract: One thing you learn in a socialist experiment is that equality is not a natural state of the world.
lead_paragraph: I am a grandchild of the revolution. My grandfather, Anatoly Alexandrov, was a Communist who spent his life building the Soviet Union. He traveled a path from working as an unskilled laborer at a locomotive assembly plant in Rostov-on-Don, a large industrial city in southern Russia, to becoming the head of military transportations for the strategic North Caucasian Railroad.

headline: John Ashbery, the Gift of Quiet Moments
abstract: Much of life consists of musing moments when we look at something so beautiful or surprising that we wonder, briefly, who we are. This is the feeling the poet gave his readers.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, when he was nearly 40 and his unorthodox talent was in full bloom, John Ashbery joined his friend Kenneth Koch for a mutual interview commissioned by a small press in Arizona. After a brief tongue-in-cheek discussion of how poems communicate, or don’t, Koch remarked that some uncertainties “enable the reader to escape from his ordinary consciousness of himself,” and suggested that it could be “very enjoyable” to feel like “a person you know nothing about.”

headline: How to Prep for the Front Row, and Beyond
abstract: The blogger and Instagram star Arielle Noa Charnas is no makeup expert, but she’s serious about her hair.
lead_paragraph: With a style that appears effortless, Arielle Noa Charnas, 30, of the blog and Instagram account Something Navy, has been hailed as the Lauren Conrad of the East Coast. Even her social media start is relatable: Ms. Charnas, who grew up in Old Westbury, N.Y., started documenting her looks eight years ago to get over a breakup.

headline: U.S. Open Results: Pablo Carreño Busta and Sloane Stephens Reach Semifinals
abstract: Both players reached their first semifinal at the U.S. Open, taking advantage of depleted fields in their respective brackets.
lead_paragraph: This United States Open has been a tournament packed with opportunities for players like Sloane Stephens and Pablo Carreño Busta. With their paths through their draws drained of star power by injuries and upsets, they have capitalized on what they can control — by winning.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Arsenal Threatens China’s Path to Power
abstract: Beijing has made little secret of its goal to replace the United States as the major power in Asia, but North Korea presents a nettlesome challenge.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The two men stood together on the reviewing stand in the North Korean capital: a top official in China’s Communist leadership wearing a tailored business suit and a young dictator in a blue jacket buttoned to his chin.

headline: China’s Rights Crackdown Is Called ‘Most Severe’ Since Tiananmen Square
abstract: A report by Human Rights Watch outlines moves by China to silence critics, and faults the United Nations for overlooking the country’s abuses.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — China is systematically undermining international human rights groups in a bid to silence critics of its crackdown on such rights at home, a watchdog organization said on Tuesday. The group also faulted the United Nations for failing to prevent the effort, and at times being complicit in it.

headline: Teenager Who Says Police Coerced Witnesses Faces Trial
abstract: Pedro Hernandez, 17, who says he was arrested for a shooting he did not commit, goes on trial on Wednesday in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: As New York City crimes go, the shooting in September 2015 outside a CTown supermarket in the Bronx ranked as a minor event, yet another flash of violence between warring crews of neighborhood youths: The 15-year-old victim, Shaun Nardoni, was hit in the left ankle by a slug that ricocheted off the pavement. He survived, and, as often happens in street conflicts, told the police he did not see who pulled the trigger.

headline: In Houston, a Terrifying Real-Life Lesson for Disaster-Prone Cities
abstract: For cities facing their own kinds of disasters —earthquakes, tornadoes, floods — Houston is providing a real-life, if terrifying, lesson.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Cities across the country that live with the threat of disaster — from earthquakes in San Francisco to hurricanes in Miami — are anxiously watching the catastrophe unfolding in Houston for lessons learned, cautionary tales, anything to soften the blow when their residents are the ones in danger.

headline: On the College Campus of the Future, Parking May Be a Relic
abstract: As they wrestle with parking woes, universities are beginning to consider where transportation is headed, like ride-hailing, car-sharing and driverless vehicles.
lead_paragraph: With just one parking space for every five people, on a campus of roughly 65,000, the University of Wisconsin-Madison has one of the lowest parking ratios of any major university in the country.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $3.2 MILLION

headline: C.E.O.s See a ‘Sad Day’ After Trump’s DACA Decision
abstract: Business leaders objected to President Trump’s decision to end Obama-era protections for children who entered the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, created by President Obama to allow children who entered the United States illegally to remain in the country, spurred reactions through the business community — many of them opposed to the rollback of protections.

headline: Danish Sub Inventor Describes Journalist’s Death to Skeptical Court
abstract: Peter Madsen said Kim Wall had died in an accident on his submarine. A judge called the account “not reasonable” and approved more serious charges.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — He said he was into S-and-M, but not with his submarine passenger. He said she died on board in an accident, and he buried her at sea because that was maritime tradition. And why did he initially lie to the police about what happened? He said he wanted to see his wife and his three cats.

headline: At CNN, Retracted Story Leaves an Elite Reporting Team Bruised
abstract: Created with much fanfare, CNN’s investigative unit was reshaped and its focus narrowed in the wake of a story that led to a retraction and an apology.
lead_paragraph: Late on a Monday afternoon in June, members of CNN’s elite investigations team were summoned to a fourth-floor room in the network’s glassy headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: How to Be a Modern Parent
abstract: Modern parents have the entire internet at their disposal and don’t follow any single authority. It’s hard to know what to trust. In this guide, we’ll talk about how to raise a person you really like, without losing yourself in the process.
lead_paragraph: Modern parents have the entire internet at their disposal and don’t follow any single authority. It’s hard to know what to trust. In this guide, we’ll talk about how to raise a person you really like, without losing yourself in the process.

headline: How to Be a Modern Parent
abstract: Modern parents have the entire internet at their disposal and don’t follow any single authority. It’s hard to know what to trust. In this guide, we’ll talk about how to raise a person you really like, without losing yourself in the process.
lead_paragraph: Modern parents have the entire internet at their disposal and don’t follow any single authority. It’s hard to know what to trust. In this guide, we’ll talk about how to raise a person you really like, without losing yourself in the process.

headline: Boston Red Sox Used Apple Watches to Steal Signs Against Yankees
abstract: When confronted by Major League Baseball, the Red Sox admitted they were using Apple Watches in a scheme to gain an edge at the plate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, spying on another team has been as much a part of baseball’s gamesmanship as brushback pitches and hard slides. The Boston Red Sox have apparently added a modern — and illicit — twist: They used an Apple Watch to gain an advantage against the Yankees and other teams.

headline: North Korea, Myanmar, Vladimir Putin: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: I Went to the Flood Expecting Misery. I Found Humanity.
abstract: I had been warned about looting and price gouging. What I saw was an army of volunteers helping to save a community.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — As I sat in my office complaining about the rain we were having here more than a week ago, I stumbled across a Facebook page run by the Rockport Volunteer Fire Department and the words hit me like a bus. “Fellow First Responders who are willing to go in and help we need certified, capable able-bodied people to come help,” it read. As my wife read the post over my shoulder, she put her hand on me and said, “Be safe down there sweetheart.” She knew I was going.

headline: How to Resolve the North Korea Crisis
abstract: Readers offer their ideas, including a peace treaty, ignoring North Korea’s leader and a huge economic aid package.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Sam Dolnick, Dan Saltzstein and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Heard the One About Jamestown? State Bets Comedy Can Spark a Revival
abstract: New York State officials have invested nearly $10 million in a National Comedy Center, hoping it draws people to a city where the poverty level is around 29 percent.
lead_paragraph: JAMESTOWN, N.Y. — This is not really a funny place.

headline: To View Clyfford Still Retrospective, Just Click
abstract: The website of the Clyfford Still Museum will publish some 450 paintings and 1,750s drawings by the Abstract Expressionist.
lead_paragraph: Among the Abstract Expressionists, Clyfford Still was the un-New Yorker.

headline: Utah Hospital Bars Police From Patient-Care Areas After Nurse Is Handcuffed
abstract: The police are conducting a criminal investigation into the detention of a nurse at the University of Utah Hospital that was captured on video.
lead_paragraph: Police officers will be barred from patient-care areas at a hospital in Utah that drew widespread notice when an officer handcuffed a nurse, hospital officials said this week.

headline: House Tour | Andrea Tognon
abstract: A stroll through the architect’s laid-back live/work space in Milan.
lead_paragraph: A stroll through the architect’s laid-back live/work space in Milan.

headline: What They Saved: Texans Reflect on Treasures Plucked From Harvey
abstract: A photo-booth snapshot, a beloved set of cups, a Turkish rug: After a hurricane, Texans found ways to save valued possessions.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The floodwaters here ruined floors, walls, carpets, furniture, appliances and so much more. And yet the damage caused by Harvey was not total. The towers of debris cluttering the curbs of Houston are a deceptive measure of the storm’s devastation. Some things – small things, personal things – survived.

headline: In a Desolate Corner of Milan, an Unexpected Home
abstract: The architect Andrea Tognon lives and works on a property he got for free, which was once a neglected industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: THE NORTHERN MILAN district of Bicocca is not an obvious inspiration for an architect’s fantasies. Semi-industrial (but not in that noble wrought-iron way), perpetually bedraggled and largely devoid of historical significance, Bicocca is just 20 minutes from fashion’s golden triangle of Via Monte Napoleone, Via della Spiga and Via Sant’Andrea, but it’s as defiantly dour and dazzle-free as that area is refined and lacquered. The district’s signature feature is Borgo Pirelli, an early 20th-century village of red-roofed, low-slung apartment clusters, now used as public housing, built to keep the Pirelli tire factory workers tethered to the nearby assembly line. In 2004, the company turned one of its spaces into a cavernous gallery, HangarBicocca, featuring site-specific, 82-ton Anselm Kiefer installations, but there’s been no Bilbao effect, no open tap of artists streaming in searching for loft space. Change comes slowly in Italy, and the Milanese have never seen much charm in grittiness.

headline: What Trump Told ‘Dreamers’ — Before He Ended DACA
abstract: President Trump is winding down DACA. But Trump and his administration have at times suggested that this wouldn’t happen.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is winding down DACA. But Trump and his administration have at times suggested that this wouldn’t happen.

headline: City to The News: Hang In
abstract: With its new owners focused on pixels, not ink, let’s hope New York’s storied tabloid keeps its brashness in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: By now, it is a cliché to describe The Daily News as the newspaper of New York’s working class. But some clichés come to be because they are essentially true. For nearly a century, The News has taken on the world with sleeves-rolled-up sensibilities and New York brass, even amid nose-pressed-against-the glass ogling of celebrities that is a staple of tabloid journalism.

headline: Lego Will Cut 1,400 Jobs as Profit Dips, Despite Big-Screen Heroics
abstract: The earnings report comes as the company faces an increasingly competitive landscape with more children using mobile devices for entertainment.
lead_paragraph: To hold children’s attention, Lego has enlisted the help of Batman, Darth Vader and Harry Potter. Unfortunately, that does not seem to be enough.

headline: Worried and Frustrated, ‘Dreamers’ Say They Won’t Give Up
abstract: With the Trump administration announcing an end to a program that let them live and work in the United States, many young immigrants expressed renewed insecurity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Safir Wazed, a graduate student born in Bangladesh and raised in California, struggled to focus on his studies. Evelin Salgado, born in Mexico and raised in Tennessee, was ending plans to buy a house and wondering what would happen to her teaching job.

headline: 2 Knicks Stroll Into the Autopub
abstract: Recalling an encounter with two members of New York’s last championship basketball team.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: DACA, North Korea, Rohingya: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
