headline: Escalating Tensions With North Korea Rattle Wall Street
abstract: Investor jitters led to the United States stock market’s worst day in almost three weeks, but Asian markets were mostly unruffled.
lead_paragraph: Nervousness over North Korea and debt ceiling discussions in Washington sent stock indexes sliding on Tuesday to their largest single-day losses in three weeks.

headline: The End of DACA: What We Know and Don’t Know
abstract: The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program will be shut down, raising questions about the effects on 800,000 recipients.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration announced on Tuesday that it would begin phasing out the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program on March 5, 2018.

headline: Bernadette Peters to Replace Bette Midler in ‘Hello, Dolly!’
abstract: Victor Garber will join Ms. Peters, playing the man she fancies, Horace Vandergelder. They will begin performances on Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Bernadette!

headline: A Brutal Competition, Island to Island, in Sweden
abstract: On the Stockholm Archipelago, athletes cover a 46-mile trek that takes them over 26 islands. Rich Roll, who runs a fitness podcast, was one of them.
lead_paragraph: At dawn on Monday, 300 athletes from 24 countries donned wetsuits, swim caps, goggles, hand paddles and running shoes, and dove into the surf off Sandhamn Island, Sweden. (Yes, in their shoes, too.)

headline: United Technologies’ Deal for Rockwell Collins Faces Skepticism
abstract: Investors and customers like Boeing and Airbus questioned the benefits of uniting the two big airplane parts makers.
lead_paragraph: Buying Rockwell Collins for $23 billion — one of the biggest deals in the history of the aerospace industry, uniting two major manufacturers — was meant to be a crowning achievement for United Technologies.

headline: A Typical ‘Dreamer’ Lives in Los Angeles, Is From Mexico and Came to the U.S. at 6 Years Old
abstract: There are roughly 800,000 current beneficiaries of the DACA program. Here’s who they are.
lead_paragraph: There are roughly 800,000 current beneficiaries of the DACA program. Here’s who they are.

headline: Murray Lerner, Who Filmed Music’s Biggest Stars, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Lerner’s documentaries about the Newport Folk Festival and the Isle of Wight Festival captured performances by Bob Dylan, the Who and more.
lead_paragraph: Murray Lerner, whose documentaries captured some of the world’s greatest folk and rock musicians in era-defining performances, died on Saturday at his home in Long Island City, Queens. He was 90.

headline: Touting Record as Mayor, de Blasio Laments His Lack of Acclaim
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has sounded a tone that is both self-aggrandizing and self-pitying as he appears headed toward an easy re-election this year.
lead_paragraph: Poor Bill de Blasio — so good at being mayor and so misunderstood.

headline: German Police Uncover $3 Million Art Heist, Including Baselitz Work
abstract: The police in Munich said that they have recovered 15 of 19 works of art stolen from the personal collection of the artist Georg Baselitz.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The boisterous sculptures and strident upside-down paintings of the Neo-Expressionist Georg Baselitz are known the world over. But when more than $3 million worth of works from his personal collection, including some he had created, disappeared from a German storage depot, it took months before anyone noticed.

headline: Satellite Images of North Korea Show Landslides at Nuclear Test Site
abstract: Analysts writing for the website 38 North said the disturbances were more numerous and widespread than those observed after previous tests.
lead_paragraph: Analysts peering at satellite images of North Korea after the latest nuclear test reported Tuesday that they had spotted many landslides and wide disturbances at the country’s test site, in the North’s mountainous wilds. Tunnels for the nuclear blasts are deep inside Mount Mantap, a mile-high peak.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gardening With a Checkbook
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 6, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “God has given you too much money when you have someone else tend your vegetable garden.”

headline: For Daily News, a Publisher From Its Past Faces Digital Future
abstract: Tronc, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, is taking over the New York tabloid, giving Tronc newspapers in the nation’s three largest markets.
lead_paragraph: The world has changed since the last time one of New York’s legendary tabloids was controlled by the company that owns The Chicago Tribune.

headline: Two Trump Children Escape the Traditional Spectacle as School Begins
abstract: Barron and Tiffany Trump have been afforded breathing room while starting school in the Washington area. Not all first children have had it so easy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In this age of smartphones and a politically divided public, President Trump’s two youngest children have managed the nearly impossible: They’ve turned up on their respective school campuses without the traditional news media and security brouhaha that surrounds the first day of school for a commander in chief’s child.

headline: Trump Chooses Sessions, Longtime Foe of DACA, to Announce Its Demise
abstract: The president has expressed conflicting emotions about those who were brought to the country as children, but Attorney General Jeff Sessions expressed no such qualms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As an up-and-coming politician in Alabama, Jeff Sessions watched as his state’s poultry industry illegally hired Mexican and Central American immigrants to jobs that had once been filled by poor, unskilled American workers. As a senator, Mr. Sessions argued that displaced American workers like these — not the people replacing them — deserved compassion.

headline: After 16 Futile Years, Congress Will Try Again to Legalize ‘Dreamers’
abstract: President Trump gave Congress six months to pass legislation protecting young, undocumented immigrants that lawmakers have not been able to pass for 16 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For 16 years, advocates for legalizing young immigrants brought here illegally by their parents have tried to pass legislation to shield them from deportation. The bill was called the Dream Act, and in Congresses Democratic and Republican, and in the Bush and Obama administrations, whether by stand-alone bill or comprehensive immigration legislation, it failed again and again.

headline: Nafta Talks Lurch Ahead Without Signs of Major Progress
abstract: Negotiators for the United States, Canada and Mexico concluded the second round of Nafta talks, saying they were moving ahead but providing few details.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement sputtered forward on Tuesday as officials from the United States, Canada and Mexico concluded their second round of talks with plenty of pleasantries but little major progress to announce.

headline: Lucasfilm Will Get New Director for ‘Star Wars: Episode IX’
abstract: Colin Trevorrow will no longer direct the film, to be released in May 2019. It is the latest in a string of shake-ups involving the lucrative series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ejecting directors from its movie galaxy is starting to become a regular occurrence for Lucasfilm, which said on Tuesday that Colin Trevorrow would no longer direct the ninth chapter in the “Star Wars” saga.

headline: Donald Trump’s Cowardice on ‘Dreamers’
abstract: So that the president can make a political point, 800,000 people face deportation.
lead_paragraph: President Trump didn’t even have the guts to do the job himself. Instead, he hid in the shadows and sent his attorney general, Jeff Sessions, to do the dirty work of telling the country that the administration would no longer shield from deportation 800,000 young undocumented immigrants brought to this country as children.

headline: Hurricane Irma, Packing 185-M.P.H. Winds, Makes Landfall in Caribbean
abstract: Among the most powerful storms recorded in the Atlantic Ocean, the storm arrived in the islands with 185 m.p.h. winds, with the eye passing over Barbuda as it headed toward Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to our live updates.

headline: U.S. Snatches Tie in Honduras, Saving World Cup Campaign
abstract: Bobby Wood scored a tying goal in the 85th minute, which could ultimately prove vital in the Americans’ effort to reach the 2018 tournament in Russia.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — When the Honduran goalkeeper Luis López dove and punched Kellyn Acosta’s free kick up in the air in the 85th minute, Matt Besler used the outside of his foot — the only part that would have kept the ball in play — to flick it back across the goal mouth.

headline: John Ashbery’s Avoidance of the Easy
abstract: He was probably the most famous living American poet, yet his poems offer no comfortable affirmations.
lead_paragraph: The poet John Ashbery once said, “To be a famous American poet is not the same thing as being famous.”

headline: Federer and Nadal Have Never Met in New York, but Have Come Close
abstract: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, who have played 37 times in 14 cities, could square off in the U.S. Open semifinals Friday.
lead_paragraph: They have played four times in Miami, three times in Indian Wells, Calif., and once in Cincinnati. They have also found each other four times at the calendar’s first hardcourt Grand Slam event, the Australian Open.

headline: Trump May Make Congress Decide Future of Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Frustrated certifying Iran’s compliance with a deal he abhors, President Trump may kick the decision to Congress, forcing a debate few there want to have.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the midst of a nuclear crisis with North Korea, the Trump administration signaled on Tuesday that it is paving the way for a simultaneous standoff with Iran, suggesting it could refuse to certify that Tehran is complying with the 2015 nuclear accord. But the administration could leave it up to Congress to decide whether to withdraw from the deal.

headline: The Ancient Yankees-Red Sox Rivalry Gets a High-Tech Boost
abstract: At Fenway Park, an Apple Watch is at the center of accusations that the Red Sox stole signs when they played their most bitter rival.
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought musty old Fenway Park, the 105-year-old dowager of the Back Bay, would be a battleground for technological espionage?

headline: Man Tied to Cinder Block and Dumped in Water Was Son of Mob Associate
abstract: The body of Carmine Carini, 35, was found floating in Mill Basin in Brooklyn. The police do not yet know why he was killed.
lead_paragraph: A man whose body was found tied to a cinder block and floating near a dock over the weekend in Brooklyn was the son of a Mafia associate, the police said Tuesday.

headline: Brazilian Corruption Case Ensnares Ex-Presidents da Silva and Rousseff
abstract: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, convicted in another case, and Dilma Rousseff, who faces charges for the first time, are accused of helping to collect millions in bribes.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s attorney general on Tuesday charged former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva; his successor, Dilma Rousseff; and several other senior figures of the Workers’ Party with running a “criminal organization” that raked in hundreds of millions in bribes during the party’s nearly 14-year reign.

headline: One-Named Swedish Singer
abstract: Daniel Raymon, a priest, a rabbi and a minister...
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hi intrepid solvers, Martin here again. Deb is off on another boondoggle — I mean assignment — and she’s once again desperate enough to have me mind the store. Remind me to clean up any messes before she gets back.

headline: Upon Reflection, Mets Won’t Start Matt Harvey on Short Rest
abstract: The team thought about playing Harvey, their injury-plagued starter, on Wednesday, but it reconsidered following Tuesday’s loss to the Phillies.
lead_paragraph: For most of Tuesday, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, Manager Terry Collins and the team’s pitching coach, Dan Warthen, all seemed to be of the same mind — that it would be beneficial for Matt Harvey to start Wednesday’s game against the Philadelphia Phillies, even though he would be doing so on short rest.

headline: Corrections: September 6, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 6, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Yankees Gain a Measure of Satisfaction in Red Sox’ Embarrassment
abstract: The team was already aware that Boston had used electronics to steal its signs, which is against league rules. So there was little surprise in the clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Yankees have been trying to catch the Boston Red Sox in the American League East standings for over a month. But they have already caught them cheating.

headline: A Resurgent Venus Williams Advances Past a Valiant Opponent
abstract: Williams became the oldest woman to reach a semifinal in the U.S. Open after defeating Petra Kvitova.
lead_paragraph: Though there were two sentimental journeys worth cheering for on Tuesday night at the United States Open, only one could continue.

headline: Longtime Trump Aide Said to Have Plans to Leave the White House
abstract: Keith Schiller, who has been Donald J. Trump’s bodyguard since 2004 and is the head of Oval Office operations, has told friends that he dislikes being in the White House.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump traveled to Iowa before the caucuses, Keith Schiller was by his side. When Mr. Trump wanted to eject a Univision reporter from a news conference, he merely glanced at Mr. Schiller and it happened. And when Mr. Trump spent his first few weeks as president in virtual solitude in the White House residence, Mr. Schiller eased his loneliness.

headline: Is It New York Fashion Week? Or Is It Rihanna Inc.?
abstract: As some major designers decide not to show in New York, aesthetics face off against Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Is New York Fashion Week, which officially begins Thursday but actually begins Wednesday (thank you, Tom Ford), a dead duck? Is it a sinking ship, in the soup, up the creek? Is it — gasp! — over?

headline: Raf Simons Knows What America Needs
abstract: The newly reopened Calvin Klein store on Madison Avenue is both soothing and stimulating.
lead_paragraph: The three floors of the newly renovated Calvin Klein store on Madison Avenue are painted yellow, the kind of color saturation that makes a room an environment.

headline: Lasker Prizes Go to Planned Parenthood and Developers of HPV Vaccine
abstract: The prestigious awards come during a time of uncertainty for reproductive health care in the United States.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s most prestigious prizes in medicine will go to Planned Parenthood and two scientists who played a crucial role in developing the vaccine to combat HPV, a sexually transmitted virus that can cause cervical cancer. A third honor will go to a Swiss molecular biologist, who made a groundbreaking discovery about cell growth.

headline: ‘Dreamers,’ Irma, Vladimir Putin: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘I’m Sorry’ and ‘Funeral Directors: Dead Good Job’
abstract: Andrea Savage checks her biological clock in the season finale of her autobiographical comedy. And a documentary series on funeral directors comes to Britbox.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Savage checks her biological clock in the season finale of her autobiographical comedy. And a documentary series on Britain’s funeral directors comes to Britbox.

headline: Word + Quiz: ursine
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Unisex Clothing
abstract: A British department store chain has moved toward gender-neutral labeling of its clothing. Is this a good idea, or not?

headline: Louvre Abu Dhabi Will (Finally) Open in November
abstract: After significant delays, the Jean Nouvel-designed museum in the United Arab Emirates is finally scheduled to open.
lead_paragraph: It has long seemed like the project that would never be completed: The Louvre Abu Dhabi, announced in 2007, has had an opening date that kept getting delayed, from 2012 to 2013 to 2015 and beyond.

headline: Manny Machado’s 9th-Inning Homer Ends the Yankees’ Long Night on a Sour Note
abstract: Machado hit a two-run, game-ending home run off Dellin Betances with two out, dealing the Yankees a setback in their attempt to catch the Red Sox in the A.L. East.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Dellin Betances was just one pitch away from a save and a win for the Yankees on Tuesday night. But unfortunately for Betances, and the Yankees, he had to throw that pitch to Manny Machado, one of the hottest hitters in baseball.

headline: Ruin and Reinvention in a Transforming Brooklyn
abstract: In “Brooklyn Photographs,” a group show at BRIC Arts, 11 photographers showcase the tension between old and new in Brooklyn’s changing neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: In “Brooklyn Photographs,” a group show at BRIC Arts, 11 photographers showcase the tension between old and new in Brooklyn’s changing neighborhoods.

headline: How Local Housing Regulations Smother the U.S. Economy
abstract: Americans can’t afford to move to the cities with strong job markets like New York, San Francisco and Boston.
lead_paragraph: If you live in a coastal city like New York, Boston or San Francisco, you know that the cost of housing has skyrocketed. This housing crisis did not happen by chance: Increasingly restrictive land-use regulations in the last half-century contributed to it.

headline: The Apostle to the Media
abstract: Michael Cromartie and the arc of evangelical history.
lead_paragraph: When a public person you know and care for dies too soon, there is a temptation to elevate their historical significance, to cast them as an era’s representative figure in order to persuade easily distracted readers to pay closer attention to the life they lived.

headline: The Ivanka Trump Guarantee
abstract: Stop wondering which of these people will save us. There is not going to be a surprise silver lining to this presidency.
lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump, first daughter, strode into Washington back in January with big promises: She was passionate about helping “working women,” she said, and she was going to close the gender wage gap even if it killed her.

headline: An Incoherent Strategy on North Korea
abstract: President Trump’s approach to the North’s nuclear plans has produced no results and sowed confusion about his intentions.
lead_paragraph: The North Korean nuclear threat is worsening by the day. Tougher economic sanctions have not accomplished much, if anything. Nor has President Trump’s bellicosity. Sunday’s nuclear test was the North’s most powerful blast in the 11 years it has been detonating nuclear weapons. There are signs of another test soon.

headline: The Way to Make North Korea Back Down
abstract: Threats of American military action are empty bluster. But money talks.
lead_paragraph: After Sunday’s nuclear test, the most powerful yet, and two successful intercontinental missile tests in July, North Korea can credibly threaten to nuke a major United States city and kill millions of Americans. To date, the Trump administration, frustrated by its misplaced hopes of Chinese cooperation to restrain Pyongyang, has been reduced to empty bluster, while others, including a senior official in the previous administration, are resigned to living with a nuclear-armed regime on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Can We Talk About Tom Brady’s Brain?
abstract: If we objectified football players less, maybe we’d protect them better.
lead_paragraph: Another pro football season is about to begin, Tom Brady will again be taking snaps for the New England Patriots, and there’s chatter galore about how much longer that can last. He turned 40 on Aug. 3. In quarterback years, he’s a fossil.

headline: Neo-Nazis in Your Streets? Send in the (Coup Clutz) Clowns
abstract: When it comes to frustrating bigots who want to stir up violence in the streets, well-targeted humor can do the job better than violent resistance.
lead_paragraph: In Olympia, Wash., in 2005, a march of about a dozen brown-shirted neo-Nazis was met by protesting clowns, goose-stepping, Nazi-style. Hundreds of counterprotesters turned the occasion into a celebration of diversity and unity.

headline: Dream of Obamacare Replacement Fades to Bipartisan Patch Job
abstract: Congress is having its first bipartisan Obamacare hearings in years. It may agree only on thwarting the president.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Senate will do something it hasn’t done in seven years: hold bipartisan hearings on the future of the Affordable Care Act. Serious and creative ideas will be presented.

headline: E.U. Countries Must Accept Their Share of Migrants, Court Rules
abstract: With many European Union member states lukewarm about taking in migrants, Hungary and Slovakia stood out by trying to overturn a quota system in court.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union won an important victory on Wednesday in its fractured effort to deal with the huge wave of migration that began in 2015, as the bloc’s top court ruled that Hungary and Slovakia were obligated to accept migrants under a contentious quota system.

headline: Ruin and Reinvention in a Transforming Brooklyn
abstract: In “Brooklyn Photographs,” a group show at BRIC Arts, 11 photographers showcase the tension between old and new in Brooklyn’s changing neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: In a generation, Brooklyn has gone from being the Borough of Homes and Churches to the Land of Hipsters and High-Rises. Neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Bushwick went from ruin to reinvention, with gleaming towers and millennial-friendly hotspots. Even East New York, once the city’s homicide capital, is being touted as a hot neighborhood as real estate speculators swoop in for bargains.

headline: Intel’s $1.3 Billion Fine in Europe Requires Review, Court Says
abstract: The Court of Justice of the European Union is sending the case back to a lower court, a decision that bodes well for technology companies facing competition inquiries.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The highest court in the European Union ruled on Wednesday that Intel’s $1.3 billion antitrust fine get a second look, a decision that could ease some of the legal pressure that American tech giants face in the region.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘A Baby Wails, and the Adult World Comes Running’
abstract: Why do adults come running when a baby cries?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Colbert Says Trump Should Punish His Own Children, Not the ‘Dreamers’
abstract: Mr. Colbert jabbed President Trump for issuing a statement saying that he did “not favor punishing children.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: U.S. Open Results: Kevin Anderson Beats Sam Querrey to Reach Semifinals
abstract: Twenty-eighth-seeded Anderson beat 17th-seeded Sam Querrey. He will face 12th-seeded Pablo Carreño Busta in the semifinals on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The towering Kevin Anderson took advantage of an even bigger opportunity, beating 17th-seeded Sam Querrey, 7-6(5), 6-7(9), 6-3, 7-6(7), in a quarterfinal match that began Tuesday night at the United States Open and ended at 1:51 a.m.

headline: Billy Eichner Wants You to Know He’s Mainstream
abstract: The actor and comedian on how journalists mess up interviews and the similarities between his “Billy on the Street” character and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: You star in ‘‘Difficult People’’ and ‘‘American Horror Story’’ this season, but I know you from ‘‘Billy on the Street,’’ your interview game show. I’m always nervous interviewing people who are interviewers. How has it changed you? It has made me much more sympathetic to all those Greenpeace people. I will always take your flier, because I know what it’s like.

headline: Is Sex With a Brain-Damaged Man Assault?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on sexual consent among the cognitively disabled and the use of robo texts.
lead_paragraph: There is a man in our congregation who suffered a head injury in an accident. He is now permanently cognitively damaged. He lives in his own home with helpers. He has difficulty speaking and says that he has greater difficulty understanding what is said to him. When I write ‘‘says,’’ it sounds as though he speaks normally and conveys his meaning in normal sentences. He doesn’t.

headline: Would You Like to Be a Fashion Model?
abstract: What do fashion models themselves say about the work they do?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever dreamed about being a fashion model?

headline: Le Grand Aioli Brings Everyone to the Table
abstract: The dish combines the bounty of the garden with a bracing garlic mayonnaise.
lead_paragraph: Some could see it as ill timed that just as you are giving the porch a final sweep and nailing shut the screen doors of summer, this perfect, languid, lavish alfresco meal — the kind pitched in food magazines back in June — pulls up the driveway, windows down, honking its horn. You might frown: Summer’s over, you loon. Back to work! Back to school!

headline: A Funeral of 2 Friends: C.I.A. Deaths Rise in Secret Afghan War
abstract: The number of C.I.A. deaths in Afghanistan rivals those killed in the Southeast Asia conflicts of nearly a half-century ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a sweltering day earlier this summer, operatives with the Central Intelligence Agency gathered at Arlington National Cemetery to bury two of their own. Brian Ray Hoke and Nathaniel Patrick Delemarre, elite gunslingers who worked for the C.I.A.’s paramilitary force, were laid to rest after a firefight with Islamic State militants near Jalalabad in Afghanistan, close to the border with Pakistan.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: CPR Training
abstract: First aid frames the world as an unpredictable set of chances to do your modest best.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of summer, as I prepared to teach a seven-week writing workshop to 35 teenagers, I received a frightening email from my boss. Before class started, this email informed me, I had to pass a basic CPR-and-first-aid class. My first thought was, simply, Oh, no. Second thought: Maybe it’s not really required. (I Googled: It was.) Third thought — admittedly, more of a question, charged from within by a hot embarrassment that bordered on shame — What if I pass out?

headline: The Resegregation of Jefferson County
abstract: What one Alabama town’s attempt to secede from its school district tells us about the fragile progress of racial integration in America.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, a flier began making the rounds in Gardendale, Ala., a suburb of Birmingham. On it, a blond white girl wearing a red backpack and knee-high socks peered innocently at a question hanging above her head: “Which path will Gardendale choose?” Beside her was a list of communities in Jefferson County — Pleasant Grove, Center Point/Huffman, Adamsville/Forestdale, Hueytown — under the heading: “Places that chose NOT to form their own school system.” Below that was a list of four communities — Homewood, Hoover, Vestavia Hills, Trussville — that did form their own school systems and were “listed as some of the best places to live in the country.”

headline: The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy
abstract: Novels, graphic and otherwise, about the world at war, life with no future and imagined universes.
lead_paragraph: Ann Leckie’s latest space romp, PROVENANCE (Orbit, $26), isn’t really a space opera in the same way as the award-winning Imperial Radch trilogy that made her famous. It might be tempting, therefore, to insist that comparisons are unfair. Yet they’re also unavoidable — largely because, even though “Provenance” centers on non-Radchaai societies, it is effectively a sequel. Now that a treaty has been established between the empire and the enigmatic, violent, technologically superior Presger, countless planets breathe easier. But the peace will last only so long as the “civilized” races of the universe actually act civilized.

headline: Mikhail Gorbachev Brought Democracy to Russia and Was Despised for It
abstract: William Taubman’s definitive new biography, “Gorbachev,” describes a leader who was celebrated abroad, reviled at home.
lead_paragraph: GORBACHEV His Life and Times By William Taubman Illustrated. 852 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $39.95.

headline: In Praise of the Black Men and Women Who Built Detroit
abstract: In “Black Detroit,” Herb Boyd celebrates the city’s rich history through its unsung heroes.
lead_paragraph: BLACK DETROITA People’s History of Self-DeterminationBy Herb BoydIllustrated. 416 pp. Amistad/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

headline: Life on Mars: An Interplanetary Marriage
abstract: Six people are living in isolation for eight months on a volcano in Hawaii as part of a NASA-funded study to simulate human exploration of Mars. In the sixth episode of this 360-video series, we observe the challenges of an interplanetary marriage.
lead_paragraph: Six people are living in isolation for eight months on a volcano in Hawaii as part of a NASA-funded study to simulate human exploration of Mars. In the sixth episode of this 360-video series, we observe the challenges of an interplanetary marriage.

headline: Paul Ryan to Speak With The Times on Congress’s Packed Agenda
abstract: A crushing September agenda could determine whether Republicans deliver on any of their big promises, including a tax overhaul, before next year’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan will participate on Thursday in a TimesTalks conversation with The New York Times, moderated by Jonathan Weisman, the Times’s congressional editor.

headline: Trump Bypasses Republicans to Strike Deal on Debt Limit and Harvey Aid
abstract: The president sided with Democratic leaders in agreeing to extend government funding and raise the debt ceiling until December, setting up a year-end showdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump struck a deal with Democratic congressional leaders on Wednesday to increase the debt limit and finance the government until mid-December, blindsiding his own Republican allies as he reached across the aisle to resolve a major dispute for the first time since taking office.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Politics: Liberal, With One Big Exception
abstract: A new Stanford study found that the nation’s tech elite are extremely liberal on most issues — except when it comes to regulation.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has long preferred to remain aloof from national politics, but the Trump era has altered that stance.

headline: We Wanted a Carefree Family Trip. So We Invited a Second Family.
abstract: A trip to New Orleans with friends fails to recapture the footloose feeling of life before toddlers. But it did make memories and save money.
lead_paragraph: It was Friday night at Bacchanal, a lusty backyard wine shop, open-air restaurant and performance stage deep in a postindustrial corner of New Orleans’s Bywater neighborhood, a levee away from the muddy Mississippi. I drank wine and flirted with a handsome man as a jazz quartet played and a warm wind shook the flowering trees overhead. The man was my husband and the semitropical air was weighted with expectation. This was a rare opportunity.

headline: On Mulberry Street, a Violent Sort of Homecoming for a Little Italy Native
abstract: The police said Frank Caserta, after serving a long prison sentence for murder, returned to his old neighborhood and his old ways.
lead_paragraph: Many Italian-Americans have long bristled at their tribe’s portrayal in popular culture as consisting primarily of Mafia bosses, thugs, goons and Frank Sinatra. The Mulberry Street Bar in Little Italy is not actively courting the business of those progressive sorts.

headline: Plunging His Pen Into the Dark Heart of 1980s Wall Street
abstract: With “Junk,” the Pulitzer-winning playwright Ayad Akhtar examines financial chicanery in the 1980s — and how it shaped the blind worship of affluence today.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 7, Ayad Akhtar, the son of two doctors in suburban Milwaukee, was seized by a religious fervor. He began asking his parents to take him to the one mosque in the area, a converted schoolhouse on the city’s Polish south side that they only occasionally attended. He taught himself to pray, and he saw the Prophet Muhammad in his dreams. One year, on the day in the calendar when some Muslims say all of creation bowed in respect to Muhammad, he stayed up all night, looking out his bedroom window and waiting to see the trees bend. “I don’t know why, but I was a very sensitive kid. I had an acute awareness of splendor,” Mr. Akhtar told me in one of the conversations we had over the summer. “The only thing that really responded to that register of life for me was the Quran — and ‘Star Wars.’”

headline: Into the Deluge: Stories from Harvey
abstract: As Harvey's rains bore down on Texas, a 911 dispatcher and a pastor's daughter felt nature at its fiercest — and saw humanity at its best.
lead_paragraph: As Harvey's rains bore down on Texas, a 911 dispatcher and a pastor's daughter felt nature at its fiercest — and saw humanity at its best.

headline: The Storm Reaches Puerto Rico: ‘There Is Nothing Like This’
abstract: We followed the news from the Caribbean on Wednesday as the hurricane battered islands like Barbuda, Antigua and French territories.
lead_paragraph: This is Wednesday’s storm coverage. Read the latest with Friday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.

headline: Hurricane Irma, DACA, Boston Red Sox: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘The Daily’: Where Did DACA Come From?
abstract: We discuss the origins and significance of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program with Cecilia Muñoz, former President Barack Obama’s chief domestic policy adviser.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Fitness May Lower Breast Cancer Risk
abstract: In a new study, rats with low natural fitness were about four times as likely to develop breast cancer as those with high fitness.
lead_paragraph: Aerobic fitness seems to alter the interior workings of cells in ways that may substantially lower the risk of breast cancer.

headline: How to Be Mindful When Running
abstract: When we reconnect to the world with our feet, we can experience a powerful shift in mental and emotional states.
lead_paragraph: “Movement is medicine. When we reconnect to the world with our feet, we can experience a powerful shift in mental and emotional states. Deeply therapeutic, mindful running simply offers a return to the real world from which we so often find ourselves adrift.” – William Pullen, a psychotherapist and founder of Dynamic Running Therapy.

headline: New York Today: DACA and New Yorkers
abstract: Wednesday: Changes to an immigration protection law, a discussion with Carl Zimmer, and a women’s convention.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this wet Wednesday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Intel Scores a Victory in Europe
abstract: A mandated re-examination of a $1.3 billion fine against the chip maker is a blow to Europe’s tough stance against American technology giants.
lead_paragraph: Intel has won a point in its antitrust battle with the European Commission — and the American technology industry as a whole may be feeling a little victorious as well.

headline: Prominent Republicans Urge Supreme Court to End Gerrymandering
abstract: The politicians filed briefs asking the justices to protect democracy by declaring unconstitutional the practice involving the drawing of voting districts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Breaking ranks with many of their fellow Republicans, a group of prominent politicians filed briefs on Tuesday urging the Supreme Court to rule that extreme political gerrymandering — the drawing of voting districts to give lopsided advantages to the party in power — violates the Constitution.

headline: Putin Rejects Cutting Off Oil to North Korea
abstract: In a meeting with South Korea’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said an oil embargo would hurt the people of North Korea more than its leadership.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said his country opposed cutting off oil supplies to North Korea as part of new sanctions being considered in the wake of the country’s latest nuclear test, according to official accounts of his meeting Wednesday with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea.

headline: High Levels of Carcinogen Found in Houston Area After Harvey
abstract: Air sampling near a Valero Energy refinery in the Manchester district showed elevated levels of benzene, which has been linked to health problems.
lead_paragraph: High levels of the carcinogen benzene were detected in a Houston neighborhood close to a Valero Energy refinery, local health officials said Tuesday, heightening concerns over potentially hazardous leaks from oil and gas industry sites damaged by Hurricane Harvey.

headline: Trump Gifts From Saudi Arabia: Tiger Fur Robes and Chiffon Dresses
abstract: The president received more than 80 gifts from Saudi Arabia, some of them extravagant. But diplomatic gift-giving is not unusual, a former official said.
lead_paragraph: When he was a presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump took a hard line against Saudi Arabia, criticizing its human rights record and slamming his opponent, Hillary Clinton, for the donations her family foundation received from the country.

headline: The Dreamers Need a Vote, Not Talk
abstract: Members of Congress offer warm words for the Dreamers. The words are meaningless unless Congress acts.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: ‘A Doll’s House, Part 2’ Is Closing on Broadway
abstract: Although it is closing early, the play, which opened April 27, has enjoyed a longer run than many other nonmusical productions.
lead_paragraph: “A Doll’s House, Part 2,” an ambitious and much-admired sequel to the classic Ibsen play, will close on Broadway on Sept. 24.

headline: No, Hurricane Irma Won’t Be a ‘Category 6’ Storm
abstract: There is no such thing as Category 6, and there won’t be, even for a storm like Irma that threatens to break Atlantic hurricane records.
lead_paragraph: You may have seen it circulating online: a big, bold headline warning that Hurricane Irma is on track to become a “Category 6” storm.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Near Completion of Missile-Defense System
abstract: North Korea’s nuclear detonation over the weekend spurred the deployment of the rest of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense, which is designed to stop missiles from the North.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States military plans to complete the deployment of an advanced missile-defense system in South Korea on Thursday, days after North Korea detonated what it called a missile-delivered hydrogen bomb in an underground nuclear test, the South Korean Defense Ministry said.

headline: Bad News, World: China Can’t Solve the North Korea Problem
abstract: The oft-repeated idea that China can rein in Pyongyang is based on assumptions that have not held up well in recent years.
lead_paragraph: After each North Korean provocation, a soothing mantra echoes through the halls of government and think tanks in the United States.

headline: California Today: Going to the Mat Over DACA
abstract: Wednesday: California leaders condemn the DACA decision, an update on the Oroville Dam, and rescuing Texas animals after the flood.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Living in ... Alphabet City
abstract: Does change spell gentrification in Alphabet City?
lead_paragraph: Does change spell gentrification in Alphabet City?

headline: 20 Years of Covering Checks and Balances
abstract: The Times’s new congressional editor is hardly new to covering Congress.
lead_paragraph: As Congress returns this week from its summer recess, Washington and its press corps are stirring from what has been a fitful August slumber. It will be a busy fall, just as it was in 1998, when I became the congressional correspondent for The Baltimore Sun as a new name entered the political conversation: Monica Lewinsky.

headline: U2 Offers ‘Songs of Experience’ to a World That’s on Fire
abstract: After putting the band’s new album on pause to absorb the “shock” of the elections, the group is returning with songs that present joy as defiance.
lead_paragraph: Back in March 2016, U2 was in Killiney, a luxurious seaside suburb of Dublin, immersed in sessions for the follow-up to its 2014 album “Songs of Innocence.” The band had rented a white Victorian mansion and outfitted it as a recording studio, with equipment set up in the bay-windowed parlor so the band — Bono, the Edge on guitar, Adam Clayton on bass and Larry Mullen Jr. on drums — could jam together.

headline: Review: ‘It’ Brings Back Stephen King’s Killer Clown
abstract: This new, updated adaptation follows a bunch of kids on the trail of an evil force.
lead_paragraph: Late in the summer of 1989, the marquee of the downtown movie theater in Derry, Me., advertises “A Nightmare on Elm Street 5.” This is an accurate period detail, and also a declaration of kinship, if not outright homage. “It,” Andy Muschietti’s adaptation of the novel by Stephen King, belongs in the same tradition of small-town terror as Wes Craven’s “Nightmare” franchise, though the question of influence has a certain chicken-and-egg quality. Pennywise the clown, the designated predator in “It,” (played by Bill Skarsgard) is, like Freddy Krueger, an avatar of deep childhood fears. And like Freddy, he’s also the literal, lethal manifestation of the evil of the world. As such, he has the potential to spawn endless sequels. He’ll be back.

headline: Living In: Alphabet City
abstract: Does change spell gentrification in Alphabet City?
lead_paragraph: In Alphabet City, a stylishly scruffy part of Manhattan’s East Village, civic pride sometimes comes with a dose of gallows humor.

headline: Pacific Northwest Fires Smother Region in Smoke and Ash
abstract: Dozens of blazes burning across Oregon and Washington have tainted the air and sent ash raining down on urban centers.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of wildfires that have been raging across the Pacific Northwest flared up this week, unfurling a blanket of opaque smoke from the Cascades to the coast and raining ash down on cars, streets and people.

headline: The ‘Mean Girls’ Musical Is Coming to Broadway in March
abstract: Tina Fey has written the musical’s book based on her screenplay for the 2004 film, keeping the same basic storyline but updating it to the present day.
lead_paragraph: “Mean Girls” is back. This time with smartphones.

headline: What You Get for $1.7 Million
abstract: An 1841 converted church and parsonage on Martha’s Vineyard, a midcentury-modern home in Calabasas, Calif., and a 1769 house in Boothbay, Me.
lead_paragraph: An 1841 converted church and parsonage on Martha’s Vineyard, a midcentury-modern home in Calabasas, Calif., and a 1769 house in Boothbay, Me.

headline: $1.7 Million Homes in Massachusetts, California and Maine
abstract: An 1841 converted church and parsonage on Martha’s Vineyard, a midcentury-modern home in Calabasas and a 1769 house in Boothbay.
lead_paragraph: WHAT An 1840s converted church and house with a total of three bedrooms and three bathrooms

headline: ‘Crooklyn’ Wins the One Film, One New York Contest
abstract: Residents voted for Spike Lee’s portrait of 1970s Brooklyn, and it will be screened for free in all five boroughs on Sept. 13.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have voted, and Spike Lee’s “Crooklyn” is the winner of One Film, One New York, in which the whole city is invited to watch the same movie on the same night.

headline: In the Rainy Season, Savings in Asia and Central America
abstract: Resorts in Cambodia, Thailand, Costa Rica and Guatemala are offering packages and lower prices in what is sometimes called the green season.
lead_paragraph: Travelers willing to trade unbroken sunshine for cooling rain showers may want to investigate green season deals. While traditional travel advice often suggests avoiding destinations during their rainy season, hotels and tour providers are now offering compelling reasons to rethink that point of view.

headline: Kate Winslet Relives Two Haunting Film Experiences
abstract: The actress talks about working With Woody Allen on the ’50s period piece “Wonder Wheel” and filming at freezing heights for “The Mountain Between Us.”
lead_paragraph: Kate Winslet is the type to take her work home with her. The actress has two films coming this year, and making them has haunted her nights.

headline: The Fate of ‘The Last Jedi’ Is in His Hands
abstract: Picking up “Star Wars” where J.J. Abrams left off, Rian Johnson got to write Skywalker’s next lines. He also had to contend with Carrie Fisher’s death.
lead_paragraph: NICASIO, Calif. — Skywalker Ranch, the 5,000-acre spread that George Lucas established here in Marin County, is hardly a shrine to the “Star Wars” movies; the quiet campus has no giant Yoda statue or Death Star murals. If you weren’t looking carefully, you might have missed Rian Johnson, the director and writer of “Star Wars: The Last Jedi” (due Dec. 15), having breakfast in a guesthouse on a recent August morning.

headline: House Hunting in ... Corsica
abstract: A two-story stone villa with a swimming pool on the French island of Corsica is on the market for $1.76 million.
lead_paragraph: A two-story stone villa with a swimming pool on the French island of Corsica is on the market for $1.76 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Corsica
abstract: The price of waterfront properties on this Mediterranean island has increased sharply in recent years, but the housing market still faces challenges.
lead_paragraph: A STONE VILLA IN CORSICA

headline: Nope, Mastery Is Not a Requirement for Happiness and Fulfillment
abstract: It’s just fine to hit 80 percent proficiency and then move on to something new. At that point, you’ve already climbed the steepest part of the learning curve.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been a member of a club that I never knew existed until recently. I learned about this club when I read Yvon Chouinard’s book, “Let My People Go Surfing.”

headline: When Getting a College Degree Requires Self-Exile
abstract: Ghada Tafesh left the Gaza Strip to get an education in the U.S. in 2012. She hasn’t been home since.
lead_paragraph: Before Ghada Tafesh left the Gaza Strip for college in the United States, her family gave her a necklace with two pendants. One was in the shape of historic Palestine. The other was an olive tree. “They wanted me to have something that would remind me of home, and to never be ashamed of where I come from,” she told me.

headline: Reflections on Summer Jobs
abstract: Teenagers from across the country shared their experiences and the role race and class played in their employment.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here for a free subscription to the Race/Related newsletter, which explores race with provocative reporting and discussion. The newsletter originally published these personal stories.

headline: World Cup Qualifying: What do U.S., Argentina and Ghana Have in Common?
abstract: In the scramble to secure a spot in next summer’s World Cup in Russia, the door is about to slam shut on some soccer heavyweights.
lead_paragraph: With two games to play, the United States could be in peril of failing to qualify for the World Cup for the first time since 1986. But the U.S. is not the only Cup perennial that could miss out on Russia 2018. Several other prominent teams are also struggling and might be sitting it out next summer, depending on the results of the final games in October.

headline: Pope Francis Visits Colombia, Where Even Peace Is Polarizing
abstract: During the pope’s six-day visit, his challenge is to nudge the country, torn apart by 52 years of war, toward a peace with former guerrillas.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The memory of the land mine that tore off the leg of Helena González’s nephew years ago is still fresh.

headline: What to Cook Tonight
abstract: Repurpose some Labor Day leftovers and finish it off with a hot-fudge sundae.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: To Allies’ Chagrin, Trump Swerves Left
abstract: Republican congressional leaders went into an Oval Office meeting on spending plans expecting a photo-op and walked away shellshocked.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican congressional leaders perched on the couches in the Oval Office froze in mid-smile on Wednesday afternoon when they realized President Trump was bypassing them to cut a short-term spending and debt ceiling deal with Democrats, and not them.

headline: U.N. Panel Faults Syria’s Military for Chemical Attack
abstract: A commission of inquiry added to the mountain of evidence of the military’s role in the April 4 attack, which killed at least 83 people.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — United Nations investigators added their voices on Wednesday to a mountain of evidence of the Syrian military’s responsibility for a chemical attack on a rebel-held town five months ago that left villagers foaming at the mouth and gasping for breath.

headline: Leaders of Hungary and Poland Chafe at E.U., but How Do Their People Feel?
abstract: Although the countries joined the European Union in 2004 on a wave of enthusiasm, their governments are now loud critics. Polish and Hungarian readers shared their views.
lead_paragraph: Poland and Hungary have had a testy relationship with the European Union. Their national economies have benefited enormously since joining the bloc in 2004, but in recent years, both countries have elected right-wing leaders that have defied Brussels by cracking down on judges and the news media, refusing to take in migrants and lashing out at the European Union as elitist and antidemocratic.

headline: Stanley Fischer, Fed’s No. 2 Official, Is Stepping Down
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman says he will depart in mid-October, leaving just three people on the seven-seat board.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stanley Fischer, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Wednesday that he would resign in mid-October, an unexpected decision that gives President Trump greater leverage over central bank policy.

headline: Review: Lana Del Rey, a Character No More
abstract: At a show kicking off a handful of concerts supporting her latest album, “Lust for Life,” the focus wasn’t on the singer’s persona, but her voice.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Lana Del Rey arrived six years ago, she was like a recovered memory, familiar and unsettling. Her preoccupations were nostalgia and melodrama, and strategic falseness became a kind of calling card. Her songs were sly and sometimes bracing, but they were most effective as a soundtrack for her real-time performance art.

headline: The Lure of the Big City Fishing Tackle Shop
abstract: Capitol Fishing Tackle Company, in Manhattan’s garment district, has been selling rods and reels for 120 years.
lead_paragraph: It was midmorning, and some guys were shooting the breeze at Capitol Fishing Tackle Company.

headline: Czar Nicholas II, Under Arrest and Doomed to Die
abstract: One of the most famous photos from the Russian Revolution was published a century ago in The New York Times Mid-Week Pictorial.
lead_paragraph: It had come to this: His Imperial Majesty Nicholas II, Emperor of All Russia, perched despondently on a tree stump under armed guard outside the palace at Tsarskoye Selo, where he had been detained by the provisional government after his abdication in March.

headline: Case Against Bronx Teenager Who Says He Was Framed by Police Is Dismissed
abstract: The Bronx district attorney said information in the original investigation “has now proven to be inconsistent and contradictory.”
lead_paragraph: The Bronx district attorney on Wednesday asked a judge to dismiss gun and assault charges against a teenager in a case that had become a rallying point for critics of the criminal justice system, saying a crucial witness had disappeared. The teenager, Pedro Hernandez, had refused a plea deal, then sued the city, alleging that police detectives in the 42nd Precinct framed him.

headline: She’s Taking the Show Uptown
abstract: The runway impresario Brandice Daniel speaks candidly about her 10-year fight to get Harlem fashion the respect it deserves.
lead_paragraph: The pivotal event in Brandice Daniel’s career arrived without fanfare. She had attended a small fashion show at a restaurant in Brooklyn. “Honestly I don’t remember what the models had on,” Ms. Daniel recalled. “I have no idea who the designers were, or who organized the event.”

headline: Keeping Your Files Safe in Google’s Cloud
abstract: Google Drive encrypts files you store online and its desktop software makes it easy to back them up, but be aware of privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: Q.  When I upload a file to the Google Drive cloud, where is it actually stored, and is it protected from hackers?

headline: Seahawks’ Michael Bennett Says Police Pointed a Gun at His Head
abstract: A two-time Pro Bowl defensive end reported on Twitter that he was held at gunpoint and handcuffed after the Mayweather-McGregor fight in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks star Michael Bennett said he was held at gunpoint and handcuffed by the police in Las Vegas after the Mayweather-McGregor fight.

headline: Hurricane Irma's Eye Passes Over Florida Keys
abstract: Hurricane Irma churned toward the Florida Keys after leaving a path of destruction across the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Irma churned toward the Florida Keys after leaving a path of destruction across the Caribbean.

headline: The Weird Brilliance of Joaquin Phoenix
abstract: He’s the greatest screen actor of his generation, but also a reluctant celebrity.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘I’M 42!’’ JOAQUIN PHOENIX EXCLAIMS when asked why he has zero social-media presence. It’s a late afternoon in May — a few weeks before he wins Best Actor at Cannes for playing a contract killer in Lynne Ramsay’s ‘‘You Were Never Really Here’’ — and he’s sitting by an open window on the 11th floor of a high-rise overlooking the flatlands of West Hollywood. One hand clutches an iPhone-5, earbud wires are wrapped around his neck, a pack of American Spirits are balanced on his knee, his sunglasses are hung in the crook of a white tee. He has a dad bod and his stubble is grayish. Phoenix is an activist, primarily concerned with animal rights (he’s been a vegan since he was 3) and has supported, among others, PETA, Red Cross and Amnesty International — but how would anyone know this, since he has no social-media presence (no Facebook, no Instagram, no Twitter) to connect with followers and inspire them? It seems indicative of Phoenix himself; extremely passionate but unconcerned with the reality, the tangible facts, of what he does and who he is: the most soulful screen actor of his generation, and arguably its greatest.

headline: Criminal Justice Reform Unites 5 Former New Jersey Governors
abstract: A report from a nonprofit run by the former governors, four Democrats and one Republican, offers policy recommendations for the state’s next leader.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has done away with cash bail, has a governor leading a national campaign to combat opioid addiction, and has a police chief in Camden who is reimagining community policing.

headline: Sale of Brooklyn Housing Complex Would Benefit Trump
abstract: The owners of Starrett City, the country’s biggest federally subsidized housing complex, are selling the development for more than $850 million. President Trump is a partial owner.
lead_paragraph: The longtime owners of Starrett City, the sprawling Brooklyn housing complex overlooking Jamaica Bay, are selling the development for more than $850 million, and among those who stand to benefit is President Trump, a partial owner.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘It’
abstract: The director Andy Muschietti narrates a scene from "It," featuring Wyatt Oleff as Stanley Uris.
lead_paragraph: The director Andy Muschietti narrates a scene from "It," featuring Wyatt Oleff as Stanley Uris.

headline: 8 Cozy, Graphic Sweaters for Fall
abstract: Autumnal knits with playful patterns make cooler weather something to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: Cozy sweaters with playful patterns make autumn weather something to celebrate.

headline: Craig Carton, Sports Radio Host, Is Accused of Ponzi Scheme
abstract: The co-host of “Boomer & Carton” on WFAN is accused of raising funds to buy and sell concert tickets, and then using the money to pay debts.
lead_paragraph: Craig Carton, a co-host of a New York morning sports-radio program “Boomer & Carton,” was arrested on Wednesday morning by the F.B.I. on charges that he helped orchestrate a fraudulent multi-million-dollar ticket-reselling scheme.

headline: Andy Muschietti Narrates a Scene From ‘It’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The creepy clown Pennywise doesn’t appear in this scene from the latest adaptation of Stephen King’s novel, but it’s an unnerving sequence nonetheless.

headline: Gwendoline Christie on Playing the ‘Complete Opposite’ of Brienne of Tarth
abstract: The “Game of Thrones” actress stars in the new season of Jane Campion’s “Top of the Lake”
lead_paragraph: If Jane Campion’s first season of the crime drama “Top of the Lake” seemed remote and somber to some, the second season, “Top of the Lake: China Girl” has more of a sense of humor, even when delving into the darker recesses of life. (In this case, migrant sex workers, institutionalized misogyny, mental illness and more.) In the second season, which begins Sunday on Sundance, Elisabeth Moss’s detective Robin Griffin, who returns home to Australia after time in New Zealand, is assigned an overeager assistant, played by “Game of Thrones” star Gwendoline Christie.

headline: We Are Not ‘White Supremacist Groups’
abstract: The New Century Foundation and the VDARE Foundation object to being described that way in an Op-Ed essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: There Are No Hollywood Endings in ‘BoJack Horseman’
abstract: The celebrated animated series about a washed-up actor who happens to be a horse offers a mixed fourth season with some high points.
lead_paragraph: “BoJack Horseman,” Netfiix’s animated series about a Hollywood has-been who happens to be a talking horse, has had a storybook existence. Released in 2014 to shrugs, it caught on after its second season, becoming a fiercely loved critic’s favorite and a fixture on top-10 lists.

headline: First Harvey, Then Irma and Jose. Why? It’s the Season.
abstract: Experts say that with conditions just right in the tropical Atlantic, late summer and early fall is prime time for hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: First came Hurricane Harvey, which barreled into Texas on Aug. 25. Now Irma, one of the most powerful hurricanes on record, is battering the Caribbean and has Florida in its sights.

headline: In Canada, an Immigration Minister Who Himself Is a Refugee
abstract: Ahmed Hussen was a 16-year-old Somali refugee with nothing of his own but a change of clothes. Now, 24 years later, he is the country’s immigration czar.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — He arrived in Toronto, an exhausted 16-year-old, carrying nothing but a small gym bag packed with a change of clothes. As a Somali, he applied for asylum and was jettisoned into adulthood. He registered for high school, learned to cook and landed his first job all on his own.

headline: Stephen Fybish, Who Had Much to Say About the Weather, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Fybish carved out a unique amateur niche in meteorological circles as an ardent hoarder and disseminator of weather data.
lead_paragraph: It was drizzling in Central Park on Aug. 30, which was not unusual, since it had rained one out of three days that month. The temperature that day ranged between 60 and 78, which was nowhere near the historic low and high of 50 and 98.

headline: 10 Shows We’ll Be Talking About in September
abstract: Summer is unofficially over, but that’s good news in TV land, as a slew of promising new shows and beloved favorites come back this month.
lead_paragraph: Another Labor Day has come and gone, another summer met its unofficial end. That’s bad news for beach going, but good news for TV watching. With the exception of “Twin Peaks” and some show about dragons, this summer was slow.

headline: TMZ Veteran Who Split With Site’s Founder Emerges as a Rival
abstract: Mike Walters left TMZ after clashing with Harvey Levin. Now he is running The Blast, a well-financed entrant on the sharp-elbowed celebrity news scene.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before dawn on Wednesday, a celebrity news site here published an anonymously sourced article about a kerfuffle involving Scott Disick of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” fame.

headline: An Enormous, Urgent Task: Hauling Away Harvey’s Debris
abstract: After the storm, clearing all the mounds of rubbish is a top priority. Experts warn of the task’s complexity, and the need to meet environmental standards.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — On Labor Day, Pireta Darby sat on the front porch of her house in the Kashmere Gardens neighborhood. The fruits of her labors were before her: the sodden objects lugged out of the home she shares with her mother and granddaughter. Here were two couches piled high with ripped-out carpet. A coffee table. A folding chair. And so much more, removed from the family home of about 60 years.

headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Tugboats
abstract: The Great North River Tugboat Race, a New York harbor tradition now in its 25th year, is a showcase of hard-working, river-churning power and tradition.
lead_paragraph: As annual New York competitions go, the Great North River Tugboat Race is, not surprisingly, a bit of a plodder. Organized by the Working Harbor Committee, the 25-year-old race is contested over the same mile of Hudson River, often by many of the same entrants, year after year, generally to little fanfare.

headline: If You Build It, the Dutch Will Pedal
abstract: Utrecht, the Netherlands’ fastest-growing city, is one of the world’s most bike-friendly places in one of the world’s most bike-friendly countries.
lead_paragraph: UTRECHT, the Netherlands — When city officials unveiled the first section of the world’s largest bike parking garage in Utrecht, a small city in the center of the Netherlands, late last month, the feeling of accomplishment was short-lived.

headline: Dresses Our Brides Have Worn
abstract: A selection of wedding-day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.
lead_paragraph: A dramatic hooded gown designed by the bride. A petal pink dress for a cathedral ceremony. A traditional kimono and a nod to a new tradition. The women featured in our wedding announcements in recent months wore bridal outfits that told many stories. Here is a selection of photographs from their weddings, with details on where they purchased their outfits and why.

headline: What Older Americans Stand to Lose if ‘Dreamers’ Are Deported
abstract: Many of those who care for older Americans are low-wage immigrants, and replacing them could prove difficult and costly for families and taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: When the Trump administration announced on Tuesday that it would end an Obama-era program that shielded young undocumented immigrants from deportation, Sherwin Sheik quickly sized up the potential toll on his business.

headline: Refugees’ Flight and Land Mines Spur Bangladesh Protest to Myanmar
abstract: Reports that Myanmar had placed mines along the countries’ shared border led Bangladesh to issue a protest and demand “immediate measures to de-escalate” the crisis.
lead_paragraph: COX’S BAZAR, Bangladesh — Bangladesh on Wednesday protested the huge influx of people fleeing violence in Myanmar and raised concerns with Myanmar’s government about reports that its military was placing land mines along the countries’ shared border.

headline: Review: Resonant Bodies Festival, a Summer Camp for Singers
abstract: This annual event of experimental vocal music features Theo Bleckmann, Jennifer Walshe and Davóne Tines.
lead_paragraph: The most telling paean to the Resonant Bodies Festival at its opening night on Tuesday came from the vocalist and composer Theo Bleckmann, who took the stage first. Thanking the audience for coming, he said that the festival, this year at Roulette in Brooklyn, had organized the most impressive backstage he had encountered in 30 years of performing.

headline: The Outcry Over Ending the ‘Dreamers’ Program
abstract: “With one heinous act, this administration chose to ruin lives, destroy promising futures and tear apart loving families,” a reader writes. Others agree.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Self-Driving Cars’ Prospects Rise With Vote by House
abstract: A showdown between carmakers and safety advocates looms after the House approved a bill that would put driverless vehicles onto public roads more quickly and curb states from slowing their spread.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers in the House took a major step on Wednesday toward advancing the development of driverless cars, approving legislation that would put the vehicles onto public roads more quickly and curb states from slowing their spread.

headline: Brexit? For Now, E.U. Leaves Fights to the U.K.
abstract: While Britain obsesses, the European Union regards its departure as a second- or third-tier issue, behind things like debt, migration, terrorism and the euro.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The vexed question of Britain’s exit from the European Union, or Brexit, is all-consuming there, the stuff of daily leaks, denials, political proclamations and banner headlines in the nation’s newspapers, tabloid and otherwise.

headline: ‘Despacito’ Owned the Summer. What’s Next for Latin Pop?
abstract: Artists and executives from the Spanish-speaking world believe the hit song and the world of streaming have broken down barriers.
lead_paragraph: From Memorial Day to Labor Day, only one pop song really mattered: Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee’s “Despacito” remix featuring Justin Bieber led the Billboard Hot 100 for a record-tying 16 weeks and now ranks as the most-streamed song ever, in addition to its radio ubiquity. The song’s official YouTube video — for the all-Spanish version without Mr. Bieber — has had more than 3.5 billion views in less than six months.

headline: The National Gives Its Sound a Jolt on ‘Sleep Well Beast’
abstract: Seven albums into its career, the band moves beyond elegant melancholia as its music grapples with knottier questions.
lead_paragraph: Elegant melancholia isn’t enough for the National anymore. On its seventh album, “Sleep Well Beast,” its new songs have more rhythmic ferment and melodic crosscurrents; they translate emotional complexity into musical counterpoint.

headline: Small Business, Big-Hearted Personality
abstract: A national correspondent reporting on Trump Country gravitates toward a factory owner with an unexpected sticky note on her computer monitor.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, The Times brought together a group of national correspondents to write in-depth stories about regions and people who might have received short shrift in the run-up to last November’s election.

headline: Indian Jewelry: A History Lesson
abstract: Rings to conceal Kama Sutra, store poison — and other clever designs from the past.
lead_paragraph: Rings to conceal Kama Sutra, store poison — and other clever designs from the past.

headline: Inside the Sparkling World of Siddharth Kasliwal
abstract: An heir to the Gem Palace, Jaipur’s legendary jewelry emporium, shares his inspirations — and vision.
lead_paragraph: As a boy, Siddharth Kasliwal accompanied his father, Munnu — an heir to the Gem Palace, Jaipur’s legendary jewelry emporium — to mines in Brazil and on business trips to Paris. ‘‘He would give me ruby and sapphire beads to occupy me,’’ the younger Kasliwal says, ‘‘as though they were toys.’’ In the jewelry trade for nine generations, the Kasliwals and their storied 109-year-old store and workshop have created spectacular pieces for royals (Princess Diana), maharanis (the Ava Gardner-like Gayatri Devi of Jaipur) and rock stars (Mick Jagger). In the wake of Munnu’s 2012 death at age 54 from brain cancer, his 33-year-old son, who friends call Sid, has emerged in his own right as a designer — and bon vivant. Munnu brought Indian fine jewelry the international recognition once reserved for European houses and championed previously unsung stones like the spinel; his son, who opened a vivid new Mumbai boutique in 2015, aims to further marry historical influences with contemporary settings in his work. Good-naturedly dodging his mother’s entreaties to settle down, the peripatetic and engaging Kasliwal scours the world for outrageous gems (a recent find was an old 10-carat mine diamond at a Las Vegas antiques show) and the best parties. When not on the road or in India, he can be found in his Upper East Side Manhattan atelier, entertaining clients in the scarlet-upholstered suite of a townhouse, surrounded by velvet-lined trays of glittering adornments. ‘‘I was raised for this,’’ he says. ‘‘It’s the best life you can imagine.’’

headline: Profile in Style: Sid Kasliwal
abstract: Inside the world of an heir to Gem Palace, Jaipur’s legendary jewelry emporium.
lead_paragraph: Inside the world of an heir to Gem Palace, Jaipur’s legendary jewelry emporium.

headline: Overtreatment Is Common, Doctors Say
abstract: Doctors surveyed believed that 20.6 percent of all medical care was unnecessary, including 22 percent of prescriptions.
lead_paragraph: Most physicians in the United States believe that overtreatment is harmful, wasteful and common.

headline: Salvador Dalí Was Not Woman’s Father, DNA Test Shows
abstract: The result of the paternity test should close a lawsuit by a woman who believed she was the artist’s daughter.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A paternity test has demonstrated that Salvador Dalí, the surrealist painter, was not the father of a woman who could have claimed part of his estate, the foundation responsible for the artist’s museums in Spain announced on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Ranger Games’ Investigates a Crime and a Soldier’s Mind
abstract: Ben Blum tries to get to the bottom of his cousin’s participation in an armed bank robbery.
lead_paragraph: To a hammer, everything looks like a nail. To an Army Ranger — or to some Rangers, it seems fair to say — every building looks like a potential target. In 2006, Pfc. Alex Blum would often find himself sitting with his Ranger buddies near their base in Tacoma, Wash., imagining the logistics of taking down local establishments. Especially enthusiastic about these exercises was Specialist Luke Elliott Sommer, a more senior Ranger with two combat tours behind him. He turned every brief, banal excursion — to Dairy Queen, Quiznos, a porn shop — into a teachable moment.

headline: Wild Dogs Sneeze to Hunt
abstract: African wild dogs, highly social pack hunters, need a consensus to start a hunt. The votes, of sorts, may be cast by sneezing.
lead_paragraph: African wild dogs, highly social pack hunters, need a consensus to start a hunt. The votes, of sorts, may be cast by sneezing.

headline: Wild Dogs Sneeze When They Are Ready to Hunt
abstract: The number of African wild dogs in a pack who sneeze determines whether or not the pack goes on a hunt.
lead_paragraph: When they want to move as a group, meerkats call to each other. Capuchin monkeys trill. Gorillas grunt. Honeybees make what is called a piping sound.

headline: In India, Another Government Critic Is Silenced by Bullets
abstract: Gauri Lankesh, an outspoken journalist, was assassinated Tuesday night. Friends said she had received too many threats to count, but laughed them off.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Gauri Lankesh, one of India’s most outspoken journalists, was walking into her house on Tuesday night.

headline: New York to Welcome Supersize Cargo Ship Into its Waters
abstract: The Bayonne Bridge has been raised and New York Harbor has been dredged to accommodate the giant container vessels.
lead_paragraph: Overhead on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, some drivers might crane their necks in appreciation as cargo ships pass below. But that is about as much excitement as such ships typically generate as they enter New York Harbor.

headline: The DACA ‘Fix’ That Immigration Activists Fear
abstract: By upending Obama’s executive order, Trump is likely to reopen fault lines in a beleaguered movement.
lead_paragraph: When news leaked on Monday that President Trump had decided to dismantle Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) — the 2012 policy that granted administrative relief to some 800,000 undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as minors — some commentators tried to find a ray of hope in the dismal forecast. Trump, they noted, would give Congress six months to save the DACA-protected “Dreamers” from deportation with a legislative fix. Never mind that House Republicans sabotaged a chance to help Dreamers in 2013, when John Boehner, the House speaker, refused to hold a vote on an immigration-reform bill that had passed in the Senate to a vote on the House floor. Now, NPR reported, Republicans might favor a bill introduced by Representative Carlos Curbelo of Florida that would give Dreamers a path to citizenship. “Overwhelmingly, Republicans tell me: ‘Yes, I could support giving these young immigrants permanent status in our country,’ ” Curbelo told “All Things Considered,” “ ‘as long as we continue moving towards better border security, the enforcement of our immigration laws.’ ” Yet among the undocumented activists whom I got to know while reporting in Arizona earlier this year, such a compromise is hardly viewed with relief. Rather it is the Catch-22 that they have been dreading ever since Trump was elected.

headline: If de Blasio Wants My Vote
abstract: A reader explains what the mayor needs to do differently this time.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Revising the 25th Amendment
abstract: A member of Congress suggests that former presidents and vice presidents should be the ones to decide whether a sitting president is unfit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: $2.2 Billion Deal for Rockets Is a Casino Mogul’s Bet on Houston
abstract: Buying a trophy asset as the city rebuilds after Hurricane Harvey makes for awkward timing. And yet the investment suggests an abiding faith in a recovery.
lead_paragraph: An American casino mogul is making a timely bet on Houston.

headline: Charlie Parker’s Rules
abstract: A music professor writes that the jazz musician exceeded the musical norms of his peers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fantasy Football Week 1: Players to Start on Sunday
abstract: Most fantasy owners did not draft Carson Palmer to be their main quarterback, but they may want to consider him against the Lions.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account,@5thdownfantasy.
