abstract: These player rankings from the Sablich brothers are for standard scoring formats and will be updated each week.
lead_paragraph: These player rankings from the Sablich brothers are for standard scoring formats and will be updated each week.

headline: Barred From Suing
abstract: A constitutional law professor shares his experience.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Open: Del Potro Disrupts Federer-Nadal Meeting; Keys Rounds Out All-American Semifinals
abstract: Madison Keys defeated Kaia Kanepi of Estonia to join Sloane Stephens, Venus Williams and CoCo Vandeweghe in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: Stay here for live results and analysis from quarterfinals and semifinals of the U.S. Open.

headline: Rachel Comey Wants to Show You Her Clothes. But First, Dinner Is Served.
abstract: Friends and fans including Sandra Bernhard, Gaby Hoffmann and Molly Ringwald came to toast the designer’s return to New York.
lead_paragraph: The opening salvo of New York Fashion Week came, mercifully enough, with steak and oysters, the kind of sanguinary pleasures fashion week usually does its best to avoid. Rachel Comey, who brought her show back from a sabbatical in Los Angeles last season, returned to New York with a lengthy dinner party presentation at Flora Bar, in the concrete cavern of the Met Breuer, something few designers would risk.

headline: 29Rooms Is a Creative Playhouse for the Instagram Set
abstract: In its third year, this annual pop-up space for interactive installations attracts the likes of Jill Soloway, Emma Roberts and Jake Gyllenhaal.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean artist JeeYoung Lee stood surrounded by piles of New York City trash: 4,500 plastic water bottles, 1,500 wine corks, dozens of sheets of cardboard and recycled newspapers. Ms. Lee, who lives in Seoul, was in a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last week, turning the local garbage into a cheery seascape installation, complete with gulls and rolling waves against a backdrop the color of Caribbean waters. At the center of it was a sailboat, where visitors could perch, bobbing on a sea of their own detritus. By Ms. Lee’s request, the newspapers covering her boat were awash in articles about Hurricane Harvey.

headline: How Red Sox Used Tech, Step by Step, to Steal Signs From Yankees
abstract: Boston used an Apple Watch and video cameras to illegally gain an advantage, decoding the signs of the Yankees’ catcher to the pitcher.
lead_paragraph: Boston used an Apple Watch and video cameras to illegally gain an advantage, decoding the signs of the Yankees’ catcher to the pitcher.

headline: Where to Party in New York This Fall
abstract: A clutch of bars and clubs are opening in New York in the coming months, some in giant new hotels.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, a subterranean lounge named Mailroom began luring downtown types to the financial district with the siren call of free drinks, food from Momofuku and D.J.s including James Murphy of LCD Soundsystem, Mark Ronson and Clara 3000.

headline: A Texas Town, Weary From Floods, Goes Underwater Again
abstract: Deweyville, Tex., swamped by a flood in 2016, gets hit once more. Some residents blame a decision to open floodgates even more than the weather.
lead_paragraph: DEWEYVILLE, Tex. — Jimmy LaVergne and Tommy Williams were chatting on the banks of their underwater town.

headline: Blocked in China, Facebook Is Said to Seek a Shanghai Office
abstract: The office search indicates the company is growing more positive about its prospects in mainland China, where it has been unavailable for nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Facebook is blocked in China, but it is feeling comfortable enough there to look for its own place.

headline: Announcing a New Monthly Feature: What’s Going On in This Graph?
abstract: In this experiment with the American Statistical Association, we’ll ask students to look closely at a graph published in The Times and interpret what they see.
lead_paragraph: Note: To find the latest “What’s Going On in This Graph?”, visit this page.

headline: Advice if You’re Traveling and There’s a Hurricane
abstract: If you have a trip planned where a storm is expected, call your hotel and airline. If you have already arrived, have your bags packed — and phone charged.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Harvey hit and battered much of Houston on Aug. 25, and now Hurricane Irma, which is considered to be the most powerful Atlantic storm ever recorded, struck the Caribbean island of Barbuda early Wednesday morning and is expected to reach Puerto Rico and other islands later in the day or this evening. The tropical storm Jose currently trails behind Irma, and early Wednesday, a fourth tropical storm, Katia, was strengthening in the southwestern Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Fitzroy Fights Australia Day and Demands Respect for Indigenous History
abstract: How a Melbourne suburb and its city council is confronting Australia’s celebration of “discovery” by European settlers.
lead_paragraph: FITZROY, Australia — Uncle Jack Charles, a well-known Australian Aboriginal actor, was born in 1943 under Australia’s assimilation policy, which he said absorbed Aboriginal people into white society by removing children from their families.

headline: A Tate Modern Show Examines Race in the U.S.
abstract: After recent events in Charlottesville, Va., a London exhibition by African-American artists takes on a new dimension.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At first glance, the painting seems abstract: white shapes and streaks hovering irregularly across a night-dark background. But after a moment, the forms become clearer in this Norman Lewis painting, “America the Beautiful,” which immediately hits the eye as you enter “Soul of a Nation: Art in the Age of Black Power,” at Tate Modern. They are the peaked white hoods and flaming crosses of the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: How to Achieve Instant Style Cred This Fall
abstract: Savvy shoppers will invest first in accessories.
lead_paragraph: Spring 2018 fashion will be paraded on the runways in New York this week, but it’s definitely all fall in the stores, which of course puts folks with cash on hand in the mood for shopping. The first purchases of any new season are always the most exciting, but they should also be the most strategic since their appeal will have to last for months and months. Savvy shoppers, then, will invest first in accessories — items that add instant style cred to a look, but are also versatile enough to wear as temperatures drop. Here, a roundup of the best accessory updates of the season.

headline: Boys Puberty Book is Pulped After Aging Badly
abstract: A passage about breasts in “Growing Up for Boys” leads to some awkward conversations for a British publisher.
lead_paragraph: Parents often turn to books to help them navigate complicated, and sometimes uncomfortable, conversations with their children about puberty. This week one such book, “Growing Up for Boys,” by Alex Frith, became the topic of the type of conversation it is supposed to help people avoid.

headline: For This Artist Duo, a Third Act: A Shrine to Oscar Wilde
abstract: After 20 years, and ups and downs, McDermott & McGough conjure their temple to a martyr of gay rights.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Wilde’s immense talent, inimitably foppish style and personal tribulations as a gay man make him a natural subject for the artistic duo known as McDermott & McGough.

headline: In the W.N.B.A., 3-Pointers Are a Newfound Weapon
abstract: The 3-point shot has become a more important part of W.N.B.A. teams’ arsenals.
lead_paragraph: When Rebekkah Brunson walked off the court last October, she could not have known that in a few months she would remake her game and become part of a revolution in W.N.B.A. offenses.

headline: It’s 10 P.M. Do You Know What Apps Your Children Are Using?
abstract: A brief primer on the apps, and their minefields, keeping teens and tweens glued to their phones.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Graham Bell didn’t expect his telephone to be widely used for prank calls. And Steve Jobs was chary of children using his iThings.

headline: Immigrants Shouldn’t Have to Be ‘Talented’ to Be Welcome
abstract: When Americans focus on immigrants’ economic contributions, they fail to stand up to the Trump administration’s fundamentally hateful agenda.
lead_paragraph: The terms of the debate over President Trump’s decision to revoke the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program are familiar, as are the terms of the larger conversation about immigration in this country: On one side are hardworking immigrants; on the other are politicians who wrongly claim that these immigrants harm the economic interests of native-born Americans.

headline: Myanmar, Florida, Vladimir Putin: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Florida Sheriff Plans to Check for Warrants at Hurricane Shelters
abstract: People seeking safety from Irma could be arrested if they have outstanding warrants, Sheriff Grady Judd of Polk County said on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Irma barreled down on his state, a county sheriff in Florida said on Wednesday that law enforcement authorities would check the identities of people who turn up at shelters and take to jail anyone found to have an active arrest warrant.

headline: Do Androids Dream of Being Featured in Portrait Competitions?
abstract: A portrait of an android has been shortlisted for the Taylor Wessing Photographic Portrait Prize, as the debate about artificial intelligence intensifies.
lead_paragraph: A portrait shortlisted for this year’s Taylor Wessing Photographic Portrait Prize features a clear-skinned young woman gazing out of the frame with a slight smile. She looks shy but a little playful, almost as if she’s keeping a secret.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Peter Gallagher Reads ‘Promises That Can Bend Without Breaking’
abstract: On this week’s podcast, the star of “The O.C.” reads Robert St. Amant’s story of a diagnosis that shapes the contours of his marriage.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s podcast, the actor Peter Gallagher reads “Promises That Can Bend Without Breaking,” about how the strength of a marriage can outweigh the uncertainty of health.

headline: Critics Say City Has Not Investigated Yeshivas, Breaking Pledge
abstract: The schools that serve Orthodox students are accused of ignoring secular subjects. One graduate called them, ‘an educational catastrophe.’
lead_paragraph: Responding to complaints that several dozen yeshivas in New York City fell short of the state requirement that they provide an education “at least substantially equivalent” to that offered in public schools, officials at the city’s Department of Education said they would investigate. That was two years ago.

headline: Simplicity, Space, Lines
abstract: The contemporary choreographer and dancer Jodi Melnick has never been inhibited about moving in public.

headline: Hurricane Andrew: How The Times Reported the Destruction of 1992
abstract: With Florida’s governor warning that Hurricane Irma will be stronger than Andrew, here’s a refresher on that powerful storm.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Rick Scott of Florida said on Wednesday that Hurricane Irma, projected to make landfall in the state on Sunday, would be stronger than Hurricane Andrew, those who lived through that August 1992 storm would have had little doubt about the seriousness of the warning.

headline: Bringing Contemporary Dance to Russia, Citadel of Classicism
abstract: The ballerina Diana Vishneva’s Context festival will present choreographers like Wayne McGregor and Marco Goecke to an audience weaned on ballet.
lead_paragraph: Wayne McGregor, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui, Marco Goecke, Richard Siegal, Justin Peck: Not exactly household names in Russia, storied home to classical ballet with little audience fondness for more contemporary offerings. But these choreographers, as well as Alexei Ratmansky and Hans van Manen, are among the high-profile artists whose work will be part of the Context festival, founded and run by the ballerina Diana Vishneva.

headline: Aeroflot Flight Attendants Win Challenge Over Clothing Sizes
abstract: The Moscow City Court said the airline could not link income levels to clothing size, a ruling that could affect hundreds of other employees.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two Aeroflot flight attendants secured an unexpected legal victory on Wednesday when the Moscow City Court ruled that the airline could not link income levels to clothing sizes.

headline: Review: In ‘Charolais,’ Competing With His Mother and His Cow
abstract: Noni Stapleton wrote and stars in a solo show about an Irishwoman unsettled by life on the farm.
lead_paragraph: Something grisly has transpired. That much we can deduce. The blood is one clue, the red of it soaked and spattered all over the pregnant woman’s apron as she walks into the kitchen. There’s a hefty carving knife in her hand, matted with blood and — is that hair on the blade? Maybe fur?

headline: John le Carré’s ‘A Legacy of Spies’: An Excerpt
abstract: George Smiley returns in this coda to le Carré’s classic, “The Spy Who Came In From the Cold.”
lead_paragraph: A new novel by John le Carré is always an event, and doubly so when it includes an appearance by his iconic spymaster George Smiley. “A Legacy of Spies” is published this week: To mark the occasion, read le Carré in conversation with Ben Macintyre about the intricacies of espionage in real life and in fiction; read Dwight Garner’s review of the novel; and, below, treat yourself to an excerpt from the opening chapter.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. to Meet With Senate Russia Investigators
abstract: President Trump’s eldest son is to meet Thursday with Senate Judiciary Committee investigators to answer questions about his meeting with a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr., the president’s eldest son, is set to meet with Senate Judiciary Committee investigators behind closed doors on Thursday to answer questions about his June 2016 meeting with a Kremlin-connected lawyer, committee officials said.

headline: New York City Offers Free Lunch for All Public School Students
abstract: The city becomes the largest district in the country to feed all children free of charge, ending stigma for those who can’t afford to pay.
lead_paragraph: Lunch at New York City public schools will be available free of charge to all 1.1 million students beginning this school year, Carmen Fariña, the schools chancellor, said on Wednesday in the basement cafeteria of a Hell’s Kitchen elementary school. The new school year begins on Thursday.

headline: Review: Celebrating Sibelius and His Slowly Imparted Secrets
abstract: Led by Esa-Pekka Salonen, the Sibelius Academy and the Juilliard School performed his “Lemminkainen Suite” and other selections emulating the composer.
lead_paragraph: Through much of the 20th century, it bears recalling, the Finnish composer Jean Sibelius remained a puzzling figure, an outlier from the frozen north largely preoccupied with exotic local color. His music, urgent and pulsating, was either very hot or very cold — no one could quite be sure. His reputation rode a pendulum: in one generation, out the next.

headline: Wirecutter Editor Shares the Tech That Can Improve Your Life
abstract: Jacqui Cheng, who leads The Wirecutter, a product recommendations site owned by The Times, has tested many consumer electronics products. Here is what stood out to her.
lead_paragraph: How do journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Jacqui Cheng, editor in chief of The Wirecutter, the product recommendations site owned by The New York Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline: After Harvey Hit, a Texas Hospital Decided to Evacuate. Here’s How Patients Got Out.
abstract: The hospital, Baptist Beaumont, was one of many health care institutions disrupted as the storm Harvey, once a Category 4 hurricane, swept across the region.
lead_paragraph: As floodwaters from Hurricane Harvey began filling his north Beaumont, Tex., home last week, Theodore Atwood waded outside to get a utility knife, so he could pull up his carpet and protect it. Coming back to his kitchen, he slipped and fell on the wet linoleum, and ended up at a local hospital with a severely broken pelvis. But that was only the beginning of his journey, as he became one of 243 patients evacuated from the hospital last Thursday and Friday, according to a hospital spokeswoman, after flooding from the storm damaged the city’s water system.

headline: 6 Models to Watch This Season
abstract: T’s cheat sheet to the faces on the spring/summer 2018 runways.
lead_paragraph: 20, United Kingdom

headline: Ryan Praises Trump on DACA, but Promises a Legislative Response
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan, after urging President Trump to keep DACA, said Wednesday that the president made “the right call” — and promised a legislative answer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan, just days after saying President Trump should hold off on scrapping an Obama-era program that shields young undocumented immigrants from deportation, reversed course on Wednesday and said the president made “the right call” by ending the program.

headline: What You Tried That Summer
abstract: Summer is a time of exploration. Here is what you told us you tried for the first time.
lead_paragraph: The unofficial end of summer is already here so it’s time to reminisce. We asked some of our favorite authors what they tried for the first time in summers’ past: Francine Prose went on a scary ride at Coney Island. Alexander Chee learned how to take a real vacation. And Joyce Maynard celebrated love and life on the back of a motorcycle.

headline: Fake Russian Facebook Accounts Bought $100,000 in Political Ads
abstract: Facebook said that fake accounts and pages had bought 3,000 ads focused on divisive social issues, including race and immigration.
lead_paragraph: Providing new evidence of Russian interference in the 2016 election, Facebook disclosed on Wednesday that it had identified more than $100,000 worth of divisive ads on hot-button issues purchased by a shadowy Russian company linked to the Kremlin.

headline: Hurricane Irma, DACA, ‘It’: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Harvey Swept Hazardous Mercury Ashore. The Mystery: Its Source.
abstract: A property owner rolled the silvery globules around in the palm of his hand before he realized they were clusters of mercury, a dangerous liquid metal.
lead_paragraph: CHANNELVIEW, Texas — Public health officials are investigating a case of dangerous liquid mercury that appears to have washed or blown ashore here, east of Houston, in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey.

headline: They Validate Parking
abstract: A woman does a good deed, and reaps a small benefit.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Sugar Ramos, 75, Boxer Remembered for a Fatal Fight, Dies
abstract: The death of Davey Moore three days after Ramos knocked him down led to calls for legislation that would outlaw boxing.
lead_paragraph: Sugar Ramos, a Cuban featherweight boxing champion who was best known for winning a title fight that led to the death of his opponent, Davey Moore, and that prompted calls to abolish the sport, died on Sunday in Mexico City. He was 75.

headline: Facebook Tells Advertisers It Can Reach Many Young People. Too Many.
abstract: An analyst pointed out that the company said it could reach 25 million more young Americans than last year’s United State census says exist.
lead_paragraph: Facebook faced criticism on Wednesday after an analyst pointed out that the company’s online advertising tools claim they can reach 25 million more young Americans than the United States census says exist.

headline: How to Join the Fashion Pack at New York Fashion Week
abstract: Open houses and special shopping events at Barneys, Bergdorf, Bloomingdale’s and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the makeup artist Kirsten Kjaer Weis and the fashion illustrator Clym Evernden will take up residence at Barneys New York on Madison Avenue from noon to 6 p.m. Shoppers will receive a custom mini-makeover and have a live portrait drawn when they buy the new Kjaer Weis Artist Kit, which includes six lip and eye pencils ($145).

headline: For Brazil’s Departing Top Prosecutor, ‘One Last Cannon Barrage’
abstract: Days before his term ends, Attorney General Rodrigo Janot is leaving the country’s current and past two presidents facing corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Call it the ultimate mike drop.

headline: Elizabeth McGovern of ‘Downton Abbey’ Plays a Bad Mom This Time
abstract: The actress is back to starring as an Edwardian matriarch in “Time and the Conways,” which begins performances on Sept. 14 in New York.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy morning, Elizabeth McGovern, late of “Downton Abbey,” arrived at a Midtown rehearsal space dressed in a pink cardigan, white capri pants and slip-on shoes that would appall a dowager countess. A film and stage actress who ditched Hollywood for London more than two decades ago, she found midcareer fame playing Cora Crawley, the American wife of an English lord and a woman who can really wear a tiara.

headline: Red Sox Cheating Scandal Highlights Apple Watch’s Illicit Uses
abstract: The Apple Watch, which is bound for an update Sept. 12, has been called the “new easiest way to cheat” on exams.
lead_paragraph: Commercials for the Apple Watch show people swimming, running, climbing, jumping. But the watch can also be used, it turns out, for another activity: cheating.

headline: Tomorrow’s Marquee Names, Now in the Making
abstract: Unknown talents — some joining high-profile projects like “Mean Girls,” others creating brand-new work — will soon brighten New York theater.
lead_paragraph: Alex DeLarge in “A Clockwork Orange”

headline: Trump Chooses 12 Charities for His Harvey Donations
abstract: The Red Cross and the Salvation Army will receive the largest portions of the president’s $1 million total donation to assist in relief efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has selected a dozen charitable organizations, including the Red Cross and the Salvation Army, to support with personal donations to help with Hurricane Harvey relief, White House officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Trump’s Choice for Top Civil Rights Job Defends Private-Sector Work
abstract: Eric S. Dreiband, the nominee to run the Justice Department’s civil rights division, defended Abercrombie & Fitch over its firing of a Muslim woman and fought the agency over transgender bathroom access.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s nominee to lead the Justice Department’s civil rights division defended his work on both sides of discrimination cases on Wednesday during his confirmation hearing, seeking to ease the concerns of civil rights advocates who have denounced his nomination.

headline: Jack Webb, Photographed by Glen Luchford
abstract: For years, the photographer would photograph his lighting assistant, Jack Webb, who is himself a photographer in his own right. This week, they published the results in a new book.
lead_paragraph: For years, the photographer would photograph his lighting assistant, Jack Webb, who is himself a photographer in his own right. This week, they published the results in a new book.

headline: One Lighting Assistant, Captured in Photos Over Two Decades
abstract: The photographer Glen Luchford always snaps a picture of his lighting assistant Jack Webb before the model gets into the frame. Now, those images are revealed — alongside the final photographs.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Glen Luchford has shot hundreds of fashion images over his more than two-decade- career. In 1991, he met Jack Webb and hired him as a lighting assistant. Webb, a photographer in his own right, began to stand in for models on set — so that Luchford could test the lighting. As the writer Lou Stoppard writes in the book, “Those pictures were made without the sense that they’d ever been seen again, because usually what happens at the end of a session is you separate test shots out and they get trashed,” Luchford says in a conversation with Webb that is included in his new book, “The Agony and the Ecstasy: Jack Webb by Glen Luchford,” which will be published by IDEA this week. “But for some reason, I hung onto them.”

headline: Fashion Month, Demystified
abstract: The Styles desk and T Magazine begin preparing for the twice-yearly event months in advance.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Month — the four-week period twice a year when top designers debut their latest collections in New York, London, Milan and Paris — brings out a horde of photographers intent on capturing interesting clothes, both on the runways in the shows and on the sidewalks outside of them.

headline: Work Toward Bipartisan Fix for Health Markets Begins in Senate
abstract: Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, the chairman of the Senate health committee, said Wednesday that he hoped for a deal by the end of next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate health committee said Wednesday that he hoped the panel would reach a consensus by the end of next week on a small, bipartisan bill to stabilize health insurance markets and prevent prices from skyrocketing next year under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: In North Dakota, Trump Repeats Call for Rewrite of Tax Code
abstract: President Trump urged North Dakotans to pressure members of Congress to support a plan that he promised to detail within weeks.
lead_paragraph: MANDAN, N.D. — President Trump on Wednesday used the backdrop of an oil refinery here to repeat his call for an overhaul of the nation’s tax code, including a steep cut in the business tax rate.

headline: National Cathedral to Remove Windows Honoring Confederate Generals
abstract: Officials at Washington National Cathedral announced a decision that they said had been made more urgent by the racially tinged violence in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials at Washington National Cathedral will remove two stained-glass windows that pay tribute to the Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson, a decision reached after two years of discussion and made more urgent by the recent racially tinged violence in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Charles Burnett and Donald Sutherland Among 4 to Receive Honorary Oscars
abstract: Four film artists whose work spans from the French New Wave to the African-American experience will be honored by the motion picture academy on Nov. 11.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has once again decided to use its honorary Oscars to emphasize inclusion, announcing on Wednesday that statuettes would go to Agnès Varda, a French New Wave director, and Charles Burnett, an independent filmmaker known for his portrayal of the African-American experience.

headline: Opening Arguments in Menendez Trial Focus on the Meaning of Friendship
abstract: The opening statements of the federal corruption case of Senator Robert Menendez centered on the question: What constitutes a permissible friendship with a politician?
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Senator Robert Menendez spent seven years enjoying a “life of luxury he could not afford” in return for acting as a personal senator to a wealthy ophthalmologist in Florida, federal prosecutors told jurors here on Wednesday during the opening chapter of a case whose outcome could reverberate far beyond New Jersey.

headline: With Rupert Murdoch’s Help, Tab Media Targets Young and Cheeky on Campus
abstract: The youth-oriented media company, which describes itself as “anti-establishment and a little subversive,” compiles breaking news from unpaid student writers at 40 American colleges.
lead_paragraph: The American news operations of Tab Media are on a Brooklyn side street in a nondescript brick building that also houses an acupuncture studio and a mortgage lender.

headline: How to Follow Hurricane Irma
abstract: A wealth of storm information is available at your fingertips on the internet, but individual data points can be misleading.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Irma is already historic. Its winds, which have held at 185 miles an hour for 24 hours, are the strongest ever recorded in the open Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Robert E. Lee Statue’s Removal in Dallas Delayed by Federal Court
abstract: Work to take down the statue began soon after the City Council voted to remove it, but was stopped by a temporary restraining order.
lead_paragraph: The City of Dallas voted Wednesday to immediately remove a statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee from a public park, but the work was abruptly stopped by a federal judge.

headline: After Andrew, Florida Changed Its Approach to Hurricanes
abstract: In South Florida, Hurricane Andrew remains a benchmark that few have forgotten. The storm changed how Florida prepared for high winds and lashing rains.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Survivors of Hurricane Andrew — a Category 5 storm that decimated cities south of Miami — talk of pre-Andrew and post-Andrew as a kind of biblical milestone.

headline: Simeon Wright, Witness to Abduction of Emmett Till, Dies at 74
abstract: Two young cousins, one visiting from Chicago, shared a bedroom on the night of a murder in 1955 that shook the nation and galvanized the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Simeon Wright picked cotton all day in his father’s field on Wednesday, Aug. 24, 1955, just as he had done every summer growing up in the Mississippi Delta. It was just too hot, though, for his 14-year-old citified cousin, Emmett Till.

headline: Democrats Begin Legal Assault on Trump’s Move to End ‘Dreamer’ Program
abstract: A group of 16 Democratic attorneys general have filed suit in New York, claiming that Mr. Trump had improperly upended the policy known as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s immigration policies faced a renewed legal onslaught on Wednesday, as a coalition of Democratic attorneys general, nonprofit groups and private companies announced they would oppose his rollback of Obama-era protections for people who entered the country illegally as children.

headline: Guatemala’s Democratic Crisis Point
abstract: The country’s president faces a choice: Cater to his friends in organized crime or uphold the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: HAVERFORD, PA. — Guatemala is facing a moment of political reckoning. Last Sunday, the country woke to the news that President Jimmy Morales had expelled Iván Velásquez, the commissioner heading the United Nations panel charged with eradicating the country’s organized-crime networks. Within hours Guatemala’s Constitutional Court provisionally blocked Mr. Morales’s decree. Whether the president follows the court’s ruling will determine the future of Guatemala’s already fragile democracy.

headline: Charge Dropped Against Reporter Who Questioned Tom Price
abstract: The journalist, Dan Heyman, was arrested in West Virginia in May after peppering the health secretary with a question about health care legislation.
lead_paragraph: A reporter in West Virginia who was arrested four months ago after he aggressively questioned Tom Price, the secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, will not be prosecuted, officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Is Said to Hire Advisers to Help Weigh Bankruptcy
abstract: The toy retailer must find a way to pay back $400 million in debt over the next few months.
lead_paragraph: Toys “R” Us has hired restructuring advisers from the prominent law firm Kirkland & Ellis as it tries to cope with hundreds of millions of dollars of debt coming due, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Why Did Israel Let Mengele Go?
abstract: New history sheds light on why the Mossad didn’t capture Auschwitz’s ‘angel of death.’
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — For decades, Israel’s espionage agency, the Mossad, kept a file on Josef Mengele, the Nazi doctor responsible for, among other atrocities, selecting which new inmates at Auschwitz would die immediately in the gas chambers and which would be put to work first or subjected to his horrible “medical” experiments.

headline: Hurricane Irma, One of the Most Powerful in History, Roars Across Caribbean
abstract: The storm left wreckage and flooding on Caribbean islands and is making its way toward Florida.
lead_paragraph: This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to Thursday's live Irma updates.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Finances Add to Vulnerability in Hurricane
abstract: With the island having effectively declared bankruptcy, its infrastructure reflects years of neglect, and the storm could be a new economic blow.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Ricans have ample experience with hurricanes, but the storm approaching on Wednesday brought an added level of anxiety. The island’s dire financial straits have left essential public works, from power plants to retaining walls, weakened by years of scrimping on maintenance.

headline: HBO’s ‘Veep’ to End in 2018 After Acclaimed Run
abstract: The biting comedy about a self-obsessed vice-president-turned-president-turned-aspiring-candidate will conclude after seven seasons.
lead_paragraph: HBO’s “Veep” will end after its seventh season next year, HBO confirmed on Wednesday night.

headline: For Conservatives, Trump’s Deal With Democrats Is Nightmare Come True
abstract: The president’s move further destabilized a volatile situation for his party, which many Republicans now believe is headed toward a reckoning it can no longer avoid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is the scenario that President Trump’s most conservative followers considered their worst nightmare, and on Wednesday it seemed to come true: The dealmaking political novice, whose ideology and loyalty were always fungible, cut a deal with Democrats.

headline: Lacking a Point Person on China, U.S. Risks Aggravating Tensions
abstract: Aside from President Trump himself, it remains unclear who in the administration wields genuine influence on the relationship with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump insisted that he and President Xi Jinping had a “very strong phone call” on Wednesday. But if Mr. Trump kept alive the rapport he has painstakingly cultivated with the Chinese leader, the 45-minute call still served to underscore the widening fissures between Washington and Beijing and the deepening confusion about how the Trump administration is managing the relationship.

headline: Kate Millett, Ground-Breaking Feminist Writer, Is Dead at 82
abstract: Ms. Millett’s 1970 book, “Sexual Politics,” was revolutionary in its analysis of gender roles in society and provoked a backlash in some quarters.
lead_paragraph: Kate Millett’s first and most famous book, “Sexual Politics” (1970), is credited with inciting a Copernican revolution in the understanding of gender roles, but it began life somewhat unobtrusively, as a doctoral thesis. And its author was a somewhat reluctant standard-bearer for the new feminism.

headline: The 103 Reasons to Doubt the Twins Haven’t Stopped Them Yet
abstract: No team has ever lost 100 games one season and reached the playoffs the next. But the Twins believe they can do it.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — As the home runs piled up late last season for the Minnesota Twins’ Brian Dozier, so did a gnawing sense of emptiness. Dozier set an American League record for homers by a second baseman, with 40 of his 42 coming at the position. But his team stumbled to 103 losses, a low point across more than five decades in Minnesota. Baseball was no fun.

headline: Sloane Stephens Beat Stresses, Physical and Mental. Can She Beat Venus Williams?
abstract: Injury and other pressures behind her, Stephens is girding for a semifinal match against Williams at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Through the first four months of the 2016 tennis season, Sloane Stephens had won three WTA titles and was being considered a contender for the French Open.

headline: So This One Time, I Overheard...
abstract: In this week’s Australia Letter, a New-York-inspired call for personal vignettes, plus same-sex marriage, rejecting Australia Day, and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: In Final Primary Debate, de Blasio Again Defends His Record
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, seeking a second term, and his challenger, Sal F. Albanese, sparred in the last debate before the Democratic mayoral primary.
lead_paragraph: It could have been mistaken for a slightly unorthodox mayoral news conference, with Mayor Bill de Blasio giving a forceful defense of his record and sometimes sparring testily with reporters.

headline: Aroldis Chapman Will Return to His Role as Yankees’ Closer, Girardi Suggests
abstract: Manager Joe Girardi, who is famously tight-lipped about reliever roles, came as close as he ever has to making a definitive statement on his closer.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For nearly two decades, there was never a question about who would close out a Yankees game. From 1997 to 2013 — with a detour because of a serious knee injury in 2012 — it was Mariano Rivera. Others then followed — David Robertson, Andrew Miller, Aroldis Chapman and sometimes Dellin Betances. Starting this season, the Yankees thought, it would be Chapman again for the next five years.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Vicious Storm, Roaring West, Hits Caribbean
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 7, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “I was 13 and I obviously remember Hurricane Hugo, but this is something incomparable. This is something terrible, an experience out of this world.”

headline: Scarlet Stigma
abstract: A very orderly puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Thursday is “gimmick day” (or “shtick day” in the Bronx), which often means a challenge, like a rebus element where more than one letter goes in a box, or letters outside the grid, or some other extra puzzle-in-a-puzzle.

headline: U.S. Seeks U.N. Consent to Interdict North Korean Ships
abstract: The measure would fall short of a full blockade of the kind used in the Cuban missile crisis, but could set the stage for conflicts at sea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday circulated a draft resolution at the United Nations Security Council that would effectively empower the United States Navy and Air Force to interdict North Korean ships at sea, inspect them to determine whether they are carrying weapons material or fuel into the country, and use “all necessary measures” to enforce compliance.

headline: Tom Ford: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Review: In ‘Home Again,’ an Imitation of Life (and Mom)
abstract: Reese Witherspoon plays cute and single in a mirthless romantic comedy in a movie by Hallie Meyers-Shyer, the daughter of Nancy Meyers and Charles Shyer.
lead_paragraph: For her directorial debut, “Home Again,” Hallie Meyers-Shyer, Nancy Meyers’s daughter, has made a shabby copy of a Nancy Meyers romantic comedy. If you’ve watched any of Ms. Meyers’s movies, the resemblance between influence and imitation will be readily apparent. To wit: A star (Reese Witherspoon) plays a would-be charmer (here called Alice) whose neuroses are as fabulously customized as her kitchen. She’s what the brand-conscious call a creative, and while she works (a bit), she spends much of her time on man troubles. Her life is as fluffed as a throw pillow and so drained of realism it is best described as a lifestyle, which can make for a killer aspirational fantasy, at least in Nancy Meyers’s hands.

headline: U.S. Charges 4 Turks With Conspiring to Violate Iran Sanctions
abstract: The indictment, an expansion of a broader conspiracy case, claims that the Turks provided services to the Iranian government and “intended to deceive U.S. regulators.”
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in New York announced on Wednesday the filing of a new indictment that charges a former Turkish economy minister and three other Turks with participating in a broad conspiracy to violate the United States’ sanctions against Iran.

headline: In Rarity, Four Americans Reach U.S. Open Women’s Semifinals
abstract: CoCo Vandeweghe and Madison Keys won their quarterfinals Wednesday, joining Venus Williams and Sloane Stephens.
lead_paragraph: It has been 32 years since four American women reached the semifinals of the same Grand Slam tournament, and 36 since they managed it at the United States Open.

headline: Man Dies in First New York City Police Shooting Caught on Body Camera
abstract: Officers were checking on a man in the Bronx who they said pulled out a knife and a toy gun with a laser.
lead_paragraph: Police officers fatally shot a 31-year-old Bronx man on Wednesday afternoon after they were called to his home by his landlord and the man confronted them with a knife and what turned out to be a toy gun with a laser, the authorities said. It was the first shooting involving a New York City officer to be captured on police body cameras.

September will also play host to a trio of high-profile auctions that put the private artworks and personal possessions of three tastemakers with strong ties to the fashion world under the hammer.

lead_paragraph: New York has hosted many grand events, from Broadway spectacles and heavyweight prize fights to World Series and World’s Fairs. It has also been the stage for compelling tennis matches involving the likes of Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova, John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his seven months in office, President Trump has proved to be the commander in chief of mixed messages. But even for him, the nighttime tweet on Tuesday was a head-turner.

headline: Inner Racism Revealed
abstract: Being president has not changed Trump but exposed him.
lead_paragraph: Allow me a moment of personal indulgence: When I began writing a column many years ago, it quickly dawned on me that although I had strong and firm views on some things, there were many others about which my opinions weren’t fully formed. I believe that many of us have areas in our lives where our opinions are fungible. It was only through my experience in this job that my own opinions became so clear to me. Doing the job honed me, revealed me, exposed me.

headline: New York’s Bad Teachers, Back on the Job
abstract: Doing a disservice to the city’s most vulnerable students, Mayor Bill de Blasio is forcing principals to take the dregs of the system’s employees.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, a million New York City children will return to school. Educators have long been concerned about a “summer slide” — the learning loss that often occurs when students are out of school for two months. It’s a serious problem. But it’s not just students who can slide backward during these months. Facing political and budgetary pressures, an entire school system can slide without strong leadership. That’s now happening in New York.

headline: A Devious Threat to a Nuclear Deal
abstract: Mr. Trump has not abandoned his foolish quest to kill the hard-won agreement to stop Iran’s nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley laid the Trump administration’s cards on the table this week with a new proposal aimed at sabotaging one of the Obama administration’s most important diplomatic initiatives — the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran. President Trump promised during his campaign to kill the deal, despite its clear benefits to American security. Ms. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, has set forth a scheme that could not only allow Mr. Trump to carry out his threat, but also shift final responsibility to Congress.

headline: Trump’s Global Democracy Retreat
abstract: The State Department’s new “America First” mission betrays historic U.S. values.
lead_paragraph: Under the leadership of Donald Trump and Rex Tillerson, the State Department is considering a mission reform that includes the abandonment of democratic assistance and human rights. The current mission statement reads, “The department’s mission is to shape and sustain a peaceful, prosperous, just and democratic world and foster conditions for stability and progress for the benefit of the American people and people everywhere.”

headline: Strip Aung San Suu Kyi of Her Nobel Prize
abstract: The Muslims I’ve met describe a meticulously planned ethnic cleansing in Myanmar. The laureate has dismissed it as “misinformation.”
lead_paragraph: SHAMLAPUR, Bangladesh — Among Westerners, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is often mentioned as a paragon of liberty, in the same breath as Mandela and Gandhi, thanks to her decades-long campaign against Myanmar’s kleptocratic military junta. But to the Rohingya, the Muslim minority now fleeing Myanmar (formerly Burma) by the tens of thousands, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and the country’s political leader is the embodiment of evil.

headline: The Struggle Between Clinton and Sanders Is Not Over

lead_paragraph: The surge in Democratic enthusiasm and activism driven by animosity to President Trump is proving to be a mixed blessing.

headline: Still Processing: A New Canon of Music by Women
abstract: We discuss NPR’s list of 150 greatest albums by women and why it matters.
lead_paragraph: Last month, NPR published a list of the 150 greatest albums by women. The list was debated. It was discussed. There were alternative lists of 150 additional albums not on the NPR list. Quibbling with the particulars of the list is one thing. It did overlook a lot. But the quibbling misses an important concern about what it means to argue for a female-only canon. The power of the list came, in part, from its mere existence, from how necessary it felt. Behold the many artists ignored by mainstream coed lists! Aaliyah! Shakira! Tori Amos! Chaka Khan! Why would albums by women who rank so prominently on a list determined by women be missing from one determined by all genders but really mostly men? The question matters. This week we talk about why it does. We also talk about the very different ways we experienced the list, and we revisit the song of the summer, a phenomenon that, once again, was ruled by male artists.

headline: Ryan Says Trump Cut Deal With Democrats to Avoid Partisan Fight Over Hurricane Aid
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan said he understood President Trump’s motivation for making a spending a deal with Democrats, but remained skeptical of the plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan voiced his disagreement with President Trump’s decision to cut a debt limit deal with Democrats and cast doubt on his call to cut the corporate tax rate by more than half in an interview on Thursday with The New York Times.

headline: An Ideal Sundae
abstract: Like many of life’s great things, ice cream concoctions are best when governed by rules.
lead_paragraph: Having decided quite suddenly to marry, Michael and I had a wedding so small that when my mother claimed we eloped, I didn’t disagree. There was some family fallout, but the disadvantages were minor when set against the joy of not having to worry about who wasn’t speaking to whom and where they were seated, or the relief of avoiding bridesmaids’ discontent. Best of all, the ceremony was short, which meant that at 10 p.m. I was just where I wanted to be, sitting next to Michael at New York’s long-­cherished and now-gone Rumpelmayer’s ice cream parlor, sharing a hot-fudge sundae generously crowned with whipped cream — a dessert I still consider a celebration and one I wouldn’t swap for a fancy wedding cake.

abstract: Investigators believe the president’s son is crucial to understanding a June 2016 meeting between the Trump inner circle and a Kremlin-connected lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr. told Senate investigators on Thursday that he set up a June 2016 meeting with a Russian lawyer because he was intrigued that she might have damaging information about Hillary Clinton, saying it was important to learn about Mrs. Clinton’s “fitness” to be president.

headline: That ‘Spider Bite’? Blame It on Something Else
abstract: Spiders rarely bite humans, experts say. What people believe to be a spider bite often is caused by another pest or even an infection.

headline: Still Lives That Won’t Hold Still
abstract: Maria Cosindas’s dreamlike photographs have a magic all their own.
lead_paragraph: Marie Cosindas, who was born in Boston in September 1923 and who died in the same city in May of this year at age 93, made photographs of such potency that they seem magical, dependent on something beyond mere sleight of hand for their mesmerizing effects and unified mood, so that the experience of looking at a selection of them is like watching a single sentence unfurl over several pages, driven along by an invisible inner consistency, not unlike the atmosphere of imaginative abundance that Gabriel García Márquez evoked in his novel “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” an atmosphere he used as the backdrop for the dense saga of the Buendía family in the mythical town of Macondo, and especially in his account of the magician Melquíades, a “heavy Gypsy with an untamed beard and sparrow hands,” a bearer of dazzling and arcane knowledge, including visions of the present and the future, as well as the secrets of optics, telescopes and magnetism, so that many different kinds of insight seem to find a natural unity inside him, and whose work re-emerges in the final pages of the novel in Sanskrit parchments, with “the even lines in the private cipher of the Emperor Augustus and the odd ones in a Lacedaemonian military code,” the inscrutabilities layered on one another to arrive at a startling lucidity of the kind that might be experienced by someone whose tangled dreams, regardless of their wildness or relentlessness, give way to a pure vision of wakefulness, though not the uninflected wakefulness of one who rises in early morning to a hot and innocent white light but rather the shadowed knowingness of one who has slept all day and awakes to the infinitesimally graded colors of a deepening evening, a moodiness recognizable to any viewer of Cosindas’s photographs, which make the most of small, dark spaces, a talent that perhaps originated in her being the eighth of 10 children raised by Greek immigrant parents in a small apartment in Boston’s South End, just as her experience as a child attending her parents’ Greek Orthodox church, with its gilded Byzantine icons and busy walls, was possibly the origin of her luminous sense of color and the suggestion of incense even when there is no smoke to be seen, a dimension of her work which certainly did not arrive instantaneously, though it did finally arrive, after she had worked as a painter and also as a photographer in black and white, including time spent in the workshop of Ansel Adams, whose grayscale lessons she abandoned in order to take up color with an alchemical force that is reminiscent of the great Amsterdam painter Rachel Ruysch, a widely celebrated artist in the very first rank of still-life painters of the Dutch golden age, who was active from the final quarter of the 17th century until shortly before her death in 1750 at age 86, and who, moreover, was one of very few women to be feted in that profession, and who outgrew both her botanist father and painter husband, outshining them in reputation as she consolidated both botanical and artistic knowledge, while raising 10 children, to produce ferociously accurate bouquets of flowers, some of which were literal works of fiction that showed in a single vase blooms that would have been seen in life only in different seasons but which through the magical art of painting could permanently be brought together, each precisely painted and often accompanied by equally fine depictions of marble plinths, tabletops, vases and insects, the entire arrangement set against a dark background, as was the vogue during the maturity of Dutch floral painting, a branch of art that was the elevation of the most modest and domestic material into an intensity that approached the sublime, a gift given to only a few: to leverage the ordinary into the glorious, to turn the soft petals of flowers into a flamelike radiance,

headline: Who Benefits From the Expansion of A.P. Classes?

lead_paragraph: Laura Fuchs has been teaching Advanced Placement U.S. government and politics at H.D. Woodson High School in Washington for six of her 10 years there. She is in her early 30s, wears her hair pulled back in a bun and has a no-nonsense way of dealing with her students. But that apparent sternness belies a genuine love of teaching and a deep well of patience, two qualities that have prepared her for teaching a college-level course at a school like Woodson.

headline: Review: The Crime Drama ‘True to the Game’ Lacks Finesse
abstract: A drug lord finds love and tries to exit his way of life in this movie based on the Teri Woods novel.
lead_paragraph: “True to the Game” presents a Philadelphia parable. Gena (Erica Peeples) is an aspiring writer, Quadir (Columbus Short) is a cocaine kingpin. Their love promises a new beginning, but there may be no way to exit a life on the streets. Based on the Teri Woods novel of the same name, the hustlers of “True to the Game” are trapped in a world of twists and treachery. But though Ms. Woods’s novel was a resonant entry in the crime genre when it came out nearly 20 years ago, this adaptation lacks the vision to find a fresh angle on her story. It’s all too easy to guess which characters will be marked for tragedy and which characters will learn from their loss.

headline: Review: ‘Nobody’s Watching,’ an Actor’s Immigration and Alienation

lead_paragraph: There’s a slight and not unpleasing paradox at the heart of Julia Solomonoff’s smart and engaging new movie,  “Nobody’s Watching.” It is an uncommonly unhurried film about a character for whom time is running out.

headline: Review: In ‘Fallen,’ Girl Meets Angel Boy (Eternity Looms)
abstract: From Lauren Kate’s young adult novel, this twist on the “Twilight” formula is big on production values but shaky on emotional sincerity.

Its heroine, Luce, is a self-possessed 17-year-old making her way through the jungle of a new school, navigating unfriendly cliques and obsessing over glowering boys even as a supernatural shadow threatens her safety and her sanity.

headline: ‘The Way to Survive It Was to Make A’s’
abstract: They were the first black boys to integrate the South’s elite prep schools. They drove themselves to excel in an unfamiliar environment. But at what cost?
lead_paragraph: The road to Virginia Episcopal School was more secluded in those days, winding a few miles from the white section of segregated Lynchburg through a wood of maple and oak to the school’s rolling campus, shielded by trees and the more distant Blue Ridge Mountains. The usual stream of cars navigated the bends on the first day of school, white families ferrying their adolescent sons. Like nearly every other elite prep school in the South, it had been the boarding school’s tradition since its founding in 1916 that its teachers guide white boys toward its ideal of manhood — erudite, religious, resilient. But that afternoon of Sept. 8, 1967, a taxi pulled up the long driveway carrying a black teenager, Marvin Barnard. He had journeyed across the state, 120 miles by bus, from the black side of Richmond, unaccompanied, toting a single suitcase. In all of Virginia, a state whose lawmakers had responded to the 1954 court-ordered desegregation of public schools with a strategy of declared “massive resistance,” no black child had ever enrolled in a private boarding school. When Marvin stepped foot on V.E.S. ground, wearing a lightweight sport jacket, a white dress shirt, a modest necktie and a cap like the ones the Beatles were wearing, the white idyll was over.

headline: Your Coming Tax Increase

headline: Tom Ford Exhumes the 1990s and It’s Almost Fabulous
abstract: New York Fashion Week begins with a history lesson. And it’s a surprising amount of fun.
lead_paragraph: The 1990s have been resurgent of late, largely thanks to their somewhat ignoble contributions to contemporary life: reality television and “Baywatch”; White House scandal and congressional shutdown; and, of course, the introduction of Donald J. Trump as a pop culture tabloid star. Well, we all need something to blame. Why not a time period?

headline: Bruce Chatwin, an Homage
abstract: The photographer Bruce Weber pays loving tribute to the British author and explorer, Bruce Chatwin, in these images of the actor Brenton Thwaites.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Bruce Weber pays loving tribute to the British author and explorer, Bruce Chatwin, in these images of the actor Brenton Thwaites.

headline: Bruce Chatwin: One of the Last Great Explorers
abstract: Forty years after the publication of his groundbreaking travelogue, ‘‘In Patagonia,’’ the author’s writing — and style — have lost none of their power to bewitch and inspire.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, Bruce Chatwin left England and began to travel. This was not so long ago, and yet the world back then was still so unmapped: A traveler could and did wander through it like Pausanias, like Ibn Battuta, like the explorers who wrote the first drafts of the romance of movement, of the twinned danger and delight of finding oneself in a place where one was at the mercy of unfriendly but intriguing strangers. A traveler, back then, was far less likely to find in the foreign traces of the familiar. Depending on where he ventured, he had significantly fewer guarantees of safety, and equally thrillingly, only limited ways of communicating with those he knew and had left behind. And it wasn’t only that you could (and, indeed, would) travel as Ibn Battuta had, but, crucially, you could travel where Ibn Battuta had, as well: Sanaa and Baghdad and Damascus, all of which are now treacherous or off-­limits, cities in countries forced by war or disaster or bad governance to deny their cultures’ extravagant senses of hospitality.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Murray Hill and Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

abstract: This week’s properties include houses in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. and Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: Patriots vs. Chiefs: How to Watch the N.F.L. Opener
abstract: The defending Super Bowl champs, led by Tom Brady, welcome Kansas City to Gillette Stadium.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. football begins on Thursday night. And as usual, it’s a big game, with the Super Bowl champions against an elite contender. Here’s what there is to know about Game No. 1 of 256:

headline: How You Can Prepare to Evacuate Your Home for a Hurricane
abstract: Here are some tips for getting ready: Make a plan, bring documents, close lids, clear the yard, blast the freezer.
lead_paragraph: When a hurricane is poised to make landfall and the authorities issue an evacuation order, you may not have much time before you leave to protect your home from the storm — and from flooding.

headline: Explosion at Indiana Post Office Injures One
abstract: The F.B.I., which is leading the investigation, said that it had not yet determined whether the blast was an act of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: An explosion at a post office in Indiana on Wednesday left one person injured and is being investigated by the F.B.I.

headline: Review: In ‘Rememory,’ the Machine Knows What You Did
abstract: A traumatized car-crash survivor turns into an amateur sleuth, using a machine that records and recovers memories.
lead_paragraph: In one disturbingly cautionary 2011 episode of the British science-fiction series “Black Mirror,” people wear implanted chips that allow them to record and play back their memories. Exploring a similar idea with significantly less resonance, the writers of “Rememory,” Mark Palansky (who also directed) and Michael Vukadinovich, mash a fertile premise into sentimental mush.

headline: August’s Most Popular Listings
abstract: The most popular properties on The New York Times’s “Find a Home” real estate listings site.
lead_paragraph: The most viewed listings on The New York Times’s “Find a Home” site last month included a Beaux-Arts townhouse on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan listed at $50 million and an elegant 1924 property in California, on Pasadena’s Millionaires’ Row.

headline: In Land of Many Rivalries, New One Bubbles Up: Falafel vs. Falafel
abstract: Two brothers run competing shops, right next to each other. But their falafel rivalry, fierce as it is, is nothing compared to their sibling one.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — “Falafel Sahyoun” reads the awning of one storefront.

headline: The Red Cross and Hurricane Harvey
abstract: “The American Red Cross encourages people to donate to the charity of their choice.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Milestone for BMI: More Than $1 Billion in Music Royalties
abstract: The music licensing agency, whose members include stars like Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran, reached that milestone a year ahead of its own predictions.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the music licensing agency BMI reached $1 billion in revenue for the first time, and Michael O’Neill, the company’s chief executive, predicted that it would take another three years before the agency could, after expenses, pay $1 billion in royalties to its songwriters and music publishers.

headline: ‘Angels in America’ Is Returning to Broadway With Nathan Lane
abstract: Andrew Garfield and Denise Gough will join Mr. Lane in the pair of acclaimed plays by Tony Kushner on Broadway next year.
lead_paragraph: “Angels in America,” Tony Kushner’s sweeping masterwork, will be revived at the Neil Simon Theater next spring, a quarter century after its winged title character first hovered over a Broadway stage.

headline: Change Is in the Air at the E. B. White Farm
abstract: Discovering the author’s home in Maine, where he wrote “Charlotte’s Web” and heard those darn crickets.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLIN, Me. — There is a lovely passage in “Charlotte’s Web” that goes:

headline: One Nation Under a Movie Theater? It’s a Myth.
abstract: Hollywood wants us to think that its films are for everyone, but our critics say that was never true. Still, they see a way forward.
lead_paragraph: This fall and winter will bring the familiar blockbuster blowouts — a new “Thor” and “Star Wars” — and smaller movies striving for relevance along with awards. These include “Marshall,” Reginald Hudlin’s biopic about the Supreme Court justice Thurgood Marshall; “LBJ,” Rob Reiner’s drama about the president who appointed Justice Marshall; and “The Post,” Steven Spielberg’s dramatization of the Pentagon Papers case, which Justice Marshall ruled on.

headline: Law Firm Sees Britain as Hunting Ground for U.S. Whistle-Blower Cases
abstract: Its lawyers say that United States laws offering rewards for exposing corporate misdeeds present a business opportunity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When federal prosecutors recently charged a little-known British luxury knitwear company with evading custom duties, few knew the role a small New York law firm played in the case.

headline: Paul Ryan on Taxes, DACA and Trump’s Deal With Democrats
abstract: During an interview with The New York Times at the inaugural TimesTalk D.C., Speaker Paul D. Ryan discussed his plan to pass tax reform legislation by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: During an interview with The New York Times at the inaugural TimesTalk D.C., Speaker Paul D. Ryan discussed his plan to pass tax reform legislation by the end of the year.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include houses in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. and Ridgefield, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include houses in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. and Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Murray Hill and Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Murray Hill and Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

headline: They Thought the Monsoons Were Calm. Then Came the Deadly Floods.
abstract: Despite hard experience with monsoons, many in northern India say no warning came when the floodwaters started coursing last month. Now, the death toll is rising.
lead_paragraph: MURMALA, India — As the floodwaters sloshed into her hut, Phoolvati, a poor and landless woman living in a farming village in Bihar State, scrambled to grab some jewelry, a soccer ball and a wad of rupees — the last of the family’s meager treasure. She hurriedly stuffed it all into a big aluminum box.

headline: Getting Waze Alerts During a Phone Call
abstract: Waze announcements, your phone calls and your music can all share time with your car’s audio system.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I get a decent volume for my Waze audio alerts when I’m on a phone call in the car over a Bluetooth connection?

headline: Review: The Hard Road of Decency in ‘The Unknown Girl’
abstract: A young doctor struggles with her conscience in this latest film from the Dardenne brothers.
lead_paragraph: “The Unknown Girl,” the latest film by the Belgian writer-directors Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, is about the consequences of trying to do the right thing. By a logic at once elusive and meticulous, it is also, therefore, about the consequences of inaction. Moral indifference is an easy path, and it leads to other, graver sins, including cruelty and dishonesty. But the harder road of decency has its own traps and byways, as a young doctor named Jenny Davin discovers.

headline: Review: In ‘The Limehouse Golem,’ Bawdy Limericks and Bloody Corpses
abstract: Bill Nighy pursues a serial killer in 19th-century London in Juan Carlos Medina’s film.
lead_paragraph: Owner of a face that’s one of the marvels of modern cinema, Bill Nighy can give even the most somber movie a comic bent. So his central presence in “The Limehouse Golem,” a baroque Victorian whodunit set in London’s East End, is like a wink-wink signal that what we’re seeing is being played for laughs, not scares. Yet despite the lurid images and florid dialogue, this over-the-top adaptation of Peter Ackroyd’s 1994 novel takes itself very seriously indeed.

headline: Review: For the Wild Things in ‘Trophy,’ Life Has a Price
abstract: This thoughtful documentary raises tough questions about big-game hunting and wildlife conservation.
lead_paragraph: “Trophy,” an extraordinary documentary from Shaul Schwarz and Christina Clusiau, is filled with astonishing sights. An American hunter welling up over the body of the lion he has just shot; a South African rhino breeder calmly sawing the horns off his helpless charges. The intimacy of the film’s images and the surprising candor of its participants are disarming: Whatever your initial response, be prepared to re-evaluate.

headline: Glorious Excess at Prontito in Queens
abstract: Extravagance — and generosity — define the restaurant’s menu, a catalog of ornately swagged hot dogs and hamburgers that look designed with a snake’s jaws in mind.
lead_paragraph: Extravagance — and generosity — define the restaurant’s menu, a catalog of ornately swagged hot dogs and hamburgers that look designed with a snake’s jaws in mind.

headline: Burgers and Franks Go Over the Top at Prontito in Queens
abstract: This Colombian restaurant in Elmhurst specializes in glorious excess.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to know whether to eat a cholado or sip it, or to somehow try both at once. Better just to say that you submit to it, this red-orange tower of fruit, ice and condensed milk like a mashed-up sunrise.

headline: Cultivating Mindfulness for Educators Using Resources From The New York Times
abstract: Practical strategies for bringing mindfulness into your life both inside and outside of the classroom to support your own well-being and, in turn, the well-being of the young people in your care.
lead_paragraph: The Well section runs a regular column called “Meditation for Real Life,” which includes helpful tips on how to be mindful — for instance, when walking in the rain or while doing the dishes.

headline: These Obsessive Men of MoMA Furnished Your Modernist Home
abstract: The forward drive that Alfred H. Barr Jr. and Philip Johnson embraced seems utterly contemporary — and covetable — today.
lead_paragraph: “Partners in Design: Alfred H. Barr Jr. and Philip Johnson,” at the Grey Art Gallery in Washington Square, is the story of two men and a whole country. The men are men of MoMA — the first museum with a curatorial department dedicated to architecture and design, which preached the gospel of the International Style both in New York and via touring exhibitions. The country is the United States — to which they imported, wholesale, a European industrial aesthetic meant to wash away Prairie Style organicism and Art Deco ornament.

headline: Energized Trump Sees Bipartisan Path, at Least for Now
abstract: A day after reaching a fiscal deal with Democrats, the president waged peace with the opposition party in hopes of finding more areas of agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time President Trump woke up on Thursday morning, he was feeling upbeat. And as he watched television news reports about his fiscal agreement with Democrats, he felt like telling someone.

headline: Kara Walker Traces Slavery’s Bitter Legacy With New Ways of Drawing
abstract: After the triumphant “Sugar Baby,” the artist pushes her incendiary art into the present, merging collage, political cartoons and history painting.
lead_paragraph: Like most outstanding artists, Kara Walker is unrelenting. In a press statement for her latest show at Sikkema Jenkins & Co., she wrote in her familiar, mock-serious yet dead-serious tone that she was “tired of ‘having a voice’ or worse ‘being a role model’ ” and of “being a featured member of my racial group and/or gender niche.” But Ms. Walker’s desire to stand down from the demands of her particular brand of fame has not made her stand down in her art, which is as disturbing and challenging as ever, if not more so.

headline: Treating Reflux With Diet
abstract: A plant-based diet is just as effective as proton pump inhibitors in treating laryngopharyngeal reflux, a study found.
lead_paragraph: A small study has found that a plant-based diet is just as effective as proton pump inhibitors in treating laryngopharyngeal reflux, or LPR.

headline: Starting Fires to Unearth How Neanderthals Made Glue
abstract: Some 200,000 years ago, Neanderthals used tar to attach handles to tools and weapons. Archaeologists performed experiments to show how they could have made this adhesive.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals seem stuck with unflattering reputations. The entire species of early human ancestors has long been reduced to a pejorative for describing someone who isn’t very bright, despite growing evidence of the sophistication of Homo neanderthalensis. And recent research suggests another overlooked mark of their ingenuity: they made the first glues in the form of tar.

headline: Why Is My Daughter Such a Drama Queen?
abstract: And: clothes before hellos; explaining a mysterious bodily odor; and the lady who lunched and brought leftovers home to her husband.
lead_paragraph: I have a brilliant, intense and dramatic daughter in her 30s who works in the theater in New York. I am a retired schoolteacher in the Midwest. She nurses many grievances against me that I don’t understand: If I don’t send her flowers on opening night, for instance. (I received no flowers for my decades in the classroom.) She is also unhappy if I don’t praise every play she’s involved with. (Some I like; some I don’t.) I come from a working-class family who worked hard and never sought praise for our labor. So, we’re stuck in an ugly pattern. Advice?

headline: N.F.L. Expands Use of Chips in Footballs, Promising Data Trove
abstract: The league is taking another step in tracking players’ performance with a microchip inside every game ball.
lead_paragraph: Football is all about getting the ball over the goal line. Now teams will know more than ever about how the ball got there.

headline: A Succulent Brisket Almost as Good as Mom’s
abstract: It may not be the same, but a version seasoned with spices, topped with tons of caramelized onions, gets close to a beloved original.
lead_paragraph: Brisket, for me, is an aromatic memory. The scent of it wafted through my childhood home for hours as the meat braised slowly, with the familiar bouquet of bay leaf and onion, the beefy perfume of the simmering broth.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Treasures from Native artists of North America, a structure with a rotting organic foundation and a trip back to photorealismville are on offer this week.
lead_paragraph: Through Oct. 8. Metropolitan Museum of Art; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.

headline: Gene Michael, Whose Yankee Teams Won 4 World Series, Dies at 79
abstract: A former shortstop, Michael rose to general manager under a mercurial George Steinbrenner and built powerful teams starting in the mid-’90s.
lead_paragraph: Gene Michael, a Yankee for nearly a half-century, rising from sure-handed shortstop to general manager and building teams that won four World Series championships, died on Thursday at his home in Oldsmar, Fla. He was 79.

headline: In Brooklyn’s District Attorney Race, the Focus Isn’t on Prosecuting Crime
abstract: The six candidates seem to believe the surest way to win votes is not to vow to lock people up, but to offer policies to keep them out of jail.
lead_paragraph: It is a sign of the times — and perhaps of a place — that for several months now the six lawyers running for Brooklyn district attorney have rarely mentioned what has, at least historically, been the central issue in law-enforcement races: fighting crime.

headline: Graydon Carter to End 25-Year Run as Vanity Fair’s Editor
abstract: When he steps down in December, Mr. Carter will leave the role that established him as a celebrity in his own right and a ringmaster of the spheres of Hollywood, Washington and Manhattan media.
lead_paragraph: Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, plans to step down from the magazine in December after a 25-year tenure, leaving the role that established him as a ringmaster of the Hollywood, Washington and Manhattan power elite.

headline: Stream These Great Movies From Richard Linklater’s Diverse Career
abstract: Slipping in and out of mainstream and indie circles, director Richard Linklater has followed his curiosity through nearly every genre. Here are some of his best films available to stream.
lead_paragraph: Slipping in and out of mainstream and indie circles, director Richard Linklater has followed his curiosity through nearly every genre. Here are some of his best films available to stream.

headline: Steinbeck’s Heir Wins Lawsuit
abstract: A dispute that dragged on for years, and involved none of the author’s blood relatives, is settled.
lead_paragraph: A bitter family feud over John Steinbeck’s estate escalated this week, when a Los Angeles jury awarded the novelist’s stepdaughter, Waverly Scott Kaffaga, $13.15 million in damages in an intellectual property dispute. The defendant plans to appeal.

headline: Police Consider Releasing Body Camera Footage in Fatal Bronx Shooting
abstract: The encounter, which left a 31-year-old man dead, was the first fatal police shooting captured on city officers’ body cameras, and there is not yet a formal policy in place.
lead_paragraph: A day after officers shot a man in the Bronx, capturing a fatal police encounter on body cameras for the first time in New York, the police commissioner on Thursday was weighing whether to release the footage.

headline: The Times and Texas Hurricanes
abstract: When the great hurricane walloped Galveston 117 years ago, The New York Times was helpless. Hurricane Harvey posed its own challenges.
lead_paragraph: “Not a wire is working into Galveston, either telegraph or telephone, and as all bridges carried wires, the fears that all these structures are gone is strengthened,” The New York Times reported ominously on Sept. 9, 1900, a day after Galveston Island on the Gulf of Mexico was pummeled by what remains the deadliest hurricane in national history.

headline: Review: ‘Boris Without Beatrice’ Offers Modernity Laced With Mythology
abstract: She is struck with a melancholia that renders her unresponsive and takes a leave from her job. He goes about business as usual, until a stranger appears.
lead_paragraph: Ostentatiously peppering a shaggy-dog story with allusions to Greek myth — and, depending on how you take the title, Dante — the Quebecois director Denis Côté’s “Boris Without Beatrice” appears to have something to say about the hubris of the modern business tycoon, but it never coalesces into more than a self-amused goof.

headline: No Relief for Islamic State Convoy Blocked in Syria
abstract: “It has not reached Iraq and will not reach Iraq,” an American official said, though the military says food and water are reaching the militants and their families.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State convoy stranded in the middle of the Syrian desert has whittled down in size as the American military and Syrian government allies traded accusations on whether food and water were reaching the hundreds of beleaguered bus passengers.

headline: For a Hot Dog Vendor, It’s Open Season on Cheap Franks
abstract: During the U.S. Open, Tommy Chan’s usually sleepy hot dog hut, located just outside tournament grounds in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, thrives.
lead_paragraph: As New York City hot dog locations go, Tommy Chan’s vending spot in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens is a slow one.

headline: A Sportswriter, a Hall of Famer
abstract: The longtime New York Times sportswriter Harvey Araton will be honored by the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: For over a quarter of a century, Harvey Araton has written about basketball for The New York Times with great insight and creativity. On Thursday, he will be recognized for that body of work when he will be honored by the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., as part of its annual enshrinement ceremonies.

headline: JR’s Latest: A Child Caught Between the U.S.-Mexico Border
abstract: For his first installation in Mexico, the artist JR has pasted an image of a child overlooking the United States from the Mexico border. It’s viewable only from the northern side.
lead_paragraph: In Tecate, Mexico, a little boy with dark hair and curious eyes peers carefully over the barrier wall that borders San Diego County. Rising up almost 70 feet, his hands seemingly grip the barrier tightly, as if he were holding onto his mother’s body.

headline: The Fake Americans Russia Created to Influence the Election
abstract: Posing as ordinary citizens on Facebook and building “warlists” of Twitter accounts, suspected Russian agents intervened last year in the American democratic process.
