lead_paragraph: Sometimes an international offensive begins with a few shots that draw little notice. So it was last year when Melvin Redick of Harrisburg, Pa., a friendly-looking American with a backward baseball cap and a young daughter, posted on Facebook a link to a brand-new website.

headline: For Patrick McEnroe, the U.S. Open Is Home
abstract: Perhaps no sporting event is as linked to New York as the U.S. Open, and perhaps no duo is as linked to the U.S. Open as Patrick and John McEnroe.
lead_paragraph: McEnroe was smiling. McEnroe was happy. McEnroe was wading through a sea of fans, frequently stopping for a photograph or to sign an autograph or to offer a hug to an old friend.

headline: Novella Nelson, 78, Dies; Brought Authority to Myriad Roles
abstract: An actress whose face was more familiar than her name, Ms. Nelson was seen onstage, in movies and on television for a half-century.
lead_paragraph: Novella Nelson, a powerful and versatile actress whose long career included prominent roles in the hit Broadway musical “Purlie” in 1970 and the film “Antwone Fisher” more than 30 years later, died on Aug. 31 in Brooklyn. She was 78.

headline: A Bike for Every Kid
abstract: A Brooklyn bike shop owner starts a foundation to give adaptive bicycles to special-needs children.
lead_paragraph: It all started with a run — uphill, and against traffic.

headline: Britain’s Greatest Brexit Obstacle: Itself
abstract: Britain is supposed to be engaging in an epic battle with Brussels. But the fiercest battles are in London within the governing Conservative Party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For all the talk of an epic conflict between the European Union and Britain over its planned withdrawal, known as Brexit, there are, in fact, several battles underway.

headline: Review: A Good-Enough ‘La Fanciulla del West’ at New York City Opera
abstract: The soprano Kristin Sampson is a standout in this uninspiring staging of an often-underrated Puccini masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera’s production of Puccini’s “La Fanciulla del West,” which opened on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center, may not be great. But it’s good enough to get the job done.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: If the 21st-century world order has you longing for the comparatively clear politics of the Cold War, this is your lucky week: John le Carré has just published a new novel, “A Legacy of Spies.” (You can read an excerpt here.) If, on the other hand, you’re focused on the future, try Alissa Nutting’s zeitgeist tale set in too-close-for-comfort 2019, “Made for Love,” in which a woman runs away from the husband who’s implanted a surveillance chip in her brain. Other recommended novels this week: Gabriel Tallent’s acclaimed debut, “My Absolute Darling”; David Williams’s twist on “prepper” fiction, “When the English Fall”; and Louise Penny’s latest Three Pines mystery, “Glass Houses.” And if you’re getting excited for the big fall movies, you might want to dive into some Hollywood history with David Thomson’s “Warner Bros: The Making of an American Movie Studio.”

headline: Naomi Campbell Judges Voguing Ball. Tom Ford Parties on Park Avenue.
abstract: The makeup artist Pat McGrath holds a vogue ball with celebrity judges, while Tom Ford trots out shirtless waiters for his New York return.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist Pat McGrath holds a vogue ball with celebrity judges, while Tom Ford trots out shirtless waiters for his New York return.

headline: A Nurse Ratched Origin Story Comes to Netflix
abstract: The infamous nurse from “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” will be portrayed by Sarah Paulson in a new series executive produced by Ryan Murphy.
lead_paragraph: It’s back to the mental ward for Ryan Murphy and Sarah Paulson. The creator and star of “American Horror Story: Asylum” will collaborate once again on “Ratched,” a Netflix series about the origins of the infamous “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” character Nurse Ratched.

headline: Review: ‘Pinocchio,’ the Opera, Is a Hit for a Renovated Theater
abstract: Brussels’s opera house, La Monnaie, reopened after two years with Philippe Boesmans’ darkly entertaining adaptation of the classic story.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A major opera house opened its season with a contemporary work on Wednesday. And when the lights went up, the stormiest ovations weren’t for an eminent maestro or famous diva, but for the 81-year-old composer. It’s undeniable: Philippe Boesmans’ “Pinocchio,” which inaugurated the newly renovated La Monnaie theater here, is a hit.

headline: The Odd Timing of City Elections in New York
abstract: Since the 1800s, the city’s voting schedule has changed at the whim of opportunistic state politicians looking to take advantage of voting trends.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are city elections held in odd-numbered years, rather than on the same schedule as state and federal elections?

headline: Shining a Light on Campus Rape
abstract: Vanessa Grigoriadis’s fascinating but often frustrating “Blurred Lines” is a kaleidoscopic tour through the campus sexual assault controversy.
lead_paragraph: BLURRED LINESRethinking Sex, Power and Consent on CampusBy Vanessa Grigoriadis332 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $28.

headline: An 88-Foot-High Keith Haring Mural Is Restored in Paris
abstract: The artwork, “Tower,” is on the exterior of a stairwell at the Necker-Enfants Malades hospital in Paris’s 15th arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: “I made this painting to amuse the sick children in this hospital, now and in the future,” the American artist Keith Haring wrote in his diary in 1987. He had just spent several days leaning off a crane, as he and his boyfriend Juan Rivera painted the exterior of a stairwell at the Necker-Enfants Malades hospital in Paris’s 15th arrondissement.

headline: Pope Francis Urges Colombia to Seize ‘Second Chance’
abstract: On the second day of his six-day visit, the pope sought to bolster support for a peace deal between the government and the country’s main rebel group.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Leading prayers before a huge crowd in Bogotá, the capital, Pope Francis on Thursday urged Colombians to avoid “the thirst for revenge” and finally accept peace, whose arrival last year ended a half-century of war but left the country bitterly divided.

headline: Review: In ‘School Life,’ Teachers Who Make All the Difference
abstract: A documentary captures the routines of an Irish boarding school and two of its cherished teachers.
lead_paragraph: John and Amanda Leyden have taught at Headfort School in Kells, Ireland, for so long than the headmaster, Dermot Dix, recognizes at one point that Ms. Leyden is using the same children’s novel that she taught his class many years ago. Neasa Ni Chianain and David Rane’s documentary “School Life” is a loving portrait, primarily, of the inspirational educator couple, who command the respect of their students and always seem to know what a particular child needs to hear.

headline: Review: Falcons and Falconers in the Desert of Qatar
abstract: The new documentary “The Challenge” observes the leisure pursuits of a group of rich young men.
lead_paragraph: There are images in “The Challenge,” a compact, intriguing documentary by Yuri Ancarani, that seem to belong less to a nonfiction film than to a hallucination. A group of falcons, hooded and tethered to their man-made roosts, sits in the cabin of a private jet. A cheetah (unless it’s a jaguar) lounges in the passenger seat of a black Lamborghini.

headline: Why Bats Crash Into Buildings
abstract: Smooth, vertical plates — like those in skyscrapers and other human structures — can fool bats into thinking they are flying in open air, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Bat echolocation is a finely tuned sense. By emitting high-frequency calls and listening for returning echoes, bats can deftly navigate complex surroundings and precisely target moving prey in the dark. They can even discriminate differences of less than one millimeter in surface textures.

headline: Review: All Is Not Well in ‘Company Town’
abstract: Sick residents, environmental pollution and questions of corporate accountability in a small town in Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Company Town,” by Natalie Kottke-Masocco and Erica Sardarian, feels fueled by pure desperation; even the rudimentary qualities of the filmmaking (cheap-looking camera work, poorly punctuated title cards) somehow add to its urgency, as if the movie needed to get its message out by any means necessary.

headline: Good Writing Matters, Mr. President
abstract: Readers say this holds true, even on Twitter and email.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Awakening of Colin Kaepernick
abstract: In college, Kaepernick began a journey that led him to his position as one of the most prominent, if divisive, social activists in sports.
lead_paragraph: The standout college quarterback went to the meeting alone that winter night, looking to join. The fraternity brothers at Kappa Alpha Psi, a predominantly black fraternity with a small chapter at the University of Nevada, knew who he was. He was a tall, lean, biracial junior, less than a year from graduating with a business degree.

headline: New York’s Mayoral Race
abstract: The Campaign Finance Board writes that “a debate can do little to transform the race.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Top of the Lake: China Girl’ Soaks in Mood More Than Logic
abstract: Elisabeth Moss returns for Season 2 of the Jane Campion crime series.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Moss is a vessel for cultural misogyny. Her TV characters have been harassed, sexually assaulted, threatened, degraded, lied to and betrayed. How much sexist abuse can befall one person? Oh, plenty. Between “Mad Men,” in which she played the ambitious but put-upon Peggy Olsen; “Top of the Lake,” in which she plays sex-crimes detective Robin Griffin; and “The Handmaid’s Tale,” in which she plays the enslaved Offred, one can watch Ms. Moss survive sexist torture in stories set in the past, the present and the crypto future.

headline: 2026 World Cup Bid Will Consider 41 Cities
abstract: The list from the joint U.S.-Canada-Mexico bid includes a wide range of cities but, like the tournament itself, is tilted heavily toward the United States.
lead_paragraph: Forty-one cities — nearly every market identified as a potential venue by organizers bidding to host the 2026 World Cup in North America — have submitted formal proposals to stage matches in the tournament, bid officials said Thursday.

headline: New York DNA Crime Lab
abstract: The city’s chief medical examiner discusses upgraded technology to comply with new F.B.I. requirements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Senate Votes to Raise Debt Limit and Approves $15 Billion in Hurricane Relief
abstract: The Republican-led chamber reluctantly approved the new debt ceiling after the surprising deal reached by President Trump and the Democratic leadership on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican-led Senate on Thursday approved legislation to raise the debt limit and keep the government funded until December while providing $15 billion in disaster aid, giving a reluctant stamp of approval to the surprising deal that President Trump struck with Democratic congressional leaders.

headline: Nordea May Be Snubbing Sweden, but Investors Should Not
abstract: Swedish banks’ generous dividends are attractive – and if Nordea’s move to Finland leads to lighter regulation, they may get more so.
lead_paragraph: The likes of Swedish banks S.E.B., Handelsbanken and Nordea are stable, well capitalized and dull. Investors have spurned them in favor of eurozone banks. Yet the banks’ generous dividends are attractive – and if Nordea’s move to Finland leads to lighter regulation, they may get more so.

headline: In Hurricane Irma’s Ruinous Wake: ‘I Feel Like I’m on the Moon’
abstract: Images show the extent of the devastation in the eastern Caribbean islands directly in the path of Hurricane Irma.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest with Saturday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.

headline: In a Topsy-Turvy World, Fashion Finds Solace in the Mundane
abstract: The season’s men’s wear is wonderfully, plainly normal.
lead_paragraph: For her most recent fall/winter men’s wear show, Miuccia Prada eschewed a dramatic, spectacular set, presenting her collection instead in an environment that recalled a dorm room, with beds and low tiled walls decorated with images that looked cut from a magazine. The clothes, too, were understated and unfussy: hand-woven sweaters, trench coats in tweed and suede, corduroy slacks, brown blazers. Backstage, Prada talked about intimacy, about the idea of going from big to small: from ‘‘the big deal of fashion, the big deal of art, the big deal of everything — to the opposite.’’

headline: Disney Plots Streaming, From ‘Star Wars’ and Marvel to Pay-Per-Sports
abstract: All new-release movies made by Walt Disney Studios will be on the movie and TV service, while sports programming may come á la carte.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney’s two planned streaming services took clearer shape on Thursday, as the entertainment giant vowed to bring “Star Wars” and Marvel movies to one and proposed a novel approach to the other: sports á la carte.

headline: New Backpacks and Beginnings
abstract: The new school year started for 1.1 million students at New York City public schools on Thursday. For many, that meant managing first-day jitters and meeting old, and new, friends.
lead_paragraph: New pencils (do they still use pencils?), bright backpacks (they still have those) and first-day jitters: Back to school is upon us. For the little ones entering classrooms for the first time, there may be tears. But for the veterans like middle schoolers and high school teens, there is stoicism. Crisp in uniforms or clad in trendy clothes — a sort of schoolyard armor — they stride out of summer and over zebra street crossings with purpose, catching up with old friends, and perhaps, for a secret second, grasping a parent’s hand.

headline: Trump’s Debt Deal With the Democrats
abstract: A reader surprises himself by offering praise for the president. Others worry about Mr. Trump’s “self-interest” and politicizing the debt ceiling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Not to Raise a Ray of Sunshine
abstract: The preschool assigned children the job of Class Sunshine, but I wanted my daughter to feel free to be Class Dark Cloud if she wanted.
lead_paragraph: When I was 24, I moved into a 645-square-foot apartment on New York’s unfashionable Upper East Side, which I shared with a roommate. The nicest thing about the place was the view from the kitchen window. It looked out over the white steeple of a Unitarian church with a sign out front that read: “We’re in the business of serving — not saving — souls.” I could hear the kids from its preschool laughing at recess on the rooftop playground when I worked from home. I’d see the little ones lining up in the mornings, and moms in yoga pants pushing strollers into the church courtyard. Hopelessly single for much of the decade I lived in that apartment, I dreamed that one day I’d have a child I could walk around the corner to preschool.

headline: 4 Takeaways From The Times’s Interview With Paul Ryan
abstract: The House speaker talked about the coming tax overhaul effort, what it’s like to work with President Trump, and how Congress can pick up its pace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan participated in a TimesTalks conversation in Washington on Thursday. He discussed the coming tax overhaul effort, immigration, this week’s surprise debt limit deal and what it’s like to work with President Trump.

headline: Arie Luyendyk Jr. Is the New ‘Bachelor.’ Wait, Who?
abstract: “This just fit perfect, the timing of this really fit,” said Mr. Luyendyk, a racecar driver from Arizona. Many fans weren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: It was the announcement fans of “The Bachelor” were waiting for, except ... it wasn’t.

headline: Bag? Check. Racket? Check. Dog? Of Course.
abstract: Dogs are more than accessories or travel companions on the pro tennis tour. Some players are registering them as emotional support animals, vital to surviving life on the road.
lead_paragraph: When Svetlana Kuznetsova had to leave her dog, Dolce, at home in Russia this spring when she left for a tournament in California, she cried.

headline: Hurricane Irma: Assessing the Damage, and What’s Next
abstract: The storm, weakened and downgraded, has inundated Florida with rain and lashing winds and is working its way through the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Irma, now a tropical storm, is weakening, but dangers still remain as it tears a path through the Southeast with rain and lashing winds. The Times, which has journalists deployed through the region, is providing free digital access to all storm news.

headline: Betsy DeVos Says She Will Rewrite Rules on Campus Sex Assault
abstract: The education secretary said in a speech that the Obama administration had gone too far and had forced colleges to deprive accused students of their rights.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Saying that the Obama administration’s approach to policing campus sexual assault had “failed too many students,” Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said on Thursday that her administration would rewrite the rules in an effort to protect both the victims of sexual assault and the accused.

headline: Harvey and Irma, Married 75 Years, Marvel at the Storms Bearing Their Names
abstract: Harvey and Irma Schluter are 104 and 92 years old. Never before have two storms bearing their names followed each other.
lead_paragraph: Harvey and Irma Schluter have been married for 75 years. He turned 104 in July; she will be 93 in November.

headline: T Fashion Editors’ Guide to New York
abstract: A short list of places to relax, enjoy a meal, shop a bit — and find some peace between the shows during fashion week (and always).

headline: Shimon Peres, in Memoir, Takes On Israel Past and Future
abstract: A year after his death, the last of the founding generation of Israel’s leaders describes a life “entwined with the birth and construction of Israel.”
lead_paragraph: JAFFA, Israel — The ousted French prime minister had just signed the letter authorizing the sale of a nuclear reactor to Israel — for peaceful purposes, he had been assured — even though he no longer had the authority to do so.

headline: N.F.L. Predictions: Who We Pick to Win in Week 1
abstract: The N.F.L. kicks off with some strong matchups, including the Seahawks at Packers and the Giants at Cowboys. Here’s who we think will win.
lead_paragraph: It was a difficult off-season for the N.F.L. The league continued to have issues with player discipline off the field, concussions studies confirmed some of the worst fears for many retired players, and a continuing debate about national anthem protests factored into quarterback Colin Kaepernick’s not currently being on any N.F.L. roster.

headline: Hurricane Irma, North Korea, Amazon: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Struggle After the Storm
abstract: The survivors of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma have a long, painful recovery ahead of them. I’ve been there.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly 12 years ago, in October 2005, I made a fearful, six-hour drive from Houston to my New Orleans home. My neighborhood had simmered in flood water for weeks after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: From an Undervalued Region in France, New Energy, New Inspiration and Great Wines
abstract: A younger generation of winemakers has created reasons to care about Cahors.
lead_paragraph: PRAYSSAC, France — Back in 1975, Jean-Marie Sigaud had a brilliant idea.

headline: Roger Waters: Congress Shouldn’t Silence Human Rights Advocates
abstract: Lawmakers from both parties want to criminalize boycotting Israel. That’s un-American.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress are currently considering a bill that threatens to silence the growing support for the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement for Palestinian freedom and human rights, known as B.D.S. This draconian bill, the Israel Anti-Boycott Act, threatens individuals and businesses who actively participate in boycott campaigns in support of Palestinian rights conducted by international governmental organizations with up to 20 years in prison and a $1,000,000 fine.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: And do you like wordplay? Or humor? Or Bambi? What kind of monster doesn’t like those things?
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Subway Riders Beware: Littering Fines Will Double to $100
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the change will help reduce rail fires caused by garbage on subway tracks. Increased fines will go into effect on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Fines for littering in New York City’s subway will double to $100 from $50 next week, the latest move by transit officials to address the problems afflicting the city’s fraying subway system.

headline: Brock Collection: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Hurricane Jose Is Next on Radar, With Fresh Alert for Antigua and Barbuda
abstract: A day after Irma devastated Barbuda, a second storm threatens the tiny two-island nation. Meanwhile, Hurricane Katia churns toward Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest with Friday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.

headline: Tom Ford Wants You to Be Really Fabulous
abstract: Fashion’s most unfiltered designer returns to New York with an extravagant fashion show and a heady new fragrance.
lead_paragraph: Tom Ford, one of fashion’s most passionate proponents of sex, glamour and dressing for both, returned to New York Fashion Week on Wednesday night with a runway show calibrated for maximum oomph: a collection modeled by Amazons (Gigi Hadid, Kendall Jenner and Joan Smalls, among them) amply bedazzled but often without pants; Kim Kardashian West and Chaka Khan planted in the front row; and the air thick with the heady scent of Mr. Ford’s new fragrance, called, in a perfect Tom Fordism, “[Expletive] Fabulous.” (The expletive is an amplifying adjective; suffice it to say that Mr. Ford enjoys alliteration.) The fragrance is available in Tom Ford boutiques and at tomford.com.

headline: Emmanuel Macron, in Greece, Calls for ‘Rebuilding’ E.U.
abstract: “We have lost our ambition,” the French leader said on his first state visit to Greece, calling for a more united Europe in a speech short on specifics.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In an appearance filled with symbolism on his first state visit to Greece , President Emmanuel Macron of France on Thursday outlined his vision for a stronger, more united Europe from the heart of the country whose severe financial problems threatened the viability of the euro.

headline: Equifax Says Cyberattack May Have Affected 143 Million in the U.S.
abstract: Criminals gained access to certain files in the company’s system from mid-May to July, according to an investigation by Equifax.
lead_paragraph: Equifax, one of the three major consumer credit reporting agencies, said on Thursday that hackers had gained access to company data that potentially compromised sensitive information for 143 million American consumers, including Social Security numbers and driver’s license numbers.

headline: For DACA Recipients, Losing Protection and Work Permits Is Just the Start
abstract: The rollback of the DACA program could disrupt many other aspects of immigrants’ lives, like health coverage, financial aid and driving privileges.
lead_paragraph: It is not just the threat of deportation that is hanging over Amparo Gonzalez. The 31-year-old single mother could also lose her job at a warehouse company, even if she stays in the country. With it would go the health insurance she gets through her employer, which covers her 13-year-old daughter, as well as the exams and treatments that Ms. Gonzalez needs for her chronic colon disease.

headline: A French Interior Designer Tries His Hand at Furniture
abstract: On Thursday, Pierre Yovanovitch launches his own pieces for the home — in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The renowned French interior designer Pierre Yovanovitch has launched his debut furniture collection and opened his first public exhibition in the United States under the name “Oops,” of all monikers. He explains that word was his response when the R & Company gallery in TriBeCa, asked him to temporarily take over their space this fall (in French, “oops” often expresses surprise or being caught off guard). “The idea had been to create an installation using the furniture there and maybe some of my pieces,” Yovanovitch says. “But it became mostly my furniture — made especially for this. And, in the process, I realized you say ‘oops’ a lot of times during the day.”

headline: Staten Island, for Locals
abstract: Gareth Smit, a South African photographer, discovered the North Shore of the “forgotten borough” when working on a project about the death of Eric Garner.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Gareth Smit moved to New York City from South Africa to study photography. His first subject was Eric Garner, or rather the memory of Eric Garner, a black man who was killed by Officer Daniel Pantaleo on July 17, 2014, on the North Shore of Staten Island, across the street from Tompkinsville Park.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: For the New Cadillac, Now Comes the Real Test
abstract: The first tangible products from a revamped Cadillac under Johan de Nysschen will soon come to the market.
lead_paragraph: For the last three years, Johan de Nysschen has led a daring effort to revive Cadillac, the storied but tarnished luxury-car brand of General Motors.

headline: Off the Runway: Desigual, Cinq à Sept, Collina Strada and More
abstract: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Toast to Summer
abstract: The Hampton Classic Grand Prix caps off the East End social season; the 9/11 Memorial & Museum benefit dinner is held in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Hampton Classic Grand Prix caps off the East End social season; the 9/11 Memorial & Museum benefit dinner is held in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

headline: Katrina Lenk Can Quietly Break Your Heart
abstract: Ms. Lenk, who will reprise her role in “The Band’s Visit” on Broadway, has mastered the art of delivering equal emotional weight in song or in silence.
lead_paragraph: Quiet may well be the new loud in the world of show tunes. Unexpectedly, one of last season’s most acclaimed new musicals, “The Band’s Visit,” did not feature flashy choreography or cathartic 11 o’clock belters. Based on the 2007 art house film of the same title, the show, which played Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater, is a low-key charmer in which looking at someone in silence carries as much emotional weight as delivering one of David Yazbek’s insidiously catchy songs.

headline: Will the Old Gay Play Have Something New to Say?
abstract: A spate of revivals will allow audiences to consider what’s changed, what hasn’t, and what Bob Mackie has in the sequin drawer.
lead_paragraph: Many of us who arrived in New York in the last decades of the last century, looking to the theater for news about what it meant to be gay, found ourselves serially disheartened.

headline: Reinventing Shakespeare, According to the Gospel of Joseph Papp
abstract: A new play about Papp, the founder of the Public Theater, sets the tone for a season of audacious interpretations of the Shakespeare canon.
lead_paragraph: All the world loves a David and Goliath story, especially when a scrappy little David goes on to become a towering Goliath in his own right. Such is the tale of Joseph Papp, the man who took on City Hall — and the powerful urban planner Robert Moses, and the perhaps even more powerful preconceptions of the cultural ownership of one William Shakespeare — to become a titan of contemporary American theater.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: For Meningitis B Vaccines, Climbing Revenue, and Plenty of Skepticism
abstract: Two drug firms have developed pricey vaccines they are advertising widely on TV, raising concerns among experts that they are stoking parents’ fears about a rare disease unnecessarily.
lead_paragraph: Small college outbreaks four years ago of meningitis B — an extremely rare variation of the dangerous infection — have set off a lucrative new business: persuading parents that pricey vaccines are a loving investment for their college-bound children.

headline: Still Ready for Her Closeup
abstract: A bank teller helps a film star with a transaction.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: Getty Images Grant Winners Announced for 2017
abstract: Photographers working on personal projects focused on underreported social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2017 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.
lead_paragraph: Photographers working on personal projects focused on underreported social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2017 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.

headline: Getty Images Grant Winners Announced for 2017
abstract: Photographers working on personal projects focused on underreported social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2017 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Photographers working on personal projects focused on underreported social issues, from poverty in Venezuela to sperm smuggling, received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2017 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.

headline: Dance in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to dance performances.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Montana Battles Wildfires Amid a Severe Drought
abstract: The fire season was extreme this year in Montana, and it is not over yet. Thousands of people have been evacuated, and two firefighters have died.
lead_paragraph: Montana has been burning for months, and there is still no end in sight.

headline: Film Series in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: 5 New Designers to Watch This Season
abstract: Amid it all, a handful of new designers are debuting collections.
lead_paragraph: Designer: Snow Xue Gao

headline: Next Repair at Penn Station: Fixing Those ‘Disgusting’ Bathrooms
abstract: Amtrak officials said they would overhaul the restrooms inside Pennsylvania Station that have evoked harsh critiques from users.
lead_paragraph: Now that the summer that was not very hellish is over and Amtrak officials have restored normal operations at Pennsylvania Station, they are turning their attention to the most reviled places in the building: the bathrooms.

headline: New Round of Contracts Is Issued for Border Wall Prototypes
abstract: The contracts are the latest step in President Trump’s bid to build a wall along the border with Mexico, a central campaign issue for him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new round of contracts has been awarded to build prototypes for a wall along the border with Mexico, the Department of Homeland Security announced on Thursday.

headline: Caribbean, Florida, Patriots: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to new art shows, and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to art shows that will be closing soon in New York City museums and galleries.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Where to Evacuate: Irma Inspires a Travel Search
abstract: Airfares temporarily shot up and cruises were canceled as evacuees took to the road.
lead_paragraph: For many families in South Florida and Georgia, evacuating for a hurricane has become somewhat of an ordinary routine. Dealing with last minute airfare, pet-friendly accommodations and overwhelming lines for gas is par for the course.

headline: After Harvey, a Grim Hunt in Texas for Those Still Missing
abstract: Police in Houston say more than 20 people remain unaccounted for, and efforts to find them have been complicated by post-storm chaos.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They found Jill Renick’s dog, Sweet Pea, at the Omni Houston Hotel. They found her car. But they did not find Ms. Renick until Thursday — 11 days after she went missing.

headline: It’s the DACA Decision, Not Hurricane Harvey, That May Tear Houston Apart
abstract: Jeff Sessions called the choice to end DACA “the compassionate thing.” But that doesn’t look like any kind of compassion I’ve seen here.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As the floodwaters rose in my west Houston neighborhood after Hurricane Harvey landed, my husband and many of our neighbors pulled boats through waist-high water, knocked on doors and plucked people from their submerged houses. They rescued elderly couples, young roommates, families who do not speak English. There was no checking of IDs, no debate on whether a life was worth saving.

headline: F.D.A. Accuses EpiPen Maker of Failing to Investigate Malfunctions
abstract: The agency said Pfizer ignored hundreds of complaints that the device failed to operate in life-threatening emergencies, including incidents when patients died.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration this week accused the drugmaker Pfizer of failing to properly investigate reports of malfunctioning EpiPens, including incidents when patients died or became severely ill after the device failed to work. Pfizer manufactures the EpiPen, which treats allergic reactions, for the drugmaker Mylan.

headline: Do You Have DACA Students? We’d Like to Hear From You
abstract: How will your work be affected by the president’s decision?
lead_paragraph: How will your work be affected by the president’s decision?

headline: The Book That Made Us Feminists
abstract: Betty Friedan pointed out the problem that had no name. In “Sexual Politics,” Kate Millett named it and explained its cause.
lead_paragraph: I was 19 years old when I bought a first edition of “Sexual Politics” in 1970. Kate Millett’s first book, published the year before, was that unlikeliest phenomenon — a dissertation heard around the world. What I remember most about that year was the dizzying experience of reading Ms. Millett, who died on Wednesday, and the new theories of her sister feminists that came in its wake. Like one of Yayoi Kusama’s “Infinity Rooms,” my consciousness, and that of the women I knew, gained new dimensions.

headline: Eight Years Later, del Potro Faces Same Daunting Task at U.S. Open
abstract: Juan Martín del Potro will have to beat Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal again in New York if he is to have a chance to win a second Grand Slam title.
lead_paragraph: Despite all that natural power and innate talent, despite those world-class nerves and his imposing physique, Juan Martín del Potro never seems to have it easy.

headline: Safety Workers Sickened by Fumes Sue Texas Chemical Plant
abstract: The workers said Arkema, where chemicals exploded after Hurricane Harvey, failed to warn them of potential risks at the site. They are seeking more than $1 million.
lead_paragraph: Seven emergency workers filed suit on Monday against the French chemical company Arkema, saying they were sickened by fumes from explosions last week at the company’s flood-stricken plant near Houston. They say they were not given ample warning of the dangers from volatile chemicals stored at the plant.

headline: Governors Rally Around Health Law Fixes as White House Pushes Repeal
abstract: Governors from both parties testified before the Senate on behalf of modest changes to the Affordable Care Act, but the White House and some senators have not given up on repeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Governors from both political parties told Congress on Thursday that they supported immediate action on modest, bipartisan steps to repair the Affordable Care Act without repealing it, even as the Trump administration continued to encourage efforts to dismantle the law.

headline: Online Chats Tie Politicians to the Troll of Staten Island
abstract: Despite their denials, web conversations reveal that two borough candidates knew a political operative was creating phony Facebook pages to tar their opponents.
lead_paragraph: Russian trolls had the run of Facebook and Twitter last year, it now emerges, spinning up thousands of phony accounts to spread propaganda during the election, weigh in on political issues, place ads.

headline: After Marriott Breach, How to Protect Your Information Online
abstract: There are more reasons than ever to protect your personal information, as major website breaches become ever more frequent.
lead_paragraph: There are more reasons than ever to protect your personal information, as major website breaches become ever more frequent.

headline: The Debt Ceiling: Why We Have It, and What Would Happen if It Died
abstract: President Trump made one debt limit deal this week, but apparently he has another one in mind: doing away with the debt ceiling entirely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump made one debt limit deal this week, but apparently he has another one in mind: doing away with the debt limit entirely.

headline: How the U.S. Could Respond to Another North Korean Missile Test
abstract: President Trump has both military and nonmilitary options. Each has its own downside.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s prime minister is saying publicly what American officials will not: In the next few days, intelligence reports predict, North Korea will launch another intercontinental ballistic missile.

headline: With Racket and Voice, Kevin Anderson Looks to Make Noise at U.S. Open
abstract: A usually stoic athlete is approaching his semifinal as a new, demonstrably more vocal player, tapping into another side of his on-court personality.
lead_paragraph: Going into his first Grand Slam semifinal at the United States Open on Friday, the veteran Kevin Anderson is playing some of the best tennis of his career, and certainly the loudest.

headline: In Florida, Searching for Gas and Water, and Watching Irma
abstract: Residents across South Florida scrambled to prepare for the hurricane. Gas, water, plywood and sandbags were in short supply.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Fuel was such a scarce commodity that some drivers took to trailing gas tankers down the road to see where they stopped to unload. Bottled water was so scarce that residents simply gave up looking. Sandbags, like plywood, were gone, as were certain kinds of screws and nails.

headline: Caribbean Devastated as Irma Heads Toward Florida
abstract: The storm turned beach paradises into half-habitable emergency zones as it headed toward Florida, where panicked residents were scrambling to find gasoline and water.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — One of the most powerful Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded crescendoed over the Caribbean on Thursday, crumpling islands better known as beach paradises into half-habitable emergency zones and sideswiping Puerto Rico before churning north. It is expected to hit the Florida Keys and South Florida by Saturday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Penn Station’s To-Do List Adds a Foul-Smelling Task
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 8, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t think of a single worse public restroom that I’ve ever been in in my entire life.”

headline: Graydon Carter’s Singular Impact on Culture and Media
abstract: Mr. Carter’s 25-year tenure at Vanity Fair established him as a ringmaster of Hollywood and Manhattan society. But his influence went beyond a monthly magazine and into the realms of literature, politics, and pop culture.
lead_paragraph: Graydon Carter’s 25-year tenure at Vanity Fair, which he announced on Thursday would come to a close in December, established him as a ringmaster of Hollywood and Manhattan society. But his influence went beyond a monthly magazine and into the realms of literature, politics, and pop culture.

headline: Adam Selman: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: His Bravery Unsung, Varian Fry Acted to Save Jews
abstract: In 1940, a young Manhattan editor rescued thousands of refugees from the Nazis, bringing many to America. His life has special resonance today.
lead_paragraph: In June of 1935, two years after the German government falsely portrayed the burning of the Reichstag as a Communist plot to overthrow the state and just at the moment that it had banned all but “Aryans’’ from serving in the military and made homosexuality a crime, Varian Fry, a young Manhattan editor who was preparing to take over a magazine called The Living Age, traveled to Berlin.

headline: ‘This One Was for Stick’: Yankees Do Gene Michael’s Legacy Proud
abstract: The Yanks’ spirited play and four homers were a fitting tribute to an ex-player, manager and general manager for the franchise who died Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Yankees took the field at Camden Yards on Thursday afternoon wearing the traditional symbol of mourning, a black armband on the left sleeve of their uniforms in honor of Gene Michael, a former player, manager, general manager and superscout for the team who died of a heart attack earlier in the day at 79.

headline: ‘We Have Nothing Left’: Islanders Survey Irma’s Destruction
abstract: Two residents from St. Martin island's two nations, the French St. Martin and the Dutch St. Maarten, describe Irma’s destruction.
lead_paragraph: Two residents from St. Martin island's two nations, the French St. Martin and the Dutch St. Maarten, describe Irma’s destruction.

headline: Hillary Clinton, in Book, Regrets Not Striking Back at James Comey
abstract: The regret is one of a catalog of mistakes — large and small — that Mrs. Clinton lists in the election post-mortem “What Happened.”
lead_paragraph: In an angry, unsparing new book, Hillary Clinton said she regretted not striking back at James B. Comey in July 2016, when he accused her of acting recklessly in using a private email account while secretary of state, even as he announced that the F.B.I. would not seek criminal charges against her.

headline: Matt Harvey Registers His First Win for the Mets Since May 28
abstract: In his second start since coming back from the disabled list, Harvey pitched five innings against the Reds and allowed five hits, two runs and a walk while striking out one batter.
lead_paragraph: With his arm tucked into a large black sling, David Wright made a surprise appearance on Thursday at Citi Field before the Mets’ game against the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: Navy Ships Kept at Sea Despite Training and Maintenance Needs, Admiral Says
abstract: Crews and commanders have little time to train and ships go without maintenance because of growing demands in the Pacific, a top admiral told lawmakers on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a string of deadly accidents in the western Pacific, a top admiral acknowledged on Thursday that the Navy had knowingly operated warships there despite a growing number of major training and maintenance shortfalls — all to meet increasing operational demands.

headline: Patriots Fans Mock Roger Goodell Before Loss to Chiefs
abstract: The N.F.L. commissioner was a target of derision after suspending quarterback Tom Brady for the start of the team’s Super Bowl-winning season last year.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Sports commissioners love to be on hand for happy events like opening days and title games. They are also used to fans booing them for slights real and perceived.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Discuss Campaign and New Book on Colbert’s ‘Late Show’
abstract: Mrs. Clinton will talk about her failed bid for the White House and more in her first late-night TV appearance since the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: “What happened,” you ask?

headline: Appeals Court Limits Trump Travel Ban and Allows More Refugees
abstract: The court exempted grandparents, other family members and thousands of refugees from President Trump’s travel ban, now under Supreme Court review.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court on Thursday reopened the country’s door to thousands of refugees who had been temporarily blocked by President Trump’s travel ban, and also upheld a lower court decision that had exempted grandparents and other relatives from the ban.

headline: Sardinas and Sangria
abstract: Is it Friday already?
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Three-day weekends always mess up my internal calendar. Especially when they come at the end of a three-week road trip. Anyway, it’s time for a fairly crunchy themeless by Sam Trabucco. My solve, at least, was impeded by a couple of spots I call “knotholes,” areas that I found tougher than the grid-at-large. That’s what makes Friday and Saturday puzzles so challenging. Not knowing one or two entries can make a huge difference.

headline: Corrections: September 8, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, September 8, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Sloane Stephens and Madison Keys Reach U.S. Open Final
abstract: Stephens outlasted Venus Williams, 6-1, 0-6, 7-5, and Keys routed CoCo Vandeweghe, 6-1, 6-2, in a pair of all-American semifinals.
lead_paragraph: The four women wore pink, green, black and gray, and they swatted yellow balls, but the theme inside Arthur Ashe Stadium on Thursday was decidedly red, white and blue.

headline: Dallas Can Remove Robert E. Lee Statue, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit to stop the city from taking down the monument. The plaintiffs argued that their First Amendment rights had been violated.
lead_paragraph: The City of Dallas can proceed again in taking down a statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee from a public park, a day after a federal judge halted the removal at the last minute.

headline: Italy's Ghost Towns
abstract: Almost 2,500 rural villages have nearly no one living in them at all.
lead_paragraph: Almost 2,500 rural villages have nearly no one living in them at all.

headline: Ex-U.S. Presidents Start Fund to Help Hurricane Harvey Victims
abstract: The campaign, One America Appeal, is expected to expand to help people affected by Hurricane Irma, which is expected to hit Florida this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The five living former United States presidents joined forces on Thursday to start a hurricane recovery effort to raise money for victims of Hurricane Harvey in Texas.

headline: Who Will Save These Dying Italian Towns?
abstract: Near-empty villages try to hold on to an endangered way of life — and some of the country’s most important artisanal traditions.
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST THING that must be said about the ancient town of Civita di Bagnoregio, just two hours away from Rome and Florence, is that it is beautiful. From a distance, it looks literally otherworldly: The town sits so high atop a perilously steep pinnacle of eroding volcanic rock that it seems as if it’s perched upon clouds rather than tethered to the earth. Its very sediment is strafed with 2,500 years of architectural history: Etruscan caves, ancient remains, medieval dwellings and Renaissance villas.

headline: Fashion Is a Little Obsessed With Cartoon Characters
abstract: A “Snoopy & Belle in Fashion” exhibition, emoji jewelry and a Marc Jacobs collaboration with Disney: Nostalgia is riding high.
lead_paragraph: He stands regally, decked out in a navy and tan 18th-century suit with ruffles peeking out from the sleeves and wrapping around his throat. His black shoes are polished, and his brass buttons are shined. And in back, prominent amid the folds of his coat, is his short white tail.

headline: Finding God in a Hot Slice of Pizza
abstract: After her divorce, a mother and son who had been living by the rules of Orthodox Judaism decide to test (and taste) a new world of possibilities.
lead_paragraph: “Do you really believe God cares about kosher pizza?” my 10-year-old son asked me as I was tucking him into bed.

headline: A Memoir of Dieting in the Age of Total Body Vigilance
abstract: In “Beautiful Bodies,” Kimberly Rae Miller recounts her lifelong addiction to deprivation through dieting.
lead_paragraph: BEAUTIFUL BODIES A Memoir By Kimberly Rae Miller 222 pp. Little A. $24.95.

headline: Hurricane Irma, Emmanuel Macron, ‘Brexit’: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Calvin Klein: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Revoke Shkreli’s Bail, Citing Post About Clinton
abstract: Martin Shkreli, the pharmaceutical executive already convicted of fraud, wrote online that he would pay $5,000 to anyone who grabbed a hair off Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli’s social-media habits have once again gotten him in serious trouble: A post of his about Hillary Clinton set off a Secret Service investigation and a request from federal prosecutors to revoke his bail because he poses “a risk of danger to the community.”

headline: The National: Something Out of Nothing
abstract: The Oscar-nominated director Marshall Curry takes you behind the scenes, in virtual reality, with the rock band the National as they record in their cozy studio and perform a frenetic live rock show.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-nominated director Marshall Curry takes you behind the scenes, in virtual reality, with the rock band the National as they record in their cozy studio and perform a frenetic live rock show.

headline: The National: Something Out of Nothing
abstract: Join the National onstage during an epic performance in Copenhagen and in a cozy Hudson Valley recording studio. This V.R. experience, directed by Oscar nominee Marshall Curry, follows the creative process as members of the band puzzle out their new album, “Sleep Well Beast.”
lead_paragraph: Join the National onstage during an epic performance in Copenhagen and in a cozy Hudson Valley recording studio. This V.R. experience, directed by Oscar nominee Marshall Curry, follows the creative process as members of the band puzzle out their new album, “Sleep Well Beast.”

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Wild Castles’ and ‘Gary Owen: I Got My Associates’
abstract: Smithsonian’s streaming platform offers a glimpse of ancient European castles, now home to wildlife. And the comedian Gary Owen gets a new stand-up special.
lead_paragraph: Smithsonian’s streaming platform offers a glimpse of ancient European castles and the wildlife now living in them. And the comedian Gary Owen gets personal in a new stand-up special.

headline: Word + Quiz: prosaic
abstract: This word has appeared in 72 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Mexico Earthquake, Strongest in a Century, Kills Dozens
abstract: The quake, which struck off the Pacific Coast, set off tsunami warnings and scattered frightened residents into the streets as far as Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: JUCHITÁN DE ZARAGOZA, Mexico — Thousands of homes in this city were severely damaged. Half of the 19th-century city hall, with its 30 arches, collapsed. The main hospital here was so devastated that staff members evacuated patients to an empty lot and worked by the light of their cellphones.

headline: Feet on a Map
abstract: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to recent news events?

headline: Right and Left on Trump’s Split With the Republican Leadership
abstract: Writers from across the political spectrum on President Trump’s deal with the Democrats and his strains with members of his own party.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Dreamers, Liars and Bad Economics
abstract: Trump and Sessions falsely justify a cruel action that hurts everyone except racists.
lead_paragraph: Does it matter that Jeff Sessions, the attorney general, tried to justify Donald Trump’s immigration cruelty with junk economics?

headline: Christine Todd Whitman: How Not to Run the E.P.A.
abstract: The agency is too important to treat like a reality TV show. People’s lives and our country’s resources are at stake.
lead_paragraph: I have been worried about how the Environmental Protection Agency would be run ever since President Trump appointed Scott Pruitt, the former attorney general of Oklahoma, to oversee it. The past few months have confirmed my fears. The agency created by a Republican president 47 years ago to protect the environment and public health may end up doing neither under Mr. Pruitt’s direction.

headline: Why the Return of Bigger Banks Means Bigger Risks for Everyone Else
abstract: The Trump administration has signaled to Wall Street that it needn’t worry about Dodd-Frank regulations.
lead_paragraph: Among the most appalling aspects of the financial collapse nine years ago was that no matter how reckless and predatory big financial institutions had been, they had grown so big and so interconnected that the federal government found itself forced to prop them up to avoid failures that would wreck the economy. The resulting bailouts, which included billions of dollars in bonuses for executives responsible for the fiasco, provoked deep public anger and became a rallying cry for populists on the right and the left.

headline: School Lunch Without Shame
abstract: New York is removing the stigma of free lunch by making it available to all 1.1 million students.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s public school system set an important national example this week when it made free lunch available to all of its 1.1 million students regardless of income level. The program ensures that more children will get proper nutrition during the school day. It will also relieve the sense of stigma and shame that often leads children to refuse subsidized meals — and go hungry — rather than let classmates find out that their families are poor.

headline: Hands Up. It’s Showtime.
abstract: Long before President Trump, the militarization of police was being shaped by fantasy and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been studying Americans’ accelerating penchant for blending the fantastical into the real world — from Disneyland to reality TV, from themed restaurants to war re-enactments to ubiquitous porn to Burning Man.

headline: How the Far Right Came to Love Hippie Food
abstract: Something that started in a wave of hope migrated to closed-minded, mercenary quarters.
lead_paragraph: Some time ago, I found myself in a buffet line around piles of inedible looking grains, greens and grassy-smelling gratins at an alternative food cooperative’s Sunday dinner. No part of this meal, I was assured, had been touched by the corporate food chain, the Big Ag puppeteers with their taxpayer-subsidized toxins.

headline: Swap DACA for Wall Funding? No Way!
abstract: Suddenly Trump and the Democrats are making deals. Here’s one the party should avoid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Suddenly, Washington is awash in talk about deal-making. On Wednesday, President Trump agreed with the Democrats on a plan to increase the debt limit and fund the government until December, enraging his Republican allies. This sudden thaw sets up the possibility of an even bigger deal: In exchange for making the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program permanent law, the Democrats would agree to maybe a couple of billion for the president’s beautiful wall on the border.

headline: What the Rich Won’t Tell You
abstract: “There’s nobody who knows how much we spend. You’re the only person I ever said those numbers to out loud.”
lead_paragraph: Over lunch in a downtown restaurant, Beatrice, a New Yorker in her late 30s, told me about two decisions she and her husband were considering. They were thinking about where to buy a second home and whether their young children should go to private school. Then she made a confession: She took the price tags off her clothes so that her nanny would not see them. “I take the label off our six-dollar bread,” she said.

headline: Netanyahu’s No-State Solution
abstract: Trump should emulate James Baker, who gave the White House switchboard number and told the Israelis: “When you’re serious about peace, call us.”
lead_paragraph: The leader is worried. He grows tetchy. Investigations are closing in on him. Former aides, even a family member, are suspected of corrupt dealings with a foreign company. He gets irritable, lashes out at “the left” and the “fake news media.” He claims there is a “witch hunt,” and raves about “a coup.” His tolerance for dissent is zero.

headline: Trinity Mirror Looks to Expand Tabloid Empire in U.K.
abstract: A deal to buy a rival group would shake up Britain’s fiercely competitive newspaper market and bring together outlets on opposite ends of the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The publisher of The Daily Mirror, a left-wing tabloid in Britain, said on Friday that it was negotiating to acquire the print assets of the Northern & Shell Media Group, in what would be a major shake-up of the country’s fiercely competitive newspaper market, bringing together outlets on opposite ends of the political spectrum.

headline: How Closely Do Your Parents Monitor Your App Use?
abstract: Should parents supervise their children’s apps? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever had a parent or caregiver ask to see your Instagram or Snap photos, or follow you on social media? Have they ever asked to see what new apps you have on your phone and asked for access to them?

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Hurricane Irma Devastates Caribbean and Heads Toward Florida’
abstract: Where has Irma hit and done damage so far? Where has the impact been worst?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Seth Meyers Says Trump This Week Was Like a Hurricane Without a Path
abstract: The president said he was not having second thoughts about his controversial decision to end DACA. Mr. Meyers quipped, “He doesn’t have first thoughts.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Pierre Bergé, Transformative Fashion Executive and Opera Czar, Dies at 86
abstract: He was the managerial genius behind Yves Saint Laurent, his former lover, and had a stormy run as the head of Paris’s opera houses.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Bergé, who transformed the French fashion industry as the managerial genius behind Yves Saint Laurent, and went on to have a tempestuous career as the czar of Paris opera, died on Friday in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, France. He was 86.

headline: How to Count Sheep
abstract: Trust your dogs. Don’t trust your head (use a clicker or pencil and paper). Find another way to fall asleep.
lead_paragraph: “A sheep hates to be alone,” says Paul Rodgers, from the sixth generation in his family to raise sheep on the same 600 acres in the West Virginia hills. The animals cluster together when grazing, which makes them exceptionally hard to tally, especially when little lambs are underfoot. Shepherds in states like Idaho and Montana will spend whole summers in the high country with thousands of sheep, unable to get a precise head count.

headline: Poem: Even the Gods
abstract: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Terrance Hayes

headline: New Credit Card Option for Those With Scant Credit Histories
abstract: A start-up, Petal, is offering a card that is the latest in a batch of new tools that expand financial options for consumers, often by using digital data.
lead_paragraph: A New York start-up aims to use everyday financial information to qualify people with scant or no credit histories for its credit cards.

headline: Using Silicon Valley Tactics, LinkedIn’s Founder Is Working to Blunt Trump
abstract: Reid Hoffman, who founded LinkedIn, is funding groups to create a bulwark against Mr. Trump’s agenda. Whether his start-up approach is effective is unclear.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Reid Hoffman, the founder of LinkedIn and a billionaire Silicon Valley venture capitalist, has made a half-dozen or so investments in recent months with a specific aim: to counteract the influence of President Trump.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Paranormal Taxonomy
abstract: Is a ghost a monster?
lead_paragraph: Liz writes: I believe that the Loch Ness Monster and the Chupacabra are monsters, but ghosts are not. My friend believes that because ghosts are undead, they should be considered monsters. Please put this dispute to rest.

headline: Education by the Numbers
abstract: Statistics show just how profound the inequalities in America’s education system have become.
lead_paragraph: There are as many American public school educations as there are students. One shared factor that affects a vast number of them, however, is race. Its impact drives the four narrative features in this week’s Education Issue. But numbers can tell their own stories too. The statistics here suggest how much has changed — and not changed — in the more than 60 years since the Supreme Court’s ruling in Brown v. Board of Education was supposed to make education equally accessible to all Americans.

headline: As Trump Pushes for Tax Overhaul, Wealth Advisers Say, ‘Wait and See’
abstract: The lack of details in President Trump’s tax plan has advisers urging caution with clients eager to know what changes, if any, they will need to make.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump made it clear during the presidential campaign that he wanted to cut taxes to spur economic growth. With Congress back from its summer recess, the president may get the chance to do just that — though analysts and wealth advisers are less confident that he will get wholesale tax overhaul.

headline: New Study Favors Fat Over Carbs
abstract: Researchers found that people who ate higher amounts of carbohydrates had a higher risk of dying than those who ate more fats.
lead_paragraph: High carbohydrate intake is associated with a higher risk of mortality, and high fat intake with a lower risk, researchers report.

headline: Behind the Cover: 9.10.17
abstract: For this issue, the children who still face racism in American Education.
lead_paragraph: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: “We needed a design that would convey a lot of information to ensure that readers would understand the historical context of this photo of 13-year-old Kymiyah Reeves. A cover with a lot of type like this is also a way of signaling a certain kind of seriousness to readers, and inviting a more careful read.”

headline: The 8.27.17 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE U.S. OPEN ISSUE

headline: Mother and Daughter in a Doomsday Cult
abstract: In Rebecca Wait’s novel “The Followers,” a lonely woman and her child are lured into an isolated community on the Yorkshire moors.
lead_paragraph: THE FOLLOWERS By Rebecca Wait 298 pp. Europa Editions. Paper, $17.

headline: When Friendship Ends, Does Betrayal Begin?
abstract: The teenagers in Claire Messud’s novel “The Burning Girl” have always been best friends. Now they’re growing painfully, possibly dangerously, apart.
lead_paragraph: THE BURNING GIRLBy Claire Messud247 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $25.95.

headline: The Posh, Psychological Thrills of ‘The Party’
abstract: Elizabeth Day dissects the 21st-century British class system in this novel rife with literary allusions.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Day’s sly fourth novel is an enticing mix of social climbing, barely hidden lust and possible crimes. The story rests on two central questions: Why is Martin Gilmour, a minor success as an art critic, being interrogated at a police station in the Cotswolds? What happened at the lavish 40th-birthday party of his aristocratic best friend, Ben Fitzmaurice, to make Martin squirm under the detectives’ glare? The novel’s underpinnings are much richer. Building on generations of fiction dissecting the British class system, Day carries that theme into the 21st century, adding the swift pace of a psychological thriller.

headline: The Man Whose Cabinet of Curios Helped Start the British Museum
abstract: James Delbourgo’s “Collecting the World” recounts the life of Sir Hans Sloane, a pioneering natural scientist.
lead_paragraph: COLLECTING THE WORLD Hans Sloane and the Origins of the British Museum By James Delbourgo Illustrated. 504 pp. The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $35.

headline: The Novels Explaining Britain’s Path From the Raj to Brexit
abstract: Revisiting Paul Scott’s “The Raj Quartet,” 70 years after the partition of India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Seventy years ago, a British government reeling from the costs of world war granted independence to India. The decision was made hastily and with a shocking lack of care for the people whose lives it affected and, in many cases, ended. The British partitioned the country at the moment they relinquished it, birthing Pakistan, and setting off population transfers and ethnic cleansing that left more than one million people dead. It was a fitting end: Far from pursuing a “civilizing mission,” the British Empire had exploited India, enforcing a policy of “divide and rule” and entrenching Hindu-Muslim tensions.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘21 Secrets of Million-Dollar Sellers,’ by Stephen J. Harvill
abstract: Business books can be treasure troves of unexpected similes and mind-boggling analogies.
lead_paragraph: Business books are Pez dispensers of breezy illustrative references: animal factoids, celebrity anecdotes, contextless quotation from famous writers, historical object lessons. They pop out, page by page, in a candy-colored stream that dissolves immediately on contact with the mind.

headline: A Sydney Bridge, a Falling Man and Three Witnesses to a Miracle
abstract: The stories of three Australians in three different centuries are linked by a miraculous vision in Ashley Hay’s “The Body in the Clouds.”
lead_paragraph: The Australian writer Ashley Hay’s second novel, “The Railwayman’s Wife,” was a contender for her country’s premier literary prize, the Miles Franklin award. Which may explain why her exquisite first novel, “The Body in the Clouds,” is finally being published in the United States. At its center are three men, seen in three different eras of the history of Sydney, whose lives are joined and changed by witnessing the same miracle: a man falling from the clouds into the sparkling harbor yet surviving, “marvelously alive.”

headline: ‘Blade Runner 2049’: Harrison Ford, Ryan Gosling and the Creators Discuss the Sequel
abstract: The “Blade Runner” sequel is coming, and Mr. Ford, Mr. Gosling, Ridley Scott and Denis Villeneuve talk about why they’re reviving it now.
lead_paragraph: “Blade Runner” debuted more than 35 years ago to mixed reviews and unexceptional ticket sales, much of the world unmoved by what its creator, Ridley Scott, believed was an audacious step forward in science-fiction filmmaking.

headline: Gregory Berns Knows What Your Dog Is Thinking (It’s Sweet)
abstract: The neuroscientist scans the brains of dogs for glimpses at their inner lives. One conclusion: Fido does love you.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Gregory Berns, 53, a neuroscientist at Emory University in Atlanta, spends his days scanning the brains of dogs, trying to figure out what they’re thinking. The research is detailed in a new book, “What It’s Like to Be a Dog.”

headline: Hal Willner’s Vanishing, Weird New York
abstract: The music producer came to New York for the sleaze and the flea circus. He stayed to make the mixtapes of a city’s imagination.
lead_paragraph: Hal Willner was new in New York, working as an assistant to a record producer named Joel Dorn, when Mr. Dorn called him aside after a session one night. “You’re not going home yet, baby,” Mr. Willner remembered his boss telling him. It was 1974. Mr. Dorn had produced enormously successful records for Bette Midler and Roberta Flack, and experimental jazz albums that Mr. Willner loved.

headline: Ted Cruz 2.0? Senator Adjusts With Trump in Office and Houston Under Water
abstract: As he prepares for re-election next year, Senator Ted Cruz faces a challenge in helping millions of people — in his hometown, Houston, and beyond — rebuild after Hurricane Harvey.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was just getting going, summoning his down-home artillery from the Senate floor — the faith-flecked tales, the weathered statesman’s gaze, the theatrical pauses deployed not so long ago before caucus-inclined Iowans.

headline: James Kelman’s ‘Dirt Road’ Travels a Path to Solace
abstract: A father and son escape painful reminders of their lost loved ones in Scotland to discover a new outlook in the American South.
lead_paragraph: DIRT ROAD By James Kelman 407 pp. Catapult. Paper, $16.95.

headline: A Free Food Forest in the Bronx
abstract: Swale is a public art project that doubles as a call to action. It aims to raise awareness about food access by allowing local residents to forage food and herbs for free.
lead_paragraph: Swale is a public art project that doubles as a call to action. It aims to raise awareness about food access by allowing local residents to forage food and herbs for free.

headline: After Charlottesville, Colleges Vow to Do Something. But What?
abstract: Universities are grappling with a dramatic spike in white supremacist activity on their campuses, forcing them to weigh competing priorities: safety, free speech and diversity.
lead_paragraph: Seven days after hundreds of white nationalists paraded tiki torches through the University of Virginia campus, Shaun R. Harper, an expert on race and education, stood before the school’s faculty and asked who had been disgusted by the white supremacy on display. Almost every hand rose. He nodded slowly. “Well, then do something about it,” he said.

headline: The Cheap Charms, Altered and Otherwise, of Portland, Ore.
abstract: The Rose City is full of great food, shopping and comedy — all enhanced by a legalized pot-tourism scene.
lead_paragraph: The trick was figuring out where to get high.

headline: Give My Regards to E Street: Imagining a Springsteen Musical
abstract: Theater writers go down the shore with Harold and Kumar, Rosalita and Cynthia Erivo, with a side trip to the Stone Pony.
lead_paragraph: You can’t start a fire without a spark.

headline: Rebuilding Your Home After a Disaster
abstract: Whether it’s a hurricane or a tree that falls through the roof, navigating the insurance maze that follows takes time and patience.
lead_paragraph: Catastrophe can arrive at your doorstep in any number of ways: A century-old tree could hit the roof, faulty wiring could spark a fire or a storm like Hurricane Harvey could unleash its fury and yours could be one of countless homes in its path.

headline: Florida, Mexico, Stephen King: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Leave Now,’ Florida Governor Warns as Storm Nears
abstract: One of the most potent Atlantic Ocean hurricanes ever recorded battered Turks and Caicos and the Bahamas on Friday, then made landfall in northern Cuba.

headline: The Anniversary Malady
abstract: In the year after my husband died, every memory triggered flashbacks: Blackberry ice cream. A song on the radio. The angle of sunlight.
lead_paragraph: This past spring, as I moved closer to the date that would have been my husband, Jim’s, 65th birthday — and four days later, the anniversary of his death — the calendar was filled with land mines. I never knew when I might step on one.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Pain, Marital Discord and Mosquitoes
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: New York Today: Rafael Nadal’s New York
abstract: Friday: What Rafael Nadal likes most about New York, weekend events, and canine couture.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this spectacular Friday.

headline: From a Cairo Prison to a Poignant Wedding
abstract: Mohamed Soltan, a human rights advocate who was imprisoned in Egypt and staged a hunger strike, marries Habiba Shebita, a longtime supporter.
lead_paragraph: Not every bride would be thrilled with the idea of being upstaged by a wedding guest. But Habiba Shebita would have welcomed the chance to share the spotlight with Omar Malek, a friend of her fiancé, Mohamed Soltan.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Trump’s New Prom Date: Democrats
abstract: We talk with Glenn Thrush and Senator Chuck Schumer about the president’s surprising new alliance with the other party.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Morning Agenda: An End to Debt-Ceiling Fights, Maybe
abstract: Washington may not get the 15 percent corporate tax that President Trump wants. But an end to annual dramas over the debt limit may be near.
lead_paragraph: For the markets, this week has proved that in Washington, you win some, you lose some.

headline: Daniel S. Schwartz of Restaurant Brands International on the Value of Hard Work
abstract: The C.E.O. who runs Burger King, Tim Hortons and Popeyes says he is looking for a specific answer when he asks, “Are you smart or do you work hard?”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Daniel S. Schwartz, chief executive of Restaurant Brands International, the parent company of Burger King, Tim Hortons and Popeyes, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: How Henry Threadgill, Composer, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The longtime East Village resident wakes early, avoids the brunch crowd, and looks for inspiration in books, trees, art shows and dance performances.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Henry Threadgill, the Pulitzer Prize-winning musician and composer, has been racking up critical accolades, not to mention fans, with his jazz-influenced compositions. On Sept. 23, he will introduce a new work at Jazz at Lincoln Center: “Dirt, and More Dirt,” which was inspired by the longstanding conceptual-art piece in SoHo, the New York Earth Room. For most of his adult life, Mr. Threadgill, 73, has been a resident of the East Village, estimating that he has lived on almost every street in the neighborhood since moving there in 1975. He currently shares a two-bedroom apartment with his wife, Senti, an administrator at New York University, and his daughter, Nhumi, a college student.

headline: 270,000 Rohingya Have Fled Myanmar, U.N. Says
abstract: Camps in Bangladesh, already crowded and underserved, are “bursting at the seams” with people fleeing the military crackdown in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The number of Rohingya who have fled fighting in western Myanmar has climbed sharply to 270,000, placing a huge strain on camps in Bangladesh where they are seeking shelter, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday.

headline: Giant Earthquake Shakes Mexico
abstract: The country was struck by an 8.2-magnitude quake, the strongest in decades, killing at least 58 people and leveling areas in some southern states.
lead_paragraph: The country was struck by an 8.2-magnitude quake, the strongest in decades, killing at least 58 people and leveling areas in some southern states.

headline: Do Colonics Provide Health Benefits? Are They Dangerous?
abstract: There is no scientific support for colon cleansing, and the procedure carries risks.
lead_paragraph: Q. I feel great after getting a colonic. In addition to feeling energized and lighter, I have a sense of well-being. Are colonics dangerous? Can you have too many colonics? Is once a week O.K.?

headline: Where Amazon Should Go
abstract: The company would help itself, and the country, by putting its new headquarters outside of the Northeast, the West Coast or Chicago.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Shamir Steps Away From the Spotlight, and His Signature Sound
abstract: After two years of all kinds of ruptures, the 22-year-old musician returns with a raw new album, “Revelations.”
lead_paragraph: Shamir arrived three years ago, fully formed, highly evolved — a queer, confident and stylish Las Vegas teenager playing dance-pop with punk spirit, an avatar for a progressive era. But those days are gone.

headline: California Today: A Deadly Outbreak Stalks San Diego
abstract: Friday: San Diego tries to contain a hepatitis A outbreak, several cities court Amazon, and a look back at California’s first female lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Lizz Wright’s ‘Grace,’ an Ode to the South and to Forgiveness
abstract: Ms. Wright, who will celebrate this album’s release on Sept. 15 at the Highline Ballroom, said she was finding language for how real healing is possible.
lead_paragraph: The sensual and the spiritual have always been at play in the vocalist Lizz Wright’s music. On her new album, “Grace,” she adds to the scrum, mixing the sanctified with the political, the sexual with the social.

headline: Daniil Simkin Joins Staatsballett Berlin
abstract: Mr. Simkin, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, will retain his position there.
lead_paragraph: Daniil Simkin, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will join the Staatsballett Berlin in September 2018. Mr. Simkin, 29, who was born in Russia, but grew up in Germany, will retain his position at Ballet Theater, but will be based in Berlin.

headline: Where to Go in Italy’s Small, Dying Towns
