abstract: Deborah Needleman, who visited ancient and now semi-desolate hillside villages for T, shares how to get the experience.
lead_paragraph: Staying a night or two (or longer) in an ancient, largely depopulated but glorious Italian hill town is not for everyone, but for those who like the idea of passing a couple of quiet days walking, reading, eating (really well) and drinking in the sublime surroundings, it can be bliss. If you can forgo a minibar, room service, a gym and much in the way of entertainment, read on for two excellent places to visit.

headline: At Calvin Klein, Dressing for Dystopia
abstract: With satin cowboy shirts and Kim Novak curves, Raf Simons continues to redesign the contours of his new country.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough gig to be crowned the savior of American fashion. Excessive expectations and all that. Most designers would quail at the thought.

headline: Farhad’s and Natasha’s Week in Review: Tech Tackles Trump, Again
abstract: Once again, the tech industry tried to get the president to change his mind. Once again, they failed. Plus a look at the week’s other tech news.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike was away this week, so Natasha Singer, a Times tech reporter, filled in.

headline: David Rockefeller’s Westchester Estate Lists for $22 Million
abstract: The 75-acre estate of David Rockefeller, who died in March, includes a Georgian-style mansion and a complement of buildings for a gentleman farmer.
lead_paragraph: The 75-acre estate of David Rockefeller, who died in March, includes a Georgian-style mansion and a complement of buildings for a gentleman farmer.

headline: David Rockefeller’s Westchester Estate Lists for $22 Million
abstract: The 75-acre estate of David Rockefeller, who died in March, includes a Georgian-style mansion and a complement of buildings for a gentleman farmer.
lead_paragraph: In New York City, David Rockefeller led Chase Manhattan bank and brokered deals that shaped the city skyline.

headline: T’s Men’s Style Issue: Editor’s Letter
abstract: Anyone who makes things for a living understands this sensation: the realization that the object you thought you were making is sometimes not what actually gets made.
lead_paragraph: One of the sustaining fictions of being a magazine editor is that you somehow determine the publication you produce. Strictly speaking, of course, this is true: It is editors who generate the ideas for the stories, who assign and edit the text and the photos, who style the shoots and design the layouts and fact-check and copy-edit — it would not exist without us.

headline: Trump Lashes Out at Congressional Republicans’ ‘Death Wish’
abstract: President Trump rejected Republican complaints about his decision to work with Democrats and chided his own party for failing to advance major legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday rejected Republican complaints about his decision to work with Democrats on fiscal and immigration issues, chiding his own party for failing to advance major legislation and calling on congressional leaders to begin overhauling the tax code immediately.

headline: How Hard Could It Be to Combine Two Apartments?
abstract: Harder than you’d think, as one couple discovered.
lead_paragraph: Toy creep had already begun to take hold in the two-bedroom, one-bath apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Dara and Mike Dierks shared with their toddler, Julian. And with plans to add another family member soon, space was becoming a growing concern.

headline: From Australia’s ‘Stolen Generation’ to Celebrated Poet
abstract: Ali Cobby Eckermann was taken away from her Aboriginal family at birth. Having fought her demons, she will soon pick up a literary award at Yale.
lead_paragraph: When Ali Cobby Eckermann met her biological mother for the first time at age 34, she did not think her life could be enlarged further, she said. Four years later, in 2001, Ms. Cobby Eckermann was reunited with her son, then 18, who had been taken from her at birth.

headline: 1967: U.S. Will Construct Barrier Across DMZ
abstract: American idea to construct a barrier across Vietnam during the war to halt northern soldiers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 — The United States will build a complex barrier between North and South Vietnam in hopes of hindering enemy infiltration, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara announced today.

headline: Grab All Your iTunes Music With One Tap
abstract: Apple lets you download your iTunes purchases to multiple devices, but you don’t have to do it one song at a time.
lead_paragraph: Q. I am trying to figure out how to download my iTunes music library from iCloud to my iPad Pro. It appears there is no mass download feature, and I have been able to download only one song at a time. Is there a way to download all my music more efficiently?

headline: 8 Things Fans Did Not Expect in the Patriots-Chiefs Game
abstract: The Patriots lost to the Chiefs, 42-27, on a night of rarities for the Bill Belichick era.
lead_paragraph: What happened?

headline: A Cake That Showcases the Beauty of Figs
abstract: Chopped up fresh figs and a honeyed cream cheese frosting make this cake perfect for Rosh Hashana and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Figs are showy fruit.

headline: A ‘Battle of the Sexes’ Rages On, More Than 4 Decades Later
abstract: Filmmakers thought their recreation of this 1973 media circus of a tennis match would be unfathomable to today’s audiences. They were mistaken.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — As the trumpets struck up a brassy fanfare, Emma Stone — perched on a pink feather-bedecked golden litter held aloft by a retinue of bare-chested men — made her entrance into a cavernous arena here.

headline: In ‘Coco,’ Bringing the Land of the Dead Back to Life
abstract: A look at the world Pixar Animation Studios created for their latest film.
lead_paragraph: With the new “Coco,” Pixar Animation Studios aims to bring the dead to vivid, reverent life. The movie is set against the backdrop of Día de los Muertos (the Day of the Dead), the Mexican holiday when families gather to honor ancestors by building altars to them and decorating their grave sites.

headline: Action! Vivid Moments on Set, Relived
abstract: Actors in forthcoming movies talk about their worst, weirdest or most unforgettable moments of making the film.
lead_paragraph: Landing the job is only the beginning — it’s what happens afterward that tests an actor’s mettle. Here, actors and actresses talk about the worst, weirdest or most memorable days on the sets of their forthcoming movies.

headline: Fall 2017 Movie Release Schedule
abstract: A guide to all the films headed to theaters this season.
lead_paragraph: More listings for the new season: Art | Classical | Dance | Pop | Television | Theater

headline: Florida Is Due for a Reckoning. Will Irma Be It?
abstract: Despite its vulnerability to hurricanes, the state continues to encourage growth and building in dangerous places.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Irma, one of the most powerful storms in recorded history, looks set to hit the continental United States in the coming days. If we are lucky the storm will veer back out to sea, but the National Hurricane Center’s forecast shows the hurricane bearing down on South Florida. Even if it only sideswipes the state, it will wreak havoc.

headline: How to Understand Israel’s Strike on Syria
abstract: This week’s attack represents a major strategic and moral improvement in the Jewish state’s policy toward the Assad regime, Iran and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Thursday night, according to the Syrian Army, the Israeli Air Force attacked a military site in the Syrian town of Masyaf that produces advanced missiles. Though the attack does not compare in strategic value to Syria’s Al Kibar nuclear reactor, which was destroyed a decade ago, it represents a major step in the right direction for Israel’s policy toward Syria. This strike sent five key messages — messages that point toward Israel adopting a more proactive strategy in confronting the threats posed by the Assad regime and its partners, Iran and Hezbollah.

headline: Stories of Familial Unrest and Displacement
abstract: Four new novels set around the globe explore the causes and consequences of family estrangement.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTOWN By Kei Miller 256 pp. Pantheon, $25.95.

headline: Read Thomas Lesnak's Deposition
abstract: Thomas Lesnak, a retired agent in the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into the A.T.F.'s operation that was filtering money into an unsupervised and off-the-books account.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Lesnak, a retired agent in the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into the A.T.F.'s operation that was filtering money into an unsupervised and off-the-books account.

headline: Read Christopher Small's Deposition
abstract: Christopher Small, an employee at Big Tobacco Sales, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into an operation by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives that filtered money into an unsupervised, off-the-books account.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Small, an employee at Big Tobacco Sales, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into an operation by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives that filtered money into an unsupervised, off-the-books account.

headline: Read Jason Carpenter's Deposition
abstract: Jason Carpenter, a small-time Alabama tobacco distributor, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into an operation by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives that filtered money into an unsupervised, off-the-books account.
lead_paragraph: Jason Carpenter, a small-time Alabama tobacco distributor, gave the following sworn statement as part of an investigation into an operation by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives that filtered money into an unsupervised, off-the-books account.

headline: House Passes Hurricane Aid and Raises Debt Ceiling
abstract: The House gave final approval to a fiscal deal that raises the debt ceiling and keeps the government funded until December, while also providing $15 billion in hurricane relief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican-controlled House on Friday gave final approval to President Trump’s fiscal deal with Democrats, leaving conservative lawmakers frustrated and grumbling as Mr. Trump continued to assail his party for failing to advance major legislation.

headline: How to Explore a City Like a Local Using Your Smartphone
abstract: Three apps that make it easy to connect with locals — without having to talk to them in person.
lead_paragraph: It’s now easier than ever to get travel advice from locals, and you don’t even have to talk to them in person.

headline: The Psychic Toll of Trump’s DACA Decision
abstract: Undocumented immigrants have long suffered while living in legal limbo. The Trump administration is making it far worse.
lead_paragraph: “I did not raise you to cry,” my father would say when I fell off my bike, as he poured rubbing alcohol on my bloody 6-year-old knees. Not hydrogen peroxide — alcohol. Whenever I cried, which was usually when I did not get an A on a math test or saw a lost-dog poster or read about Anne Frank, my parents, immigrants from Ecuador, handed me a mirror to observe myself. They wanted to desensitize me to my own tears, to line my small heart with bulletproof glass, even if doing so meant making me hate my own weakness.

headline: ‘I Smell Cash’: How the A.T.F. Spent Millions Unchecked
abstract: A pair of informants got $6 million and agents spent freely. The Justice Department fought to keep records of the operation secret.
lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, Va. — For seven years, agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives followed an unwritten policy: If you needed to buy something for one of your cases, do not bother asking Washington. Talk to agents in Bristol, Va., who controlled a multimillion-dollar account unrestricted by Congress or the bureaucracy.

headline: The Last Days of ISIS’ Capital: Airstrikes if You Stay, Land Mines if You Flee
abstract: A Times reporter travels to Raqqa, the wounded heart of the Islamic State, and finds residents trapped by airstrikes, artillery fire and land mines.
lead_paragraph: RAQQA, Syria — Every few minutes, a deafening boom. Then a whistle of artillery. Occasionally, the clatter of a pickup truck, piled with soldiers, advancing to the front line.

headline: More Than 40 Sites Released Hazardous Pollutants Because of Hurricane Harvey
abstract: In the Houston area, air pollution, flooded toxic waste sites and reports of oil spills after the storm have residents and environmental groups concerned.
lead_paragraph: In the Houston area, air pollution, flooded toxic waste sites and reports of oil spills after the storm have residents and environmental groups concerned.

headline: Hotel Buffets, a Culprit of Food Waste, Get Downsized
abstract: Hyatt has teamed up with Ideo, the global design firm, to remake the buffet, a hotel staple that oozes excess.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Eells, the executive chef at the Hyatt Regency Orlando, in Florida, would like his kitchen, or at least its operations, to be as lean as his roast beef. So in April, he welcomed a team of researchers looking at ways to reduce food waste, especially around the abundant all-you-can-eat buffets.

headline: All Kinds of Outrageous Behavior in These New Picture Books
abstract: A little seed who’s unapologetically bad, a horrible baby brother, the kid who won’t stop screaming and more.
lead_paragraph: He’s bad all right. Never washes his hands. Lies “about pointless stuff.” Cuts in line! But the antihero of this inspired collaboration between John (“All My Friends Are Dead”) and Oswald (“Mingo the Flamingo”) has a fascinating back story, involving a happy childhood on a sunflower, a terrifying incident at a ballpark that sent him to the dark side and years of delinquency before he decides to reform. This is kid-book humor at its best, both warmhearted and frisky — the kind that leaves adults, too, cracking up and grateful.

headline: An Israeli Chef Looks to the Landscape
abstract: Erez Komarovsky influenced a generation of Israeli chefs by embracing local ingredients and dishes long before it was in style.
lead_paragraph: MATTAT, Israel — The winding path to the chef Erez Komarovsky’s home, overlooking a village here in the Upper Galilee in Israel, is lined with a wild mix of pomegranate and olive trees, fennel and chickpea plants. It is fragrant with lemon, quince or apple blossoms, depending on the season.

headline: What We Talk About When We Talk About and Exactly Like Trump
abstract: The president has lodged his pronouncements in our collective memory and discourse like no other public figure in recent history.
lead_paragraph: Tremendous. Yuge. Sad. Beautiful. Disaster. Horrible. Disgusting. Failing media. Fake news. Believe me. Frankly. Blood coming out of her wherever. I like people who weren’t captured. He’s a showboat, he’s a grandstander. You look at what’s happening last night in Sweden. Paris is no longer Paris. Fire and fury. On many sides. I have the best words.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: There are two weeks left before the fall equinox: Embrace the waning days of summer with grilled pork and peaches or steamed corn with clams and bacon.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Witness Warrants Were Misused in Queens and Elsewhere, Court Papers Say
abstract: Documents on behalf of Alexina Simon — who claims she was unlawfully detained — cites several cases in which the warrants appear to have been abused.
lead_paragraph: It is one of law enforcement’s most expansive powers: If the authorities believe that someone has knowledge of a crime, they can — under threat of arrest — force the person to testify in court by obtaining what is known as a material witness warrant.

headline: Josh Brown, Free Agent Kicker, Suspended Six More Games
abstract: Brown, who has not played in almost a year, was accused of domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. suspended Josh Brown, a free-agent kicker, for six more games after spending nearly a year evaluating additional evidence related to charges of domestic violence.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: TV, Pre-Golden Age
abstract: In “Little Boxes,” writers share how they were influenced by TV shows, in the days before prestige TV.
lead_paragraph: “Little Boxes,” a new collection of essays in which writers appraise the TV shows that influenced them, is for people old enough to remember when “prestige TV” was an oxymoron. People like me, whose first experience with cultural water-cooler talk (water-fountain?), in elementary school, involved the most recent episode of “The A-Team.”

headline: Houston’s Alley Theater Picks Up the Pieces After Hurricane
abstract: Houston’s Alley Theater, drenched and damaged by the recent hurricane, is rising above the floodwaters with plans to salvage its productions.
lead_paragraph: It would be days before the full nature of the loss could be known, weeks before handmade props and state-of-the-art lighting rigs, or what was left of them, would be tallied and appraised. At the Alley Theater, in the anxious days immediately after hurricane Harvey slashed through Houston and surrounding areas, the scale of destruction was still obscured.

headline: Graham Norton’s World of Wonder
abstract: On tour to promote his new mystery novel, the BBC host pauses to shop for some bedding at a favorite furniture store.
lead_paragraph: At around 11:15 on Monday morning, when Manhattan was mostly empty because of the Labor Day holiday, Graham Norton, the BBC talk show host, entered the ABC Carpet & Home store on Broadway and 18th Street. Dressed in a dark green, intricately patterned Thorsun shirt and slate gray Citizens of Humanity jeans (the same outfit he had worn earlier in the day on “Good Morning America”), he had on his face the anticipatory look of a child about to run free in his favorite toy shop.

headline: On Hurricane Irma
abstract: Irma is one of the most powerful Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded.
lead_paragraph: Irma is one of the most powerful Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded.

headline: James Patterson’s Latest Villain Looks a Lot Like Amazon
abstract: “The Store,” at No. 4 after three weeks on the hardcover fiction list, features a married couple at war with a dominant online retailer.
lead_paragraph: GODZILLA VERSUS MOTHRA: James Patterson’s latest diversion, “The Store,” is about a mass-market behemoth standing astride the globe, anticipating and manipulating customers’ desires in a bid for total cultural domination. Surprisingly, it is not an autobiography. The store of the title is an Amazon-like tech company with management anger issues, which reacts murderously when it discovers that a couple of married employees plan a tell-all book. If nothing else, it will leave you questioning the wisdom of drone delivery.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: A look at Mikhail Gorbachev’s memoir and the former statesman’s divisive reputation.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s issue Peter Baker reviews a new biography about Mikhail Gorbachev, one of the 20th century’s most controversial figures. In 1996, Bill Keller reviewed Gorbachev’s memoir and tried to understand the former statesman’s divisive reputation. Below is an excerpt.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to the complicated relationship we have to Freud.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Getting People to Get Along, Even When They Disagree
abstract: Discussing good books with peers who often disagree with you can promote tolerance and comity.
lead_paragraph: We live in a time of great discord. Republicans and Democrats, conservatives and liberals, and fans and critics of President Trump not only disagree, they often despise each other. In a small way, however, I am trying to change that.

headline: What to Remember Before the ‘Outlander’ Season 3 Premiere
abstract: The long “Droughtlander” is over. What the deuce was happening again?
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: Live Event: Discussing Food Fads With the New York Times Podcast Club
abstract: Are you a podcast obsessive? Join us on Tuesday, Sept. 26, for a live meetup of the New York Times Podcast Club.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests. Times Insider offers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: His Dream in Reach, an Immigrant Chef Is Suddenly Unsettled
abstract: Suny Santana, brought to America as a child, was set to open a restaurant when he learned that the government may end his permission to stay.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Suny Santana hadn’t been working long as a prep cook at St. Francis, a stylish restaurant in the heart of this city, when his employer learned that he was an undocumented immigrant, brought by his parents from Mexico to the United States as a 12-year-old.

headline: Review: Fox’s ‘The Orville’ is Star Trek, the Next Regurgitation
abstract: In his first live-action TV series, Seth MacFarlane, the creator of “Family Guy,” delivers a sincere, unnecessary homage to the “Star Trek” franchise.
lead_paragraph: The first question a lot of people will have about “The Orville,” Seth MacFarlane’s first live-action television series — “Aren’t you afraid of being sued by the folks who own ‘Star Trek’?” — was asked and answered last month at the Television Critics Association press tour. Dana Walden, the Fox TV chief executive, gave a long reply that included the phrase, “We obviously have a big legal team.”

headline: Sara Netanyahu, Wife of Israeli Prime Minister, to Face Fraud Charges
abstract: The case, involving accusations of the misuse of some $100,000 in public funds, is one of four corruption investigations closing in on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s attorney general said Friday that he intended to bring fraud charges against Sara Netanyahu, the wife of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, accusing her of misusing some $100,000 in public funds in her management of the prime minister’s official residence.

headline: When the Universe Calls
abstract: He became an astronomer by accident, without ever taking a formal course. It has changed his life.
lead_paragraph: Dean Regas, 43, is an astronomer at the Cincinnati Observatory in Cincinnati, Ohio.

headline: What to Remember Before the ‘Outlander’ Season 3 Premiere
abstract: The long “Droughtlander” is over. What the deuce was happening again?
lead_paragraph: The long “Droughtlander” is over. What the deuce was happening again?

headline: Ellen Pao Is Not Done Fighting
abstract: With her new book, “Reset,” a thwarted Silicon Valley power player hopes to do for gender discrimination what Anita Hill did for sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: Every day, Ellen Pao receives written messages of support from all over: to her office, through her lawyers, over email, on LinkedIn, in postcards she keeps in a small wooden box on her desk.

headline: Saved on 9/11, by the Man in the Red Bandanna
abstract: Welles Crowther — who rescued at least 10 people at ground zero and became known as the man with the red handkerchief — is the subject of a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: SUFFERN, N.Y. — Welles Crowther, 24, a rookie equities trader from Upper Nyack, N.Y., who died in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, became known as the Man in the Red Bandana, for the handkerchief he wore as a protective mask while assuming a rescuer’s role in the South Tower before it collapsed.

headline: Tory Burch: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Read These 3 Books on Hurricanes
abstract: Two books follow families affected by similar disasters, and a third argues that humans may hold the key to mitigating their impact.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of just one week, two hurricanes, Harvey and Irma, have hit the United States and a number of islands in the Caribbean, claiming lives and property in their wake. For a better understanding of the people who have lived through similar disasters, here are two books that illuminate their lives and another that explains how to reduce the effect these catastrophes have on communities.

headline: Peter Max’s U.S. Open Image: Variation on a Classic Theme
abstract: The artist was challenged to recapture the essence of Arthur Ashe Stadium, which he portrayed 20 years ago when it opened.
lead_paragraph: When the artist Peter Max was asked to recapture the essence of Arthur Ashe Stadium, 20 years after he delivered a rendering for its debut, he quickly spotted a new test of his talent: how to convey the 2016 addition of a retractable roof.

headline: What to Look Forward to in the Fall Dance Season
abstract: Our critics choose the choreographers, companies and performances that they’re most excited about.
lead_paragraph: Our critics choose the choreographers, companies and performances that they’re most excited about.

headline: Planes Fill Florida Skies as Hurricane Irma Approaches
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration expected “increased volume” at airports in South Florida as airlines raced to get flights off the ground.
lead_paragraph: Airline and airport workers raced to get flights off the ground as Hurricane Irma swirled toward Florida on Friday, filling the skies above the state with planes.

headline: For Renters, Harvey Was the First Blow, Followed by Orders to Move
abstract: Houston officials have called on landlords to show compassion after the storm, but some tenants find themselves forced out of homes, with few options.
lead_paragraph: KATY, Tex. — After years of shuttling from apartment to apartment, Emma Nelson thought she would settle down in the orange-brick rental house with a big oak tree and roomy backyard.

headline: Sarbanes-Oxley, Bemoaned as a Burden, Is an Investor’s Ally
abstract: Corporate chiefs are pushing Congress to repeal a provision on internal controls. But a study shows just how effective it has been.
lead_paragraph: Seismic accounting scandals like the ones that sank Enron and WorldCom in the early 2000s have, happily, been scarce in recent years. But they may well resurface if elements of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, the law created to curtail accounting fraud, are rolled back as some corporate executives are urging.

headline: Napolitano Sues Trump to Save DACA Program She Helped Create
abstract: Ms. Napolitano, the homeland security secretary under President Obama, signed the memo creating DACA and now is president of the University of California system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As secretary of homeland security in 2012, Janet Napolitano created DACA, the federal program that protected more than 800,000 young, undocumented immigrants from deportation and allowed them to work legally in the United States.

headline: Equifax Hack Exposes Regulatory Gaps, Leaving Consumers Vulnerable
abstract: Despite the wealth of sensitive information in their databases, credit bureaus don’t face the same kind of scrutiny and oversight that banks do.
lead_paragraph: Equifax warehouses the most intimate details of Americans’ financial lives, from the credit cards in their wallets to the size of their medical bills.

headline: Dance Listings for the Fall Season and Beyond
abstract: Our critic’s list of forthcoming performances through May covers inventive takes on old favorites and bold new works.

headline: Jeffrey Tuchman, 62, Dies; Directed Clinton ‘Man From Hope’ Film
abstract: An award-winning documentarian, Mr. Tuchman introduced Bill Clinton to many Americans in a film nationally broadcast from the 1992 Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Tuchman, the man who directed “The Man From Hope,” the promotional film that introduced Bill Clinton to America at the 1992 Democratic National Convention, died on Sept. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 62.

headline: Bill Skarsgard Talks About ‘It’ and Giving His Family a Scare
abstract: “Normally when you do a movie, you have those mundane days when it’s like, ‘Today is the scene where I get coffee,’” Mr. Skarsgard said. But not in “It.”
lead_paragraph: Bill Skarsgard was calling from his native Sweden, where “It” — the much-anticipated horror film in which he co-stars — was set for a premiere in Stockholm on Friday. “It’s more of a family gathering,” Mr. Skarsgard said. “I’ve invited all my cousins and uncles, and my sister, who works in event planning, is throwing the after-party. My brother Alexander did the same thing with ‘The Legend of Tarzan’ last year, so he inspired me.”

headline: What Does a College Pay for Its Football Coach? It Depends on How Many It’s Paying
abstract: Texas is paying three head coaches this season. So is Oregon. But each only gets the services of one.
lead_paragraph: What if a college football team paid not only its own head coach but another one? And another one?

headline: Twirly Legs and All: Spike Jonze Spreads His Dance Wings
abstract: Mr. Jonze is collaborating with the buzzy choreographer Ryan Heffington and the fashion house Opening Ceremony on a dance narrative. (Oh, he has great stars, too.)
lead_paragraph: Lakeith Stanfield auditioned for a dance show, and he didn’t even know it. In January, Mr. Stanfield, a star of the hit movie “Get Out” and of the hit television series “Atlanta,” was at the Golden Globes. When “Atlanta” won the prize for best comedy, he celebrated onstage with an impressively continuous hula-style hip swivel, his stance wide, arms sinuous. His happy dance quickly went viral and became a GIF.

headline: To Defend Against Irma, Locals Raid Miami Beach for Sand
abstract: With Hurricane Irma approaching, Miami Beach residents are filling up sandbags. But in so doing they could be weakening one of the city’s best lines of defense — its beaches.
lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Irma approaching, Miami Beach residents are filling up sandbags. But in so doing they could be weakening one of the city’s best lines of defense — its beaches.

headline: The Playlist: Sam Smith Guards His Heart, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear the 13 songs that caught our critics' ears this week, from the pop-soul of Kelly Clarkson to the giddy rock of the Fluids.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Kelly Clarkson returns with a dose of pop-soul; Tony Allen brings his beats to two American projects; and Rostam (formerly of Vampire Weekend) releases the title song from his solo debut.

headline: Pop and Jazz Fall Preview: 66 Albums, Shows and Festivals

headline: North Carolina, Still Reeling From Hurricane Matthew, Stares at Irma
abstract: Hurricane Matthew devastated rural parts of the state last October. Many people are still displaced, and now they have a new storm to worry about.
lead_paragraph: FAIR BLUFF, N.C. — The flooding is long gone, but its shadow is everywhere. It is etched in the waterline on the windows of empty storefronts, in the mold blooming on the walls of a neglected building, in the rippled sign hanging in a window: “We will be closed Saturday Oct. 8 due to the storm.”

headline: Jerry Garcia Goes Off Broadway in ‘Red Roses, Green Gold’
abstract: A new musical at Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village will feature music from Jerry Garcia, Robert Hunter and other Grateful Dead members.
lead_paragraph: Deadheads, be grateful.

abstract: The region’s latest vote on separation, scheduled for Oct. 1, is significantly riskier than previous efforts and thrusts Spain into uncharted territory.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — The accelerating battle over Catalonia’s status hit warp speed this week.

headline: The Drop Shot: An Answer to the U.S. Open Slugfest
abstract: With forehands and backhands being hit harder and harder, players are setting up farther from the net, making them vulnerable to the drop shot.
lead_paragraph: With forehands and backhands being hit harder and harder, players are setting up farther from the net, making them vulnerable to the drop shot.

headline: Sexism and Shopping: Female Players Get Most of the Odd Questions at the U.S. Open
abstract: A study casts a light not just on gender bias, but also on how algorithms work.
lead_paragraph: The tennis finals of the United States Open are Saturday for the women and Sunday for the men. On the court, except for the number of sets, they all face the same rules. When they walk off the court, though, the game changes.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Delays London Opening and Ticket Buyers Aren’t Happy
abstract: Sixteen performances will be rescheduled, disappointing ticket holders from as far away as Oklahoma and Japan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some theatergoers had plans to fly to London from as far away as the United States, Japan and New Zealand. Others had bought tickets nearly a year ago, or booked rooms in pricey hotels months in advance.

headline: F.B.I. Investigates Uber Software Used to Monitor Lyft Drivers
abstract: In another legal headache for Uber, federal investigators are looking into a past program called “Hell” that the ride-hailing company used to compete with rival Lyft.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States attorney’s office in New York are looking into whether Uber used tactics and software to illegally interfere with Lyft, its largest American competitor.

lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Panaro is the latest steward of the butcherly barber Sweeney Todd’s gleaming implements. He follows Norm Lewis, a Broadway fixture who himself replaced the British actor Jeremy Secomb in the role. This immersive Tooting Arts Club production, a transfer from London that’s been playing in New York since February, situates the action of Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s well-loved and lyrically dexterous musical in a functioning pie shop. LOUIS LUCERO II

headline: North Korea’s Trade Troubles Could Point to a Need for Cash
abstract: As sanctions take effect, China is selling more goods to North Korea than it is buying, raising questions about Pyongyang’s potential cash needs.
lead_paragraph: DANDONG, China — After sunset, when American spy satellites can no longer see as well, the main bridge connecting China to North Korea comes to life.

headline: Miami Always Thinks the Storm Will Turn
abstract: It’s not going to be that bad, we say, until it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: We are raised not to take them seriously.

abstract: Readers discuss the consequences of the 1928 Kellogg-Briand Pact.

headline: Harlem Restaurateur Is Sentenced to 5 Years for $12 Million Ponzi Scheme
abstract: The investigation of Hamlet Peralta led the police to a wider anticorruption inquiry, and ultimately an indictment, of top police officials.
lead_paragraph: A former restaurateur, whose $12 million Ponzi scheme embroiled two businessmen accused of bribing New York City law enforcement officers, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison.

headline: How to Fix the Person You Love
abstract: It’s hard to make our spouses feel valued and accepted while pushing them to be the best they can be.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the American ideal of marriage lurks a potential conflict. We expect our spouse to make us feel loved and valued, while also expecting him or her to help us discover and actualize our best self — to spur us to become, as Tom Cruise’s titular character in “Jerry Maguire” puts it, “the me I’d always wanted to be.”

headline: Long a Refuge for the Elderly, Florida Is Now a Place of Danger
abstract: In a state where one in five residents is over 65, caring for older residents is one of the main challenges in planning for Hurricane Irma as it heads toward Florida.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With all the challenges and complications as one of the most powerful hurricanes ever recorded bears down on South Florida, there is also this: One in five residents here is over the age of 65, a percentage greater than any other state.

headline: Even ‘The Bachelor’ Can’t Find a Man
abstract: In the new season, vastly overqualified women will, once again, compete for the attention of a mediocre man. This time he drives racecars.
lead_paragraph: A good man is hard to find, whether you’re a single woman or a reality TV producer. This past week, People magazine reported that ABC’s 15-year-old dating show, “The Bachelor,” was in “full-blown panic mode” searching for a suitable guy to lead its next season.

headline: Las imágenes del terremoto en México
abstract: El sismo de mayor magnitud en un siglo ha causado estragos particularmente en las zonas de Oaxaca y Chiapas.
lead_paragraph: El sismo de mayor magnitud en un siglo ha causado estragos particularmente en las zonas de Oaxaca y Chiapas.

headline: At Google, Employee-Led Effort Finds Men Are Paid More Than Women
abstract: A spreadsheet created by employees to share salary information shows pay for women is falling short of what men make at various levels.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Female employees are paid less than male staff members at most job levels within Google, and the pay disparity extends as women climb the corporate ladder, according to data compiled by employees that provide a snapshot of salary information at the internet giant.

headline: The Time Has Come, at Last, for Madison Keys and Sloane Stephens
abstract: The friends and now rivals have reached the United States Open final in grand style in a season they began on the mend instead of on the court.
lead_paragraph: That Sloane Stephens and Madison Keys have made it to a Grand Slam singles final is no surprise to anyone who has followed their careers from the start.

headline: Have You Been a Victim of Identity Theft?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from people who have been victims of identity theft.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from people who have been victims of identity theft.

headline: When Protest Signs Become Art
abstract: Tania Bruguera uses installation and performance art to oppose the inhumane treatment of immigrants. T visited her at work in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: On an unseasonably warm afternoon in San Francisco, I met the Cuban-born artist Tania Bruguera at a pop-up print shop downtown that’s run by her friend the artist Sergio de la Torre, whose work explores surveillance and U.S. immigration policy.

headline: Kendall Jenner, Kim Kardashian West, Marc Jacobs and Porn Stars Partied During Fashion Week
abstract: There were parties galore on the first night of fashion week, including a book party for Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott, and a drag ball with RuPaul.
lead_paragraph: There were parties galore on the first night of fashion week, including a book party for Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott, and a drag ball with RuPaul.

headline: Life After the Storm: Children Who Survived Katrina Offer Lessons

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The children upended by Hurricane Katrina have no psychological playbook for the youngsters displaced by Harvey, or those in the path of Irma, the hurricane that spun through the Caribbean and Florida.

headline: Texas Energy Industry Recovering From Hurricane’s Disruption
abstract: Two weeks after the storm, refineries are resuming operations, deliveries and shipping are getting back to normal and gasoline prices are stabilizing.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Two weeks after Hurricane Harvey slammed into the Texas coast, the local oil industry is getting back on its feet even as another powerful storm bears down on Florida.

headline: Passing Through Airport Security With the Touch of a Finger
abstract: Plucked out of bankruptcy after a data security problem seven years ago, a firm called Clear uses biometrics — fingerprints, iris scans — to speed up passenger identification at airports.
lead_paragraph: Airport terminals are often a maze of lines that choke check-in counters and kiosks, baggage drop-off areas, gates and security checkpoints.

abstract: On Aug. 29, three Times journalists discussed our coverage of race issues — and directly addressed questions from our readers.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests. Times Insider offers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: Cassini Burns Into Saturn
abstract: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft will plunge into Saturn on September 15, incinerating itself after 20 years in space.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft will plunge into Saturn on September 15, incinerating itself after 20 years in space.

headline: Cassini Flies Toward a Fiery Death on Saturn
abstract: Launched in 1997, the Cassini-Huygens mission has reshaped scientific understanding of the solar system’s most exotic planet and its mysterious moons.
lead_paragraph: The Cassini spacecraft that has orbited Saturn for the last 13 years would weigh 4,685 pounds on Earth and, at 22 feet high, is somewhat longer and wider than a small moving van tipped on its rear. Bristling with cameras, antennas and other sensors, it is one of the most complex and sophisticated spy robots ever set loose in interplanetary space.

headline: Jack Keil, Creator of the Crime-Fighting Dog McGruff, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Keil spearheaded a campaign to educate Americans on how to “take a bite out of crime,” and provided the voice for its cartoon spokesman.
lead_paragraph: Jack Keil, the advertising executive who created and gave voice to McGruff, the cartoon hound who exhorts Americans to “take a bite out of crime,” died on Aug. 25 at his home in Westminster West, Vt. He was 94.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from KJ Dell’Antonia, Michael M. Grynbaum and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Last Night, Calvin Klein — This Morning, Algebra
abstract: For Ariel Nicholson Murtagh, an appearance in a PBS documentary on trans kids led to a Vogue spread and a modeling agent. Now, she’s walking runways.
lead_paragraph: Ariel Nicholson Murtagh made her fashion week debut Thursday night walking in Raf Simons’s Calvin Klein show. She is 6-foot-1, weighs 125 pounds and has a kind of Pre-Raphaelite-by-way-of-Joni Mitchell hairdo.

headline: Canada Letter: A TIFF Film About Film and an Immigrant’s Story
abstract: A roundup of news for and about Canada.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto International Film Festival, a major event on the movie festival circuit, is underway. It’s facing some uncertainty now that Piers Handling has announced that he will end his 23-year run as chief executive and step down after next year.

headline: How Jake Paul Set the Internet Ablaze
abstract: The 20-year-old YouTube megastar is mining a summer of controversy to build a social media empire.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With grave concern, a television reporter for KTLA described the mayhem in the upscale Los Angeles neighborhood of Beverly Grove in July: The residents of a graffiti-marred, $17,000-a-month white contemporary house, led by a 20-year-old “social media megastar” named Jake Paul, had turned this “tightknit community” into a “war zone.”

headline: Brock Long, the FEMA Chief, Faces Test in Back-to-Back Hurricanes
abstract: The emergency management agency is stretched by disaster response from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, as well as fires and severe storms elsewhere in the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Brock Long, has received widespread praise for his handling of the federal response to Hurricane Harvey, the first major natural disaster faced by the Trump administration.

headline: Review Board Recommends Stiffest Punishment for Officer in Garner Case
abstract: The Civilian Complaint Review Board found that Officer Daniel Pantaleo used a chokehold and restricted Eric Garner’s breathing, a person familiar with the case said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City agency that investigates police misconduct has found that the officer who put his arm around the neck of  Eric Garner before his death did use a chokehold and restricted Mr. Garner’s breathing, a person familiar with the case said on Friday.

headline: T Magazine Editors on Things They’re Into Right Now
abstract: A not exhaustive list of what's on our radar.
lead_paragraph: On a leafy block of Cypress Avenue, which runs parallel to the Los Angeles River in Northeast L.A.’s Cypress Park neighborhood, the writer and editor Christie Hayden has opened Oof Books. Hayden, who developed a love for artist-made books while a graduate student at the Maryland Institute College of Art and most recently worked with Hauser & Wirth’s Book & Printed Matter Lab, found the pocket-size space while searching for an apartment on Craigslist. The idea for a bookshop came together almost immediately. She tapped designers Jonathan Olivares, Paul Matevosyan and Raffy Mardirossian to create simple, bold shelving — painted mustard yellow in a nod to the Ed Ruscha painting from which the shop takes its name — and began sourcing books. Oof specializes in artist-made and locally published books and zines, as well as older catalogs and monographs. Some of Hayden’s favorite recent finds include Jenny Holzer’s “Truisms” and a Fernand Léger that she says, “I’m definitely going to grieve a bit to sell.” The shop also features art objects by ceramist Grant Levy-Lucero and hosts regular work and talks from emerging L.A. artists.  — MERRELL HAMBLETON

headline: Cue the Castanets: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
abstract: A "Pinocchio" opera, an Amy Beach concerto and Puccini are among the highlights.

headline: Street Style: New York Fashion Week
abstract: New York Fashion Week is in full swing, and with it comes street style. We’ll be updating all week with looks from between the shows. Come back soon.

headline: A Different Brand of Leading Man
abstract: The fall movie schedule is filled with films, but few seem to be relying on their men to lead.
lead_paragraph: “Leading man” is one of those movie terms you take for granted. Then you think about it. What’s he leading? Or who? And where? Then you stop thinking: He’s leading the movie, dummy. He’s leading us. It’s a term that describes, with perfect blandness, a job that used to be tough to get but, until fairly recently, all sorts of men managed to do, from the silent era of men like Douglas Fairbanks to the advent of Channing Tatum.

headline: The New Season of Classical Music: Listings for the Fall Season and Beyond
abstract: Leonard Bernstein’s 100th birthday, a new “Tosca,” a Philip Glass residency and an operatic “Brokeback Mountain” are among the highlights.

abstract: Four new series based on Marvel Comics franchises will debut, as Netflix rolls out a David Fincher series, a new Margaret Atwood adaptation and the return of “Stranger Things.”

headline: Seriously, Equifax? This Is a Breach No One Should Get Away With
abstract: Equifax’s main job is to collect and maintain data. Now the hacking at the credit agency uncovers a gaping flaw in regulation over data storage.
lead_paragraph: Equifax, you had one job. Your only purpose as a corporation, the reason you were created and remain a going concern, is to collect and maintain people’s most private financial data.

headline: India’s Modi Criticized for Following Twitter Feed Tied to Nasty Post
abstract: Should influential people be held to a higher standard in choosing whom to follow? Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s defenders say following someone doesn’t mean you agree with them.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — What are the ethics in choosing whom to follow on Twitter? Do influential people — say, a head of state — have a higher responsibility not to follow people who post hateful tweets?

headline: Rick Stevens, Funk-Soul Singer Convicted of Murder, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Stevens’s promising career with the band Tower of Power was derailed when he was sentenced to life in prison. He was paroled after 36 years.
lead_paragraph: Rick Stevens, a vocalist for the funk-soul band Tower of Power who, after leaving the group, was convicted of killing three men in a drug-addicted haze and served 36 years in prison, died on Tuesday in Antioch, Calif., where he lived with a son. He was 77.

headline: The New Season of Art: Listings for the Fall Season and Beyond
abstract: Borders will be crossed, from Latin America to Cambodia. The fall’s hottest shows also include a David Hockney retrospective and a video installation about actors who play medical patients.

headline: Don Williams, Singer of Plain-Spoken Country Songs, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Williams, whose admirers included Pete Townshend and Eric Clapton, was best known for ballads extolling the virtues of romantic commitment.
lead_paragraph: Don Williams, a singer of heartfelt country ballads who emerged as one of the biggest stars in country music during the late 1970s, died on Friday in Mobile, Ala. He was 78.

headline: In Houston After the Storm, a City Split in Two
abstract: Life in Houston now comes with a twinge of survivor’s guilt for those in dry neighborhoods, and envy among those still dealing with floodwater.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Natural disasters are capricious, carving a hopscotching path of destruction that can swamp one neighborhood but spare another, destroy a city block but leave one lone house untouched.

headline: ‘Youzhny Lobs! Federer’s Underneath!’ Challenge of Tennis on Radio
abstract: Tennis would appear to be inherently ill suited to radio, both overly busy and potentially as narratively soporific as the shipping news.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in his radio commentary booth at the United States Open, Russell Fuller was talking fast. The players on the court far below — Roger Federer and Mikhail Youzhny, slugging it out in a drawn-out second-round match in Arthur Ashe Stadium — were playing even faster, so he had to keep up.

headline: New White House Chief of Staff Has an Enforcer
abstract: The first step in taming the White House, John F. Kelly believes, is installing a No. 2 who is willing to be hated.
lead_paragraph: Lost in the scramble to cope with Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, the response to North Korea’s nuclear provocations and the shock at President Trump’s instant alliance with Democrats was a little-noticed bureaucratic earthquake that shook the White House this week.

headline: Whistle-Blower Says He Told of Rio Olympics Corruption Years Ago
abstract: The former head of Brazil’s ice sports federation said he had raised concerns about Carlos Nuzman, the leader of Rio’s Olympics organization.
lead_paragraph: A former sports official in Brazil said he told the International Olympic Committee about corruption among organizers of the 2016 Rio Olympics several years ago — long before law enforcement officers raided the home of Brazil’s top Olympic official this week during a continuing investigation into corruption and bribery.

headline: Halim El-Dabh, Composer of Martha Graham Ballets, Dies at 96
abstract: An Egyptian-American composer, Mr. El-Dabh was best known for the haunting, Eastern-inflected scores for “Clytemnestra” and other ballets by Ms. Graham.
lead_paragraph: Halim El-Dabh, an Egyptian-American composer best known for the haunting, Eastern-infused ballets he wrote for Martha Graham, died on Sept. 2 at his home in Kent, Ohio. He was 96.

headline: We Lived Through a Flood. Now We Have a Very Long To-Do List.
abstract: Harvey left a reporter and his family with a damaged home, ruined cars and a lot of worries. But navigating the adversity yielded some perspective.
lead_paragraph: BELLAIRE, Tex. — All I could do was reach for the towels.

headline: Equifax’s Instructions Are Confusing. Here’s What to Do Now.
abstract: You’ll need a credit freeze. You’ll need a fraud alert. And don’t expect Equifax to be much help.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for all of us to play defense, because Equifax clearly did not.

headline: Panel Will Devise Guidelines for Addressing Monuments Deemed Offensive
abstract: The mayor announced the members of a commission who will recommend what to do about statues seen as “oppressive and inconsistent with the values of New York City.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday announced the members of a commission to recommend what to do about statues and other monuments in New York City that he has called “symbols of hate.”
