headline: A Generation of Architects Making Its Mark at Dizzying Speed
abstract: There’s a bumper crop of designers around the globe who are hitting their stride, adding new depth to architecture.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Johnston and Mark Lee, of the Los Angeles architectural practice Johnston Marklee, are busy getting famous.

headline: Caribbean Islands Battered by One Hurricane Are Bracing for the Next
abstract: Days after Hurricane Irma struck the Caribbean, the islands that bore the brunt of the storm are bracing for Hurricane Jose.
lead_paragraph: CODRINGTON, Antigua and Barbuda — Paul De Windt abandoned his home and holed up in his office with his family and pet cat on the island of St. Martin to wait out the fury of Hurricane Irma.

headline: It’s Thurgood Marshall to the Rescue in a New Thriller
abstract: Reginald Hudlin’s courtroom drama, starring Chadwick Boseman, depicts a Connecticut rape trial early in the future Supreme Court justice’s career.
lead_paragraph: Thurgood Marshall would be a good candidate for a dusty and dutiful biographical drama, one surveying his central role in Brown v. Board of Education, the towering 1954 civil rights landmark, and his years as the Supreme Court’s first black justice.

headline: How to Protect a Drug Patent? Give It to a Native American Tribe
abstract: Under a novel deal, Allergan will pay the Saint Regis Mohawk tribe $13.75 million. In exchange, the tribe will claim sovereign immunity as grounds to dismiss a patent challenge.
lead_paragraph: The drugmaker Allergan announced Friday that it had transferred its patents on a best-selling eye drug to the Saint Regis Mohawk Tribe in upstate New York — an unusual gambit to protect the drug from a patent dispute.

headline: Apocalyptic Thoughts Amid Nature’s Chaos? You Could Be Forgiven
abstract: Americans were excited about the eclipse, but hurricanes, wildfires, and an earthquake have some — and not just deeply religious people — thinking dark thoughts.
lead_paragraph: CLEWISTON, Fla. — Vicious hurricanes all in a row, one having swamped Houston and another about to buzz through Florida after ripping up the Caribbean.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About Apple’s New iPhones
abstract: Brian X. Chen, our lead consumer technology writer, gives answers to more than two dozen reader questions about Apple’s new devices.
lead_paragraph: Brian X. Chen, our lead consumer technology writer, gives answers to more than two dozen reader questions about Apple’s new devices.

headline: How Hurricane Irma Became So Huge and Destructive
abstract: A mix of meteorological conditions has conspired over the past week to make the storm unusually large and powerful.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Hurricane Irma barrels dangerously toward Florida, scientists say that a perfect mix of meteorological conditions has conspired over the past week to make the storm unusually large and powerful.

headline: The New Season of Theater: Listings for the Fall Season and Beyond
abstract: Creative adaptations abound, including Elevator Repair Service’s “Measure for Measure” and a musical of “The Honeymooners.” And don’t forget “Frozen.”

headline: Irma Is So Big That There Is No Good News for Florida
abstract: A growing model consensus that Irma is likeliest to make landfall on the western side of the the peninsula, but all of South Florida is in peril.
lead_paragraph: Over the last day or so, the weather forecast models have come into better agreement on Hurricane Irma’s path. It is expected to make landfall in Florida as a major hurricane.

headline: Fox News Ousts Eric Bolling After Probe Into Lewd Text Messages
abstract: The longtime host was accused of sending inappropriate messages to three female colleagues. He is the latest network personality to be forced out.
lead_paragraph: Fox News confirmed Friday that it had ousted the longtime host Eric Bolling and canceled the show he co-hosted about a month after a report that he had sent lewd photographs to three female colleagues via text message.

headline: Afghan Anger Simmers Over U.S. Leaflets Seen as Insulting Islam
abstract: With an image of Quranic text on a dog, American forces inadvertently offend the people they are there to help defend.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The sermon at the mosque in Kabul’s diplomatic quarter on Friday sounded a familiar but disquieting theme.

headline: Conservationists See a Hurricane Risk: Florida’s Exotic Pets Could Escape
abstract: With Hurricane Irma fast approaching Florida, wildlife organizations are concerned that captive, nonnative wildlife could break loose.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Andrew battered South Florida in 1992, conservationists say, a slithering, voracious species escaped a breeding facility and made its way toward Everglades National Park. There, the Burmese python, originally from Southeast Asia, would feast on raccoons, eggs and deer, multiplying into the tens of thousands, until it had ravaged the ecosystem.

headline: Why Common Critiques of DACA Are Misleading
abstract: Claims that DACA spurred a surge of unaccompanied minors from Central America, put Americans out of work and granted citizenship are not accurate.
lead_paragraph: Defenders of President Trump’s decision to rescind an Obama-era immigration policy that shielded young immigrants from deportation have offered misleading critiques of the program.

headline: Bridgewater’s Ray Dalio Spreads His Gospel of ‘Radical Transparency’
abstract: Mr. Dalio has created an unusual and confrontational workplace at Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund firm. With a new book, he hopes to inject his ideas into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of Egyptians took to the streets during the Arab Spring protests of 2011, Ray Dalio, a hedge fund billionaire, decided to sail the Nile River with some friends, including some other financiers.

headline: Monse: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Holger Czukay, 79, Influential Rock Experimenter, Is Dead
abstract: As the bassist and primary sound architect of the German band Can, Mr. Czukay made music that, he said, “creates a certain sort of vision.”
lead_paragraph: Holger Czukay, a guiding force in the German experimental rock group Can, one of the most influential bands of the 1970s, died on Tuesday at his home studio in Weilerswist, Germany. He was 79.

headline: Two Hurricanes in Two Weeks Bring Two Very Different Reactions
abstract: While officials in Houston did not order an evacuation before Hurricane Harvey, their counterparts in Florida were urging residents to leave as Hurricane Irma approached.
lead_paragraph: WEST KENDALL, Fla. — In the psychology of evacuations, what Hurricane Katrina was to Rita in 2005, so Harvey has been to Irma today.

headline: Troy Gentry of the Country Music Duo Montgomery Gentry Dies at 50
abstract: Mr. Gentry made dynamism out of country hollers and recorded three platinum albums with Eddie Montgomery.
lead_paragraph: Troy Gentry, who was part of the popular country music duo Montgomery Gentry, was killed on Friday in a helicopter crash in Medford, N.J., where the group was to play that night. He was 50.

headline: Mercurial Trump Rattles Republican Party Ahead of Midterms
abstract: From siding with Democrats to inspiring Trump-like primary challengers, President Trump is shaking up the political environment ahead of the midterms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s mercurial politics are already rattling Republicans heading into the 2018 midterm campaign, sparking Trump-like primary challenges in two high-profile Senate races and a host of lower-profile House contests, while pushing a growing number of moderate House members to the exits.

headline: 'We Shall Overcome’ Verse Not Under Copyright, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge said that the song’s adaptation from an older work, including changing “will” to “shall,” was not original enough for protection.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday struck down the copyright for part of the civil rights anthem “We Shall Overcome,” saying that the song’s adaptation from an older work — including changing “will” to “shall” — was not original enough to qualify for protection.

headline: Jim McDaniels, 69, Dies; Led Western Kentucky to Final Four
abstract: An all-American in college, McDaniels got off to a tangled start in his professional career because of contract disputes.
lead_paragraph: Jim McDaniels, a star center who led Western Kentucky University to the N.C.A.A. Final Four but whose professional career was marred by contract disputes at the start, died on Wednesday in Bowling Green, Ky. He was 69.

headline: Next Stop for the Steve Bannon Insurgency: China
abstract: President Trump’s former chief strategist is to push a combative China policy in a speech in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon has held court in the Capitol Hill townhouse of Breitbart Media since he packed up his West Wing office last month, meeting with conservative lawmakers, advocating hard-line policies on undocumented immigrants and waging gleeful war on those he considers traitors to the Trump cause.

headline: ‘The Lungs of Our Region Are on Fire:’ Wildfires Exact a Punishing Toll on the West
abstract: Times readers share personal stories about the wildfires sweeping across arid lands.
lead_paragraph: For much of this week and last, devastation wrought by Hurricane Harvey in Houston and Hurricane Irma in the Caribbean has grabbed front-page headlines. But wildfires in the West have been wreaking destruction of their own, though it has attracted less attention. Vast swaths of land have burned, choking the air with ash and smoke.

headline: Hurricane Irma Barrels Toward U.S., Threatening to Engulf Florida
abstract: The storm prompted the largest evacuation in Florida history, with people scrambling into crowded shelters and jamming highways.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to Saturday’s live Irma updates.

headline: The Arts This Fall, in 42 Articles and 80,837 Words
abstract: The fall preview issue of the Arts & Leisure section is a labor of love that takes more than six months — and dozens of journalists — to put together.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s issue of The New York Times is sure to be one of the single heaviest your newspaper carrier will ever deliver. Inside, the Arts & Leisure fall preview issue — all three parts, 42 articles, 80,837 words and 1.9 pounds of it — is independently the largest section produced by Times journalists each year.

headline: Pope Sees Two Slain Clerics as Martyrs for Peace in Colombia
abstract: In beatifying a priest and a bishop who were killed during decades of bloody conflict, Francis urges Colombians to ask and offer forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: VILLAVICENCIO, Colombia — Pope Francis acknowledged the scars of Colombia’s civil conflict on the Roman Catholic Church on Friday, honoring two clerics in the country who were murdered during the war.

headline: Rafael Nadal and Kevin Anderson Advance to U.S. Open Final
abstract: Nadal overwhelmed Juan Martin del Potro, 4-6, 6-0, 6-3, 6-2; Anderson, 31, beat Pablo Carreño Busta, 4-6, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4, to reach his first Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: One by one, over the course of several weeks, the top male tennis players dropped out of the United States Open because of injuries.

headline: Hurricane Irma Forces Yankees to Play Tampa Bay Rays at Citi Field
abstract: Major League Baseball took the cautionary step of moving the three-game series, which begins Monday, to the Mets’ home.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — As the Yankees try to chase down the Boston Red Sox during the final weeks of the season, they were handed an advantage on Friday — not by an Apple Watch, but by Hurricane Irma.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Search for Reason in Nature’s Chaos
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 9, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “For so many years, talking about the weather was talking about nothing. Now it really is our survival.”

headline: How to Help Hurricane Irma Victims
abstract: Here are some things you can do — and things you should not do — for the hardest-hit communities in the Caribbean and Florida.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Irma roars over the Florida Keys after causing destruction in the Caribbean, here is a guide to how you can help the people it affects.

headline: Betsy DeVos Ends a Campus Witch Hunt
abstract: Liberals can learn from this ugly saga of creeping authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you’re the kind of thoughtful liberal who concluded from Donald Trump’s election that you’ve been living in a bubble and need to better understand the causes of America’s distemper. Suppose, too, that you have friends who voted for Trump — and who you know for a fact are neither bigots nor buffoons.

headline: Anguilla, Reeling From Irma While Readying for Jose
abstract: Business owners and other officials in Anguilla braced for the second hurricane this week amid the destruction of Irma.
lead_paragraph: Business owners and other officials in Anguilla braced for the second hurricane this week amid the destruction of Irma.

headline: Brandon Maxwell: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Republicans Chew Gum. Walk? Not So Much.
abstract: It’s a super-heavy news time, and all the stories no longer involve the president saying something incredibly insensitive.
lead_paragraph: Tough times, concerned citizens.

headline: Something Soon to Happen
abstract: A sparkly pinwheel of a crossword.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY CROSSWORD — A themeless puzzle has fewer and longer words than a themed one. A 15 by 15 (“daily sized”) crossword can have a maximum of 78 entries on Monday through Thursday, but only 72 on Friday or Saturday. [This can vary depending on the entertainment value of an individual puzzle and is at the discretion of the editors. — D.A.] It’s one way the challenging nature of these wide-open puzzles is “engineered” in.

headline: Corrections: September 9, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 9, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Russia’s Fake Americans
abstract: The Kremlin’s stealth intrusion into the American election was broader than previously believed.
lead_paragraph: It is commonly believed that Russia’s interference in the 2016 presidential campaign consisted mainly of the hacking and leaking of Democratic emails and unfavorable stories circulated abroad about Hillary Clinton. But as a startling investigation by Scott Shane of The New York Times, and new research by the cybersecurity firm FireEye, now reveal, the Kremlin’s stealth intrusion into the election was far broader and more complex, involving a cyberarmy of bloggers posing as Americans and spreading propaganda and disinformation to an American electorate on Facebook, Twitter and other platforms.

headline: Liberty on His Mind, Doubles Champion Seizes Opportunity at the Mike
abstract: Jean-Julien Rojer’s Statue of Liberty shirt, it turns out, was no accident of fashion. The idea followed the recent violence in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: After Jean-Julien Rojer won his second Grand Slam men’s doubles title on Friday, a question about his Statue of Liberty shirt seemed obvious and innocuous.

headline: Federal Judge Halts Ezekiel Elliott’s Suspension
abstract: Elliott, the Cowboys’ star running back, appears likely to play most of the N.F.L. season instead of sitting out for six games over domestic-abuse accusations.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliott will likely play several games, if not the whole season, after a federal judge Friday issued an injunction halting his suspension for a domestic abuse accusation.

headline: Hungary Is Making Europe’s Migrant Crisis Worse
abstract: Hungary once celebrated the lifting of the Iron Curtain. Now it blocks entry to refugees.
lead_paragraph: Another summer has passed, and still there seems to be no lasting solution to one of the great humanitarian conundrums of our time: how to resettle the thousands of migrants who continue to risk dangerous passage across the Mediterranean in search of sanctuary from violence in the Middle East and Africa. The number of arrivals in Greece has steadily declined since 2015, after measures that all but closed the route from Turkey. But the problem will remain so long as conflict and poverty drive people to take huge risks in the hope of reaching Europe.

headline: Facebook Wins, Democracy Loses
abstract: Healthy democracies have transparency in political advertising. That doesn’t matter to Facebook.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — On Wednesday, Facebook revealed that hundreds of Russia-based accounts had run anti-Hillary Clinton ads precisely aimed at Facebook users whose demographic profiles implied a vulnerability to political propaganda. It will take time to prove whether the account owners had any relationship with the Russian government, but one thing is clear: Facebook has contributed to, and profited from, the erosion of democratic norms in the United States and elsewhere.

headline: Where There’s Fire, There’s Smoke
abstract: Out West, the ash in the air has literally changed how we look at the world.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — This was the summer that the forests turned red. From the fir and hemlock stands of Puget Sound to the oak and pine groves of California, the light in the woods has gone all kinds of wrong. The greens have been replaced by oranges, the normal hues vaporized in the smoke that has choked so much of the West in this season of wildfire.

headline: The Cold Warrior Who Never Apologized
abstract: Walt Rostow, an M.I.T. professor turned national security adviser, epitomized the overweening confidence of the civilian strategists of Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: As Gen. H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, wrote in his book “Dereliction of Duty,” the early stages of the Vietnam War caught America’s military leaders flat-footed. Having gone through World War II and Korea, they were all ready for a conventional war. But insurgencies and unconventional warfare were something else. As a result, they were inordinately acquiescent to the wishful thinking of their civilian overseers — and no one thought more wishfully about the war than Walt Whitman Rostow.

headline: Jeremy Scott: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Hurricane Irma Is One of the Strongest Storms In History
abstract: The hurricane has broken records for wind speed and number of days as a Category 5 storm.
lead_paragraph: The hurricane has broken records for wind speed and number of days as a Category 5 storm.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Hidden Figures’ and ‘Portlandia’
abstract: The tale of three bold African-American women who made NASA history arrives on HBO. And Season 7 of “Portlandia” comes to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: The tale of three bold African-American women who made NASA history arrives on HBO. And Season 7 of “Portlandia” comes to Netflix.

headline: Amazon Eclipse Glasses Lawsuit
abstract: Corey Payne did not see that the glasses he purchased, and gave to his fiance, were recalled by Amazon because he purchased them through his aunt's account.
lead_paragraph: Corey Payne did not see that the glasses he purchased, and gave to his fiance, were recalled by Amazon because he purchased them through his aunt's account.

headline: Europtics Eclipse Glasses Lawsuit
abstract: A couple in Colorado has accused an eyeglasses chain of providing them with counterfeit glasses, which they say damaged their eyes.
lead_paragraph: A couple in Colorado has accused an eyeglasses chain of providing them with counterfeit glasses, which they say damaged their eyes.

headline: Belgian Clubs and Foreign Money: A Modern Soccer Mix
abstract: Foreign investors are snapping up clubs in Belgium’s second division. The question everyone from Tubize to Leuven is asking is: Why?
lead_paragraph: TUBIZE, Belgium — There is something incongruous about the pregame razzmatazz at the Stade Leburton, about Michael Buffer’s catchphrase — “Let’s get ready to rumble!” — crackling out of the loudspeakers, and the pulsing, earsplitting techno soundtrack that follows.

headline: Yankees Squander an Opportunity in Texas
abstract: A chance to stay with Boston in the division race and extend their lead in the wild-card chase fell apart in the fifth after the Yankees had forged a four-run lead.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — As Yankees right fielder Aaron Judge tracked a fly ball down the right-field line that drifted into the stands, he misjudged how far he was from the wall and hit his head against it.

headline: Can a Giant Science Fair Transform Kazakhstan’s Economy?
abstract: With Expo 2017, the former Soviet Republic is trying to wean itself from oil and create a new global financial hub.
lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — By day, the huge and gleaming sphere looks like the spaceship of aliens who may not have come in peace. At night, it blinks out a playful pattern of colors and boosterish slogans on its high-tech outer skin — a few parts light show, a few parts bumper sticker.

headline: Bleak Refuge for Rohingya at Bangladesh Camps
abstract: A new wave of violence in Rakhine State in western Myanmar has caused 270,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee to Bangladesh. Many Rohingya end up in limbo in a series of refugee camps near the Cox's Bazar area.
lead_paragraph: A new wave of violence in Rakhine State in western Myanmar has caused 270,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee to Bangladesh. Many Rohingya end up in limbo in a series of refugee camps near the Cox's Bazar area.

headline: For Iraq’s Long-Suffering Kurds, Independence Beckons
abstract: A referendum on Kurdish independence is favored by Kurds and opposed by every major power in the region.
lead_paragraph: BARZAN, Iraq — A pair of rusted eyeglasses, a grimy antique watch, torn bank notes and old identification cards.

headline: Dear Amazon, We Picked Your New Headquarters for You
abstract: Let’s skip the nationwide bidding war and cut right to the winner.
lead_paragraph: Let’s skip the nationwide bidding war and cut right to the winner.

headline: Legal Marijuana Is Almost Here. If Only Pot Farmers Were on Board.
abstract: The black market for marijuana in California is thriving as growers shun the legalized system that comes into effect in January.
lead_paragraph: LAYTONVILLE, Calif. — From the sky they look like citrus groves, neat rows of lush emerald-colored plants set amid the hills of Northern California.

headline: Vetting an Apartment Before You Buy
abstract: You can be alerted to some problems ahead of time by doing your homework before you sign on the dotted line.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I investigate an apartment, its history and potential problems, before I buy it? Is there a way to determine if the neighbors are noisy, disruptive or have problems with hygiene, like hoarding? Can I test for environmental issues like mold or, in my case, cat dander? Is it possible to find out if the apartment ever had an infestation of bedbugs or other vermin? What about crime in the building? How would I know if the building has ever been reported to the city?

headline: ‘We Are Not Criminals, We Are Prisoners’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss the so-called Dreamers, incarcerated women fighting wildfires, and a nurse arrested in Utah.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: Storm Gains Strength as It Nears Florida
abstract: Officials upgraded Irma to a Category 4 hurricane early Sunday, reporting maximum sustained winds of 130 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest with Sunday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.

headline: Frustrated Survivors of Grenfell Fire Ask, ‘When Will We Get Our Lives Back?’
abstract: Almost three months after the deadly inferno in a London high-rise, only 24 of 158 households have permanent housing, and the outrage is growing at the slow pace of finding them new homes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been almost three months since the inferno that tore through Grenfell Tower, a public housing complex, killing at least 80 people and leaving hundreds more homeless. Yet, in that time, only 24 households out of 158 have been placed in permanent housing.

headline: Ralph Lauren Is Still Behind the Wheel
abstract: The designer, whose half-century ride rates among the longest in the American fashion business, also happens to have the best wheels.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t have a bike growing up,” Ralph Lauren said one recent afternoon, referring to his modest middle-class boyhood on Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx.

headline: Helmut Lang Returns! Or Does He?
abstract: To breathe life into a once great brand, Helmut Lang’s owners brought in Shayne Oliver, a host of new collaborators and a few of Mr. Lang’s classics.
lead_paragraph: In fashion, where hysteria is the dominant mode of expression and praise is often ladled out in heaps rather than spoonfuls, coronations can be instantaneous, new gods and icons minted every season. And then there is Helmut Lang.

headline: ‘Dear Sugars’: Sexless Relationships
abstract: Cheryl Strayed and Steve Almond, along with couples therapist Esther Perel, advise a letter writer whose loving partner is erotically absent.
lead_paragraph: Erotic intimacy often wanes in long-term monogamous relationships, but it’s especially confusing when your partner remains loving and affectionate. In this week’s episode, a letter writer who calls herself “About to Burst,” writes about the dual pain of emotional and physical stonewalling.

headline: A Chicago Restaurant With an Impressive Pedigree and a Nordic Soul
abstract: Elske, which opened in December in the restaurant-rich West Loop, offers a relatively affordable tasting menu and à la carte options that nimbly blend Midwestern and Nordic sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: Chicago is home to many pricey temples of fine dining (Alinea, Oriole, Grace, et al), but chefs Anna and David Posey wanted to create an alternative to the overly formal, often dauntingly expensive prix fixe experience. “We both like very fancy things, but we like going about them casually,” Mr. Posey said. The result is Elske, which opened in December in the restaurant-rich West Loop, offering a relatively affordable tasting menu ($85) and à la carte options that nimbly blend Midwestern and Nordic sensibilities.

headline: Youth in San Diego: Skateboards, Beach Hangs and Chicano Culture
abstract: “The city breathes skateboarding,” said Bruna Stalliviere, whom John Francis Peters met while photographing young San Diegans this summer.
lead_paragraph: San Diego is credited as one of the birthplaces of skateboarding. The sport took hold there in the 1950s, serving as an alternative to surfing when there were no waves. Today, locals see the skateboard as “a logistical form of transportation but also a style accessory,” the photographer John Francis Peters, who has been living there on and off for five years, said.

headline: Shades of Noir: My Hunt for an Eclipse Glasses Villain
abstract: As the first reports of eclipse eye damage emerge, a reporter attempts to get to the bottom of the shady shades fiasco.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, a couple in Colorado filed a class-action lawsuit against an eyewear chain they say gave them faulty eclipse glasses. Watching the moon’s spectacular crossing of the sun on Aug. 21 left them with distorted vision, according to their lawyer. A couple in South Carolina filed a similar lawsuit against Amazon in late August.

headline: Ian Buruma on a New Era at The New York Review of Books
abstract: Buruma has officially begun his tenure at the intellectual magazine, taking over from Robert Silvers, who died in March after having edited it since 1963.
lead_paragraph: Some shoes are harder to fill than others. Robert Silvers, the editor synonymous with The New York Review of Books, ran the left-leaning intellectual magazine with single-minded fervor from the time he co-founded it in 1963 until he died at 87 in March. His shoes may as well be Shaquille O’Neal’s.

headline: Slovak Village Prospers in Partnership With Roma Residents It Once Shunned
abstract: As other villages in Slovakia have withered and vanished, Spissky Hrhov is thriving, along with the Roma residents it has worked hard to integrate into the community.
lead_paragraph: SPISSKY HRHOV, Slovakia — In a part of eastern Slovakia where other villages are withering, Spissky Hrhov shows signs of surprising prosperity. The houses are solid and well-tended. There is running water and electricity. A former distillery has been turned into an art space, its facade decorated with a colorful mosaic.

headline: Trump Monitors Hurricane as His Cabinet Descends on Camp David
abstract: Aides said President Trump would receive hurricane briefings throughout the day as the powerful storm marches toward the southern tip of Florida.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump monitored the impact of Hurricane Irma from the presidential retreat at Camp David on Saturday as he held the fourth full cabinet meeting of his presidency to discuss how to advance his administration’s priorities during the balance of his first year in office.

headline: Introducing the Next New York Times iPad App
abstract: We are pleased to unveil a completely redesigned New York Times app for your iPad. Learn how to get it.
lead_paragraph: We are pleased to unveil a completely redesigned New York Times app for your iPad. To get the new version, go to the App Store and download it. Tap here and then hit the “GET” button.

headline: The Paranoid Style In Conservative Politics
abstract: Rush Limbaugh isn’t an outlier.
lead_paragraph: Lots of people are having fun with Rush Limbaugh’s insistence that warnings about Irma were a liberal plot, part of the great conspiracy to scare people about climate change — plus a sales gimmick for batteries and bottled water. (He evacuated his Palm Beach mansion soon afterwards.)

headline: Hurricane Irma in Pictures
abstract: Photographs from the storm and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Irma churned north into Georgia on Monday as a tropical storm, after lashing Florida with hurricane-force winds and pummeling islands in the Caribbean.

headline: Refugee Youths Build Community in an Embracing Space
abstract: The International Rescue Committee helps children acclimate to their new homes through a summer academy with a creative bent.
lead_paragraph: Riotous applause and boisterous chanting escorted Mukamil Bakhski, 16, onto the auditorium stage. He had previously sung only in the shower, never before a large crowd, and conquering his nerves was as high a priority as his performance.

headline: He Dropped a Plate. She Was Charmed.
abstract: The groom was a waiter when the couple met, and when he recovered from a moment of clumsiness, she was impressed.
lead_paragraph: Molly Elizabeth Matles and Paul Alperin Whiteman are to be married Sept. 10. Rabbi Myra Soifer is to officiate at St. Mary’s College of California in Moraga, Calif.

headline: He Loves Her Spirit, Energy, Laugh, and Her Daughter
abstract: She made it clear early on that any relationship would also include her 7-year-old daughter. He couldn’t be happier.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Szu-Pei Tang and Steven Louis DeLuca were married Sept. 9 at the Yale Club in Manhattan. Dr. Louis DeLuca, an uncle of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Drone Footage Shows Desolate Miami Beach as Hurricane Irma Nears
abstract: Normally a tourist hotspot bustling with activity, Miami Beach was all but abandoned Friday evening as Hurricane Irma approached.
lead_paragraph: Normally a tourist hotspot bustling with activity, Miami Beach was all but abandoned Friday evening as Hurricane Irma approached.

headline: U.S. Students in Florence Accuse Police Officers of Rape
abstract: Italian authorities are investigating the accusations, and Italy’s defense minister has said there appeared to be “some basis” to the allegations.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Italian authorities are investigating accusations by two American women studying abroad in Florence that they were raped on Thursday by two uniformed members of Italy’s Carabinieri police force, and Italy’s defense minister said there appeared to be “some basis” to the allegations.

headline: Leveled Mexican Town Digs for Survivors. ‘Can You Tell Me if My Dad’s O.K.?’
abstract: Rescue workers in Juchitán de Zaragoza searched desperately in the ruins of town hall for the police officer who guarded the building at night.
lead_paragraph: JUCHITÁN DE ZARAGOZA, Mexico — Under the glare of portable floodlights and the flashlights that some held, men in sweat-soaked jumpsuits dug into a hillock of rubble in this town, the night after the largest earthquake to hit Mexico in a century flattened buildings here and across southern Mexico.

headline: Data Breach Victims Talk of Initial Terror, Then Vigilance
abstract: The breach at Equifax comes on the heels of numerous cyberattacks. “It feels like there’s nothing you can really do to protect yourself,” one woman said.
lead_paragraph: One man said his name had been used to set up a fraudulent company that processed payments made with stolen credit cards. A woman said her bank had told her she was being sought by a collections agency — her Social Security number had been used to open a wireless account that was never paid off.

headline: Trump’s Bid to End Saudi-Qatar Stalemate Ends in Recriminations
abstract: President Trump brokered a phone call with the leaders of Qatar and Saudi Arabia that later resulted in dueling, ill-tempered statements.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An attempt by President Trump to break the stalemate that has divided the wealthiest countries in the Middle East ended in failure on Saturday, when leaders from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, after speaking by phone for the first time in months, exchanged dueling, contradictory statements.

headline: The Prayer Circle: Texans Rebuild After Harvey as a Practice of Faith
abstract: After the storm, 17 people joined in prayer before clearing out the flooded house of an aging widow. God, they insisted, was also there.
lead_paragraph: “In the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit …”

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: A Puns and Anagrams puzzle by Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today we have another Puns and Anagrams crossword (or “PandA”) from Mel Taub. PandA’s are a sort of hybrid between British cryptic puzzles and regular American crosswords. Cryptic purists will disagree with this description. They see PandA’s as undisciplined imitations of the real thing, but I don’t think it’s that simple.

headline: Death Toll Climbs, and Relief Efforts Stall, as Caribbean Braces for Hurricane Jose
abstract: Aid workers responding to devastation from Hurricane Irma have been stalled by the next dangerous storm: Hurricane Jose.
lead_paragraph: POINTE-À-PITRE, Guadeloupe — As communications started to be restored to the storm-ravaged islands of the Caribbean, five deaths were reported from the British Virgin Islands, raising the toll across the Caribbean to 25 people as the islands braced for yet another storm set to strike as early as Saturday afternoon.

headline: Being Like Mike: The Indians’ Corey Kluber Makes Winning Look Easy
abstract: As Cleveland has surged, running its winning streak to 17 games through Saturday, so has Kluber’s case for a second Cy Young Award.
lead_paragraph: On the bench during a recent Cleveland Indians game, the pitching coach Mickey Callaway thought of a thoroughly incongruous comparison: Corey Kluber and Michael Jordan.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Extended Rallies in Tennis Can Be a Boost, or a Backbreaker
abstract: While the winner of a drawn-out point can receive a jolt of adrenaline, the loser may be left with a damaged psyche and a fading resolve.
lead_paragraph: On the scoreboard, every point is worth the same amount, as is every game. But on the court, it’s a different story.

headline: For Rafael Nadal and His Uncle Toni, the Coaching Never Ends
abstract: Rafael Nadal will play in the United States Open final on Sunday, the final Grand Slam match with his uncle Toni as his full-time coach.
lead_paragraph: Midnight was approaching on Friday. Rafael Nadal was safely back in a United States Open final after wearing down the dangerous Juan Martín del Potro, and the next generation of Nadals was eager to get back on the court.

headline: Marching to a Second Term, de Blasio Faces a Diminished Mayoralty
abstract: The mayor’s efforts to seize the national stage may have backfired, casting him, and New York City, as less than representative of the country.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio should be at the peak of his powers. Crime is down. The economy is up. He has scared away his most serious possible challengers this election year.

headline: Nicki Minaj, the Weeknd, Raf Simons and Paris Jackson Partied Last Night at Fashion Week
abstract: Friday night of New York Fashion Week included parties for Harper’s Bazaar, Calvin Klein and The Daily Front Row.
lead_paragraph: Friday night of New York Fashion Week included parties for Harper’s Bazaar, Calvin Klein and The Daily Front Row.

headline: Airlines Face Criticism Amid Irma Price-Gouging Complaints
abstract: A tweet that went viral earlier this week sparked outrage over suspected price-gouging by airlines of Hurricane Irma evacuees.
lead_paragraph: Amid complaints of airlines taking advantage of those trying to flee Hurricane Irma, Senators Richard Blumenthal and Edward J. Markey have written to Transportation Secretary Elaine L. Chao, asking her to look into reports of possible price gouging.

headline: Bound to No Party, Trump Upends 150 Years of Two-Party Rule
abstract: In many ways, Donald J. Trump has demonstrated a level of party independence even formidable figures like Theodore Roosevelt could not achieve.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump set his sights on the presidency in the 2000 election, he pursued the nomination of the Reform Party, a home for disenchanted independents. “The Republican Party has just moved too far to the extreme right,” he explained. “The Democrats are too far to the left.”

headline: Irma’s Fearsome Winds Reach Florida Shores, With Full Strike Yet to Come
abstract: Florida opened dozens more shelters as the first wind and rainbands reached the state Saturday; more than 100,000 people were already without power.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Read the latest with Saturday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.

headline: Paraplegic Girl Attacked by Rats in France, Spurring an Investigation
abstract: Rats in northeast France repeatedly bit a disabled girl as she slept, according to her parents, who say they were upstairs at the time.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A 14-year-old girl, described as a paraplegic by her father, was so badly bitten by rats as she slept one night this month that her family says she was bleeding from her ears as well as her fingers, toes and much of her body.

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: A Nobel Peace Prize Winner’s Shame
abstract: Aung San Suu Kyi, a beloved Nobel Peace Prize winner, is presiding over an ethnic cleansing in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Aung San Suu Kyi, a beloved Nobel Peace Prize winner, is presiding over an ethnic cleansing in Myanmar.

headline: As China Moves In, Serbia Reaps Benefits, With Strings Attached
abstract: China’s leader promised the poor Balkan nation jobs, cash and investments, but its “One Belt, One Road” initiative is on a collision course with E.U. projects.
lead_paragraph: SMEDEREVO, Serbia — When President Xi Jinping of China chose an industrial town on the Danube River to announce that Serbia was at the center of a $900 billion “One Belt, One Road” infrastructure initiative, it was a bold declaration that his country had set up shop on Europe’s southeastern flank.

headline: In Kenya, Will the Peace Hold?
abstract: This time, elections did not lead to tribal violence. But the politicians will still try to turn us against one another.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Peace means so much more after you’ve experienced violence. Less than a month ago, my country, Kenya, held a hotly contested presidential election. On the morning the polls opened, my heart raced — I come from and work in the Kibera slums, and it is often said, “When Kibera burns, so does Kenya.” But not this time.

headline: The Trump Fever Never Breaks
abstract: The enthusiastic crowds I saw and the political establishment I trusted lived in separate universes.
lead_paragraph: In the first year of his presidency, Donald Trump has achieved at least three things that few presidents ever have. His approval rating is in the 30s. His former aides — and reportedly the president himself — are under federal investigation. And members of Mr. Trump’s own party are running what has been described as a shadow campaign to replace him in 2020.

headline: Move Over DiCaprio and da Vinci — Here’s Ireland’s Leo
abstract: As America and Britain reel backward, Ireland’s first openly gay, half-Indian, youngest-ever prime minister is leaping toward the future.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — It was a true Irish honeymoon — short and judgmental.

headline: ‘Dreamers’ Put Their Trust in DACA. What Now?
abstract: When your existence is shrouded in doubts, every decision is a gut check.
lead_paragraph: Past the Ferris wheel, a line of young immigrants snaked into the crowded hallways of an event space on Chicago’s Navy Pier. It was August 2012. I overheard two women wondering whether they should have showed up and gotten in the line, to apply for a new program that would let some undocumented people who had come to this country as children get a work permit.

headline: Ex-Inmate Takes to Hong Kong’s Airwaves, and Prisoners Tune In
abstract: Bruce Aitken, a convicted money launderer, sees his radio outreach to prisoners and their families as his “own personal penance.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the tiled corridors of Stanley Prison, a maximum-security complex on a rocky edge of Hong Kong’s main island, the chatter among the foreign inmates on Monday mornings tends to revolve around a single question.

headline: These Are Not the Robots We Were Promised
abstract: We were expecting Rosie from “The Jetsons” or maybe C3PO. Why did we end up with Alexa?
lead_paragraph: From the moment we humans first imagined having mechanical servants at our beck and call, we’ve assumed they would be constructed in our own image. Outfitted with arms and legs, heads and torsos, they would perform everyday tasks that we’d otherwise have to do ourselves. Like the indefatigable maid Rosie on “The Jetsons,” the officious droid C-3PO in “Star Wars” and the tortured “host” Dolores Abernathy in “Westworld,” the robotic helpmates of popular culture have been humanoid in form and function.

headline: The Donald Trump Gold Rush
abstract: Without pause or shame, exiled aides stake their claims to greater fame and fortune.
lead_paragraph: Sean Spicer lasted a mere half-year as the White House press secretary, but that was plenty long enough to mortify himself. He began with that kooky, laughable lie about the unprecedented size of President Trump’s inauguration crowd, and things didn’t pick up much from there. A punching bag for the administration, he became a punch line for much of America.

headline: Malaysian Leader, Under Corruption Cloud, Will Meet With Trump
abstract: The White House visit by Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is being investigated by the Justice Department in a case involving billions in missing funds, may give him a political lift at home.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — For more than a year, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia has been under the cloud of a corruption investigation by the United States Department of Justice. On Tuesday, his scheduled visit to see President Trump at the White House may give him a chance to offset the political damage.

headline: ‘The Shape of Water’ Takes Top Venice Film Festival Prize
abstract: This year’s festival was notable for big films that approached issues of social concern from surprising angles.
lead_paragraph: Guillermo Del Toro’s “The Shape of Water” was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 74th Venice International Film Festival by the jury led by Annette Bening. In the film, set in the 1960s, a mute cleaning woman (Sally Hawkins) falls in love with a fishlike hominid in a top-secret laboratory.

headline: The Ivanka Way
abstract: The first daughter’s not-so-naïve ideas.
lead_paragraph: About six months ago, in the long-ago springtime of the Trump presidency, Ivanka Trump made an offer to Cecile Richards, the head of Planned Parenthood. The first daughter had pressed her father to say positive things about Planned Parenthood during the 2016 campaign, and now she had a proposal for the organization’s leader: What if Planned Parenthood split up, creating a small operation that ran abortion clinics and a larger one whose health clinics didn’t perform abortions? Then her father would call for increasing funding to the larger operation, instead of joining with congressional Republicans in their efforts to defund Planned Parenthood entirely.

headline: Loneliness and the College Experience
abstract: Readers discuss a subject not often talked about.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kabul Streets Turn Violent in Annual Reminder of Civil War
abstract: Armed supporters of Ahmad Shah Massoud, an anti-Taliban leader killed in 2001, took to the capital’s streets on the anniversary of his death.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In what has become an annual breakdown of law and order, the capital turned into a scene of chaos on Saturday with little visible sign of government control. Young men armed with knives and Kalashnikov rifles sped around Kabul, firing into the air and terrorizing residents, who mostly stayed indoors.

headline: Sean McVay, 31, Raced to N.F.L. Pinnacle Faster Than His Counterparts
abstract: At McVay’s age, most current head coaches were unheralded assistants. Three were playing football. One was selling IBM software.
lead_paragraph: Sean McVay, the first-year coach of the Los Angeles Rams, is the youngest head coach in modern N.F.L. history. Two starters on the team’s offensive line are older than him. His defensive coordinator had five seasons of experience in that role before McVay was even born.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit on Care of the Disabled
abstract: A judge dismissed a longstanding lawsuit over Tennessee’s treatment of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, ending federal oversight of state programs.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — A judge on Friday dismissed a longstanding lawsuit over Tennessee’s treatment of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities, ending federal oversight of state programs.

headline: Eckhaus Latta: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: How Is President Trump’s Business Doing? Check the Electoral College
abstract: The red-blue political divide is not only informing the president’s policies, it is influencing the bottom line of the family-run Trump Organization.
lead_paragraph: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Business is booming here at the Trump National Golf Club.

headline: President Trump’s War on Science
abstract: The White House and its lackeys in certain federal agencies are censoring scientific inquiry that could inform the public and government policy.
lead_paragraph: The news was hard to digest until one realized it was part of a much larger and increasingly disturbing pattern in the Trump administration. On Aug. 18, the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine received an order from the Interior Department that it stop work on what seemed a useful and overdue study of the health risks of mountaintop-removal coal mining.

headline: Tyler Austin, Seizing a Rare Opportunity, Delivers a Win for the Yankees
abstract: Austin’s run-scoring single in the ninth backed up another strong outing by starting pitcher Luis Severino and helped the Yankees beat the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — After looking at the first pitch from reliever Richard Rodriguez, Tyler Austin stepped out of the batter’s box to gather himself. He did not need to remind himself that the bases were loaded and the score tied with one out in the ninth inning.

headline: Dolphins, Flamingos and Pigs: The Animals Rescued From Hurricane Irma
abstract: While millions of humans are evacuating ahead of the storm, the relocation of animals is an extra challenge.
lead_paragraph: Humans are not the only ones seeking shelter from the strong winds, heavy rains and deadly floods of Hurricane Irma.

headline: Sloane Stephens Beats Madison Keys to Claim U.S. Open Title
abstract: Stephens, 24 and ranked 83rd, won her first Grand Slam championship with a 6-3, 6-0 victory against Keys, her American contemporary.
lead_paragraph: It was springtime in the United States, and the women’s tennis tour was in full swing, with the clay-court season underway. Kamau Murray received a call in April from his injured protégé Sloane Stephens, who explained that she was ready to start practicing.

headline: Off the Runway: Creatures of the Wind, Adam Lippes and More
abstract: Our photographer caught the action during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Our photographer caught the action during New York Fashion Week.

headline: Well, What Should Hillary Clinton Do Now?
abstract: She is not going to be off on an indefinite hike in the Chappaqua woods.
lead_paragraph: What’s to be done with Hillary Clinton, the woman who won’t go away?

headline: Waiting for the Big One in Florida
abstract: We became hurricane veterans. We learned the drill.
lead_paragraph: ABBEVILLE, S.C. — In September 1984, my wife, Susan, and I left Fairfield, Conn., our home for 43 years, and drove south. We’d had enough of New England winters. We stopped 23 hours later in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., rented a 450-square-foot apartment on the Intracoastal Waterway a mile from the beach, and began our new life in “paradise.”

headline: Pope Francis Shifts Power From Rome With ‘Hugely Important’ Liturgical Reform
abstract: By giving more power to bishops to translate prayers into their local languages, Pope Francis reverses Vatican policy enacted by his more conservative predecessors.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis, who has used his absolute authority in the Vatican to decentralize power from Rome, made a widespread change Saturday to the ways, and words, in which Roman Catholics worship by amending Vatican law to give national bishop conferences greater authority in translating liturgical language.

headline: Weather Channel Goes Into Overdrive Covering Back-to-Back Hurricanes
abstract: In the network’s Atlanta newsroom, there is free pizza, lots of energy and scant mention of climate change.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At 8:06 on Friday morning, Nora Zimmett had a minor crisis on her hands.

headline: Size Matters
abstract: Brendan Emmett Quigley informs us of something we already knew.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I recently mentioned Brendan Emmett Quigley and his ear for speech (remember the WHY YOU LITTLE entry?). Today, he gives us a phonetically-based crossword.

headline: Not Surfing on 9/11
abstract: The waves were great. But suddenly it didn’t matter.
lead_paragraph: A large but widely ignored presence in New York City on the eve of Sept. 11, 2001, was Hurricane Erin, its cyclonic swirl starkly visible in weather maps like an ominous asterisk just off the coast. Two groups noticed: meteorologists, who mentioned the storm in passing, if at all, in news reports; and surfers, who chattered breathlessly about it.

headline: A de Kooning, a Theft and an Enduring Mystery
abstract: The recovery of “Woman-Ochre” 32 years after it was stolen raised as many questions as it answered. Could the thieves have taken it to grace their bedroom wall?
lead_paragraph: Willem de Kooning completed “Woman-Ochre” in 1955. It depicts a defiantly naked figure facing the viewer, arms akimbo. At the time, de Kooning had a studio in Greenwich Village, where his artistic vision — not to mention his quiet charm and energetic drinking — made him a figure of renown on the art scene.

headline: Irma Will Test Florida’s Infrastructure, From Dikes to Sewage Plants
abstract: The state has deferred costly maintenance, raising fears that the storm could overrun its waterworks, flood systems and other facilities.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Engineers stopped releasing water from Lake Okeechobee on Saturday, confident that they had lowered levels enough to keep the dike and the towns around it safe as Hurricane Irma swept into southern Florida.

headline: Christian Siriano: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: ‘The New Washington’: How Schumer’s Power Play Led to a Deal With Trump
abstract: In an interview for “The New Washington” podcast, Senator Chuck Schumer provides the back story for the stunning bipartisan spending-and-debt deal with President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost from the moment Republican efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act collapsed this summer and weary senators fled the capital, Senator Chuck Schumer began calculating how best to take advantage of the persistent Republican struggle to govern.

headline: A Driving Lesson. An Art Show. A Start.
abstract: Raghida had to leave her drawings behind in Syria, but now new work is on display.
lead_paragraph: Raghida had to leave her drawings behind in Syria, but now new work is on display.

headline: As Irma Swings West, Officials Scramble to Open Shelters
abstract: As thousands of people on the west coast of Florida have been forced to evacuate at the last minute, makeshift shelters have opened — and rapidly filled.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Pedro Cruz, a maintenance worker at Temple Shalom, was already taking shelter there with his family when he got a call from his supervisor on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Out With the Old, and in With La Biennale Paris
abstract: The former Biennale des Antiquaires gets a new name and a new leader, and it will become a yearly event.
lead_paragraph: Global competition has brought some big changes to the latest edition of the venerable art fair La Biennale Paris.

headline: Irma Grazes Puerto Rico but Lays Bare an Infrastructure Problem
abstract: While the island was spared the worst of the storm, widespread power failures raised questions about its future viability.
lead_paragraph: LOÍZA, P.R. — As government workers cleared roads obstructed by uprooted trees and repaired toppled electricity lines, residents of Puerto Rico felt some relief that the eye wall of Hurricane Irma had skirted the island on its recent rampage through the Caribbean.

lead_paragraph: A new series on the sex trade in 1970s New York City presents a lesser-known side of the metropolis. And Elisabeth Moss uncovers a painful truth in “Top of the Lake: China Girl.”

headline: Former FIFA Official’s Testimony Could Raise New Ethics Questions
abstract: An ex-chairman of the soccer body’s governance committee who accused top officials of improperly pressuring him may offer details at a hearing in Britain this week.
lead_paragraph: A former chairman of FIFA’s governance committee who accused top FIFA officials of pressuring him to ignore regulations said Saturday that if asked, he would provide specifics at a British parliamentary hearing this week.

headline: Instead of Launching a Missile, North Korea Throws a Party
abstract: Kim Jong-un honored his nuclear scientists for their recent test explosion as the world waited for an intercontinental missile test seen as inevitable.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea marked its government’s 69th anniversary not with another missile test, as many had feared, but with a gala party for the scientists involved in carrying out the country’s most powerful nuclear test yet last week, the state-run news media reported on Sunday.

headline: Oscar de la Renta Was Their First Job. Now, They’re in Charge.
abstract: Before their fashion week show, meet the young designers who are preserving the Oscar de la Renta brand — and pursuing a new vision.
lead_paragraph: Before their fashion week show, meet the young designers who are preserving the Oscar de la Renta brand — and pursuing a new vision.

headline: Oscar de la Renta’s New Designers Have a Hillary Clinton Story to Share
abstract: And other secrets contained in their office walls.
lead_paragraph: In the latest installment of our video series that goes inside the private working worlds of designers, Fernando Garcia and Laura Kim, co-creative directors of Oscar de la Renta, talk about taking over the corner office, their arguments over waists, and how Hillary Clinton helped them at an emotional time. And that’s what didn’t make it on screen. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: The National in Virtual Reality
abstract: Check out the trailer for the virtual reality experience “The National: Something Out of Nothing.” Directed by the Oscar nominee Marshall Curry, the experience follows the rock band The National, from studio to stage.
lead_paragraph: Check out the trailer for the virtual reality experience “The National: Something Out of Nothing.” Directed by the Oscar nominee Marshall Curry, the experience follows the rock band The National, from studio to stage.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: 15 Berkshire Road, Maplewood

headline: Storm’s Winds Begin Battering Tampa Bay Area
abstract: Downgraded to a Category 1 hurricane but still carrying fierce winds, the storm crawled up the state’s west coast after thrashing the Florida Keys.
lead_paragraph: After tearing through the Florida Keys and making landfall along the state’s southwest coast, Hurricane Irma crawled up the middle of Florida late Sunday night, slowly spinning toward the Tampa region.

headline: Traditions Revived at a Tribal Culture Camp
abstract: An ancient ceremonial practice of regalia is flourishing anew. For the Yurok Indians it is art — and a conduit to the spirit world.
lead_paragraph: KLAMATH, Calif. — The gathering known simply as “Uncle Dave’s camp” begins at daybreak on the pebbled banks of the Klamath River, the age-old spruce and redwoods on the bluffs shrouded in mist.

headline: Hurricane Irma, Mexico City, Rohingya: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Atop a Manhattan Convention Center, a Harvest of Honey
abstract: Beehives on the Javits Center’s roof are yielding their first batches of honey, which will go into dressing on salads sold in a center cafe.
lead_paragraph: Let us begin not with the who, which was several thousand bees and a bunch of people in anti-sting gear that looked like spacesuits, or the what, which was harvesting honey. Let us go directly to the where.

headline: Hurricane Irma: ‘A Low Howl,’ ‘Tearing Through the Trees,’ ‘Like Waiting for a Monster’
abstract: Those in the path of Hurricane Irma describe the looming storm in terrifying words.
lead_paragraph: Straits where there were streets. Trees snapped like twigs. Howling winds and pounding rains punctuated by the sounds of alarms in the distance.  As Hurricane Irma, continuing its  destructive march after tearing through  the Caribbean, roared across  the Florida Keys early Sunday and drove northward, Times journalists and others in the storm’s path described in words, images and social posts what they were experiencing: the sights and sounds  of a storm Florida hoped would never come.

headline: Irma Shifting Forecasts: It’s All a Matter of Probability
abstract: Floridians may feel whipsawed by the changing predictions on Irma’s course. But the forecast models “did very well with this,” one expert said, but there is room for improvement.
lead_paragraph: For much of last week, the predicted track of Hurricane Irma snaked across Florida from south to north. When it seemed to be headed toward Miami, residents on the Atlantic Coast feared the worst, and many on the west side of the state felt safer by comparison.

headline: N.F.L.: Highlights From Every Game in Week 1
abstract: The Cowboys, Packers and Raiders all won big games on Sunday. Here are the highlights from Week 1 of the N.F.L. season.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of N.F.L. Week 2 here.

headline: Egyptian Archaeologists Find Goldsmith’s 3,500-Year-Old Tomb
abstract: It belonged to a royal goldsmith who had lived in the desert province of Luxor, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: His name was Amenemhat, and he lived in Egypt about 3,500 years ago, toiling away as a royal goldsmith whose work was dedicated to an ancient Egyptian sun god.

headline: Monserrate, Ex-Senator and Ex-Convict, Seeks Votes Amid Disdain
abstract: Hiram Monserrate, who was convicted of assaulting his girlfriend and fraud, still has significant support in Corona, to the dismay of many Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Along 57th Avenue in Corona, Queens, even the storefronts can be a battlefield in what has been one of the most bitterly contentious City Council Democratic primary races of the 2017 election.

headline: Hurricane Irma’s Toll on Florida
abstract: The storm hit Florida after leaving a path of destruction across the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: The storm hit Florida after leaving a path of destruction across the Caribbean.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Tonight, make Gabrielle Hamilton’s recipe for le grand aioli, a garlicky mayonnaise served with cod and vegetables, and plan for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: A Cellist’s Challenge: Playing Bach, Surrounded by Twisting Bodies
abstract: Jean-Guihen Queyras, a specialist in Bach’s suites for solo cello, is now playing them for a dance work by Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG — The cellist Jean-Guihen Queyras has collaborated with period-instrument ensembles, made expeditions into the craggy corners of the avant-garde and produced burnished readings of chamber-music classics.

headline: Indonesia, Long on Sidelines, Starts to Confront China’s Territorial Claims
abstract: A military buildup and maritime skirmishes involving Chinese boats suggest a more aggressive posture by Indonesia in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When Indonesia recently — and quite publicly — renamed the northernmost waters of its exclusive economic zone in the South China Sea despite China’s claims to the area, Beijing quickly dismissed the move as “meaningless.”

headline: Victoria Beckham: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: 99 Years Later, Navy Probing Warship Disaster Off Long Island
abstract: What caused the sinking of the U.S.S. San Diego, the only major American warship lost in World War I, which became an underwater haven for divers and marine life?
lead_paragraph: The 15,000-ton armored cruiser U.S.S. San Diego, the only major United States Navy warship lost by the United States during World War I, lies in a watery grave about 10 miles off Fire Island, N.Y., where for nearly a century the corroding hulk has kept the secret of why it sunk.

headline: Mexico Mourns After Quake: ‘We Have No Idea How We Are Going to Rebuild’
abstract: With the death toll of Mexico’s strongest earthquake in living memory reaching 90, and further aftershocks, rescue workers began to assess the damage.
lead_paragraph: ASUNCIÓN IXTALTEPEC, Mexico — The death toll from Mexico’s strongest earthquake in living memory rose to 90 on Sunday, as the people of southern Oaxaca State mourned their dead and rescue workers began assessing the damage in small towns where dust still hung in the air.

headline: ‘It’ Breaks September Records, Supercharging the Box Office
abstract: The Stephen King adaptation arrived to $117.2 million in weekend ticket sales in North America, smashing predictions and ending an alarming Hollywood slump.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The horror movie “It” arrived as a cultural juggernaut over the weekend, smashing September box office records with an eye-popping $117.2 million in estimated North American ticket sales and ending an alarmingly slow period at multiplexes.

headline: Review: ‘Newton’s Law,’ a Comic (and Australian) ‘Good Wife’
abstract: The creators of the cult hit “Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries” return with a contemporary cross of courtroom drama and romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: The Australian television producers Deb Cox and Fiona Eagger are the creators of the series “Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries,” about a female private eye in Jazz Age Melbourne. With its raciness and its exoticism of period and place, it’s gained a cult following in the United States on PBS stations and AcornTV.

headline: Mass Trial Over Turkey’s Coup Plot Becomes an Arena of Emotion
abstract: Nearly 500 servicemen and civilians are on trial, accused of planning last year’s bloody coup attempt, a proceeding that has stirred deep passions.
lead_paragraph: SINCAN, Turkey — When it began in August, the largest mass trial of those accused of masterminding last year’s failed coup in Turkey had all the signs of a show trial. Handcuffed prisoners were marched in a line to the court past a crowd of protesters calling for them to be hanged.

headline: Trump’s Voter Fraud Panel, No Stranger to Controversy, Creates Another One
abstract: Ahead of a meeting in New Hampshire, a member of the panel called it “highly likely” that the state’s Senate race was decided with bogus votes. Outrage ensues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s commission on voter fraud, which has ricocheted between controversies since its creation in May, is scheduled to hold its second public meeting on Tuesday in New Hampshire. Already, the commission’s de facto leader has warmed up for the session by suggesting that the election in November of Senator Maggie Hassan, a New Hampshire Democrat, was rigged.

headline: Public School : Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Why Ryan, Undercut by Trump, May Actually Emerge Stronger
abstract: In a trying week, Speaker Paul D. Ryan took shots from his unruly House conservatives, but he deftly channeled their anger onto the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul D. Ryan rode to power two years ago like a hero on a white horse, a reluctant candidate for House speaker elected to heal wounds left by his predecessor, who could not tame the incessant infighting between hard-line conservatives and establishment Republicans.

headline: Michael Friedman, Co-Creator of ‘Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,’ Dies at 41
abstract: A versatile, cerebral and witty composer and lyricist, Mr. Friedman had a particular fascination with politics, which informed much of his work.
lead_paragraph: Michael Friedman, a versatile, cerebral and witty composer and lyricist who brought a historian’s eye and a journalistic sensibility to pathbreaking work off and on Broadway, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 41.

headline: Dry Cleaning the City’s Oldest Maps
abstract: They call themselves “dry cleaners” — government workers who wash and care for some of the oldest maps and architectural drawings of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The tables in the basement of the Municipal Archives are covered with household staples: cotton swabs, tweezers, food strainers, measuring cups, ashtrays and other materials.

headline: Snapchat Videos of Florida Keys Show Irma's Fury
abstract: With few reporters stationed in the Florida Keys on Sunday morning, Snapchat videos posted by residents who chose to brave Irma showed the fury of the Category 4 hurricane.
lead_paragraph: With few reporters stationed in the Florida Keys on Sunday morning, Snapchat videos posted by residents who chose to brave Irma showed the fury of the Category 4 hurricane.

headline: At $1,000, Apple’s iPhone X Crosses a Pricing Threshold
abstract: Apple will unveil a luxury iPhone on Tuesday that will feature innovations like facial recognition, but its price could be an issue in global markets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple unveils its new top-of-the-line iPhone on Tuesday, it isn’t just expected to offer features like infrared facial recognition and wireless charging for the first time.

headline: 4 Things You Should Do About the Equifax Hack
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: After Equifax Breach, Here’s Your Next Worry: Weak PINs
abstract: Now that as many as 143 million Social Security numbers may be out in the wild, everyone wants to freeze their credit files at once. It isn’t always easy.
lead_paragraph: When Helene Muller-Landau first heard the news about the Equifax security breach, she set about freezing her credit files and those of her husband and mother.

headline: Nancy Hatch Dupree, Scholar of Afghanistan, Is Dead at 89
abstract: Mrs. Dupree, who arrived in Afghanistan in 1962, devoted decades to preserving the country’s heritage in its darkest days.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nancy Hatch Dupree, an American writer and historian who arrived in Afghanistan in 1962 and devoted decades of her life to preserving the country’s heritage during some of its darkest times, died in Kabul on Sunday. She was 89.

headline: Thanks, Internet Outrage! Now Dapper Dan and Gucci Are Buds
abstract: He borrowed their logos. They bit his look. Now Gucci and Dapper Dan are going to do some appropriating in Harlem — and around the world.
lead_paragraph: In a twist of fortune that could hardly have been imagined back in the day, Daniel Day — better known as Dapper Dan, his nom de knockoff — is reopening his famous studio and atelier with the support of Gucci.

headline: Religious Rite Takes Hamlet Back in Time Every Seven Years
abstract: An ancient Catholic procession featuring hooded faithful and parades attracts thousands of tourists to a village in Italy’s south.
lead_paragraph: GUARDIA SANFRAMONDI, Italy — Centuries ago, legend has it, a farmer discovered a wooden Madonna statue in a field in the emerald hills northeast of Naples. After locals fought to keep the statue, they honored it with rituals. Some 500 years later, those rituals continue.

headline: As Irma’s Winds Rise, So Does a Debate Over TV Storm Reporting
abstract: Television correspondents are standing out in the storm as Hurricane Irma lashes Florida. Is that necessary? Reporters say better them than you.
lead_paragraph: Early Sunday morning, Bill Weir, a veteran CNN correspondent, was talking to the anchor Chris Cuomo in the middle of a live shot in Key Largo, Fla. He could barely stand up straight in the lashing winds of Hurricane Irma. At one point, he was nearly blown over by a gust.

headline: Tome: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: A Village Voice Reunion, and Nobody Got Punched
abstract: As the storied alt-weekly prepared to end its print edition, some alums gathered. They hugged, they cried, they groused.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like the end of ‘Recherche du Temps Perdu,’” the writer Richard Gehr said Saturday night, looking over the crowd at the Downtown Community Television Center in TriBeCa. “Everyone is here, but they’re older.”

headline: Hurricane Irma, Apple, Myanmar: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Month Has Passed Since Trump Declared an Opioid Emergency. What Next?
abstract: While the president’s opioid commission has urged him to move swiftly, President Trump and his cabinet are confronting warnings from deficit hawks about the potential costs.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump announced in early August, following a presidential commission’s recommendations, that the opioid crisis was a “national emergency,” he called it “a serious problem the likes of which we have never had.”

headline: A Lot of Sound and Supermodels, Signifying Not Much
abstract: Alexander Wang, Tory Burch, Jeremy Scott, Victoria Beckham and more search for relevance on the runway. A hashtag isn’t the answer.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, long after the sun had set and a pre-autumn chill had returned to the air, a horde of fashion folk were standing on the sides of an otherwise deserted dead-end street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, penned up and shivering behind metal barriers.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 11
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Writing the Vows Column Means Crashing Weddings for a Living
abstract: Wedding announcements in The Times have changed over the years, but the cataloging of “I do” remains constant.
lead_paragraph: Together, Brunilda Burgos, a student working toward her dental technician degree, and Adalberto Rodriguez, a foreman at a plexiglass company, achieved a special honor: The first couple to have their wedding, held on a rainy May afternoon in 1992, profiled for The New York Times’s Vows column, a feature in the Weddings section that describes “How couples got from dating to ‘I Do.’ ”

headline: Off the Runway: Sies Marjan, Victoria Beckham, Public School and More
abstract: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Sunday.

headline: Ex-Leader, Now a Man Without a Country, Surfaces in Ukraine
abstract: Mikheil Saakashvili, a former president of Georgia who is stripped of citizenship there and in Ukraine, is an exceptional position: He’s a stateless ex-head of state.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Mikheil Saakashvili, a former president of Georgia, finds himself in an unusual position for a former head of state: He is stateless, and spent Sunday trying to enter a country that does not want him, first by train, then by bus and finally on foot with a crowd of supporters who forced open the border into Ukraine.

headline: Where Trump’s Hands-Off Approach to Governing Does Not Apply
abstract: Social conservatives are enjoying clout in Washington as they secure new policies on gays, guns and abortion. Some civil servants have left as a result.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration opened the door to allowing more firearms on federal lands. It scrubbed references to “L.G.B.T.Q. youth” from the description of a federal program for victims of sex trafficking. And, on the advice of religious leaders, it eliminated funding to international groups that provide abortion.

headline: Tracy Reese: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Robots and Humans Team Up at Amazon
abstract: Amazon’s warehouses, which now employ more than 125,000 people across the United States, are being outfitted with the latest in robots and tech, but not at the expense of human jobs.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s warehouses, which now employ more than 125,000 people across the United States, are being outfitted with the latest in robots and tech, but not at the expense of human jobs.

headline: As Amazon Pushes Forward With Robots, Workers Find New Roles
abstract: Amazon is on the forefront of automation, finding new ways of getting robots to do the work once handled by human employees.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, N.J. — Nissa Scott started working at the cavernous Amazon warehouse in southern New Jersey late last year, stacking plastic bins the size of small ottomans. It was not, she says, the most stimulating activity. And lifting the bins, which often weigh 25 pounds each, was also tiring over 10-hour shifts.

headline: Anthem Demonstrations Include a Show of Unity in Cleveland
abstract: Browns players locked arms during the national anthem with law enforcement agents and emergency workers.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Cleveland Browns and law enforcement agents and emergency workers ran onto the field together and locked arms during the national anthem on Sunday before the team’s first game of the season, defusing tension over earlier protests by some Browns players during the song.

headline: Total-Look Denim, One More Time
abstract: There’s still life to be mined from the workingman’s standby.
lead_paragraph: Seriously taken with denim — the top-to-toe kind — designers advanced the look for spring with eye-catching, if occasionally oddball, variations on this all-purpose staple.

headline: Hurricane Irma Inspires Stay-at-Home Church Services
abstract: As Floridians bunkered up on Sunday morning awaiting Hurricane Irma, pastors conducted services from home and streamed live messages of hope online.
lead_paragraph: As Floridians bunkered up on Sunday morning awaiting Hurricane Irma, pastors conducted services from home and streamed live messages of hope online.

headline: To Sell Themselves to Donors, Nonprofits Are Turning to the Pros
abstract: Branding and marketing experts are helping groups explain their aims more clearly and connect with potential supporters on an emotional basis.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the website for the nonprofit Colon Cancer Alliance offered a treasure trove of information about colorectal screening, colon cancer research and other topics related to the deadly disease.

headline: Doctor in the House
abstract: An evening at the theater yields a potentially lifesaving tip.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Head-in-the-Clouds Place
abstract: Erik Agard and Paolo Pasco let their minds wander.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Did you notice today’s unusual grid? For one thing, it’s 14x16, not 15x15. One less square. No wonder it went so fast.

headline: Sies Marjan: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.
