headline: In the Future, Warehouse Robots Will Learn on Their Own
abstract: At the University of California, Berkeley, robots are teaching themselves to grab objects they’ve never seen before.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The robot was perched over a bin filled with random objects, from a box of instant oatmeal to a small toy shark. This two-armed automaton did not recognize any of this stuff, but that did not matter. It reached into the pile and started picking things up, one after another after another.

headline: Chasing Alexander Wang’s Citywide Runway Show
abstract: In this season’s biggest and logistically complicated fashion show, Mr. Wang staged not one but three separate runway shows. We followed the Wang entourage for 266 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang likes to make a spectacle during New York Fashion Week, whether it’s hosting blowout parties or forcing fashion editors to trek out to far-flung locations.

headline: A ‘Call’ to Shoot at Hurricane Irma Gains Unexpected Attention
abstract: A Facebook post about firing weapons into Hurricane Irma went viral this week. Not everyone was in on the joke.
lead_paragraph: The event was called “Shoot at Hurricane Irma,” and everyone was invited.

headline: ‘Uncontacted’ Amazon Tribe Members Reported Killed in Brazil
abstract: Investigators are looking into reports that around 10 tribe members died when they were set upon by gold miners.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — They were members of an uncontacted tribe gathering eggs along the river in a remote part of the Amazon. Then, it appears, they had the bad luck of running into gold miners.

headline: Pope Ends Colombia Visit With Plea for Those ‘Still Being Sold as Slaves’
abstract: Rounding out a six-day trip, Pope Francis visited the bones of a Roman Catholic saint who devoted his life to helping slaves in the 17th century.
lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — Pope Francis concluded his trip to Colombia on Sunday by visiting the bones of a 17th-century Roman Catholic saint who devoted his life to helping slaves, and whose legacy the pontiff called an example to all for his defense of the poor.

headline: Rafael Nadal Wins the U.S. Open for His 16th Grand Slam Title
abstract: The top-ranked Nadal defeated the surprise finalist Kevin Anderson, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4, to win his third U.S. Open and his first since 2013.
lead_paragraph: They did the time warp again on Sunday. It has been that sort of season in men’s tennis. Scar tissue? What scar tissue? Creaky knees, wrists and confidence? Banish the demons and roll back the years.

headline: China’s Electric Car Push Lures Global Auto Giants, Despite Risks
abstract: G.M., Ford and Volkswagen are increasingly working on new-energy vehicles in a country that is pressuring them to share trade secrets.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Volkswagen, the German auto giant, is preparing for a swift expansion in its output of electric cars next year — and the biggest jump in production will be in China. General Motors is making China the hub of its electric car research and development. Renault-Nissan, the French and Japanese carmaker, and Ford Motor have hustled to set up joint electric-car ventures in China.

headline: Taxi Medallions, Once a Safe Investment, Now Drag Owners Into Debt
abstract: Some taxi owners say they cannot hold on much longer as they lose riders and fares to Uber and other rivals, and their taxi medallions plummet in value.
lead_paragraph: Owning a yellow cab has left Issa Isac in deep debt and facing a precarious future.

headline: Child Welfare Proceedings, and a Racial Divide
abstract: An advocate for families writes of racial and economic disparities in child welfare cases.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: When Tech Companies Enlist Teachers
abstract: Readers discuss how corporations have courted teachers as their “ambassadors” to bring their products into the classroom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Doing Right by the Dreamers
abstract: A reader says it would be ironic if President Trump were the one to nudge DACA into legislation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Construction Cranes in Miami Become Multi-Ton Threats During Irma
abstract: The arms of at least two cranes collapsed on Sunday after city officials said it was impossible to move them in time for the hurricane.
lead_paragraph: Construction cranes are a ubiquitous sight in Miami, symbols of a growing city towering hundreds of feet above its streets. They are built to withstand high winds, but maybe not to withstand Hurricane Irma.

headline: Memo to Hollywood
abstract: A technology management consultant writes that Hollywood should be striving to create high-quality content.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Women in the Work Force
abstract: A reader asks what happens when women leave the job market.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sanitation in India
abstract: A sociologist writes that “experiences within one’s personal networks are likely to shape rural Indians’ decisions to build and use toilets.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Recovery From Two Hurricanes, and German Automakers Look Forward
abstract: Damage assessments begin from Irma as Houston regains its footing, and a big auto show in Frankfurt could be a breath of fresh air for BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: Spared Irma’s Worst, Puerto Ricans Sail to Virgin Islanders’ Aid
abstract: Using pleasure boats, civilians have improvised a boatlift to carry donated supplies to the devastated islands and bring back evacuees.
lead_paragraph: FAJARDO, P.R. — Puerto Rico, dealt only a glancing blow by Hurricane Irma, has become an impromptu emergency hub for its Caribbean neighbors that were left devastated by the storm’s wrath.

headline: Florida Is No Stranger to Hurricanes, but This Is Different
abstract: As Hurricane Irma made landfall twice on Sunday and drove up the Gulf Coast, Floridians were left with hardly anywhere to hide.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Bracing for hurricanes is almost a summer tradition here: the steady, clanking sound of wood banged to windows, the endless lines for bottled water and fuel, the pilgrimages to fortified shelters.

headline: Bannon Calls Comey Firing the Biggest Mistake in ‘Modern Political History’
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist, spared few from criticism in a new interview, going after Republicans, former colleagues and the media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first extended interview since he left the White House last month, Stephen K. Bannon was unsparing in his criticism: calling out top Republicans, West Wing staff, the “pearl-clutching mainstream media,” special counsel investigators and the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Irma Roars In, and All of Florida Shakes and Shudders
abstract: Hurricane Irma hit hardest at the Florida Keys and the Gulf Coast, but the whole state felt its wrath after one of the largest evacuations in American history.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ready or not, Florida found itself face to face with Hurricane Irma’s galloping winds and rains on Sunday, as evacuees and holdouts alike marked uneasy time in homes and shelters from the Keys to the Panhandle, tap-tapping their nearly dead cellphones for news they were frantic to hear but helpless to change.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Yankees Prepare to Settle in at Home After Soundly Defeating Rangers
abstract: The Yankees left the road on a high note, hoping to make the most of a return to New York, where they have fared much better this season.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When the Yankees packed their bags and headed for home Sunday night, a 16-7 thrashing of the Texas Rangers that featured two homers apiece from Aaron Judge and Gary Sanchez was not all that left them buoyant.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 3 Premiere: All That Was Me Is Gone
abstract: As a new season begins, Claire and Jamie find themselves swimming in a difficult aftermath.
lead_paragraph: As romantic as “Outlander” can be, it’s always been most fascinated by who people become when they’re suffering. It’s one of the show’s most interesting threads, although it goes wrong as often as it goes right.

headline: Desperation Mounts in Caribbean Islands: ‘All the Food Is Gone’
abstract: Food and water were in short supply on many islands in the Caribbean after Hurricane Irma, and witnesses spoke of a disintegration of law and order.
lead_paragraph: MARIGOT, St. Martin — At dawn, people began to gather, quietly planning for survival after Hurricane Irma.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Devastated Island’s Cry: ‘All the Food Is Gone’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 11, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “All the food is gone now. People are fighting in the streets for what is left.”

headline: Prabal Gurung: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Review: Sexual Assault as Both History Lesson and Satire
abstract: The playwright Michael Yates Crowley mixes unlikely genres in “The Rape of the Sabine Women, by Grace B. Matthias.”
lead_paragraph: Only one of the title characters in “The Rape of the Sabine Women, by Grace B. Matthias” — a new play by Michael Yates Crowley — is a living human. She is Grace, a teenager in a generic Springfield where the football team reigns and “weird” girls get called pigs with impunity.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Series Premiere Recap: No Such Thing as a Free Breakfast
abstract: Like David Simon’s other creations, HBO’s new series about the ’70s porn industry in Times Square reminds us that the devil’s in the details.
lead_paragraph: In the defining scene of the pilot episode of “The Deuce,” a Times Square prostitute named “Candy,” played by Maggie Gyllenhaal, agrees to deflower a nervous student named Stewart for the going rate of “30 and 10” — $30 for the service, $10 for the room. Once they get up to the room and Candy gets down to business, however, Stewart’s excitement and inexperience betrays him, much as it has many overeager young men in his position.

headline: A 13-Year-Old’s Success in Tennis Raises Questions About Age Limits
abstract: Unlike the men’s tour, the women’s tour carries age restrictions that limit the number of professional tournaments open to players under age 18.
lead_paragraph: The retired players Kim Clijsters, Lindsay Davenport, Mary Joe Fernandez and Martina Navratilova held a news conference after their exhibition doubles match on Sunday at the United States Open and spoke glowingly of American women’s tennis success.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Her Political Future: ‘I Am Done With Being a Candidate’
abstract: In an interview with CBS’s “Sunday Morning,” part of a publicity tour for her new book, Mrs. Clinton spoke about losing the election and her plans for the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton, who grapples with her second failed presidential run in a new memoir to be published Tuesday, said on Sunday that she does not plan on running again for public office.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 2 Finale: Prentice Penny on Issa, Lawrence, Safe Sex and Narrative Swerves
abstract: “If our characters start always making good choices, then we don’t have a show,” Mr. Penny said.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 2 finale of “Insecure.”

headline: Don Ohlmeyer, ‘Monday Night Football’ Producer, Dies at 72
abstract: Two decades after Mr. Ohlmeyer managed diverse personalities on the football program, he guided NBC in an era of prime-time hits like “Seinfeld” and “ER.”
lead_paragraph: Don Ohlmeyer, whose influential television career ranged from producing ABC’s “Monday Night Football” during its 1970s heyday to guiding NBC to No. 1 in prime time two decades later on the strength of programs like “Seinfeld” and “ER,” died on Sunday in Indian Wells, Calif. He was 72.

headline: Need to Catch Up on the German Election? Here’s a Guide
abstract: With the vote on Sunday, read New York Times coverage to learn more about the election and the issues that have been roiling Germany and Europe.
lead_paragraph: For daily news updates from a European perspective, sign up for our Morning Briefing.

headline: A Picturesque Retreat in a Tiny Town in Puglia
abstract: When his Rome apartment grew too small for his collections, an American curator found a historic home — and layers of lost history.
lead_paragraph: THE ART HISTORIAN and curator Peter Benson Miller was 13 when his parents began taking him to antiques markets and junk shops near their weekend house in Litchfield County, Conn. By the time he moved for good to Italy almost 30 years later, in 2009 — he is now in charge of the exhibition program and special events at the American Academy in Rome — he had amassed a huge number of objects, or, to be precise, collections of objects: 30 prints depicting Mary, Queen of Scots (‘‘I am attracted to the history of English female martyrs,’’ he says), dozens of French ice buckets in the form of pineapples, 200 cactus-shaped vintage ceramic salt and pepper shakers from the American Southwest. He had hundreds of pieces in storage, and several hundred more jammed into the rented apartment in central Rome he shared with his partner, Giovanni Panebianco, a civil servant.

headline: Gunman Kills 8 at Cookout at Suburban Dallas Home
abstract: A police officer shot and killed a gunman in Plano, Tex., after responding to reports of shots being fired at a residence.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A gunman opened fire during a cookout for a Cowboys game at a suburban Dallas home on Sunday night, killing eight people before a police officer fatally shot him, the authorities said.

headline: For Qatari Network beIN Sports, Political Feud Spills Into Stadiums
abstract: The fallout is affecting business for beIN Sports across the Middle East and Africa, where it has millions of subscribers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the world’s biggest buyers of sports rights has a problem: It’s Qatari.

headline: Bills Defeat the Jets in a Clash of Expected Also-Rans
abstract: Buffalo quarterback Tyrod Taylor threw two touchdown passes, running back LeSean McCoy racked up 110 yards, and the Bills won a game between teams with slim prospects.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — In a season-opening showdown between two of the least-promising teams in the N.F.L., the Buffalo Bills beat the Jets, 21-12, on Sunday and, because of an upset and a natural disaster, will spend the next week alone atop the A.F.C. East standings.

headline: Dallas Cowboys, With a Jolt From Ezekiel Elliott, Overwhelm the Giants
abstract: Punchless without Odell Beckham Jr., who sat out to recuperate from a sprained ankle, the Giants fell to Dallas and Elliott, who gained 104 yards rushing and 36 receiving after a stay of a suspension.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The rivalry between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys is long and storied. But the young men involved in the teams’ latest white-hot confrontations do not much care about what happened in 1960, the first time the teams met.

headline: Hurricane Irma, Apple, Pope Francis: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Fenty Rihanna X Puma: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: U.S. Open Shows One Road to the Top Goes Through College
abstract: Kevin Anderson is the first ex-college tennis player since 1999 to reach a final at the United States Open, which includes a collegiate invitational.
lead_paragraph: When four American women squared off in the semifinals of the United States Open, it signaled a resurgence of women’s tennis in this country. And Kevin Anderson’s appearance in the men’s singles final is giving a boost to college tennis.

headline: A Behind the Scenes Look at Rihanna’s Fenty x Puma Show
abstract: Rihanna followed up her Fenty Beauty launch with a fashion show that began and ended with BMX stunts over pink sand dunes.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna followed up her Fenty Beauty launch with a fashion show that began and ended with BMX stunts over pink sand dunes.

headline: The Man Who Keeps the Wheels Turning at the U.S. Open
abstract: For tennis’s wheelchair competitors, having a fine-tuned chair is vitally important. That’s why the technician Mike Zangari is always nearby, with casters and spokes at the ready.
lead_paragraph: Shingo Kunieda was fretting. It was Thursday, and Kunieda, his coach, his trainer, his clothing sponsor and his wife were all bent over, trying to pump air into the tires of his wheelchair.

headline: No Corrections: September 11, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, September 11, 2017.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, September 11, 2017.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Preacher’ and ‘Newton’s Law’
abstract: In the Season 2 finale of “Preacher,” the deadly trio plans to hit the road again. And Claudia Karvan tackles cases big and small in “Newton’s Law.”
lead_paragraph: In the Season 2 finale of “Preacher,” the deadly trio plans to hit the road again. And Claudia Karvan tackles cases big and small in “Newton’s Law.”

headline: Word + Quiz: concave
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Giancarlo Stanton Is Nearing 61 Homers. But Is He Chasing a Record?
abstract: Stanton has a shot at passing Roger Maris’s 61 home runs in a season, which many consider to be the true mark, even though it was bested during the steroid era.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — If you want to understand someone’s baseball soul, look at the game when that person was 8 years old. Those are the days of miracle and wonder, the sweet spot when baseball grabs ahold of you and fixes your view of it forever.

headline: What Kind of Time Management Skills Are You Learning from the Adults in Your Life?
abstract: Do your parents model good behavior when it comes to things like being punctual, finishing tasks on time and allowing themselves appropriate amounts of unscheduled time?
lead_paragraph: Are your parents good at managing their time? What habits, if any, have you picked up from them?

headline: In Guantánamo, Ensnared in the War on Terror
abstract: Debi Cornwall’s new book on detainees at Guantánamo Bay Naval Base looks at a complicated reality that has been forgotten by most.
lead_paragraph: Debi Cornwall’s new book on detainees at Guantánamo Bay Naval Base looks at a complicated reality that has been forgotten by most.

headline: The Dogma of Dianne Feinstein
abstract: In grilling Catholic judicial nominee Amy Coney Barrett about her faith, the senator revealed her own orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: In September 2015, amid the Republican Party’s fervid primary campaign, Ben Carson briefly outshone Donald Trump for nuttiness. The retired neurosurgeon (now the secretary of housing and urban development) declared in an interview that a Muslim should never be placed “in charge of this nation.” Liberals were horrified, and rightly so. Yet today liberals have their own tolerance blind spot, and Christians are most likely to get caught in it.

headline: Conspiracies, Corruption and Climate
abstract: It’s not just Rush Limbaugh: Know-nothings are running America.
lead_paragraph: After the devastation wreaked by Harvey on Houston — devastation that was right in line with meteorologists’ predictions — you might have expected everyone to take heed when the same experts warned about the danger posed by Hurricane Irma. But you would have been wrong.

headline: Soul Survival in Trump’s Hell
abstract: Trying to maintain hope in today’s America.
lead_paragraph: You could stay in hell for a little while if you knew that you were going to get out.

headline: Remembering the Disappeared
abstract: We must emulate the families of terror victims who wouldn’t let their loved ones’ memory be erased.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Of the 2,753 victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, no physical trace has been found for 1,112 of them. Thus, for 40 percent of those who died that day, no remains have been returned to their families. In the aftermath of the carnage, some people exhibited photos, family snapshots, of those who had vanished and remained unaccounted for, despite the efforts of the authorities.

headline: A Way to Get Great Teachers Into the Classroom
abstract: As a teacher who has had to jump through New York’s certification hoops, I’m pleased by a plan to let charter schools certify teachers themselves.
lead_paragraph: When schools reopened in New York last week, students were greeted by teachers who had spent the summer preparing for their return. Unfortunately, many of those teachers had had to devote some of their time not to lesson plans, but to a state teacher-certification process that emphasizes bureaucratic procedures more than real-world qualifications.

headline: Cambodia’s Democracy Betrayed
abstract: Hun Sen says he will continue his corrupt regime for another 10 years, and he is trying to silence journalists and other critics.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia has been in power for more than 30 years. On Wednesday, he vowed to stay in power. “After witnessing the treasonous acts of some Cambodians in recent days,” he said, “I have decided to continue my job for another 10 years.”

headline: 9/11: Finding Answers in Ashes 16 Years Later
abstract: New York’s medical examiners have never given up hope that their analysis of DNA can help identify the victims lost 16 years ago.
lead_paragraph: An inscription on the lobby wall greets visitors in Latin at the offices of the New York City medical examiner. It is an adage familiar to places where autopsies are performed. Reasonably translated, it says: “Let conversation cease. Let laughter flee. This is the place where death rejoices to help the living.”

headline: The South Doesn’t Own Slavery
abstract: Rooting out racial injustice only in former Confederate States ignores our country’s true history.
lead_paragraph: The violent furor that erupted this summer over the removal of Confederate monuments in several cities was a stark reminder that Americans remain trapped in the residue of slavery and racial violence. In confronting this difficult truth, our attention is naturally drawn to the South. And rightfully so: The South was the hotbed of race-based labor and sexual exploitation before and after the Civil War, and the caldron of a white supremacist ideology that sought to draw an inviolable line between whiteness and blackness, purity and contagion, precious lives and throwaway lives. As the author of three histories on slavery and race in the South, I agree that removing Confederate iconography from cities like New Orleans, Baltimore and Charlottesville, Va., is necessary and urgent.

headline: Why George Bernard Shaw Had a Crush on Stalin
abstract: The radical playwright imagined a utopia ruled by a great leader who embodied Russia’s soul.
lead_paragraph: Dublin — Shortly after midnight on Nov. 2, 1950, when the Cold War was well underway, all the illuminated signs on Broadway and Times Square were dimmed in salute to the most prominent Western admirer of Stalin. The Irish dramatist George Bernard Shaw had just died, and the tribute reflected the fame of plays such as “Pygmalion,” “Man and Superman” and “Saint Joan.”

headline: Kris Kobach and His 5,313 Fraudulent Voters
abstract: President Trump’s phony electoral integrity commission strikes out again.
lead_paragraph: The voter-fraud crusaders who run President Trump’s electoral-integrity commission have found their holy grail: evidence that large-scale illegal voting swung a pivotal Senate election in 2016.

headline: The Problem of ‘Living in the Present’
abstract: Taken literally, it’s just bad advice. But philosophy can redeem this self-help cliché.
lead_paragraph: These days, many of us would rather not be living in the present, a time of persistent crisis, political uncertainty and fear. Not that the future looks better, shadowed by technological advances that threaten widespread unemployment and by the perils of catastrophic climate change. No wonder some are tempted by the comforts of a nostalgically imagined past.

headline: In Guantanamo, Ensnared in the War on Terror
abstract: Debi Cornwall’s new book on the detainees held at Guantánamo Bay Naval Base looks at a complicated reality that has been forgotten by most.
lead_paragraph: To Debi Cornwall, Guantánamo Bay Naval Base is a study in contradictions.

headline: Storm Pushes North, but Millions Are Without Power in Florida
abstract: After days of frantic preparation, Floridians awoke Monday to destruction that fell short of the direst forecasts, but still faced life-altering damage.

headline: New York Today: The Children of 9/11
abstract: Monday: A film about strength and hope, Tribute in Light, and an anniversary at the Williamsbridge Oval.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this autumn Monday.

headline: An Exit Interview With Richard Posner, Judicial Provocateur
abstract: Retiring abruptly after 35 years on the bench, Judge Richard A. Posner says he will devote himself to helping people who cannot afford lawyers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Richard A. Posner, whose restless intellect, withering candor and superhuman output made him among the most provocative figures in American law in the last half-century, recently announced his retirement.

headline: In Free-Range Trump, Many See Potential for a Third Party
abstract: Many Republicans believe President Trump may have made it inevitable that the G.O.P. will rupture and spawn a third party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican Party likes to think of itself as a big tent — not always a harmonious one, but full of all types.

headline: What to Read Before Your U.S. Road Trip
abstract: These three writers saw the country from the ground.
lead_paragraph: There is something quintessentially American about feeling compelled — whether it be by the lyrics of a song (“Promised Land” by Chuck Berry), or by the journey of another writer — to jump on a bus (or a train or a car) and ride across the country. Here are three books that celebrate seeing the United States at eye level.

headline: Houstonians Adrift in Their City, Trying to Call Somewhere Home
abstract: After Hurricane Harvey, residents are in shelters, hotels, packed in with relatives, and on the sofas of friends. They face worry, exhaustion, mold.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Hurricane Harvey’s floodwaters have left this sprawling metropolis partially ruined and eager to return to something like normalcy. But the storm has also forced many thousands of people out of their homes. As a result, the city is engaged in one giant collective improvisation. Its defining creative endeavor is where to find a place to sleep.

headline: Hunting for the ‘Promised Land,’ Haunted by Chuck Berry
abstract: The musician’s 1964 hit chronicles the African-American experience in the 20th century. We followed Mr. Berry’s lyrical route to see what had changed.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Berry’s 1964 classic “Promised Land” is all about motion. The opening guitar riff is a big and fast thing taking off, a bus leaving the station, a jet rising from the tarmac. The poor boy, our narrator, is endlessly rollin’ and ridin’, straddling that Greyhound, smoking into New Orleans, swinging low chariot, coming down easy.

headline: Broken Promises in the Promised Land
abstract: Mixing genres and voices, Nathan Englander’s novel “Dinner at the Center of the Earth” offers a tragicomic take on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: DINNER AT THE CENTER OF THE EARTHBy Nathan Englander252 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: Irma May Force Florida Insurers to Turn to Deeper Pockets
abstract: Big insurers pulled back after Hurricane Andrew, leaving coverage largely to smaller companies leaning on a state fund and on reinsurance policies.
lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Irma’s destructive force having pushed north, Floridians are beginning to check on what has become of their homes. They may also want to check on their insurers.

headline: Hurricane Irma Linked to Climate Change? For Some, a Very ‘Insensitive’ Question
abstract: Scientists are concerned that Trump administration officials are sidestepping questions about climate change after two major hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Pruitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says it is insensitive to discuss climate change in the midst of deadly storms.

headline: The Right Way to Memorialize an Unpopular War
abstract: James Reston Jr.’s “A Rift in the Earth” tells how a bitter controversy over the Vietnam War memorial ended in national reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: A RIFT IN THE EARTH Art, Memory, and the Fight for a Vietnam War Memorial By James Reston Jr. Illustrated. 267 pp. Arcade. $24.99.

headline: Can You Pick the Bees Out of This Insect Lineup?
abstract: How can we save the pollinators if we don’t even recognize them?
lead_paragraph: How can we save the pollinators if we don’t even recognize them?

headline: Shopping for Kitchen Faucets
abstract: A faucet may seem like a minor part of your kitchen, but it plays an outsize role in the way the space functions — and how it looks.
lead_paragraph: Compared with towering refrigerators and commercial-style ranges, a faucet may seem like a minor component in a kitchen. But it has an outsize effect on the overall look — and function — of the space.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 11, 2017
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 14, 2017

headline: 摩登情爱：被战争推迟的吻
abstract: 因为波斯尼亚和黑塞哥维那的战争，这个12岁女孩的人生和爱情被击碎了。
lead_paragraph: 因为波斯尼亚和黑塞哥维那的战争，这个12岁女孩的人生和爱情被击碎了。

headline: A Helpful Tool to Combat the Opioid Crisis
abstract: Prescription drug monitoring programs can reduce the overuse of narcotics — but many states have adopted relatively weak versions.
lead_paragraph: The opioid crisis is so complex and so large — drug-related deaths now exceed those caused by cars, H.I.V. or guns — that there is no single solution. Among the partial ones: prescription drug monitoring programs, an approach highlighted in the draft report from President Trump’s Commission on Combating Drug Addiction and the Opioid Crisis.

headline: Florida, September 11, N.F.L.: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Girls in Western Australia Gain Right to Wear Pants and Shorts to School
abstract: Public schools in Australia have often mandated that girls wear skirts, which can inhibit physical activity. Complaints about the policy have renewed momentum.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Girls at public schools across the state of Western Australia will be allowed to wear pants and shorts to class, no longer restricted to only dresses, skirts or skorts.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: In Florida and Bracing for Irma
abstract: We speak with two Miami residents, one who refused to evacuate and one who drove north, only to end up in Irma’s path.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Alternatives to Drugs for Treating Pain
abstract: Specialists are exploring nondrug, noninvasive treatments, some of which have proved highly effective.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago I was plagued with debilitating headaches associated with a number of seemingly unrelated activities that included cooking for company and sewing drapes for the house. I thought I might be allergic to natural gas or certain fabrics until one day I realized that I tensed my facial muscles when I concentrated intently on a project.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Cost of Irma to Florida’s Insurers
abstract: The hurricane’s human toll has been considerable, but while initial damage estimates are being rolled back, the health of Florida’s insurers could still be on the line.
lead_paragraph: After battering a string of Caribbean islands, Hurricane Irma hit Florida on Sunday, but was downgraded on Monday.

headline: In Praise of Pragmatism, the Champions League’s Secret Weapon
abstract: The Premier League sells entertainment, and its top teams are conditioned to deliver it. But the Champions League doesn’t hand out points for style.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — José Mourinho has never sought points for style. Throughout his career, he has positioned himself at every turn as the standard-bearer for substance, a man at war with soccer’s legion of self-appointed, self-identifying aesthetes.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Irma Roars In, and All of Florida Shakes and Shudders’
abstract: How does this article show the hurricane’s force? How does it help readers understand what it was like for some Floridians to live through it?
lead_paragraph: Note: Our Article of the Day generally focuses on just one compelling piece, but when there is important breaking news — like this unfolding disaster — we provide a wide range of materials for broader help in teaching and learning about the topic.

headline: This Is the Greatest N.F.L. Rookie Class Since ...
abstract: Kareem Hunt, T.J. Watt and Leonard Fournette all impressed in their N.F.L. debuts. Does that mean anything?
lead_paragraph: By the end of the season, Kareem Hunt will hold the N.F.L.’s rushing record. Dubious? He’s already the league’s best running back.

headline: 5 Questions About Single-Payer Health Care
abstract: The odds are rising that Democrats will make a push toward single-payer when they next are in charge. Here are the questions to consider.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Homeless and Facing a Hurricane, One Man Tells a Reporter His Story
abstract: While covering Hurricane Harvey, Julie Turkewitz met a man preparing to weather the storm under a highway.
lead_paragraph: I met Roy Joe Cox outside a Wal-Mart the morning before Harvey rolled into Houston. Beneath the gray sky and spitting rain, he wore a red hat and stood like a statue in the parking lot, a hand on his black rolling suitcase.

headline: California Today: From L.A. to Florida, With Rescue Boats in Tow
abstract: Monday: Los Angeles rescuers help out in Florida, a still thriving black market for marijuana, and the brilliance of California sunsets.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Rohingya Crisis in Myanmar Is ‘Ethnic Cleansing,’ U.N. Rights Chief Says
abstract: The security campaign that has led more than 300,000 people to flee to Bangladesh is in clear violation of international law, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official accused Myanmar on Monday of carrying out “a textbook example of ethnic cleansing” against Rohingya Muslims, hundreds of thousands of whom have crossed into Bangladesh since late August to escape a military crackdown.

headline: Hurricane Irma: Video and Images From Social Media
abstract: As the hurricane rolled north, leaving residents to cope with widespread flooding, images on social media captured the powerful effects.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Irma rolled north on Monday, videos and pictures on social media captured the storm’s powerful effects throughout Florida.

headline: The Season’s Best Bohemian Dresses
abstract: From floral to folk, free-spirited designs make a statement with print, color and embellishment.
lead_paragraph: Simone Rocha dress, $3,615, simonerocha.com.

headline: Tempted to Worry? Try Making Concrete Plans Instead.
abstract: Taking action — not fretting — is an excellent career and business strategy. It took our Sketch Guy a while to figure that out, though.
lead_paragraph: Worry is a terrible business strategy.

headline: The Day Nothing Changed
abstract: Why 9/11 wasn’t another Pearl Harbor.
lead_paragraph: It’s 9/11 again – and almost nobody is commemorating the anniversary. It didn’t even occur to me to use my print column space for the purpose, given all the ongoing current horrors. But since I have a bit of time before my 14-hour flight, I thought I’d take a few minutes to talk about what was supposed to happen after 9/11, but didn’t.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ and ‘Stranger Things’ Take Early Emmys Lead
abstract: The shows each won multiple Creative Arts Emmy awards, which were given out last weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live,” “Westworld” and “Stranger Things” have an early lead at this year’s Emmy Awards after a batch of technical and guest acting awards were handed out this past weekend.

headline: Trump Commemorates Sept. 11 Attacks With Vow to Conquer ‘Evil’
abstract: President Trump commemorated the anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks with a vow to conquer evil and to keep the nation safe.
lead_paragraph: President Trump led a national moment of silence on the 16th anniversary of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Monday, the first commemoration for a New York native who has described the destruction of the Twin Towers as a defining event in his political life.

headline: Cook to Bring Comfort
abstract: Mushroom lasagna, pasta with caramelized cabbage, anchovies and bread crumbs: Make cooking a priority on a mournful day.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: China’s Currency Rebounds as Economic Optimism Returns
abstract: Though the country faces long-term problems, like soaring debt, the government’s recent moves have reassured investors that it can stave off crises.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For those who worry about the state of the world economy, China has long been a major reason to lose sleep. Its financial system labors under a mountain of loans, while weaker growth has prompted many Chinese people and companies to move their money overseas in recent years.

headline: Merkel Suggests Germany Should Join North Korea Talks
abstract: With German elections approaching, the chancellor highlighted her global status by urging negotiations with North Korea based on the model of the nuclear deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In what the Germans themselves are calling a “sleep campaign,” Chancellor Angela Merkel, seeking a fourth term in office in elections on Sept. 24, has moved to highlight her international status by calling for a new round of negotiations with North Korea — including Germany.

headline: Women Dominating Rock: There’s More to the Conversation
abstract: What happens when the media shines a light on feminist punk? A conversation about D.I.Y. scenes and representation, on Popcast.
lead_paragraph: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: After U.S. Compromise, Security Council Strengthens North Korea Sanctions
abstract: The Security Council adopted a measure that sets a modest cap on oil imports to North Korea, far weaker than what the United States had sought.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Monday ratcheted up sanctions yet again against North Korea, but they fell significantly short of the far-reaching penalties that the Trump administration had demanded just days ago.

headline: Suicide Data Incorrectly Reported in Drug Trials, Suit Claimed
abstract: Paxil was approved following large clinical trials. But two suicides recorded in the placebo group should not have been counted, an F.D.A. reviewer wrote.
lead_paragraph: For many years GlaxoSmithKline and its predecessor, SmithKline Beecham, marketed Paxil as an antidepressant that would reduce the risk of suicide in depressed patients. The results of the company’s clinical trials, presented to the Food and Drug Administration in 1989, suggested Paxil was far safer than a placebo.

headline: Lawsuit Over a Suicide Points to a Risk of Antidepressants
abstract: Some patients taking antidepressants experience nearly intolerable agitation, a side effect that experts say may be linked to suicide.
lead_paragraph: The last dinner Wendy Dolin had with her husband, Stewart, he was so agitated that he was jiggling his leg under the table and could barely sit still. He had recently started a new antidepressant but still felt very anxious. “I don’t get it, Wen,” he said.

headline: Indians and Dodgers: A Tale of Two Streaks
abstract: The Indians are on an 18-game winning streak, one of the longest in history. And the Dodgers have somehow lost 10 in a row.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is an up-and-down game. You win one, and, well, you’ll probably lose one tomorrow or the next day.

headline: What Does It Cost to Create a Cancer Drug? Less Than You’d Think
abstract: A new study suggests that biotech companies are spending far less than believed on research and development for approved drugs, despite rising prices.
lead_paragraph: What does it really cost to bring a drug to market?

headline: Coach, Husband, Architect, Father. One Title Was a Fake.
abstract: Paul J. Newman forged signatures and used a phony stamp to work on hundreds of construction projects in several New York counties for years.
lead_paragraph: BALLSTON SPA, N.Y. — A rumpled man sat in the back row of the Saratoga County courthouse on Tuesday, waiting for his criminal case to be called. His was third on the docket, after the arraignment of a sex offender facing charges of child molestation and the sentencing of a drunken driver. The man, Paul J. Newman, thought back to his old life, one that ended April 17, with his arrest.

headline: Hemingway’s Six-Toed Cats Ride Out Hurricane Irma in Key West
abstract: The 54 cats, many of them descendants of one owned by Hemingway, live at the author’s house in Key West, which was hit hard by Hurricane Irma.
lead_paragraph: Entire islands have been reduced to rubble, streets have turned to rivers, cranes have buckled and more than 30 people have died. But the six-toed Hemingway cats are fine.

headline: LCD Soundsystem, Leaning on Traditional Sales, Has a No. 1 Album
abstract: The band’s first studio album in seven years, “American Dream,” debuted at the top of the chart with only 6.3 million streams.
lead_paragraph: The dance-rock band LCD Soundsystem called it quits in 2011 at what seemed to be the top of its game, with a farewell concert at Madison Square Garden that was captured in a documentary. Festooned with critical praise, the band, led by the producer and wit James Murphy, had never reached higher than No. 10 on the Billboard chart.

headline: What Swims Like a Duck and Quacks Like a Duck Could Be a Hybrid of Two Duck Species
abstract: Hybridization has nearly wiped out bird species in the past, so researchers studied whether mallard ducks could put pressure on less-common Mottled ducks.
lead_paragraph: A duck is a duck, right? Well, yes, but when one duck mates with a duck of another species, there’s the risk that one of the original species could cease to exist. And then that duck is a duck no more.

headline: Decades After Alcohol Ban, Iran Admits It Has a Problem
abstract: Drinking remains a crime, but Alcoholics Anonymous is flourishing and dozens of private and government clinics have opened alcohol rehabilitation centers.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — For most of his life, alcohol rehab for Mehdi consisted of regular stretches in prison and lashings that left dark marks on his back. Now, at 36, he has prematurely gray hair, but with the help of an Alcoholics Anonymous group he swears he has finally stopped drinking.

headline: Pope Criticizes Climate Change Deniers and Trump on DACA
abstract: On his flight back to Rome, Pope Francis said climate change deniers need to consult scientists and urged President Trump not to end DACA.
lead_paragraph: ROME — As he flew near Caribbean islands devastated by Hurricane Irma on his way back to the Vatican from Colombia on Sunday, Pope Francis said that political leaders and others who denied climate change reminded him of a passage from the psalms about man’s stubbornness.

headline: Michael Friedman, a Man of Many Voices and a Gift for Prophecy
abstract: His versatility as a musical theater composer was matched by his emotional ardor and political shrewdness.
lead_paragraph: “Populism, yea, yea…”

headline: Rosie Assoulin: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: ‘It’: What You Should Read After Watching the Blockbuster Movie
abstract: The Stephen King adaptation broke box-office records this weekend. Here are some of the most interesting spoiler-filled articles from across the web.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: Ruling Conservative-Led Bloc Wins Norway’s National Elections
abstract: A race that was close in opinion polls, the election was viewed as a referendum on taxes, immigration, energy policy and European integration.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — The coalition led by the center-right Conservative Party won the final round of Norway’s national elections on Monday, in what was seen as a referendum on taxes, immigration, energy policy and European integration.

headline: Alexander Wang, The Business of Fashion, DVF and Rihanna Partied Over the Weekend
abstract: Fashion week partygoers included Selena Gomez, Tory Burch, Taylor Hill, Cardi B, Pharrell Williams and Rae Sremmurd.
lead_paragraph: Fashion week partygoers included Selena Gomez, Tory Burch, Taylor Hill, Cardi B, Pharrell Williams and Rae Sremmurd.

headline: Asking Questions Louis C.K. Doesn’t Want to Answer
abstract: The comedian tackles taboos in his surprise new film and addresses internet chatter.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “It’s not a safe space, it’s not a triggerless place, it just isn’t,” said Louis C.K., describing — in no small understatement — his darkly funny and squirm-inducing new movie, “I Love You, Daddy,” which debuted to warm applause and some revulsion at the Toronto International Film Festival over the weekend.

headline: Origin of a Protest March
abstract: A reader objects to being derided as a “cautious moderate.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pope Francis in Colombia
abstract: A reader says Pope Francis’ trip to Colombia was “in many ways deeply representative of his papacy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Are We Seeing the Trump ‘Pivot’ at Last? If So, Why?
abstract: Readers cite evidence of a pivot and offer theories why: a diversionary tactic or a way to boost his businesses’ bottom line in blue states.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Robert Fairchild to Leave New York City Ballet
abstract: With acting and musical theater roles on the horizon, Mr. Fairchild, who starred in “An American in Paris,” said he felt he needed to choose a direction.
lead_paragraph: Robert Fairchild, the New York City Ballet principal dancer who earned a 2015 Tony nomination for his performance in Christopher Wheeldon’s “An American in Paris,” will leave City Ballet at the end of this season. His final performances, the matinees of Oct. 14 and 15, will be in George Balanchine’s “Duo Concertant,” with Sterling Hyltin.

headline: Justice Kennedy’s Order Temporarily Leaves in Place Trump Travel Ban on Refugees
abstract: Justice Kennedy issued an administrative stay in the travel ban case, temporarily blocking an appeals court ruling on refugees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on Monday issued a temporary order allowing the Trump administration to exclude most refugees from entering the United States while the Supreme Court considers challenges to its revised travel ban.

headline: Equifax’s Maddening Unaccountability
abstract: I don’t doubt the company regrets what happened. But I don’t think it cares that much either.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Americans woke up to news of yet another mass breach of their personal data. The consumer credit reporting agency Equifax revealed that as many as 143 million Americans’ Social Security numbers, dates of birth, names and addresses may have been stolen from its files — just the kind of information that allows for identity theft and other cybercrimes.

headline: The Contradictions of Hajj, Through the Lens of a Smartphone
abstract: As I completed this pillar of my faith, I was preoccupied with the conflicting messages all around me. To make sense of them, I shared everything.
lead_paragraph: Is it permissible to take a selfie in front of the Kaaba during hajj? With spotty internet, I was unable to Google the answer. Forced to call an audible fatwa, I decided, “Yes, if indeed my intention is pure.”

headline: Brain-Damaged Boxer Will Receive $22 Million in Settlement With State of New York
abstract: Magomed Abdusalamov sustained severe brain damage during a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden nearly four years ago.
lead_paragraph: The State of New York has agreed to pay $22 million to a boxer who sustained severe brain damage during a heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden nearly four years ago, in a case that raised serious questions about the postfight care given to athletes who have just exchanged repeated blows to the head.

headline: Learning Local Customs, Whether by App or in Person, Eases Travelers’ Way
abstract: Some global business travelers make a point of getting to know new territories in person, but smartphone apps and training sessions are valuable.
lead_paragraph: On a sales trip last fall to Seoul, South Korea, Josh Udashkin, the founder of the smart luggage company Raden, quickly realized that he’d better leave the matte-finish suitcase samples in his hotel room.

headline: In the Art World, ‘Latinx’ Marks a Gender-Free Spot
abstract: Some curators of “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA” push for a new genderless term — Latinx — to replace Latino/Latina.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This week represents the official start of Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA, some 70 museum exhibitions, from San Diego to Santa Barbara, that explore Latin American and Latino art. With galleries getting into the act, too, visitors to the shows are likely to encounter tons of new work. And two new words: Latinx and Chicanx.

headline: From United Airlines, an Invitation-Only Restaurant at Newark
abstract: We tried Classified at Newark Liberty International Airport. The verdict: Nice room, good food. The mystery: Who gets to go?
lead_paragraph: The online chatter and curiosity surrounding Classified, the invite-only restaurant at Newark Liberty International Airport for United Airlines fliers, started soon after the carrier began emailing invites to a select few customers in late August.

headline: Irma Swiftly Lays Claim to Florida’s Sea of Trees
abstract: Perhaps more than any building or home, it was the palms, and a host of other canopy trees, that took the full force of the storm.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — After the wind and rain had passed, and the Florida sun had begun shining again, Bruce Mawry emerged from his Miami Beach home to find a grisly scene of fallen trunks, scattered fronds and rolling coconuts. It amounted to a palm tree massacre.

headline: Eyes on the Road, Not on the Phone
abstract: Driving while texting can cause accidents, but apps and gadgets can shut down notifications when you’re behind the wheel.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do those apps that block phone texting while driving know when to turn on? Do you need special hardware?

headline: In Florida, a Storm’s Fright Gives Way to a Blackout’s Troubles
abstract: In Hurricane Irma’s wake, the most widely felt damage has been to the state’s electricity system, with millions of customers left without power.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The homecoming was a relief, at first: Across much of Florida, evacuees emerged from temporary shelters on Monday to find that Hurricane Irma had spared most houses and lives.

headline: The Damage Wrought by Hurricane Irma
abstract: Readers discuss how Irma brought out the good in people, how reporters risked their lives, global warming and the Mexican quake.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rohingya, Irma, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: She Was Teaching Him to Walk. He Shot Her From His Wheelchair.
abstract: The Afghan polio patient, who had received 19 years of treatment from the International Red Cross, opened fire on his physiotherapist. She was killed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — He was a polio patient, for 19 of his 21 years receiving treatment at an orthopedic center in northern Afghanistan run by the International Committee of the Red Cross. The organization’s seven rehabilitation centers around the country are often the last hope for a new leg or arm for the thousands who have lost legs and arms to the long war.

headline: How Single-Payer Health Care Could Trip Up Democrats
abstract: It’s their version of “repeal and replace.” But converting to “Medicare for all” requires complicated choices.
lead_paragraph: Many Democrats giddy from their recent health policy successes are starting to reach enthusiastically for a mountaintop goal: establishing a single-payer system for all Americans.

headline: A ‘Futurist Woman,’ a Defunct Casino, and a Fight for Macau’s Soul
abstract: The 1960s hotel, Macau’s first casino resort, is not an architectural treasure, but many residents, especially the young, have an emotional connection.
lead_paragraph: MACAU — What will become of Lady Luck?

headline: For One Hedge Fund, a Bet on the Affordable Care Act Sours
abstract: Glenview Capital Management’s investment in a large hospital chain, Tenet, has proved disappointing as the industry struggles to adapt.
lead_paragraph: Wagering that the new federal health care law would be a boon, the billionaire investor Larry Robbins bet big on hospital stocks five years ago. Those investments helped propel his hedge fund, Glenview Capital Management, to the ranks of the top-performing funds in 2013.

headline: Cambodia’s Opposition Chief Loses Immunity in Treason Case
abstract: Parliament has approved the prosecution of the opposition leader, Kem Sokha, stripping away his last shield in a crackdown by Prime Minister Hun Sen.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Lawmakers voted on Monday to approve the prosecution of Cambodia’s opposition leader on charges he committed treason in collusion with the United States.

headline: Maria Sharapova on Serena Williams: ‘Maybe We’ll Become Friends. Or Not.’
abstract: In her new memoir, Sharapova speaks of Williams in a detailed and often antagonistic way, tracing their rivalry’s breaking point back to the 2004 Wimbledon final.
lead_paragraph: Maria Sharapova’s first significant breakthrough in professional tennis was her victory over Serena Williams in the 2004 Wimbledon final. In the years since then, the matchup has been one-sided; Williams has won their last 18 matches.

headline: Images of Heroism Emerge From Hurricane’s Turmoil
abstract: Pictures of daring rescues amid the destruction of Hurricane Irma helped buoy spirits.
lead_paragraph: The images of destruction and peril during Hurricane Irma have been hard to avoid, and the challenges are just beginning for those who evacuated or sheltered in place.

headline: Adding Pantries and Spice to New York’s Hungry Neighborhoods
abstract: Food providers are changing the way pantries are operated in the city to better serve more than 1 million people who need emergency food.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, New York City’s three biggest providers of emergency food have reorganized in an effort to feed underserved communities and get ethnic ingredients to specific neighborhoods.

headline: Patty Jenkins to Direct ‘Wonder Woman’ Sequel
abstract: After months of speculation, news emerged that Ms. Jenkins, the director of the franchise’s first installment, will helm part two.
lead_paragraph: It’s a real wonder that Patty Jenkins was not immediately signed up to direct a sequel to “Wonder Woman,” after the film smashed box office records this summer to become the highest-grossing live-action movie directed by a woman. Finally on Monday, after months of speculation and talks, news emerged that Ms. Jenkins would indeed be directing “Wonder Woman 2.”

headline: Protest in Catalonia Adds to Pressure Before Independence Vote
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Catalans celebrated their national day in Barcelona, vowing to hold an Oct. 1 referendum on whether to break from Spain.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Hundreds of thousands of Catalans took over the center of Barcelona on Monday to mark their national day and raise the pressure on the Spanish government in Madrid before an independence referendum planned for Oct. 1.

headline: Harry & Ida’s Opens a Luncheonette and More Food News
abstract: The latest from the Harry & Ida team, Delmonico’s celebrates its 180th anniversary, and a new way to make meatballs.
lead_paragraph: Will and Julie Horowitz, a brother-and-sister team, have opened a financial district offshoot of Harry & Ida’s Meat & Supply, their grocery and casual dining spot in the East Village with an Old World point of view and an emphasis on local, homemade smoked and pickled foods. This branch, called Harry & Ida’s Luncheonette (the name refers to the Horowitzes’ great-grandparents), is more spacious and serves plates priced at less than $15. “We take ideas from our heritage,” Mr. Horowitz said. “Uptown, we did the meat thing, but, here, it’s more about vegetables.” You’ll still find Mr. Horowitz’s succulent pastrami, but he is also preparing turnip-noodle kasha varnishkes, carrot tsimmes with urfa chiles and lime, and smoked apricot ras-el-hanout chicken, all available to eat in or to take out as single portions or by the pound. Pickles, sauerkraut and other items often rely on vegetable discards, like mushroom stems and the outer leaves of cabbage. Stale babka is used in burnt-sugar babka soft-serve: Harry & Ida’s Luncheonette, 11 Park Place (Church Street), 917-409-0028, meatandsupplyco.com.

headline: Derek Lam: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Sentencing of Tatar Leader in Crimea Is Called a Sham
abstract: The leader, Akhtem Chiygoz, was found guilty of inciting mass riots protesting the Russian presence in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian court in the contested Crimean peninsula sentenced a minority Tatar politician to eight years in prison on Monday, in a trial that his lawyers and human rights organizations called a sham.

headline: England’s Soccer Federation Asks FIFA to Address Cybersecurity Ahead of World Cup
abstract: F.A. has written to FIFA to express concerns about a hacking group believed to based in Russia.
lead_paragraph: England’s soccer federation has written to FIFA to express concerns about the leak of confidential antidoping correspondence by a hacking group believed to be based in Russia, and to request assurances about the soccer governing body’s cybersecurity preparations ahead of next year’s World Cup there.

headline: Off the Runway: Phillip Lim, Derek Lam, Lela Rose and More
abstract: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Our photographers caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Monday.

headline: 3.1 Phillip Lim: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Monster Surge That Wasn’t: Why Irma Caused Less Flooding Than Expected
abstract: The storm’s track over land and other elements of meteorological luck meant that far less of Florida was underwater than had been projected.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — Across coastal Florida, the dreaded storm surge from Hurricane Irma — caused when ferocious winds pile up ocean water and push it onshore — was not as bad as forecast. While some areas were hard hit, notably the Florida Keys and Marco Island, residents of neighborhoods north to Fort Myers, Sarasota and Tampa Bay were expressing relief.

headline: For Indie Designers, Uniting Is a Survival Skill
abstract: Several dozen designers have pooled their resources to market their wares in a boutique in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: For an independent designer operating in a world of megabrands like Amazon, Zara, Nike and H&M, an old maxim may hold the key to survival: United we are stronger.

headline: U.S. Seeks Decades in Prison for Ex-Rikers Guard in Fatal Beating
abstract: Federal prosecutors are seeking a nearly 30-year sentence for a former Rikers guard who was convicted in the kicking death of a seriously ill inmate.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Monday asked a judge to sentence a former correction officer on Rikers Island to nearly 30 years in prison for violating the civil rights of a seriously ill inmate who died after the officer assaulted him.

headline: Urgent, but Not an Emergency
abstract: An unexpected question from a doctor just before he stitches up a cut.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Florida, Myanmar, Pope Francis: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Len Wein, Influential Comic Book Writer, Dies at 69
abstract: Through characters like Wolverine and Swamp Thing, he helped bring a new depth to his art form.
lead_paragraph: Len Wein, a prolific comic book writer who collaborated on bringing to life two of the art form’s best-known characters, Wolverine and Swamp Thing, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 69.

headline: Travel Companies Have a New Clientele: Hurricane Evacuees
abstract: Cruise lines, Airbnb and Expedia are among those working to get people out of harm’s way and get them shelter.
lead_paragraph: Travel companies that typically transport vacationers to carefree getaways became part of the very real struggle by evacuees to get out of town or find lodging in the days before and after Hurricane Irma made its fatal sweep through the Caribbean and Florida.

headline: Lotfi Zadeh, Father of Mathematical ‘Fuzzy Logic,’ Dies at 96
abstract: Professor Zadeh sought to apply mathematics to the ambiguous ways people talk, think and interact with the world.
lead_paragraph: Lotfi Zadeh, the computer scientist and electrical engineer whose theories of “fuzzy logic” rippled across academia and industry, influencing everything from linguistics, economics and medicine to air-conditioners, vacuum cleaners and rice cookers, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Congress Rejects Trump Proposals to Cut Health Research Funds
abstract: Congress has rejected President Trump’s plan to cut funds for biomedical research and would instead increase spending by the National Institutes of Health.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in March, when President Trump released the first draft of his budget proposal for the coming fiscal year, he asked lawmakers for deep cuts to one of their favorite institutions, the National Institutes of Health — part of a broad reordering of priorities, away from science and social spending, toward defense and border security.

headline: Regents Approve Plan to Evaluate and Improve New York Schools
abstract: A federal education law passed during the Obama administration requires states to create a plan for school improvement, which Washington must approve.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Board of Regents on Monday approved a plan laying out the state’s goals for its education system, as required by the sweeping federal education law signed by President Barack Obama in 2015 known as the Every Student Succeeds Act.

headline: New Gene-Therapy Treatments Will Carry Whopping Price Tags
abstract: Kymriah, approved recently by the F.D.A., with a $475,000 price tag, is first of a coming wave of treatments whose expected prices have alarmed economists, scientists and insurers.
lead_paragraph: The first gene therapy treatment in the United States was approved recently by the Food and Drug Administration, heralding a new era in medicine that is coming faster than most realize — and that perhaps few can afford.

headline: Robert Menendez Personally Lobbied for Visas, Former Aide Testifies
abstract: As the government began its corruption case against the New Jersey senator, a former adviser testified that Mr. Menendez intervened in visa applications involving a friend.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Senator Robert Menendez took a personal interest in obtaining visas for three women who were acquaintances of a wealthy friend and donor, directing senior members of his staff to take up the issue, a former aide to Mr. Menendez testified on Monday.

headline: After the Storm, It’s Finally the First Day of School in Houston
abstract: About 80 percent of Houston’s schools opened on Monday, two weeks later than planned. Other schools need more time, amid $700 million in damage.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Kacey Cartwright and his family lost their home during Hurricane Harvey, spent a few difficult nights sheltered at a convention center and are now living in a hotel far from their old neighborhood. So the first day of school here on Monday was a welcome respite.

headline: A Stranger in Maryland, Touched by a Hurricane Story, Sends 3 Cups to Houston
abstract: After reading about a woman who lost cups that had belonged to her mother, the stranger found three identical pieces and had them sent to Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As we walked through Shirley Hines’s flood-battered Houston neighborhood on Sunday, we passed pile after pile at the curb — the soggy, ruined contents of people’s homes, mixed with floorboards, Sheetrock and insulation.

headline: Nicolaas Bloembergen, Who Shared Nobel for Advances With Laser Light, Dies at 97
abstract: Dr. Bloembergen, who began his studies in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands, showed how laser light transformed the properties of the material it passed through.
lead_paragraph: Nicolaas Bloembergen, a Dutch-born American physicist who studied quantum mechanics by the light of an oil lamp while hiding from the Nazis in the Netherlands in World War II and later shared a Nobel Prize for his contributions to laser spectroscopy, died on Sept. 5 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 97.

headline: Houston’s Floodwaters Are Tainted, Testing Shows
abstract: Water samples contained unsafe levels of fecal bacteria and other contaminants, both inside and outside homes, The Times found.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Floodwaters in two Houston neighborhoods have been contaminated with bacteria and toxins that can make people sick, testing organized by The New York Times has found. Residents will need to take precautions to return safely to their homes, public health experts said.

headline: At U.S. Open, Women Surprise and New Rules Get a Trial Run
abstract: Despite concern about tennis’s relevance to youth, the tournament did its part, with an unseeded champion and experiments with clocks and coaching.
lead_paragraph: The Open era in tennis — the period when professionals were rightfully permitted to play the marquee events — will have its 50th birthday next year. But the sport, despite all the infighting and concern about its continuing relevance to the young, keeps breaking new ground.

headline: Oscar de la Renta: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: It Distracted Us. It Gave Us Uber. It Made Selfies a Thing.
abstract: The first iPhone was released 10 years ago and swiftly turned the smartphone from a curiosity into our constant companion.
lead_paragraph: The first iPhone was released 10 years ago and swiftly turned the smartphone from a curiosity into our constant companion.

headline: In the Caribbean, Rebuilding Nations — and the Tourism Industry
abstract: As a region assesses the damage wrought by Irma, officials say it could take years for tourism to fully recover.
lead_paragraph: GUSTAVIA, St. Barthélemy — The pace is frantic. Residents with shovels clean the streets. Dump trucks laden with the stumps of storm-ravaged trees rumble back and forth along narrow streets. Construction crews clear downed telephone poles and debris from houses and businesses in a race to restore the lifeblood of this small Caribbean island — tourism.

headline: Senators Seek Answers on Equifax Breach, Including Details on Stock Sales
abstract: The stock sales have added to the consumer backlash over the breach, which may have compromised the sensitive information of 143 million Americans.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee on Monday demanded answers from Equifax about its major data breach, including pressing for more details about three Equifax executives who sold shares after the breach was discovered.

headline: The Rays, Safe and Sound, Play a Home Game on the Road
abstract: Forced by Hurricane Irma to play against the Yankees at the Mets’ park, Tampa Bay’s players tried to cope with their unfamiliar surroundings.
lead_paragraph: The Tampa Bay Rays wore their white pants on Monday. They dressed in a spacious home clubhouse, took batting practice first and took the field before the Yankees. They knew what would come next, though. This was a home game in name only.

headline: Hungry Residents in ‘Survival Mode’ on U.S. Virgin Islands
abstract: A large relief effort has begun in the Virgin Islands, where long lines for food and lack of communication contributed to a sense that residents were being ignored.
lead_paragraph: TUTU, V.I. — With residents ignoring the loosely enforced curfew here and lining up hours before the makeshift pantries opened, it was clear Monday that many were still going to end the day hungry.

headline: McConnell Says Democrats’ Glee on Debt Limit Deal Was Premature
abstract: The Senate majority leader said Democrats “spiked the ball in the end zone a little too early” when they claimed they would have maximum leverage in a December fiscal showdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell thinks Democrats were a tad premature in exuberantly celebrating the surprise spending deal they struck last week with President Trump.

headline: Yankees Fans Enjoy $25 Tickets and an Easy Victory
abstract: Monday’s game between the Yankees and Tampa Bay enabled fans to sit right near the field for prices that might normally leave them in the upper deck.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees were visitors in their hometown Monday night, which is not unusual when they are playing at Citi Field and the team in the other dugout is the Mets.

headline: Damp, Dark and Disarrayed, Florida Starts Coping With Irma’s Aftermath
abstract: Widespread power losses and localized flooding caused by the hurricane threatened to bedevil the state for days, if not weeks, to come.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest on the storm with Tuesday’s live updates on Irma.

headline: Tesla Boosts Car Battery Power During Irma, Raising Questions of Control
abstract: The company remotely enabled free software upgrades for Florida drivers during the hurricane, sparking questions about Tesla’s oversight.
lead_paragraph: Tesla drivers in Florida got an unexpected assist this weekend as they scrambled to evade Hurricane Irma.

headline: Hurricane Price Gouging Is Despicable, Right? Not to Some Economists
abstract: Eliminating price controls can increase the available supply of essential goods, the argument goes, and help prevent a black market.
lead_paragraph: When a devastating hurricane like Irma or Harvey arrives, stories about price gouging inevitably spread quickly. Last week, a one-way coach flight from Miami to Phoenix jumped in price from $547.50 to $3,258.50, prompting immediate outrage. In Houston, a picture of a case of water being sold for $42.96 at Best Buy did the same. (Best Buy apologized and said it was a “big mistake” by a few employees.)

headline: Florida Keys Battered but Still Standing After Irma’s Rampage
abstract: The Florida Keys, which took some of Hurricane Irma’s hardest blows Sunday and Monday, were a random mix of buildings unscathed and others battered or ruined.
lead_paragraph: CUDJOE KEY, Fla. — You pay a price for paradise.

headline: How Business Was Battered by Irma
abstract: Hurricane Irma has weakened to a tropical storm, but left damage to nearly all parts of a tightly connected Florida economy that relies heavily on tourism.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Irma began to wane Monday, moving north as a tropical storm after tearing through the Caribbean and South Florida, leaving homes and businesses in disarray.

headline: Zero + Maria Cornejo: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Vikings Spoil Adrian Peterson’s Return With a Tribute to Randy Moss
abstract: Peterson, now a member of the New Orleans Saints, struggled against his old team while former teammate Stefon Diggs did his best Moss impersonation.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Peterson got the start for the New Orleans Saints in his return to Minnesota, but he found himself an afterthought in a matchup that quickly turned into a game-long tribute to another former Viking: Randy Moss. With Minnesota’s defense stifling the New Orleans attack, and Stefon Diggs doing his best Moss impersonation, the Vikings rolled to a 29-19 victory.

headline: Corrections: September 12, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 12, 2017.
lead_paragraph: THE ARTS

headline: As Mexico Earthquake Aid Mounts, Many Fear It Will Be Diverted
abstract: After several corruption scandals, Mexicans are reluctant to trust officials charged with providing food and reconstruction supplies to the victims.
lead_paragraph: JUCHITÁN DE ZARAGOZA, Mexico — Concepción Rueda Gomes has been collecting food and supplies since Mexico’s strongest earthquake in living memory struck her hometown, Juchitán, last week. But when it came time to distributing the aid she turned to private agencies for help.

headline: Chief Executive of Social Finance, an Online Lending Start-Up, to Step Down
abstract: Mike Cagney, a co-founder of Social Finance, is stepping down as chief executive and chairman after sexual harassment claims at the start-up.
lead_paragraph: Social Finance, an online lender that is one of the more prominent financial technology start-ups, said on Monday that its co-founder and chief executive Mike Cagney planned to step down by the end of the year.

headline: Who Owns a Monkey Selfie? Settlement Should Leave Him Smiling
abstract: Naruto, a monkey in Indonesia, snapped a picture in 2011. Under an settlement, part of the revenue from pictures he took will go to groups that protect him.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Naruto, a curious 6-year-old monkey in Indonesia, peered into a camera lens, grinned and pressed the shutter button on the unattended camera. Little did the endangered crested macaque know that he may have been providing for his future.

headline: World’s Most Populous Democracy
abstract: Bruce Haight has a One-Track Mind
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Bruce Haight offers what could be a master class in Tuesday puzzles. The theme is accessible, meaning you might cotton on to what’s happening after filling in a couple of themers, yet interesting.

headline: Review: A Play With a Crude Name and a Powerfully Dark View
abstract: Suzan-Lori Parks’s Brechtian riff on Nathaniel Hawthorne’s “The Scarlet Letter” returns to the stage with a new vitality.
lead_paragraph: The two women sharing a late-night tipple call things as they see them, and that includes each other.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pummeled Florida Staggers Toward Long Recovery
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 12, 2017
lead_paragraph: “We didn’t dodge a bullet; we dodged a cannon. And we’re very happy about that.”

headline: Carolina Herrera: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: A Drive Through Hurricane Irma’s Destruction in Florida
abstract: The day after Hurricane Irma battered southwest Florida with high winds and flooding, we visited some of the places that were most affected.
lead_paragraph: The day after Hurricane Irma battered southwest Florida with high winds and flooding, we visited some of the places that were most affected.

headline: Mitch McConnell Talks Spending Deal
abstract: The majority leader spoke with Carl Hulse for “The New Washington” podcast.
lead_paragraph: The majority leader spoke with Carl Hulse for “The New Washington” podcast.

headline: Things Apple’s iPhone Helped Destroy
abstract: Since it was introduced 10 years ago, the iPhone has been a great disrupter, heralding an end to everything from paper maps to small talk. Here’s a (slightly) tongue-in-cheek look at all the things this ubiquitous gadget has laid to waste.
lead_paragraph: Since it was introduced 10 years ago, the iPhone has been a great disrupter, heralding an end to everything from paper maps to small talk. Here’s a (slightly) tongue-in-cheek look at all the things this ubiquitous gadget has laid to waste.

headline: The Dealer Who Saved My Life
abstract: I tried to buy some “flake” on the streets of Harlem. Billy told me to get off his block.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when I dream, I imagine the sky over Harlem is a lofty arc of stained glass. A dusted copper heaven streaked with gold and siphoned from Klimt’s aureate imagination. A profanely ornate firmament raining down with the cherubic drug dealers I grew up with in the 1970s. A legion of natty angels, felled by the hubris of fraudulent invincibility. One might envision them as the offspring of Icarus. I call them The Scramblin’ Kids of Harlem.

headline: Sub-Saharan African Migrants Face Old Enemy in Libya: Bigotry
abstract: For many African migrants trying to reach Europe, the way station of Libya can carry special peril if their skin is darker, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — When Kalilu Drammeh arrived in Libya he was in many ways similar to thousands of other migrants from across Africa, all of them desperate to cross the sea to get to Europe and, they hoped, a better life.

headline: Hillary Clinton Opens Up About ‘What Happened,’ With Candor, Defiance and Dark Humor
abstract: Clinton’s account of the 2016 election is part post-mortem, part feminist manifesto and part score-settling jubilee.
