headline: In Haiti, a Building Fights Cholera
abstract: Even in a runaway and deadly epidemic, architecture can become an important element of a cure.
lead_paragraph: Next month marks the seventh anniversary of the cholera outbreak that ravaged Haiti. The disease, which can cause death within hours if left untreated, came less than a year after Haiti was rocked by an enormous earthquake that left hundreds of thousands dead and millions injured, displaced and destitute.

headline: Time to Restrict the President’s Power to Wage Nuclear War
abstract: President Trump and Kim Jong-un are engaged in an increasingly dangerous showdown. New rules are needed to prevent us from stumbling into nuclear war.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in a generation, there is widespread anxiety about the possibility of nuclear war, stimulated by the extreme tensions between North Korea and the United States. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has advised Americans that they can sleep safely at night, a reassurance that most people probably wish they did not need to hear.

headline: What I Saw on the Way to the Revolution
abstract: In 1967, I dropped out of college to be an artist. Six months later, I was a violent radical. What happened?
lead_paragraph: In June 1967, in the freewheeling spirit of the times, I dropped out of Antioch College, in Ohio, and hitchhiked to New York. I was 19, mildly though not madly political. In junior high, I had joined civil rights demonstrations. Now I opposed the Vietnam War. But my ideology was simply the counterculture’s: peace and love, plus anything fun that could undermine convention.

lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Welcome back, Bret. It’s been ages since we conversed and, um, a lot has happened. Tell me your choice for the worst news and the best news of the summer.

headline: Want to Make a Deal, Mr. Trump?
abstract: If President Trump continues to reach across the aisle, what other deals might be possible?
lead_paragraph: Was President Trump’s bipartisan hurricane relief/debt ceiling/government funding deal last week simply a “bipartisan moment,” as the House speaker, Paul Ryan, put it? Probably, given this president’s pattern of poor impulse control and of reverting to base politics. But it’s tempting nevertheless to imagine what Mr. Trump might achieve if he could see beyond momentary, tactical wins. Hints of bipartisan consensus are popping up in Congress around enough significant issues to suggest that a determined, strategically minded president — yes, we know, but bear with us — could strike a number of important deals.

headline: The Ever-Changing Business of ‘Anti-Aging’
abstract: We don’t want to look older. But we don’t want to look as if we fear it either.
lead_paragraph: There is something telling about the moments when we, as a culture, all agree to make a change that feels right and good and true, then go on behaving in approximately the same way that we did before. Consider the September issue of Allure. On the cover, the 72-year-old actress Helen Mirren wears the tattooed arm of a 20-something guy slung around her neck as if it’s the hot new accessory. Allure calls her “the hero we need” as the magazine enlists the beauty industry in its new pet cause: “the end of anti-aging.”

headline: After a Dozen Hurricanes and 40 Years, Familiar Dangers With Higher Stakes

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Every hurricane tells a story.

headline: What Could We Lose if a NASA Climate Mission Goes Dark?
abstract: Researchers are racing to replace the pioneering Grace satellites, which are threatened by both dying batteries and Trump-era budget cuts.
lead_paragraph: In late August, as Hurricane Harvey began smashing into the Texas coast, a flood of data began pouring in along with the catastrophic quantities of rainwater. It wasn’t from the nonstop news coverage on CNN and elsewhere; it was from the transmissions that lay behind it, in the pulses of information coming down from space. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s geostationary and polar-orbiting satellites, crucial tools for monitoring big storms in the Gulf of Mexico, were capturing cloud formations, surface temperatures and barometric pressures, which were then fed into computer models tracking the storm’s strength and intensity. At the same time, NASA was using a group of satellites to keep tabs on soil moisture, flood patterns and power failures all over East Texas. In various ways, this torrent of data was being collected continuously from hundreds (or even thousands) of miles overhead, through radar instruments and spectroradiometer sensors and exquisitely calibrated imaging cameras. The machines being used aren’t household names — they go by acronyms like GOES-13, Modis and SMAP — but they demonstrate why the popular view of Earth as a big blue planet with only the Moon as its companion could do with some revising. We are also surrounded by a constellation of satellites spinning elliptical webs of environmental observation, day and night.

headline: A Family Travel Playbook: Make Plans, Prepare to Let Them Go

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For six months, Sue and Roger Powell have been hoping to find a buyer for their 7,100-square-foot home in the Houston suburb of Katy. A week ago, after they waded out of it with a few suitcases on air mattresses, those hopes had largely faded. Then they got an unexpected call from their real estate agent: a house hunter was interested.

headline: In Berlin, an Iconic Theater Gets a New Leader. Cue the Protests.
abstract: After two years of sniping (and worse) from critics, Chris Dercon has finally taken the helm of Berlin’s Volksbühne theater.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Berlin’s hulking, disused Tempelhof Airport has a long, winding history. Built by the Nazis, it was the site of the Berlin airlift and, more recently, of emergency housing for some of the hundreds of thousands of refugees who arrived in Germany in recent years. On Sunday afternoon, Berliners crowded on the tarmac outside the former terminal for a more festive occasion: a 10-hour dance event called “Fous de Danse” organized by the city’s Volksbühne theater.

This was the situation faced by Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in the summer of 2009, when Bausch succumbed to cancer, just days after her diagnosis.

headline: Wim Wenders’s ‘Pina’: Without Her but for Her
abstract: Mr. Wenders’s documentary “Pina” did something important: It helped helped to make modern dance more palatable to general audiences.
lead_paragraph: What had started out as a collaboration between the German film director Wim Wenders and the choreographer Pina Bausch became impossible when she died in 2009, just days after receiving a diagnosis of cancer. Mr. Wenders went ahead with his film, showcasing Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch, without her but for her.

headline: A Guide to Reykjavik, as Wonderfully Weird as Ever
abstract: Almost a decade after the Icelandic city was forced to reinvent itself, it’s now a health-and-wellness destination.
lead_paragraph: As a point of divergence between the North American and Eurasian tectonic plates, Iceland is home to more strange beauty than most places: snow-covered peaks, black-sand beaches, skyscraping geysers and underground caves glittering with kaleidoscopic stalactites. But the country’s drama isn’t contained to its landscapes. After the 2008 banking collapse, the government imposed a steep exit tax to keep investors from moving their funds abroad. Forced to turn inward, Icelanders instead backed domestic projects like boutique hotels, locavore eateries and designer stores. In so doing, they infused Reykjavik — a compact city of just over 122,000 — with a truly global feel.

headline: Are Artists the New Interpreters of Scientific Innovation?
abstract: Increasingly, they don’t simply reflect modern technology. They play a key role in it.
lead_paragraph: WHEN WE THINK OF ARTIST residencies today, we think of the MacDowell Colony, in the woods of New Hampshire, and of the Skowhegan School, in Maine. There’s the Rome Prize fellowship, at the city’s American Academy, and Donald Judd’s Chinati Foundation, in Marfa. To be an ­artist in residence means removing yourself from the noise and obligations of regular life, and instead getting to concentrate on your creative life, often in a beautiful locale.

headline: A Long-Tolerant Spa Town Feels the Chill of Slovak Populism

headline: J. J. Abrams Takes Over as Director of ‘Star Wars: Episode IX’

lead_paragraph: The disturbance in the Force that occurred when Colin Trevorrow was pushed out as the director of “Star Wars: Episode IX” has already been calmed. Lucasfilm, the studio behind this lucrative and long-running science-fiction franchise, said on Tuesday that J.J. Abrams would return to be the director and a writer on the ninth installment in the central “Star Wars” saga.

headline: Nina Garcia Will Run Elle
abstract: The “Project Runway” judge takes her following to the helm of the Hearst magazine.
lead_paragraph: Nina Garcia will be the next editor of Elle magazine, Hearst announced Tuesday morning.

headline: Charles Oakley Files Lawsuit Against James Dolan and Madison Square Garden
abstract: The suit stems from an incident last Feb. 8 in which Oakley was arrested by security guards during a game at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: Charles Oakley’s battle with his former team resumed on Tuesday when he filed a lawsuit in federal court against the New York Knicks’ owner, James L. Dolan, the Madison Square Garden Company and two other companies that Dolan owns.

headline: Drew Nieporent May Be the Last Old-School Restaurateur Standing
abstract: At a time when chefs get all the attention, the owner of Nobu and Bâtard is still the effusive greeter and public face of his restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Even as a kid, he didn’t eat like one. For sure, at 5 or 6 he’d kick his older brother, Tracy, under the table whenever his parents took the family to restaurants, but mostly he was paying attention, learning about the food of a time in Manhattan when the top restaurants served German, Swiss or other cuisines that are infrequently celebrated these days.

headline: Low Turnout Expected as Mayor de Blasio Faces Voters in Primary
abstract: With the mayor likely to win, turnout in Tuesday’s election will be the big question, as will his margin of victory over his chief rival, Sal F. Albanese.
lead_paragraph: With expectations of an easy win for Mayor Bill de Blasio and of a low turnout, voters in New York City headed to the polls on Tuesday to make their actual preferences known in Democratic primary races that mostly serve, in this heavily Democratic city, as the decisive contest.

headline: See Beautiful Vietnam!
abstract: In 1967, South Vietnam was at war — but it was also busy promoting itself as a tourist destination.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen sixty-seven may have been a brutal year in Vietnam — tens of thousands of Vietnamese and more than 11,000 Americans lost their lives in what increasingly looked like an endless war — but it was also, the United Nations decreed more hopefully, International Tourist Year.

headline: He’s 28, a Prince and Representing a Kingdom: Meet Washington’s Newest Ambassador
abstract: Prince Khalid bin Salman will rely on his royal status to promote Saudi Arabia’s interests in Washington, but his track record is unproven.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On Prince Khalid bin Salman’s first official American trip as the Saudi ambassador to the United States, he visited Saudi military officers at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada, met with Saudi engineers in Silicon Valley and connected with Lockheed Martin executives in Texas.

headline: Frieden’s Next Act: Heart Disease and Preparing for New Epidemics
abstract: The man who headed the C.D.C. under Obama will tackle new global health challenges, with $225 million from Gates, Bloomberg and Chan Zuckerberg
lead_paragraph: After running the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for eight years under President Obama, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden is starting a global health initiative that will focus on two big areas: heart health and epidemic preparedness.

headline: The Times Review of the First iPhone: ‘Amazing’ but ‘Not Perfect’
abstract: Ten years ago, a steady drumbeat of excitement over the iPhone turned into a frenzy. Soon it was being referred to as the “Jesus phone.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to recall, but there was a time when the iPhone wasn’t ubiquitous.

headline: Tudor City Steakhouse Opens in Manhattan, and More Dining News
abstract: Jacob’s Pickles reopens, Cuban-Chinese lands in Chelsea, and Uzbek food finds a home in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: TUDOR CITY STEAKHOUSE In the elegant space overlooking the East River that was L’Impero and then Convivio, but has stood empty since 2011, Sylvan Hospitality, a new restaurant group, has installed a steakhouse. It’s a spacious, multilevel restaurant in the genre’s requisite wood paneling, though here it’s enlivened by metal accents. The menu is packed with the typical shellfish appetizers, salads, burgers, steaks, chops and grilled seafood, but with the addition of sushi rolls, pastas and risotto. It ventures into South America with assorted ceviches, a yellow-corn Venezuelan tamale, and chimichurri sauce over Cuban black beans and rice. Three chefs, but maybe not too many considering the breadth of the offerings, will be at work here: Joaquin Linares, the specialist for dry-aged meat; Adrian Leon, whose expertise is South American fare; and Bruni Bueno, in charge of desserts, notably cheesecake. (Opens Thursday): 45 Tudor City Place (43rd Street), 212-682-4000, tudorcitysteakhouse.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Dayveon,’ Wading Into Gang Life in Arkansas
abstract: A debut feature that blends fiction and documentary elements is more vague than effective.
lead_paragraph: “Dayveon,” the debut feature of Amman Abbasi, ticks several boxes on the checklist of independent film affectations: the casting of nonprofessionals, the blending of fiction and documentary elements, a glancing editing style that is either lyrical or vague depending on your point of view. The movie bears a superficial resemblance visually and in its coming-of-age narrative to “George Washington” (directed by David Gordon Green, an executive producer here) and “Moonlight,” but it never finds the right balance between the suggestive and the concrete.

headline: Sylvia Fowles, W.N.B.A. Star and Aspiring Funeral Director
abstract: The defensive ace and possible M.V.P. from the Minnesota Lynx is studying mortuary science.
lead_paragraph: When Sylvia Fowles broke her nose in May, she did not flinch.

headline: Condola Rashad’s Next Role to Tackle: Joan of Arc
abstract: The Tony-nominated Ms. Rashad will star in “Saint Joan,” George Bernard Shaw’s classic play.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off a Tony-nominated performance in “A Doll’s House, Part 2,” Condola Rashad will take on the title character of George Bernard Shaw’s classic play “Saint Joan” in a new Broadway production.

headline: The Last Lost Flower Children of Anna Sui
abstract: It’s never the summer of love anymore.
lead_paragraph: “I found a flower child!” Anna Sui said backstage at Skylight Clarkson studio before her hippie-themed spring 2018 show. The invitations had instructed guests to bring flowers, chimes, feathers, incense and joy. Leading a young blond child by the hand, Ms. Sui looked ready for a Be-In.

headline: Review: We the (Library-Card Carrying) People of ‘Ex Libris’
abstract: In his magnificent documentary, “Ex Libris: The New York Public Library,” Frederick Wiseman takes his camera into the halls where people read, learn and seek a perfect union.
lead_paragraph: The main branch of the New York Public Library — the Beaux-Arts landmark at Fifth Avenue and 42 Street with the stone lions — opened its doors to a ravenous population on May 24, 1911. More than 50,000 souls are said to have flowed through its marble grandeur, inaugurating what has been an intimate, mutually sustaining union between the public and its library. In his magnificent new documentary “Ex Libris: The New York Public Library,” Frederick Wiseman takes his camera into those same halls as well as into more humble city branches. He sweeps into atriums and down corridors, pauses in reading and meeting rooms, and lays bare this complex, glorious organism that is the democratic ideal incarnate.

headline: New Book Will Investigate Trump-Russia Connection
abstract: The investigative journalists Michael Isikoff and David Corn will publish their new book, tentatively titled “The Russian Connection,” in March.
lead_paragraph: Conspiracies surrounding Russian meddling in American politics used to be the terrain of novelists. Now nonfiction writers get to dig in. Hillary Clinton’s “What Happened,” her account of the 2016 presidential election, went on sale Tuesday, and another book about the election, an investigative look by two journalists into the controversies surrounding Donald J. Trump, Vladimir Putin and Russia’s influence, isn’t far behind.

headline: ‘What Happened’? They Lost. With Her Memoir, Hillary Clinton Joins a Haunted Club
abstract: Jon Meacham on how Clinton’s chronicle of loss in 2016 compares with those of defeated candidates past.
lead_paragraph: She had packed for victory. There had been a white suit for election night at the Javits Center beneath a glass ceiling; white was the color of the suffragists who, a century earlier, had at last won the franchise for women. But now, in the morning hours after Donald J. Trump’s White House upset, Hillary Clinton donned gray and purple for her concession to the country. The sartorial detail, which Clinton shares in her new memoir of the 2016 campaign, is a touch worthy of Plutarch, who observed that “a small thing … often makes a greater revelation of a character than battles where thousands die.” For there had been a different plan. The gray and purple, she writes, was the “one I had intended to wear on my first trip to Washington as President Elect.”

headline: After More Than 20 Years, Newark to Regain Control of Its Schools
abstract: The State of New Jersey took over running the district because of low performance, but real educational progress has been slow in coming.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — In 1995, when Marques-Aquil Lewis was in elementary school, the State of New Jersey seized control of the public schools here after a judge warned that “nepotism, cronyism and the like” had precipitated “abysmal” student performances and “failure on a very large scale.”

headline: Grooming for the Groom
abstract: Some products to help men through those likely bouts of sleepless nights and hangovers.
lead_paragraph: Today’s grooms are just as concerned about how they look on their wedding day and in photos. Here are some products to help them through those likely bouts of sleepless nights and hangovers.

headline: Mexico, Hit by Its Own Disasters, Can’t Help Texas After All
abstract: After Hurricane Harvey left part of Texas under water, Mexico offered to help its neighbor. That was before an earthquake and Hurricane Katia.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Sorry, we have too many troubles of our own.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Makeup Guide for Brides
abstract: Being camera-ready in today’s click-and-post era is easier than ever as more brands incorporate technological advancements into products.
lead_paragraph: Being makeup-ready in today’s click-and-post era is easier than ever for many brides as more cosmetic brands incorporate technological advancements and HD-ready, finely infused ingredients into their products.

headline: Razza
abstract: At Razza in Jersey City, local buffalo milk and hazelnuts go into pies that can stand up to the best of the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: At Razza in Jersey City, local buffalo milk and hazelnuts go into pies that can stand up to the best of the five boroughs.

headline: Is New York’s Best Pizza in New Jersey?
abstract: At Razza in Jersey City, local buffalo milk and hazelnuts go into pies that can stand up to the best of the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — We were on our third pie of the night at Razza, across the street from City Hall here, when Ed Levine stopped chewing long enough to ask me a question:

headline: M.L.B. Opening Day 2018: Every Team Will Start on March 29
abstract: It’s the earliest start ever for domestic games, and the first time since 1968 that all the teams will start on the same day.
lead_paragraph: All 30 teams will begin play on the same day in 2018, Major League Baseball announced on Tuesday. It is the first time that has happened since 1968.

headline: John Oliver Extends HBO Contract Through 2020
abstract: A new three-year contract means Mr. Oliver’s weekly show “Last Week Tonight” will be on HBO through at least the next presidential election.
lead_paragraph: John Oliver will be on HBO through the next presidential election.

headline: Dispatches From the Nomad Musician Alex Zhang Hungtai
abstract: You may know him as Dirty Beaches. Or Last Lizard. Or the guy from “Twin Peaks.”
lead_paragraph: Alex Zhang Hungtai is a man of many names. As Dirty Beaches, he released several critically acclaimed indie rock albums, mixing what Pitchfork called “grimy, dissonant love songs” with a 1950s greaser look that made fashion editors take notice.

headline: In ‘Liner Notes,’ Loudon Wainwright Looks Squarely at His Flaws and His Musical Family Tree
abstract: The folk singer — ex-husband of Kate McGarrigle and father of Rufus Wainwright, among his other connections — does not go easy on himself in this memoir.
lead_paragraph: Pity the folk singer raised in the Northeast. As John Gorka put it in “I’m From New Jersey,” a nearly perfect song, “It’s not like Texas / There’s no mystery / I can’t pretend.”

headline: Kaia Gerber, Jordan Barrett, Shayne Oliver and Olivier Zahm Partied at Fashion Week
abstract: Paper magazine celebrated its “Beautiful People” issue, and Purple Magazine turned 25 at the Standard hotel.
lead_paragraph: Paper magazine celebrated its “Beautiful People” issue, and Purple Magazine turned 25 at the Standard hotel.

headline: Medical Marijuana for Vets
abstract: The group Marijuana Majority writes that V.A. doctors should be allowed to recommend the drug to veterans who need it.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Will Corporate Tax Cuts Help America’s Workers?
abstract: Readers offer opposing views.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Future
abstract: A reader suggests that Mrs. Clinton should do as she likes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Explore 7 N.F.L. Cities Beyond Football
abstract: Not everyone loves football, but there’s plenty to like about the N.F.L. cities hosting games this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Whether you are a football lover or not, there’s plenty to like about each one of the N.F.L.’s 32 host cities, and fans will be flocking to several of them this weekend for Week 2 of the 2017 season. If you’re one of them, but looking for more to do than just the game — or if you’re just curious to learn more about some of these great American cities — here are seven to explore.

headline: Why Getting the Power Back On in Florida Could Take Weeks
abstract: Irma has left up to 15 million people in Florida without electricity. Restoring service could be the most complex operation of its kind in United States history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Hurricane Irma rampaged through Florida, snapping power lines and damaging vital equipment, it left as many as 15 million people in the state without electricity, the Department of Homeland Security said on Tuesday. While some homes may see power restored within days, utilities said that other customers may have to wait weeks.

headline: Where Horror Gets the Red Carpet Treatment
abstract: The Midnight Madness section of the Toronto International Film Festival is now considered a premier showcase for genre films. It wasn’t always so respectable.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Each night around 11 p.m. at the Toronto International Film Festival, after the Oscar-bait wannabes and acclaimed documentaries have called it a day, 1,200 filmgoers line up outside the Ryerson Theater for the likes of “Yakuza Apocalypse” and “No One Lives.”

headline: Top White House Official to Discuss Climate Change at U.N.
abstract: Gary D. Cohn, the White House economic adviser, has invited climate and energy ministers to a breakfast in New York as part of the annual United Nations meeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gary D. Cohn, the chief White House economic adviser, is convening senior climate and energy ministers from about a dozen nations in advance of next week’s United Nations General Assembly meeting, the White House confirmed Tuesday.

headline: World Anti-Doping Agency Clears 95 Russian Athletes
abstract: The rulings will probably spur debate over the way sports officials handle athletes who were implicated in the investigations into Russia’s doping program.
lead_paragraph: Global antidoping authorities have begun assessing the cases of individual athletes implicated in Russia’s yearslong doping program that was exposed last year, and their early decisions are expected to fuel the debate over Russian athletes’ eligibility.

headline: The Food Court Matures Into the Food Hall
abstract: Food halls — typically a mix of local artisan restaurants, butcher shops and other food-oriented boutiques — are becoming popular as consumers demand more options.
lead_paragraph: Determined to provide experiences that will attract consumers and persuade them to open their wallets, developers are opening more food halls, the food court’s up-and-coming sibling, which are in the midst of a robust expansion.

headline: Mourning the 9/11 Victims
abstract: The diversity of the names of those who perished reminds a reader that the country today is far less welcoming to those from afar.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Irma-Proof Armor and Nights at the Museum: Shielding Florida’s Arts
abstract: Many Florida cultural organizations are relieved that, thanks to careful preparation and good luck, Hurricane Irma was not as bad as they had feared.
lead_paragraph: Even before Hurricane Irma became a blip on a forecaster’s radar, the Faena Hotel Miami Beach wanted to make sure that its $15 million, glass-enclosed, outdoor Damien Hirst sculpture, “Gone But Not Forgotten,” became neither. So it tapped a company called Armor Screen to design an extra layer of protection against wind and debris.

headline: Australian Catholic Church Falls Short on Safeguards for Children, Study Finds
abstract: A report on sexual abuse in the global church found that Australia’s has done less than its counterparts in similar countries to protect children in its care.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A study that examines child sexual abuse worldwide in the Roman Catholic Church has found that the Australian church has done less to safeguard children in its care than its counterparts in similar countries have.

headline: Gabriela Hearst: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Linda Fairstein Looks Crime in the Face and Smiles
abstract: The former prosecutor turned novelist lines her walls with memorabilia from her career and marriages, and shares her bathroom with unsavory characters.
lead_paragraph: Each morning Linda Fairstein, the former sex-crimes prosecutor turned crime novelist, glances at the mug shots of early 20th-century Westchester County criminals lurking in her bathroom and grins.

headline: A ‘Frightening’ Myth About Sex Offenders
abstract: Our harsh treatment of sex offenders is based on flawed social science.
lead_paragraph: Our harsh treatment of sex offenders is based on flawed social science.

headline: Bell Pottinger, British P.R. Firm for Questionable Clients, Collapses
abstract: The firm’s financial failure was hastened by a race-baiting campaign it undertook in South Africa that spiraled into a disaster.
lead_paragraph: When the South African track star Oscar Pistorius stood trial for the brutal killing of his girlfriend, he hired Bell Pottinger, an aggressive British public relations firm, to try to smooth his tattered reputation. President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his wife turned to the firm for help in recasting their image. So did Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the dictator of Belarus.

headline: Christopher Columbus Statue in Central Park Is Vandalized
abstract: An 1892 bronze statue of Columbus was found covered with graffiti, its hands painted red.
lead_paragraph: A more than century-old statue of Christopher Columbus inside Central Park was discovered defaced on Tuesday morning, its hands stained with red paint and its pedestal scrawled with graffiti including the hashtag “#somethingscoming.”

headline: Jeremiah Goodman, Portraitist of Gilded Homes, Dies at 94
abstract: In paintings, he captured bold interiors by the best designers at the homes of luminaries like Greta Garbo, Ronald and Nancy Reagan, and Wallis Simpson, the duchess of Windsor.
lead_paragraph: Jeremiah Goodman was a house painter to the stars. Not the guy who smeared two coats on the siding and shutters, but the preferred illustrator commissioned to paint shimmering portraits of glamorous interiors for design magazines and advertisements and as keepsakes for the homeowners themselves.

headline: Fox News May Add Laura Ingraham and Move Up Sean Hannity
abstract: The network is in discussions with Ms. Ingraham, a right-wing commentator, and could move Mr. Hannity into direct competition with Rachel Maddow of MSNBC.
lead_paragraph: Fox News’s influential prime-time lineup — a three-hour stretch of conservative commentary with a loyal viewer in the Oval Office — is poised to change again.

headline: Edith Windsor, Whose Same-Sex Marriage Fight Led to Landmark Ruling, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Windsor’s case struck down the Defense of Marriage Act in 2013 and granted same-sex married couples federal recognition for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Edith Windsor, the gay-rights activist whose landmark case led the Supreme Court to grant same-sex married couples federal recognition for the first time and rights to a host of federal benefits that until then only married heterosexuals had enjoyed, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: A Political Conservative Goes to Berkeley
abstract: The Bay Area braces itself for a “fascist” named Ben Shapiro.
lead_paragraph: Ben Shapiro is a 33-year-old who supports small government, religious liberty and free-market economics and opposes identity politics, abortion and Donald Trump. He is, in other words, that wildly exotic creature: a political conservative.

headline: Baja East: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Cleveland Indians (20 Wins and Counting) Are Streaking Toward October
abstract: They came close in 2016, nearly winning the World Series. A year later, the Indians have put together a winning streak that could break a record.
lead_paragraph: The way it all happened last fall — storming through the American League playoffs, grabbing a three-games-to-one lead in the World Series — made the aftermath easier for the Cleveland Indians to process. Yes, they lost the last three games of the World Series to the Chicago Cubs. But the Indians have not dwelled on the outcome, because they remember the journey.

headline: Ferguson Drops Charges Against Man Cited in Justice Dept. Report
abstract: After five years, the city reversed course in its case against Fred Watson, a black man charged while sitting in his parked car. Here’s why it matters.
lead_paragraph: After five years of pursuing a host of minor charges against Fred Watson, whose case was held up as an example of systematically hostile treatment of black residents in Ferguson, Mo., the city abruptly dropped its prosecution this week without explanation.

headline: J.Mendel: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Judith Light: The First Time I Quit a Big Job
abstract: Ms. Light was terrified to leave the soap opera “One Life to Live,” her first television series. But making the leap transformed her career.
lead_paragraph: The first and only time I ever quit a job was in 1982, when I decided to leave “One Life to Live,” the soap opera that I had worked on for five years.

headline: Apple, North Korea, Florida: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Taking Hormones for Menopause Doesn’t Raise Early Death Risk
abstract: Two large clinical trials found no difference in premature death rates for women who took hormones during menopause compared with women who didn’t.
lead_paragraph: The largest and longest clinical trials to date of menopausal hormone therapy have found that the drugs do not increase the risk of premature death.

headline: Rower Jack Carlson Updates the Zany Sport Blazers
abstract: A former member of the United States rowing team, Mr. Carlson reinvents the preppy sport coats worn by elite rowing clubs.
lead_paragraph: Name: Jack Carlson

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Abby Goodnough and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: The Fringe Binge
abstract: Loose threads are lending the runways an air of playfulness and slightly ill repute.
lead_paragraph: There’s something festive and faintly subversive about fringe. Fashion’s little trollop shimmies and sways; she rivets the eye. So you can’t fault designers for lavishing this attention-seeking accent on dresses, trousers and a saddlebag or two.

headline: Behind the Scenes with Carolina Herrera
abstract: T visits the designer in her garment district studio — and then backstage on the evening of her spring/summer 2018 show.
lead_paragraph: T visits the designer in her garment district studio — and then backstage on the evening of her spring/summer 2018 show.

headline: 48 Hours With Carolina Herrera Before Her Show
abstract: The designer presented her spring/summer 2018 collection on Monday night at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: It is Friday afternoon inside the sunlit, plush showroom of Carolina Herrera’s headquarters, a space she’s occupied in New York’s garment district for over two decades. A sweep of colorful gowns in taffeta and sequined tulle hangs in a back room, and an assortment of belts and pumps in pastels are spread out nearby. A cluster of models linger outside, waiting to be fitted in the looks they’ll wear down the runway this season. The space, however, is devoid of any of the palpable stress that might hang in the air just a few days before a show.

headline: Off the Runway: Badgley Mischka, Baja East and More
abstract: Our photographer caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Our photographer caught the action during New York Fashion Week on Tuesday.

headline: Lawmakers Want Limits on Wiretaps Despite Trump Administration Objections
abstract: House Judiciary leaders want to temporarily extend and curb an expiring surveillance law, but national security officials want it made permanent without changes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan bloc of House Judiciary Committee leaders have agreed to demand new limits on the National Security Agency’s warrantless surveillance program as a condition of temporarily extending its authorization, setting up a fight with the Trump administration.

headline: Coach: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: When Junk Science About Sex Offenders Infects the Supreme Court
abstract: An invented statistic from a magazine has informed jurisprudence about sex offenders for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: This month the Supreme Court will have a rare opportunity to correct a flawed doctrine that for the past two decades has relied on junk social science to justify punishing more than 800,000 Americans. Two cases that the court could review concern people on the sex offender registry and the kinds of government control that can constitutionally be imposed upon them.

headline: Steve Madden Gets Serious About Shoes for Men
abstract: Known for his women’s footwear, the fashion entrepreneur devotes nearly a third of his new Times Square flagship store to men’s offerings.
lead_paragraph: The name Steve Madden is practically synonymous with high-heel shoes and thigh-high boots. He has more than 250 namesake stores all over the world, and his shoes for women are carried in major department stores.

headline: World Anti-Doping Agency Report on Russian Doping
abstract: In an internal report obtained by The New York Times, the antidoping regulator agreed to close 95 of the 96 investigations into Russian athletes that have been resolved so far.
lead_paragraph: In an internal report obtained by The New York Times, the antidoping regulator agreed to close 95 of the 96 investigations into Russian athletes that have been resolved so far.

headline: Seattle Mayor Ed Murray Resigns After Another Abuse Accusation
abstract: Months after he said he would not seek a second term, Mr. Murray resigned after five men accused him of sexual abusing them decades ago, when they were underage.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Seattle, Ed Murray, said on Tuesday that he would resign after announcing in May that he would not seek a second term. Several men have come  forward to accuse Mr. Murray of sexually abusing them decades ago, when they were underage.

headline: White House Says Justice Department Should Look at Charging Comey
abstract: The White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said that the president was proved right in firing the F.B.I. director in May.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said on Tuesday that the Justice Department should “certainly look at” charging James B. Comey, the F.B.I. director whom President Trump fired, for what she described as leaks of classified information.

headline: Hurricane Irma, North Korea, Apple: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: You Won’t Find This Runway on the Fashion Week Calendar
abstract: On the first official night of New York Fashion Week, a show put on by homeless youth demonstrated the power of design.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the first official night of New York Fashion Week, while the industry and its disciples kiss-kissed at Calvin Klein and Kim Shui, nine very young, very new designers walked their creations in the fifth annual Project Streetwork Fashion Show.

headline: Naeem Khan: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Unzipping After a Big Night Out
abstract: Help isn’t far away when a woman is ready to get out of her gown.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: After Toiling in Rural China, Protégé of Xi Jinping Joins Party’s Top Tiers
abstract: A potential successor to President Xi ran one of China’s poorest provinces, giving him the gritty experience expected of an aspiring national leader.
lead_paragraph: LIUPANSHUI, China — Guizhou is one of China’s poorest provinces, yet its villages of rice paddies, buffalos and mud-brick homes have long been a proving ground for rising stars in the Chinese Communist Party. The former president, Hu Jintao, once ran this mountainous southwestern province, as did a powerful lieutenant to President Xi Jinping.

headline: Eric Luke Trump, the President’s Newest Grandchild, Is Born to Lara and Eric Trump
abstract: President Trump shared a rare bit of personal news on Twitter: The first grandchild of his presidency, a boy, was born on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In between sharing updates about Hurricane Irma and admonishing journalists, President Trump tweeted a rare bit of personal news on Tuesday: The first grandchild born during his presidency, a boy, was delivered that morning.

headline: At the Apple Keynote, Selling Us a Better Vision of Ourselves
abstract: Apple’s annual program is an odd streaming TV event: an extended commercial that the faithful watch willingly.
lead_paragraph: Talking about the new iPhone’s augmented-reality features at Apple’s announcement event Tuesday, Philip W. Schiller, the senior vice president for worldwide marketing, showed how an app could overlay an image of the constellations on a live camera picture of the sky. This got him excited. “This isn’t some generic sky!” he said. “This is the sky around you!”

headline: Philadelphia Amtrak Derailment Was ‘Likely an Accident,’ Judge Finds
abstract: A Pennsylvania judge dismissed criminal charges in the 2015 derailment, which killed eight people and injured roughly 200 more.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday dismissed involuntary manslaughter charges against an Amtrak engineer who was driving a train that derailed in Philadelphia in 2015, killing eight people. The judge said the episode appeared to be an accident and not the result of criminal negligence.

headline: 5 Shows That Sealed Peter Hall’s Stage Legacy
abstract: Recalling the original critical response to pathbreaking productions directed by the founder of the Royal Shakespeare Company.
lead_paragraph: The British director Peter Hall, who died on Monday, had an exceptionally long and eventful life in the theater, spanning more than six decades, more than a hundred productions and too many laurels to count. He oversaw two mighty institutional strongholds — the Royal Shakespeare Company (which he founded) and the Royal National Theater – and introduced works that would redefine the very nature of the drama.

headline: Canadian Judge Who Wore Trump Hat in Court Will Remain on the Bench
abstract: The judge, who wore a “Make America Great Again” cap into court the day after the presidential election, will be suspended without pay for 30 days.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A Canadian judge who wore a “Make America Great Again” cap into court the morning after Donald J. Trump’s election victory last year was suspended without pay and reprimanded by a disciplinary body on Tuesday.

headline: Vaquera: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: In Testimony, Women Describe Robert Menendez’s Role in Getting Visas
abstract: One of the women said Dr. Salomon Melgen, a wealthy friend of Mr. Menedez, told her he would contact the senator after her initial visa application was denied.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Rosiell Polanco received a surprise call in 2008 from the United States consulate in the Dominican Republic, roughly a week after her visa had been initially rejected, summoning her for a second interview, she testified in a federal courtroom here on Tuesday.

headline: Steely and Stylish, P.S.G. Opens Champions League With a Rout
abstract: By beating Celtic, 5-0, Paris St.-Germain started to validate its ownership’s billion-dollar investment.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Paolo Maldini said that every player, if at all possible, should try to taste the atmosphere at Celtic Park at least once.

headline: Action to Protect Young Immigrants Already Stumbles in Congress
abstract: President Trump gave Congress six months to pass legislation protecting young immigrants brought here as children. If anything, the effort is moving backward.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week after concerned Republicans promised quick work to shield young, undocumented immigrants from President Trump’s decision to end their federal protections, lawmakers have tied themselves in knots trying to figure out how to proceed — with only six months to find a way forward.

headline: Americans in a Battered Paradise
abstract: In the U.S. Virgin Islands, we are citizens, too — not vacationers trapped on a beach.
lead_paragraph: I lived through two hurricanes as a child and I remember all the good stuff that eventually came in the mail — M&Ms, bug spray, playing cards. So when I heard that Hurricane Irma had made landfall on American soil last Wednesday, I began gathering those kinds of things to mail to my friends and family. I put the packages together and watched the news. There was nothing in what I saw about the hurricane hitting the United States.

headline: Justices Allow Refugee Ban While Case Proceeds
abstract: A month before the Supreme Court is to hear arguments in the travel ban case, it temporarily allowed the administration to bar many refugees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday temporarily allowed the Trump administration to stop some 24,000 refugees from entering the United States while the court considers broad challenges to the administration’s revised travel ban.

headline: The Oakland A’s Are Trying to Solve Their Stadium Problem. Still.
abstract: Dave Kaval, the team’s new president, aims to accomplish what executives for decades have failed to do: Move out of the dilapidated Coliseum.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — After decades of trying to move out of the dilapidated Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum, the Athletics say they will soon announce a site, plans and a timeline for a new privately financed ballpark in Oakland. Leading the charge will be Dave Kaval, who was hired last November as team president, largely to guide the stadium effort.

headline: The Battered Southeast Grapples With Irma’s Aftermath
abstract: With streets still flooded, power still out, thousands of houses wrecked and 94,000 people still in shelters in Florida, “we’ve got a lot of work to do,” said Gov. Rick Scott.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Stressed and exhausted families across the Southeast were assessing the damage from Hurricane Irma on Tuesday, even as flooding from the storm continued to plague some areas, like Jacksonville, and the worst of its wallop was being revealed in others, like the Florida Keys.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Far From Myanmar’s Strife, Pakistan’s Rohingya Suffer
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 13, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “They won’t let me be a citizen, because then they have to give me rights and they won’t call me a refugee because then they have to give me aid.”

headline: Baltimore Officers Will Face No Federal Charges in Death of Freddie Gray
abstract: The Justice Department has closed its investigation into possible civil rights violations by six police officers in the 2015 death of Mr. Gray.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six Baltimore police officers will face no federal charges in the death of Freddie Gray, the 25-year-old black man who died of a severe spinal cord injury while in custody, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.

headline: It’s the Right Time to Talk About Climate Change
abstract: Readers call for a repudiation of the Trump administration’s “willful disregard” of climate change and other “inconvenient truths.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Man Sentenced to 25 Years for Hate-Crime Killing in Union Square
abstract: Lashawn Marten, 40, was convicted in July of punching three random people in Union Square because he was angry at whites. One of the victims later died.
lead_paragraph: A black man who said he was angry at whites and started punching people in Union Square, killing one of them, was sentenced on Tuesday to 25 years in prison.

headline: Amid Chaos of Storms, U.S. Shows It Has Improved Its Response
abstract: Technology, building codes, weather forecasts and a more sophisticated understanding of mass evacuation helped keep the death toll low, experts say.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The two massive storms brought death and suffering and damage that will be measured in the billions of dollars. They left millions of residents cowering in their homes to ride out pounding rains, and left evacuees — hundreds of thousands of them — scattered across Texas and the Southeast.

headline: Purged Facebook Page Tied to the Kremlin Spread Anti-Immigrant Bile
abstract: The page, posing as an activist group, was one of hundreds of fake accounts Russia used in an information campaign during the election, a revelation that has put Facebook on the defensive.
lead_paragraph: The notice went out on Facebook last year, calling citizens of Twin Falls, Idaho, to an urgent meeting about the “huge upsurge of violence toward American citizens” by Muslim refugees who had settled there.

headline: ‘It Was a Frat House’: Inside the Sex Scandal That Toppled SoFi’s C.E.O.
abstract: Mike Cagney is stepping down as chief executive of the lending start-up Social Finance amid questions about sexual harassment at the company. Inside the events that preceded the move.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, the text messages came. Some were flirtatious, asking her to meet him late at night. Sometimes, the texts were sexually explicit.

headline: Where to Stream 11 Essential Ken Burns Documentaries
abstract: The work of America’s premier documentarian offers a panoramic view of American life and history. Here’s what’s available online, from one-hour one-offs, to 14-hour epics.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: N.S.A. Declassifies Documents From 2011 Surveillance Case
abstract: The National Security Agency has declassified documents providing new details about a 2011 case before the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, involving problems with "upstream" internet surveillance under the FISA Amendments Act.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency has declassified documents providing new details about a 2011 case before the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, involving problems with "upstream" internet surveillance under the FISA Amendments Act.

headline: For Florida Keys Residents, Home Was the Ultimate Getaway. Then Irma Hit.
abstract: People who settle in the Keys often are escaping mainland life or resetting their own, and now some wonder if they should try a fresh start somewhere else.
lead_paragraph: BIG PINE KEY, Fla. — The rescuers from Los Angeles came prepared for anything: mud, bodies, snakes, alligators and wild-eyed survivors who had ridden out Hurricane Irma on this frail parenthetical of sand and palms at the southernmost cusp of America.

headline: White House Weighs Lowering Refugee Quota to Below 50,000
abstract: The issue has ignited intense debate within the administration, with officials at the National Security Council, the State Department and the Department of Defense opposing a precipitous drop.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering reducing the number of refugees admitted to the country over the next year to below 50,000, according to current and former government officials familiar with the discussions, the lowest number since at least 1980.

headline: Israel’s Military Exemption for Ultra-Orthodox Is Ruled Unconstitutional
abstract: The efforts in recent years to broaden the obligation of military service have underscored the country’s deep social divisions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday struck down the current government arrangement allowing for mass exemptions for ultra-Orthodox Jews from compulsory military service, calling it discriminatory and unconstitutional. The ruling redraws the battle lines over an issue that has long roiled Israeli society.

headline: Splitting 5-4, Justices Put Texas Redistricting on Hold
abstract: A lower court had ordered Texas to redraw maps found to be discriminatory. The Supreme Court blocked that order while it considers an appeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday blocked rulings from a federal court in Texas that had called for revisions to congressional and state legislative districts in the state after the court found that the districts violated the Constitution and the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Hope Hicks Is Formally Named White House Communications Director
abstract: Hope Hicks, one of President Trump’s most trusted and longest serving aides, was named communications director, among several personnel announcements.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hope Hicks, one of President Trump’s longest serving advisers working in the White House, was formally named communications director on Tuesday, a title that most accurately describes the role she has played for years.

headline: Trump Welcomes Najib Razak, the Malaysian Leader, as President, and Owner of a Fine Hotel
abstract: Prime Minister Najib Abdul Razak is under investigation by the Justice Department for corruption allegations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump welcomed Malaysia’s prime minister, Najib Razak, to the White House on Tuesday, he thanked him for “all the investment you’ve made in the United States.”

headline: Bannon Will Address Berkeley, a Hotbed of Conflict Over Free Speech
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon has agreed to speak this month at the invitation of a conservative student publication at the University of California, Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: The University of California, Berkeley, has erupted this year in response to planned speeches by conservative flamethrowers like Milo Yiannopoulos and Ann Coulter. On Tuesday, another figure was added to the mix: Stephen K. Bannon, the right-wing media executive and former chief strategist to President Trump.

headline: Congress Passes Measure Challenging Trump to Denounce Hate Groups
abstract: The House and Senate delivered a blunt message to President Trump, unanimously denouncing racist and anti-Semitic hate groups without equivocation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House and Senate have unanimously passed a joint resolution urging President Trump to denounce racist and anti-Semitic hate groups, sending a blunt message of dissatisfaction with the president’s initial, equivocal response to the white nationalist violence in Charlottesville, Va., last month.

headline: De Blasio, Seeking Second Term, Wins an Easy Victory
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio will now turn his focus to the general election and his matchup against Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican, and Bo Dietl, an independent.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio coasted to a decisive win on Tuesday in the Democratic primary in New York City, as he moved closer to securing a second term.

headline: Corrections: September 13, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 13, 2017.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Democrats on Voter Fraud Panel Join Those Criticizing It
abstract: The panel’s Republican chief is rebuked by one Democrat for claiming a New Hampshire election was probably rigged. Another questions the panel’s objectivity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s voter fraud commission met in New Hampshire on Tuesday to discuss what members characterized as declining confidence in elections. But the most telling discussions of the session addressed declining confidence in the commission itself.

headline: Eric Gonzalez Wins Primary Election for Brooklyn District Attorney
abstract: With no Republican scheduled to run in the general election, Mr. Gonzalez, the acting district attorney, will continue to serve as Brooklyn’s top prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: Defeating a field of five other candidates, Eric Gonzalez won the Democratic primary election for Brooklyn district attorney on Tuesday, taking another step toward becoming the first Latino elected to this office.

headline: They’re What Really Count
abstract: Daniel Mauer gives us a little test.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky here, filling in today and tomorrow for Martin, filling in for Deb — whew, that’s a mouthful.

headline: Review: 3 Generations Aching to Connect ‘On the Shore of the Wide World’
abstract: Simon Stephens’s play explores the dreams and disappointments in one working-class family.
lead_paragraph: If you think you’ve heard it all before, then you need to listen more closely.

headline: Nancy Gibbs, Time Magazine’s Top Editor, Is Stepping Down
abstract: Ms. Gibbs, the first woman to lead the magazine, said she would stay at Time Inc. through the end of the year to help with the transition.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Gibbs, the first woman to lead Time magazine, is stepping down as editor in chief, ending her four-year run at the publication’s helm.

headline: Local Issues Dominate New York City Council Elections
abstract: Gentrification, development and homelessness were often the focus of the contests for 10 open seats and the 10 with embattled incumbents.
lead_paragraph: If voters sent any discernible messages in the contested Democratic primaries for New York City Council, they were that gentrification is bad, Albany legislators might be good, and a staunchly liberal vision is less important than a strong neighborhood constituency.

headline: Rays Make Themselves at Home, Beating the Yankees and Sonny Gray
abstract: Gray, who pitched a great game but again got little offensive support, lost on a home run he surrendered in the eighth inning.
lead_paragraph: The strangeness of watching a baseball game in the Mets’ park without a Met on the premises had lessened somewhat by the second night of the Yankees-Tampa Bay Rays series at Citi Field.

headline: Its River Swollen, a Florida Town Wades in Rising Water After Hurricane Irma
abstract: In the aftermath of the storm, residents of Bonita Springs, Fla., were contending with waist-deep water and spotty cell service — challenges for many Floridians across the state.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the storm, residents of Bonita Springs, Fla., were contending with waist-deep water and spotty cell service — challenges for many Floridians across the state.

headline: Deal Struck to Extend Financing for Children’s Health Program
abstract: The chairman and top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee announced agreement to extend the Children’s Health Insurance Program but lower the federal share of funds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and the top Democrat on the panel announced on Tuesday night that they had reached agreement on a plan to prevent the imminent exhaustion of federal funds for the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

headline: ‘Top of the Lake: China Girl’: Jane Campion on Her ‘Ovarian’ Series
abstract: Ms. Campion discusses the gender politics of the show and the input sex workers had on the story.
lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for the entire season of “Top of the Lake: China Girl.”

headline: Police Likely to Release Body Camera Footage in Fatal Bronx Shooting, Commissioner Says
abstract: The encounter last week was the first fatal police shooting in New York City captured by body cameras.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department will likely release video from the first fatal police encounter captured by body cameras worn by officers, the police commissioner, James P. O’Neill, said Tuesday evening.

abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.
