lead_paragraph: Dr. Gary Wadler, a prominent authority on the use of performance-enhancing substances and their effects on athletes, died on Tuesday in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 78.

headline: Sean Spicer and Chelsea Manning Join Harvard as Visiting Fellows
abstract: Mr. Spicer and Ms. Manning will be part of a fellowship class that reads like a who’s who of tense political debates in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Sean Spicer and Chelsea Manning are headed back to school. Sort of.

headline: Nothing Can Replace the Bodega
abstract: A new start-up aims to drive the neighborhood corner stores out of business. Good luck with that.
lead_paragraph: Like solar eclipses and bipartisan legislation, moments of near-universal consensus are extremely rare. One such event took place on Wednesday, when a start-up named Bodega stated its intention to put its namesake — real-life, neighborhood corner stores — out of business by replacing them with unmanned pantries.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Redemption and Rejection: From Prison to Ph.D.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 14, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Is it that she did not show the appropriate degree of horror in herself, by applying?”

headline: After Irma, a Grim Sense of Déjà Vu in St. Augustine
abstract: At 452 years old, St. Augustine is no stranger to flooding. But damage from hurricanes in two consecutive years has left residents soaked, frustrated and worried about the future.
lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — This place calls itself the “Ancient City,” and, by the standards of American cities, that’s about right.  St. Augustine  is 452 years old, having been founded by the Spanish conquistador Don Pedro Menéndez de Avilés in 1565.

headline: Corrections: September 14, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, September 14, 2017.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Frank Vincent, Mobster on ‘The Sopranos’ and in ‘Goodfellas,’ Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Vincent, a character actor who specialized in tough-guy roles, had a particularly memorable scene in “Goodfellas.”
lead_paragraph: Frank Vincent, whose tough-guy looks brought him steady work as a character actor in film and television for four decades, including mobster roles on “The Sopranos” and in “Goodfellas,” died on Wednesday in New Jersey. He was 80.

headline: ISIS Convoy Reportedly Crosses Syria, at Russia’s Request
abstract: An Islamic State convoy of buses with fighters and family members aboard finally gets to ISIS territory in eastern Syria, after Russia asks American planes to stay away.
lead_paragraph: An Islamic State convoy stuck in the middle of the Syrian desert for more than two weeks because of American airstrikes finally reached eastern Syria late Wednesday night, according to reports from citizen journalist groups in the area. The convoy reached territory held by the Islamic State, despite vows by the American-led coalition fighting the group that it would not be allowed to do so.

headline: Mnuchin Inquired About Using Government Plane for His Honeymoon
abstract: The Treasury Department said that it had inquired about the use of a military plane for the Treasury secretary’s honeymoon so that the secretary would have access to secure communications when he was abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin inquired about the use of a military plane for his European honeymoon last month, the Treasury Department confirmed on Wednesday, a disclosure that comes as he is already under scrutiny for taking a government plane to Kentucky before viewing the Aug. 21 solar eclipse.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Something to Tie Up
abstract: John Guzzetta instructs us to mind the gap.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Of all the days of the week, Thursdays present the puzzles with the most variation. Usually, some sort of gimmick is featured that early-week solvers might have great difficulty figuring out, such as a rebus. Other times, we’ll see a tricky constructing “stunt,” such as last week’s offering. And yet there are the occasional puzzles whose themes may be slightly simpler, but their overall fill vocabulary and low-word count grids raises the difficulty to Thursday level. John Guzzetta’s puzzle today is an excellent example of the latter type; let’s take a look!

headline: Review: Reimagining ‘Peter Pan’ for the Lipitor Demographic
abstract: In Sarah Ruhl’s “For Peter Pan on her 70th birthday,” five siblings face the loss of a parent, their own mortality and a fear of flying.
lead_paragraph: Ghosts, pets and arguments without outcomes: These are reliable telltales of the work of Sarah Ruhl, whose new play, “For Peter Pan on her 70th birthday,” includes a long, digressive scene featuring all of them.

headline: 15 Marines Are Hurt, 6 Critically, in Accident at Camp Pendleton
abstract: The Marines were training in an amphibious vehicle when it caught fire Wednesday morning. The Marine Corps said the cause was under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen Marines were wounded, six of them critically, when an amphibious vehicle they were training in caught fire at Camp Pendleton on Wednesday morning.

headline: ‘Younger’ Yanks the Rug Out From Under Viewers — and Star
abstract: The show’s creator, Darren Star, and its lead actress, Sutton Foster, talk about thwarted romance, career aspirations and whether we’ll ever see Liza in Charles’s arms.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the Season 4 finale of “Younger.”

headline: Anthony Weiner Says His Actions ‘Crushed the Aspirations of My Wife’
abstract: The former congressman asked a judge to spare him a prison sentence for his online exchanges with a teenage girl, offering a deeply personal look at the history of his behavior.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Anthony D. Weiner, the former Democratic congressman whose lewd text exchanges with a teenage girl led to his prosecution and embroiled him in an F.B.I. investigation of Hillary Clinton before the presidential election, asked a judge on Wednesday night to spare him a prison sentence.

headline: Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin Letters
abstract: Anthony Weiner and his wife, Huma Abedin, wrote separate letters to Judge Denise L. Cote asking that she spare Mr. Weiner a prison sentence.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Weiner and his wife, Huma Abedin, wrote separate letters to Judge Denise L. Cote asking that she spare Mr. Weiner a prison sentence.

headline: In Angela Merkel, German Women Find Symbol, but Not Savior
abstract: The highest office in the land has been held by a woman for 12 years. It’s all the other offices that still pose a problem for women in Germany.
lead_paragraph: OSNABRÜCK, Germany — Just 9 years old when Chancellor Angela Merkel was first elected in 2005, Kristin Auf der Masch cannot really remember a time when Germany was led by a man.

headline: Jon Hamm’s Second Act
abstract: More than two years after “Mad Men,” the man who was Don Draper gives himself a pep talk: “Let’s improve. Let’s get better.”
lead_paragraph: I had only two or three questions for Jon Hamm. I wanted to know if fame had rattled him. I wanted to know if, more than two years after the “Mad Men” finale, he had plotted out a second act worthy of his talent. I wanted to know if he still wanted to be a star.

headline: Jean-Claude Juncker, Rohingya, Russia: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Test Your Knowledge of Cassini and Its Grand Mission to Saturn
abstract: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft has been exploring Saturn for the past 13 years. How much do you know about this robotic explorer and the sixth planet from our sun?
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft has been exploring Saturn for the past 13 years. How much do you know about this robotic explorer and the sixth planet from our sun?

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Better Things’ and ‘Riviera’
abstract: Pamela Adlon brings a humorous twist to the pressures of being a single working mother. And Julia Stiles stars in a crime drama set along the French Riviera.
lead_paragraph: In Season 2 of “Better Things,” Pamela Adlon puts a humorous twist on the pressures of being a single working mother. And Julia Stiles stars in a crime drama set along the French Riviera.

headline: ‘Tiny Home’: Affordable, Stylish — but a Bit Too Easy to Steal
abstract: The police in Australia have arrested a man in the theft of a 1.5-ton Canberra home, which was hauled cross-country before they caught up with it.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s housing affordability crisis took a strange turn this week, after a woman’s “tiny home” was stolen from her Canberra business.

headline: Word + Quiz: diaphanous
abstract: This word has appeared in 29 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: The Best Pizza
abstract: Are you a pizza lover? What’s the best slice you’ve ever had?
lead_paragraph: Are you a pizza lover? What’s the best slice you’ve ever had?

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Items You Need in Your Bathroom
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: How to Clean Up Safely After a Hurricane or Flood
abstract: Cleaning after a hurricane, flood, or other major storm is different from regular, and even heavy duty, cleaning.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Texas and Louisiana, Hurricane Harvey cleanup is underway. Florida, Georgia and the Caribbean islands are just starting to assess the damage from Irma, while the storm pushed north to flood Charleston, S.C. Hurricane Jose’s path is still uncertain, but one thing is true: If you’ve been hit by either of these — or any other storm — cleaning up can be a nightmare, and few resources tell you where to start.

headline: Making Chicano Life Visible
abstract: The relatively unknown story of photography’s important role in the Chicano movement is featured in a new exhibition at the Autry Museum of the American West.
lead_paragraph: The relatively unknown story of photography’s important role in the Chicano movement is featured in a new exhibition at the Autry Museum of the American West.

headline: An Old Supreme Court Dream
abstract: Remembering a good immigration decision in a mean season.
lead_paragraph: Before there were the Dreamers, there were undocumented children occupying seats in the public school classrooms of America. And before there was Kris Kobach, or Jeff Sessions, or Donald Trump, or other exploiters of the nativist strain that runs just below the surface of the national psyche, there was Texas.

headline: Follow Kenya’s Lead on Plastic Bags
abstract: It and more than 40 other countries have taxed, limited or banned plastic bags. The rest of the world should, too.
lead_paragraph: Plastic bags are often used for a few minutes before enjoying an eternal afterlife, clogging storm drains, stuffing landfills, killing animals that eat them and contributing to the eight million metric tons of plastic that end up in the world’s oceans every year.

headline: Donald Trump Has Changed His Mind — a Heck of a Lot
abstract: Cut those taxes! No, raise them! No, just ask Chuck and Nancy.
lead_paragraph: Wow, Donald Trump is all over the place.

headline: What Trump Can Do to Prevent the Next Crash
abstract: The Federal Reserve doesn’t do enough to restrain out-of-control prices for stocks, houses and other assets. It should, and Donald Trump can help.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve arguably has more influence on the daily lives of Americans than any other government agency. In the coming year President Trump has a chance to appoint or replace five of the central bank’s seven governors, including the vice chairman, Stanley Fischer, and possibly the chairwoman, Janet Yellen.

headline: Joe Biden: Reclaiming America’s Values
abstract: Deep divisions have led to a war over our core beliefs.
lead_paragraph: In over 45 years of working in global affairs, I’ve observed a simple truth: America’s ability to lead the world depends not just on the example of our power, but on the power of our example.

headline: Trump’s Selective Devotion to Law and Order
abstract: Who’s who on the president’s naughty and nice list. And why.
lead_paragraph: Republicans — like President Trump, for instance — love to puff up their chests, grasp their lapels and declaim in foghorn voices about their devotion to law and order.

headline: Don’t Repeat the Mistakes of the Katrina Recovery
abstract: When I ask people about the disaster, they barely mention the hurricane. Instead, they talk about the decisions made afterward.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The wind isn’t racist, and the rain doesn’t target the poor. But when hurricanes strike and cities flood, people who were already disadvantaged tend to suffer the most. That’s because the wind and rain alone do not define the shape of our modern disasters.

headline: Dispatch From the Resistance
abstract: None of this is normal.
lead_paragraph: When Congress has to pass a joint resolution condemning white supremacy and plunk it on the desk of the “president” — in an effort to force him to sign it and daring him not to — you know that we as a country are beyond the pale.

headline: Making Chicano Life Visible
abstract: The relatively unknown story of photography’s important role in the Chicano movement is featured in a new exhibition at the Autry Museum of the American West.
lead_paragraph: From 1967 to 1977, La Raza, the Los Angeles newspaper turned magazine, provided a vital and dynamic forum for Chicano political and cultural expression. Employing a range of disciplines, including photojournalism, graphic art, satire, poetry and political commentary, it was both chronicler and participant in the Mexican-American struggle for equality and justice.

headline: Trump Says Jump. His Supporters Ask, How High?
abstract: Many Republican voters appear to be ready to follow the president wherever he goes.
lead_paragraph: In the Trump era, Republicans have been revising their views on right and wrong.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘The Battered Southeast Grapples With Irma’s Aftermath’
abstract: Has hurricane coverage of the United States Virgin Islands been neglected in favor of more coverage of the mainland states affected by the storm?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Fire at Malaysian Boarding School Kills 24, Mostly Students
abstract: The early morning blaze broke out in the dormitory of an Islamic school, in which the door was locked and the windows were barred.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Twenty-four people, most of them children, were killed in a fire on Thursday at an Islamic boarding school in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia’s capital, when they became trapped by a locked door and barred windows, officials said.

headline: Hike to Find the Magic of Santorini
abstract: Many visitors to Santorini come for its pristine beaches, but its open secret is the winding hiking trails that overlook the sea.
lead_paragraph: Many visitors to Santorini come for its pristine beaches, but its open secret is the winding hiking trails that overlook the sea.

headline: Can Baseball Turn a 27-Year-Old Into the Perfect Manager?
abstract: Take an inside look at the White Sox’s experiment with Justin Jirschele, the youngest coach in professional baseball.
lead_paragraph: On Opening Day this spring, Justin Jirschele’s eyes popped wide open at 9 o’clock, and he determined his chances of falling back to sleep — he’s big on percentages — to be zero. “Almost came to the park,” the 27-year-old said. Instead, the youngest manager in professional baseball fixed himself a bowl of cereal and downed it in bed while his new wife, Liz, tried to doze beside him. She has accepted that her marital contract will forever include disturbed nights.

headline: The Secret to Amazing Mango Kulfi Comes in a Can
abstract: The idea that fresh is always better is both simple and false.
lead_paragraph: Alphonso mangoes grow in India, and when they’re ripe, they’re so saturated with juice and perfume that I don’t just want to eat them; I also want to stand very close to them, like some kind of creep, and inhale. They’ve got skin the color of leaf-filtered sunlight and impossibly sweet, creamy flesh, but they’re not in season for long — a few months, starting around April — which means most of the time they’re not around at all.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Zip Ties
abstract: The cheap plastic fasteners are the best tool we have in the fight against chaos, entropy and disorder.
lead_paragraph: Successful baby-proofing requires cultivating a morbid imagination. A mother must look past obvious dangers — electrical outlets, toxic cleaning supplies — and see murderous intent in the ostentatiously benign. Bureaus, televisions, window treatments, toilets, doors, lamps, chopsticks, washing machines, stairs, fireplaces, medicine cabinets, spare change, garbage bags — she must physically restrain these objects before they cause her loved ones bodily harm. Complicating this seemingly straightforward task, no two hazards are the same shape, consistency or size.

headline: Harrowing Storms May Move Climate Debate, if Not G.O.P. Leaders
abstract: Political leaders say the politics of climate change have been steadily shifting, as extreme weather makes the impact of carbon pollution more vivid.
lead_paragraph: For years, climate change activists have faced a wrenching dilemma: how to persuade people to care about a grave but seemingly far-off problem and win their support for policies that might pinch them immediately in utility bills and at the pump.

headline: Sally Quinn: By the Book
abstract: The author of, most recently, “Finding Magic: A Spiritual Memoir,” doesn’t like to read short story collections, “especially if they’re good, because they always leave me wanting more.”
lead_paragraph: What books are currently on your nightstand?

headline: How the New Immigration Is Shaking Old Europe to Its Core
abstract: “The Strange Death of Europe,” by Douglas Murray, and “The Crisis of Multiculturalism in Europe,” by Rita Chin, examine divisive debates over Western values.
lead_paragraph: THE CRISIS OF MULTICULTURALISM IN EUROPE A History By Rita Chin 363 pp. Princeton University Press. $35.

headline: The Vietnam War Then and Now
abstract: Geoffrey C. Ward’s “The Vietnam War” relives a conflict that divided Americans 50 years ago, and continues to evoke bitter memories today.
lead_paragraph: THE VIETNAM WAR An Intimate History By Geoffrey C. Ward Introduction by Ken Burns and Lynn Novick Illustrated. 612 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $60.

headline: In Search of Authentic Santorini? Skip the Beach. Take a Hike.
abstract: Increasingly, hotel owners, walking tour companies and local travel companies are promoting the idea of experiencing Santorini by foot.
lead_paragraph: As I hiked through the village of Oia in Santorini, Greece, slightly out of breath from navigating the hilly streets, I was certain that I had seen few places in the world as attractive. Majestically perched atop a cliff, Oia faced the sparkling Aegean Sea and was awash in gleaming white villas built into the hills.

headline: The Two-Minute Commute
abstract: Dr. Robert J. Cerfolio, a thoracic surgeon, wanted a good view, a washer-dryer, an excellent gym and outdoor space — all within walking distance of work.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert J. Cerfolio is all about efficiency.

headline: ‘Will & Grace’ Is Back. Will Its Portrait of Gay Life Hold Up?
abstract: The groundbreaking NBC sitcom helped normalize gay characters in the 1990s. But its sharp-edged humor and stereotypes may feel out of step in the identity politics age.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Eleven years after parting ways, seemingly forever, the “Will & Grace” gang — same cast, same writers, same studio audience warm-up guy — reunited on the NBCUniversal lot here in mid-August. As they started work on 29 new episodes, Sean Hayes, returning to his role as the overly dramatic Jack, belted out a song from “Dreamgirls.” Megan Mullally, who plays Karen, did a little dance and shouted, “Sass is in the house!”

headline: In Undiscovered Paterson, Falls, Food and Fetty Wap
abstract: The New Jersey city was famous for industry. Now, a national park, a museum and Peruvian dishes deserve the spotlight. And it’s still a place of poets.
lead_paragraph: This Is Just to Say…

headline: 36 Hours in Perugia, Italy
abstract: One of Italy’s most underrated destinations is filled with remnants of an ancient past, complemented by a host of new bars, cafes and boutiques.
lead_paragraph: One of Italy’s most underrated destinations is filled with remnants of an ancient past, complemented by a host of new bars, cafes and boutiques.

headline: 100 Images From Cassini’s Mission to Saturn
abstract: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft burned up in Saturn’s atmosphere on Friday, after 20 years in space.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Cassini spacecraft burned up in Saturn’s atmosphere on Friday, after 20 years in space.

headline: Sean Spicer Responds to Melissa McCarthy’s Impression of Him
abstract: On “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” Mr. Spicer admitted that President Trump was never a big fan of Ms. McCarthy’s impersonation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Donald Trump, Florida, Martin Shkreli: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Much Can the Youth Vote Actually Help Democrats?
abstract: The young are typically much less likely to vote, but signs suggest participation levels could soon rise.
lead_paragraph: Young Americans have been moving left and leaving the G.O.P. in recent years, but a successful Democratic coalition built on the backs of liberal youth is far from a sure thing, especially in the short term.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: What Is Happening in Myanmar?
abstract: How a small nation celebrated as a story of democracy became condemned by the U.N. as a “textbook example of ethnic cleansing.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Our Third Annual Student Editorial Cartoon Contest
abstract: Students, do you have something to say about President Trump, immigration, fast fashion, football or anything else in the news? Make an editorial cartoon that shows us what you think.
lead_paragraph: Update, Nov. 8: You can find our 2018 Editorial Cartoon Contest here.

headline: The Crisis in Gynecological Cancer Research
abstract: We’re in an unusually productive phase for gynecological cancer research, but there has been a steep decline in clinical trials in the field.
lead_paragraph: As an ovarian cancer patient whose life is being extended by a clinical trial, I was delighted to learn this summer that research on gynecological cancers is undergoing an unusually productive period. But I’m dismayed that at the same time there has been a steep decline in clinical trials available in the field.

headline: Giving Proof
abstract: It turns out that generosity really can make us happier.
lead_paragraph: The adage says it’s better to give than to receive. But is it really? The scientific evidence that generosity is good for us has been scant, even as the benefits of selfishness are obvious. Recently, however, a neurological study published in Nature Communications found there may be some biological truth to the maxim after all. The study showed that generosity changed the activity in people’s brains in ways that increase feelings of happiness, even if the generous act is small or only imagined.

headline: Review: ‘Woodpeckers,’ a Tale of Love and Agonizing Penal Confinement
abstract: José María Cabral’s drama concerns a male and female convict in adjacent penitentiaries who use a sign language — “woodpecking” — in order to connect.
lead_paragraph: José María Cabral’s arresting drama “Woodpeckers (Carpinteros)” could be called love in a pressure cooker, but that would be understating its vivid textures and palpable vitality. The film was shot on location in the Dominican Republic’s Najayo and La Victoria prisons, where the stifling claustrophobia of those settings infuses every frame.

headline: Review: Fifth Time’s Not the Charm in This ‘Wilde Wedding’
abstract: This soulless remarriage comedy is mystifyingly seeded with acting heavyweights.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve done some stupid things in my life,” says Laurence Darling (John Malkovich), a stage actor, at one point in “The Wilde Wedding.” It’s a line that Mr. Malkovich might easily filch to excuse his participation in this execrable remarriage comedy, one that’s mystifyingly seeded with acting heavyweights. Maybe the writer and director, Damian Harris, has a dossier.

headline: New York Today: Our Past in Pizza
abstract: Thursday: The evolution of New York pizza, San Gennaro in Little Italy, and literary love across the city.
lead_paragraph: Buongiorno on this glum Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Alina’ Is the Work of an Indie Film Veteran, New at Directing
abstract: Ben Barenholtz kick-started the career of David Lynch. But his first fiction feature shows he has not mastered directing.
lead_paragraph: Ben Barenholtz has been a film distributor, exhibitor and producer, who has influenced the careers of David Lynch, John Sayles and Joel and Ethan Coen. He has even been credited with inventing the concept of the midnight movie at Chelsea’s long-gone Elgin Theater, which he ran. Alas, the self-financed “Alina,” his first fiction feature as a director, looks like the work of someone just starting out.

headline: Review: In ‘Rat Film,’ a City of Rodents and Racial Oppression
abstract: This documentary-essay about Baltimore reveals its relationship between infestations and economic inequity.
lead_paragraph: Equal parts disturbing and humorous, informative and bizarre, “Rat Film” is a brilliantly imaginative and formally experimental essay on how Baltimore has dealt with its rat problem and manipulated its black population.

headline: Are You a Hair-Twirler, Nail-Biter or Knuckle-Cracker?
abstract: Almost everybody has some kind of tic, and the degree to which you engage in them is a barometer of your peace of mind.
lead_paragraph: Are you a toe-tapper, hair-twirler, eye-blinker, head-nodder, nail-biter, knuckle-cracker, skin-picker, lip-licker, shoulder-shrugger or a chin-stroker?

headline: Jail Escape Plan: Blankets? Check. Floss? You Bet. But a Priest?
abstract: Prosecutors said Christopher Londonio had a plan to use dental floss to cut a window, sheets as a rope — and a priest to smuggle in a saw blade.
lead_paragraph: As it turns out, escaping from jail with the help of dental floss isn’t all that novel an idea. Neither is stockpiling sheets and blankets to repurpose as rope.

headline: Morning Agenda: Blocking of Lattice Sale Weighs on China Deals
abstract: The White House move to prevent the chip maker from selling itself to a Chinese-backed buyer may signal trouble for similar proposed takeovers.
lead_paragraph: “We could let it die quietly, but we’re going to kill it loudly.”

headline: Deutsche Börse to Pay $12.5 Million in Fines in Insider Trading Inquiry
abstract: Frankfurt prosecutors have been examining share purchases by the exchange operator’s C.E.O. before merger talks with the London Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse has agreed to pay 10.5 million euros, or about $12.5 million, in fines to resolve an investigation by German authorities into possible insider trading before its talks to merge with the London Stock Exchange Group became public.

headline: Review: ‘Strong Island’ Explores a Killing and Its Aftermath
abstract: The documentary looks at William Ford Jr., an unarmed black man who was killed by a white man who was never charged.
lead_paragraph: William Ford Jr. was shot and killed on April 7, 1992, an incident at the center of the documentary “Strong Island.” Something deep inside his family also died that night, and Yance Ford, one of William’s siblings and the film’s director, explores that loss, exposing a grief that is profound and agonizing.

headline: Review: Watch Manolo Blahnik Make Famous Friends — and Shoes
abstract: A new documentary about the famed designer could use more of the shoes for which he’s renowned.
lead_paragraph: The most potent, and poignant, tribute in the sweet back-scratch of a documentary “Manolo: The Boy Who Made Shoes for Lizards” is that Anna Wintour lets you see her eyes.

headline: Oktoberfest, All the Time
abstract: The Heidelberg has been serving beer and bratwurst since the 1930s. What’s new is the hipster love for Bavarian-style beer gardens.
lead_paragraph: The Heidelberg seems out of step with the high-rise aesthetic of the Upper East Side. Yet for a few hours this Saturday, the 81-year-old German restaurant, one of the last relics of German Town, now known as Yorkville, will be the star of the neighborhood, as its workers dish out sauerkraut and sausages for the annual German-American Steuben Parade. The event, named for Baron Friedrich von Steuben, the Prussian hero of the Revolutionary War, celebrates its 60th anniversary this year.

headline: Review: Love of Il Maestro Drives ‘In Search of Fellini’
abstract: A sheltered young woman enamored of the films of the famous director sets off to Italy to meet him.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Cartwright, the voice of Bart Simpson on the long-running animated television series, has made her first movie as a screenwriter and producer, a charming drama about the love of movies and youthful passion. “In Search of Fellini” reimagines a whirlwind adventure Ms. Cartwright once had to try to meet the Italian director Federico Fellini. With the help of her longtime collaborator and co-writer, Peter Kjenaas, and the first-time director Taron Lexton, Ms. Cartwright creates a Felliniesque fantasy of her own.

headline: Trump’s Support for Law to Protect ‘Dreamers’ Lifts Its Chances
abstract: President Trump said there would need to be a larger agreement on border security for any deal on young, undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An unexpected meeting of the minds between President Trump and Democratic leaders on Thursday made real a possible deal in Congress to pair enhanced border security with legislation to protect young, undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children.

headline: Portrait of the Artist in Putin’s Russia
abstract: When will artists realize that they can’t thrive under authoritarianism?
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At the beginning of August, five members of a gang accused of murdering 17 people during robberies on highways around the Moscow area were facing trial at Moscow Regional Court. While the five men were being escorted to the courtroom, they attacked their guards, seized their weapons and opened fire in the courthouse. Most likely this terrible episode could have been avoided had there been adequate security, but the five defendants were accompanied by only two armed guards.

headline: How Should the Problem of Sexual Assault on Campuses Be Addressed?
abstract: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos says she plans to rewrite federal guidelines in an effort to protect both the victims of sexual assault and the accused. Is that a good idea?
lead_paragraph: Did you know that in 2011, the Obama administration’s Education Department set forth guidelines for policing sexual assault on college campuses? The guidelines required a tougher response to campus sexual-assault accusations under Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they warned colleges that federal funding would be at risk if they did not comply.

headline: Marc Jacobs — He’s Still Here
abstract: The final show of New York Fashion Week was a litmus test for the continued relevance of the city’s favorite designer son.
lead_paragraph: For the last year, speculation around Marc Jacobs and his brand has been at a fever pitch. The onetime crown prince of New York Fashion Week, creator of the most anticipated, most controversial show of each season, the one guaranteed to electrify the city and shore up its creative cred, beloved child of downtown, channeler of the moment, seemed to be teetering on a precipice.

headline: Elevator Repair Service Tackles Shakespeare’s Problem Play
abstract: The experimental theater company stages the Bard’s enigmatic “Measure for Measure” at the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Elevator Repair Service, one of the city’s few truly essential theater companies, has always delighted in a good problem, whether it’s how to dramatize oral arguments from the Supreme Court or stage the famously difficult-to-adapt novel “The Great Gatsby” without sacrificing a word. So it makes sense that when its artistic director, John Collins, decided to direct his first Shakespeare, he decided on “Measure for Measure,” perhaps Shakespeare’s most problematic of problem plays.

headline: Review: ‘Wetlands,’ an Excursion to Noir on the Jersey Shore
abstract: This crime drama, the first feature from Emanuele Della Valle, offers atmosphere and performances that almost surmount its plot contrivances.
lead_paragraph: The moody ambience of the beachside noir “Wetlands” is almost enough to make you want to plan an off-season visit to Atlantic City, near where it is set, or to believe the film’s dramatic devices and occasionally arch dialogue. And yet, for some, its atmosphere and intriguing performances will prove worthy of the outing.

headline: California Today: A Finance Man in the Race for Governor
abstract: Thursday: Checking in with the state treasurer, homeless crises in San Diego and Anaheim, and bracing for Ben Shapiro in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: After a Chicago Teenager Is Found Dead in a Walk-In Hotel Freezer, Mystery Lingers
abstract: Kenneka Jenkins, 19, died after attending a party. While the police try to determine what happened, social media users are mining videos for clues.
lead_paragraph: A young woman was found dead in a hotel freezer on the outskirts of Chicago over the weekend, and the many unanswered questions surrounding the investigation have led to widespread speculation.

headline: Trump to Hold Call With Jewish Leaders Ahead of High Holy Days
abstract: Despite friction with rabbinical groups, President Trump will hold a conference call on Friday with Jewish leaders ahead of the High Holy Days.
lead_paragraph: President Trump will hold a conference call on Friday morning with Jewish leaders ahead of the High Holy Days, moving ahead with a standard White House event that several rabbinical groups have vowed to boycott.

headline: Bernie’s Secret G.O.P. Allies
abstract: Republicans are unwittingly helping his push for single-payer health insurance.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Grenfell Fire Inquiry Opens Amid ‘Sense of Anger and Betrayal’
abstract: An investigation of Britain’s deadliest blaze in more than a century will seek to uncover what led to the disaster and who should be held accountable.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A major public inquiry into the deadliest fire in Britain in more than a century opened on Thursday, with the retired judge who is leading the investigation citing a “sense of anger and betrayal” among former residents of Grenfell Tower in London, which was engulfed in flames in June.

headline: Mom’s Doll Needs a New Dress
abstract: The plan was to provide a comforting toy to a 90 year old with dementia. Who knew she would insist on bringing it to life?
lead_paragraph: Beth, the world’s ugliest baby doll, needs a new outfit. I got her the one she’s been wearing soon after she was presented to my 90-year-old mother, who seized on her with a single-minded adoration neither my brothers nor I recall her showering on us. Maybe this happens with dementia. New personalities pop up like those tough little stalks of green in a broken sidewalk, leaving you to wonder: Now, how did that get here?

headline: Spotting the Phish in a Sea of Email
abstract: Scammers constantly change their tactics to try to fool you into clicking into their clutches, so be aware of hidden links in spam.
lead_paragraph: Q. I got a message asking me to verify a new Dropbox account, but I never signed up for Dropbox. I suspect this is a hoax, but I looked at the return address and it seems to be pointing to Dropbox itself. Has my email account been hacked?

headline: When Dealers, Too, Were Romantics
abstract: An ambitious show salutes Richard Bellamy, who fostered Jo Baer, Donald Judd, Bruce Nauman and Claes Oldenburg, among many others.
lead_paragraph: “Dealers are as important as the artists themselves,” the gallery owner Leo Castelli once said. “He cannot exist without us, and we cannot exist without him.” Gendered language aside, Castelli’s remark captures the fragile symbiosis between those who make art and those who sell it.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cresskill, N.J., and Yonkers, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cresskill, N.J., and Yonkers, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are five-bedroom homes in Cresskill, N.J., and Yonkers, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York and New Jersey:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, on the Upper West Side and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, on the Upper West Side and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include apartments in Greenwich Village and the Upper West Side, and a co-op in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: ‘Racism Is as American as Baseball’ Banner Unfurled at Fenway Park
abstract: The banner, briefly hung by anti-racism activists over the Green Monster, was taken down and four fans removed peacefully within minutes.
lead_paragraph: Four fans were ejected from Fenway Park in Boston after they unveiled an anti-racism banner over the Green Monster on Wednesday night.

headline: Grant Hart, Hüsker Dü Drummer and Singer, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Hart, along with Bob Mould and Greg Norton, started Hüsker Dü, an early member of the hardcore movement, in the late 1970s in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: Grant Hart, a drummer, vocalist and songwriter for the influential Minnesota rock band Hüsker Dü, died on Wednesday. He was 56.

headline: Review: Hey, Jack Reacher and Jason Bourne. Room for One More?
abstract: “American Assassin,” the first adaptation of a series of thrillers, stars Dylan O’Brien as a rogue C.I.A. killer and Michael Keaton as grizzled mentor.
lead_paragraph: With “American Assassin,” Mitch Rapp, a self-taught killer who works with — but not always officially for — the C.I.A., seeks to join Jason Bourne and Jack Reacher in the rarefied company of movie-franchise heroes who did not originate in comics or children’s books.

headline: Detroit Real Estate Heats Up
abstract: The housing market in Detroit is beginning to recover.
lead_paragraph: Picture Detroit, and blocks of foreclosed and abandoned homes may come to mind. But think again: While the “Motor City” days are far from returning, this city’s real estate market is showing signs of recovery.

headline: Can South Africa Reawaken Nelson Mandela’s Dream?
abstract: President Jacob Zuma, in office since 2009, is subverting democracy.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Mandela’s dream of a free, prosperous and nonracial South Africa has turned into a nightmare. The nation’s constitution, often hailed as one of the most progressive in the world, is under siege by the very man who took an oath to protect it.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Bruce Weber
abstract: The photographer sketched his answers using a Uni-ball pen in a cabin on the sea in Montauk, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Bruce Weber, who will be releasing the 17th edition of his arts journal, ‘‘Bruce Weber’s All-American,’’ in November, sketched his answers using a Uni-ball pen in a cabin on the sea in Montauk, N.Y.

headline: To Lighten Up a Space, Try Transparent Furniture
abstract: Glass, resin and acrylic options that are anything but opaque.
lead_paragraph: Clockwise from left: Piero Lissoni for Glas Italia Wireframe table, $3,355, suiteny.com. John Hogan Ripple tables, $5,000-$7,000 each, thefutureperfect.com. Studio Sabine Marcelis for Chamber Equals chair, $15,000, chambernyc.com.

headline: A Downtown Skyscraper With Yachtlike Interiors
abstract: A new tower designed by Rafael Viñoly, will have small spaces but expansive views of the harbor and the World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: At 125 Greenwich Street, a new skyscraper rising in Manhattan’s Financial District, Bizzi & Partners Development is turning the typical condominium model on its head.

headline: ‘Fatal Attraction’ Oral History: Rejected Stars and a Foul Rabbit
abstract: No studio wanted Michael Douglas, and the filmmakers weren’t interested in Glenn Close. Don’t get them started on the bunny. A look back at the 1987 thriller.
lead_paragraph: The bunny almost was broiled. In the most notorious scene of the 1987 thriller “Fatal Attraction,” the spurned Alex (Glenn Close) terrorizes her ex-lover Dan (Michael Douglas) by boiling the family pet on the stove. “Initially, I had her grilling the bunny,” the screenwriter James Dearden said in a recent telephone interview. “But I thought that was too grotesque. So we boiled the bunny instead.”

headline: The Architect David Van Severen, at Home
abstract: In Brussels, he transformed a 19th-century mansion turned law office into a family home.
lead_paragraph: In Brussels, he transformed a 19th-century mansion turned law office into a family home.

headline: A 19th-Century Mansion Turned Law Office — Then Home
abstract: In Brussels, the architect David Van Severen honored a building’s architectural history while renovating it for his family.
lead_paragraph: IN EARLY 2016, the Belgian architect David Van Severen and his wife, the Swedish photographer Martina Bjorn, were looking for a larger apartment for themselves and their two young children, when Bjorn came across a curious property. ‘‘It was listed as having zero bedrooms,’’ she recalled recently. This was, it turned out, because the place was not technically an apartment; it had been, most recently, the offices of a law firm. But it was not technically office space, either — it was the bottom three floors of one of the opulent Beaux-Arts style mansions built by wealthy Bruxellois during the late 1800s, in the quiet, forested area south of the city center. Belgium’s architectural conservation laws had been notoriously lax, and so over the decades many of those buildings were demolished or carved up into offices or apartments. But the interiors of this one had somehow survived mostly intact, with ornate stucco moldings, marble fireplaces, wooden paneling, wrought-iron stair rails and parquet floors made in the traditional way, without a single nail. Huge windows on the grand top floor looked out across Avenue Winston Churchill on one side and into a densely wooded garden on the other.

headline: Subway Commute Snared by Debris, Switch Problem and Power Malfunction
abstract: Multiple train lines were delayed as passengers resigned themselves to waiting in transit limbo and venting on social media.
lead_paragraph: In Manhattan, it was debris on the track. In Queens, it was a switch problem. In Brooklyn, it was a power malfunction. Taken together, the various woes snarled at least eight lines on New York City’s dilapidated subway on Thursday, upending the travels of furious riders who were forced to wait on packed platforms for trains that never came or were too full to squeeze inside.

headline: One Cheer for Democracy in Kenya
abstract: Kenya needs a transparent, credible and peaceful re-election. The world will be watching.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 1 Kenya’s Supreme Court made the unprecedented decision to nullify the results of the country’s Aug. 8 presidential election, voiding the victory by incumbent President Uhuru Kenyatta and calling for fresh elections in 60 days. A decade after the 2007 presidential election was followed by violence that killed more than 1,000 people, it is a historic moment not just for Kenya but also for the continent, and guarantees greater global attention on the country this fall.

headline: How to Quit a Magazine, by Cindi Leive
abstract: After 16 years as editor in chief of Glamour, Cindi Leive is definitely not leaving her job to spend more time with her family.
lead_paragraph: Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour, says that a writer has about three seconds to grab a reader’s attention, so let’s blurt this out: After 16 years, she says, she’s quitting her job.

headline: N.F.L. Week 2 Picks: Patriots Should Bounce Back; Packers Over Falcons
abstract: The N.F.L. has a jam-packed slate, including a rematch of last year’s N.F.C. championship game. Here’s who we think will win.
lead_paragraph: Every team that won last week is Super Bowl-bound, and every team that lost is convinced it was a fluke. That is the beauty of Week 2; the predictive nature of Week 1 is entirely dependent on how your team fared. Unlike last week, when Hurricane Irma forced a postponement of a game between Miami and Tampa Bay, all 32 teams will play. Here’s how we think things will play out.

headline: Postwar Art Gets a Nervy Makeover
abstract: At the Met Breuer, “Delirious” proposes a new version of art history, one short on blue-chip names but with a terrific soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: Big thematic exhibitions are almost always by definition flawed propositions. A curator comes up with a concept — often a single word — and selects work by different artists that lend it substance. Untethered by style, medium or geography, such ventures can seem both arbitrary and amorphous.

headline: A Tour of Philipp Plein’s Master Bathroom in Manhattan
abstract: The German fashion designer known for his over-the-top runway shows created a fittingly luxe room to take a soak.
lead_paragraph: Philipp Plein

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Mother!’
abstract: Darren Aronofsky narrates a sequence from his film starring Jennifer Lawrence.
lead_paragraph: Darren Aronofsky narrates a sequence from his film starring Jennifer Lawrence.

headline: Can a Vending Machine Replace a Bodega? A Start-Up’s Plans Draw Fire
abstract: A company that wants to make its internet-connected vending machines ubiquitous did damage control after implying that it wanted to displace beloved corner stores.
lead_paragraph: Don’t mess with the beloved bodega.

headline: Darren Aronofsky Narrates a Scene From ‘Mother!’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film starring Jennifer Lawrence.
lead_paragraph: There’s no place quite like the home in “Mother!”, the new film from Darren Aronofsky. Jennifer Lawrence plays the title character who lives in (and doesn’t ever leave) an isolated house with her husband (Javier Bardem). Their peaceful life is disrupted when visitors (Michelle Pfeiffer and Ed Harris) arrive. And in this scene, even more visitors show up to ruin paradise. At the Toronto International Film Festival, where the film played ahead of its theatrical release Friday, Mr. Aronofsky spoke about his interest in biblical narratives, his decision to shoot on film and the house he used for the movie. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Saudi Arabia Detains Critics as New Crown Prince Consolidates Power
abstract: The kingdom has arrested 16 people — including clerics, scholars and a prince — and it is not clear if they have been charged.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia has begun a wide-ranging crackdown against perceived opponents of the policies of the kingdom’s new crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman.

headline: Birthplace May Be Tied to Dementia Risk
abstract: People who were born in nine states with the highest rates of stroke had a higher rate of dementia, even after they had moved away.
lead_paragraph: Place of birth may be associated with the risk for dementia, a new study has found.

headline: Tradita
abstract: At Tradita, in the Norwood section of the Bronx, a wood-fired pizza oven turns out savory Albanian specialties. And you can still get a pizza if you want.
lead_paragraph: At Tradita, in the Norwood section of the Bronx, a wood-fired pizza oven turns out savory Albanian specialties. And you can still get a pizza if you want.

headline: From a Pizza Oven in the Bronx, Albanian Specialties
abstract: Tradita turns out savory, delightfully salty dishes oozing with cheese and packed with meats.
lead_paragraph: The layers keep rising, spooned into the round pan not in full moons but in alternating rays like the sun’s, gossamer dough then melted cheese, with bouts in the oven in between. It takes hours. The top looks like parchment snatched from a fire, patched bronze at the edges and scorched at the heart.

headline: On Insider Trading, an Appeals Court Comes to Its Senses
abstract: A decision upholding the conviction of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital portfolio manager, gives the upper hand back to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old saying, “hard cases make bad law.” Perhaps a corollary should be “easy cases make good law.”

headline: Review: Ken Burns’s ‘Vietnam War’ Will Break Your Heart and Win Your Mind
abstract: Mr. Burns and Lynn Novick go back, way back, in hope of learning from the history of people who failed to learn from their own history.
lead_paragraph: “The Vietnam War” begins in reverse. After a brief introduction, there’s a sequence of familiar footage, running backward. Napalm is sucked out of the jungle. Bombs fall up. A prisoner springs to life as a bullet shoots from his head into the chamber of a gun.

headline: Trump Hands Out Hoagies and Reassurances in Storm-Battered Florida
abstract: The president praised the government’s response to the Hurricane Irma.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — President Trump traveled to Florida on Thursday to take part in what has quickly become a familiar tableau for him: the windbreaker-clad commander in chief, surveying hurricane devastation, bucking up local officials, and alighting from his helicopter to distribute food and handshakes.

headline: Testing an Electric Eel’s Shock Powers With His Own Arm
abstract: After years of studying eels, a researcher managed to experience something unexpected when he set out to study their ability to create an electric circuit.
lead_paragraph: A couple of hundred years ago, an explorer and naturalist named Alexander von Humboldt wanted to study electricity with eels in Cumana, an early settlement in what today is Venezuela. So local fishermen helped him obtain his slimy, charged subjects by leading horses into a shallow river basin full of them. The eels rubbed against the horses’ legs, zapping them with electric pulses. The horses tried to escape, but the fishermen didn’t let them until the eels ran out of juice.

headline: A Female Viking Warrior? Tomb Study Yields Clues
abstract: A DNA analysis has shown that remains from a famous 10th-century grave site belonged to a woman. But some experts don’t know how much that proves.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — When a team of scholars announced last Friday that a famous Viking tomb in Sweden contained the remains of a woman, it seemed to provide long-awaited support for legends of female Viking warriors that date to the early Middle Ages but had been dismissed, in modern times, as myths.

headline: Nestlé Targets High-End Coffee by Taking Majority Stake in Blue Bottle
abstract: The deal highlights the continued hot streak of artisanal coffee, whose rapid growth and fanatical customer base have continued to draw big business.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, James Freeman gave up on being a professional clarinetist and began pursuing his other passion, roasting coffee.

headline: China Bitcoin Exchange to Stop Trading Virtual Currencies Amid Crackdown
abstract: The announcement by BTC China raises the specter of other exchanges shutting down Bitcoin trading in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A major Chinese exchange specializing in the trading of Bitcoin announced on Thursday that it would stop trading by the end of the month, amid a broader crackdown against virtual currencies by the authorities in Beijing.

headline: A Toast for J. P. Donleavy
abstract: The author, whose picaresque masterwork “The Ginger Man” has sold more than 45 million copies, died on Monday at 91.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Dangerfield, the hero of J. P. Donleavy’s picaresque masterwork “The Ginger Man” (1955), knew how he wanted to exit this world. “When I die,” he says, “I want to decompose in a barrel of porter and have it served in all the pubs in Dublin.”

headline: The Oregon Trail
abstract: The latest winemakers to settle in the region are bringing new perspectives, fresh energy and heartfelt enthusiasm to the country’s most exciting wine area.
lead_paragraph: GASTON, Ore. — In the kitchen at the headquarters of Big Table Farm, the home of the proprietors Brian Marcy and Clare Carver, a few words to live by are written on a blackboard hanging a bit lopsidedly on a wall:

headline: Hear the Music That Inspired ‘Star Wars’
abstract: The "Star Wars" movies are rooted in the classics. So is John Williams's music for the soundtracks.
lead_paragraph: “Star Wars” is omnivorous in its inspiration. The saga, which continues in December with “Episode VIII: The Last Jedi,” nods to classical mythology, Arthurian legend and even Wagner’s “Ring” cycle.

headline: Finally, Some Answers From Equifax to Your Data Breach Questions
abstract: How will people get refunds for credit freeze fees? What about those faulty freeze PIN numbers? After a delay, the company responded to our columnist’s many questions.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, several hundred of you have sent me questions or tweeted about the Equifax breach and its credit freeze process. I don’t blame you, given that you’ve melted their websites and phone banks since the company announced last week that up to 143 million people may have had their Social Security numbers and other data stolen.

headline: Velocity School: Where Pitchers Pay to Throw Harder
abstract: The average fastball was 89 m.p.h. in 2002. Now it’s nearly 93. A big fastball doesn’t guarantee a pitcher’s success, but without it, he may be ignored.
lead_paragraph: KENT, Wash. — Trevor Bauer is the son of a chemical engineer. Those are the genes he inherited. An engineer, Bauer explained, will consider a problem, develop a process to solve it, then implement, evaluate and adjust until finding a solution. Nothing is untrainable.

headline: Conservatives Recoil at Trump’s Accommodation With Democrats Over DACA
abstract: President Trump came under sharp attack on Thursday for appearing to set aside a border wall fight while reaching a deal on DACA immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump came under withering attack on Thursday from some of his strongest supporters, who were outraged and unforgiving about his decision to set aside, for now, a fight over building the border wall he has long promised as part of a deal with Democrats on legislation to protect young, undocumented immigrants.

headline: Fantasy Football: The Best Players to Start in Week 2
abstract: Week 2 is traditionally the week when fantasy owners overreact to what happened in Week 1. Remain calm and make these sensible choices.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account,@5thdownfantasy.

headline: Top Kashmir Militant, Abu Ismail, Is Killed by Indian Forces
abstract: Abu Ismail, who was killed along with an aide, was suspected of being behind a recent attack on pilgrims who were visiting a religious shrine.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, India — Indian security forces said on Thursday that they had killed one of the most wanted militants in the Kashmir Valley, a man they said was responsible for a recent attack on pilgrims who were visiting a religious shrine.

headline: Israeli Orthodox Lawmaker in Trouble Over Gay Nephew’s Wedding
abstract: The lawmaker said that he had attended the wedding, prompting calls for his resignation and a debate over whether family unity trumps strict Jewish law.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli lawmaker had gone on the radio to promote a new single by his daughter, a singer, and to show a more liberal and hipper face of his party, the ultra-Orthodox Shas.

headline: Gastone Moschin Dies at 88; Played a Doomed Don in ‘Godfather Part II’
abstract: Mr. Moschin, an Italian character actor, had the role of Don Fanucci, a dapper crime boss gunned down by Vito Corleone, in Francis Ford Coppola’s “The Godfather Part II.”
lead_paragraph: Gastone Moschin, an Italian character actor remembered by American audiences as Don Fanucci, a dapper crime boss gunned down by Vito Corleone in Francis Ford Coppola’s “The Godfather Part II,” died on Sept. 4 in Terni, in central Italy. He was 88.

headline: 65 Percent of Mexicans View U.S. Negatively, Survey Finds
abstract: The result is a stark contrast to Pew’s survey of 2015, when 66 percent of Mexicans had a generally positive view of the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Favorable views of the United States have sharply declined among Mexicans, reaching the lowest point in 15 years amid deep disapproval of President Trump and his policies toward Mexico, according to a survey released on Thursday.

headline: Glamour and Virtue at Fashion Week Parties
abstract: This week’s parties included a few benefits for the poor, and a slew of hedonistic soirees for the fortunate.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week, with its complementary vodka and seating hierarachy, is a gilded island on a planet that seems to be pirouetting closer to apocalypse by the day. Perhaps as a counterbalance, this season’s slew of after-parties exhibited growing recognition from the fortunate tribe that their positions of influence could be used for a greater good.

headline: Ordering a Double (a Drink and a Song) at Tokyo Record Bar
abstract: A new spot in Greenwich Village pays homage to a type of Japanese bar, letting you choose a platter to spin.
lead_paragraph: To the experienced cocktail-bar fan, some things about the new place on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village will be familiar: the hard-to-find entrance, the cramped subterranean quarters, the need for reservations, the turntable and the collection of old vinyl.

headline: Trevor Noah Extends Comedy Central Contract Through 2022
abstract: Mr. Noah, who succeeded Jon Stewart on “The Daily Show,” will remain the host of that topical satire program and will produce annual year-end specials.
lead_paragraph: While it will be several more years before America chooses its next president, Comedy Central already knows who it wants to lead its satirical news coverage through the 2020 election season and for a couple of years beyond that.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates and the Alternatives to Despair
abstract: Two disagreements with the latest Coates blockbuster on Trump and race.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk for a moment about Ta-Nehisi Coates, who has one of his blockbuster essays in the Atlantic, on Donald Trump as the latest avatar of an enduring white supremacism. The essay is very long but I think my basic disagreement with it can be distilled by just looking at two passages. Here’s the first:

headline: Alcohol Abuse Is Rising Among Older Adults
abstract: The elderly still drink less on average than younger Americans, but the number who report problems with alcohol is increasing fast.
lead_paragraph: In the summer, Henry Wrenn-Meleck likes to sit on the stoop of his building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, observing the passing urban parade.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Will Shoot Multiple Endings to Prevent Spoilers
abstract: Casey Bloys, HBO’s programming president, said the producers will shoot several different endings of the final episode.
lead_paragraph: Plagued by leaks during its recently concluded seventh season, “Game of Thrones” is resorting to an old TV trick to preserve secrecy about next season’s series finale.

headline: How Edie Windsor Championed Gay Rights: ‘She Was Everywhere’
abstract: Into her late 80s, Ms. Windsor continued to leverage her national profile as a winning Supreme Court plaintiff to support her favorite L.G.B.T. causes.
lead_paragraph: Four days after the Supreme Court handed down its ruling in the case that bore her name, Edie Windsor crept down Fifth Avenue in a red convertible Ford Mustang while wearing a rainbow sash, one of three grand marshals in the 2013 New York gay pride parade.

headline: Review: True Crime? When the ‘Family Jewels’ Are Painted on Cars
abstract: In ‘American Vandal,’ Netflix’s meticulous spoof of the true-crime documentary, the accused is a clueless teenager and the crime obscene vehicular defacement.
lead_paragraph: Netflix’s “Making a Murderer” shares the credit, or blame — along with HBO’s “Jinx” and public radio’s “Serial” — for the current surfeit of true-crime documentary series. Now it’s the streaming service, Netflix, that is out in front again, with a true-crime mockumentary series: “American Vandal,” an eight-episode comedy (more or less) about a high school student accused of spray-painting penises on 27 teachers’ cars.

headline: ‘A Problem With No End in Sight’: Readers’ Exasperation With Equifax
abstract: After news of a security breach at Equifax, readers say they’re fed up with trying to protect their personal information and finding little success.
lead_paragraph: The hacking of Equifax’s company data, announced last week, may have compromised sensitive information, including Social Security numbers and driver’s license numbers, for 143 million American consumers.

headline: Motel 6 Workers Tipped Off Immigration Agency About Guests
abstract: Guests at the chain’s Arizona hotels were detained and deported after employees informed the government about them. Rights groups assailed the practice.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Employees at Motel 6 locations in Arizona regularly handed over to the government information that led to its hotel guests being detained and deported, the company has acknowledged.

headline: Ethics and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: A computer scientist describes his experiment with students at Georgia Tech.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Ben Stiller Is a Dad With a Bruised Ego in ‘Brad’s Status’
abstract: Mike White’s empty-nest comedy starring Ben Stiller is both cringy and kindhearted.
lead_paragraph: “Dad, are you having a nervous breakdown?” Troy asks his father, Brad. It’s a fair enough question, not least because Brad is played by Ben Stiller, a frighteningly high-strung performer even at his mellowest. Mr. Stiller, lean as a greyhound and gray around the temples, occupies the volatile middle ground between decent fellow and abrasive jerk, between adequacy and failure. He’s a regular guy perpetually threatening to turn into that guy, embarrassing the rest of us by association.

headline: On a Tiny Island in Scotland, Two Giants in the Family
abstract: A museum celebrates two giants in a Scottish family — one who lived in the 19th-century one, and one from YouTube.
lead_paragraph: ISLE OF SKYE, Scotland — A giant lives in the backyard of Peter MacAskill’s house on the Isle of Skye. It’s a nearly 8-foot-tall replica he commissioned of a 19th-century ancestor famous for his brawn, who once traveled the world performing feats of strength. The statue sits in a backyard museum Mr. MacAskill built and has run for nearly three decades.

headline: Cassini Vanishes Into Saturn, Its Mission Celebrated and Mourned
abstract: Orbiting the ringed planet since 2004, the spacecraft solved some mysteries and made discoveries that upended our notions about the solar system.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — NASA’s Cassini spacecraft, the intrepid robotic explorer of Saturn’s magnificent beauty, ended a journey of 20 years on Friday like a shooting star streaking across Saturn’s sky.

headline: The Shkreli Syndrome: Youthful Trouble, Tech Success, Then a Fall
abstract: Rule-breaking at an early age may point to the success of company founders like Martin Shkreli, researchers say. It may also foretell their undoing.
lead_paragraph: Rare is the gifted teenager who is not bored in high school. Yet few have signaled their boredom as extravagantly as Martin Shkreli, the pharmaceutical company founder who was sent to jail on Wednesday to await sentencing for a fraud conviction.

headline: My Aunt’s Getting Married and My Mom’s Not Invited
abstract: And: the boyfriend who self-soothes by playing with hair (not his own), a bird feeder drives neighbors crazy and a co-worker’s irritating singalong.
lead_paragraph: I am a 17-year-old with divorced parents. This fall, my aunt (my dad’s sister) is getting married. My brother and I have been invited to the wedding, but not my mom. Despite the divorce, my mom is still close to my dad and his family. She comes to holidays, is friendly with my aunt, and is clearly part of the family. My dad’s girlfriend, who is not close to any of us, is invited to the wedding. I think that’s wrong. Can I tell my aunt that my feelings are hurt?

headline: Michael Kors, Natasha Lyonne and Charli XCX Close Out Fashion Week Parties
abstract: Kenzo showed a new film, Michael Kors released a new smartwatch, and V magazine celebrated its music issue.
lead_paragraph: Kenzo showed a new film, Michael Kors released a new smartwatch, and V magazine celebrated its music issue.

headline: Blocking Offensive Websites
abstract: “I’m glad there are those who make decisions regarding internet content, even if I don’t like those decisions,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Nobody’ in New Jersey Is Paying Attention to Race for Governor
abstract: With the election just two months away, residents are showing little interest in who will replace the unpopular Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Democratic candidate for New Jersey governor opened his post-Labor Day blitz accusing his Republican opponent of abdicating her moral leadership. The Republican challenger retorted with accusations of race baiting.

headline: Hyperloop One Strikes Early-Stage Partnership With Colorado
abstract: Hyperloop One, one of several companies trying to develop high-speed transportation technology, will work with Colorado to study a potential route in the state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hyperloop One, an experimental transportation company that proposes to carry people at speeds of up to 700 miles per hour inside a system of tubes, announced its first partnership with a state government on Thursday.

headline: Genocide in Myanmar
abstract: A history teacher calls on the Security Council to take action.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tax Reform Moves Into the Spotlight
abstract: Readers expect that the president’s tax plan will benefit himself and other wealthy people.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Most Orlando Attractions Have Reopened After the Hurricane
abstract: Almost every Disney and Universal park is back in operation, as is Legoland Florida. Disney’s Typhoon Lagoon is expected to be open this weekend.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Irma, tourist attractions and hotels in Orlando and Savannah are once again open for business and welcoming visitors — for the most part, at least.

headline: South Koreans Worked a Democratic Miracle. Can They Do It Again?
abstract: After the “candlelight revolution,” the people push for a cleaner and fairer society.
lead_paragraph: When the South Korean military killed hundreds of pro-democracy protesters and laid siege to the southwestern city of Gwangju in May 1980, few people outside the city knew what was happening. Martial law had been declared, the already censored press was completely gagged, and all communications with Gwangju were cut off. The end of the 10-day siege marked the beginning of a seven-year period of military repression and terror under Gen. Chun Doo-hwan, who outdid his predecessor, Gen. Park Chung-hee, in brutality and corruption.

headline: What Did You Read, Watch or Listen to in The Times This Week?
abstract: Our favorite student comments from last week, and an invitation to join the conversation this week.
lead_paragraph: What got your attention in The Times this week?

headline: Purge of Doctors Without Borders Was a Permit Issue, Pakistan Says
abstract: The government explanation for the expulsion order came a day after Doctors Without Borders said it had been given a week to leave the Kurram region.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The Interior Ministry confirmed on Thursday that it had ordered Doctors Without Borders to leave Pakistan’s impoverished Kurram tribal region, saying the medical charity’s permit to work there expired two years ago.

headline: Our Favorite Photos From New York Fashion Week
abstract: A collection from more than 25 shows we covered this season.
lead_paragraph: A collection from more than 25 shows we covered this season.

headline: Clown Hysteria Grips Australian Media After Group Vows to Descend on Suburbs
abstract: A Facebook group said little beyond that clowns planned to appear late at night, but news coverage breathlessly described the group as “a chilling threat”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — “We’re coming back for you,” a post on Facebook warned. The purported threat? To send in the clowns.

headline: Hal Tulchin, Who Documented a ‘Black Woodstock,’ Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Tulchin shot an estimated 40 hours of footage of a landmark Harlem event in 1969, most of which the public has never seen.
lead_paragraph: In August 1969, Nina Simone took the stage at Mount Morris Park in Harlem for a remarkable performance in which she sang “To Be Young, Gifted and Black” and recited a poem that asked, provocatively, if her audience was ready to “kill if necessary,” “smash white things” and “give yourself, your love, your soul, your heart, to create life.”

headline: Floating Tar, Dead Fish: Oil Spill Threatens Greek Beaches
abstract: The Agia Zoni II tanker sank on Sunday while anchored off Salamis Island, near Greece’s main port of Piraeus.
lead_paragraph: The Greek authorities scrambled on Thursday to clean up fuel leaked by an oil tanker that sank near Athens, putting popular beaches off limits to swimmers and raising fears of environmental damage.

headline: Maurice Bluestein, Who Modernized the Wind Chill Index, Dies at 76
abstract: While shoveling his daughter’s driveway one winter day, Dr. Bluestein, a scientist, realized something: The wind chill index was wrong.
lead_paragraph: On frigid winter mornings, when weather forecasters are trying to describe whether it’s a hat-scarf-gloves day or if just a warm coat will do, they will take the temperature (T) and wind speed (V) and plug the numbers into a handy equation: WCT = 35.74 + 0.6215T – 35.75V0.16 + 0.4275TV0.16.

headline: Police Release Body Camera Footage of Shooting Death in Bronx
abstract: The shooting of Miguel Richards on Sept. 6 was the first fatal police shooting captured by the video recording devices worn by officers in New York.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department, which has lagged behind many big-city departments in adopting body cameras, released footage on Thursday from the first fatal shooting involving New York City police officers who were wearing the devices.

headline: I’m Indian. Can I Write Black Characters?
abstract: I might define myself as an American writer, but to others I will always be an Indian-American writer.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, it seems incredible I didn’t anticipate the questions.

headline: Welcoming Refugees Should Be a Settled Question
abstract: To slam the door in the face of those fleeing persecution would be an act of self-harm for America.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans, and the American government itself, have expressed shock at the treatment of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar. The Trump administration has also said it is concerned about persecuted religious minorities in the Middle East. For his part, the president has said he wants to defend the rights of the Castro regime’s opponents in Cuba.

abstract: President Trump’s dressing down of his attorney general at a meeting in May was the beginning of a tumultuous summer for the two men.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after learning in May that a special counsel had been appointed to investigate links between his campaign associates and Russia, President Trump berated Attorney General Jeff Sessions in an Oval Office meeting and said he should resign, according to current and former administration officials and others briefed on the matter.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Forty-one years ago, Antonio Inoki, one of Japan’s most popular professional wrestlers, faced off against Muhammad Ali in a bout that critics called a farcical publicity stunt.

headline: T’s 25 Best Photos of New York Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from Tom Ford, Calvin Klein and more — on (and off) the runway.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week came to a close with the Marc Jacobs show on Wednesday evening. To cover the week, T’s photographers fanned out across the city to capture Opening Ceremony’s dance performance, Solange Knowles’s concert at Maryam Nassir Zadeh, Tom Ford’s final bow — and much more.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Gorbachev was one of the most influential leaders of the 20th century, and William Taubman’s new biography of him is essential reading for the 21st, as we trace the arc from the fall of the Soviet Union to the rise of Putin’s Russia. Kurt Andersen digs up the roots of alternative facts in American culture (hint: it starts with the Pilgrims) in “Fantasyland”; and Ben Blum investigates a cousin’s inexplicable crime in “Ranger Games.” In fiction, new works by the acclaimed novelists Jesmyn Ward and Claire Messud encompass themes of childhood and loss. And Margaret Wilkerson Sexton makes a luminous debut with her novel set in New Orleans, “A Kind of Freedom.”

headline: Highflying Mnuchins Take the Country for a Ride
abstract: The Treasury secretary and his new wife are accused of abusing government perks to support a lofty lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: Public servants are supposed to serve the public, not themselves. What part of that equation does Steven Mnuchin not understand?

headline: New Product Is First to Claim It May Reduce Peanut Allergies
abstract: The label of a new powdered peanut product is the first to be allowed to claim it may reduce peanut allergies in susceptible infants.
lead_paragraph: A new powdered peanut product is the first food item allowed to claim it may reduce peanut allergies in infants, though parents of susceptible babies are urged to consult a doctor before trying it. The product, called Hello, Peanut, can be mixed into puréed baby food to expose infants to peanuts starting around five months old.

headline: Still Processing: Lessons in Loss and Power from Venus Williams and Rihanna
abstract: We watch the scene at the rollout of the singer’s new cosmetics line, Fenty Beauty, and observe Williams’s extreme grace on the tennis court.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we witnessed two extraordinary events: Venus Williams’s playing some of the best tennis in the last decade of her career (she lost in the semifinals at the U.S. Open, but with style), and the rollout of Rihanna’s new line of cosmetics, Fenty Beauty, which was splashier than the release of the new iPhone X. We learned something unexpected from each. Venus showed us what it means to lose and yet somehow remain undefeated, and the Rhianna event gave us insight into the economy of social media “influencers” who are radically changing — and possibly democratizing — the beauty and fashion industries.

lead_paragraph: As leading Democrats embrace Senator Bernie Sanders’s proposal to vastly expand Medicare to cover all Americans, Republicans are fighting back with familiar critiques of such a single-payer system.

headline: With ‘Diller Island’ Dead, Park Faces Difficult Future
abstract: With the collapse of a deal to create a $250 million performance pier in the Hudson, officials at Hudson River Park face “a big hole” in their plans.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt decision by the billionaire Barry Diller to withdraw funding from the high-priced performing arts pier in Hudson River Park rippled through the worlds of philanthropy, parks and environmental advocacy on Thursday.
