headline: Don’t Shun Conservative Professors
abstract: Welcoming the stranger is one of the great moral traditions liberals have.
lead_paragraph: These days, the news is full of sensational stories of violent campus mobs shutting down conservative speakers and freaked-out college administrators treating rioters with kid gloves. Such stories offer excellent fodder for critics who are eager to condemn university culture. But I believe they distract from a deeper, subtler intellectual problem on the modern campus: the profound alienation of professors who don’t hold the mainstream political views and are treated as outsiders as a result.

headline: A Hypocritical Battle Over Blue Slips
abstract: The Senate practice on judicial nominees has long outlived its usefulness, but Republicans are only now objecting.
lead_paragraph: Now that Republicans control both the White House and Congress, top party officials, including Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, are itching to eliminate the last remaining tool the minority party has to influence a president’s picks for the federal courts — the so-called blue slip.

headline: In Our Prison on the Sea
abstract: Remembering the early years at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: After the plane landed, a bus took us to a ferry, and beneath it we felt the sea. We were tired, hungry, in pain, and in fear about it all. We were gagged, blindfolded and shackled. We were dragged from the ferry to our cages. When we arrived at our cages, we whispered to one another, “There is a sea around.” We could feel it despite all of the pain, confusion and fear. All we were waiting for at the beginning was the sea.

headline: When History’s Losers Write the Story
abstract: Supporters of Confederate memorials airbrush slavery out of the Civil War. It reminds me of the Russians who view Stalin fondly.
lead_paragraph: I visited a summer camp in western Russia in July 2015. Its theme was “military patriotism,” and it involved dozens of teenagers lounging around in tents, wrestling, carving wood and making garlands. They were also taking history classes. Joseph Stalin, the Soviet leader who killed millions of Soviet citizens, was remembered fondly.

headline: How Trump Can Harness the U.S. Energy Boom
abstract: He has an opportunity to expand the country’s domestic economy and global leadership.
lead_paragraph: The new energy abundance in the United States has given President Trump a historic opportunity not just to expand the country’s economy at home, but also to expand its leadership globally. To maximize this opportunity, he should think about energy as more than a driver of economic growth, overcome the powerful political forces favoring isolationism and retrenchment, and rein in his tendency to alienate countries that should be energy allies of the United States.

headline: The Economy Isn’t Broken
abstract: For the last couple years, the market has worked more or less as it’s supposed to.
lead_paragraph: Middle-class wage stagnation is the biggest economic fact driving American politics. Over the past many years, so the common argument goes, capitalism has developed structural flaws. Economic gains are not being shared fairly with the middle class. Wages have become decoupled from productivity. Even when the economy grows, everything goes to the rich.

headline: Politicians, Promises, and Getting Real
abstract: How much does clarity about policy matter?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday Donald Trump demanded that Congress move quickly to enact his tax reform plan. But so far he has not, in fact, offered any such plan. Not only is there no detailed legislative proposal, his administration hasn’t even settled on the basic outlines of what it wants.

headline: What Do American Values Mean to You?
abstract: What democratic values define Americans?
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to be an American?

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘From Prison to Ph.D.: The Redemption and Rejection of Michelle Jones’
abstract: What do you learn about Ms. Jones’s crime and her academic work while in prison?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Google and Facebook Face Criticism for Ads Targeting Racist Sentiments
abstract: Both companies said they would change how their ad systems worked in response to two separate news reports exposing the issues.
lead_paragraph: Google and Facebook, the world’s biggest sellers of online advertising, faced sharp criticism on Friday for allowing advertisers to direct ads to users who searched for or expressed an interest in racist sentiments and hate speech.

headline: ‘Bucket Bomb’ Strikes London’s Vulnerable Underground
abstract: The blast on a subway train caused panic and disrupted services; 29 people were injured. The city has suffered multiple terrorist attacks this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Alex Ojeda-Sierra, 13, was on the train to school with a friend when they heard screaming and saw passengers running past.

headline: North Korea’s Threat Pushes Japan to Reassess Its Might and Rights
abstract: The limits of missile defense and a pacifist Constitution are weighing on the debate over how Japan should respond to the North’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When North Korea launched a missile that flew over Japan on Friday morning, prompting the authorities to broadcast an alert on cellphones and television, many people wondered: Why didn’t the Japanese military shoot it down?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to the value of higher education, a conversation among spies and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Salman Rushdie on importance of “global dialogue.”
lead_paragraph: This week features a review of Salman Rushdie’s new novel, “The Golden House.” In 2005, Rushdie, then president of PEN America, wrote a powerful essay stressing the importance of “global dialogue” when the world seemed the most isolated. Below is an excerpt:

headline: How to Pull Down a Statue
abstract: Keep area clear of bystanders. In rare cases, use Sawzall or arc welder to sever the figure’s feet.
lead_paragraph: “It is quite easy” to topple a statue, says Hanna Bondar, the former deputy chief architect for the city of Kiev. Don’t be intimidated by what seem to be unbreakable materials — stone, concrete, bronze can all be brought down. By 1991, when the Soviet state collapsed, some 5,500 statues of the Communist leader Vladimir Lenin had been erected in Ukraine, the highest density anywhere in the U.S.S.R. In December 2013, a mob of anti-Kremlin protesters knocked over a hulking red quartzite Lenin on one of Kiev’s main squares, setting off a wave of removals that came to be known as “Leninfall.” At its peak, in February 2014, 376 Lenins were felled in a single month.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘Lower Ed,’ by Tressie McMillan Cottom
abstract: Three words confront a particularly stubborn American delusion.
lead_paragraph: “Lower Ed” is a dense little wonder. What seems like it might be a narrow academic study — a sociological analysis of for-profit colleges — turns out to be about the whole agitated essence of America: our markets, inequalities, prejudices, blind spots and guiding mythologies.

headline: The 9.3.17 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: LOBBYISTS

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Coerced Bedtime Stories
abstract: Can fiction be ordered on demand?
lead_paragraph: Morgann writes: I bring a case against my husband, Ben, who is an incredibly talented short-fiction writer. I struggle with falling asleep, especially after a stressful workday. I often ask Ben to tell me a short story to help me get sleepy. Ben absolutely refuses. He uses precious wind-down time arguing with me instead of just telling me a silly little story.

headline: Behind the Cover: 9.17.17
abstract: For this issue, a look inside the information war waged by Russia’s media network.
lead_paragraph: Gail Bichler, design director: “This week’s cover plays with the idea of disruption with an image of a TV news anchor ripped back to reveal a hidden message. The impression that things are not as they appear on the surface speaks to the Russian government’s attempts to manipulate the media by spreading destabilizing propaganda in the countries they target.”

headline: Poem: Remaking the Music Box
abstract: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Terrance Hayes

headline: Fiery Collections of Essays From Young Feminist Writers
abstract: Three explorations of culture as it affects what it means to be a woman.
lead_paragraph: YOU PLAY THE GIRL On Playboy Bunnies, Stepford Wives, Train Wrecks, and Other Mixed Messages By Carina Chocano 275 pp. Mariner, paper, $16.95.

headline: A Writer Visits Latvia in Search of Her Roots
abstract: In her memoir “Among the Living and the Dead,” Inara Verzemnieks learns what happened to her family in World War II.
lead_paragraph: AMONG THE LIVING AND THE DEADA Tale of Exile and Homecoming on the War Roads of EuropeBy Inara Verzemnieks282 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Why the Skier Mikaela Shiffrin Loves Croatia — and Colorado
abstract: She trains in New Zealand and Chile, races in Europe and will compete in the Olympics. To fight fatigue, she naps, jogs and snacks on dried mangoes.
lead_paragraph: When Mikaela Shiffrin won the women’s World Cup overall title in March, she was the first American to conquer skiing’s most coveted title since 2012 — coincidentally, the year she won her first World Cup event at the ripe age of 17.

headline: New in Memoir: Looking for Fulfilling Work in the Gig Economy
abstract: Books on the golden age of journalism, the brave new world of internet pornography and driving for Uber.
lead_paragraph: Personal stories tend to be thought of as inextricably linked to home, but I’ve always believed some of the best material comes from the workplace. Whereas blood relations tend to share a certain monochromatic tint, professional ties can be kaleidoscopic in their randomness, not to mention intensely Machiavellian and therefore inherently dramatic. For all the comforts and familiarities of the household, it’s the job site, the place where our skills are honed and our labors converted to currency, that truly defines not just our proficiencies but our element.

headline: A Mystic Hero in Search of a ‘Beast’
abstract: The second installment of Paul Kingsnorth’s trilogy, which began with “The Wake,” follows one man’s quest for a creature and a purpose.
lead_paragraph: BEAST By Paul Kingsnorth 184 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.

headline: In Salman Rushdie’s New Novel, the Backdrop Is the Obama Years
abstract: “The Golden House” tells the story of a billionaire patriarch and his enigmatic family after they arrive in New York.
lead_paragraph: THE GOLDEN HOUSEBy Salman Rushdie380 pp. Random House. $28.99.

headline: Alice Waters’s Grilled Cheese Is Not Like Yours and Mine
abstract: In her best-selling new memoir, “Coming to My Senses,” the chef recommends a French mountain cheese and homemade sauerkraut for a childhood staple.
lead_paragraph: LUNCH MENU: The chef and restaurateur Alice Waters’s new memoir, “Coming to My Senses,” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 13, and for all of its frank talk about free love and hard drinking, its most scandalous revelation may be that when Waters was in grade school in suburban New Jersey, she used to trade her peanut butter-and-banana sandwiches for bologna and cheese on white bread. Alice Waters? The owner of Chez Panisse and generalissimo of the organic food revolution? Back then, she happily admits, her favorite lunch was grilled cheese with pickles and maybe an orange soda, if she could sneak out to a local dinette. “I think of grilled cheese sandwiches as one of the great comfort foods,” she writes, before snapping out of it to become the Waters we all recognize: “These days I make them with a Cantal, a mountain cheese from France that’s a little like a Swiss — I like my cheese to be a bit tangy. I usually choose some good whole wheat or levain bread from Acme Bread Company. I slice the cheese and put it inside the bread, put some olive oil in a cast iron pan — not too much! — drizzle oil on the top of the sandwich, and then weight it down with another cast iron pan. When it gets really brown, I turn it over, and when the cheese starts to bubble out the sides, I take it out. Then I rub both sides with half a clove of garlic and serve it with a dill pickle or some sauerkraut (good homemade sauerkraut, not the kraut out of the can that I never liked as a child!). Or I’ll have a little undressed salad on the side — the melted cheese and the olive oil from the sandwich almost dress the lettuce. Sometimes in the summer I’ll put some hot peppers in.” All right, that does sound pretty good. But it’s probably for the best that Chez Panisse never established a children’s menu. I’d hate to see what Waters does to chicken fingers.

headline: A Booming Church and Its Complicated, Ugly Past
abstract: Zarephath Christian Church is a dynamic evangelical congregation. But perhaps it’s best not to mention the sect’s fiery founder who embraced the K.K.K.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people each weekend drive up the hill to a newly built $12 million church surrounded by soccer fields in a New Jersey community named Zarephath. They worship by singing along with rock-ballad style prayer songs, following lyrics projected on three overhead screens. They sway and lift their arms high overhead, or say the words quietly with their eyes closed.

headline: He Puts Bill Maher on TV, and Jefferson, Dickens and Tolstoy on Stage
abstract: Scott Carter, a longtime late-night producer, talks about the creative and spiritual journey that led him from the profane to the sacred.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Jefferson, Charles Dickens and Leo Tolstoy were bickering again.

headline: A 19th-Century Smuggler in the Peruvian Andes
abstract: Natasha Pulley’s rambunctious historical novel “The Bedlam Stacks” sends a British adventurer on a magic realist mission to South America.
lead_paragraph: THE BEDLAM STACKS By Natasha Pulley 337 pp. Bloomsbury. $26

headline: A Dip in the Living Room Pool
abstract: In a slowing luxury real estate market, developers are investing in amenities to attract buyers. Explore Soori High Line, where more than half of the units come with private, saltwater pools.
lead_paragraph: In a slowing luxury real estate market, developers are investing in amenities to attract buyers. Explore Soori High Line, where more than half of the units come with private, saltwater pools.

headline: C.I.A. Wants Authority to Conduct Drone Strikes in Afghanistan for the First Time
abstract: The C.I.A. is pushing for expanded powers to carry out its own drone strikes, and the White House is said to favor the proposal despite Pentagon objections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. is pushing for expanded powers to carry out covert drone strikes in Afghanistan and other active war zones, a proposal that the White House appears to favor despite the misgivings of some at the Pentagon, according to current and former intelligence and military officials.

headline: Five Places to Go in Ojai, Calif.
abstract: A hipster haven in the mountains near Los Angeles, Ojai is drawing fashion types and foodies with new shops, restaurants and cool places to hang out.
lead_paragraph: Spend some time in Ojai and locals will let you in on their motto: “Keep Ojai lame.” It’s a tongue-in-cheek resistance to the increasing tourist traffic in this small, verdant city, 80 miles northwest of Los Angeles. Long a haven for yogis, spa-goers and anyone with vaguely spiritual inclinations — the Ojai Valley runs east-west rather than north-south, which some say creates an “electromagnetic vortex” of good energy — the city is also drawing fashion types and foodies with new shops, restaurants and cool places to hang out. Many popular spots are located along or just off Ojai Avenue, the main drag that is easily traversable by foot or bike.

headline: Readers Weighed in on the Best Books About the Vietnam War
abstract: The Times Book Review put together a list of essential reading, but suggestions kept coming in.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: After we posted this article, Times readers weighed in with their favorite books on the Vietnam War. These 10 books, in addition to the ones below, were recommended multiple times. For fiction: ‘Matterhorn: A Novel of the Vietnam War,’ by Karl Marlantes; ‘The Sympathizer,’ by Viet Thanh Nguyen; ‘The 13th Valley,’ by John M. Del Vecchio; ‘The Short-Timers,’ by Gustav Hasford; and ‘The Ugly American,’ by Eugene Burdick and William Lederer. Fon nonfiction: ‘Chickenhawk,’ by Robert Mason; ‘Kill Anything That Moves: The Real American War in Vietnam,’ by Nick Turse; ‘The Killing Zone: My Life in the Vietnam War,’ by Frederick Downs; ‘Pharoah’s Army: Memories of the Lost War” by Tobias Wolf; and ‘Street Without Joy: Indochina at War, 1946–1954,’ by Bernard Fall.

headline: Gender-Fluid Artists Come Out of the Gray Zone
abstract: “Trigger” at the New Museum brings a new level of visibility to artists who have only been acknowledged before in a trickle of mainstream shows.
lead_paragraph: In the window of the New Museum this month, the performance artist Justin Vivian Bond plans to periodically strike a pose in a pink gown with rhinestone teardrop, framed by hand-drawn wallpaper twinning the artist’s face with that of the former Estée Lauder model Karen Graham. As a closeted transgender teenager in the 1970s, Bond obsessively drew Ms. Graham, until “I made myself my canvas.” The artist is wearing a vintage dress by Frank Masandrea, one of several little-known couturiers who outfitted Ms. Graham before AIDS cut them down in their creative prime.

headline: Jordan Klepper Wants to Be a Colbert for the Breitbart Era
abstract: A former correspondent for “The Daily Show” plays an incendiary fringe pundit on his new Comedy Central series, “The Opposition w/ Jordan Klepper.”
lead_paragraph: This was a crucial opportunity for Jordan Klepper to figure out who Jordan Klepper is.

headline: Now Starting for the Jets: The Marvin Ridge High School Quarterbacks Coach
abstract: Josh McCown had many stops along the way to starting for the Jets. One of them was a two-season stint teaching the game to teenagers.
lead_paragraph: During football season a few years back, Scott Chadwick, a high school coach in North Carolina, had a Sunday night ritual as practical as it was peculiar. Every week, he would scan the list of N.F.L. players injured that day, hoping that no quarterbacks were seriously hurt.

headline: In Amish Country, the Future Is Calling
abstract: Some members of the famously tech-shunning sect have begun to incorporate cellphones and computers into their lives, raising unique questions about the balance between work and home.
lead_paragraph: A young woman, wearing a traditional full-length Amish dress and white bonnet, stepped away from a farmer’s market, opened her palm and revealed a smartphone. She began to scroll through screens, seemingly oblivious to the activity around her.

headline: The Next Wave of New York Condos
abstract: A look at new luxury condo buildings rising in New York City
lead_paragraph: A look at new luxury condo buildings rising in New York City

headline: New Development: Soft in the Middle, Splashy Up Top
abstract: The luxury market in New York is pulling in two directions, with developers betting on big-ticket palatial aeries and million-dollar “starter” homes.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Soo K. Chan, an architect well known in Singapore but new to the Manhattan luxury condo scene, posed a question to jaded New Yorkers: How about a pool in the living room?

headline: Seth Meyers Can’t Keep Track of Trump’s DACA Deal Making
abstract: Mr. Meyers said, “The last time somebody changed positions that much on Twitter, Ted Cruz liked it.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Teaching With: ‘Girl Boxer’
abstract: In this short documentary, we meet Jesselyn Silva, known as “JessZilla,” a 10-year-old girl who loves to box. She dreams of someday winning an Olympic gold medal.
lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, we meet Jesselyn Silva, known as “JessZilla,” a 10-year-old girl who loves to box. She dreams of someday winning an Olympic gold medal.

headline: The Minuscule Importance of Manufacturing in Far-Right Politics
abstract: In both the United States and Europe, far-right voters are far more likely to express concerns about immigration and race than trade.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s electoral victory, Brexit and the growing prominence of anti-trade and anti-immigration far-right political parties in Europe appear closely linked in timing and motivation. Some have interpreted this to mean that Trump voters and supporters of far-right parties in Europe must be the losers of globalization in jobs like manufacturing.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Trump and the Democrats
abstract: We discuss the president’s latest surprising alliance with Democrats, and call Senator Bernie Sanders to get his take on this moment.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: North Korea, Parsons Green, Cassini: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Childless in a Houseful of Children
abstract: I alone among eight siblings have decided not to breed – a choice that baffles everyone in a family as fertile as mine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I sit on the bottom stair of my mother’s house, my plate of rice balanced gently on one knee, as chaos unfolds around me. Madiha is crying after a thwarted nap, Arif is whizzing up the stairs with Zayn not far behind, Mizan is whimpering for the iPad, and Sara needs a nappy change.

headline: New York Today: An Art Show Made of MetroCards
abstract: Friday: An exhibition of everyday objects, your weekend lineup, and the Oscars of food trucks.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:02 a.m.

headline: Two Pastors in Love, and Only God Knows
abstract: Twanna Gause and Vanessa Brown, who met as choir girls nearly 30 years ago, were wed, much to the displeasure of Ms. Gause’s father, also a minister.
lead_paragraph: Pastor Twanna Gause stepped out of a limousine amid the whir of cameras outside the New Vision Full Gospel Baptist Church in East Orange, N.J.

headline: Morning Agenda: Where’s the Next Big Deal for Fancy Coffee?
abstract: Nestlé’s deal for a majority stake in Blue Bottle Coffee is in part an effort to reach coffee-loving millennials. Other food giants may be hunting similar targets.
lead_paragraph: Nestlé built its coffee kingdom on Nescafé and Nespresso pods. But the Swiss food giant is aiming higher with its newest deal: buying a majority stake in Blue Bottle Coffee, part of the vanguard of so-called third wave coffee. (Disclaimer: one of us drank a lot of Blue Bottle when living in San Francisco.)

headline: At Risk in Rohingya Exodus: 230,000 Children, Hundreds All Alone
abstract: More than half of the 400,000 refugees who have fled Myanmar for Bangladesh since late August are children, and hundreds came without parents, Unicef said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than half of the Rohingya refugees who have fled Myanmar in the past three weeks are children, including hundreds who traveled without family members, putting them at particular risk in cramped, muddy camps in Bangladesh, aid workers say.

headline: Kenneth Ziegler of Logicworks on Embracing Dysfunction
abstract: The chief executive of a cloud-management company says that as long as people don’t think they’re more important than the team, he can work them.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Kenneth Ziegler, chief executive of Logicworks, which provides cloud-management services, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: After Irma: Caribbean Tourism, Island by Island
abstract: Some places emerged from the hurricane unscathed. Others are in ruins. A look at the damage, bright spots and uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most idyllic — and tourism-dependent — destinations in the Caribbean have been crippled in the wake of one of the most powerful Atlantic basin storms ever recorded.

headline: How to Plan for a Major Career Change
abstract: Sometimes deciding to quit is the easy part. But then what?
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: California Today: Price Tag to Protect Speech at Berkeley: $600,000
abstract: Friday: Ben Shapiro comes to Berkeley, a flurry of bills in Sacramento, and California’s cornucopia of food festivals.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: G.M. Chief, in China, Challenges Planned Bans of Gasoline Cars
abstract: As the country joins others taking aim at combustion engines, Mary Barra of G.M. said customers, not government rules, should choose car technologies.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Cars should run on gasoline for a little while longer.

headline: Tough Guys and Gals on Film
abstract: A series at Film Forum pays tribute to gangster movies from the 1930s and ’40s, including “Little Caesar” and “High Sierra.”
lead_paragraph: Sure, Warner Bros. broke the sound barrier with “The Jazz Singer,” but in the early years of talkies it carved out its true turf as the home of gangster films. Film Forum’s “Tough Guys, Tough Dames … Tough Pictures” series, starting Friday, Sept. 22, includes 27 movies from the 1930s and ’40s; David Thomson, author of  a new history of the studio, introduces several screenings.

headline: With New Leadership, New York Philharmonic Warms to Philip Glass
abstract: Jaap van Zweden, the next music director, opens the season with contemporary music and Mahler.
lead_paragraph: His official title is still Music Director Designate, but for the musicians of the New York Philharmonic he’s the new boss: Jaap van Zweden, the Dutch conductor who will take over the reins of the city’s most storied ensemble, tests the waters with a pair of concerts comprising Mahler and Philip Glass. Critics who fretted over his lackadaisical embrace of contemporary music may be heartened to see Mr. van Zweden start the new season with a New York premiere of the Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra by Mr. Glass, who has long been cold-shouldered by the Philharmonic.

headline: Wizkid, a Budding Star, Takes Afrobeats Worldwide
abstract: The Nigerian singer, known for his songs with Drake, will perform in New York.
lead_paragraph: On his third album, “Sounds From the Other Side,” released in July, the Nigerian singer Wizkid finally took a leap, years in the making, toward crossover success. As one of the best-known figures in the West African Afrobeats scene, which has been mined for the current wave of so-called tropical pop (Drake’s “One Dance,” featuring none other than Wizkid), the singer signed with RCA Records and collaborated with Major Lazer and Chris Brown. Though not a smash — the gentrifiers still typically come out ahead — the album is brisk and danceable, cementing Wizkid as a lasting international pop-cultural ambassador. (8 p.m., Saturday, Sept. 23, terminal5nyc.com.)

headline: New York City Ballet Reclaims Lincoln Center to Start the Season
abstract: In “Swan Lake,” Sara Mearns takes on the dual role of Odette/Odile, and there are three other premieres this season from company members.
lead_paragraph: It’s never truly fall until New York City Ballet reclaims Lincoln Center. Before the company hosts its fashion-forward gala evening on Sept. 28 — with designers and choreographers collaborating on new works — there will be two weeks of Peter Martins’s “Swan Lake.” It’s all about the dancers, and Sara Mearns, who is scheduled to perform opening night opposite Tyler Angle, should start the run off right: Her rendition of the dual role of Odette/Odile is extraordinary. As the season continues, there will be three premieres by company members, the principal Lauren Lovette and the soloists Troy Schumacher and Justin Peck, City Ballet’s resident choreographer. There’s one wild card in the mix: Gianna Reisen, a 2017 graduate of the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, will create her first work for the company. Ms. Reisen, 18, and now an apprentice at Ballet Semperoper Dresden, is the youngest choreographer the company has ever featured. And the season bids farewell to a principal when, on Oct. 7, Rebecca Krohn takes her final bow. (Tuesday, Sept. 19, through Oct. 15 at the David H. Koch Theater; nycballet.com.)

headline: Lady Gaga and Netflix: A Documentary Goes Behind the Scenes
abstract: “Gaga: Five Foot Two” explores this pop star’s personal infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: “You have to go to that broken place of your heart to write songs,” Lady Gaga says early in “Gaga: Five Foot Two,” a documentary due Friday, Sept. 22, on Netflix. “It’s like open-heart surgery, making music. Every time it’s invasive.” The source of this particular affliction is “Joanne,” the 2016 album of soft-rock ballads that plunged her into a tailspin as she wondered if fans would accept her transformation from disco-pop provocateur into grief-driven chanteuse. The director, Chris Moukarbel, frames the story with scenes from Gaga’s February Super Bowl halftime performance, her studded boots dangling midair as she is hoisted to the stadium rafters. But it’s her cyclonic private life that fascinates as a multitude of producers, publicists, masseuses, doctors and makeup artists help manage her workday and the pain caused by a hip fracture in 2013. Still, being the woman born Stefani Germanotta can be deafening in its loneliness. “I go from everyone touching me all day, and talking at me all day,” she says, “to total silence.”

headline: A Solo Show for Adrian Piper
abstract: The conceptual artist’s bold multimedia work comes to Lévy Gorvy Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Those impatient to see Adrian Piper’s first American museum exhibition in more than 10 years at the Museum of Modern Art this spring can get a taste of the Conceptual artist’s bold philosophical work in an exhibition that opened Thursday at Lévy Gorvy Gallery.

headline: Trump’s Tweets About London Bombing Anger British Leaders
abstract: The president suggested British intelligence officials were aware of whoever was behind a terrorist attack on in the London subway.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump seized on a terrorist attack in London on Friday to promote his ban on travel to the United States by Muslims and, in the process, ran afoul of Britain by claiming without evidence that the assailants had been “in the sights” of the British police.

headline: Roald Dahl’s Widow Says ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ Hero Was Supposed to be Black
abstract: Mr. Dahl’s agent thought it would be a bad idea to have a black main character, his widow and his biographer said in an interview with the BBC.
lead_paragraph: The widow and the biographer of the beloved British children’s writer Roald Dahl told the BBC in an interview this week that Charlie Bucket, the young boy whose life is changed by a golden ticket in “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” was originally supposed to be black.

headline: Tiger Species Thought Extinct Is Possibly Spotted in Indonesia
abstract: Rangers at a national park in West Java photographed a rare big cat, leading to speculation that it was a Javan tiger, a species declared extinct 40 years ago.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Park rangers in Indonesia may have spotted an animal thought to live only in folklore and history books: a Javan tiger, declared extinct more than 40 years ago.

headline: Blasts From the Past From the Rolling Stones, D’Angelo, Neil Young and Can
abstract: Reissued, rearranged, remastered and repackaged, pieces from pop music history reappear.
lead_paragraph: ‘Their Satanic Majesties Request’

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: New iPhones and Facebook Ads
abstract: Two Times tech reporters discuss the week’s events and developments in Silicon Valley, including a certain Apple iPhone event.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Scheduling Your Smartphone for a Little Peace and Quiet
abstract: If you need a break from the constant stream of alerts, notifications and calls, check your device’s settings for a Do Not Disturb feature.
lead_paragraph: Q. I signed up for alerts from a bunch of news sites on my iPhone to keep up with the headlines, but now they’re waking me up at night with their sounds and turning on the phone screen. Is there a way to mute them before bed? I don’t want to turn off the phone because I use it as an alarm clock.

headline: The Headache of Living Next to Endless Construction
abstract: Construction scaffolding is a part of New York City’s streetscape. When it happens next door, developers sometimes pay neighbors for their trouble.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the things that have shattered the skylight of the NoHo apartment owned by Jeffrey and Suzanne Stewart: a hammer, concrete and a 50-pound slab of wood.

headline: Alice Archer Is a Name to Know at London Fashion Week
abstract: The young British embroidery maestro, who develops all her work on her computer, is moving into prints in a bid for new audiences.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There are few emerging fashion designers who can say they have dressed both Sean Combs and Pippa Middleton. But Alice Archer’s intricate digital embroidery and prints that meld technology and biology to captivating effect attract a broad range of clients.

headline: Dog Yoga and Electric Guitars: Amenities, at a New Level
abstract: To help new developments stand out from the crowd, developers are intent on introducing never-before-seen amenities. Dog yoga, anyone?
lead_paragraph: Lights dimmed. An instructor spoke Sanskrit. And a collective howl went out from a group on mats.

headline: Cassini Is Gone. Here Are the Next Space Missions to Watch Out For.
abstract: Now that Cassini has gone out in a blaze of glory, here's our guide to cosmic missions over the next decade that you should get excited about now.
lead_paragraph: Now that Cassini has gone out in a blaze of glory, you’re probably wondering what cosmic missions you can get excited about next. Though NASA is reviewing proposals that may include a return to Saturn to seek signs of life on ocean worlds like its moons Enceladus and Titan, other endeavors into deep space are already on the calendar. Here are a variety of space missions worth keeping tabs on over the next decade or so.

headline: Ranting and Rapping Online in China, and Raking In Millions
abstract: Li Tianyou is one of China’s best-known internet personalities and a hero for a generation of disaffected youth from smaller cities and rural areas.
lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — He delivers rants about unfaithful girlfriends, sky-high housing prices and spoiled young people. He films himself spinning on his head and doing push-ups at the gym. He sings about love and desperation and shouts like a military sergeant.

headline: The Timeless, Imperfect Beauty of the Handmade
abstract: From exactingly stitched American quilts to one-of-a-kind painted lights, there’s much to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: From exactingly stitched American quilts to one-of-a-kind painted lights, there’s much to celebrate.

headline: What Do Artists’ Final Works Say About Their Lives?
abstract: Every body of work comes to an end. And judging by recent late-career achievements, the best is sometimes saved for last.
lead_paragraph: ONE OF THE CURSES of the modern age is the terminal diagnosis. We live each day knowing that we will die, but most of us find it easy enough, and more than congenial, to forget about it. To be told that you have two years or one year or six months left is to be excused from a paradise of ignorance into rude knowledge. And yet to have this appointment in Samarra inked on your schedule is also a kind of blessing or special power. We expect that those facing death ought to live a little differently because of it. They have an opportunity, or so we think — to put things right, to make reparations and bequests and ‘‘arrangements.’’ To book a special experience, long desired but deferred. To prepare a statement. For artists, the knowledge that the end is beckoning may provoke a last surge of inspiration to begin or complete final works, works that invariably come to acquire an extra significance, no matter how flawed the works themselves.

headline: Danny McBride Is Not Who You Think He Is
abstract: Mr. McBride, a star and writer of HBO’s “Vice Principals,” talks about his foulmouthed characters, moving to the South (again) and remaking a horror classic.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, Danny McBride is not that guy — not Kenny Powers, the boorish former Major League Baseball pitcher turned substitute phys ed teacher he played for four seasons in “Eastbound & Down.” Not Neal Gamby, the nasty-tempered, aggressively striving school administrator he now plays in “Vice Principals.” Not a redneck. Not even a sitcom fan.

headline: Do I Carry a Dangerous Amount of Belly Fat?
abstract: Visceral fat, which collects around the middle, is tied to a host of serious medical problems.
lead_paragraph: Q. How can I tell if I have a dangerous amount of visceral fat? Do we understand why the body decides to store some fat as visceral fat and other as subcutaneous?

headline: Review: A Japanese Writer’s Reveries Inspire ‘Four Nights of Dream’
abstract: The opera has much to admire, but its music and plot weighs down the feather-light beauty of Natsume Soseki’s stories
lead_paragraph: A samurai, balked on his path to enlightenment, contemplates killing his spiritual adviser, or himself. A likable wastrel takes up with a beautiful woman, who offers him the choice of leaping from a precipice to his death or being licked by a pig, as ultimately happens. A father trudges a great distance, with his blind son on his back, only to discover the child is a man he murdered 100 years before. A dying woman asks a man to bury her and wait 100 years for her return — as a white lily.

headline: The Addictive Charms of South Korean Drama
abstract: Three streaming services — DramaFever, Kocowa and Viki — bring romance, action, variety (but mostly romance!) from South Korea to American viewers.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, we mostly get our foreign films through a filter: the filter of art. The movies of Philippe Garrel, for instance, are far outside the mainstream of contemporary French cinema, but festivals and the efforts of boutique distributors are likely to make you more conscious of his (very excellent) oeuvre than you will be about the “Astérix and Obélix” movies many French families eat up.

headline: A Starburst Is Born: Watch the Building of the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: The operatic-scale drama of the Met’s 1966 move to Lincoln Center is explored in “The Opera House,” a new documentary.
lead_paragraph: There was no shortage of operatic-scale drama in the building of the Metropolitan Opera House, which celebrated its 50th anniversary last season.

headline: What I Love | Moisés Kaufman
abstract: When you’re a playwright and director who shares an apartment with a husband and collaborator, it isn’t always easy to draw a line between work and home.
lead_paragraph: When you’re a playwright and director who shares an apartment with a husband and collaborator, it isn’t always easy to draw a line between work and home.

headline: Moisés Kaufman on Marrying Art and Life
abstract: For a playwright and director, sharing an apartment with a husband who’s also a collaborator can get a little messy.
lead_paragraph: The playwright and director Moisés Kaufman lives with his husband, Jeffrey LaHoste, in what Mr. LaHoste puckishly calls the smoked fish belt. Murray’s Sturgeon Shop, Barney Greengrass and Zabar’s are all just a cherry stone’s throw away from the rental the men have shared since 1989, soon after meeting in a political theater class at New York University.

headline: Canelo Álvarez vs. Gennady Golovkin: How to Watch, Odds and Predictions
abstract: Two of the world’s top fighters enter the ring Saturday night. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The way boxing works these days, it’s all too easy for top fighters to pick and choose their spots, ducking the top competition to keep their titles and records.

headline: A Prison Sentence Ends. But the Stigma Doesn’t.
abstract: Harvard’s rejection of Michelle Jones, a former convict, reveals the lie we are telling ourselves about the possibility of redemption.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Jones served 20 years in prison for a heinous crime: murdering her 4-year-old son. During her two decades behind bars, Ms. Jones compiled a record of accomplishment that would be remarkable even for someone who had never been locked up. She published a scholarly article on the first prisons for women in the United States. She wrote a play that will open in December in an Indianapolis theater. She led a team of incarcerated women whose efforts won the Indiana Historical Society’s prize for best research project for 2016. Not best research project by prisoners. Best project. Period.

headline: The Suburb of the Future, Almost Here
abstract: Millennials want a different kind of suburban development that is smart, efficient and sustainable.
lead_paragraph: The suburbanization of America marches on. That movement includes millennials, who, as it turns out, are not a monolithic generation of suburb-hating city dwellers.

headline: William Howard Taft Is Still Stuck in the Tub
abstract: Our heaviest president, born this day in 1857, loved the bath. But it didn’t take six men to wrest his body from it.
lead_paragraph: It took six of the strongest men on White House grounds, the story goes, to wrest William Howard Taft’s substantial body out of the bathtub. Taft was born on this day in 1857, and that humiliating story is often the only thing people remember him for — a real shame, considering his unique position in American political history. As the 27th president and the 10th chief justice of the United States, Taft is the only person to have served in the highest office of both the executive and judicial branches.

headline: Nat Wolff, a Movie Star on the Rise, Likes a Uniform
abstract: “I’m trying to be a ring guy,” says the actor known for his role in “The Fault in Our Stars.”
lead_paragraph: The actor and musician Nat Wolff, 22, has been performing since the age of 7. Perhaps best known as the leading man in “Paper Towns,” this month he is featured in the romantic comedy “Home Again.” Though he was born in Los Angeles, Mr. Wolff remains sartorially faithful to New York City, where he grew up, favoring the style of the Strokes and the young Al Pacino. Here, he shares five favorites from his closet.

headline: Former St. Louis Officer, Jason Stockley, Acquitted in Shooting of Black Driver
abstract: Protesters began marching downtown, calling the verdict flawed. Aiming to avoid violent protests, the governor placed the National Guard on standby.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — A white former police officer who fatally shot a 24-year-old black man here after a high-speed chase in 2011 was acquitted of first-degree murder on Friday, rekindling protests in a region that has been at the center of the country’s debate over police treatment of African-Americans.

headline: In London Terror Attack, Witnesses Describe ‘Big Bang’
abstract: Britain was hit by a terrorist attack on a Friday morning in September 2017, when a crude device exploded on a crowded London Underground train. Passengers described seeing a wall of fire.
lead_paragraph: Britain was hit by a terrorist attack on a Friday morning in September 2017, when a crude device exploded on a crowded London Underground train. Passengers described seeing a wall of fire.

headline: SoFi Board Says C.E.O. Is Out Immediately Amid Sexual Harassment Scandal
abstract: Mike Cagney, the company’s chief executive, had said earlier this week that he would step down at year’s end.
lead_paragraph: Social Finance, a privately held online lender and technology start-up, said on Friday that Mike Cagney would step down immediately as chief executive, accelerating a departure announced this week amid a sexual harassment scandal.

headline: Readers React: Redemption, Then Rejection From Harvard
abstract: Times readers debated Harvard’s decision to withdraw an offer to a woman who had been imprisoned for the murder of her young son.
lead_paragraph: Many Times readers debated Harvard University’s decision to rescind its acceptance of Michelle Jones, who was recently released from prison, as a Ph.D. student.

headline: How New Yorkers Sank a Floating Park
abstract: Plans for a park and arts space on the West Side were squashed by a few vocal critics, a sign of how hard it is to get anything done in this city.
lead_paragraph: Diller Island just became Shuttered Island, and that’s a shame.

headline: After the Storm
abstract: ... came the superstorms.
lead_paragraph: ... came the superstorms.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: If you’re celebrating, build a menu for the High Holy Days. For those not observing, New Mexican posole, braised sauerkraut and more await.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: What’s New on Netflix, HBO and Amazon Prime This Weekend
abstract: Here’s our pick of the titles joining streaming services this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: Gallery of Horrors
abstract: “Paperbacks from Hell” collects hundreds of memorable horror-fiction cover designs.
lead_paragraph: Grady Hendrix’s “Paperbacks From Hell” beautifully displays the cover designs for hundreds of mass-market horror novels. Some of the designs are lovely; many are so hideous that they almost bend back toward lovely.

headline: A Police Bombing, Homes on Fire and an Opera That Grapples With It All
abstract: “We Shall Not Be Moved,” directed by Bill T. Jones, reflects on the deadly 1985 attack in Philadelphia on the members of the black radical group, Move.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The scars are still there.

headline: The Cubs Badly Needed Some Wins. Enter the Mets.
abstract: For those keeping score, it was Cubs 8, Mets 3; Cubs 17, Mets 5; and, in the finale, Cubs 14, Mets 6.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, the Chicago Cubs lost three straight games at home to the Milwaukee Brewers and scored all of three runs in the process.

headline: Veterans Report More Credit Issues Than Other Consumers, Study Finds
abstract: Yet veterans have good savings habits. They may employ “mental accounting,” a researcher said, leading them to see saving as separate from bill paying.
lead_paragraph: Military veterans are more likely than other consumers to report problems managing credit, to owe more on their mortgages than their houses are worth and to have made a late mortgage payment, a new study of veterans’ finances finds.

headline: Canned Are Grand, but Fresh Sardines Are Deliciously Simple
abstract: These small fish are healthy, sustainable and easy to grill at home, whether over hot coals or under the broiler.
lead_paragraph: Consider the sardine. The name alone evokes a crowded subway car (“packed in like sardines”) or Saltine crackers — or, if you’re me, a lip-smacking treat.

headline: During London Fashion Week, the Names You Need to Know
abstract: From Edward Enninful to Charles Jeffrey, Theo Adams to Adwoa Aboah, here are the characters shaking up the fashion scene in Britain
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A changing of the guard in some of London’s most high-profile industry power houses has shuffled the hierarchy. Here is a who’s who of 2017’s movers and shakers — and why they matter.

headline: Congress and Climate Change
abstract: Senator Sheldon Whitehouse describes how Congress is beholden to the fossil fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mass Psychology Supports the Pricey Stock Market
abstract: Stock prices are high but an expert on bubbles says the psychological underpinnings of this market appear to be different from those of 1929 or 2000.
lead_paragraph: Canny stock investors are like judges in a quirky beauty contest. They aren’t looking for real beauty but for qualities that other people believe still other people will find beautiful.

headline: Buried Inside Bernie Sanders’s Bill: A Fallback Plan
abstract: The bill envisions a wholesale transformation of the U.S. health system, but it also considers more modest reforms to smooth the transition.
lead_paragraph: The Bernie Sanders “Medicare for All” plan promises rapid, sweeping change to the American health care system, with the elimination of all private insurance and the creation of a costly new government insurance program that will cover everyone and nearly every medical service.

headline: Austin Official Is Reprimanded for Avoiding Meetings With Women
abstract: William Manno, who oversees the South by Southwest festival, was accused of skipping meetings because he thought a colleague had romantic feelings for him.
lead_paragraph: An events manager for the city of Austin, Tex., who is known for overseeing the South by Southwest festival, has been formally reprimanded for refusing to meet with female city employees.

headline: Hotels That Bring Sports Fans Close to Their Teams
abstract: Properties in Atlanta, Chicago and Green Bay, Wis., will put guests near the action with the Braves, Cubs and Packers.
lead_paragraph: A number of new hotels aim to allow fans to stay close to their favorite sports teams, encouraging tourism outside of game time.

headline: Protecting Andy Warhol From Flood, Fire and Quake
abstract: Insurers are finding that protecting multimillion-dollar homes and art collections before disaster strikes is far less expensive than paying to rebuild or replace them after.
lead_paragraph: People commonly pay insurance companies to secure their property against loss or damage. But for the affluent, insurance companies sometimes take matters into their own hands.

headline: Giorgio Moroder Still Feels Love at 77
abstract: The disco producer, who is enjoying a late-career comeback, celebrates the 40th birthday of his monster hit with Donna Summer, “I Feel Love.”
lead_paragraph: What does a 77-year-old D.J. require before playing a late-night set of disco hits?

headline: National Book Awards Longlists Are Announced
abstract: Nominees include Jennifer Egan, Lisa Ko, David Grann, Kevin Young and Alarcón.
lead_paragraph: It’s still early in literary awards season — the winners of the Man Booker Prize, the Nobel Prize for Literature and the National Book Awards won’t be announced until later this fall — but speculation started heating up this week about who will take home the world’s most prestigious literary prizes this year.

headline: Barbara Kruger Heads to Berlin, With Virginia Woolf in Tow
abstract: The conceptual artist caps a busy summer with the opening of “Forever” at Sprüth Magers.
lead_paragraph: During her four-decades-long career, the conceptual artist Barbara Kruger has riffed on the words of Virginia Woolf, returning, time and again, to lines from “Mrs. Dalloway” or “To the Lighthouse.” And for her exhibition “Forever,” opening in Berlin this weekend, Kruger plucked a quotation from Woolf’s extended essay “A Room of One’s Own,” filling an entire gallery wall with: “You know that women have served all these centuries as looking glasses possessing the magic and delicious power of reflecting the figure of man at twice its natural size.” (Kruger appended “you know that,” for the Woolf purists out there.)

headline: Friday Night Music: Dakhabrakha in Kyiv
abstract: Hats!
lead_paragraph: Since that’s where I am at the moment. It is, by the way, a surprisingly handsome city. Just looking at the city center you’d have no idea how much stress Ukraine is under.

headline: $8 Million to Aid Poor North Koreans? South Korea and Japan Disagree
abstract: Illustrating a split in their approach to the North, the two American allies differ on Seoul’s plan to provide humanitarian help through United Nations agencies.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea and Japan, the United States’ two main East Asian allies, differed on Friday over providing humanitarian aid to North Korea’s malnourished children and pregnant women, hours after that country launched a ballistic missile over Japan.

headline: Roasted Summer Vegetables Tucked Into Tartlets
abstract: September’s cooler weather means it’s the perfect time to bake with late summer zucchini and tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: A summer vegetable quandary: My favorite way to eat zucchini, eggplant and peppers is to roast them until their sugars caramelize, their centers collapse and they turn floppy, rich and sweet. But my least favorite thing to do in summer is crank up the oven to achieve this glorious state.

headline: More Classmates of Treasury Secretary Hound Him to Quit Trump Post
abstract: First, Steven Mnuchin’s Yale classmates asked him to resign. Now the alumni of his exclusive private high school are piling on.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, whose fellow Yale alumni called for him to resign because they thought he was slow to denounce hate groups after violence in Charlottesville, Va., last month, came under fire Friday from another rarefied academic realm: the former students of his private country day school.

headline: Fashionable Causes
abstract: Charity events were held last week for Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund, Unitas and the ARD Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Charity events were held last week for Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund, Unitas and the ARD Foundation.

headline: Edda Gimnes Spring/Summer 2018
abstract: An exclusive first look at pieces from the Norwegian designer’s new collection, which she will present in London this weekend.
lead_paragraph: An exclusive first look at pieces from the Norwegian designer’s new collection, which she will present in London this weekend.

headline: The Emerging Designer Mentored by Alber Elbaz
abstract: The 25-year-old Norwegian Edda Gimnes will present her spring/summer 2018 collection in London this weekend.
lead_paragraph: “If someone had told me all of the things that would happen to me after leaving university just two years ago, I never would have believed them,” says the 25-year-old Norwegian designer Edda Gimnes, sitting in a cafe in east London. This weekend, she will present her spring/summer 2018 women’s collection at London Fashion Week as part of Vauxhall Fashion Scout, an independent showcase for emerging talent. “I wanted to stage a presentation instead of a show so people can spend time interacting with the looks,” she says. “It’s going to be so much fun.”

headline: ‘Haute Bohemians’ by Miguel Flores-Vianna
abstract: Exclusive images from the photographer’s new book.
lead_paragraph: Exclusive images from the photographer’s new book.

headline: Men, Women, Cinema — No Longer the Same Old Story
abstract: Among the bounty at this year’s Toronto International Film Festival are a wonderful solo directing debut from Greta Gerwig and a provocation from Louis C.K.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In my dream film festival, I would program Lucrecia Martel’s historical fiction “Zama” on a double bill with Louis C.K.’s contemporary comedy, “I Love You, Daddy.” Ms. Martel is an Argentine director best known on the festival circuit; Louis C.K., of course, is the American standup behind the television show “Louie” and the web series “Horace and Pete.” Shortly after “Zama” opens, a man spies on a group of naked women enjoying some kind of 18th-century spa day. When the women catch him, they shout, “Voyeur, voyeur!” And when one grabs him, he slaps her, which made the whole scene read like a metaphor for our gendered movie moment.

headline: From Instagram to ‘Bodak Yellow,’ Cardi B Has Arrived
abstract: The rapper behind one of the summer’s biggest hits has made swift moves in the music industry, and is making waves in the fashion world, too. A panel discussion, on Popcast.
lead_paragraph: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Giving Kinky Boots a Good Name
abstract: A sex shop classic lends ballast, and aggression, to even the most fragile springtime looks.
lead_paragraph: Propped on elevator platforms or killer heels, laced to the thighs or traveling unfettered to the hip, the boots that stalked the runways this week might have stepped off the set of “The Deuce,” the HBO series about the early 1970s Times Square demimonde.

headline: Review: The Ghosts and Rites of Pina Bausch
abstract: “Café Müller” and “The Rite of Spring,” presented by Bausch’s company at the Brooklyn Academy, feel haunted by Bausch’s death.
lead_paragraph: When Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch made its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1984, Bausch already had a reputation. An imposing one. She was not merely a major force in European theater, but was also said to be a creator of life-changing experiences. And this reputation, as much as the work itself, fueled the extreme reactions (truth! terrorism!) that inscribed the performances into lore.

headline: Sampha, the Tender Vocalist and Producer, Wins Mercury Prize
abstract: “Process” beat out competition from Ed Sheeran, Stormzy and the xx for the prestigious album of the year award given to British and Irish musicians.
lead_paragraph: Sampha, the London-born singer, songwriter and producer known for scene-stealing collaborations with the likes of Drake, Beyoncé and Kanye West, is the recipient of the 2017 Hyundai Mercury Prize, the prestigious album of the year award honoring musicians from Britain and Ireland, for his debut LP “Process.”

headline: Dances by Isadora Duncan and Trisha Brown in Paul Taylor Season
abstract: The sophomore edition of the “Icons” program is among the highlights of the season, which is planned for Lincoln Center next March.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor American Modern Dance’s coming season will feature the sophomore edition of “Icons,” a mixed bill that is to include works by Isadora Duncan (1877-1927), Trisha Brown (1937-2017) and Mr. Taylor, 87, the company announced on Friday.

headline: Bill de Blasio and the Politics of iPhone City
abstract: If New York has turned inward and become obsessed with its screens, is Bill de Blasio, on his way to a second term, the mayor the city deserves?
lead_paragraph: It seemed perhaps all too appropriate that on the day after Bill de Blasio, master of somnolent arrogance, effectively won a second term as the mayor of New York City, came a report that a former product manager at Google and his partner had started a company called Bodega, meant to rid cities of actual bodegas.

headline: Ryan Lo: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: End of an Era for New York’s Oldest Political Club
abstract: The McManus Midtown Democratic Club ruled politics in Hell’s Kitchen for a century. But the recent success in the Democratic primary of a new club, formed by a drag queen after the presidential election, ended all that.
lead_paragraph: September has traditionally been a celebratory time for Jim McManus, the fourth-generation scion of the venerable McManus Midtown Democratic Club in Manhattan’s Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood — a time of victorious candidates and high-powered politicians attending Mr. McManus’ birthday party, held conveniently before Primary Day to help mobilize voters for candidates backed by the club.

headline: In Trumpworld, a ‘Menu of Unsavory Crepes’
abstract: A reader humorously imagines crepes named for people in the news, including Trump, Putin and Bannon (recently taken off the menu).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Playlist: Björk Rediscovers Love and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear the new songs that made an impact this week, from Labrinth's "Misbehaving" to Lorde's remix of "Homemade Dynamite."
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Weezer sings an ode to the Beach Boys, Labrinth gets a lift from an Apple commercial, and Lorde looks for trouble on a new remix.

headline: Sexual Harassment Charges Roil Elite University Department
abstract: University of Rochester faculty members say the administration protected a professor who harassed women, and retaliated against those who complained.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — With its frosted glass windows, gleaming hardwood floors and modern teal chairs, the office of the University of Rochester’s Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences seems designed to project prestige. The sleek appearance fits the department’s reputation as one of this private university’s crown jewels, with a graduate program ranked as high as fourth in the nation by the National Research Council.

headline: Saudis Say Arrests Target Foreign-Funded Dissidents
abstract: The prominent citizens who were arrested had received support to threaten the national unity and undermine the monarchy, Saudi Arabia says.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A recent wave of arrests in Saudi Arabia targeted citizens who were working at the behest of foreign powers to undermine the monarchy, a Saudi government official said on Friday.

headline: For Eco-Minded Shoppers
abstract: A reader proposes a supermarket express lane for shoppers who bring their own bags.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Whether Corporate Spying or Just a Spoof, Imitation Is a Dangerous Game
abstract: Trying to be something you’re not isn’t necessarily illegal, but what you do during your subterfuge might make it a crime.
lead_paragraph: It may be that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, but pretending to be something you are not could land you under threat of legal action, whether you’re a digital prankster or a darling of the tech sector.

headline: Online Sex Trafficking
abstract: A member of Congress urges passage of legislation to protect children from trafficking.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Declines to Release List of His Mar-a-Lago Visitors
abstract: The administration’s refusal to turn over the names of people who met with the president at Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club, escalates a legal battle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday escalated a battle with government ethics groups by declining to release the identities of individuals visiting with President Trump at his family’s Mar-a-Lago resort during the days he has spent at the private club in Palm Beach, Fla., this year.

headline: Watch a Human-Powered Fleet of ‘Fireflies’ Create a Nighttime Dreamscape
abstract: For a public art project in Philadelphia, the artist Cai Guo-Qiang transformed pedicabs with paper lanterns ablaze.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Not every street in America deserves a birthday party, but this city chose to honor its 100-year-old Benjamin Franklin Parkway on Thursday with a mesmerizing centennial celebration.

headline: The Snow Leopard Is No Longer Endangered. It’s Still at Risk.
abstract: The animals have been reclassified as vulnerable by a leading conservationist group, but poaching and habitat loss still threaten their populations.
lead_paragraph: The snow leopard is no longer an endangered species, but its population in the wild is still at risk because of poaching and habitat loss, conservationists said this week.

headline: Harvard’s Rejection of Michelle Jones, an Ex-Inmate
abstract: Three Harvard grad students harshly condemn the university, while another writer praises it and objects to the “glorification” of a murderer.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Canada Letter: The Avro Arrow and an Amazon HQ
abstract: This week’s Canada Letter, which is for and about Canada and Canadians, looks at the underwater hunt for traces of a Cold War fighter.
lead_paragraph: Time has only increased interest among Canadians in the Avro Arrow supersonic fighter jet that was abruptly canceled by the government in 1959, putting at least 25,000 people out of work.

headline: A Judge, a Clerk and Secret Recordings: Drama Engulfs a Staten Island Court
abstract: At the center of the spectacle are allegations that a former top judge, who is married to the district attorney, stayed involved in criminal matters.
lead_paragraph: The state Supreme Court on Staten Island is the quietest court of its kind in New York City, handling not quite 4,500 cases last year — or about a sixth of those that passed through its sister courts in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

headline: T Magazine Editors on Things They’re Into Right Now
abstract: A not-exhaustive list of what's on our radar.
lead_paragraph: Fashion collaborations can feel like calculated mismatches meant to surprise you with their own improbability. Peter Pilotto and Christopher de Vos have taken the opposite approach, filling a pop-up shop in a South Kensington, London townhouse with design pieces by people they already love and collect: their friends. It’s an impressive group that includes Martino Gamper, famous for his 3D drawing project “100 Chairs in 100 Days,” whose button-top stools figure in the space, and his wife, the sculptor Francis Upritchard, who helped choose a vibrant orange for the walls. The shade reminded Pilotto and de Vos of houses they’d seen on a recent trip to Lima, Peru (“we’re currently in a South America phase,” Pilotto says). Elsewhere is a hand-knotted rug with a painterly diamond motif from Ecuador, an actual painting by Peter McDonald and a bench that the designer Bethan Laura Wood covered with a rainbow-hued patchwork textile. It’s a perfect complement to the brand’s latest ready-to-wear collection, which Pilotto describes as “tropical-baroque” and includes quilted microfiber jackets and an asymmetrical dress embroidered with chenille yarn. One day, he and de Vos were in the studio of the glassblower Jochen Holz and found themselves drawn to a series of glass coat hooks Holz had made, which Holz has now remade for them as a series of sculptural glass-drop earrings and cuffs. “It was about playing with different materials and seeing what we could do,” says Pilotto. “And just such a natural dialogue between disciplines.” Fittingly, the shop will stay open through fashion week, the London Design Festival and Frieze. 3 Cromwell Pl., London — KATE GUADAGNINO

headline: How to Bring Your Vacation Home With You
abstract: Be open to unexpected, immersive experiences.
lead_paragraph: The cruel thing about vacations is that they are pleasurable but finite. I recently had time to contemplate this unwelcome fact during a 10-hour flight home from a Greek island where I had spent a paradisiacal two weeks. I found myself wondering about the relationship between the duration of a vacation and the longevity of its mental health benefits.

headline: After Graydon, Who?
abstract: Graydon Carter’s exit means the Vanity Fair editorship is up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: So Graydon is gone. Now what?

headline: Want to Stream Emmy-Winning Shows?
abstract: Many of this year’s best TV shows are available to stream immediately. Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site, can show you where.
lead_paragraph: Many of this year’s best TV shows are available to stream immediately. Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site, can show you where.

headline: Announcing a Trump Poetry Contest
abstract: Enter my contest for poems about our times and the Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: Shall I compare thee to a Trump?

headline: Chelsea Manning Has a Lot to Teach. Harvard Doesn’t Agree.
abstract: Her whistle-blowing was a powerful contribution to the debate over national security. But the university would rather listen to the C.I.A. than to her.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Harvard’s Kennedy School announced that Chelsea Manning, the former Army intelligence analyst and whistle-blower, would be a visiting fellow this fall. The reaction was swift: A day later, Michael Morell, a former acting director of the C.I.A. and also a visiting fellow at the school, resigned from his own fellowship in protest. His resignation was quickly followed by the current director of the C.I.A., Mike Pompeo, canceling a speech scheduled at the school. In a statement, Mr. Pompeo unilaterally declared Ms. Manning a “traitor.”

headline: René Laurentin, Investigator of Celestial Visions, Dies at 99
abstract: A theologian honored by the Vatican, Father Laurentin assessed reports of sightings of the Virgin Mary, from Lourdes to a Texas backyard.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. René Laurentin, a prominent Roman Catholic theologian who devoted his career to investigating reports of supernatural religious visions, died on Sept. 10 in Evry, a suburb of Paris. He was 99.

headline: Greg Escalante, Champion of ‘Lowbrow’ Art, Dies at 62
abstract: As a collector, gallery owner and general enthusiast, Mr. Escalante helped put the brash art of comics and California car culture into galleries.
lead_paragraph: In his 30s and several years out of college, where he had studied art and been bored by much of it, Greg Escalante saw a skateboarding magazine and was so bowled over by the artwork on the cover that he spent the rest of his life championing the genre it represented — what came to be known as Lowbrow Art.

headline: Robot-Voice Quartet: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
abstract: Simon Rattle, Virgil Thomson and a soprano singing alongside film of herself were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what’s delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: One Night a Year, This Cactus Flower May Surprise You
abstract: A look at the night-blooming cereus, a group of cactus flowers that make a one-night appearance and then disappear.
lead_paragraph: Rarely is it a good idea to respond to a stranger on a Brooklyn street at night when he asks if you want to see something cool. But occasionally, it pays off.

headline: Byron Buxton, the Twins’ Magician in Center, Cleans Up at the Plate
abstract: Buxton’s hitting improved after he eliminated his leg kick and shortened his stride, a technique that worked for his manager, Paul Molitor, in a Hall of Fame career.
lead_paragraph: Byron Buxton had one hit in the last week of June. In 20 at-bats, he had a single and eight strikeouts, and his average cratered to .195. He was barely passable as a major league hitter, and the Minnesota Twins might have wondered if they had whiffed when they chose him second over all in the 2012 draft.

headline: Serving the Community, Working for Microsoft
abstract: A community development specialist employed by Microsoft tries to help people, especially children, while using the company’s products.
lead_paragraph: Shy Averett, 36, is a community development and event specialist for Microsoft in Troy, Mich.

headline: Keegan Bradley, Stuck in a Title Drought, Seeks to Extend His Season
abstract: Bradley, the 2011 P.G.A. Championship winner, opened the BMW Championship with a 65 and a 72 while needing a good finish to advance to next week’s Tour Championship in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — The Air Jordan golf shoes on his feet and the United States Ryder Cup yardage book cover poking out of his back pocket spoke to Keegan Bradley’s august credentials. They established his connections to the sporting nobleman Michael Jordan and to the game’s most patrician pro team event.

headline: The Terrorist Attack That Failed to Terrify
abstract: Londoners like to “keep calm and carry on.” But there’s a problem with such insouciance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Friday morning in London a terrorist failed. There were flames but no deadly blast at the Parsons Green Station on the London Underground subway system in this, the fourth terrorist attack in London and the fifth in Britain this year. Not only did the as-yet-unidentified terrorist fail because he bungled his bomb-making, he failed because he failed to terrify.

headline: Fall TV Is Finally Here. So When Do My Favorite Shows Come Back?
abstract: Here’s a quick guide to when some of our favorites return. TV’s cup runneth over.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: At Fashion Show, U.N. Tour Guides Walk Runway
abstract: The designer Elie Tahari wanted the new uniforms “to look elegant, classic and professional, and be comfortable.”
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — New York City has had Fashion Week in some form for more than 70 years, and the United Nations has had guides leading visitors on tours for almost as long. So perhaps it was inevitable that the fashion world and the diplomatic world would converge.

headline: From Heat Waves to Hurricanes: What We Know About Extreme Weather and Climate Change
abstract: A string of extreme events has brought new focus to a familiar question: Is climate change to blame?
lead_paragraph: A string of extreme events has brought new focus to a familiar question: Is climate change to blame?

headline: S.&P. 500 Crosses 2,500 for First Time
abstract: The benchmark index rose nearly five points on the day to close at 2,500.23. The Dow Jones industrial average also reached a new high at 22,268.34.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets continued their march higher Friday, with the Standard & Poor’s 500 index passing the threshold of 2,500 for the first time in its 60-year history.

headline: David Madden, Former Fox Executive, Is Taking Over Programming at AMC
abstract: At Fox, Mr. Madden helped develop shows like “The Americans” and showed a preference for grittier dramas.
lead_paragraph: AMC made it official on Friday and announced that it had hired the former Fox executive David Madden to be its new head of original programming.

headline: Lurid Lawsuit’s Quiet End Leaves Silicon Valley Start-Up Barely Dented
abstract: For all the outcry over how women are treated in the tech industry, the resolution of a sexual harassment case against Upload, a virtual reality start-up, shows that little has changed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At Upload, the parties never seemed to stop.

headline: Ashley Williams: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Gut Bacteria May Play a Role in Weight Loss
abstract: A study found that people with a high ratio of two gut bacteria lost more weight than those with a low ratio.
lead_paragraph: Whether a diet works might depend on which bacteria are in your gut.

headline: Manfred Fines Red Sox Over Stealing Signs and Issues Warning to All 30 Teams
abstract: The commissioner’s office said it would donate the fine to hurricane relief efforts in Florida.
lead_paragraph: The sign-stealing confrontation between the Yankees and the Red Sox came to an apparent conclusion on Friday when Rob Manfred, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, fined the Boston team an undisclosed amount but chose not to hit it with more forceful penalties for using an Apple Watch to try to swipe signals from Yankees catchers.

headline: Paradise Lost: Devastation on the U.S. Virgin Islands
abstract: Residents of St. Thomas and St. John showed signs of resilience amid the ruins left by Hurricane Irma.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I. — The United States Virgin Islands no longer has the air of paradise.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Sydney Ember, Damien Cave and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge.
abstract: Dogecoin was meant to poke fun at the hype around virtual currency. But now, its creator says, Dogecoin illustrates the risks.
lead_paragraph: Jackson Palmer no longer thinks it’s funny to imitate Doge, the internet meme about a Shiba Inu dog whose awe-struck expressions and garbled syntax (e.g. “Wow. So pizza. Much delicious.”) made him a viral sensation several years ago.

headline: Knife-Throwing as a Sport: Who Would Have Thunk It?
abstract: No, ESPN is not televising it — at least not yet. But there are a growing number of devotees who love the sound of knife hitting wood.
lead_paragraph: DANBY, N.Y. — Reaching the 2017 Finger Lakes Fling, held on the last weekend in August, required entering Paul Maccarone and Chris O’Brien’s driveway. Still in your car, you eased left onto their vast, flat front lawn, careful not to clip the three skinny maples. You minded the garden fence, guarded by pink flamingoes and watering cans.

headline: Monica’s 3 Movies to Stream This Weekend
abstract: If you’re in the mood for a tense wartime drama, a cute romantic comedy or a creepy horror movie, here’s what to watch.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.
