abstract: Who to watch for at London Fashion Week, highlights from New York — and much more.
lead_paragraph: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: If ESPN Wants to Discipline Jemele Hill, She Might Have Law on Her Side
abstract: A Connecticut statute provides free-speech protections beyond the First Amendment, making it illegal for ESPN to punish Hill, according to some labor lawyers.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said that tweets by an ESPN host disparaging President Trump were a “fireable offense,” she added on Friday that the network “should hold anchors to a fair and consistent standard.”

headline: Back to Saturn? Five Missions Proposed to Follow Cassini
abstract: Although NASA does not have yet a follow-up mission to Saturn on its schedule, scientists are dreaming up ideas for one.
lead_paragraph: For 13 years, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft sent back captivating observations of Saturn, and its rings and moons, solving some mysteries but raising plenty of new questions. With the spacecraft’s demise on Friday, the stream of data from Saturn has dried up.

headline: ‘Dictators of My Well-Being’
abstract: In a letter to a New York Times reporter, Kharon Davis describes a jail stay so long, "you have to violate just to stay sane."
lead_paragraph: In a letter to a New York Times reporter, Kharon Davis describes a jail stay so long, "you have to violate just to stay sane."

headline: I.O.C. Investigation of Russian Doping Might Soon Yield Penalties
abstract: “We feel we have found a number of elements to charge a certain number of athletes,” said a member of the I.O.C.’s executive board.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — The first group of Russian athletes suspected of being part of the country’s sophisticated doping program at the 2014 Sochi Games may soon face the prospect of banishment from the Olympics, an official leading an investigation for the International Olympic Committee said on Friday.

headline: London, Japan, Cassini: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 5 Styling Tips From New York Fashion Week
abstract: From oversize shirts to sneakers with dresses, tricks to take away from the shows in New York this week.
lead_paragraph: It's not only a sporty jacket — but also a versatile styling piece. At Marc Jacobs and Oscar de la Renta, anoraks were shown over evening dresses, while at Calvin Klein, one came layered beneath a brown checked coat.

headline: Trump Teams With Democrats on DACA: What’s the Logic?
abstract: Mixed messages, backtracking and a bit of verbal combat after a bipartisan meeting between President Trump and Democratic Party leaders have added confusion to the fate of DACA. Three New York Times reporters, Maggie Haberman, Peter Baker, and Glenn Thrush, explain what happened.
lead_paragraph: Mixed messages, backtracking and a bit of verbal combat after a bipartisan meeting between President Trump and Democratic Party leaders have added confusion to the fate of DACA. Three New York Times reporters, Maggie Haberman, Peter Baker, and Glenn Thrush, explain what happened.

headline: A Saint’s Remains and the Pope’s Choir at St. Patrick’s Cathedral
abstract: A scheduling quirk has brought two Italian guests to the cathedral this weekend: relics from a popular Catholic saint and the Sistine Chapel Choir.
lead_paragraph: The popular Roman Catholic saint known as Padre Pio has gained rock star appeal since his death in 1968 and his canonization in 2002, so perhaps it is fitting that he is on a national tour.

headline: El Chapo’s Claims of Improper Extradition Are Dismissed
abstract: The ruling means the sprawling international drug case against Joaquín Guzmán Loera can continue moving toward a trial scheduled for April.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Brooklyn dismissed claims on Friday that Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord best known as El Chapo, had been improperly extradited to the United States from Mexico, handing the defendant the latest in a string of legal defeats.

headline: While Amazon Plays the Field, Walmart Stays True to Arkansas
abstract: A week after Amazon announced plans for a second headquarters somewhere in North America, Walmart said on Friday that it is building a new home office in Bentonville.
lead_paragraph: Take that Amazon. Walmart is doubling down on its hometown of Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Funding Talks at Uber and Lyft Complicate Ride-Hailing Allegiances
abstract: With Uber reportedly nearing a deal with SoftBank and Lyft having held discussions with Alphabet, alliances are shifting quickly in the industry.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The only thing changing faster than who is winning the race in the cutthroat world of ride hailing are the shifting behind-the-scenes allegiances between those companies and investors.

headline: Jerry Pournelle, Science Fiction Novelist and Computer Guide, Dies at 84
abstract: An aerospace consultant, advice columnist, blogger and best-selling author. (And maybe the first to write a novel on a word-processor.)
lead_paragraph: Jerry Pournelle, a prolific writer of science fiction novels and witty advice columns for computer users, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: A Green Light Is Given, It’s True, for a Grown-Up Cindy Lou Who
abstract: A federal judge has ruled that “Who’s Holiday!” doesn’t violate the copyright of the Dr. Seuss classic, “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!”
lead_paragraph: It may be lewd, profane and in poor taste, and it could tarnish your childhood memories of a beloved Dr. Seuss tale, “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!” But Matthew Lombardo’s theatrical parody, “Who’s Holiday!” — a dark and decidedly adult sequel of sorts to the Christmas classic — doesn’t violate the copyright of the original story, according to a judge presiding over a lawsuit that Mr. Lombardo brought against the Seuss estate.

headline: Notes From a Crazy Campaign Trail
abstract: Jill Abramson discusses Katy Tur’s new memoir, “Unbelievable: My Front-Row Seat to the Craziest Campaign in American History.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: A Shorebird to Watch
abstract: The great migration of shorebirds can be overwhelming for the novice bird-watcher. Focusing on the graceful greater yellowlegs is a good place to start.
lead_paragraph: If you wait for autumn to see the great migration of shorebirds through New York City, you’ll miss half the show. These long-range migrants begin their travels south in August. They have to; they need to cover a lot of ground.

headline: Amid Pornography Case, Vatican Recalls Priest From Washington Embassy
abstract: A priest working as a diplomat in Washington has returned to the Vatican amid suspicions by American officials that he possessed child pornography.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has recalled a high-ranking priest working as a diplomat in the Holy See’s embassy in Washington after American authorities sought to strip his immunity and potentially charge him with possession of child pornography, the Vatican said Friday.

headline: Why the U.S. Allowed a Convoy of ISIS Fighters to Go Free
abstract: American officials say the decision to end a two-week standoff involved a trade-off of competing priorities, and speaks to the complexity of the Syrian war.
lead_paragraph: Needing to relieve himself, the man stepped out of a bus into the night air of the Syrian desert.

headline: Harry Dean Stanton, Character Actor Who Became a Star, Dies at 91
abstract: The gaunt, hollow-eyed Mr. Stanton had his breakthrough in “Paris, Texas.” As one critic wrote, he was able “to make everything he does seem immediately authentic.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Dean Stanton, the gaunt, hollow-eyed, scene-stealing character actor who broke out of obscurity in his late 50s in two starring movie roles and capped his career with an acclaimed characterization as a corrupt polygamist on the HBO series “Big Love,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Ralph & Russo: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: South Vietnam Had an Antiwar Movement, Too
abstract: Like most students in the United States, most South Vietnamese students only wanted the violence and fighting to stop.
lead_paragraph: The year 1967 was a watershed for antiwar protest in the United States, from bold statements like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s Riverside Church speech in April to the March on the Pentagon in October. Equally noteworthy, but less well known, is the student protest movement that emerged in South Vietnam. Vietnamese youth, of all political orientations, played an active and critical role in the politics of South Vietnam, at times acting like the official opposition with the ability to shape events on the national stage. And just like in the United States, 1967 was a momentous year for the movement.

headline: Hurricane Jose Spins North, With East Coast Watching Warily
abstract: There is a good chance that the storm, which appears to have strengthened, will not make landfall. Still, forecasters are urging vigilance.
lead_paragraph: The storm Jose reclaimed its hurricane classification as it spun over the Atlantic Ocean on Friday, a day after it had been downgraded to a tropical storm.

headline: How Sheryll Durrant, Urban Farmer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The resident manager of the Kelly Street Garden, in South Bronx’s Longwood neighborhood, sleeps in and spends time with her husband and teenage son.
lead_paragraph: As the resident manager of Kelly Street Garden, part of an affordable housing development in South Bronx’s Longwood neighborhood, Sheryll Durrant, 52, likens her job to an intense workout. “I’m constantly moving 40-pound bags of compost, digging, weeding and trellising,” she said. “There’s no time for sitting around.” The 2,500-square-foot community garden grows more than 30 varieties of fruits, vegetables and herbs, which are free for residents in the development. On Sundays — her only day off — Ms. Durrant relaxes with her husband, Bruce Zeines, 62, an artist and graphic designer, and their 16-year-old son, Noah. Their apartment, naturally, faces the garden.

headline: Manhattan’s Confusing Avenue Addresses
abstract: A 19th-century grid organized most of the borough’s cross street addresses. In 1940, an attempt to regulate avenue addresses failed because of Fifth Avenue business interests.
lead_paragraph: Q. Address numbers in Manhattan are intuitive on the cross streets, but not so much on the avenues. Why is that?

headline: Trump Gives Conservatives Their Just Comeuppance
abstract: Trump’s move toward Democrats is about betrayal, not pragmatism.
lead_paragraph: Uh-oh. I’m starting to enjoy Donald Trump’s presidency.

headline: With Cost-Cutting Zeal, Tillerson Whittles U.N. Delegation, Too
abstract: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, who sees himself as a steward of taxpayer dollars, slashed the number of diplomats attending the United Nations General Assembly next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long called the Super Bowl of diplomacy, the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly attracts diplomats from 193 nations and dozens of heads of state. And every September, hundreds of State Department specialists in regional politics or subjects such as nuclear nonproliferation use the gathering to meet their counterparts from other nations without having to trek to the far corners of the world.

headline: Judiciary Chairman Considers Subpoenas in Trump Investigation
abstract: Senate Judiciary Committee leaders are growing frustrated with what they see as stonewalling from the Justice Department over their Russia probe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Grassley, facing what he sees as Justice Department stonewalling, is considering subpoenas to compel several witnesses to appear before the Senate Judiciary Committee and divulge what they know about President Trump’s connections to Russia and his firing of James B. Comey as F.B.I. director.

headline: Fast Track to Citizenship Is Cut Off for Some Military Recruits
abstract: The recruits had signed up for a program to attract immigrants with certain language and other skills that are in short supply into the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Anwar enlisted in April 2016 in the United States military through a program that promised him a fast track to citizenship. His ship date for basic training, expected within six months, was postponed twice. “It was common knowledge that there were delays because of new security checks,” said the 27-year-old Pakistani national, who lives in Jersey City.

headline: The Dodgers: From Blazing Hot to Bitterly Cold. And Now What?
abstract: Despite a recent 1-16 streak, the Dodgers have the best record in baseball.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The best team in baseball arrived here on Thursday night and, no, it was not the Cleveland Indians. The Indians were at home then, down to their last strike, before coming back to earn their 22nd victory in a row. Dave Roberts, the manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, could relate as he watched from afar.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Korean Threat Pushes Japanese to Reassess Military Constraints
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 16, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “In Japan’s case, I don’t think we can shoot before we are shot. Most likely, once we are shot and the second or third missiles are coming and they are on the ground, we can shoot back.”

headline: Morality Is Negotiable for Mr. Trump
abstract: Compassion for young immigrants? Dream on. When he does the right thing, he’s only playing the angles.
lead_paragraph: This week President Trump reached a deal with Democrats to enshrine into law protections for young illegal immigrants brought to the United States as children. Within a matter of days, these young people went from fearing deportation to homelands some had never known, to having a potential shot at citizenship.

headline: Pleas for Help at Florida Nursing Home Where Heat Took Lives
abstract: The home said it had called the power utility repeatedly after its air-conditioning went out, and was assured that help was on the way.
lead_paragraph: The Florida nursing home where eight residents died on Wednesday after the building lost air-conditioning said Friday that it had repeatedly called the local power company and had been assured that help was on the way.

headline: With Chelsea Manning Invitation, Harvard Got a Discussion It Didn’t Want
abstract: After the university’s Kennedy School gave Manning a visiting fellowship, backlash led to a reversal and criticism from across the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — For Jim Pershing, who aspires to a career in international relations, studying at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government was a chance to immerse himself in a heady ecosystem where power players from the top echelons of the state, the nonprofit sector, the military and the media all converge.

headline: Corrections: September 16, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 16, 2017.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: The Forgotten Victims of Agent Orange
abstract: The United States has acknowledged the horrifying effects of Agent Orange on its military veterans. Why won’t it do the same for Vietnamese citizens?
lead_paragraph: Phan Thanh Hung Duc, 20, lies immobile and silent, his midsection covered haphazardly by a white shirt with an ornate Cambodian temple design. His mouth is agape and his chest thrusts upward, his hands and feet locked in gnarled deformity. He appears to be frozen in agony. He is one of the thousands of Vietnamese victims of Agent Orange.

headline: Congress Goes for Its Guns
abstract: Silencers are not golden.
lead_paragraph: The gridlock in Congress has been so bad that there’s even been a shortage of insane gun bills.

headline: Plucky Words
abstract: A very nice joint effort.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Natan Last and Finn Vigeland teach a class in crossword construction at the Jewish Association Serving the Aging (also known as J.A.S.A.) in Manhattan, and this is another in the series of annual class projects. I’m always blown away by how good a job the group does.

headline: ‘Truffle Oil’ Without Any Actual Truffles
abstract: Most products sold as truffle oils are flavored by chemicals, and consumers don’t know the difference.
lead_paragraph: My cousin Mario, who lives in Certaldo, Italy, southwest of Florence, is a retired barber who hunts white truffles. One year when we joined him on a hunt, Mario gave my father a truffle about the size of an almond, which he dropped into the inside pocket of an old bomber jacket. On the train ride back to Florence, that tiny truffle filled the car with an extraordinary scent, an intoxicating, slightly nasty and wholly seductive mixture of garlic and lilies and dirty socks.

headline: In This Sports Gender Gap, Men Fall Short
abstract: We’d rather our male athletes not have emotional lives, but if they have to have them, we’d rather not know about it.
lead_paragraph: The electric talent Sloane Stephens, a player just now coming into her own after having her career nearly wrecked by injuries, won the U.S. Open women’s tournament last week. But let’s not kid ourselves: The real winner of this year’s tournament was Serena Williams.

headline: More Jokes From Martin Shkreli
abstract: Who could have imagined that the disgraced pharmaceutical executive was also a comedian?
lead_paragraph: Comedy is hard. Anyone who has performed for three people in the back of a juice bar, trying to land a punch line over the whir of a blender full of kale (for example) can vouch for that.

headline: Didi Gregorius Hits His 22nd Homer to Lead the Yankees Past the Orioles
abstract: Gregorius drove in four runs Friday night as the Yankees won for the sixth time in their last seven games.
lead_paragraph: While Aaron Judge and Gary Sanchez have commanded most of the attention for the Yankees this season, shortstop Didi Gregorius has mostly shined in the background.

headline: Map: Tracking Hurricane Jose’s Path
abstract: Real-time map showing the position and forecast for Hurricane Jose.
lead_paragraph: Real-time map showing the position and forecast for Hurricane Jose.

headline: Sea Captain’s Mansion Restored in High Style as Luxury Hotel
abstract: The Victorian-era Spicer Mansion opened in May 2016 as a boutique hotel in a quiet residential neighborhood in the seafaring town of Mystic, Conn.
lead_paragraph: From $370.

headline: Love the Club. Loathe the American Owner.
abstract: Owners from the United States are more prominent than ever in British soccer, but not everyone is cheering their inroads, or their results.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few weeks before last November’s presidential election in the United States, Matthew Barzun, the country’s ambassador to Britain at the time, hosted a party.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘La La Land’ and ‘One Mississippi’
abstract: Damien Chazelle’s musical on the wonders and struggles of making it in Hollywood comes to HBO. And life goes on in Season 2 of “One Mississippi.”
lead_paragraph: Damien Chazelle’s musical on the wonders and struggles of making it in Hollywood comes to HBO. And life goes on in Season 2 of “One Mississippi.”

headline: 5 Things to Cook While Watching ‘Seinfeld’ Reruns
abstract: “Seinfeld” wasn’t a show about “nothing.” It was, at least in part, a show about food.
lead_paragraph: Even now, nearly two decades after the final episode of “Seinfeld” aired, I can’t order a big salad or eat a Junior Mint without thinking about the show. If I eat more than one piece of shrimp off a shrimp cocktail platter, I inevitably worry that someone is going to tell me that the ocean called. And forget about double-dipping a chip.

headline: Rare White Giraffes Cause a Stir in Kenya
abstract: A conservancy captured video footage of the mother and child after a villager tipped off rangers.
lead_paragraph: A villager in Kenya was herding animals one day recently when he came upon a head-turning sight. A ghostly creature with a mighty long neck was grazing off in the distance.

headline: How Big Business Got Brazil Hooked on Junk Food
abstract: As growth slows in wealthy countries, Western food companies are aggressively expanding in developing nations, contributing to obesity and health problems.
lead_paragraph: As growth slows in wealthy countries, Western food companies are aggressively expanding in developing nations, contributing to obesity and health problems.

headline: ‘Their Deaths Are the Stuff of Nightmares’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss deaths at a sweltering nursing home, a new universal health care proposal, and cute Wi-Fi network names.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: Inside Simone Rocha’s All-Female Fashion House
abstract: At Simone Rocha's studio, women’s wear means practicality — not fantasy. We give you a tour during London Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: At Simone Rocha's studio, women’s wear means practicality — not fantasy. We give you a tour during London Fashion Week.

headline: Bump in U.S. Incomes Doesn’t Erase 50 Years of Pain
abstract: Recent trends have produced positive statistics, but forces undermining the middle class may reach back farther than many economists have thought.
lead_paragraph: Incomes are up. Poverty is down. And job openings have hit a record high. But if the economy is so wonderful, why are so many Americans still feeling left behind?

headline: How to Make the Most of a Layover
abstract: Consider a daylong stop, check with airlines about free layover programs, and make sure the destination is a contrast to your vacation location.
lead_paragraph: Many fliers view layovers as an inconvenience, but for Jaclyn Sienna India, the owner of the New York City travel company Sienna Charles, they’re an opportunity to explore the destination her flight stops in. “I try to make the place where I have to change planes a part of my vacation,” she said. “Often, these side trips end up being as exciting as my final destination.”

headline: Chips Off the Old Block: Computers Are Taking Design Cues From Human Brains
abstract: New technologies are testing the limits of computer semiconductors. To deal with that, researchers have gone looking for ideas from nature.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — We expect a lot from our computers these days. They should talk to us, recognize everything from faces to flowers, and maybe soon do the driving. All this artificial intelligence requires an enormous amount of computing power, stretching the limits of even the most modern machines.

headline: Diversifying Fashion Week
abstract: Designer Tracy Reese’s show is among the most inclusive at New York Fashion Week. For several years, more than half of her models have been women of color.
lead_paragraph: Designer Tracy Reese’s show is among the most inclusive at New York Fashion Week. For several years, more than half of her models have been women of color.

headline: Where Tourism Thrives in Mexico, Bloodshed and Poverty Are Blocks Away
abstract: A surge of violence has shaken the once-peaceful tourist destination of Los Cabos, exposing stark inequality and longstanding government indifference.
lead_paragraph: LOS CABOS, Mexico — In recruiting foot soldiers, the drug gang did not have to look hard to find 18-year-old Edwin Alberto López Rojas. He, in fact, had been looking for them.

headline: In Irma’s Wake, Surveying the Damage Along the Coast
abstract: A photo essay of the Southeast, where residents emerged to find debris, eroded beaches and a reason to feel lucky.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Irma threw its hardest punches in the eastern Caribbean and throughout the state of Florida. But long after its winds diminished, it did enormous damage up and down the Eastern Seaboard.

headline: Trump Translated for Egypt, by a Queens Bodega Owner
abstract: Few of Hatem El-Gamasy's customers know that he also appears on Egyptian television news programs, holding forth on subjects from immigration policy to North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Few of Hatem El-Gamasy's customers know that he also appears on Egyptian television news programs, holding forth on subjects from immigration policy to North Korea.

headline: ‘Dear Sugars’: Sexless Relationships Part 2
abstract: The Sugars return with Esther Perel, and they advise a letter writer who is looking for a way to help his wife heal from trauma and enjoy sex again.
lead_paragraph: An adoring husband desires intimacy with his wife, but as a trauma survivor, she doesn’t enjoy sex. In this week’s episode, a letter writer who calls himself “Faithful Friend” describes his frustrating predicament.

headline: As Wildfires Burn in West, Ash Rides Wind High Across U.S.
abstract: Wildfires in the Pacific Northwest have impacted the air quality in the region and sent plumes of smoke and ash across North America as far east as New York and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Wildfires in the Pacific Northwest have impacted the air quality in the region and sent plumes of smoke and ash across North America as far east as New York and Pennsylvania.

headline: Hillary Clinton and America Ferrera on Pain and Progress (and Hiking)
abstract: The former presidential candidate and the politically active actress discuss the hurt of the 2016 election and how they are both moving on.
lead_paragraph: Hiking, yoga, reading, prayer, chardonnay (but not Xanax): These are the things, along with family and friends, that helped Hillary Clinton after her stunning defeat in the presidential election last year. But these are gentle pastimes. What about kicking things — or weeping?

headline: An Ode to Acts of Kindness on the New York City Subway
abstract: “The New York City subway is this great equalizer,” said the photographer Andre Wagner, who spent four years taking photographs on its platforms and in its cars. “For this brief moment in time, we’re all in it together.”
lead_paragraph: For many New Yorkers, their subway line is a second home. They see their neighbors on the same route; they know which car will be closest to their exit; and they have favorite spots for the ride.  Mr. Wagner, who has been taking photographs in the subway since 2013 and whose book, “Here for the Ride,” will be published this week, likes to stand in front of the doors. “I can see everything in the car that way,” he said.

headline: British Police Make ‘Significant Arrest’ in Subway Bombing
abstract: An 18-year-old man was detained in southeastern England, and the police searched at least one house about three miles from Heathrow Airport in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British police said on Saturday that they had arrested an 18-year-old man in connection with the terrorist explosion in a London subway station that injured at least 30 people and unleashed panic among fleeing passengers.

headline: Jesuit Priest Stands Up for Gay Catholics, Then Faces Backlash
abstract: The Rev. James Martin’s latest book calls for a dialogue with L.G.B.T. Catholics. His critics called him everything from “heretic” to “pansified.”
lead_paragraph: The Rev. James Martin knew his latest book – which urges a dialogue between the Roman Catholic Church and lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Catholics who feel estranged from it – would be provocative. Even though the book was approved by his Jesuit superior as in line with church teachings and was endorsed by several cardinals, he did not expect everyone to agree. That’s fine, he said. That’s why dialogue was needed.

headline: Fashion East: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Alice Archer: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Hold the Egg Sandwich: Egyptian TV Is Calling
abstract: Hatem El-Gamasy often appears as a pundit for Egyptian television news programs. His viewers don’t know his day job: He owns a bodega in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Every other day or so, Hatem El-Gamasy connects to a news audience nearly halfway around the world, delivering hot takes on American politics, live from New York, but on Egyptian television.

headline: Simple Investing for Nonprofits
abstract: Like individuals saving for retirement, nonprofits are often better off when their investments are straightforward and low cost.
lead_paragraph: The boards of small nonprofit organizations must make major investment decisions, but they are often flying in the dark.

headline: JW Anderson: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Nun With a Chain Saw, and Other People We Met During Irma
abstract: Photogenic police officers and a man who playfully suggested firing guns at the storm were among the people Hurricane Irma introduced to the world.
lead_paragraph: A perhaps unexpected person trying to clear a road with a chain saw. Police officers who were appreciated for being easy on the eyes. A jokester who lost control of his joke. A sheriff bent on checking for active arrest warrants. A mother in peril who relied on the kindness of others.

headline: Molly Goddard: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: 36 Burundian Refugees Are Shot Dead in Congo
abstract: The Burundians had fled political violence at home but died in a clash with soldiers, according to the U.N. and a civil society group in Congo.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Burundians who had fled to neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo had escaped the kind of political violence that human rights investigators have described as crimes against humanity: torture and rape at the hands of the military and the police back home.

headline: Construction in Hudson Yards Continues
abstract: In addition to megaprojects like Hudson Yards and Manhattan West, a range of smaller projects across the area are nearing completion.
lead_paragraph: In addition to megaprojects like Hudson Yards and Manhattan West, a range of smaller projects across the area are nearing completion.

headline: Hudson Yards: A New (Far) West Side Story
abstract: While big projects slowly add high-rises to the area, smaller buildings are already opening.
lead_paragraph: The makeover of the Far West Side has been taking shape for so long, anticipating its completion can feel like waiting for Godot, as if the moment will never arrive.

headline: Bewildered by That Rarest of Sightings in Washington: Bipartisanship
abstract: In a city where common ground has been uncommon, there has been some bewilderment over the lost art of reaching across the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bipartisanship can be disorienting.

headline: Bangladesh Plans to Build Huge Refugee Camp for Rohingya
abstract: The new settlements will be built in the next 10 days on 2,000 acres near the border to house the thousands who have fled from Myanmar, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Bangladesh, facing an unprecedented influx of ethnic Rohingya, plans to build a vast camp to house about 400,000 refugees who have poured into the country over the past three weeks.

headline: Facing a Brick Wall and Wondering How to Make it Bearable
abstract: A reader asks what can be done about a brick wall opposite a bathroom window.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a co-op in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. My bathroom window faces a brick wall of another apartment building three feet away. I would like to paint the brick outside my window with a simple white wash to allow more reflected light into my bathroom. Since the other building has no windows or doors on that side, no one would ever see the paint. But could doing this damage the brick? Could I get in trouble?

headline: Two Proposals, One on the Set of ‘Hamilton’
abstract: The couple, having met in 2004 and then again in 2008, had first one marriage proposal and then another.
lead_paragraph: Leah Marie Michalos and Rachel Ann Pitkin were married Sept. 16 at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Miriam Niles, a friend of Ms. Pitkin and a nondenominational Christian minister in Washington, officiated, with the Rev. Jeffrey N. Wise, a friend of Ms. Michalos and a Lutheran pastor, taking part.

headline: It’s a Good Thing Big Brother Was Watching
abstract: The couple had a crush on each other since their early 20s despite their college football rivalry.
lead_paragraph: Jill Robin Wagner and Michael Sean Deutsch were married Sept. 16 at Kimpton Hotel Eventi in New York. Rabbi Steven Moskowitz officiated.

headline: Stephen Strasburg Plans to Be All In This October
abstract: The Washington Nationals pitcher has made just one postseason start in his career. That, he hopes, is about to change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The emergence of the Washington Nationals as one of the best teams in baseball was spearheaded by players such as Jayson Werth, Ryan Zimmerman, Bryce Harper and Stephen Strasburg.

headline: U.S. Expands Kabul Security Zone, Digging In for Next Decade
abstract: The remaking of the Afghan capital almost triples the footprint of a fortresslike Green Zone to take in nearly all ministries and Western compounds.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Soon, American Embassy employees in Kabul will no longer need to take a Chinook helicopter ride to cross the street to a military base less than 100 yards outside the present Green Zone security district.

headline: Rape Accusations Against Italian Police Dismay Florence
abstract: Two Americans have accused officers of raping them, an unsettling allegation for a city that relies on money spent by foreign students and reveres its Carabinieri police force.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — As a group of American students studying abroad followed their professor on a field trip through an exquisite Renaissance palazzo, an Italian television reporter around the corner offered viewers a different kind of tour.

headline: Simone Rocha: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The World’s Most Powerful Woman Won’t Call Herself a Feminist
abstract: Angela Merkel doesn’t need you to call her one either.
lead_paragraph: TORGAU, Germany — Angela Merkel has spent her political career playing down her gender: shunning a feminist label, offering modesty, caution and diligent preparation as an implicit contrast to male swagger. The chancellor seems to be coasting to re-election next Sunday as the most powerful woman in the world.

headline: British Virgin Islands: ‘Knocked Down, but Not Knocked Out’ by Irma
abstract: The Times visited tiny Jost Van Dyke, whose 298 residents set up a de facto command center at a bar that has some of the ravaged island’s only working generators.
lead_paragraph: JOST VAN DYKE, B.V.I. — This little island draws boats from all around the globe to its powdery beaches and ebullient bar scene. Thousands of visitors come for the boisterous New Year’s Eve celebration at Foxy’s — a wooden beachside bar decorated with the license plates and flags that visitors have left behind since the 1960s.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon croon to us.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon is about crooning. Specifically, it’s about how crooning couldn’t have been invented until after sound recording, or at least sound reproduction, was first invented.

headline: Ports 1961: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Cake Is His ‘Art.’ So Can He Deny One to a Gay Couple?
abstract: A Colorado case that pits a gay couple against a baker who refused to serve them will mostly center on the protections of free speech.
lead_paragraph: LAKEWOOD, Colo. — Jack Phillips bakes beautiful cakes, and it is not a stretch to call him an artist. Five years ago, in a decision that has led to a Supreme Court showdown, he refused to use his skills to make a wedding cake to celebrate a same-sex marriage, saying it would violate his Christian faith and hijack his right to express himself.

headline: How a Cake Triggered a Supreme Court Case
abstract: A Colorado baker’s refusal to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple has led to showdown at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado baker’s refusal to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple has led to showdown at the Supreme Court.

headline: Saved From Harvey’s Floodwaters, Twice. So How Did She End Up Dead?
abstract: A Houston great-grandmother was put on a rescue boat. That much is known. But how she got off, was rescued a second time and then ended up in the morgue is one of Hurricane Harvey’s mysteries.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It was a hard choice, but in the end it was no choice at all. A small rescue boat had come up the driveway, offering help. Carl Ellis was with his frail, 73-year-old mother, Wilma Jean. The boat had room for one.

headline: The Big Question as the U.N. Gathers: What to Make of Trump?
abstract: All eyes will be on the new American president at his first United Nations General Assembly as international leaders take his measure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every year, the president heads to New York to welcome world leaders to the United Nations General Assembly. He gives a speech and meets with an endless string of foreign potentates to discuss a dizzying array of complicated, often intractable issues.

headline: The China Puzzle
abstract: President Trump has reason to worry about China, but he should seek areas of agreement with Beijing and enlist it in addressing global problems.
lead_paragraph: Steve Bannon, the former presidential confidante, was as apocalyptic as ever about China on the eve of his trip to Hong Kong. The man who had all but declared “economic war” with China in earlier interviews said to a Times reporter, “A hundred years from now, this is what they’ll remember — what we did to confront China on its rise to world domination.” On arrival, in a speech to a big investor conference, he seemed to have softened a bit, praising China’s leadership and offering hopes that a trade war could be averted.

headline: ‘Enough Already,’ Said God
abstract: A secret transcript of a recent conversation between the Almighty and a televangelist.
lead_paragraph: The famous televangelist Jim Bakker, who is preaching again on television after a rape accusation and a prison term for financial fraud, recently warned that Christians would start an armed insurrection if President Trump were impeached. “If it happens, there will be civil war in the United States of America,” Bakker told his television audience. “The Christians will finally come out of the shadows, because we are going to be shut up permanently if we’re not careful.”

headline: What Trump Needs to Learn From Vietnam
abstract: The stalemate strategy didn’t work there. It won’t in Afghanistan either.
lead_paragraph: In August 1965, a resolute President Lyndon Johnson said: “America wins the wars that she undertakes. Make no mistake about it.” But the strategy on which he committed America to its ill-fated intervention in Vietnam that year did not aim at winning, but at not losing. McGeorge Bundy, Johnson’s national security adviser, later admitted as much to a biographer, saying that he had personally approved a strategy that used just enough military pressure to achieve a battlefield stalemate, which “would eventually compel the Vietnamese Communists to compromise their objectives,” forcing them to the negotiating table or to a Korea-style armistice.

headline: The Baseball Theory of Relativity
abstract: Giancarlo Stanton will set a record if he hits 62 homers. Or will he?
lead_paragraph: For Major League Baseball, 2017 has been a season of extremes. The Los Angeles Dodgers went on an extraordinary tear, winning 84 percent of the time during one 67-game stretch. Then they pulled a U-ie and lost all but one of their next 17 games. The Cleveland Indians entered the weekend Friday night having triumphed in 22 straight games, an American League record.

headline: The Boys of Brexit: Tony Blair and Nigel Farage
abstract: The veteran pols on either side of the vituperative, vertiginous Brexit debate spar.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It seems like an impossible feat. But Tony Blair has done it. He has made himself even less popular in Britain.

headline: Amber Tamblyn: I’m Done With Not Being Believed
abstract: A man called me a liar, and it reminded me of all the people who have doubted me.
lead_paragraph: When I was 21, I went into the office of a producer of the television show I was starring in to discuss a big problem. By this point I had been acting for more than a decade, and the show was very successful and beloved. Still, I was nervous about facing the firing squad of Emmys that sat behind him and saying what I had to say.

headline: Is Nothing Funny, Mr. President?
abstract: Humor is a policy tool that leaders from both parties deploy. But not Trump.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump almost never laughs. The leader of the free world frequently displays a tight-lipped smile, but mirth-wise, that is as far as he will go. Except for the fact that Nazis don’t seem to mind him too much, Mr. Trump is the Captain von Trapp of commanders in chief.

headline: Eric Cantor: How to End the Immigration Wars
abstract: Congress should use this crisis to improve DACA, but it shouldn’t stop there.
lead_paragraph: THE decision by the Trump administration to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program and to defer instead to Congress for a solution to the problem threw a wild card onto a congressional agenda that was already packed. But far more important, it thrust the lives of roughly 800,000 of our friends and neighbors into instant uncertainty.

headline: Meet Me in St. Louis, Bezos
abstract: Why Amazon’s new headquarters decision should be an act of patriotism.
lead_paragraph: A couple of interesting things are happening with the massive companies that rule our online lives. First, the lords of Silicon Valley face political headwinds. There is tech-company skepticism on the populist right, the anti-corporate left and the good-government center. There is talk of trustbusting and utility-style regulation from Steve Bannon as well as Bernie Sanders. There is a palpable feeling, as Ben Smith of Buzzfeed wrote last week, that the online giants’ “golden age” of political immunity is ending, and that it might be “normal politics, normal regulation” from here on out.

headline: Ellen Pao: Has Anything Really Changed for Women in Tech?
abstract: Let’s not be blinded by optimism or biased by what we want to see. We could be stuck in an unfair loop indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — Just five years ago, I sued Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm in Silicon Valley where I had worked since 2005, for bias and gender discrimination. The lawsuit, which I lost, led to the venture capital world closing ranks against me. I had trouble finding work. People were afraid to support me publicly. I was called a fraud, and greedy, and was accused of being in a fake marriage.

headline: They Have Money. (Shhh.)
abstract: An essay about the discomfort some people feel about their wealth provoked strong reactions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Erect a Statue of This Civil Rights Hero
abstract: The Rev. Joseph De Laine, an unsung activist, deserves to be honored.
lead_paragraph: If you look closely at Brown v. Board of Education, the landmark 1954 school desegregation decision, you’ll see that Brown wasn’t a single case. It was five cases consolidated into one. Briggs v. Elliott, the first of them, took place in my home state, South Carolina. Briggs came about after the Rev. Joseph De Laine organized a group of black parents in Clarendon County to petition for equal educational facilities. The man who stood fast against that request — the Elliott of Briggs v. Elliott — was the chairman of the school board, Roderick Miles Elliott. Or as he was known in my family, Uncle Roddy.

headline: This Season, Western Wildfires Are Close By and Running Free
abstract: Extreme fire behavior — difficult to predict and dangerous to fight — has been the watchword for the year. And these fires are menacing more lives and property.
lead_paragraph: TROUTDALE, Ore. — Some fires suddenly exploded in size. One in Montana doubled in 24 hours, charring 78 square miles overnight — an area bigger than Brooklyn. Already burning fires started new ones, shooting embers like artillery barrages, including one that apparently jumped several miles across the Columbia River into Washington from Oregon, breaching a natural firebreak that long seemed impregnable.

headline: Halpern: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Our Constitution Wasn’t Built for This
abstract: It’s lasted 230 years, but the founders didn’t plan for this economy.
lead_paragraph: Exactly 230 years ago, on Sept. 17, 1787, a group of men in Philadelphia concluded a summer of sophisticated, impassioned debates about the fate of their fledgling nation. The document that emerged, our Constitution, is often thought of as part of an aristocratic counterrevolution that stands in contrast to the democratic revolution of 1776. But our Constitution has at least one radical feature: It isn’t designed for a society with economic inequality.

headline: Nicopanda: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: He’s on Wanted Posters in U.S., and Campaign Posters in Pakistan
abstract: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed has a $10 million American bounty on his head but lives in the open in Pakistan. Now, he has become the face of a new political party.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — For years, Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, one of the most-wanted militant leaders in South Asia, has lived in the open in Pakistan despite a $10 million American bounty on his head. He has mocked efforts by the United States to capture him and led large public gatherings in Lahore, Pakistan’s second-largest city.

headline: Protests Flare in St. Louis for Second Night After Ex-Officer’s Acquittal
abstract: Peaceful demonstrations during the day gave way to outbursts of violence at night, the police said, after the acquittal of an officer charged in the 2011 killing of a black driver.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — On edge after a night of protests that led to dozens of arrests and a broken window at the mayor’s home, this city faced more demonstrations on Saturday after the acquittal of a white former police officer who shot and killed a black driver.

headline: Burberry M/W: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Super Looper
abstract: A roller-coaster ride of a crossword.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is the second crossword in The New York Times from Mark MacLachlan. His first was a Thursday with a decidedly chemical taste. Not surprisingly, Mark is a professor of chemistry. While this second offering doesn’t have a chemical theme, it does have a couple of interesting chemical entries, which we’ll get to anon.

headline: Syrian Children Return to School Amid the Ruins in a Rebel-Held Area
abstract: In the battered suburb of Douma on the outskirts of Damascus, students are trying to resume their studies, which have been cut short by war.
lead_paragraph: Small boys wearing backpacks gathered in a Syrian elementary school on Saturday, smiling as they walked between desks covered in dust.

headline: Trump Administration Moves to Open Arctic Refuge to Drilling Studies
abstract: An Interior Department memo has proposed lifting restrictions on seismic surveys in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which may open it to drilling.
lead_paragraph: An internal Interior Department memo has proposed lifting restrictions on exploratory seismic studies in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a possible first step toward opening the pristine wilderness area to oil and gas drilling.

headline: Brenda Lewis, Versatile American Soprano, Is Dead at 96
abstract: A singing actress known for performing work by contemporary composers, Ms. Lewis originated signal roles in the opera house and on the Broadway stage.
lead_paragraph: Brenda Lewis, an American soprano whose mastery of a vast range of vocal styles carried her to the world’s foremost opera houses and the Broadway stage, died on Saturday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 96.

headline: ‘The New Washington’: Mitch McConnell
abstract: Carl Hulse spoke with the majority leader about why the Democrats didn’t strike as good of a spending deal as they let on, his non-reaction to Steve Bannon’s attacks and more.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode:

headline: Quotation of the Day: Twice Saved From Houston Floods but Still, Mysteriously, a Victim
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 17, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Somebody called me and told me that my sister was floating in the water. ‘China, your sister is on CNN.’”

headline: Juggalos on the Mall? Just Another Weekend of Washington Protests
abstract: A Saturday filled with protests seemed a potentially combustible mix, but clashes were limited to a few harsh words exchanged near some porta-potties, and the city went about its business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bound for the Lincoln Memorial, thousands of demonstrators ambled block after block through the city, shouting obscenities, their faces streaked with sweat and clown paint.

headline: Yankees Continue to Batter the Orioles (and the A.L. East)
abstract: Didi Gregorius and Greg Bird each hit a homer for the second consecutive day as the Yankees beat the Orioles for the 12th time in 18 games this year.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when playing against their divisional rivals in the American League East was the most daunting part of the Yankees’ schedule. As recently as last season, the Yankees lost 41 of the 76 games they played against the other A.L. East teams, while going 49-37 against everyone else they faced.

headline: British Press Watchdog Says Climate Change Article Was Faulty
abstract: The Mail on Sunday was forced to issue a note saying an article asserting that U.S. researchers had manipulated data was inaccurate.
lead_paragraph: A self-policing group within the British news industry has forced the tabloid The Mail on Sunday to acknowledge that an article it published asserting that climate researchers in the United States had manipulated data was inaccurate and misleading.

headline: Nursing Home Deaths Prompt New Rules by Florida Governor
abstract: They will require nursing homes and assisted living facilities to have generators that can keep comfortable temperatures for four days after power loss.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida announced new rules on Saturday requiring nursing homes and assisted-living facilities in the state to have generators capable of maintaining comfortable temperatures for at least 96 hours in the event of a power loss.

headline: Tropical Storm Maria Is Latest Threat to Caribbean Islands
abstract: A hurricane watch has been issued for Antigua and Barbuda, and Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands may be affected by the middle of next week.
lead_paragraph: The tiny two-island nation of Antigua and Barbuda in the Caribbean faced its third hurricane watch in two weeks as forecasters announced on Saturday the formation of Tropical Storm Maria, which was expected to strengthen to a hurricane.

headline: Memo on the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge
abstract: The text of the Interior Department memo.
lead_paragraph: The text of the Interior Department memo.

headline: Corrections: September 17, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 17, 2017.
lead_paragraph: BOOK REVIEW

headline: Carrie Levande, Matthew Colbert
abstract: The couple met in 2009 while attending Cornell.
lead_paragraph: Carolyn Brown Levande and Matthew Joseph Colbert were married Sept. 16 at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson officiated.

headline: Meghan Cross, Todd Breeden
abstract: The bride and groom, both venture capitalists in New York, met as colleagues in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Anna Blanche Cross and Todd Peterson Breeden were married Sept. 16 in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the Fairview Country Club.

headline: Kayla Zemsky, Michael Myers
abstract: Kayla Zemsky, a fan of sculptor Andy Goldsworthy, weds Michael Myers, his project manager, at Chestnut Hill Guest House and Farm in Orchard Park, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Kayla Haughton Zemsky, the daughter of Leslie Haughton Zemsky and Howard A. Zemsky of Buffalo, was married Sept. 16 to Michael Alfred Gerard Myers, the son of Catherine Cherry-Myers of Orchard Park, N.Y., and the late Michael M. Myers. Rabbi Ronne Friedman officiated at Chestnut Hill Guest House and Farm, the home of the groom’s mother.

headline: Kristina Altman, Daniel Nealis
abstract: The couple met in 2014 at the dinner party of a mutual friend.
lead_paragraph: Kristina Geraldine Altman and Daniel Patrick Nealis were married Sept. 16 at Fir Creek Ranch in Moran, Wyo., which is owned by the bride’s family. Dr. Douglas Vlchek, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

headline: Allison Fedirka, Andrew Horn
abstract: The bride is an analyst for an online geopolitical publication and the groom crafts United States defense policy and strategy for Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Allison Marie Fedirka and Andrew Luxton Horn were married Sept. 16 in Arlington, Va. The Rev. Dr. Elizabeth Foss, the pastor of Cherrydale United Methodist Church, performed the ceremony there.

headline: Emily Barlow, Brian Darrow
abstract: The bride and groom, who met as Teach for America corps members, now both work in education.
lead_paragraph: Emily Applegate Barlow and Brian Alan Darrow were married Sept. 16 at the Chocorua Island Chapel on Squam Lake in Holderness, N.H. The Rev. Harold E. Masback III, a Congregational minister, officiated in a ceremony incorporating Jewish and Christian traditions.

headline: Andrea Katz, Marshall Spevak
abstract: The couple met in 2013 at a Young Democrats of America convention in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Beth Katz and Marshall Aaron Spevak were married Sept. 16 by Rabbi Barry L. Schwartz at One Atlantic, an events space in Atlantic City.

headline: Grace Heusner, Jonathan Levinsohn
abstract: The bride is a lawyer and the groom is a medical and Ph.D. student at Yale.
lead_paragraph: Grace Emily Heusner and Jonathan Lewis Barfod Levinsohn were married Sept. 16 in Arcadia, Mich. Richard Walsh, Jr., a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Watervale Inn.

headline: Katina Fortunato, Alexander Baren

headline: Three Planets Will Slide Behind the Moon in an Occultation
abstract: The moon will momentarily block Venus, then Mars and then Mercury, offering a vivid reminder of the cosmic clockwork of our solar system.
lead_paragraph: At the start of this week, the moon will play a game of planetary peek-a-boo as it momentarily blocks Venus, then Mars and then Mercury in the sky. Although it will be difficult to see this disappearing act in much of the world, it’s a vivid reminder of the cosmic clockwork at play in our solar system.

The entire league is likely scratching its collective head, however, after the Denver Broncos simply crushed the Dallas Cowboys. Here is what we learned in Week 2:

She was 95.

In a few hours, more than a dozen Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army fighters from his village would strike a nearby police post with an assortment of handmade weapons.

headline: Shinzo Abe: Solidarity Against the North Korean Threat
abstract: The international community must stay united and enforce the sanctions against Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The whole world confronts an unprecedented, grave and imminent threat from North Korea. On Sept. 3, the regime carried out a reprehensible nuclear test. Late last week, it launched a ballistic missile over my country, Japan, only two weeks after a similar missile launch. By repeatedly testing missiles — in violation of United Nations Security Council resolutions — Pyongyang has shown its reach now extends to the United States and Europe.

headline: When Affirmative Action Isn’t Enough
abstract: Black and Hispanic students are more underrepresented at top schools nationwide, despite affirmative action. Some schools, though, saw gains.
lead_paragraph: How did Elvis Kahoro, the son of a truck driver and a retirement home aide in Kennesaw, Ga., end up attending Pomona College, an elite liberal arts school over 2,000 miles from his hometown? The total cost of tuition, fees and room and board at Pomona, east of Los Angeles, runs over $67,000 per year. Fewer than 10 percent of applicants are admitted.

abstract: The Times’s advertising reporter found out what it’s like to be a brand in the middle of a social-media-driven disaster.

headline: Nawaz Sharif’s Supporters Win a Pakistan Election
abstract: The by-election was cast as a chance for voters to speak out on a Pakistan Supreme Court ruling that ousted Mr. Sharif as prime minister in July.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Voters in Pakistan’s second-largest city handed a narrow victory to the governing party on Sunday, according to unofficial results of a bitterly contested by-election seen as a referendum on Nawaz Sharif, who was forced to resign as prime minister by the Supreme Court over corruption charges.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: The Ways We Inherit Historical Traumas
abstract: In “Survivor Café,” Elizabeth Rosner writes about how we recognize and cope with the traumas that directly affected previous generations.
lead_paragraph: Both of Elizabeth Rosner’s parents survived the Holocaust, and her new book is about “trans-generational epigenetic inheritance” — a fancy name for the “environmentally induced changes passed down from one generation to the next.” Rosner writes that this inheritance is common in plants, has been observed in mice and is only starting to be understood in humans. One researcher told her: “If you are looking for it all to be logical and fall into place perfectly, it isn’t going to yet.” “Survivor Café” grapples with big and possibly unanswerable questions about how we recognize and cope with the traumas we inherit, and how we can properly keep alive the personal stories behind great historical atrocities even after everyone who lived through them is gone. “I am more afraid of forgetting my parents’ stories than I am of forgetting my own,” Rosner writes. Below, she discusses the trip to Germany that inspired her book, the urgency she felt while writing it and more.

headline: The Rare, Potent Fuel Powering North Korea’s Weapons
abstract: Despite a long record of intelligence warnings, there is no evidence that Washington has ever moved with urgency to cut off Pyongyang’s access to a rocket fuel.
lead_paragraph: When North Korea launched long-range missiles this summer, and again on Friday, demonstrating its ability to strike Guam and perhaps the United States mainland, it powered the weapons with a rare, potent rocket fuel that American intelligence agencies believe initially came from China and Russia.

headline: Irma is Most Recent Stop for ‘Adrenaline Junkies’ of Disaster Rescue Team
abstract: The United States has 28 search-and-rescue teams it can send into disaster zones. The New York Times embedded with one for its work after Hurricane Irma.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The rescuers from California Task Force 1 had finally dried out. They had waded in the floodwaters left by Hurricane Harvey in southeast Texas. They had slept in stalls ordinarily used for horses, and two of the task force’s men had survived being suctioned through a large pipe.

headline: Europe Weighs Taxing Tech Companies and the Fed Meets
abstract: The likes of Google and Amazon could see their tax bills rise, and the Fed appears to be poised to start selling off securities.

headline: Harry Dean Stanton: Fully Inhabiting Scenes, Not Stealing Them
abstract: In his long career, the actor became a cult figure and an emblem of cool in films as distinct as “Alien” and “Paris, Texas.”
lead_paragraph: Soon after the start of “Paris, Texas,” Harry Dean Stanton appears in an astonishing gorge called the Devil’s Graveyard. He’s playing a lost soul, Travis, who will spend the rest of the film getting found. Right now, though, surrounded by rock formations that evoke the westerns of John Ford, Travis is an enigma. On foot and wholly alone save for a watchful eagle, wearing a red cap and an inexplicable double-breasted suit, Travis looks like a former cowboy or maybe a businessman who took a wrong turn. He looks like someone Dorothea Lange might have photographed during the Great Depression. He looks like the American West, all sinew, dust and resolve.

headline: Buck Showalter’s Big Gamble Pays Off, Leaving the Yankees Stagnant
abstract: Showalter, the Baltimore Orioles’ manager, decided on a risky intentional walk with one out to go, but it produced a win that prevented the Yankees from moving in the standings.
lead_paragraph: Considering the frustrating way the previous three hours had unfolded for the Yankees, things could definitely have been worse for them as the bottom of the ninth inning unfolded at Yankee Stadium on Sunday.

headline: Gin Wong, Who Designed Futuristic Buildings in Los Angeles, Dies at 94
abstract: Perhaps best known for a Union 76 gas station in Beverly Hills, Mr. Wong also did design work for the Los Angeles airport and CBS Television City.
lead_paragraph: Gin Wong, a Chinese-born architect whose modernist designs helped define the postwar landscape of Los Angeles in structures as diverse as a gas station, CBS Television City and Los Angeles International Airport, died on Sept. 1 in Beverly Hills. He was 94.

headline: Awkward Moment at the Barber Shop
abstract: A man is surprised to see someone he thought he’d left behind.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In Apple-Pie Order
abstract: A very colorful puzzle by Tom McCoy.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today we have a straightforward theme that’s still imaginative. The constructor is Tom McCoy. This is his 29th New York Times crossword and his eighth Monday. (He has no themeless Fridays or Saturdays yet, but a very impressive 14 Sunday crosswords.)

headline: Italy, Going It Alone, Stalls the Flow of Migrants. But at What Cost?
abstract: Some charge that Rome’s solution to the crisis may be strengthening Libya’s most rapacious warlords, while condemning thousands to misery.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As they scrambled to curb the flow of migrants, Europe’s leaders wrestled with a vexing question: How to stop the ruthless Libyan militias that control the human-trafficking trade from dispatching countless boats across the Mediterranean?

headline: Emmys 2017 Red Carpet
abstract: See what Issa Rae, Nicole Kidman, Donald Glover and more celebrities wore on television’s biggest award show.
lead_paragraph: See what Issa Rae, Nicole Kidman, Donald Glover and more celebrities wore on television’s biggest award show.

headline: Tillerson Says U.S. May Close Cuba Embassy Over Mystery Ailments
abstract: Closing the embassy would be the most dramatic action yet by the Trump administration to return the Cuba relationship to its Cold War deep freeze.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering closing the recently reopened United States Embassy in Havana after 21 Americans associated with the embassy experienced a host of unexplained health problems.

headline: Saint’s Tour Arrives in New York to Fanfare From the Faithful
abstract: Legions of followers of Padre Pio lined up outside St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan to see a bloodstained glove and other relics of the 20th-century saint.
lead_paragraph: There were concert style T-shirts, commemorative merchandise and a line that stretched down 51st Street in Manhattan on Sunday, buzzing with all the anticipation of a rock show. In place of a stadium was St. Patrick’s Cathedral, and at the center of it all was St. Padre Pio — or, more specifically, his cloak and his bloodstained glove.

headline: When U.N. Envoy Nikki Haley Talks, Does President Trump Listen?
abstract: Ms. Haley has cast herself as someone who can sway President Trump on important foreign policy issues — including the value of the United Nations itself. This week will test her influence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Friday in August, the president of the United States casually said at a televised news briefing that his administration could not rule out a “military option” to respond to the crisis in Venezuela.

headline: What We’re Watching at This Year’s United Nations General Assembly
abstract: North Korea, Iran, Myanmar, Climate Change. Oh, and Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — When the 193-member United Nations convenes this week for the annual General Assembly speeches and high-level meetings, world leaders will be paying closest attention to the words and gestures of the most unconventional — and powerful — leader among them.

headline: The United Nations Explained: Its Purpose, Power and Problems
abstract: As representatives of the body’s 193 member countries gather for the annual session of the General Assembly, a look at how the institution has attempted to live up to its founders’ ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Almost everybody has heard of the United Nations. But how many people know what it actually does? Or how it works? Or why, as world leaders gather for the 72nd session of the United Nations General Assembly, the institution has struggled to live up to the promise of its founders: making the world a better, more peaceful place?

headline: Amid Opioid Crisis, Insurers Restrict Pricey, Less Addictive Painkillers
abstract: Drug companies and doctors have been accused of fueling the opioid crisis, but some question whether insurers have played a role, too.
lead_paragraph: This article was written through collaboration between The New York Times and ProPublica, the independent, nonprofit investigative journalism organization.

headline: Why Are Drug Prices So High? We’re Curious, Too
abstract: The New York Times and ProPublica have teamed up to investigate who is to blame for skyrocketing drug prices — and have turned up some surprising answers.
lead_paragraph: This much is clear: The public is angry about the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs. Surveys have shown that high drug prices rank near the top of consumers’ health care concerns, and politicians in both parties — including President Trump — have vowed to do something about it.

headline: Heng on Opposition and Democracy in Cambodia
abstract: Hun Sen’s government continues to accuse the opposition of colluding with the United States.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia has been in power for more than 30 years. He recently vowed to stay in power and resist foreign interference. Authorities in the country arrested opposition leader, Kem Sokha and voted last week to approve his prosecution on charges he committed treason in collusion with the United States.

headline: Now It’s Hurricane Maria, and Caribbean Braces for New Hit
abstract: Less than two weeks after Hurricane Irma devastated the islands, residents learned Tropical Storm Maria had intensified and was heading their way.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Oh, no. Not again.

headline: Emmy Awards Analysis
abstract: Our television critics discussed the highs and lows of the 69th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards. Read their analysis and reactions to the nominees and winners.
lead_paragraph: Our television critics discussed the highs and lows of the 69th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards. Read their analysis and reactions to the nominees and winners.

headline: St. Louis Protests: Police Say They ‘Owned’ the Night After 80 Arrests
abstract: Protests continued for a fourth day in St. Louis after a former police officer who fatally shot a black man was acquitted. Here’s a look at what happened.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — After a third night of protests following the acquittal of a white former St. Louis police officer in the fatal shooting of a black man, city officials early Monday were striking a more aggressive tone, with the acting police chief telling reporters that the police had “owned” the night.

headline: Rolling Stone, Once a Counterculture Bible, Will Be Put Up for Sale
abstract: After 50 years, the magazine founded and nurtured by Jann Wenner is bowing to the pressures of a troubled industry.
lead_paragraph: From a loft in San Francisco in 1967, a 21-year-old named Jann S. Wenner started a magazine that would become the counterculture bible for baby boomers. Rolling Stone defined cool, cultivated literary icons and produced star-making covers that were such coveted real estate they inspired a song.

headline: An Absent Friend Casts a Shadow Over a Rookie’s Tour Milestone
abstract: Patrick Cantlay reached the PGA Tour’s season finale but will be there without his friend and former caddie Chris Roth, who was killed by a hit-and-run driver last year.
lead_paragraph: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — With an 11-foot birdie putt on the last hole of the BMW Championship on Sunday, the rookie Patrick Cantlay earned a spot in the PGA Tour’s 30-man season finale. It was a breakthrough that Cantlay and his close friend Chris Roth had imagined they would someday experience together.

headline: Emmys 2017 Winners List
abstract: A look at the shows, actors and production teams who won at the 69th Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: These are the major winners of the 69th annual Primetime Emmy Awards. Additional winners are listed at emmys.com.

headline: Stephen Colbert Opens 2017 Emmy Awards
abstract: Stephen Colbert capped his opening monologue with an extended roast of President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert capped his opening monologue with an extended roast of President Donald Trump.

headline: Trump Lawyers Clash Over How Much to Cooperate With Russia Inquiry
abstract: The debate, which led to an angry confrontation between two members of the legal team, could shape the course of the special counsel’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s legal team is wrestling with how much to cooperate with the special counsel looking into Russian election interference, an internal debate that led to an angry confrontation last week between two White House lawyers and that could shape the course of the investigation.

headline: Facebook Knows More About Russia’s Election Meddling. Shouldn’t We?
abstract: The social media giant owes it to its users to let them know if they interacted with what amounts to a digital spy. And that’s just the start.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what we know, so far, about Facebook’s recent disclosure that a shadowy Russian firm with ties to the Kremlin created thousands of ads on the social media platform that ran before, during and after the 2016 presidential election:

headline: Sean Spicer Makes a Cameo at the Emmys
abstract: The former White House press secretary appeared on stage behind a rolling lectern.
lead_paragraph: The former White House press secretary appeared on stage behind a rolling lectern.

headline: Sean Spicer Joins Stephen Colbert at the Emmys
abstract: The former White House press secretary poked fun at himself in an Emmy bit, but some critics were not ready to laugh along.
lead_paragraph: It was not the cameo you might have expected to see.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: The Prison I Live in Now
abstract: It’s well established that this show loves to watch Jamie process trauma. This week’s violence was almost piling on.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of drama: If a group of irrepressible scamps find a contraband pistol in the first act, one of them has to lose a hand by the third act.

headline: Stephen Colbert’s Emmys Opening Monologue
abstract: Mr. Colbert’s first time hosting the Emmys had one big podium-sized surprise.
lead_paragraph: As expected, Stephen Colbert’s first time hosting the Emmy Awards featured swipe after swipe against President Trump, as well as digs against those in the room, whom he mocked for having another night dedicated to patting themselves on the back. But the most talked about moment was when the former White House press secretary Sean Spicer made a surprise appearance near the end of the monologue. Here is a full transcript:

headline: In Alaska’s Far-Flung Villages, Happiness Is a Cake Mix
abstract: The store-bought box, one of the few dependable food items in a place of scarcity, is tricked out for dinners and fund-raisers by many a “cake lady.”
lead_paragraph: GAMBELL, Alaska — In a modest boardinghouse on an Alaskan island just 30 miles across the sea from Russia, a handwritten order form hangs on the refrigerator. There are photos of cakes a few women in this village can make for you: rectangles of yellow cake and devil’s food enrobed in buttercream, with local nicknames piped out in pink.

headline: Alec Baldwin: ‘At Long Last, Mr. President, Here Is Your Emmy’
abstract: Alec Baldwin, who impersonates President Trump on “Saturday Night Live,” won best supporting actor in a comedy series.
lead_paragraph: Alec Baldwin, who impersonates President Trump on “Saturday Night Live,” won best supporting actor in a comedy series.

abstract: A running collection of transcripts of the most notable acceptance speeches from the Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the notable acceptance speeches from the 69th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards.

headline: Answers to Your Questions About the Equifax Hack
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: How Facebook Is Changing Your Internet
abstract: Behind the scenes, Facebook is involved in high-stakes diplomatic battles across the globe that have begun fragmenting the internet itself.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes, Facebook is involved in high-stakes diplomatic battles across the globe that have begun fragmenting the internet itself.

headline: Facebook Faces a New World as Officials Rein In a Wild Web
abstract: The web is not as open as it once was, with nation-states exerting their power over the internet. Facebook and other tech companies are dealing with the consequences.
lead_paragraph: On a muggy, late spring evening, Tuan Pham awoke to the police storming his house in Hanoi, Vietnam.

headline: Dylan, Obama and a Crown of Thorns: 50 Years of Rolling Stone
abstract: A music magazine whose influence stretched beyond entertainment and into the world of politics could elevate a career with its cover.
lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone helped define the counterculture epoch. It filled its pages with the words of renowned writers, including Hunter S. Thompson, Tom Wolfe, Cameron Crowe and Greil Marcus. Its covers minted stars. And while it focused on music, its influence ultimately stretched into pop culture, entertainment and politics.

headline: Review: In ‘Oh My Sweet Land,’ Dinner Is Served. Don’t Come Hungry.
abstract: Set in a real home, an unnamed woman cooks while she relates piercing tales about the horrors in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through “Oh My Sweet Land,” the writer-director Amir Nizar Zuabi’s wrenching and shrewd solo show, you will begin to worry about the onions. You have heard them sizzle in the pan, seen the steam rise up, smelled the sweet-savory aroma. And then you should have forgotten those onions, because the unnamed woman frying them (a ferocious and radiant Nadine Malouf) is telling you a terrible story. The story is about a prisoner who knows he must leave Syria when a captain of the secret police brings the man’s daughter to the jail. The captain tickles her and plies her with chocolates, an oblique and sickening threat.

headline: Review: ‘In the Blood’ and the Singular Talent of Suzan-Lori Parks
abstract: The play, about a single mother with five children, explores the dimensions of American sexual and societal guilt in a first-rate revival.
lead_paragraph: Tragedy stalks Hester La Negrita, the heroine of Suzan-Lori Parks’s “In the Blood,” as relentlessly as it does the doomed queens of Euripides and Racine. Played with exquisitely clouded radiance by Saycon Sengbloh in the Signature Theater’s first-rate revival of this genre-mutating 1999 drama, the illiterate Hester would probably never presume to talk in such highfalutin terms.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Season 1, Episode 2: Rinse and Repeat
abstract: Vinnie and Eileen flash some entrepreneurial spirit.
lead_paragraph: The second episode of “The Deuce” is book ended by scenes of two cops, Alston and Flanagan, rounding up prostitutes to toss in the paddy wagon. As law enforcement, this catch-and-release ritual seems to accomplish little more than irritating the pimps, who have surely budgeted for it anyway. The cops face annoyance but not resistance: The women dutifully pile into the van and sit around in lockup, waiting to get bailed out. In a particularly satisfying detail, they’re brought in on the Chinese takeout order. Egg rolls, the No. 9 with extra lobster sauce. The usual.

headline: President Trump, Emmy Punching Bag
abstract: Although he wasn’t in the building, President Trump had a large presence at the Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Though he wasn’t in the building, President Trump had a large presence at the Emmy Awards.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, September 18, 2017.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, September 18, 2017.
