abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 18, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Cake mixes are the center of our little universe. I have four damn shelves full.”

headline: A Down Payment With a Catch: You Must Be an Airbnb Host
abstract: A start-up in Seattle will lend money to home buyers who promise to make a room available for rent continuously for up to three years.
lead_paragraph: “If only we had the down payment” may be one of the most frequent complaints among aspiring home buyers in cities across the country.

headline: When Adolescents Want Tattoos or Piercings
abstract: Chipped teeth from tongue piercings or infected cartilage are among the health risks parents and pediatricians should watch for.
lead_paragraph: When I was reviewing for my recertification exam recently, I gave the wrong answer to a question about an infected ear. Not a standard inner ear infection; this was a painful red swollen outer ear, in an 18-year-old. I thought she had a skin abscess, and said to put her on antibiotics for standard skin organisms. Wrong. The adolescent in the problem had recently had a high piercing done, through the cartilage up toward the top of her ear, and she had perichondritis, an infection of the tissue layer that surrounds and nourishes that cartilage.

headline: After Chelsea Ties Arsenal, a Feeling Something Has Been Lost
abstract: Casting off the last member of a generation of player-warriors, Chelsea still can bare its teeth, but it seems to be missing its customary bite.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The plan that Arsenal defenders Per Mertesacker and Rob Holding hatched to stymie Chelsea’s Diego Costa in last season’s F.A. Cup final was little more than a variation on the old good cop/bad cop routine.

headline: Review: The Emmys Figured Out How to Handle Trump
abstract: References to President Trump on Sunday’s Emmys were plentiful and pointed but contained. “Saturday Night Live” raked in awards in what felt like a political statement.
lead_paragraph: Last year the Emmy Awards took place under the looming shadow of Donald J. Trump, nominated but not yet president, and the humor directed at him had a raw, tense, incredulous edge.

abstract: What rare genetic condition can make giraffes lack their trademark spots?

headline: ‘Friends,’ the Sitcom That’s Still a Hit in Major League Baseball
abstract: Several Latino ballplayers relish the show as a device for polishing their English. (And who can resist Joey?)
lead_paragraph: When he returns home from the stadium, Philadelphia Phillies shortstop Freddy Galvis often gets into bed and watches reruns of “Friends.” Even though Galvis, 27, is from Venezuela and grasped English late in life, he is so addicted to the sitcom that he has watched every episode of the 10-season run at least five times — and counting — to the exasperation of his wife.

headline: Safest Bet in Sports: Men Complaining About a Female Announcer’s Voice
abstract: When Beth Mowins made her debut last week on “Monday Night Football,” some male viewers objected to the way she sounded.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “Shrill.”

headline: Cuomo Proposes Stricter Regulations for Credit Reporting Agencies
abstract: The governor said the Equifax breach was a wake-up call that stronger laws were needed to protect consumers’ personal information.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, responding to the massive security breach at Equifax, will propose regulations on Monday that subject credit reporting agencies to the same rules as banks and insurances companies in order to protect consumers.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Jemele Hill Controversy?
abstract: Should public figures like Jemele Hill be allowed to express their political views without fear of losing their jobs or encountering other retaliation?
lead_paragraph: As you may already know, Jemele Hill, who co-hosts the 6 p.m. “SportsCenter” program on ESPN, called President Trump a white supremacist on Twitter last week. She also wrote, “Trump is the most ignorant, offensive president of my lifetime. His rise is a direct result of white supremacy. Period.”

headline: Feminism and the Future of Philosophy
abstract: Viewing it only as a political cause that benefits women ignores its full potential.
lead_paragraph: “There is a deep well of rage inside of me. Rage about how I as an individual have been treated in philosophy; rage about how others I know have been treated; and rage about the conditions that I’m sure affect many women and minorities in philosophy, and have caused many others to leave.” Those words, written a decade ago by Sally Haslanger, a distinguished professor of philosophy at M.I.T., well express the moral energy behind the feminist ferment currently shaking American philosophy.

headline: Is Trump a White Supremacist?
abstract: Accounting for Trump and those who surround him.
lead_paragraph: “Donald Trump is a white supremacist who has largely surrounded himself w/ other white supremacists.”

headline: Complacency Could Kill Health Care
abstract: Graham-Cassidy is the Donald Trump of health reform.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t yet read Hillary Clinton’s “What Happened,” but it seems pretty clear to me what did, in fact, happen in 2016.

headline: Who Gets to Define Campus Rape?
abstract: Betsy DeVos is rolling back the clock on university policies around sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Who should have the right to define rape: survivors who have experienced sexual violence or those who are accused of perpetrating it?

headline: Using the E.P.A. to Prop Up Big Coal
abstract: But practical-minded utility executives are still shutting down coal-fired plants in favor of more affordable energy sources.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is unflinching in its misbegotten campaign to protect the coal industry from what has become an obvious and inevitable decline. Eight months in, the administration has already killed, or is in the process of killing, rules that would prevent the dumping of coal mining wastes in streams, impose a temporary moratorium on new mine leases in the West, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions from coal-fired power plants — one of President Barack Obama’s most important efforts to resist climate change. All of this to prop up an industry whose workers would be best served not by false promises of new mining jobs, but by aggressive programs to retrain them for a changing economy.

headline: What Punk Rock Meant to Communist Yugoslavia
abstract: The Party authorities let us scream obscenities and insult the system. But did we change society?
lead_paragraph: ZAGREB, Croatia — In Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, during the 1984 Winter Olympics, Elvis J. Kurtovic and his Meteors were performing a cover of Bob Dylan’s “Maggie’s Farm” in a stifling little basement hall before 300 wild punk rock fans. But it wasn’t Dylan’s rendition they were playing, it was their own, a deliberate extension that ostensibly was about Margaret Thatcher, the prime minister of Britain. But actually, Elvis J. Kurtovic and his Meteors were singing about — in an extremely brutal way that should have been unacceptable to the Communist authorities — Yugoslavia’s own prime minister, Milka Planinc.

headline: Squeeze Myanmar’s Military
abstract: The U.N. is unlikely to pass new sanctions, but there is nothing to stop Washington from acting on its own.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, when President Barack Obama announced that, given Myanmar’s progress on democracy, the United States would lift remaining sanctions on Myanmar’s military, rights groups warned that easing the pressure was premature: The country’s democratic transition was incomplete, they said, the military retained vast powers and its record on human rights was dismal.

headline: Libraries Can Be More Than Just Books
abstract: Pairing affordable housing with new library branches can revitalize New York’s far-flung communities.
lead_paragraph: For all of Sunset Park’s celebrated taquerias, dim sum parlors and picturesque piers, the most popular destination in that neighborhood might just be the local branch of the Brooklyn Public Library. Despite its squat concrete frame and fluorescent lights — a far cry from the neighboring brownstones — the library draws a capacity crowd most days.

headline: What’s the U.S.’s Best Chance With North Korea? Russia
abstract: Moscow is in a unique position to help defuse the current crisis.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia is usually seen as relatively unimportant to most discussions about the North Korea nuclear crisis, yet it is in a unique position to help de-escalate it.

headline: Witness a Changing Amazon
abstract: Visit a reserve in the remote central Amazon jungle, where researchers are shedding new light on how stronger, more frequent storms are driving major changes in the forest.
lead_paragraph: Visit a reserve in the remote central Amazon jungle, where researchers are shedding new light on how stronger, more frequent storms are driving major changes in the forest.

headline: What to Read Before a Jewish Heritage Trip
abstract: These three books explore Jewish culture and how it has evolved since the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: Jewish culture in Europe and Israel has been explored deeply in literature. Below, three books look at Jewish heritage, the Holocaust and what has followed.

headline: Survival of the Prettiest
abstract: Darwin’s theory of aesthetics may be the sexiest, most dangerous idea in evolution.
lead_paragraph: (“The Evolution of Beauty” by Richard Prum was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: How Party Bosses, Not Voters, Pick Candidates in New York
abstract: In one of the last, most powerful vestiges of Tammany Hall-style politics, New York party bosses pick the politicians when vacancies occur.
lead_paragraph: It was hardly a secret that Herman D. Farrell Jr. had planned to retire from the New York State Legislature. The governor feted him at a goodbye breakfast in June. Colleagues sent the 85-year-old assemblyman off to shouts of “for he’s a jolly good fellow.” They even named a state park after him.

headline: How the Internet Kept Humming During 2 Hurricanes
abstract: While millions lost electricity across Florida, and thousands of homes and businesses were flooded in Miami and Texas, the data centers powering the internet held firm.
lead_paragraph: At one node of the industrial backbone that keeps the internet running, employees sheltered from the worst of Hurricane Irma in a stairwell of a seven-story building in downtown Miami. When the power had gone out, diesel generators instantly kicked in to keep the lights on and prevent the internet from going down.

headline: The Life of a Live-in Super in Bedford-Stuyvesant
abstract: Tony Obey has spent most of his life within a few blocks of the large house converted to apartments where he works as the superintendent.
lead_paragraph: Elmo Anthony Obey Jr. has lived nearly all his life within a few blocks’ radius of the converted Bedford-Stuyvesant house where he lives and works as the superintendent.

headline: Iran’s Holding of 2 Americans Is Illegal, U.N. Experts Find
abstract: The opinion on Baquer and Siamak Namazi by the Working Group on Arbitrary Detention may embarrass Iran’s president as he attends the General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s imprisonment of a prominent Iranian-American father and son on vaguely defined charges of collaboration with the United States is illegal, and they should be freed, a United Nations panel of international legal experts has concluded.

headline: The Real Unknown of Climate Change: Our Behavior
abstract: Scientific predictions about Earth’s sensitivity to greenhouse gases have generally held up. But no one can predict how much more carbon pollution people will choose to pump out.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Harvey bore down on the Texas coast, few people in that state seemed to understand the nature of the looming danger.

headline: From Poland to Lithuania: A Writer’s Search for Her Jewish Past
abstract: From the Jewish districts of historic cities to small, out-of-the-way towns once known as shtetls, the author finds remnants of the past at every turn.
lead_paragraph: I think I was in an iced-over bus lot in northeastern Poland, standing in front of a mound of desecrated gravestones, when I first had the feeling that Jewish heritage travel in Europe might be a mistake. I had been walking with a guide and an interpreter, both Polish men in late middle age, through Makow Mazowiecki, a small town about 45 miles north of Warsaw. This was where two of my great-grandparents were born in the late 19th century, when Jews made up nearly half the local population.

headline: What Jamie Dimon Is Missing About Bitcoin
abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive may be pessimistic about the worth of digital currencies. But an investor says, he isn’t seeing the full picture.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, is the most successful banker of his generation. He has successfully navigated a challenging environment over more than a decade, and his firm is stronger than ever.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: The Sheriff Bind
abstract: If they hold an undocumented criminal too long, sheriffs are violating the constitution. If they don’t, they’re crossing the White House.

abstract: Monday: What to see, eat and do in Astoria, a food truck from Macao, and a free Citi Bike ride.

abstract: Quick-and-dirty relationship fixes — tested by researchers.
lead_paragraph: After studying thousands of couples, the psychologist Eli Finkel has an explanation for the decline in people’s satisfaction with their marriages over the past four decades: It’s a matter of emotional supply and demand.

headline: Giving Migraine Treatments the Best Chance
abstract: To be most effective, new therapies may require patients to recognize and respond to the early warning signs of a migraine.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve never had a migraine, I have two things to say to you:

headline: Morning Agenda: Tech Giants Feel the Pressure Worldwide
abstract: Facebook, Google and other technology titans are encountering more resistance to their empire-building, both abroad and at home.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, American technology giants have received a chilly reception from skeptical audiences in Europe, including from government regulators, while at home, companies like Google, Facebook and Amazon have been largely lauded for their innovation and their astonishing growth.

headline: Myanmar Draws Scorn for Rohingya Crisis, but Few Urge Sanctions
abstract: Under military rule, Myanmar endured some of the world’s harshest sanctions. A return to those seems unlikely, despite violence against a Muslim minority.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Despite international condemnation of Myanmar’s campaign of violence against the Rohingya people, there have been few calls for a return to the sort of sanctions that were long a part of the country’s relationship with the West.

headline: Roksanda: Spring 2018

headline: Driver of Charter Bus in Fatal Queens Crash Was Fired by M.T.A.
abstract: The driver had been fired by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in 2015 after he was convicted of driving under the influence, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A charter bus driven by a man who had been fired two years ago by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority barreled through an intersection in Queens early Monday and collided with a New York City bus, killing the charter bus driver and two other people and injuring 16 others, the authorities said.

headline: In Syria, the World’s Democracies Failed Us
abstract: The free world kept a safe distance when Syria erupted.
lead_paragraph: Umar ibn al-Khattab, a chief adviser and successor to the Prophet Muhammad, was the last truly just ruler in the Arab world, and he died 1,400 years ago. Khattab was called “al-Farooq” — the one who distinguishes between right and wrong.

headline: How Operation Car Wash Is Exposing Political Crime in Brazil
abstract: Nothing better illustrates the complex web of Brazil’s decline than operation Car Wash, the wide-ranging investigation into corruption.
lead_paragraph: Brazil, a nation rich in natural resources, fertile lands and cultural diversity, has struggled for decades with underdevelopment. Some blame it on the “custo Brasil,” or “Brazil cost” — the accumulated price, in cash, time and other resources, of doing business here — pointing to the weight of bureaucracy, high taxes and poor investment. Others cite insufficient investments in infrastructure, science, technology and education.

headline: Stanislav Petrov, Soviet Officer Who Helped Avert Nuclear War, Is Dead at 77
abstract: After a Soviet computer system warned that the Americans had launched a nuclear missile attack, he decided — correctly — that it was a false alarm.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of Sept. 26, 1983, Stanislav Petrov helped prevent the outbreak of nuclear war.

headline: Comments: The Best Health Care System

lead_paragraph: To better understand one of the most heated American policy debates, we conducted a small tournament to explore the idea of what makes a great health care system, and which nation might do it best. A panel of judges chose between Germany, Switzerland, France, Britain, Canada, Australia, the United States and Singapore.

Then, on a chain-link fence that seems to guard nothing, a hand-lettered sign pointing down a rocky path: ‘‘Cacti.’’

Television’s night of nights, once spurned by blue chip designers and their megastar clients as a dreary also-ran, has emerged to compete with the Oscars as a powerful contender in the image-boosting derby.

headline: Obamacare Repeal, Thought Dead in July, May Be Revived in Senate

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act sprang back to life on Monday as Senate Republicans pushed for a showdown vote on new legislation that would do away with many of the health law’s requirements and bundle its funding into giant block grants to the states.

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Gary D. Cohn, the top White House economic adviser, told ministers from several major allies on Monday that the Trump administration was “unambiguous” about its plans to withdraw from the Paris agreement on climate change unless new terms were met.

headline: On the Market in Toronto

headline: Homes for Sale in Toronto
abstract: This week we visit and review properties in South Riverdale and Upper Beach.
lead_paragraph: The real estate market in Toronto peaked earlier this year when the average home price hit 919,086 Canadian dollars ($753,679) in April, sending the industry into a panic that the area might be experiencing a real estate bubble that would soon burst. The Ontario government responded with legislation designed to stabilize the market, including a foreign buyer’s tax, fees on vacant properties and expanded rent controls. These actions helped push the average home price down to 732,292 Canadian dollars ($600,502) last month.

headline: Outlook for Android, Plain and Simple

lead_paragraph: When Joanairys Merced was living in group foster care, she once baked Ina Garten’s cheesecake for herself and a dozen other girls.

headline: Indian Police File Murder Charge After Times Describes Cover-Up
abstract: Villagers, police officers and political leaders appear to have worked together to hush up a woman’s murder. A New York Times article on the case led to an arrest.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A man suspected of bludgeoning his wife to death in front of at least a dozen people has been charged with murder, after the killing in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh was described in an article in The New York Times.

headline: Meet a Looser, More Personal Seinfeld
abstract: In “Jerry Before Seinfeld,” his first new special in decades, the comedian tries out reminiscences of his early years, a shift that only sometimes works.
lead_paragraph: When Jerry Seinfeld started criticizing political correctness in comedy a few years ago, some nodded their heads and others rolled their eyes, but nearly everyone was baffled. Why would the squeaky clean, rigorously inoffensive comic even care?

headline: Banksy Strikes Again, With Nod to Basquiat
abstract: Two new Banksys, which appear to be a homage, of sorts, have popped up at the Barbican Center, days ahead of a show of Jean-Michel Basquiat’s work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — People lining up at a ticket booth under a Ferris wheel. Police officers questioning a skeleton figure as his dog looks on. Two new Banksys have popped up at the Barbican Center here, authenticated on Sunday by the British graffiti artist on his Instagram account.

headline: Bill and Melinda Gates Grade the World’s Health
abstract: Poor nations get high marks for meeting important goals. But the Gateses warn that deep aid cuts and donor fatigue still could doom millions.
lead_paragraph: Bill and Melinda Gates handed the world a report card last week, assessing its progress on 18 global health indicators: infant mortality, AIDS, vaccine use, smoking rates and so on.

lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Trump Soft-Soaps the U.N. Of Course, It Was Only Day 1 . . .
abstract: “We pledge to be partners in your work,” the America First president told a room full of world leaders in New York. He even tweeted nice.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The polished and protocol-obsessed diplomats of the United Nations hardly knew what to expect when President Trump arrived at their citadel along the East River on Monday for the first time since taking office. But this was not it.

headline: The Shameful Embrace of Sean Spicer at the Emmys
abstract: In this morally addled country, fame matters more than the reasons for it.
lead_paragraph: I’m an awards-show geek who usually spends the morning after the big event nattering about who was unjustly robbed, who was unwisely dressed and whether it’s a felony in Hollywood to consume more than 300 calories a meal, because it sure looks that way.

headline: The Emerging Designer Who Makes Both Furniture — and Jewelry
abstract: Eny Lee Parker is a busy and accomplished 28-year-old. And we haven’t seen her clothing line yet.
lead_paragraph: Accented with dusty pink carpeting and velvety elephant-ear plants, Eny Lee Parker’s exhibition booth at the Sight Unseen Offsite fair in New York last May was as modern as it was earthy; a Pantone time capsule of how we decorate now. The 28-year-old designer and ceramist filled the space with furniture that felt unattached to the whims of trend, however, with mixed-media pieces like a glass coffee table with juglike terracotta legs and a lamp with a cone-shaped ceramic base and an upturned metal shade. For the clay elements in her designs, Parker employs a unique technique: She applies a clear glaze, sandblasts it to remove the high gloss and finally coats the pieces with beeswax, which deepens their tone.

headline: 1851 | Born Into a Racial Turmoil That Has Never Ended
abstract: In issue No. 1, The Times described the recent killing of a slaveholder in an attack that has been called the first battle of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Happy birthday? Not entirely.

headline: Pirogi From ‘the Great Comet of 1812’ Hit the Lower East Side
abstract: The producers of the closed Broadway musical will open Samovarchik, the foods of the samurai and more news.
lead_paragraph: After the musical “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” closed on Broadway this month, the producers — including Darren Sussman and Roman Gambourg — realized there was such enthusiasm for the production that they decided to keep up the interest by opening a place to serve pirogi. (Theatergoers were given a small box containing one potato pirogen at the start of the show.) Samovarchik, a little spot with a counter and a few seats indoors and out, offers a menu of Russian specialties made from the recipes of Lena Gambourg, a native of St. Petersburg, a real-estate broker and Mr. Gambourg’s mother. Pirogi, pelmeni dumplings, savory kachapuri pastries, borscht and beef stroganoff are among the richly alluring temptations: Samovarchik, 11 Stanton Street (Bowery), 646-882-0333.

headline: A Father and Son Sail Through Homer’s ‘Odyssey’ Together
abstract: In “An Odyssey,” Daniel Mendelsohn recounts what happened when his 81-year-old father enrolled in one of his classes at Bard College.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Mendelsohn is a classics scholar, a translator, a memoirist and a quick-witted literary and television critic. The idea of reading his account of being trapped on a theme cruise — the theme is Homer’s “Odyssey” — is an attractive one.

headline: Amateur U.K. Archaeologists Stumble on a Roman Masterpiece
abstract: With just two weeks to dig, a team of local people uncovered a spectacular mosaic, what experts are calling the most important of its kind in 50 years.
lead_paragraph: BOXFORD, England — Their ages range from 9 to about 80. They include a butcher and a builder. Some devoted vacation days to laboring on their hands and knees in an open field.

headline: High Tech Meets High Art in a 3-D Opera
abstract: Michel van der Aa’s “Blank Out,” at the Park Avenue Armory, brings together a live singer onstage and another who appears only in a 3-D film.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — As a boy soprano in the youth opera company that his parents ran in their small town, the Dutch composer Michel van der Aa once accompanied his father to the clockmaker who was painting a set for them. What he saw, he recalled recently, was revelatory.

headline: Meredith Monk Wins the Gish Prize
abstract: The venerated multidisciplinary artist of New York’s avant-garde will collect $250,000 for pushing boundaries and contributing to social change.
lead_paragraph: The Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, one of the most generous arts honors in the United States, has been awarded to the singer, composer and multidisciplinary artist Meredith Monk, whose wordless vocal pirouettes and otherworldly theater compositions have reverberated in New York and internationally for five decades.

headline: Review: ‘The Peculiar Patriot’ Puts Iron Bars Between Best Friends
abstract: The National Black Theater production of Liza Jessie Peterson’s monologue explores the personal and societal costs of mass incarceration.
lead_paragraph: Betsy LaQuanda Ross, the intense and charming chatterbox at the center of Liza Jessie Peterson’s “The Peculiar Patriot,” is nothing if not a devoted friend. When she makes the long slog by bus to see her bestie, Joann, Betsy often brings something to show. Lately she’s started working on a quilt, and its first square represents Joann.

headline: In Mexico, Weavers Embrace Natural Alternatives to Toxic Dyes
abstract: Concerned about the health impacts of textile chemicals, traditional artisans are producing vivid colors from crushed insects and forest plants.
lead_paragraph: TEOTITLÁN DEL VALLE, Mexico — As a child, Porfirio Gutiérrez hiked into the mountains above the village with his family each fall, collecting the plants they would use to make colorful dyes for blankets and other woven goods.

headline: Thomas Rhett’s ‘Life Changes’ Is Country’s First No. 1 Album in 2017
abstract: The National opened at No. 2 and Odesza at No. 3 in a week that replenished the Top 5 with new releases.
lead_paragraph: Nine months into the year, a country album has finally reached No. 1 on Billboard’s chart. Thomas Rhett’s “Life Changes” (Valory) opens with the equivalent of 123,000 album sales, including 94,000 copies sold as complete albums and 30 million streams, according to Nielsen.

headline: How to Fight ‘Fake News’ (Warning: It Isn’t Easy)

lead_paragraph: No, the Reese’s Peanut Butter Cup is not being discontinued. No, Earth  will not be plunged into darkness for 15 days. And, no, Katy Perry did not broker peace with the Islamic State.

headline: Arrests in London Tube Bombing Stun a Suburban Town

The other was a 21-year-old from Syria who fled the civil war there and made his way via Egypt to London, where he found work at a fried-chicken shop.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: More than nearly any of his remaining peers from rock’s 20th-century heights, Mr. McCartney cares about giving audiences their money’s worth. His shows these days — the Barclays gigs are  Sept. 19 and 21 — are multiple-hour affairs, full of hits from throughout his storied career, and he performs each one with all his heart; even if it’s his 400th time or so through “Maybe I’m Amazed,” it never feels like he’s coasting. SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON

headline: Myanmar Follows Global Pattern in How Ethnic Cleansing Begins

Joining the mix of edgier spaces on New York’s Lower East Side is the Sara Kay Gallery, opening Sept. 28 in an 1890 townhouse at 4 East 2nd Street — the former home of the Rivington Arms gallery.

headline: Seizures Drove Him Out of Coaching. Now He’s Back, and So Are They.
abstract: Jerry Kill’s epilepsy forced him off the sidelines two years ago. But he’s back this season, managing his health and his love of the game with the blessing of his family, and his boss.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Jerry Kill knew he was headed down a familiar path. Kill, the Rutgers offensive coordinator, acknowledged as much on a lunchtime walk around the Scarlet Knights’ football stadium two weeks ago.

headline: John W. Lewis, China Expert and Vietnam War Critic, Dies at 86
abstract: Professor Lewis opposed the war in Southeast Asia early on and later made unconventional peace overtures to Beijing and North Korea.
lead_paragraph: John W. Lewis, a political scientist whose unconventional peace overtures — engaging in Ping-Pong diplomacy with China and providing antibiotics to North Korea — helped lift the Bamboo Curtain, died on Sept. 4 in Stanford, Calif. He was 86.

headline: ‘He’s Doing Poorly,’ Says Wife of Princeton Student Jailed in Iran
abstract: Xiyue Wang, a Ph.D. candidate, has been imprisoned in Iran for more than a year. His wife, Hua Qu, spoke about the trauma that his detainment has caused.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Iran’s imprisonment of Xiyue Wang, a naturalized United States citizen from China who is a Ph.D. candidate in history at Princeton University, has left his family, colleagues and supporters despondent and outraged. Mr. Wang, 37, was arrested in August 2016 while doing dissertation research at public archives in Iran. The Iranian judiciary said this July that he had been sentenced to a 10-year term for espionage.

headline: North Korea, Rohingya, Hurricane Maria: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Genes Color a Butterfly’s Wings. Now Scientists Want to Do It Themselves.
abstract: In two new studies, researchers turned to DNA editing to learn how master genes shape the patterns and colors of butterfly wings.
lead_paragraph: Only nature can paint the gorgeous colors and patterns on a butterfly’s wings. But scientists said on Monday that they have mastered the first steps and hope in time to control the entire coloring system, making it possible to design living butterfly wings.

headline: Cuomo, Nudged, Finally Gives de Blasio the Nod in Mayor’s Race
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, never one to hand out endorsements easily, finally gives one to his frequent foe, Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It wasn’t effusive, electric, or particularly enthusiastic, but there it was: On Monday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo endorsed Mayor Bill de Blasio’s run for a second term.

headline: A Short List of What We Like Right Now
abstract: A new Malick Sidibé retrospective, designer building blocks — and a dream house in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Next month, Malick Sidibé, the photographer known for his black-and-white images of youth culture in Mali, will have his biggest retrospective since his death last year. Opening at the Fondation Cartier in Paris, ‘‘Malick Sidibé: Mali Twist’’ features more than 125 never-before-seen images, to be displayed alongside his iconic shots of sub-Saharan hipsters showing off their bell-bottoms, wristwatches, radios and James Brown records, and couples dancing barefoot, their heads nearly touching, to music we can no longer hear.

headline: Will Bill O’Reilly’s Latest ‘Killing’ Book Climb the Charts?
abstract: The disgraced TV host is still churning out history books, but without his perch at Fox, can he sell them?
lead_paragraph: Every fall for the last six years, Bill O’Reilly, the former Fox News host, published a new book in his blockbuster “Killing” series. And every year without fail, the books shot to the top of the nonfiction best-seller list.

headline: Six Lightweight Jackets That Are Perfect for Travel
abstract: Inspired by a look on Gabriela Hearst’s spring runway, we tracked down updated versions of the classic staple you can buy now.
lead_paragraph: A khaki jacket in a light cotton or linen has long been a staple in the closets of men and women — traditionally worn on exotic journeys to tropical locales. Yves Saint Laurent’s famous ’60s safari shirts (which he also wore himself) are an enduring example of the appeal and versatility of the style. They were inspired by his muse, the French model Danielle Luquet de Saint Germain, who was fond of wearing men’s clothing and whom Saint Laurent also credited as the genesis of his Le Smoking design. At Gabriela Hearst’s spring/summer 2018 show in New York, she sent out a limited-edition putty-colored wrap blazer and matching skirt, in sustainable linen, that interpreted the classic travel suit in a wonderfully sexy, modern way. While you wait for her designs to hit stores, here are a few versions of the timeless design you can buy now — perfect for any imminent adventures.

headline: U.S. Governors at U.N. Assembly: ‘You Have Allies’ on Climate Change
abstract: As world leaders gather at the United Nations for the world body’s annual General Assembly, a group of American state governors is taking an increasingly high-profile role on climate change.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Jerry Brown, the governor of California, huddled on Sunday night with European, Brazilian and small-island leaders — gathered here for the 72nd session of the United Nations General Assembly, which formally begins on Tuesday — and pledged to work with them on climate change. On Monday he met with António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, to discuss the future of the Paris agreement.

headline: Laura Ingraham Will Host 10 O’Clock Show as Part of Fox News Shuffle
abstract: Ms. Ingraham will host “The Ingraham Angle” weeknights starting Oct. 30 as part of a prime-time shake-up that moves Sean Hannity to 9 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Laura Ingraham, the conservative radio host who has been a steady supporter of President Trump, will host a Fox News show at 10 p.m. Eastern, as part of a prime-time shake-up that moves Sean Hannity to 9 p.m.

headline: Boris Johnson Gets Back in the Brexit Game
abstract: With an inflammatory essay, he has injected himself into the debate over how to leave the E.U. — and possibly devised an intricate route to the top.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What is Boris Johnson up to this time?

headline: Here Are the 10 National Monuments the Interior Department Wants to Shrink or Modify
abstract: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke has proposed that President Trump make changes to 10 national monuments, including Bears Ears in southern Utah, according to a memo addressed to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke has proposed that President Trump make changes to 10 national monuments, including Bears Ears in southern Utah, according to a memo addressed to the White House.

headline: Mystics Discover Hurdles on the Way to a W.N.B.A. Breakthrough
abstract: Washington made a big splash by acquiring Elena Delle Donne in the off-season, but its ambitions were derailed by a combination of overseas commitments and injuries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Washington Mystics General Manager and Coach Mike Thibault pondered his team’s accomplishments in Year 1 of the Elena Delle Donne era, his answer was as complicated as the campaign itself.

headline: Best Buy’s Secrets for Thriving in the Amazon Age
abstract: Hubert Joly, Best Buy’s chief executive, has reshaped nearly every aspect of the business. He explains the playbook behind the company’s success.
lead_paragraph: While running errands the other day, I ducked into a local Best Buy to pick up a pair of new headphones. What I saw inside was shocking.

headline: Student Loan Creditor, Fined for ‘False’ Lawsuits, Must Halt Collections
abstract: Under a federal settlement, the National Collegiate Student Loan Trusts will refund millions to borrowers and temporarily suspend debt collections.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s largest holders of private student-loan debt must refund millions of dollars to borrowers and temporarily stop many of its collection activities, under a settlement with federal regulators announced on Monday.

headline: Country of the Week: South Africa
abstract: Can you find South Africa on a map? Did you know South Africa has 11 official languages? Test your knowledge with our new quiz.
lead_paragraph: Can you find South Africa on a map? Did you know South Africa has 11 official languages? Test your knowledge with our new quiz.

headline: Woman Says Fox News Banned Her After She Accused Charles Payne of Rape
abstract: The political commentator Scottie Nell Hughes said her allegation that Mr. Payne, an anchor on the network, had sexually assaulted her led to her being blacklisted as a guest.
lead_paragraph: Fox News, which for more than a year has dealt with the fallout from an embarrassing sexual harassment scandal, was sued on Monday by the political commentator Scottie Nell Hughes, who claimed that she had been raped by the longtime anchor Charles Payne and was then retaliated against by the network after she came forward with her allegation.

headline: After 4 Years in Jail, Release Looms for Irishman in Egypt
abstract: An Egyptian court acquitted a high-profile Irish prisoner on Monday, but handed a five-year sentence to an American arrested at the same time.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A young Irish prisoner punched the air and wept with relief at a prison courthouse near Cairo on Monday, as a judge acquitted him on all charges relating to a 2013 political protest that turned violent.

headline: Going a Round at P.J. Clarke’s
abstract: A late-afternoon beer leads to a memorable encounter.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hurricane Maria, St. Louis, Sean Spicer: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Brazil’s New Top Prosecutor Inherits Politically Explosive Cases
abstract: Raquel Dodge, the first woman to serve as Brazil’s attorney general, takes office amid a vast corruption investigation that extends to the president.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Raquel Dodge, Brazil’s new attorney general, stood on stage during her swearing-in ceremony on Monday, vowing to clamp down on graft and quoting Pope Francis on the corrosive effect of corruption on societies.

headline: Racially Charged Incidents Shake Cornell Campus
abstract: An assault of a black student was at least the second bias-related episode at the Ivy League university since the start of the school year.
lead_paragraph: Cornell University, the Ivy League university in Ithaca, N.Y., has been roiled by two racially charged incidents in recent weeks, with the new school year barely off the ground.

headline: And This Year, the Emmy Goes to … Politics
abstract: From “Saturday Night Live” to “The Handmaid’s Tale,” shows with a political — and anti-Trump — viewpoint ruled the day at the Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In any other year, big-hearted dramas like “Stranger Things” or “This Is Us” or a period drama like “The Crown” would dominate the Emmys.

headline: Georgia Tech Student Leader Is Shot Dead by Campus Police
abstract: Scout Schultz, 21, the president of the gay and transgender student group, left behind suicide notes, was carrying a knife and yelled “shoot me” at the officers. One did.
lead_paragraph: A campus police officer shot and killed the president of a gay and transgender student group outside a Georgia Tech dormitory in Atlanta on Sunday. A cellphone video shared widely online showed the student, who was believed to be holding a knife, yelling “shoot me” at the officers before one opened fire.

headline: Iran Is Smuggling Increasingly Potent Weapons Into Yemen, U.S. Admiral Says
abstract: The outgoing top Navy admiral in the Middle East said that Iran is helping worsen the conflict in Yemen by giving rebels more precise missiles to fire deeper into Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: The top American admiral in the Middle East said on Monday that Iran continues to smuggle illicit weapons and technology into Yemen, stoking the civil strife there and enabling Iranian-backed rebels to fire missiles into neighboring Saudi Arabia that are more precise and far-reaching.

headline: With a Search Warrant and a Threatened Indictment, Mueller’s Inquiry Sets a Tone
abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, has aggressively used warrants and subpoenas for the Russia investigation, sending a message in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul J. Manafort was in bed early one morning in July when federal agents bearing a search warrant raided his Virginia home. They took binders stuffed with documents and copied his computer files, looking for evidence that Mr. Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, set up secret offshore bank accounts. They even photographed the expensive suits in his closet.

headline: Prosecutors Open Criminal Investigation Into Equifax Breach
abstract: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. are investigating a cyberattack that potentially exposed personal data on 143 million Americans.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation into the massive data breach at Equifax, which potentially exposed the personal information of up to 143 million Americans, including their Social Security and driver’s license numbers.

headline: Bobby Heenan, Professional Wrestling Personality, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Heenan, known as the Brain, managed some of wrestling’s top stars and was one of the most colorful commentators the business has seen.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Heenan, a professional wrestler who found greater success managing other wrestlers and working as a quick-witted commentator, becoming one of the most colorful figures in a flamboyant business, died on Sunday in Tampa, Fla. He was 72.

headline: Trump Envisions a Parade Showing Off American Military Might
abstract: At a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations, Mr. Trump said he got the idea after watching the Bastille Day parade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Monday that he was looking into staging a display of American military might in a Fourth of July parade down Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Senate Passes $700 Billion Pentagon Bill, More Money Than Trump Sought
abstract: The Senate and House will have to reconcile versions of the bill that differ over whether to create a Space Corps to manage satellite and other space-related programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare act of bipartisanship on Capitol Hill, the Senate passed a $700 billion defense policy bill on Monday that sets forth a muscular vision of America as a global power, with a Pentagon budget that far exceeds what President Trump has asked for.

headline: Push for Nafta Overhaul May Fall Short, U.S. Negotiator Says
abstract: A tight timeline and ambitious goals leave the Trump administration with a narrow path to success in talks on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top United States trade negotiator said Monday that it was unclear whether Canada, Mexico and the United States could reach a deal to overhaul the North American Free Trade Agreement within the ambitious timetable set by the Trump administration.

headline: Trump at U.N. Talks Up, but Does Not Press, Mideast Peace
abstract: President Trump will try to resolve the feud in the Persian Gulf, but not the one between the Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump will try to play the peacemaker in his first appearance at the United Nations General Assembly this week, but not on the issue that American presidents have historically spent their energy and prestige on at diplomatic gatherings like this.

headline: Protesters Descend on St. Louis, and Police Respond: ‘We’re in Control’
abstract: We asked law enforcement experts and activists to assess the police response. Some saw it as well-reasoned, while others called for quieter rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — “We’re in control,” the acting police chief of this city announced early Monday, as he reported scores of arrests in protests that culminated with broken windows at downtown businesses, overturned trash cans and upended concrete planters. “This is our city,” Lawrence O’Toole, the acting chief, went on to say, “and we’re going to protect it.” Police later reported that 123 people had been arrested.

headline: Long Delays Cloud Police Department Disciplinary Trials
abstract: Data obtained by The Times shows how long it takes for the Police Department to decide on a case after an officer is found to have used excessive force.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City police officer who tackled the former tennis star James Blake steps into a dim departmental trial room this week, Mr. Blake will have waited more than 700 days to see the officer answer for his actions since a civilian oversight board found that he used excessive force.

headline: Like Issa Rae, I’m Also ‘Rooting for Everybody Black’
abstract: Expressing black pride is not the same as being racist toward whites.
lead_paragraph: I was 13 when the black woman I was rooting for on “American Idol” won. After black women failed to reach the top spot in the first two seasons, Fantasia finally did. With vocals straight out of a church choir in North Carolina, she deserved it.

headline: Mattis Leaves the Door Open to Military Options in North Korea
abstract: The defense secretary also said the United States had not shot down any missiles so far because they did not directly threaten American territory or allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies have not shot down any North Korean missiles because Pyongyang has yet to launch one that directly threatens American or Japanese territory, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said on Monday.

headline: Hurricane Maria Makes Landfall in Dominica as Other Islands Brace for Potential Disaster
abstract: The Caribbean islands scrambled to prepare for another big storm, Hurricane Maria, which was barreling through only days after Irma killed more than two dozen.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Maria barreled through the islands that curve through the Caribbean on Monday night as it quickly grew into “a potentially catastrophic Category 5 hurricane” and made landfall in Dominica, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Russian Court Refuses to Reveal Holocaust Hero’s Fate
abstract: A Russian court ruled against the claim filed by Raoul Wallenberg’s niece, who wanted get documents about his mysterious death.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian court refused on Monday to order Russia’s top security agency to release documents that would shed light on the mysterious death of Raoul Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat and Holocaust hero.

headline: In Turkey’s New Curriculum, Ataturk, Darwin and Jihad Get Face-Lifts
abstract: Critics say the overhaul of more than 170 curriculum topics by the Turkish government represents a frontal assault on the country’s fragile tradition of secularism.
lead_paragraph: When high school students in Turkey arrive for the fall term, Charles Darwin will be conspicuously absent from biology classes.

headline: Didi Gregorius, Shortstop and Occasional Slugger, Is at Heart of Yankees’ Revival
abstract: The Yankees took a bit of a gamble with Gregorius when they acquired him three years ago, but he has developed into a worthy heir to Derek Jeter.
lead_paragraph: When Didi Gregorius joined the Yankees, everyone else in the regular lineup was at least 30 years old. Players can excel in their 30s, of course, but they rarely get much better, and they tend to cost a lot.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Gives Up Secret Service Protection, Seeking Privacy
abstract: Separately, Kellyanne Conway, a counselor to the president, is losing her protection after a revision in the assessment of threats against her, an official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald Trump Jr., the president’s eldest son, has elected to forgo protection by the Secret Service, according to a senior administration official, and another top White House official is losing hers.

headline: Fixing the ‘Brain Damage’ Caused by the I.P.O. Process
abstract: Entrepreneurs are exploring new ways to list companies on exchanges — and placate stock-holding Silicon Valley employees — while avoiding the pitfalls of initial public offerings.
lead_paragraph: “It seems like a way of living in hell without dying.”

headline: State Department Tightens Rules for Visas to U.S.
abstract: If applicants do something they failed to mention in their application in their first three months in the United States, it would jeopardize their status.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department is giving immigration and consular officials new grounds to deny entry to visitors to the United States or to kick them out if they are already here.

headline: British Columbia Proposes Ban on Corporate and Union Donations in Elections
abstract: The measures are expected to become law as the far western province tries to ban big money in politics.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER — The government of British Columbia introduced legislation on Monday to ban corporate and union donations as part of a broad effort to tighten the reins on political contributions in provincial elections, remove outside influence and erase the province’s reputation as the “wild west” of Canadian political financing.

headline: Satellite Images Show More Than 200 Rohingya Villages Burned in Myanmar
abstract: Satellite images show that at least 200 villages of Myanmar’s Rohingya ethnic minority have been set ablaze since late August.
lead_paragraph: Satellite images show that at least 200 villages of Myanmar’s Rohingya ethnic minority have been set ablaze since late August.

headline: Bugs on the Road
abstract: A quiet sort of crossword from Don Gagliardo and Zhouqin Burnikel.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The team of Don Gagliardo and Zhouqin Burnikel are back with their 12th collaboration for The Times.

headline: Review: In ‘Charm,’ Challenges Emily Post Never Dreamed Of
abstract: A transgender etiquette expert faces pupils who have bigger issues than what fork to use in Philip Dawkins’s new play.
lead_paragraph: To an etiquette maven like Miss Darleena Andrews — you can call her Mama — proper introductions are crucial. So I wish that Philip Dawkins’s “Charm,” which opened on Monday at the Lucille Lortel Theater, did a better job of acquainting us with her unusual story.

headline: Trump Administration Rejects Study Showing Positive Impact of Refugees
abstract: A draft report by the Department of Health and Human Services contradicts a central argument made by advocates of deep cuts in refugees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trump administration officials, under pressure from the White House to provide a rationale for reducing the number of refugees allowed into the United States next year, rejected a study by the Department of Health and Human Services that found that refugees brought in $63 billion more in government revenues over the past decade than they cost.

headline: Jaime Garcia Leads Yankees Past Twins, Bringing His 2017 Season Full Circle
abstract: Garcia pitched for Minnesota once, in July, before the Twins shipped him to the Yankees. In a crucial game Monday, he delivered a painful blow to his former team.
lead_paragraph: Jaime Garcia was a Minnesota Twin for less than a week in July, an eye blink in the context of a baseball season, and his claim to fame in that brief period was being the winning pitcher in the only game his new club won in a 10-day period.

headline: Quotation of the Day: With a Picked Lock and a Threatened Indictment, Mueller’s Inquiry Sets a Tone
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 19, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “They are setting a tone. It’s important early on to strike terror in the hearts of people in Washington, or else you will be rolled.”

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi, a Much-Changed Icon, Evades Rohingya Accusations
abstract: In her first speech since the crisis started, the de facto leader of Myanmar defended the security forces despite accusations of ethnic cleansing.
lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and de facto leader of Myanmar, stood before a room of government officials and foreign dignitaries on Tuesday to at last, after weeks of international urging, address the plight of the country’s Rohingya ethnic minority.

headline: Climate Change Is Complex. We’ve Got Answers to Your Questions.
abstract: We know. Global warming is daunting. So here’s a place to start: 17 often-asked questions with some straightforward answers.
lead_paragraph: We know. Global warming is daunting. So here’s a place to start: 17 often-asked questions with some straightforward answers.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 19, 2017.

headline: United Nations, Hurricane Maria, Martin Schulz: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Giants Sputter Against Lions in Odell Beckham Jr.’s Return
abstract: Beckham, who was recovering from an ankle injury, returned to the lineup but could not save the Giants from stumbling to an 0-2 start to the season.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants were embarrassingly inept in their season-opening loss to the Dallas Cowboys, the glaring lack of offense was blamed on an ankle injury that kept the All-Pro wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. out of the game.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Jerry Before Seinfeld’ and ‘Somewhere Between’
abstract: Jerry Seinfeld revisits his most memorable bits in a new special. And Paula Patton must outpace time in the season finale of “Somewhere Between.”
lead_paragraph: Jerry Seinfeld revisits his most memorable bits in a new special. And Paula Patton must outpace time in the season finale of “Somewhere Between.”

headline: Word + Quiz: caucus
abstract: This word has appeared in 525 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Files for Bankruptcy, Crippled by Competition and Debt
abstract: The toy store chain will get $3 billion in financing to continue paying employees and suppliers as it deals with Chapter 11.
lead_paragraph: Toys “R” Us, one of the world’s largest toy store chains, has filed for bankruptcy protection, becoming the latest casualty of the pressures facing brick-and-mortar retailers.

headline: Pitching In
abstract: When have you pitched in instead of waiting for someone else to do a task?
lead_paragraph: Do you recognize this picture of Sister Margaret Ann?

headline: How to Work From Home
abstract: Working remotely has become an increasingly easy and breathlessly viable option for many employees.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast in October 2012 while I lived in New York and juggled three jobs. Along with working at a restaurant and a news agency on nights and weekends, I spent my weekdays commuting from Brooklyn to a media company in Manhattan. When the hurricane made landfall, it crippled the city’s public transportation system for weeks, leaving me all but severed from office headquarters.

headline: In New Zealand, a Translated ‘Moana’ Bolsters an Indigenous Language
abstract: Screenings of Disney’s “Moana” in te reo Māori, the language of the indigenous Maori, sold out quickly, bolstering efforts to keep the tongue relevant.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The families lined up at the theater above a shopping mall here in New Zealand’s biggest city and filed past posters for Stephen King’s “It” and “Captain Underpants” for a film unlike any they had ever seen — the Disney hit “Moana,” translated into the indigenous language of New Zealand.

headline: Justice Delayed: 10 Years in Jail, but Still Awaiting Trial
abstract: Kharon Davis was 22 when he was charged with murder in Dothan, Ala. He has served half the minimum sentence, but has yet to have his day in court.
lead_paragraph: DOTHAN, Ala. — Kharon Davis was 22 when he was charged with capital murder and booked into the county jail. Ten years later, he is still there, awaiting trial.

headline: Right and Left React to Hillary Clinton’s Reckoning With the 2016 Race
abstract: Writers from across the political spectrum on Mrs. Clinton’s new book reflecting on her failed bid for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: Looking for the Soul of Abkhazia
abstract: Isolated since a bloody 1992 conflict with Georgian troops, Abkhazia is like a time capsule. Ksenia Kuleshova looked beyond the bullet holes to find its soul.
lead_paragraph: Isolated since a bloody 1992 conflict with Georgian troops, Abkhazia is like a time capsule. Ksenia Kuleshova looked beyond the bullet holes to find its soul.

headline: How Not to ‘Win Hearts and Minds’
abstract: America’s failure to understand Vietnam’s culture and people doomed the war effort.
lead_paragraph: From the early stages of the Vietnam War, American officials insisted that winning the hearts and minds (yes, the acronym was WHAM) of the South Vietnamese people was the key to victory. But the Americans tasked with carrying out that strategy were ill equipped, linguistically and culturally, to make it work. And in the end, that deficit destroyed whatever good will might have existed on either side and doomed America’s foray into Vietnam to failure.

headline: When Community College Is Free
abstract: Chicago is experimenting with a K-14 model for educating some of its most successful students.
lead_paragraph: Does free community college work? An experiment in Chicago suggests that the answer is yes.

headline: The Sanders Single-Payer Plan Is No Miracle Cure
abstract: It will share the same flaws of “Medicare for all”-style systems around the world.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Senator Bernie Sanders introduced “Medicare for all” legislation, which would enroll all Americans into the nation’s Medicare program within four years. Senator Sanders, the Vermont independent, argues that his proposal would create a system that “works not just for millionaires and billionaires, but for all of us.”

headline: In Africa, a Glimpse of Hope for Beating H.I.V.
abstract: H.I.V. infection rates are falling in Africa, a sign that the AIDS epidemic could be brought to an end.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago, European researchers began studying more than a thousand couples, gay and straight, in which one member had been infected with H.I.V. and the other hadn’t. These couples weren’t using condoms. But the infected partner was taking antiretrovirals successfully; the virus was suppressed, undetectable in the blood. The researchers published their results in July 2016 in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: A Solution to New York City’s Gridlock
abstract: Midtown traffic for the United Nations General Assembly is a reminder of the need for a plan to cut traffic and fund mass transit by adding tolls.
lead_paragraph: New York commuters ably survived the “summer of hell” that Gov. Andrew Cuomo had forecast because of repair work at the hobbled Pennsylvania Station. Now Manhattan is enduring a different form of hellishness: severe Midtown traffic as the United Nations General Assembly convenes and world leaders gather. It’s a familiar late-summer headache. But it’s likely to be worse than usual this time, with extra streets closed off as protection for President Trump, ensconced for several days in his Fifth Avenue aerie.

headline: When Life Asks for Everything
abstract: Two models of human development involve self, with one transcending it and the other actualizing it.
lead_paragraph: I’d like to offer you two models of human development.

headline: The Lingering Damage of Ferguson’s Racism
abstract: A police shooting in the Missouri town uncovered systemic bigotry. One man’s case shows how hard that is to overcome.
lead_paragraph: When Justice Department investigators examined the city of Ferguson, Mo., after a white police officer shot and killed an African-American teenager named Michael Brown in 2014, they found no grounds to charge the officer with federal civil rights violations. But they did uncover endemic bigotry among city officials, as well as policing that routinely violated black residents’ constitutional rights, with brutality and excessive, often bogus, enforcement.

headline: The Republican Health Care Zombie Is Back
abstract: After spending much of this year trying to kill the Affordable Care Act, House and Senate leaders try again with a worse plan.
lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers have wasted much of the year trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act, a move that would deprive millions of people of health insurance. They’re back at it. Like a bad sequel to a terrible movie, a proposal whose main architects are Bill Cassidy of Louisiana and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina would in many ways be worse than bills that came before. It would punish states like California and New York  that have done the most to increase access to health care and set in motion cuts to Medicaid, the federal-state program that provides insurance to nearly 70 million people, many of whom are disabled and elderly.

headline: My Mother Speaks Through Me
abstract: Her style of talking has shaped how I hear other people’s words.
lead_paragraph: I was looking forward to having my friend Tamara over for dinner last year, since she had hosted me and my husband many times. But it didn’t turn out as I’d expected. Tamara kept trying to help in various ways, like retrieving items from the kitchen or clearing items from the table. Each time, I told her to please sit down, that I didn’t want her to help. But then she’d be up again.

headline: John McCain Faces a New Test of His Principles
abstract: The health insurance of millions may rest on the senator’s willingness to stand firm.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if John McCain’s Senate colleagues are going to test him once again. And the health insurance of millions of Americans depends on the outcome.

headline: What Convenience Foods Make You Happy?
abstract: Why do Alaskans derive so much happiness from cake-mix cakes?
lead_paragraph: Do you and your family mostly eat homemade food, or do you eat convenience food of some kind, whether precooked, packaged or takeout? Which do you like best?

headline: Looking for the Soul of Abkhazia
abstract: Isolated since a bloody 1992 conflict with Georgian troops, Abkhazia is like a time capsule, still dependent on Russian tourist dollars. Ksenia Kuleshova looked beyond the bullet holes to find its soul.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after Russian-backed Abkhaz rebels pushed out Georgian troops in a bloody, year-long proxy war decried by Georgian authorities as illegal and a step towards “de facto annexation,” only four United Nations member states — Nicaragua, Venezuela, Nauru and Russia— recognize Abkhazia, a small territory on the eastern coast of the Black Sea bordering the Caucasus Mountains.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘At Risk in Rohingya Exodus: 230,000 Children, Hundreds All Alone’
abstract: Why are the Rohingya fleeing their homes?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: The Least-Known Most Influential Man in Fashion
abstract: Forty years after his death, it’s time to give the rocker Marc Bolan his due.
lead_paragraph: These days Rihanna is a designer. So is Kanye. So is Pharrell. So is Selena. Musicians have gone from fashion muses to fashion makers in the turn of a few seasons, one-upping style heroes of yesteryear like Mick Jagger and David Bowie — who nevertheless are routinely name-checked as inspiration in show notes.

headline: Hurricane Maria Does ‘Mind-Boggling’ Damage to Dominica, Leader Says
abstract: Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit said the Caribbean island had sustained “widespread devastation” from the storm, which hit at Category 5 strength.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It was about midnight, as Hurricane Maria was battering the Caribbean nation of Dominica, that Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit took to Facebook. Roofs everywhere, he wrote, were being torn off by the powerful storm’s winds. He himself had to be rescued from his official residence.

headline: A Family’s Return to Mosul
abstract: Thousands have been returning to western Mosul after Iraqi forces pushed ISIS out of the city. The Salman family moves back amid risks and widespread damage to their neighborhood. They now hope to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: Thousands have been returning to western Mosul after Iraqi forces pushed ISIS out of the city. The Salman family moves back amid risks and widespread damage to their neighborhood. They now hope to rebuild.

headline: Books That Show the Heights of Human Strength, the Limits of Endurance
abstract: From natural disaster to wild beasts and warfare, tragedies factual and fictional so vivid that they’ll strike terror in the heart of any reader.

headline: The Education of Ellen Pao
abstract: In “Reset,” the Silicon Valley executive and former venture capitalist explains how she came to question the culture of the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: RESET My Fight for Inclusion and Lasting Change By Ellen K. Pao 274 pp. Spiegel & Grau. $28

headline: How to Have a Lavish but Affordable Trip to Ireland
abstract: Dine at pubs (the food is first-rate), avoid July and August travel, hire a driver-guide.
lead_paragraph: Go to Ireland, live lavishly but don’t spend a lot. A dream? It doesn’t have to be, said Siobhan Byrne Learat, the founder of Adams & Butler, a Dublin-based company selling luxury Ireland trips. “Ireland, in general, is an affordable destination,” she said. “And with some insider knowledge, you can stretch your money further and have a fabulous upscale vacation here.”

headline: How North Korea Evades Sanctions
abstract: The United Nations has tried to limit North Korea’s resources — and cripple its nuclear program — by imposing limits on trade. Here’s how the country skirts those sanctions.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has tried to limit North Korea’s resources — and cripple its nuclear program — by imposing limits on trade. Here’s how the country skirts those sanctions.

headline: Health Bill Tests a Signature Senate Bond: John McCain and Lindsey Graham
abstract: The bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act bears the name of Mr. Graham, but Mr. McCain, who helped sink an earlier repeal attempt, has remained undecided.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I always do whatever Lindsey Graham tells me to do,” Senator John McCain, the unpredictable Arizona Republican, said last week, while entertaining questions from a scrum of reporters in a Capitol hallway.

headline: When Corruption and Venality Were the Lifeblood of America
abstract: “The Republic for Which It Stands,” Richard White’s broad-ranging history, describes a country lashed by greed and brutality.
lead_paragraph: THE REPUBLIC FOR WHICH IT STANDS The United States During Reconstruction and the Gilded Age, 1865-1896 By Richard White Illustrated. 941 pp. Oxford. $35

headline: Making ‘Mother!,’ the Year’s Most Divisive Film
abstract: Is it the most confusing movie of 2017 or merely the most provocative? Darren Aronofsky, Jennifer Lawrence and Javier Bardem explain the movie.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — “Doesn’t this look like where people come to get fired?”

headline: Why The Times Covers Its Own Industry
abstract: “Rolling Stone influenced a generation. That it can no longer survive on its own suggests that something about our culture has been lost.”
lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone was one of the many magazines that covered my family’s coffee table when I was growing up. Not only was it physically bigger than the others, it also ran weighty articles, about music, entertainment and politics. My dad was a subscriber for 30 years, and I recently asked him how he would describe the magazine in its heyday. “The bible,” he said.

headline: Democrats Mount Effort to Recruit Women as State Attorneys General
abstract: Few Democratic state officeholders are women, a shortfall the party is seeking to fix.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Hillary Clinton’s defeat last year ignited an intense debate about the role of gender in American politics, but the presidential race overshadowed a deeper structural challenge for Democrats: They have a scarcity of female officeholders in state capitals.

headline: 7 Steps to a Clutter-Free Kitchen
abstract: What’s the secret to an organized kitchen? The experts share their tricks.
lead_paragraph: With the school year in full swing and holidays quickly approaching, it’s time to organize your kitchen. No more fumbling for the spices behind the tortilla chips or bumping into your partner while trying to get breakfast for the family on the table. To get started, here are some tricks professional organizers use to keep their own kitchens clutter-free.

headline: At U.N., Trump Singles Out ‘Rogue’ Nations North Korea and Iran
abstract: The 193-member United Nations is gathering for the 72nd session of the General Assembly. Here are the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from around the globe took the lectern at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday — a particularly big moment for President Trump, who addressed the gathering for the first time.

headline: In New York City, a New Moxy Hotel Has a History
abstract: A new property — once the New Mills Hotel — will be the design-focused brand’s largest, with 612 rooms, five restaurants and rates starting at $139.
lead_paragraph: When the American banker and philanthropist Darius Ogden Mills opened the New Mills Hotel in October 1907, on the corner of Seventh Avenue and 36th Street in Manhattan, he wanted it to be a place where working-class men could find affordable accommodations.

headline: James Corden Denies Kissing Sean Spicer — Then Apologizes, Sort of
abstract: Mr. Corden addressed charges that he had helped lend legitimacy to Sean Spicer, the former White House press secretary, by treating him playfully at a party after the Emmys.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 19, 2017
abstract: Look closely at this graph, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 23, 2017

headline: One Reason to Take the Latest Obamacare Repeal Seriously, and Three Reasons It Could Fail
abstract: The political and procedural hurdles are many, but the hunger for victory among Republicans may overcome all.
lead_paragraph: How seriously should Americans take the Republicans’ last-ditch effort to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
