abstract: We look at the tactics being used to investigate Russia’s election interference. And a Times reporter overhears the president’s lawyers at a steakhouse.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: German Court Fines 3 for Failing to Help Ailing Retiree in Bank
abstract: The defendants, who stepped over or around an unconscious 83-year-old man to make their way to an A.T.M., were fined $2,900 to $4,300.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As a neatly dressed elderly man lay unconscious in the foyer of a bank in western Germany, four people stepped over or around him to make their way to cash machines.

headline: The Fatal Toll of Cheap Cigarettes
abstract: The availability of cheaper, off-brand cigarettes is associated with an increase in infant mortality.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that the availability of cheaper, off-brand cigarettes is associated with an increase in infant mortality.

headline: New York Today: Hurricane Jose Approaches
abstract: Tuesday: Tracking the storm, the Big City Book Club, and President Trump at the U.N.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:08 p.m.

headline: How Honesty Could Make You Happier
abstract: An honesty journal can teach you a lot about living a better life.

headline: Making Dance Out of the Unspeakable
abstract: The work of the Rwandan-born choreographer Dorothée Munyaneza addresses rape and genocide: “It’s a question of creating, mending, performing.”
lead_paragraph: Dorothée Munyaneza was 12 when the Rwandan genocide began, in April 1994, forcing her and her siblings to flee Kigali, where her father was a pastor. She was witness to horrific crimes; many of her friends, neighbors and their families were killed. But the Munyanezas were lucky. Their mother, already working for an N.G.O. in London, was able to get the family out of Rwanda in July of that year. By September, the children were with her and their father, and at school at the French lycée there.

headline: Morning Agenda: Retailers (Not Named Amazon) Continue to Struggle
abstract: The bankruptcy filing by Toys “R” Us shows just how much pain store operators are feeling — and highlighted that more suffering is in store.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a retailer and you’re not Amazon or Walmart, life can be very hard. The bankruptcy filing by Toys “R” Us on Monday is just the latest example.

headline: Italian Titans Add Some Glitz to London Fashion Week
abstract: Giorgio Armani and Donatella Versace both dazzled with collections from their younger, more playful lines in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As politicians in London and Brussels continue their tussles over Britain’s exit from the European Union, the British capital received a vote of Continental confidence on Sunday, when two of the biggest names in Italian fashion — Giorgio Armani and Donatella Versace — decided to show the latest collections from their younger, more accessible lines during London Fashion Week.

headline: The iPhone 8: A Worthy Refinement Before the Next Generation
abstract: Apple’s new iPhone 8 and 8 Plus have a ring of familiarity. But the phones may feel like a solid upgrade from older models because of their new processor.
lead_paragraph: What does one say about a new iPhone? At this point, a decade after the first one sent the earth spinning in directions both magical and ghastly, it can be difficult to summon any fresh wonder when appraising the familiar little slab of digital horror and delight.

headline: Faustine Steinmetz: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Richemont Opens an Innovation Lab in Switzerland
abstract: The luxury giant intends for research to benefit its watch and jewelry companies as well as other brands.
lead_paragraph: In today’s challenging retail climate, top watch brands are searching for any edge they can find. So the Swiss luxury giant Richemont has opened a research and innovation center in Microcity, Switzerland’s well-known think tank and laboratory.

headline: My Watches Were in a Fire. Now What?
abstract: Experts give their advice on how to proceed if your timepiece has been exposed to flames or water.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the firefighters let us back into the house, I checked on our passports first. (They weren’t damaged.) My jewelry box was next — and wasn’t quite as lucky.

headline: At 100, the Cartier Tank Transcends Time
abstract: Jacqueline Kennedy wore one. So did Cary Grant and Cole Porter. Andy Warhol called it “the watch to wear.” Now it’s celebrating its centenary.
lead_paragraph: It’s been called the most iconic watch on the planet, the ultimate in classic timepieces. And this fall, the Cartier Tank will mark its 100th birthday with new variations and an updated biography.

headline: As Warren and Sanders Jockey for Support, One Takes a Road More Traveled
abstract: Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders are taking different paths to win new fans ahead of 2020. The outcome will say much about the Democrats’ future.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It took a few minutes to find an opening, but when it came, Senator Elizabeth Warren did not squander her best chance to connect with a heavily black audience inside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s Ebenezer Baptist Church late last month.

headline: A ‘Quest for Justice’ for a Murdered Civil Rights Pioneer, 52 Years Later
abstract: Who killed Alberta Jones, Louisville’s first female black prosecutor, in 1965? Prodded by a professor, the police are trying again to find out.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Alberta Jones is the civil rights pioneer almost no one knows. She was Louisville’s first female black prosecutor and negotiated the first fight contract for Muhammad Ali, her neighbor. She registered thousands of African-American voters in the 1960s and paved the way for a ban on racial discrimination by local theaters and lunch counters.

headline: In Tokyo, Stories on Their Wrists
abstract: Some vintage watch collectors talk about their favorite timepieces.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to describing food, fashion or culture in Tokyo, fans often find themselves using superlatives. And the vintage watch scene is much the same: Tokyo is one of the best places in the world to hunt for classic treasures. The city is filled with secondhand shops and most of the pre-owned timepieces on sale are in pristine condition.

headline: Hamas Offer Reflects Pressure From Egypt and Fatah
abstract: The militant group that controls Gaza agreed to Palestinian Authority demands, but said nothing about disarming. In the past, hopes for unity have been dashed.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The announcement from Hamas over the weekend arrived like a bouquet of roses for Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority.

headline: In Grenfell Inquiry, U.K. Weighs 2 Types of Manslaughter Charge
abstract: The investigation into the London high-rise fire may test laws under which organizations can be prosecuted for deaths. Individual charges are also being considered.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The fire in June at Grenfell Tower in London, which killed around 80 people, prompted a wave of anger in Britain.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 12-18, 2017
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the headlines this week? Take our 10-question quiz and see.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the headlines this week? Take our 10-question quiz and see.

headline: California Today: What if Legal Pot Costs More Than Black-Market Pot?
abstract: Tuesday: Looming trouble with black-market marijuana, a raucous news conference for Nancy Pelosi, and the pain of San Diego’s Charger fans.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The 2017 Hurricane Season Really Is More Intense Than Normal
abstract: It’s not your imagination. From Harvey to Irma to Jose to Maria, this year’s Atlantic hurricane season “has been an overachiever by almost every index.”
lead_paragraph: It was only 25 days ago that Hurricane Harvey made landfall.

headline: In Geneva, ‘Dirty Money’ of Another Kind — Flushed Down the Toilet
abstract: Prosecutors in the Swiss city are investigating the disposal of about $120,000 in high-denomination bank notes.
lead_paragraph: Flushing money down the toilet is usually only a metaphor, reserved for spendthrifts or those casual with their cash. But not in Geneva.

headline: Giant Monument to Kalashnikov, Creator of AK-47, Is Unveiled in Moscow
abstract: The nationalist ceremony made no mention of the millions killed and wounded by the world’s most prevalent assault weapon.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A towering monument to Lt. Gen. Mikhail T. Kalashnikov, designer of the AK-47, the Soviet rifle that has become the world’s most widespread assault weapon, was unveiled on Tuesday in the middle of one of central Moscow’s busiest thoroughfares.

headline: The Playwright Lauren Yee Wins the Kesselring Prize
abstract: The writer of “In a Word” and “The Hatmaker’s Wife” will win $25,000 from the National Arts Club.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Yee has won the National Arts Club’s 2017 Kesselring Prize, awarded to emerging playwrights since 1980. She will receive $25,000 and two-week residency at the club.

headline: Senate Panel Cancels Meeting With Trump Lawyer Over Public Comments
abstract: The lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, said the rush to presume guilt was “un-American.” Senators had asked that he not speak publicly, and they quickly shut down the meeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday abruptly postponed an interview with President Trump’s longtime lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, shortly after the publication of his opening statement, which asserted his innocence and defended the president.

headline: Playing Tackle Football Before 12 Is Tied to Brain Problems Later
abstract: The Boston University study links cognitive and behavioral problems later in life — among all players, not just in the N.F.L. — to playing tackle at a young age.
lead_paragraph: Athletes who began playing tackle football before the age of 12 had more behavioral and cognitive problems later in life than those who started playing after they turned 12, a new study released on Tuesday showed.

headline: ‘Isn’t That the Trump Lawyer?’: A Reporter’s Accidental Scoop
abstract: Kenneth P. Vogel overheard a conversation at a Washington steakhouse that led to a story on the White House legal team’s internal discord over the Russia investigations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I have always thought of overhearing conversations as an underappreciated journalistic tool.

headline: Review: In Season 2, ‘The Good Place’ Blows Itself Up, Hilariously
abstract: After a stunning first-season twist, NBC’s comedy of ethics drastically changes its premise but keeps its philosophical bent.
lead_paragraph: Season 1 of NBC’s “The Good Place” had one hell of a final twist.

headline: Harvey and Irma Wiped Out Our Kitchens. Still, We Cook.
abstract: America has never lost so many stoves and pantries at once, but home cooks are intent on finding a way — any way — to make meals.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — No matter what, cooks are going to cook.

headline: The New Earth Tones for the Home
abstract: When selecting slabs of stone, consider marble, granite, onyx and quartzite in otherworldly hues.
lead_paragraph: When selecting slabs of stone, consider marble, granite, onyx and quartzite in otherworldly hues.

headline: The Extra-Long Hair Trend, Decoded
abstract: Long and untamed, the villainous look has roots in Asian art and film — and ghosts.
lead_paragraph: In the ’80s in Southern California, there was only one channel with Korean-language programming: It aired for a few hours only in the evenings. This was during that sweet spot of Korean immigration in America — a decade or so after the arrival of the first major waves but before their descendants bastardized the cuisine with their kimchi tacos. In those days, there was a mystical angle to some of the television dramas the channel showed, which were creepier and more experimental than today’s Korean versions of ‘‘This Is Us.’’ One evening, I watched one of these dramas, which happened to co-star a ghost — a woman in white standing hunched over in a swampy rice field. Her eyes were wide open, her body taut. It was terrifying.

headline: Fox Presses for Arbitration or Dismissal in Suit Over Seth Rich Article
abstract: The lawsuit, which makes allegations of defamation and racial discrimination, was filed by a private detective at the center of the article. Fox News says it is “without merit.”
lead_paragraph: Fox News and its parent company, 21st Century Fox, have filed a motion to move the defamation and racial discrimination lawsuit involving a Fox News article about the death of a young Democratic aide from a New York federal court to arbitration.

headline: I Love My Fiancé, but Am Totally Crushing on a Co-Worker
abstract: A restaurant server in her mid-20s worries that the relationship she’s committed to has lost its sizzle, but knows that flirting is playing with fire.
lead_paragraph: The “Dear Sugars” podcast is an advice program hosted by Steve Almond and Cheryl Strayed. The audio contains more letters; submissions are welcome at dearsugars@nytimes.com. If you’re reading this on desktop, click the play button below to listen. Mobile readers can find “Dear Sugars” on the Podcasts app (iPhone and iPad) or Radio Public (Android and tablet).

headline: Why Deleted Tweets Still Linger Online
abstract: Even if you kill a Twitter post from your timeline, a search engine may give it a second life until it updates its index files.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do deleted tweets sometimes still show up on the web when you search?

headline: Prune
abstract: Now that Prune’s owner, Gabrielle Hamilton, shares her chef’s title with her wife, Ashley Merriman, the restaurant’s sensibility has expanded.
lead_paragraph: Now that Prune’s owner, Gabrielle Hamilton, shares her chef’s title with her wife, Ashley Merriman, the restaurant’s sensibility has expanded.

headline: Hunger and Desire, Stripped of Window Dressing, at Prune
abstract: The chef Gabrielle Hamilton’s thoughts on what makes a satisfying dinner are extremely clear.
lead_paragraph: First, some disclosures are in order. Gabrielle Hamilton, who owns Prune, writes one column a month for The New York Times Magazine. I don’t have anything to do with that, but I have edited a few of her essays in the past. We had a fine time working together, and kept in touch for a while. About a decade ago we introduced our toddlers for a play date while she cooked breakfast. It ended after her son hit mine over the head with a toy truck.

headline: Shou Sugi Ban, in Photos
abstract: Examples of the ancient Japanese technique that involves charring a specific kind of Japanese cedar.
lead_paragraph: Examples of the ancient Japanese technique that involves charring a specific kind of Japanese cedar.

headline: The Latest Design Trend: Black and Burned Wood
abstract: An ancient Japanese technique protects cedar by charring it a witchy charcoal. It’s having a renaissance in the West (for less practical reasons).
lead_paragraph: ON THE WINDSWEPT southern side of Martha’s Vineyard, at the end of a rural road that emerges from a dark copse of oak trees, sit two austere, inky-black farmhouse-style buildings — a studio and a private residence — that compose Chilmark House. Designed by the New Haven, Conn., firm Gray Organschi Architecture with Aaron Schiller, founder of the New York City-based Schiller Projects, the home, which was built for Schiller’s family, is clad in approximately 80 charred louvers he torched entirely by hand. The striking ebony hue feels at once ancient and modern: Here is the enveloping matte darkness of Anish Kapoor’s Vantablack paint and the glittering primordial obsidian of lava rock. In the foggy early morning light, as the heavy marine layer rolls off the Atlantic, the house emerges dark and startling, as though it was dipped in oil. At other times of day, its opaque blackness, which seems to absorb all the light that surrounds it, acts as a kind of backdrop for the sky’s quicksilver mood changes.

headline: Home and Work: Anthony Esteves
abstract: In Maine, a home built with Japanese-style soot-based paint — and charred cedar slats.
lead_paragraph: In Maine, a home built with Japanese-style soot-based paint — and charred cedar slats.

headline: A Family Compound in Coastal Maine, Made From Scratch
abstract: At just 31 and with no formal training in architecture, Anthony Esteves has built a beautiful place to live — with a Japanese influence.
lead_paragraph: The only thing more impressive than the fact that Anthony Esteves, who is 31, built a house from scratch and painstakingly restored another on his family compound on coastal Maine is the fact that he’d never done it before. This is not to say he hadn’t had any training, but it was not the kind you might assume: At RISD, he studied not architecture but sculpture, “which I think now comes through in my work more so than ever,” he says. “I got out of school and figured out over a couple years that the building process was really like my studio practice.”

headline: A Decaying Waterfront in Washington Returns to Life
abstract: The revitalization of the Wharf follows a pattern in other cities that have transformed industrial and commercial riverfronts into prime destinations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A struggling waterfront along the Potomac River will morph into a long-awaited commercial and residential destination known as the Wharf when it opens next month.

headline: It Might Have Been a Masterpiece, but Now It’s a Cautionary Tale
abstract: A disputed Mondrian passed unchecked around some important art institutions as though it were the real thing.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — When the cultural historian and Piet Mondrian biographer Léon Hanssen visited the Bozar Center for the Arts in Brussels in the spring of 2016, a painting stopped him dead in his tracks.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: A $25 million apartment tower in Flushing, Queens, was among the recent transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $25 MILLION

headline: Document Revives Mystery of Vatican Teenager Who Vanished in ’83
abstract: The document, stolen from an armored cabinet, suggests the Vatican is not telling all it knows about the kidnapping 34 years ago of a teenage girl.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The disclosure this week of a five-page, typewritten document that was stolen from an armored cabinet inside the Vatican has revived the mystery surrounding a 15-year-old who vanished in 1983.

headline: Puerto Rico Flooded by Hurricane Maria
abstract: All regions of Puerto Rico battled floodwaters as Hurricane Maria regained “major hurricane status” off the coast of the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: All regions of Puerto Rico battled floodwaters as Hurricane Maria regained “major hurricane status” off the coast of the Dominican Republic.

headline: Sarah Michelson’s Cryptic Modes and Codes at Bard
abstract: The choreographer has been working with Bard students for four years. What she’ll show is anyone’s guess.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “Mode 3C. Mode 3C.”

headline: Russian Military Helicopter Fires Rockets by Accident
abstract: A video showed rockets exploding in a parking lot, damaging a truck and nearly killing a bystander.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At least one bystander narrowly escaped death when a Russian military helicopter accidentally fired rockets into a parking lot during a training exercise, a video released on Tuesday shows.

headline: Chasing Fashion’s Cutting Edge
abstract: Dustin Pittman points his lens at the strange, the brash and the sublime.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Pittman’s gaze roamed the bustling back office of Century 21 on Cortlandt Street, where Kim Shui was prepping her fashion show. In an instant, he found his mark. She was China Lee, who would be modeling one of the giddily mismatched plaids and brocades Ms. Shui planned to unveil a couple of floors below.

headline: While Premiums Soar Under Obamacare, Costs of Employer-Based Plans Are Stable
abstract: A new survey of employers shows moderate price increases in health benefits despite turmoil in the individual insurance market.
lead_paragraph: In sharp contrast to the soaring health insurance premiums in many Affordable Care Act marketplaces, the cost of coverage for the vast numbers of people who get insurance through their jobs rose relatively little this year, continuing a period of remarkable stability in the employer market, according to a national survey released Tuesday.

headline: From Truman to Trump: How U.S. Presidents Have Addressed the U.N.
abstract: With President Trump’s first address to the United Nations on Tuesday, here’s a look at past presidents’ first speeches.
lead_paragraph: In 1946, President Harry Truman welcomed the first session of the United Nations General Assembly to New York. After remarking on the pride that the United States felt in hosting the  international body, his speech quickly shifted into a display of American strength in the wake of World War II.

headline: Blue States Face Biggest Cuts Under New Republican Health Care Plan
abstract: Which states would gain or lose federal funding in 2026.
lead_paragraph: Which states would gain or lose federal funding in 2026.

headline: Dumbo Gets a Panoramic Menu at Sugarcane Raw Bar Grill
abstract: Asia and Latin America are in the mix, plus openings by Dale Talde and Leah Cohen, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: SUGARCANE RAW BAR GRILL Like virtually all the new restaurants opening in Dumbo, Brooklyn, this one captures the stunning water view both indoors and on a patio. It’s a big, vibrant place — 11,000 square feet, with 300 seats, in the Empire Stores complex — with three kitchen stations run by the chef David Sears, under the direction of the chef and partner Timon Balloo, who also oversees the group’s Miami flagship and Las Vegas branch. The menu mixes Asian, Latin and American influences, with bites like bacon-wrapped dates, an array of sushi rolls, crudos and ceviches, and more substantial Korean-style short ribs and lamb chops. Rum drinks aplenty can fuel lunch or dinner, including a tobacco rum old-fashioned scented with homemade cigar bitters, appropriate enough since the former Tobacco Warehouse (now St. Ann’s Warehouse theater) is next door:  55 Water Street (Main Street), Dumbo, Brooklyn, 718-473-9555, sugarcanerawbargrill.com/Brooklyn.

headline: Review: ‘Thirst Street’ Hollows Out Hollywood Obsession
abstract: Rose-colored glasses keeps a flight attendant from noticing her boyfriend’s suicidal depression in this film by Nathan Silver.
lead_paragraph: The preamble of the new black comedy “Thirst Street” finds Gina, an American flight attendant, in a period of stability, happily partnered with her doting boyfriend, Paul (Damien Bonnard), as she jetsets from Berlin to Chicago to Rome.

headline: New York’s Bet on New Casinos Has Yet to Hit Jackpot
abstract: This year was expected to be big for the state’s growing gambling industry. But revenues have been weaker than expected.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — This was to be a year of celebration for New York’s booming gambling industry, with gleaming new casinos opening, rapturous bettors flocking in and a win-win for the state, and a torrent of new taxes pouring into government coffers at no cost to anyone but the bettors themselves.

headline: Nationals Join Elite Teams Who Have Crushed Their Divisions
abstract: Washington is in position to join a small group of clubs that have won by 20 games or more.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Nationals’ season has essentially been on automatic pilot for months. By May 1 the Nationals were already four and a half games ahead in the National League East. By June 1, the margin was 10 games. By Aug. 1, it was 13.

headline: Yotam Ottolenghi on Creating Recipes for His Cookbook ‘Sweet’
abstract: For the British chef, author and self-described baking nerd, there is no limit to the number of times you can make a cake in order to get it right.
lead_paragraph: Here is an image that I can’t shake: It’s a Sunday afternoon, around 4, probably. My husband, Karl, looks out the window of our first-floor West London flat; an expression of clear foreboding appears on his face and then, very quietly, he says, “Helen’s here … with her cakes.”

headline: Rolling Stone Faces Revived Lawsuit Over Campus Rape Article
abstract: An appeals court ruled that a defamation lawsuit involving two members of a fraternity at the center of a discredited article should go back to district court.
lead_paragraph: Just days after announcing that it was for sale, Rolling Stone learned that it still faces litigation over its retracted article about a purported gang rape at the University of Virginia, news that may complicate the magazine’s efforts to find a buyer.

headline: Chemical Industry Ally Faces Critics in Bid for Top E.P.A. Post
abstract: Michael L. Dourson, who has long run a premier firm for the chemical industry, is set for a confirmation hearing before a Senate panel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The scientist nominated to head the federal government’s chemical regulatory program has spent much of his career helping businesses fight restrictions on the use of potentially toxic compounds in consumer goods.

headline: International Tourism to the U.S. Declined in Early 2017
abstract: The figures, released by the U.S. Department of Commerce, included a 10.1 percent drop in European travelers compared to the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: Fewer international travelers came to the United States during the first few months of this year than over the same period last year, confirming concerns of some in the travel industry.

headline: Alive in Stone, Now in Mel Ziegler’s Home
abstract: Rocks to remember from Mount Rushmore: An artist collects mass-produced memories.
lead_paragraph: They call Mount Rushmore the “Shrine of Democracy”: four presidents blasted out of the face of a granite escarpment in the Black Hills of South Dakota. For the artist Mel Ziegler, it’s literally a touchstone. In the mid-1980s, he and his partner, Kate Ericson, stopped there on a cross-country trip and returned home with the four rocks off the rubble at the base of the mountain that would comprise “From the Making of Mount Rushmore,” one of their signature works. “We knew we weren’t supposed to take them,” Mr. Ziegler recalled, “but there weren’t any signs or anything.” Ericson died of brain cancer in 1995 at the age of 39. But Mr. Ziegler, now chair of the art department at Vanderbilt University, has kept going back, collecting souvenirs he plans to use as the basis of some future exhibition.

headline: YouTube Star Hank Green Will Publish His First Novel Next Year
abstract: Following in the footsteps of his older brother, the best-selling novelist John Green, Hank Green will publish his first novel with Dutton.
lead_paragraph: The heroine of Hank Green’s debut novel, “An Absolutely Remarkable Thing,” is an art student in New York City named April May, who finds herself at the center of a vast international mystery. One day, April stumbles on a giant robot sculpture in Midtown Manhattan, and makes a video with the figure, which goes viral. She becomes famous as news spreads that similar sculptures have mysteriously appeared in dozens of cities, and people around the world struggle to understand where the figures came from and what they mean.

headline: Hurricane Harvey Closes Houston’s Opera and Ballet Home for a Season
abstract: Flood damage to the Wortham Theater Center caused by Hurricane Harvey was so extensive that the theater will not be able to reopen until at least May.
lead_paragraph: The Wortham Theater Center — home to Houston Grand Opera and Houston Ballet — was so severely damaged by the flooding brought on by Hurricane Harvey that it will remain closed through at least May 15, the center announced on Monday night. The news sent the opera and the ballet companies scrambling to find new spaces for performances they had planned for this season.

headline: Review: ‘Hissein Habré, a Chadian Tragedy’ Shows the Victims of a Dictator
abstract: The director Mahamat-Saleh Haroun gives voice to the people affected by Mr. Habré’s dictatorial government.
lead_paragraph: Documentarians have long struggled with how to depict the aftermaths of atrocities. Claude Lanzmann’s “Shoah” spreads its interviews out over more than nine hours, implicitly acknowledging the limitations of making a Holocaust film even as it serves as a record of survivors’ memories. Joshua Oppenheimer’s “The Act of Killing” goes for the throat: The director shows the former members of Indonesian death squads re-enacting their crimes.

headline: With Combative Style and Epithets, Trump Takes America First to the U.N.
abstract: In a bellicose speech before world leaders, President Trump framed differences with North Korea, Iran and Venezuela as a battle of good versus evil.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump brought the same confrontational style of leadership he has used at home to the world’s most prominent stage on Tuesday as he vowed to “totally destroy North Korea” if it threatened the United States and denounced the nuclear agreement with Iran as “an embarrassment” that he may abandon.

headline: White Baton Rouge Suspect Is Charged With Murder in Killings of Two Black Men
abstract: The police said that the killings may have been racially motivated. The suspect was arrested twice in recent days on unrelated charges but was released.
lead_paragraph: The police in Baton Rouge, La., have charged a 23-year-old white man in the separate killings of two black men last week.

headline: Islands Seek International Funding for Hurricane Recovery
abstract: In a special United Nations session, leaders of islands battered by hurricanes made worse by climate change appealed to wealthy countries for aid.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — As Hurricane Maria thunders through the Caribbean, island leaders still reeling from Hurricane Irma are calling on international organizations to provide money to help vulnerable countries recover from devastating storms linked to climate change.

headline: 9 Back-to-School Tips for Parents and Students
abstract: Between the social-media-fueled pressure, college admissions madness and bullying culture, schools today can be a minefield. We collected some education-themed Op-Eds to help guide families as they settle into the new year.
lead_paragraph: Is your child feeling left out? Angry at you? Embarrassed to speak up during class? Don’t ignore these feelings. Unless emotions are properly dealt with, children won’t be able to reach their full academic potential.

headline: In Ruins by the Shore, Some See Connecticut’s ‘Crown Jewel’
abstract: On a pristine slice of shoreline, a vacant sanitarium designed by a renowned architect could be transformed into a lodge that might help the state’s ailing finances.
lead_paragraph: WATERFORD, Conn. — The craggy coast of the Long Island Sound breaks for a grassy slope sweeping gently into a powdery beach and a clearing overtaken by a sprawling old hospital, where it looks as though humanity has surrendered, allowing nature to reclaim its turf.

headline: An Earthquake Hits and Angelenos Shelter on Twitter
abstract: It may have been mild and standard, but it happened in Los Angeles. So, naturally, earthquake was a trending topic on Twitter by early Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Hurricanes in Florida, Texas and the Caribbean; record-high temperatures in San Francisco; and wildfires in the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Puerto Rico Braces for ‘Potentially Catastrophic’ Hit by Hurricane Maria
abstract: A glancing hit by Hurricane Irma left 70 percent of households without power and 34 percent without water. Now Hurricane Maria is on a path to hit the vulnerable island directly.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Read the latest with Wednesday’s live updates on Hurricane Maria.

headline: U.C. Berkeley Students: What Does Free Speech Mean to You?
abstract: As the university braces for more protests, Times reporters would like to hear from students and faculty.
lead_paragraph: As the university braces for more protests, Times reporters would like to hear from students and faculty.

headline: Discussing ‘The Vietnam War’
abstract: What do you think of the new documentary from Ken Burns and Lynn Novick?
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, PBS debuted “The Vietnam War,” Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s long-awaited, 18-hour documentary on the conflict and its legacy. As engrossing as the film is, just as noteworthy has been the commentary about it, both critical and in praise. And this, I am sure, is one of the filmmakers’ goals: to jumpstart a conversation about a conflict that deepened divisions within America, opened new ones and redefined the country’s role in the world — with repercussions that are still felt today.

headline: Whiting Foundation Announces New Grants for Magazines
abstract: The three grants for print and digital publications, designed to “ignite growth,” will total up to $120,000.
lead_paragraph: At a moment when some glitzy magazines — including Vanity Fair, Rolling Stone and Elle — have announced big changes during nervous financial times for legacy media, the world of nonprofit magazines has gotten a boost.

headline: Mexico Earthquake Kills Hundreds, Trapping Many Under Rubble
abstract: In Mexico City, where a school collapsed, ordinary citizens used their bare hands to try to free the students trapped in the rubble.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A powerful earthquake struck Mexico on Tuesday afternoon, toppling buildings, killing children in a school that collapsed, rattling the capital and sending people flooding into the streets for the second time in just two weeks.

headline: 116 Cameras
abstract: What if your most important experiences could live on after you die?
lead_paragraph: What if your most important experiences could live on after you die?

headline: Why Australia Wasn’t Ready for a Dangerous Flu Season
abstract: A historically high number of cases have been reported in some states, with the death of a young girl raising alarms.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australia’s carefree attitude toward preventive medicine may have met its match: the flu.

headline: 116 Cameras
abstract: What if your most important experiences could live on after you die?
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Toronto in the 1980s, I had a connection to Holocaust history that was direct, visceral and human. Each year, Holocaust survivors came to my school to talk about what they had experienced during the war. It wasn’t unusual for these survivors to be the grandparents of a classmate. Some of them had just begun telling their stories for the first time. I thought of my own grandparents, survivors from Poland who eventually immigrated to Montreal. They hardly ever spoke to me about what happened to them and the family members they lost. It was too painful for them to tell, and I was too afraid to ask.

headline: On the Road With the Casualties of the Great Recession
abstract: To write “Nomadland,” Jessica Bruder spent three years traveling and working alongside grandparents and others living in school buses and vans seeking seasonal work.
lead_paragraph: As far as human inventions go, retirement is shockingly recent, and proving fragile. A fringe idea until the 20th century — and one that outraged many — it took tenuous hold in the United States in the 1930s, during the Great Depression. Today, only 17 percent of Americans imagine they will be able to afford to stop working someday.

headline: Lena Waithe Made History, and She Gave an Emmys Speech for Right Now
abstract: The “Master of None” writer and actress wants to put more culturally diverse perspectives onscreen. And she credits Halle Berry for inspiring her.
lead_paragraph: It was a speech that felt thoroughly, almost preternaturally, attuned to its moment.

abstract: A song from the musical “KPOP.”
lead_paragraph: A song from the musical “KPOP.”

headline: The Princess, the Private Investigator and Another Inquiry for FIFA
abstract: The Jordanian princess, whose brother twice lost bids for the FIFA presidency, has been discreetly working with British investigators for more than a year to collect evidence of soccer corruption.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Jordanian princess who is married to the billionaire ruler of Dubai has for more than a year been discreetly working with British private investigators in an attempt to collect evidence of corruption in global soccer, according to several people with direct knowledge of the effort.

headline: A Mirthless Trump
abstract: A reader sees a significant shortcoming.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Blackmail Case With Prostitutes, a Video and Sex Abuse Charges
abstract: A Manhattan private investigator was charged with trying to derail a sex abuse case by secretly recording a witness having sex with prostitutes he hired.
lead_paragraph: Like many private investigators, Vincent Parco has, for nearly 30 years, made his living in the darker corners of New York.

headline: Trump Offers a Selective View of Sovereignty in U.N. Speech
abstract: The president declared that nations should respect each other’s sovereignty. But he threatened to act aggressively against some nations, like North Korea and Iran.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump, in declaring Tuesday that sovereignty should be the guiding principle of affairs between nations, sketched out a radically different vision of the world order than his forebears, who founded the United Nations after World War II to deal collectively with problems they believed would transcend borders.

headline: Rejected Report Shows Revenue Brought In by Refugees
abstract: A draft of a study rejected by Trump administration officials that found that refugees brought in $63 billion more in government revenues over the past decade than they cost.
lead_paragraph: A draft of a study rejected by Trump administration officials that found that refugees brought in $63 billion more in government revenues over the past decade than they cost.

headline: Don’t Play Politics With the ‘Dreamers’
abstract: A reader writes that Congress must advocate a path to citizenship for these young people.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sean Spicer’s Resurrection Might Be the Most Normal Event of the Trump Presidency
abstract: The former press secretary’s rapid return to public life shows there are few problems that fame can’t solve.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the general abnormality of Donald Trump’s presidency, the speedy and frictionless rehabilitation of Sean Spicer in recent days was curiously predictable. In the past week, the once-disgraced White House press secretary has made a sudden and jolly re-emergence: an appearance on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!,” a fellowship at Harvard and, at the Emmy Awards, a self-parody of his demonstrably false claim that Trump’s inaugural crowds were bigger than Barack Obama’s. “This will be the largest audience to witness the Emmys, period — both in person and around the world,” Spicer insisted in a perfect sendup of his most famous lie.

headline: Undercover With the Alt-Right
abstract: A Swedish graduate student infiltrated far right groups in the United States and Europe. This is what he saw.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Patrik Hermansson, a 25-year-old graduate student from Sweden, went undercover in the world of the extreme right. Posing as a student writing a thesis about the suppression of right-wing speech, he traveled from London to New York to Charlottesville, Va. — and into the heart of a dangerous movement that is experiencing a profound rejuvenation.

headline: Making Medicare Better
abstract: Medicare advocates suggest filling in coverage gaps, for starters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed critique of Senator Bernie Sanders’s “Medicare for All” proposal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Allan J. MacEachen, a Force in Bringing Public Health Care to Canada, Dies at 96
abstract: “Canadians are living in a country that Allan J. built, and they like it,” Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said.
lead_paragraph: Allan J. MacEachen, Canada’s first deputy prime minister and a legislator whose mastery of parliamentary politics ensured the country’s adoption of national health care and other far-reaching social programs, died on Sept. 12 in Antigonish, Nova Scotia. He was 96.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from John Schwartz, Lynda Richardson, and more.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: This New G.O.P. Publication Looks a Lot Like a News Website
abstract: The Free Telegraph is funded by the Republican Governors Association, which dismissed criticism that the website amounted to “propaganda.”
lead_paragraph: It may look and feel like a standard conservative news source — with the headlines, name and features to match — but The Free Telegraph is anything but. It’s actually a publication funded by the Republican Governors Association.

headline: Unemployment Is So 2009: Labor Shortage Gives Workers an Edge
abstract: Earnings are rising at a pace not seen in almost two decades. Will it be enough to draw more people off the bench and into the job market?
lead_paragraph: Is a new golden age for the American worker around the corner?

headline: Review: Grieving Among the Redwoods in a Pretty but Dull ‘Woodshock’
abstract: Kirsten Dunst stars in the hallucinatory first feature from the founders of Rodarte, Kate and Laura Mulleavy.
lead_paragraph: Unlike their spring 2018 fashion collection, Kate and Laura Mulleavy’s first foray into moviemaking, “Woodshock,” is depressingly dull and terminally inarticulate. Oh, it’s pretty enough, in the superficially embellished style of a perfume ad or fashion video — the gifted Finnish cinematographer Peter Flinckenberg virtually empties his bag of tricks. But it’s more lacking in substance than a yard of silk chiffon.

headline: When We’ll Recommend a Play, but Not Name It
abstract: Times readers disagreed with our decision not to include the obscene name of a play in our review of it. Our standards editor explains our policy.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center is a newsroom initiative that is helping The Times build deeper ties with our audience.

headline: Joyce Matz, Fervid Voice for Historic Preservation, Dies at 92
abstract: St. Bartholomew’s Church, Lever House and the Town Hall were among the sites she helped protect against developers, including Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Matz, a publicist who tenaciously represented civic groups seeking to preserve New York City landmarks like St. Bartholomew’s Episcopal Church, Lever House and the Town Hall, and to fend off developers like Donald J. Trump, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: Strong Earthquake Strikes Near Mexico City
abstract: A deadly 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck close to Mexico City. It comes less than two weeks after the most powerful earthquake in Mexico in a century.
lead_paragraph: A deadly 7.1 magnitude earthquake struck close to Mexico City. It comes less than two weeks after the most powerful earthquake in Mexico in a century.

headline: The iPhone 8 Reviews: What the Critics Say
abstract: Reviewers considered the phones a modest upgrade over the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus, but several suggested waiting for the iPhone X.
lead_paragraph: Reviews of the newest iPhones, the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus, landed across the internet on Tuesday, with most major reviewers agreeing that they represent a modest improvement over the previous generation but remain overshadowed by the looming iPhone X.

headline: Oral History: Remembering New York’s Fiorucci Store
abstract: “You come to New York to see the Empire State Building, the Statue of Liberty and Fiorucci.”
lead_paragraph: In 1976, a bustling retail store opened on East 59th Street in New York: It was called Fiorucci — a global concept shop by the Italian designer Elio Fiorucci, who had opened other outposts in London and Milan. It housed Fiorucci’s own fashion line, which had become famous for baby-faced angels on T-shirts and some of the first stretch jeans, as well as pieces from other designers, beauty products and accessories.

headline: Broadway Training, Gangnam Style
abstract: Six actors in search of K-pop authenticity star in a new musical that looks at the entertainment factories that produce genre-busting superstars.
lead_paragraph: When most Americans think of Korean pop music, colloquially called K-pop, what comes to mind is usually Psy’s “Gangnam Style” — a high-octane fusion of rap verses, techno beats and pop hooks, complete with an ultrabright music video and hypersynchronized dance moves. But the playwright Jason Kim is hoping to change that.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger M/W
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: As the Clintons Step Back From Global Stage, Bloomberg Steps Up
abstract: In a symbolic passing of the guard, Mr. Clinton will be the first speaker Wednesday at the Bloomberg Global Business Forum.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the Clinton Global Initiative was the star-studded marquee attraction during the annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, a place where heads of state, celebrities, billionaire philanthropists and business people mingled, made deals and gave away millions, sometimes billions, of dollars.

headline: A Sleepless Journey
abstract: A poem about a weary traveler.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Trump, Hurricane Maria, Mexico: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Details of Luxury Travel Dominate Robert Menendez’s Corruption Trial
abstract: The corruption trial of the New Jersey senator has often been a methodical parsing of details of the life of luxury he enjoyed courtesy of Dr. Salomon Melgen.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Abbe Lowell, a lawyer for Senator Robert Menendez, had a pressing question for the witness.

headline: Navy Leaders Pledge to Solve Problems Stretching Limits of Sailors
abstract: Navy officials cited extended deployments and 100-hour workweeks as among factors plaguing sailors as senators demanded answers for deadly accidents this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Navy’s top leaders acknowledged on Tuesday that the country’s fleet of warships and their accompanying sailors are deeply stretched because of a combination of 100-hour workweeks, budget constraints, extended deployments and delays in training and maintenance.

headline: The Ageless Ichiro Suzuki Methodically Chases Pinch-Hits Record
abstract: He has 26 pinch-hits this season for the Miami Marlins and three more will give him the major league record for a single season.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ichiro Suzuki is nearly 44 years old and it is already over a year since he recorded his 3,000th hit in the major leagues. And yet he may not be done making his mark on American baseball.

headline: Cornell Fraternity Closes Indefinitely After Racially Charged Attack
abstract: The Psi Upsilon alumni board at Cornell plans to devote the fraternity’s building to organizations that promote inclusiveness.
lead_paragraph: The alumni board of a Cornell University fraternity has decided to close the school’s chapter indefinitely, the school said Tuesday, after students who may have been involved in the fraternity were accused of attacking a black student, beating him and calling him by a racial epithet.

headline: Harvard Endowment Reports ‘Disappointing’ 8.1 Percent Return
abstract: The endowment’s new chief, N.P. Narvekar, said the university’s $37.1 billion fund had problems that would “require time to overcome.”
lead_paragraph: Describing the results as “disappointing,” Harvard University reported on Tuesday that its $37.1 billion endowment earned an 8.1 percent return for its most recent fiscal year.

headline: As Economy Grows, Fed Set to Shrink Bond Holdings
abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to announce on Wednesday it will begin to reduce its bond holdings, signaling confidence in the economy’s health.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, which invested trillions of dollars to prop up the American economy after the 2008 financial crisis, is finally ready to take away the crutches.

headline: Officials Fault Charter Bus Industry After Fatal Queens Crash
abstract: Calls for regulation followed the deaths of three people in a crash that occurred when a bus, driven by a man previously fired for drunken driving, hurtled through an intersection in Flushing.
lead_paragraph: Officials called for stricter regulation of private buses on city streets after the revelation that the man who plowed a charter bus into a New York City bus early Monday, killing himself and two others, had lost his license overr drunken driving two years ago but was able to get back behind the wheel relatively quickly.

headline: Charles Owens, Golfer, Dies at 85; Novel Putter Brought Late Success
abstract: Owens overcame segregation, severe injuries and, with a long putter, the “yips” to win on the Senior PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: If Charles Owens was going to jump-start a late-blooming golf career, he had to fix his putting. He was 51 and playing on the Senior PGA Tour. He had bad legs and a painful back. And he had the yips — involuntary hand and arm movements that caused him to yank his putts one way or the other.

headline: The Police Need to Understand Autism
abstract: A 14-year-old Arizona boy’s terrifying experience underscores that officers should be trained on how to recognize people on the spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Diane Craglow was caring for a 14-year-old autistic boy named Connor Leibel in Buckeye, Ariz., one day in July. They took a walk to one of his favorite places, a park in an upscale community called Verrado. She was not hesitant to leave Connor alone for a few minutes while she booked a piano lesson for his sister nearby, because he usually feels safe and comfortable in places that are familiar to him, and he learns to be more independent that way.

headline: Widespread Deceptive Practices May Reduce Payouts in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
abstract: “We don’t want to watch these awards be cannibalized,” a lawyer for retired players told a judge investigating lenders and others seeking a cut of payments.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Lawyers for professional football players who reached a landmark settlement with the N.F.L. over concussions said Tuesday that hundreds of their clients may have been swindled by unscrupulous lenders and advisers looking for a cut of their payments.

headline: Amid Protests, St. Louis Mayor Walks a Political Tightrope
abstract: Mayor Lyda Krewson promised to curb violence and heal racial divisions. Then a former police officer was acquitted of murder.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — After hours of mostly peaceful protests over a white former police officer’s acquittal in the fatal shooting of a black man, a crowd of demonstrators gathered in St. Louis Friday night outside the new mayor’s house. Soon, rocks were flying.

headline: Executive’s Sexist Rant at Kathy Griffin Prompts Backlash
abstract: Jeffrey Mezger, the C.E.O. of KB Home, used a crude reference to the female anatomy to refer to the comedian during a dispute over a noise complaint.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Mezger, the chief executive of KB Home, one of the country’s largest homebuilders, was captured on audio Saturday night yelling at his neighbor, the comedian Kathy Griffin, using a series of sexist and homophobic slurs.

headline: Theaster Gates Wins $100,000 Nasher Prize for Sculpture
abstract: Mr. Gates, an artist whose work spans many disciplines, said he will use the money in part to develop literature.
lead_paragraph: Theaster Gates’s work spans many disciplines, from sculpture to pottery to performance art to urban development. So it’s unsurprising that when given a $100,000 award for his achievement in one field, he would use it to jump right into another.

headline: Wheaton College Football Players Charged With Violent Hazing Attack
abstract: The five players were charged with multiple felonies in connection with a 2016 attack.
lead_paragraph: Five football players at Wheaton College, an evangelical school in Illinois, were charged with a string of felonies on Tuesday in connection with what prosecutors said was a hazing episode in 2016 in which another student was bound, beaten and left half-naked on a baseball field in the middle of the night.

headline: With Home Run No. 5,694, Baseball Sets a Record With Time to Spare
abstract: Major league hitters have continued a power surge that began several years ago, and one that does not have a clear explanation.
lead_paragraph: With no outs, the bases empty and a full count in the top of the eighth inning in Toronto on Tuesday, Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin set his target low and in against Alex Gordon, a left-handed hitter for the Kansas City Royals. Ryan Tepera, a Blue Jays right-hander, tried a cutter but left it belt-high on the outer half of the plate. Gordon swung hard and ripped the mistake over the fence in right center for a homer.

headline: Senate Republicans Embrace Plan for $1.5 Trillion Tax Cut
abstract: Senate Republicans, abandoning a key fiscal doctrine, agreed to move ahead on a budget that would add to the federal deficit in order to pave the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, abandoning a key fiscal doctrine, agreed on Tuesday to move forward on a budget that would add to the federal deficit in order to pave the way for a $1.5 trillion tax cut over the next 10 years.

headline: Officer Who Tackled James Blake Was Told He Might Be Armed
abstract: Officer James Frascatore, at his disciplinary trial, said the former athlete resembled a picture of a suspect that a supervisor warned might be armed.
lead_paragraph: In the New York City police officer’s recollection, a man who was leaning against a pillar outside the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Midtown in 2015 looked just like the person he was supposed to arrest, a suspect in a credit card fraud ring who the officer had been told might be armed.

headline: Republican Leaders Defy Bipartisan Opposition to Health Law Repeal
abstract: Senator Lamar Alexander gave up on his effort to shore up health care markets as his fellow Republicans pressured lawmakers to back the latest Affordable Care Act repeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eleven governors, including five Republicans and a pivotal Alaskan independent, urged the Senate on Tuesday to reject a last-ditch push to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.

headline: In Michael Beasley, the Knicks Have a Perfectly Imperfect Symbol
abstract: Once the No. 2 pick in the N.B.A. draft, Beasley has been something of a basketball vagabond. But he is only 28, and he is brimming with confidence.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Michael Beasley, one of the Knicks’ new acquisitions, said Tuesday that he had shed about 20 pounds since last season, when he was a reserve forward with the Milwaukee Bucks. He altered his diet: fewer carbohydrates, more fruits and vegetables. He said he is old enough now, at 28, to know what foods he can handle.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pledging to ‘Destroy’ North Korea if Provoked
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 20, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “The United States has great strength and patience, but if it is forced to defend itself or its allies, we will have no choice but to totally destroy North Korea.”

headline: Warmongers and Peacemakers at the U.N.
abstract: President Trump, unlike Barack Obama, brought lots of fury to the General Assembly and hardly a hint of compromise or interest in negotiating.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations isn’t the venue one would expect for threatening war. Yet that’s what President Trump did in his first address to the General Assembly.

headline: Green Monster’s Ballpark
abstract: Hal Moore collects a complete set.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hal Moore’s first Wednesday offering solves a bit like a themeless crossword. It’s not, but the theme is one of those you might not discover until you’ve filled in the entire grid. A crossword koan might be, “Is a grid, completed without an understanding of the theme, actually complete?”

headline: Review: ‘One Night Only,’ With Energy to Spare
abstract: Monica Bill Barnes and Anna Bass explore friendship, competition and endurance in a show that mixes physical exertion and mischievous humor.
lead_paragraph: Competition is inherently dramatic, yet sports have been woefully underrepresented on stage. When they have, whether in “Damn Yankees,” “Take Me Out” or “Lombardi,” the focus has largely been on relationships rather than the beauty, power and endorphin-fueled giddiness of athletic feats. (Boxing is the exception, with “Beautiful Burnout” and even the musical “Rocky.”)

headline: Yankees Roll to a Victory That Yields Little Reward
abstract: The Yankees got a second straight win over Minnesota, a team they have dominated in recent years, but hurt their chances of facing the Twins in a potential wild-card matchup.
lead_paragraph: Brett Gardner and Starlin Castro each had three hits, and C. C. Sabathia turned in a solid start as the Yankees kept pace with the Boston Red Sox in the American League East with a perfunctory 5-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday night.

headline: Listen: Locals Describe Hurricane Maria’s Damage in Dominica
abstract: With no power, phones or internet, Dominica residents turned to amateur radio to give updates on their situation after Hurricane Maria battered the island.
lead_paragraph: With no power, phones or internet, Dominica residents turned to amateur radio to give updates on their situation after Hurricane Maria battered the island.

headline: Buildings Across Mexico City That Toppled in the Earthquake
abstract: Photographs and maps reveal the intensity of Tuesday’s earthquake and the extent of the damage.
lead_paragraph: Photographs and maps reveal the intensity of Tuesday’s earthquake and the extent of the damage.

headline: Corrections: September 20, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 20, 2017.

headline: The Ravenous Parties of London Fashion Week
abstract: Armani, Fiorucci and Love Magazine hosted the week’s most spectacular parties.
lead_paragraph: London — For all the spectacles that took place on the runways of London Fashion Week, it was at the after-parties where the real fun began.

headline: A Stress Link to Lupus
abstract: Women exposed to trauma, including serious car crashes or sexual assaults, were at increased risk of developing the autoimmune disorder lupus.
lead_paragraph: Psychological trauma is associated with an increased risk for lupus, a new study reports.

headline: Why a World-Famous Art Exhibition Needed a Government Bailout
abstract: Documenta, the German contemporary art exhibition that some view as the world’s most important, ran into financial trouble when it expanded to Greece.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Debt was one of the core themes of the 14th edition of Documenta, the sprawling German exhibition of contemporary art that takes place every five years in the city of Kassel. The failure of this year’s show to balance its own books may be one of its enduring legacies.

headline: Before Wisconsin, Foxconn Vowed Big Spending in Brazil. Few Jobs Have Come.
abstract: The Taiwanese company’s manufacturing model has not translated easily to other countries, where it faces different social, political and labor conditions.
lead_paragraph: Before the Taiwanese manufacturing giant Foxconn pledged to spend $10 billion and create 13,000 jobs in Wisconsin, the company made a similar promise in Brazil.

headline: Word + Quiz: polyglot
abstract: This word has appeared in 36 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: United Nations, Mexico, Hurricane Maria: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump Tweets He Was ‘Saddened’ by ‘Bad’ Emmy Ratings
abstract: Politics dominated the awards show on Sunday, and two days later, the president finally reacted.
lead_paragraph: President Trump had international affairs on his mind Tuesday morning. In his speech before the United Nations, he threatened to “totally destroy North Korea.” He lambasted the Iran nuclear deal. And he proclaimed that parts of the world “are going to hell.”

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Channel Zero: No-End House’ and ‘The Good Place’
abstract: “Channel Zero” turns to another creepy internet story for its second installment. And Kristen Bell returns to the so-called “good place” with plenty of questions.
lead_paragraph: “Channel Zero” borrows from another creepy, cultish internet story for its second installment. And Kristen Bell returns to the “good place” with plenty of questions.

headline: Favorite Stores
abstract: What is your favorite brick-and-mortar store? Why? How is shopping there different from shopping online?
lead_paragraph: Did you go to Toys “R” Us when you were younger? Did you know that it has just filed for bankruptcy protection? As more and more people shop online, retailers like this one — which are known as brick-and-mortar stores — are under great pressure.

headline: For Many Medical Students, the Caribbean Was Warm and Welcoming. Until Now.
abstract: Offshore schools have become an established part of the medical education system, but two deadly hurricanes have damaged some schools and led to evacuations.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Maria roared over the island of Dominica on Tuesday, dozens of parents of students at Ross University School of Medicine posted anguished messages on the school’s Facebook page, searching for their children and praying that they had survived unscathed.

headline: Right and Left React to Trump’s Speech at the U.N.
abstract: Writers from across the political spectrum discuss President Trump’s bellicose address to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: The Women Who Toil in Ivory Coast’s ‘World of Smoke’
abstract: In an impoverished port city, women and children do the dangerous, filthy work of making charcoal from the castoffs of sawmills and workshops.
lead_paragraph: In an impoverished port city, women and children do the dangerous, filthy work of making charcoal from the castoffs of sawmills and workshops.

headline: Who Should Decide Whether a Teenager Can Get a Tattoo or Piercing?
abstract: Should parents and doctors be involved in a teenager’s decision to get a tattoo or piercing?
lead_paragraph: Do you have any tattoos or body piercings? If so, were your parents involved in your decision? If not, why have you chosen not to get one?

headline: The ‘Madman’ Is Back in the Building
abstract: I returned to work after my psychotic break, but my bipolar disorder did, too.
lead_paragraph: What do you wear the first day back to work after a 90-day leave of absence because of a psychotic break? This is the question I found myself asking a little more than a year after I joined the Legal Aid Society of New York. The last time my colleagues had seen me, I’d been wearing a handlebar mustache better suited to a Hell’s Angel than a 26-year-old public defender. I’d also taken to wearing a Mohawk — tried a case like that even. We won, thank God.

headline: Vietnam on the Reel-to-Reel
abstract: Even though I was a child in the ’60s, I saw how the war was tearing us apart.
lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 1989, and I was teaching a course called “Vietnam and Literature” at Colby College in Maine. One of my students, Mark Wilson, brought in some things of his father’s, including a Bronze Star he’d found buried in one of his dad’s bottom drawers.

headline: You Don’t Have to Be Jewish to Celebrate Rosh Hashana
abstract: If you crave an anti-new year New Year, consider adopting the Jewish one, which begins Wednesday at sundown, as your own.
lead_paragraph: I hate New Year’s Eve. For years, I tried to rally and convince myself that the hellscape of selfies and stilettos was fun. More recently I’ve wised up and fled the city to my grandparents in Florida, where I play bartender and we’re all in bed by 10 p.m.

headline: When Will Black Lives Matter in St. Louis?
abstract: Military tanks, tear gas and rubber bullets won’t bridge the gap between the police and the black community anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — On Aug. 9, 2014, Mike Brown was killed by Darren Wilson, a police officer in the St. Louis suburb Ferguson, Mo. What followed were months of overwhelmingly nonviolent protests that were policed by law enforcement officers who wore riot gear, shook their batons at protesters and took joy-rides in heavily armored military vehicles. In November 2014, a grand jury decided not to indict Mr. Wilson, and a few months later federal investigators cleared him of any wrongdoing.

headline: Even College Doesn’t Bridge the Racial Income Gap
abstract: College is supposedly the great leveler. But race still affects average pay for graduates, indicating that discrimination is a major cause.
lead_paragraph: Education is supposed to be the nation’s great socioeconomic leveler. That belief, however, is not borne out in the data. Pay gaps between white and black workers have grown since 1979, even after controlling for education, experience and location, according to research by the Economic Policy Institute. In fact, racial pay gaps have expanded the most for college graduates, which makes it seem clear that discrimination is a leading cause.

headline: Women Finding Empowerment in ‘A World of Smoke’
abstract: In an impoverished port city in the Ivory Coast, women formed a cooperative to eke out a living making charcoal from the castoffs of sawmills and workshops.
lead_paragraph: In the charcoal fields of San Pedro, a bustling port city in the southwest Ivory Coast, hundreds of women and children — some barely school-age — toil day and night among heaps moldering wood, waste water and air thick with smoke. Driving rain, withering heat and sawdust storms come with the job. This used to be men’s work. Not anymore.Making charcoal for sale out of the refuse from nearby sawmills, work for the desperate and destitute, has become almost exclusively women’s work in San Pedro. It may have started with one widow from Bogart, a desperately poor slum, who ventured into one of the three charcoal fields in San Pedro, the Parc Du Pont, intent on making a dollar to feed her family.As Joana Choumali learned when she began documenting the women in 2013, men are happy to sell wood, San Pedro’s largest export, and let women keep the filthy, back-breaking work of making charcoal. Ms. Choumali, a freelance documentary and fine art photographer from Abidjan, was on an assignment in San Pedro when she first spotted the phenomenon.Three years later, Ms. Choumali’s project, “Sissi Barra (The Work of Smoke),” illustrates the harsh reality for women with few choices, the poorest of the poor, in the Ivory Coast. While the country is enjoying an economic revival and now boasts Africa’s fastest growing economy, the charcoal producers of San Pedro live like paupers. Her conversation with Evelyn Nieves has been condensed and edited.

lead_paragraph: In the Catholic Church of Pope Francis, it is dangerous to be too conservative. headline: In Los Angeles, Hotel Hipness Makes a Grand Return
abstract: Thanks to a new breed of high-rise hotels — complete with public pools and gaggles of fashionable locals — transitory spaces have become permanent hot spots.
lead_paragraph: “It must have been marvelous when the century was young,” Eve Babitz wrote of the Garden of Allah hotel in 1977. By the time Ms. Babitz — whose frothy, witty, cutting books about Los Angeles have gained a new cult following since being recently reissued — was writing about the famed Hollywood hotel, it had already been demolished, bulldozed in 1959 to make way for the Lytton Savings bank. That bank, now a Chase, was then surrounded by a shopping center on the corner of Sunset Boulevard and Laurel Avenue.

headline: Building a Better Coral Reef
abstract: As reefs die off, researchers want to breed the world’s hardiest corals in labs and return them to the sea to multiply. The effort raises scientific and ethical questions.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are: China’s Art Dreamers at the Guggenheim
abstract: A story of China from 1989 to 2008, seen through the eyes of its avant-garde artists.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The signature work at “Art and China After 1989,” a highly anticipated show  that takes over the Guggenheim on Oct. 6, is a simple table with a see-through dome shaped like the back of a tortoise. On the tabletop hundreds of insects and reptiles — gekkos, locusts, crickets, centipedes and cockroaches – mill about under the glow of an overhead lamp.

headline: The Lonely Road Back From a Very Public Injury
abstract: Manchester City midfielder Ilkay Gundogan had braced himself for the worst when he went down with a torn A.C.L. last December. Now he just had to face it.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — From the other side of the wall, the muffled sounds of halftime drifted through to Ilkay Gundogan. He could hear the skitter of studs on the floor, the murmuring voices of his Manchester City teammates exchanging notes, and then his manager, Pep Guardiola, starting to speak.

headline: Pelham, N.Y.: Close to the City, but With a Friendly Vibe
abstract: The oldest town in Westchester County, Pelham is a place where people know one another and “there’s nothing cookie-cutter” about the homes.
lead_paragraph: Abby Balafas wasn’t sure she wanted to live in the suburbs. But the Manhattan apartment she and her husband, Evan Balafas, were renting started feeling cramped after the birth of their first daughter. So the couple began researching towns with an easy commute and a strong school system. Once they narrowed their focus to Pelham, N.Y., they made a date with a real estate broker. “We took the baby, got a Zipcar and headed out,” said Mr. Balafas, 36, who is a vice president of finance for a media company in Manhattan.

headline: How to Be Mindful When You Are Sick
abstract: We often compound our physical ailments with negative reactions, making us not just sick, but anxious about being sick, and maybe also resentful.
lead_paragraph: “It might seem crazy to want to be more conscious of illness and discomfort. Yet mindfulness — moment to moment, nonjudgmental awareness — may be exactly what your body most needs when you are run down and under the weather. Between feeling rotten, and the stress of managing responsibilities while fighting illness, we often compound our physical ailments with negative reactions, making us not just sick, but anxious about being sick, and maybe also resentful. Since stress compromises our immune system, becoming caught up in this way can slow down our recovery. Instead, aim to approach your illness with care, seeing things as they are, with acceptance and compassion.” — Mark Bertin, M.D., a doctor specializing in developmental pediatrics.

headline: The Contradiction Buried in Trump’s Iran and North Korea Policies

headline: Hear What Makes ‘Norma’ the Everest of Opera

headline: ‘The Pills Are Everywhere’: How the Opioid Crisis Claims Its Youngest Victims
abstract: Increasingly, toddlers and young children are being found unconscious or dead after consuming an adult’s drugs.
lead_paragraph: When Penny Mae Cormani died in Utah, her family sang Mormon hymns — “Be Still My Soul” — and lowered her small coffin into the earth. The latest victim of a drug epidemic that is now taking 60,000 lives a year, Penny was just 1.

headline: When Wedgwood Showed a Wilder Side
abstract: We know it for its traditional ceramics. But once, the storied pottery maker turned out the most bonkers design around.
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE, PERHAPS on a great-aunt’s Thanksgiving table, or in the drawer of a rattan nightstand in that cottage you rented on the Cape or in a yellowed photo from an advertising supplement that an Etsy find came wrapped in, you have seen it. Maybe you’ve even held it in your hand. It is a teacup, a finger bowl, a heart-shaped jewelry tray, a curved platter, likely in an unmistakable shade of chalky blue, adorned with a raised eggshell-white neo-Classical winged horse, or a gladiator kneeling in silhouette.

headline: Kenya Court Says It Nullified Election Over Possible Hacking
abstract: It said the electoral commission had failed to instill confidence in the results, but the justices stopped short of calling the vote rigged.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Kenya’s Supreme Court said on Wednesday that it had nullified last month’s presidential election because the voting may have been hacked, and accused the electoral commission of failing to verify results before announcing them.

headline: Tensions Rise in Spain as Catalonia Referendum Nears
abstract: The Spanish police have raided regional government offices and detained at least 14 people less than two weeks before a vote Madrid has vowed to block.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish police detained more than a dozen people in the region of Catalonia on Wednesday, drastically escalating tensions between the national government and Catalan separatists. The episode occurred less than two weeks before a highly contentious referendum on independence that the government in Madrid has vowed to block.

headline: Trump Pushes to Revisit Iran Nuclear Deal, and Asks Allies to Help

lead_paragraph: THE QUEST FOR PERFECTION lends itself to parody: the film director demanding the 40th take; the novelist toiling over a masterpiece for a decade in a darkened room; the artist slashing the canvas in despair over an errant brush stroke.

headline: Parliament Square in London Is Closer to Having First Female Statue

headline: She’ll Be Back ... but What Will Linda Hamilton’s New ‘Terminator’ Be Like?
abstract: James Cameron is breaking new ground by bringing the action heroine back: Older, wiser, tougher and crazier.
lead_paragraph: For years now, the world’s “Terminator” fans have been comfortable in the knowledge that we would never again be excited by the prospect of seeing another film in the franchise: The last one, “Terminator Genisys,” was even more muddled than its title. But in an announcement this week, James Cameron, the series’ creator, said that another “Terminator” would soon be rolling off the production line. And he gave us two good reasons to hope that civilization won’t be crushed by robots before its release.

headline: Jake LaMotta, ‘Raging Bull’ in and Out of the Ring, Dies at 95
abstract: LaMotta, who learned to box in a reformatory, won the middleweight championship and inspired an acclaimed film in which he was played by Robert De Niro.
lead_paragraph: Jake LaMotta, boxing’s “Raging Bull,” who brawled his way to the middleweight boxing championship in a life of unbridled fury — within the ring and outside it — that became the subject of an acclaimed film, died on Tuesday in Aventura, Fla., near Miami. He was 95.

headline: Mets’ Painful Season Can Be Summed Up in Two Words: Steven Matz
abstract: The left-hander pitched in periodic discomfort for a good part of the season and then eventually got a diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Mets selected Steven Matz out of Ward Melville High School on Long Island in the second round of the 2009 draft, his career has been defined by injuries. His latest setback, which is costing him the final month and a half of this season, helps define the current state of the Mets.

headline: The True Blue Asiatic Dayflower
abstract: Blue is rare in nature. These brief blooms — hence the term “dayflower” — are honest-to-goodness blue.
lead_paragraph: Just as the first cool hints of autumn displace summer’s sultry haze, Asiatic dayflowers’ blooms reach their peak, scattering flecks of sky blue into the corners of garden plots and local parks. As the name suggests, each bloom only lasts a day, but each plant produces many flowers, so a wet season means weeks of dayflowers. In sheltered niches, dayflowers sometimes usher in the first days of winter.

headline: Moses Sumney Does Not Sing Love Songs
abstract: The Los Angeles musician questions our culture’s fixation on couples in love on his dreamy debut album, “Aromanticism.”
lead_paragraph: Moses Sumney has a voice that can melt hearts: a gently grainy tenor that often ascends into an immaculate, unearthly falsetto. It’s no wonder that his first public gigs in Los Angeles, back in 2013, almost immediately drew fellow musicians as well as a swarm of record-label types eager to shape his music into a commercial commodity.

headline: San Francisco Chefs Serve Up a Message About Climate Change
abstract: Karen Leibowitz and Anthony Myint, who started Mission Street Food, have new ideas for the Perennial, their restaurant that promotes sustainability.
lead_paragraph: Karen Leibowitz and Anthony Myint opened the Perennial in San Francisco last year with a clear mission in mind: Run an environmentally friendly restaurant with a minimal carbon footprint, and inspire other restaurateurs to do the same.
