abstract: Photos from the Mexico Earthquake
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Mexico Earthquake

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Bunny Rogers brings her Columbine trilogy to the Whitney; Mary Heilmann’s Process Art is on view at Craig F. Starr Gallery; and more.
lead_paragraph: Through Oct. 9. Whitney Museum of American Art, 99 Gansevoort Street, Manhattan; 212-570-3600, whitney.org.

headline: Custom Jewelry With a Hip-Hop Following
abstract: An immigrant from Macau opened Popular Jewelry, a humble store on Canal Street, in 1988. But then Cappadonna from the Wu-Tang Clan walked in. The rest is history.
lead_paragraph: On Canal Street, between a huddle of tarp-covered sidewalk stalls hawking sunglasses and key chains, is a yellow sign over an awning that reads “Popular Jewelry.”

headline: Chinese Dialects in Singapore: The Government Responds
abstract: Singapore’s ambassador to the United States takes issue with a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For Refugee Chefs, This Meal Is a Business Card
abstract: A food and arts festival aims to help migrants and asylum seekers build professional networks and foster better understanding of displaced people.
lead_paragraph: Adwa Alsubaie had never cooked outside a home kitchen until last May. Two years after she and her sister fled their home in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Ms. Alsubaie, 20, got a job in the kitchen at Emma’s Torch, a brunch spot in Red Hook, Brooklyn, that doubles as a culinary school for refugees and political asylum seekers.

headline: Why Mexico Is So Prone to Strong Earthquakes
abstract: Two powerful quakes, 12 days apart, have killed hundreds of people in Mexico this month. We look at how, where and why the big ones happen.
lead_paragraph: Two strong earthquakes, 12 days apart, have shaken Mexico this month, crumpling buildings, sending panicked people into the streets, and together killing hundreds of people who were unable to escape the destruction.

headline: BTS Takes a Different Approach to K-pop: Ease
abstract: On this boy band’s new EP, “Love Yourself: ‘Her’,” the group steps back from the genre’s sometimes manic energy.
lead_paragraph: The best song on “Love Yourself: ‘Her’,” the new EP from the K-pop stars BTS, isn’t the main single, “DNA,” with its shuddering club-music drops and urgent Shawn Mendes-esque guitar intro. Nor is it “Best of Me,” which was written in part by Andrew Taggart, of the dim pop-EDM outfit the Chainsmokers, and fits neatly into that duo’s litany of songs that swell and throb yet still feel like dirges.

headline: Lillian Ross, Acclaimed Reporter for The New Yorker, Dies at 99
abstract: One of her rules of journalism was, “Do not call attention to yourself.” Yet she did just that in a memoir about her long affair with her celebrated editor.
lead_paragraph: Lillian Ross, who became known as the consummate fly-on-the-wall reporter in more than six decades at The New Yorker, whether writing about Ernest Hemingway, Hollywood or a busload of Indiana high school seniors on a class trip to New York, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 99.

headline: The Awful Beauty of the ‘White War’
abstract: One of the most perilous and least known battlefields of the war was in the Dolomites. Corpses are still emerging.
lead_paragraph: The caption that appeared 100 years ago in The New York Times Mid-Week Pictorial referred to a “picturesque scene” in the Dolomites, where Italian soldiers were defending the frontier against Austrian and German invasion.

headline: Gucci: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Alberta Ferretti: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Europe Renews Offensive on Silicon Valley With Tax Reforms
abstract: A new set of proposals presented by officials in Brussels seek to tax technology companies differently, but risk being seen as an effort to target American tech giants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s offensive against Silicon Valley looks as though it is likely to resume, as officials in Brussels consider a raft of proposals aimed at increasing the amount of tax paid by digital titans like Facebook and Amazon.

headline: Bigger Libraries for New York City
abstract: A reader asks if we trust city officials to negotiate with developers on behalf of the public.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Follow Kenya’s Example on Plastic Bags
abstract: The Plastics Industry Association takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Confident Fed Sets Stage for December Rate Increase
abstract: The Federal Reserve said a trio of punishing hurricanes were unlikely to reduce the pace of economic growth, and it continued to dismantle its stimulus programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a decade after the Federal Reserve embarked on an unprecedented effort to shore up the collapsing American economy, the central bank said on Wednesday that it would begin withdrawing some of the trillions of dollars it invested in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: G.O.P.’s $1.5 Trillion Tax Cut
abstract: A reader points out that previous Republican tax cuts exploded the deficit. “Yet here they go again.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Far Away Brothers’ Breathes Vivid Life Into Immigration Issues
abstract: Lauren Markham’s impeccably timed and intimately reported book follows twin teenage brothers on their journey from El Salvador to California.
lead_paragraph: If, as a public official, your best solution to a complicated problem is to build a wall, the odds are pretty good you’ll eventually smack into one. A wall was the thousand-mile backdrop to Donald J. Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign. But as we’ve seen over the past few weeks, with the president declaring and then undeclaring his intention to end the DACA program, the realities of immigration reform are complicated. They correspond little to the anxieties of the public imagination. Realities seldom do.

headline: Trump’s Bellicose Speech at the U.N.
abstract: Readers criticize his speech for promoting the “dark alleys of nationalism” and threatening to destroy North Korea.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: A Priceless Violin, a Cut-Rate Caper
abstract: Loosely inspired by a true story, Dan McCormick’s play “The Violin” follows a lost Stradivarius that falls into greedy hands.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Philippe Quint, a classical violinist, left his Stradivarius in the back of a Newark airport taxi. The driver returned the instrument. Mr. Quint rewarded him and his fellow cabbies with a command performance.

headline: Review: Fugues, Rags and Dylan by Twyla Tharp. Oh, She Dances Too.
abstract: Twyla Tharp Dance returns to New York, with a world premiere to Dylan songs, a staged rehearsal and two classics from the early 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Twyla Tharp is a brand name twice over. She’s the maker of both a large, epoch-making body of choreography and a legendarily sensuous dance style.

headline: T Fashion Editors’ Guide to Milan
abstract: A shortlist of places to relax, enjoy a meal, shop a bit — and find some peace between the shows during fashion week (and always).
lead_paragraph: Classic Milanese Meals

headline: Prosecutors Want Anthony Weiner to Serve About 2 Years in Prison
abstract: The government asked a judge to sentence Mr. Weiner to a prison term of 21 to 27 months for his conviction in a sexting case.
lead_paragraph: Anthony D. Weiner, the disgraced former Democratic congressman, has asked not to serve any prison time for his conviction in a sexting case. But his request for probation was “simply inadequate,” federal prosecutors said on Wednesday, adding that “his crime deserves time in prison.”

headline: On a California Ranch, Perfect Conditions for Pro Surfing
abstract: The World Surf League hosted a test event Tuesday at Kelly Slater’s Surf Ranch in Lemoore, Calif., the first time a wave system has been used competitively.
lead_paragraph: The world’s top professional surfers got a glimpse of their competitive future on Tuesday: an assembly line of perfect waves, each one identical to the one before it, and all breaking at perfectly timed intervals.

headline: Forget Fan Fiction. In Nerdlesque, the Garters Come Off.
abstract: In this pop-culture twist on burlesque, performers put on tributes to movies and shows like “Doctor Who.” Not a fan? You can still admire the dancing.
lead_paragraph: On stage at the Slipper Room this month, Lilly Hayes, the performer known as Miranda Raven, kicked off her black moon boots before zipping out of her astronaut costume to reveal a pair of jeans, white button-down shirt and denim jacket — the signature look of River Song, a character from “Doctor Who.”

headline: Months After Second Avenue Subway Opening, Safety Testing Is Not Finished
abstract: In a rush to finish the Second Avenue subway, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority failed to complete final safety testing before opening the line.
lead_paragraph: In a rush to finish New York City’s long-awaited Second Avenue subway by a New Year’s Day deadline imposed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority failed to complete final safety testing before opening the line to the public, according to oversight reports submitted to the federal government.

headline: Republicans Defend Health Bill Against Another Adversary: Jimmy Kimmel
abstract: “I wish he understood completely,” Senator Bill Cassidy, one of the bill’s co-authors, said of Mr. Kimmel, who has been a frequent critic of G.O.P. health legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after Jimmy Kimmel unleashed a monologue attacking the latest bill that would undo much of the Affordable Care Act, two of the bill’s authors spent Wednesday morning defending the legislation against the late-night host, who in recent months has become an unlikely — and increasingly impassioned — critic.

headline: Mueller Seeks White House Documents Related to Trump’s Actions as President
abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, is interested in Mr. Trump’s firing of his F.B.I. director and national security adviser and other events.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, has asked the White House for documents about some of President Trump’s most scrutinized actions since taking office, including the firing of his national security adviser and F.B.I. director, according to White House officials.

headline: In Central Park, Teaching Dogs to Sit (in Yiddish)
abstract: There’s a lot of kibitzing and not much kvetching in a course sponsored by a Jewish nonprofit that teaches dogs (and humans) commands in Yiddish.
lead_paragraph: The humans gathered for coffee and chocolate rugelach at the check-in table near the 67th Street and Fifth Avenue entrance of Central Park. The dogs sampled homemade apple cookies, or kichel, and sipped water. Owners were encouraged to take training treats to keep in their pockets.

headline: How to Conquer Fashion’s New Frontier
abstract: Cowboy boots, stiff denim, contrast stitching, boot-cut jeans — here’s how to shop the best of fall’s Western trend.
lead_paragraph: Are you feeling nostalgic for a certain kind of America, one that was simpler, wilder and full of possibility? Fashion sure is. Themes and motifs pillaged from the Wild West — or our fantasy of it — played out all over the fall 2017 runways, most notably at Raf Simons’s debut collection for Calvin Klein, which featured bygone staples in unexpected color combinations.

headline: Hating ‘Mother!’: Readers Speak Out
abstract: After Jennifer Lawrence and Darren Aronofsky offered their explanation of the film, you offered your verdict. Thumbs down doesn’t even begin to describe it.
lead_paragraph: It may not have attracted mass audiences, but “Mother!,” Darren Aronofsky’s allegorical thriller, did succeed in getting a lot of people talking — even if they hadn’t seen the movie. “Mother!,” which stars Jennifer Lawrence and Javier Bardem, is meant to be a parable about climate change and environmental destruction, as Mr. Aronofsky and Ms. Lawrence revealed in a recent New York Times article. Critics were divided — A.O. Scott called it “a hoot” — but on nytimes.com and on our Facebook page, most moviegoers weren’t persuaded. Here is a selection of their comments, edited for length and clarity.

headline: Where to Donate to Mexico Earthquake Victims
abstract: Here is a list of local and international organizations that are helping those affected.
lead_paragraph: The powerful earthquake that struck Mexico on Tuesday has killed more than 200 people, and more deaths are expected. Buildings collapsed across Mexico City, including a school where at least 30 students were believed to have been killed. Rescuers on Wednesday scrambled to dig out people trapped beneath rubble.

headline: The 15 Best Photos of London Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from Versus, J.W. Anderson and more shows at London Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from Versus, J.W. Anderson and more shows at London Fashion Week.

headline: Our Favorite Photos of London Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from Versus, J.W. Anderson and more — on (and off) the runway.
lead_paragraph: London Fashion Week came to a close with the Tommy Hilfiger show on Tuesday evening. To cover the week, T’s photographers fanned out across the city to capture Molly Goddards’s party-within-a-show, Simone Rocha’s Edwardian-inspired show — and much more.

headline: Graham-Cassidy Has One Great Idea
abstract: It gives states more control over their health care.
lead_paragraph: The latest Republican stab at overhauling the Affordable Care Act manages to be both more timid and more sweeping than previous efforts to replace Obamacare. Known as Graham-Cassidy, it was written by a quartet of Republican senators led by Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Bill Cassidy of Louisiana.

headline: Emboldened China Wields Its Laws to Silence Critics From Abroad
abstract: The case of a rights activist from Taiwan awaiting sentencing in China for subversion is emblematic of a wider, global campaign, critics say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On the morning he disappeared, the activist Lee Ming-cheh crossed from Macau into mainland China to meet with democracy advocates.

headline: ‘Yes, We Need to Do Better’: World Leaders Talk Democracy
abstract: At the Athens Democracy Forum, global leaders discussed the state of democracy and its challenges around the world.
lead_paragraph: At the Athens Democracy Forum, a conference convened by The New York Times in Athens, from Sept. 13 to 17, global leaders talked about the state of democracy and its challenges around the world. The following are edited excerpts from several of the participants, who discussed the relevancy of international organizations like the United Nations how to better engage young people in the democratic process, policy strategies can help bring democracy to the developing world and what are some new models to consider.

headline: Voter Fraud? A Trump Nominee Looks as if He Cast an Illegal Ballot
abstract: Jeffrey Gerrish, the president’s nominee to be deputy U.S. Trade Representative, is drawing Senate scrutiny for a vote cast in Virginia after he moved to Maryland.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump’s voter integrity commission looks under rocks for possible voter malfeasance, its members might want to examine a presidential nominee awaiting confirmation by the Senate Finance Committee.

headline: Street Style: London
abstract: The fashion crowds move to Britain for London Fashion Week, bringing their best street style looks along for the trip.
lead_paragraph: The fashion crowds move to Britain for London Fashion Week, bringing their best street style looks along for the trip.

headline: If You Shame Them, Will They Pay?
abstract: Forever 21 was selling a T-shirt that looked very similar to an indie designer’s. And it’s not the first time the store has come under fire.
lead_paragraph: Zoila Darton and Angela Carrasco felt sad about the state of women’s rights in the United States, and they decided to channel some of their frustration into action.

headline: 8 Pedestrian-Friendly U.S. Cities to Explore
abstract: In honor of Car Free Day — Friday, Sept. 22 — take stock of these old (and new) pedestrian-friendly American destinations.
lead_paragraph: Cities like Boston, Chicago, New York and San Francisco, with their extensive public transportation systems, have long been go-to destinations for carless travelers. But a few unexpected locales have joined the list, thanks to new and expanding transit options. In honor of Car Free Day — Friday, Sept. 22 — take stock of these old (and new) pedestrian-friendly American destinations.

headline: Battered, Not Broken: Pictures of Mexico After the Quake
abstract: As Mexicans rush to one another’s aid, portraits of a country show that it is already dusting itself off.
lead_paragraph: The earthquake that devastated Mexico on Tuesday knocked over dozens of buildings in the capital alone, killed children at a school and sent waves of people running into the streets for safety — for the second time in just two weeks.

headline: Wild Bison Killed After Wandering Across Border Into Germany
abstract: A local official ordered hunters to kill the rare animal last week after it crossed over from Poland. “Animals don’t know country borders,” a conservationist said.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a rare wild bison was spotted wandering alone near the town of Lebus in eastern Germany. A local official, alarmed that the animal could be dangerous, ordered hunters to shoot it and one of them did, using a rifle to kill an animal that had not freely roamed Germany for several hundred years, conservationists say.

headline: ‘Chuck and Nancy,’ Washington’s New Power Couple, Set Sights on Health Care
abstract: Representative Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer hold no formal reins of power, but the Democratic leaders have emerged as a surprising force.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, introduced Chuck Schumer to members of her caucus this month, she warmed up the room with a well-worn joke about her Senate counterpart: “You know they say the most dangerous place in Washington is between Chuck and a camera.”

headline: Hurricane Maria, Mexico City, Iran: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Fausto Puglisi: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Review: In ‘Kingsman: The Golden Circle,’ the Natty Spies Are Back
abstract: This espionage sequel is an emotionally sterile lark, its wounds inflicted with a smirk and a shrug, even if it’s Sir Elton John in the cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: “Kill Elton John!” is a line you’re unlikely to hear in the average spy caper, but “Kingsman: The Golden Circle” aims far above average. Like its 2015 predecessor, this latest visit with the British agents-cum-Savile Row tailors swings for the fences without caring whose head — or torso, or dignity — is shredded en route. Even if it belongs to Sir Elton.

headline: Richard Robinson of Scholastic Honored for Lifetime of Work in Children’s Publishing
abstract: Mr. Robinson brought Harry Potter to American readers, among many other highlights in a career also defined by efforts to increase literacy and improve education.
lead_paragraph: Richard Robinson, the man responsible for bringing Harry Potter to American readers, among many other career highlights in children’s publishing, has been named the winner of the 2017 Literarian Award for Outstanding Service to the American Literary Community, the National Book Foundation announced Wednesday.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Kerry Bishé Reads ‘One Bouquet of Fleeting Beauty, Please’
abstract: On this week’s podcast, the “Halt and Catch Fire” actress reads an essay about why we send flowers.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode, the actress Kerry Bishé (“Halt and Catch Fire,” “Narcos”) reads the 2015 essay “One Bouquet of Fleeting Beauty, Please,” about why we send flowers.

headline: New Trailer: A ‘Jumanji’ for the Video Game Age
abstract: Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart steal the spotlight in the newest preview for the movie, which is due Dec. 20.
lead_paragraph: The new trailer for “Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle,” which arrived Wednesday, suggests it’s less of a sequel to the Robin Williams’ 1995 family favorite than it is to “Central Intelligence,” the 2016 comedy with Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart. They’re part of the ensemble in the new film, but their easy slapstick chemistry ultimately takes center stage in the trailer, pushing aside even their co-star, the veteran scenery chewer Jack Black.

headline: Avoiding Cameras While Training the Lens on Food
abstract: Pete Wells, The Times’s restaurant critic, discussed how he avoids cameras to protect his identity and how technology has transformed the dining scene.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Pete Wells, The Times’s restaurant critic, discussed the tech he is using.

headline: De Blasio’s Gap on Climate Policy? It’s Under His Front Door
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to force landlords to make their buildings more energy efficient, but he won’t say what he has done with his own two homes.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to be seen as a leader in fighting global warming, and he says that everyone needs to do their part. But when it comes to two buildings he owns in Brooklyn, it’s not clear that he is following his own advice.

headline: Line Drive Strikes Young Girl in the Face at Yankee Stadium
abstract: The incident is the latest to occur this season at Yankee Stadium, where protective netting has not yet been extended to the far end of both dugouts.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees easily completed a three-game sweep of the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday and bolstered their bid for a postseason berth, but all of that was overshadowed by an unsettling incident in the fifth inning, when a line drive off the bat of Todd Frazier appeared to hit the face of a young girl who was seated directly behind the third-base dugout.

headline: For Hispanic Heritage Month, 3 Books on Latinos in the U.S.
abstract: From conquistadores to modern cultural enclaves, these books trace the centuries-long Latino experience in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In recognition of National Hispanic Heritage Month, which runs from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15 and coincides with the Independence Days of a number of Latin American countries including Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico, here are three books on Latinos’ history, culture and experiences in the United States.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Tomb Raider’ Aims to Mint a New Action Star
abstract: Alicia Vikander takes over for Angelina Jolie in this reboot of the franchise, based on the video game.
lead_paragraph: Stop us if you’ve heard this one before: A few years after winning an Academy Award for best supporting actress, a rising star makes the leap to above-the-title action heroine as Lara Croft from the video game “Tomb Raider.” In 2001, it was Angelina Jolie (“Girl, Interrupted”), and now it’s Alicia Vikander (“The Danish Girl”).

headline: Long Plaid Skirts to Wear This Fall
abstract: Inspired by a look on Margaret Howell’s spring runway, we tracked down versions you can buy now.
lead_paragraph: British designers have a history of toying with the enduring plaid skirt — the tartan kilt is, after all, a sartorial totem of Scottishness. The English designer Vivienne Westwood gave the style a punk treatment, ruching it in rebellious ways in the ’80s (and continues to do so today) and the late Alexander McQueen played with the idea from the beginning of his career, with his controversial “Highland Rape” collection in the ‘90s, cutting a Royal Stuart red wool tartan in a dangerously low-cut pencil skirt. For her spring 2018 collection, shown in London last weekend, Margaret Howell presented a characteristically minimal A-line skirt in a black and white cotton silk check that reminded me of starched schoolgirl uniforms, golden September days in New England and the tea-length hemlines of the late 1930s and 1940s that feel spot-on today. Howell’s design will be available with the first buds of spring, but for a tartan fix now, here are a few appealing autumnal options.

headline: Hack Will Lead to Little, if Any, Punishment for Equifax
abstract: The chances that Equifax or its executives see significant criminal or civil penalties are low, because of the nature of the attack and a quirk of regulation.
lead_paragraph: It’s a bad week when one senator says that “somebody needs to go to jail” for selling shares in your company before it disclosed a massive data breach, and another asserts that the episode was “one of the most egregious examples of corporate malfeasances since Enron.”

headline: A Paintbrush in One Hand, and a Drink in the Other
abstract: Paint-and-sip shops, many of them franchise operations, continue to spread as more and more people seek diversions in experiences rather than in buying things.
lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — On a rainy Friday evening in August, customers trickled into an art studio in a strip mall on a busy main road here. The crowd, mostly women, chatted and swarmed a bar for wine and beer before taking stools at paper-covered tables and turning to the task at hand: painting.

headline: Facebook, After ‘Fail’ Over Ads Targeting Racists, Makes Changes
abstract: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, promised “more human review and oversight” to make sure offensive terms aren’t used to target ads.
lead_paragraph: Responding to evidence that its tools had allowed ads to be directed at users who used racist comments or hate speech in their profiles, Facebook said Wednesday that it would change how ads can be targeted.

headline: Christopher Bailey Captures His Week — in Polaroids
abstract: Burberry's President and Chief Creative Officer captured his time backstage, curating an exhibition — and more.
lead_paragraph: 5:30 p.m., Wednesday Sept. 13: Trying an earring on a male model in the design studio at Horseferry House.

headline: How Can U.S. States Fight Climate Change if Trump Quits the Paris Accord?
abstract: Fourteen states have vowed to uphold the Paris climate pact with or without the federal government, and a new analysis suggests their efforts are having an impact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the months since President Trump declared that the United States would withdraw from the Paris climate deal, 14 state governors have vowed to continue upholding the agreement and press ahead with policies to fight global warming.

headline: Sea Turtles Appear to Be Bouncing Back Around the World
abstract: Researchers analyzed all existing public data of sea turtle nesting sites around the world and found a tale of “cautionary optimism.”
lead_paragraph: On this planet, so many plants and animals are disappearing that scientists worry we’re experiencing a sixth mass extinction. Many of these organisms are taking hits from a variety of angles — habitat loss, climate change and more — that it’s hard to get a grasp on how to stop their declines. Conservation success stories are rare.

headline: Dr. Edmond Eger II, 86, Dies; Found Way to Make Anesthesia Safer
abstract: Dr. Eger and colleagues developed a technique to determine the proper dosage of anesthesia in operating rooms all over the world, saving an untold number of lives.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Edmond I. Eger II, a leader in the development of a now universally used technique to determine the proper dose of anesthetic gas administered in operating rooms — an advance that has saved an untold number of lives — died on Aug. 26 at his home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Ignore TV Ratings: Golf Is Healthier Than It Appears
abstract: Some pro golfers are working to grow the game from the ground up instead of from the corporate suites down.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jim Sanford was hitting microchipped golf balls off a mat between swigs of beer and bites of sushi. He was wearing flip flops. It was a recent 100-degree Sunday night in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Sanford and his date, Karen Boldt, were playing Topgolf, a cross between Skee-Ball and archery, with the ambience of an outdoor bowling alley, in which participants take aim at 11 color-coded targets, accruing points for accuracy and distance.

headline: LeBron James’s Future May Depend on Nets’ Success or Failure
abstract: The more Brooklyn loses, the better it is for Cleveland, which holds the Nets’ first-round pick in 2018 and hopes it might persuade James to stay put.
lead_paragraph: The opportunity was presented in a variety of ways, the question posed in various forms. But on the subject of the Nets, and their progress as a team this coming season, Kenny Atkinson wouldn’t bite and neither would Sean Marks.

headline: Dogs of Wall Street
abstract: A poet reflects on a scene involving creatures of high finance.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Mexico City, Hurricane Maria, Iran: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Rochester Launches New Inquiry Into Harassment Accusations
abstract: The professor, Dr. T. Florian Jaeger, was placed on leave while Mary Jo White, the former U.S. attorney for Manhattan, leads the new investigation.
lead_paragraph: The University of Rochester, assailed by outrage from students and alumni over accusations that it covered up a professor’s sexual harassment, has placed the professor on leave and hired one of the country’s most prominent lawyers to lead a renewed investigation into the allegations.

headline: Review: ‘The Lego Ninjago Movie’ Sticks to the Instruction Manual
abstract: A father, a son and the battle to save a snapped-together city.
lead_paragraph: “When are the Wegos coming on?” the young boy sitting next to me asked his father. His impatience was reasonable enough. Here we were, five minutes into “The Lego Ninjago Movie,” gazing at a live-action prologue with Jackie Chan, a kid and a cat in a store full of exotic knickknacks.

headline: Former Apple Engineers Working on New Eyes for Driverless Cars
abstract: The Silicon Valley start-up Aeva is developing new sensors that could significantly improve how autonomous vehicles see the road.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Soroush Salehian raised both arms and spun in circles as if celebrating a touchdown.

headline: At Menendez Trial, Legal Wrestling Over Definition of ‘Constituent’
abstract: The term constituent has no definition established by federal courts or the Constitution, but it is being debated in the corruption trial of Senator Robert Menendez.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — There are 325 million people living in the United States. About 56 million of those people claim Hispanic heritage.

headline: A Start-Up Slump Is a Drag on the Economy. Big Business May Be to Blame.
abstract: The formation of new companies has failed to bounce back since the recession, and economists say the trend may be holding back wages and productivity.
lead_paragraph: Unemployment has fallen, and the stock market has soared. So why has the economic expansion since the recession been so tame, with sluggish productivity and, at least until recently, anemic wage growth?

headline: Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington
abstract: Facebook, Google and Amazon are coming under increasing pressure by regulators concerned about their growing power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, Facebook and Google came out forcefully against a bill that would hold companies accountable for hosting sex trafficking on their websites. They said that while they worked hard to combat sex trafficking, changing the law “jeopardizes bedrock principles of a free and open internet” that have been crucial to innovation for decades.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Pills Are Everywhere’: Opioid Crisis and Its Youngest Victims
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 21, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “There are no pill parties happening in preschools. These kids aren’t making a choice because they are trying to get high on a substance.”

headline: ‘These Were Our Children’: School Collapses in Mexico Earthquake
abstract: At least 30 children were killed when the Enrique Rebsamen school collapsed in Tuesday’s earthquake.
lead_paragraph: At least 30 children were killed when the Enrique Rebsamen school collapsed in Tuesday’s earthquake.

headline: Someone Made a Fake Equifax Site. Then Equifax Linked to It.
abstract: A software engineer created a fake version of the website to draw attention to the weak security of the real one. Phishers could easily do the same.
lead_paragraph: People create fake versions of big companies’ websites all the time, usually for phishing purposes. But the companies do not usually link to them by mistake.

headline: Insurers Come Out Swinging Against New Republican Health Care Bill
abstract: The health insurance industry, which has been cautious about previous bills to repeal the Affordable Care Act, came out sharply against the latest version.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The health insurance industry, after cautiously watching Republican health care efforts for months, came out forcefully on Wednesday against the Senate’s latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, suggesting that its state-by-state block grants could create health care chaos in the short term and a Balkanized, uncertain insurance market.

headline: At James Blake Trial, Judge Invokes Law Shielding Police Records
abstract: The Police Department judge invoked a statute, known as 50-a, to prevent the public from hearing questions about a witness’s role in a ticket-fixing scheme.
lead_paragraph: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has steadily expanded the city’s interpretation of a state law that bars public disclosure of the personnel records of police officers, firefighters and corrections officers.

headline: Florida Nursing Home Listed Dead Resident as ‘Resting in Bed,’ State Says
abstract: State officials said a nursing home made late and “dubious” entries in medical records on the morning eight residents died in the post-hurricane heat.
lead_paragraph: A state agency has found that the Florida nursing home where eight residents  died after it lost air-conditioning following Hurricane Irma “presents a danger to every person on its premises” and must close after staff at the facility failed to call 911 for its overheated patients, even as their temperatures began spiking as high as 109.9 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Pakistan’s Leader Says Military Has Routed Taliban From Afghan Border
abstract: The U.S. and Afghanistan doubt that claim and say Pakistan must do more to thwart militants.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s new leader, stung by President Trump’s threat to crack down on his country for harboring terrorists, insisted on Wednesday that Pakistani military forces had uprooted all the sanctuaries used by Islamic extremists along its rugged frontier with Afghanistan.

headline: Manafort Working on Kurdish Referendum Opposed by U.S.
abstract: President Trump’s former campaign chairman has continued soliciting international business even as his past international work is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul J. Manafort, the former campaign chairman for President Trump who is at the center of investigations into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election, is working for allies of the leader of Iraq’s Kurdish region to help administer and promote a referendum on Kurdish independence from Iraq.

headline: Mattis Shows How to Split With Trump Without Provoking Him
abstract: The secretary of defense has been deft at leveraging the president’s respect for him into room to maneuver on his policy goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly all of President Trump’s top national security officials have been the target of his ire, whether it was privately dressing down his attorney general, publicly disagreeing with his top diplomat or musing about exiling his national security adviser to Afghanistan.

headline: Critics Fear Trump’s Attacks on Iran Could Backfire
abstract: Critics of Mr. Trump’s threats to vacate the nuclear agreement with Iran say they may have created empathy for the country — not an outcome he sought.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Trump’s bombastic attacks on Iran over the nuclear deal may have created an unanticipated outcome: sympathy for the Iranian government.

headline: Maria Strikes, and Puerto Rico Goes Dark
abstract: Less than two weeks after Hurricane Irma, a new storm made a direct hit on the island, knocking out its power grid.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Read the latest with Thursday’s live updates on Hurricane Maria.

headline: Spokeswoman Cites ‘Demanding Schedule’ for Health Secretary’s Use of Private Jets
abstract: Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, took five work-related flights last week that cost taxpayers tens of thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, spent tens of thousands of taxpayer dollars to fly on private jets to attend routine public events instead of taking cheaper commercial airliners because he has an “incredibly demanding schedule,” his spokeswoman said Wednesday.

headline: Preet Bharara, Ousted Federal Prosecutor, Will Join CNN
abstract: Mr. Bharara, who has become a frequent critic of President Trump since being dismissed by him in March, will be a senior legal analyst for the network.
lead_paragraph: Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney in Manhattan, has been far from silent since being ousted from his job in March. He is writing a book, regularly muses on politics and legal matters to his 438,000 followers on Twitter, and just started a podcast. (First episode: “That Time President Trump Fired Me.”)

headline: The New York Times in Australia? Yes. Here’s Why.
abstract: Answers to frequently asked questions about The New York Times’s efforts in Australia. Updated in November, 2018.
lead_paragraph: This FAQ was updated on November 23, 2018.

headline: Bernie Casey, Who Glided From Football to Hollywood, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Casey was known for roles in “Revenge of the Nerds” and “I’m Gonna Git You Sucka” after eight years as an N.F.L. wide receiver. He was also an accomplished painter.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Casey, an accomplished National Football League receiver who successfully painted and acted in dozens of films, including “Revenge of the Nerds,” “Brian’s Song” and “I’m Gonna Git You Sucka,” died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

headline: Operatic Villains, Often
abstract: Matt Ginsberg is a dangerous driver.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Matt Ginsberg is back. This is his 46th Times puzzle, but only the first this year. It’s a classic Thursday: tricky and fun. (I pause here to recognize those solvers who don’t find tricky to be fun. I’m afraid Thursday is not always their day.)

headline: Deaf Man Is Fatally Shot by Oklahoma City Police, Despite Pleas
abstract: An officer’s command to drop a two-foot-long pipe did not register with Madgiel Sanchez. A second officer who arrived fatally shot him.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma City police officer fatally shot a man on Tuesday night despite pleas from neighbors that the man was deaf and could not hear the commands to drop a metal pipe he was holding, the authorities said.

headline: S.E.C. Says It Was a Victim of Computer Hacking Last Year
abstract: The commission said the attackers could have exploited private information for trading purposes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The top securities regulator in the United States said Wednesday night that its computer system had been hacked last year, giving the attackers private information that could have been exploited for trading.

headline: Google Is Buying HTC’s Smartphone Expertise for $1.1 Billion
abstract: The deal bolsters Google’s ability to build mobile hardware and joins two companies already working together on one of Google’s upcoming Pixel phones.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google announced late Wednesday night that it is spending $1.1 billion to hire a team of engineers from the smartphone business of the struggling Taiwanese manufacturer HTC in a bid to bring more hardware expertise to its own mobile technology operations.

headline: Corrections: September 21, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, September 21, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Merkel Says Germans ‘Never Had It Better.’ But Many Feel Left Behind.
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s message of strength has dominated the election campaign, but poverty, economic insecurity and income disparity have grown during her tenure.
lead_paragraph: BREMERHAVEN, Germany — In her campaign speeches, Chancellor Angela Merkel loves to tell potential voters in next week’s election that they are living in the best Germany ever. Last year she boasted to Parliament that Germans “have never had it better.”

headline: For Laver Cup, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal Are on the Same Side
abstract: Federer and Nadal may play doubles together this weekend at the inaugural Laver Cup, a team event in Prague that pits Team Europe against Team World.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — In the back seat of a new van in an old city, a stubble-faced Rafael Nadal was laughing hard on my right and a stubble-faced Roger Federer was laughing harder on my left.

headline: How to Hack Your Brain (for $5,000)
abstract: The new, new, new age is all about “defragging our nervous systems.”
lead_paragraph: EDEN, Utah — One morning last month a group of roughly 60 people, including doctors, C.E.O.s and internet entrepreneurs, gathered under a big white dome to hear the mission statement of their host, a 45-year-old man named Jamie Wheal.

headline: In Landlocked Milan, Try the Fish
abstract: Thanks to the presence of the country’s biggest and most important fish market, Milan’s post-Expo restaurant landscape serves the highest quality seafood.
lead_paragraph: Milan has no sea. It has no river or lake, just a few ebbing canals. But this landlocked city is famous for some of the best seafood in the long, double-coasted peninsula of Italy, thanks mostly to the concrete warehouse of the Mercato Ittico that my guide, Sandra Ciciriello, had sneaked me inside.

headline: Mexico, Iran, Catalonia: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Voyages Issue: How Do Families Around the World Spend Their Vacations?
abstract: Photo essays from around the world by Joakim Eskildsen, Moises Saman, Sim Chi Yin, Mark Neville, Mamadi Doumbouya, Massimo Vitali, Newsha Tavakolian, Justine Kurland and Christopher Anderson.
lead_paragraph: Photo essays from around the world by Joakim Eskildsen, Moises Saman, Sim Chi Yin, Mark Neville, Mamadi Doumbouya, Massimo Vitali, Newsha Tavakolian, Justine Kurland and Christopher Anderson.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: The Return of ‘Doc Martin’ and ‘Gotham’
abstract: Portwenn’s stiff doctor tries to salvage his marriage for the sake of his baby. And the crime-ridden city of “Gotham” finally gets its hero in Season 4.
lead_paragraph: Portwenn’s stiff doctor tries to salvage his marriage for the sake of his baby. And the crime-ridden city of “Gotham” finally gets its hero in Season 4.

headline: Word + Quiz: incendiary
abstract: This word has appeared in 298 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Tackle Football
abstract: Should children under the age of 12 play tackle football, in your opinion?
lead_paragraph: Do you play tackle football?

headline: How to Find a Qualified Dog Trainer
abstract: Beyond wasting time and money, trainers who don’t know their stuff can cause psychological damage to your pet, possibly of the permanent kind.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to finding a trainer for Fido, beware of dog ... trainer.

headline: Trump Likened to ‘a Dog Barking’ by North Korea’s Top Envoy
abstract: Threatened by President Trump with destruction, North Korea likens the American leader to a yapping canine and worries for his aides.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s foreign minister likened President Trump to a “dog barking,” ridiculing the American leader for threatening to “totally destroy” his country if it persists in its nuclear and missile threats.

headline: Meet the Man Who Dresses Melania Trump
abstract: Hervé Pierre designs for a very specific customer: First Lady Melania Trump. We take you inside his New York City studio.
lead_paragraph: Hervé Pierre designs for a very specific customer: First Lady Melania Trump. We take you inside his New York City studio.

headline: Hervé Pierre Is Designing Melania Trump’s Legacy
abstract: The first lady’s stylist and designer invites us inside his apartment and work space.
lead_paragraph: In the latest installment of our video series that goes inside the private working worlds of designers, the consultant Hervé Pierre, the former creative director of Carolina Herrera who as the designer of Melania Trump’s inaugural gown shot to fame in January, reveals how he ended up as the first lady’s stylist, where he shops and whether he will start his own label. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Global Voices and Emerging Photographers at Photoville
abstract: Photoville, the temporary photo festival underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring “emergicubes,” 4x4 foot cubes displaying the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers.
lead_paragraph: Photoville, the temporary photo festival underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring “emergicubes,” 4x4 foot cubes displaying the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers.

headline: Moscow’s Monument to Murder
abstract: Russia honors Mikhail Kalashnikov as the creator of “a true cultural brand of Russia” — the AK-47. But he felt “spiritual pain“ for the harm it did.
lead_paragraph: Like many a statue in the United States that we have struggled over of late, the towering monument to Mikhail Kalashnikov, unveiled in a highly visible spot in Moscow on Tuesday, seems to have been put up for mostly the wrong reasons. The statue was promoted by the Russian culture minister, Vladimir Medinsky, a nationalist who spends much of his time glorifying Russian military history and who described the familiar assault weapon General Kalashnikov invented, which is widely known by his name, as “a true cultural brand of Russia.”

headline: The Smart Way to Get Tough With Iran
abstract: A policy to scuttle the nuclear deal would be the height of folly.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the two negotiators who initiated the secret talks that led to the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement, we are intimately familiar with the deal’s strengths, its inevitable imperfections and the wider challenge posed by Iran.

headline: Meet the World’s Leaders, in Hypocrisy
abstract: The United Nations rings with bombast and braggadocio.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from around the world have descended on New York for United Nations meetings, fancy parties, ringing speeches about helping the poor — and a big dose of hypocrisy.

headline: Are We Down to President Pence?
abstract: The least we deserve is a less exciting finger on the trigger.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s visit to the United Nations has resurrected the question of whether we’d be better off with Mike Pence.

headline: Tax Cuts for the Rich by Another Name
abstract: A plan Republicans say will help small businesses would really benefit hedge fund managers and real estate developers.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee violated their supposedly sacrosanct principles of fiscal hawkishness this week, by saying that it would be just fine with them to add $1.5 trillion to the deficit over 10 years in order to cut taxes. They justify this hypocrisy by asserting what has been disproved time and again — that tax cuts spur the economy and compensate for any lost revenue.

headline: Let’s Stop Government Giveaways to Corporations
abstract: Providing incentives to businesses is fine, as long as they are not at the expense of taxpayers and local and state governments.
lead_paragraph: Amazon recently sent state and city officials across the country scrambling to respond to its announcement that it was seeking enticements to build a second headquarters, promising 50,000 new jobs and $5 billion in investment to the winning location. Governments are mobilizing to devise lucrative incentive packages. I know how this works, because I spent eight years supporting these types of incentives as the governor of Delaware.

headline: Get Rid of Equifax
abstract: The government can take over. Why should private companies make money on our credit reports?
lead_paragraph: Because of lax security at Equifax, one of the three major credit reporting companies, the private financial and personal details of as many as 143 million Americans have been exposed to hackers. We still don’t know what the full ramifications will be; the people who took this information — which includes birth dates, Social Security numbers and addresses — could hold on to it for as long as they want and deploy it in years to come.

headline: Global Voices and Emerging Photographers at Photoville
abstract: Photoville, the temporary photo festival underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring “emergicubes,” 4×4 foot wooden cubes displaying the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photoville, the temporary community of duplexes made by four-ton steel shipping containers underneath the Brooklyn Bridge, is featuring the work of 11 up-and-coming photographers from Africa, Asia, Latin America and the United States, displayed on four-foot wooden cubes. The photographers were chosen from participants in this year’s New York Portfolio Review — a free event sponsored by The New York Times Lens blog and The City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism.

headline: Hurricane Maria Updates: In Puerto Rico, the Storm ‘Destroyed Us’
abstract: Puerto Ricans are facing the crushing devastation wrought by Hurricane Maria — splintered homes, uprooted trees and floodwaters coursing through streets.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest on Hurricane Maria with Friday’s live updates.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Mexico Earthquake Kills Hundreds, Trapping Many Under Rubble’
abstract: How has the recent earthquake impacted Mexico?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: What Is Your Reaction to President Trump’s United Nations General Assembly Speech?
abstract: What impact will the speech have on the United States, and on the rest of the world?
lead_paragraph: Watch the video above, which shows excerpts from President Trump’s first speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
abstract: There has never been a better time to visit the Spanish capital, where the political and economic turmoil of the past decade has helped spur creativity and enterprise.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a better time to visit the Spanish capital, where the political and economic turmoil of the past decade has helped spur creativity and enterprise.

headline: Celeste Ng: By the Book
abstract: The author of, most recently, “Little Fires Everywhere,” often returns to “The Count of Monte Cristo”: “Right now, I see it as an exploration of the complexities of good and evil and how easily one shifts into the other.”
lead_paragraph: The author of, most recently, “Little Fires Everywhere,” often returns to “The Count of Monte Cristo”: “Right now, I see it as an exploration of the complexities of good and evil and how easily one shifts into the other.”

headline: 36 Hours in Madrid
abstract: Spend 36 Hours in Madrid, Spain’s vibrant capital.
lead_paragraph: Spend 36 Hours in Madrid, Spain’s vibrant capital.

headline: ‘Streampunks’ Serves Up YouTube’s Greatest Hits
abstract: Robert Kyncl, YouTube’s chief business officer, delivers a lively, if biased, history of the video-sharing platform’s most noteworthy success stories.
lead_paragraph: STREAMPUNKS YouTube and the Rebels Remaking Media By Robert Kyncl with Maany Peyvan 272 pp. Harper Business. $29.99

headline: Monsanto’s Weed Killer, Dicamba, Divides Farmers
abstract: Twenty-five million acres have been planted with genetically modified seeds to encourage the spraying of the chemical. Farmers worry about damage to crops.
lead_paragraph: Farmers planted a new kind of seed on 25 million acres of soybean and cotton fields this year. Developed by Monsanto, the seeds, genetically modified to be resistant to a weed killer called dicamba, are one of the biggest product releases in the company’s history.

headline: Michael Phelps: A Golden Shoulder to Lean On
abstract: Phelps, who confronted mental health problems three years ago, has opened his home to Grant Hackett, a friend and fellow Olympian with similar troubles. Phelps has also lent an ear to Tiger Woods.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Nearly a week into their most recent therapeutic reunion, Michael Phelps and Grant Hackett, two giants of Olympic swimming, sat down to breakfast at a packed restaurant and wondered how they would explain themselves to their children someday.

headline: When the Governments of the World Agreed to Banish War
abstract: “The Internationalists,” by Oona A. Hathaway and Scott J. Shapiro, argues that a 1928 pact was the beginning of the end of war.
lead_paragraph: THE INTERNATIONALISTS How a Radical Plan to Outlaw War Remade the World By Oona A. Hathaway and Scott J. Shapiro Illustrated. 581 pp. Simon & Schuster. $30.

headline: Battle Over Confederate Monuments Moves to the Cemeteries
abstract: Calls to remove cemetery monuments are raising questions. Are such monuments really on public display? Should they be treated like the ones in public squares?
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — One by one, Confederate monuments are coming down from their perches in front of courthouses, in public squares, along city boulevards.

headline: On ‘Star Trek: Discovery,’ a Franchise Boldly Goes Into the Serial TV Era
abstract: The first new “Star Trek” series in more than a decade deals with the demands of long-form storytelling and confronts earthbound production problems.
lead_paragraph: Space, in the “Star Trek” universe, may be an alluring and infinite frontier, but time is a much rarer and more vexing commodity.

headline: How to Use Twitter and Facebook for Emergency Travel Information
abstract: You don’t have to like social media, but when a natural disaster or emergency strikes, it can provide essential travel tools.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to like Twitter or Facebook, or even post to them, but when an emergency strikes, the networking sites can be essential travel tools.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Doubles Down on Criticism of Health Care Bill
abstract: Mr. Kimmel excoriated Senator Bill Cassidy and his legislation for a second night, though he said he hoped to avoid “a Kanye-and-Taylor-Swift-type situation.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: The G.O.P. Bill Forces States to Build Health Systems From Scratch. That’s Hard.
abstract: Every state would need to make political choices and build brand-new systems in only two years. Remember what happened with HealthCare.gov?
lead_paragraph: In 2003, health care policy makers in Massachusetts agreed that the state should build a system to expand coverage to its uninsured residents.

headline: Hurricane Maria, North Korea, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: One Last Visit to See My Patient
abstract: A doctor who has been alongside her 91-year-old patient for some 20 years prepares to say goodbye.
lead_paragraph: The rain was coming down in torrents and my shoes were not up to the job. Nevertheless, I pressed forward along the soggy blocks. My 91-year-old patient and I had been together for some 20 years — honestly I’d lost count — so this was the least I could do.

headline: How Technology Changes Teen Romance
abstract: The digital world puts a new spin on some of the timeless challenges of coming of age.
lead_paragraph: The topic of teenage romance and sex has always been charged, but today’s pervasive digital technology has succeeded in turning up the wattage. Some parents have an easy and open channel with their adolescent around all things amorous while others find the subject painfully awkward and try to avoid it altogether. Regardless of where you and your teenager sit on this spectrum, the digital world puts a new spin on some of the timeless challenges of coming of age. When you’re ready to talk, here are some points to consider.

headline: Review: The Documentary ‘Bobbi Jene’ Finds a Dancer in Flux
abstract: The film follows Bobbi Jene Smith as she leaves the Batsheva Dance Company to strike out on her own.
lead_paragraph: Enigmatic to an extreme, the documentary “Bobbi Jene” may interest viewers who are well versed in contemporary dance. All others are on their own.

headline: No Child Trapped in Rubble of Mexican Quake-Hit School, Officials Say
abstract: Rescue efforts at the school, where a girl was reported to be trapped, had transfixed the country. Officials later said all children were accounted for.
lead_paragraph: After a day in which Mexico was captivated by frantic rescue operations to reach a girl believed to be trapped beneath the rubble of a collapsed elementary school, officials said Thursday that they believed there was no girl there.

headline: Review: A Sweet Immigrant Story in ‘The Tiger Hunter’
abstract: It’s 1979 and one aspiring engineer is ready for America and to win over his childhood sweetheart.
lead_paragraph: A gentle, warmhearted immigrant comedy that’s rarely more than mildly amusing, “The Tiger Hunter” follows Sami (Danny Pudi), an aspiring engineer, from his rural Indian village to a job opportunity in Chicago.

headline: Review: Lady Gaga Unplugged, Sort Of, in ‘Gaga: Five Foot Two’
abstract: This documentary depicts Lady Gaga as a disciplined, accomplished performer, but one who inhabits a peculiar isolation despite her fame.
lead_paragraph: Even when the pop music provocateur known as Lady Gaga seemed to be changing personae by the hour, one eyebrow-raising costume or public gesture after another, those paying proper attention could discern a disciplined, focused performer/musician behind the choreographed madness. While the movie climaxes with preparations for Gaga’s strangely spectacular 2017 Super Bowl halftime show, it mostly chronicles the artist at work in 2016 on a project that would ostensibly present her “unplugged,” so to speak.

headline: New York Today: Theater in Odd Places
abstract: Thursday: Performing in unusual spaces, a Rosh Hashana Jazz service, and help for the victims in Mexico and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this balmy Thursday, and Shanah Tovah.

headline: Review: ‘Unrest,’ a Personal Account of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
abstract: In this film, Jennifer Brea describes her life that Chronic Fatigue Syndrome hijacked.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years after chronic fatigue syndrome was given its unfortunate name, it’s still not understood or even completely accepted by the medical world: No definitive cause has been identified, nor any consensus treatment. And while it affects an estimated 1 million Americans and 17 million globally, those with the condition are often dismissed as suffering from psychosomatic disorders.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: One More Bid to Repeal Obamacare
abstract: Republicans are pushing for a vote on health care, and they’re running out of time. The effort could test a long friendship in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: S.&P. Downgrades China’s Debt, Citing a Surge in Lending
abstract: The firm’s move, spurred by a borrowing spree that it said threatens the world’s No. 2 economy, comes just before a sensitive Communist Party meeting.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China and the world received a fresh warning on Thursday that the country’s dramatic debt binge of recent years threatens the stability of one of the global economy’s most important growth engines.

headline: Review: ‘Victoria and Abdul,’ a Royal Friendship in a Nest of Vipers
abstract: “Victoria and Abdul” sees a queen in a life-changing relationship with a Muslim Indian man.
lead_paragraph: This is the second movie in 20 years in which Judi Dench plays Queen Victoria. And this is the second movie in 20 years in which Queen Victoria, played by Judi Dench, has a life-enhancing relationship with a man not of her station. This movie, “Victoria and Abdul,” directed by Stephen Frears from a script by Lee Hall, goes 1997’s “Mrs. Brown” one better in the Relevant to Contemporary Concerns department by depicting a friendship between the second-longest-reigning monarch of England and an Indian Muslim.

headline: Max Mara: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Review: ‘The King’s Choice’ Depicts Norway’s Entry Into World War II
abstract: The movie sluggishly charts how the ceremonial king acquired real negotiating power during a crisis.
lead_paragraph: A saga of Norway’s entry into World War II that probably plays more stirringly in the nation where it is set, “The King’s Choice” dramatizes a celebrated moment in the country’s constitutional monarchy, when King Haakon VII (Jesper Christensen) refused to surrender to the Nazis’ invasion.

headline: Why Trump’s Softening on Immigration Is Unlikely to Splinter His Base
abstract: Many Republican voters support DACA, especially G.O.P. elites, and he could always change his mind. He’s done it before.
lead_paragraph: In a matter of weeks, President Trump has twice struck deals with Democrats in Congress that have left many of his supporters flummoxed.

headline: Review: ‘Loving Vincent’ Paints van Gogh in His Own Images
abstract: An innovative biopic explores the Dutch painter’s last days, with the people he rendered on canvas being brought to uncanny life.
lead_paragraph: “Loving Vincent” addresses its subject, the Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh, with two what-ifs — one marvelous and fantastical, the other empirical and pedestrian. What if his paintings, with their wild colors and vibrant brush strokes, had been able to move? And what if the bullet that killed him had been fired by someone else?

headline: Morning Agenda: Google Gets Serious About Producing Better Phones
abstract: Its move to hire HTC engineers is intended to improve competition with Apple and Samsung. But the tech giant’s previous foray into handset making did not go so well.
lead_paragraph: Google once owned a phone maker. It didn’t work out. Now it’s trying a different approach.

headline: Remember When They Wanted to Build a Parking Lot Over the Hudson?
abstract: ‘Never Built New York,’ a new exhibition at the Queens Museum, showcases unrealized ideas, from the almost practical to the magical.
lead_paragraph: The first item in “Never Built New York,” a thought-provoking tour of models, drawings, and newspaper headlines at the Queens Museum, is a cocktail napkin from the Plaza Hotel. On it, Frank Lloyd Wright sketched an idea for remaking Ellis Island.

headline: Review: ‘Hong Kong Trilogy,’ Captures the Voices of the People
abstract: More of a poem or a city symphony than a documentary, the film drifts freely, sometimes frustratingly, between real and fictionalized moments.
lead_paragraph: Directed by the cinematographer Christopher Doyle, “Hong Kong Trilogy: Preschooled, Preoccupied, Preposterous” is drawn from the real voices of contemporary Hong Kong residents, a title card says. More of a poem or a city symphony than a documentary, it drifts freely, sometimes frustratingly between captured and fictionalized moments.

headline: Review: Jake Gyllenhaal in ‘Stronger’ Loses His Legs in the Boston Bombing
abstract: With raw emotion, David Gordon Green’s “Stronger” tells the true tale of Jeff Bauman, catastrophically injured as he watched the 2013 marathon.
lead_paragraph: “Stronger,” the new movie directed by David Gordon Green, harks back to his work in the first decade of this century. His “All the Real Girls” (2003) and “Snow Angels” (2007) brought acute, cleareyed, compassionate consideration to trauma and tragedy as they affect intimate relationships. Unlike those pictures, though, “Stronger” carries a separate weight. It’s also about an actual galvanic event in recent American history.

headline: California Today: Mexico Has a Quake Warning System. Where is California’s?
abstract: Thursday: Checking in on California’s earthquake warning system, pro surfers compete in the San Joaquin Valley, and snow arrives in Tahoe.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Marine Le Pen Aide Leaves Far-Right Party
abstract: Florian Philippot said the National Front was taking “a terrible step backward” as it struggled to regroup.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A top aide to the French far-right leader Marine Le Pen announced on Thursday that he was leaving her National Front party, the latest sign of turmoil in the organization as it struggles to recover from her defeat in the presidential election this year.

headline: A Head-Spinning, Hope-Inspiring Showcase of Art
abstract: In Latin American Los Angeles, bridges soar, walls fall. A grand exchange beckons the art traveler to “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I guess there’s a God. During one of the meanest passages in American national politics within living memory, we’re getting a huge, historically corrective, morale-raising cultural event, one that lasts four months and hits on many of the major social topics of the day: racism, sexism, aggressive nationalism. True, the hugeness of the thing is a problem, and the contents are uneven. But it’s a gift, worth a trip to puzzle over and savor.

headline: On the Market in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a penthouse in Hoboken, N.J., and a bayfront in Merrick, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a penthouse in Hoboken, N.J., and a bayfront in Merrick, N.Y.

abstract: We pair a young adult novel with an essay by a middle schooler to explore the lives of those who cope with, but are not defined by, their disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

abstract: This week’s homes are on the Upper West Side, in the West Village, and in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes are on the Upper West Side, in the West Village, and in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

abstract: This week’s homes are on the Upper West Side, in the West Village, and in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
