headline: Patient Voices: Alzheimer’s Disease
abstract: A slow decline in memory, an inability to complete simple tasks, the concern about long-term care - five men and women speak about living with and caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease.
lead_paragraph: A slow decline in memory, an inability to complete simple tasks, the concern about long-term care - five men and women speak about living with and caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease.

headline: Fendi: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Most Pet-Friendly Cities in the United States
abstract: Where is the best place to have a pet? The country’s 100 largest cities, ranked according to how hospitable they are to animals.
lead_paragraph: We love our pets, and we have a lot of them: According to a recent survey conducted by the American Pet Products Association, there are about 90 million dogs and 94 million cats kept as pets in the United States. If you take into account canaries, rabbits, fish and other animals, the total number of pets in the country is a staggering 393 million — in 68 percent of American households. Pets are everywhere, but the quality and cost of living with them varies considerably depending on where you live.

headline: Fantasy Football: The Best Players to Start in Week 3
abstract: Kareem Hunt may be the real deal; look for a big week from Matt Ryan.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: On Trump at the United Nations
abstract: “As president of the United States, I will always put America first,” President Trump said.
lead_paragraph: “As president of the United States, I will always put America first, just like you, as the leaders of your countries, will always and should always put your countries first,” President Trump said.

headline: Meet Wetex Kang, the First Asian on New Zealand’s Maori Party Ticket
abstract: A Malay-Chinese beekeeper, borrowing slogans from Donald Trump, is trying to see whether the party can gain support from new quarters.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Wetex Kang, a Malay-Chinese immigrant beekeeper, may be the first Asian candidate to represent the Maori Party of New Zealand, but at times he sounds more like a certain American president.

headline: Retiring the Google Drive Desktop App
abstract: While its current desktop app for Windows and Mac is headed off into the sunset, Google has new apps for backing up and syncing files online.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it true that Google Drive is being discontinued?

headline: In Country Music, Nice Guys Finish First (for Now)
abstract: For most of the 2010s, Nashville was dominated by the masculinity of bro country. But now the pendulum has swung to the other side: Meet the country gentleman.
lead_paragraph: If, in the fall of 2015, you pressed play on “Tangled Up,” the second album from the young country singer Thomas Rhett, you would have thought he fit right in.

headline: Review: The Scandalous Friendship That Shaped Adam Smith
abstract: “The Infidel and the Professor” illuminates the deep bond between the father of economics, an establishment man, and the radical skeptic David Hume.
lead_paragraph: Although Adam Smith had no children, he has been identified as either the father of economics or, more expansively, of modern capitalism. And to be sure, the continuing relevance of his masterwork, “The Wealth of Nations,” published at the moment our nation came to be in 1776, is undeniable.

headline: 8 of the Season’s Best Crystal Earrings
abstract: Chandelier styles — flashy, glamorous and unapologetically decadent — with a punk-rock edge.
lead_paragraph: Chandelier styles — flashy, glamorous and unapologetically decadent — with a punk-rock edge.

headline: Seven Brian De Palma Movies Worth Streaming
abstract: Runaway strollers. Buckets of pig blood. Tony Montana. See where to find many of this singular director’s biggest movies.
lead_paragraph: The director Brian De Palma was born 77 years ago this month. In honor of his birthday, I wanted to look back at some of his more memorable movies. If you’d like to learn more about De Palma, who came up alongside filmmakers like Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Francis Ford Coppola, you can stream the documentary, “De Palma,” in which he offers up wild stories about his early days and behind-the-scenes looks at several of the movies below.

headline: Some Cartoons That Missed the Cut
abstract: The New Yorker is highly selective of the cartoons it publishes. Here are cartoons that didn’t make it.
lead_paragraph: The New Yorker is highly selective of the cartoons it publishes. Here are cartoons that didn’t make it.

headline: The New Yorker Said No, but These Cartoons Just May Make Your Day
abstract: There are likely to be some winners — and a few groaners — at an exhibition of 45 cartoons that didn’t make the cut.
lead_paragraph: Of the 1,000 cartoons submitted to The New Yorker each week, only about 15 are published in the magazine. That is a pretty high bar, though logic might suggest there are some gems among the rejects. At least, that is David Ostow’s theory. He has been submitting his cartoons to the magazine since early last year, but has yet to be published in it.

headline: The Center of Their Own World
abstract: For “Festival of Dreams” the Congolese choreographer Faustin Linyekula worked with dancers from It’s Showtime NYC for two weeks.

headline: Art in the Wild
abstract: A close look at engaging works on view in European art parks.
lead_paragraph: A close look at engaging works on view in European art parks.

headline: The Unique Value of Seeing Works in the Wild
abstract: Why three European art parks — outdoor spaces with large-scale, site-specific sculpture — have become essential places to engage with culture.
lead_paragraph: IN 2002, Jenny Holzer was invited to create a piece at Wanas Konst, an 80-acre sculpture park tucked behind a romantic 16th-century step-gabled castle in the wilds of southern Sweden. She spent two days just wandering the grounds, where contemporary sculptures (a monumental steel chair covered in antlers, a tiny wood house in a clearing) by the likes of Marina Abramovic, Robert Wilson and Maya Lin stand amid tall beech trees and, in some cases, grazing cows. (The art foundation shares the land with a working dairy farm.) Deep in the woods, Holzer found herself thinking of ‘‘fairy tales light and dark.’’ Then she came upon a waist-high stone wall that dates to the 1700s. ‘‘I started following it and knew it was the site,’’ she says. Her contribution to what is now known as ‘‘Wanas Wall’’ was to carve a different phrase or truism from her past work into a stone block every 20 feet or so. ‘‘all things are delicately interconnected,’’ reads one.

headline: NASA’s Osiris-Rex Spacecraft Is Headed for a Flyby With Earth
abstract: The spacecraft will make a flyby of Earth on Friday, using the planet’s gravity to steer it toward Bennu, an asteroid it will visit next year.
lead_paragraph: A NASA spacecraft, Osiris-Rex, is speeding toward Earth after a year looping around the sun. On Friday afternoon, it will miss the planet by about 11,000 miles, zooming underneath our blue orb at 19,000 miles per hour, passing over Australia and Antarctica.

headline: Citizens of Gucci-land, Unite!
abstract: Also creating communities via clothing at Fendi and MaxMara — and some confusion at Alberta Ferretti.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — On a giant industrial campus in the far reaches of Milan, past the room with the giant chinoiserie swans painted on the walls and the plush velvet chairs, past the garden with its crawling ivy and purple blooms, in a cavernous space traced by a river of winding blue, a mummy lay.

headline: Senator Cassidy, Please Stop Lying about Health Care
abstract: Bill Cassidy is selling his bill by telling one falsehood after another, because the truth would scare away his colleagues.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: In New York Suburbs, Plenty of Democrats — Just Not at the Top
abstract: In Nassau and Westchester Counties, where candidates for county executive are squaring off on taxes and ethics, President Trump casts a big shadow.
lead_paragraph: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — After the presidential election in November, residents here staged an impromptu vigil. Nine days after the inauguration, more met at a local church to form a grass-roots political action group. Postcard-writing events were organized; another one, a “No Democrat Left Behind” postcard party, will be held later this month at The Voracious Reader, a children’s bookstore.

headline: So, a President Walks Up to a Microphone...
abstract: Yes, of course,Trump was “only joking.” At least sometimes, we have to hope so.
lead_paragraph: By now, President Trump’s sense of humor has been pretty well discussed. Either he doesn’t have one, or it’s subtle — like a group of especially awkward 12-year-old boys yucking it up in the cafeteria.

headline: Going Local: Is It Possible, as a Foreigner, to Experience a Country as Its People Do?
abstract: Authenticity in travel has become an increasingly implausible endeavor.
lead_paragraph: During the last few decades, a curious plague came to afflict Turkey: British luxury-travel websites or, as they were known in the tourism industry, “specialist tour operators.” The most notorious was Exclusive Escapes (a.k.a. Hidden Turkey). According to one advertising executive’s blog, its distinction was to offer “off-the-beaten-track Turkish holidays for the discerning middle classes” — some hotel rooms were $300 a night, but “class” is a moving target — and for those Britons who, the executive imagined, “wanted to feel they were getting away from the crowds,” who craved “an authentic experience.” Glorious boutique hotels sprang up along the shores of the Mediterranean and the Aegean, their multiterraced buildings cascading down Turkey’s mountain slopes to the water’s edge. The website promised rooms that had windows big enough to let in entire seas and real Turkish breakfasts while you watched the graceful gulet boats drift by. It’s Turkey. Turkey is magical. It ought to be hard to get a vacation in Turkey wrong.

headline: A Bride’s Countdown to Glowing Skin
abstract: Some steps brides can take on their own to prepare and nurture their skin in the weeks, days and hours before their wedding.
lead_paragraph: Brides are supposed to glow on their wedding day, and that, of course, includes their skin. But who has the time to keep running to the dermatologist’s office for a peel, facial or fillers, especially with so many other chores to tend to?

headline: Review: ‘The Force’ Follows the Oakland Police From Crisis to Crisis
abstract: For his documentary “The Force,” Peter Nicks tracked the crisis-riddled department for two years.
lead_paragraph: In the potent documentary “The Force,” there’s a moment when Sean Whent, the Oakland chief of police, faces a tough critic: the public. It’s 2015, and he’s talking about the police response to calls. He admits the police are not providing the level of service they should but adds that they’re trying their best. When a robbery victim says their best isn’t good enough, he apologizes. “We need to do a better job, no doubt, and we are trying to do a better job.” By the end of the movie it seems clear that he didn’t apologize enough.

headline: A Consumer Advocate Battles Equifax and a Storm
abstract: “I managed to respond to the first several hundred emails, but a backlog built up as the hurricane came and went and I transported my father back home.”
lead_paragraph: Nobody appointed me vice president of customer service for Equifax, but somebody had to do the job.

headline: Columnist Biography: Nicholas D. Kristof
abstract: More about The Times columnist.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas D. Kristof, a columnist for The Times since 2001, is a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner who writes op-ed columns that appear twice a week.

headline: Jake LaMotta Was More Than Just a ‘Raging Bull’
abstract: The boxer, a very skilled craftsman, stands for what it meant to be good with your hands in industrial America.
lead_paragraph: When a champion dies, a wave of nostalgia for his era rolls over the culture. It’s like “rocket summer,” the wash of snow-melting heat that passes over a wintry Ohio town when spaceships lift off in Ray Bradbury’s “Martian Chronicles.” The more famous the champion, the more potent the wave.

headline: Let Us Help You Find Something Great to Watch Tonight.
abstract: Many of this year’s best TV shows and movies are available to stream right now. Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site, can show you where. Tell us what mood you’re in or what services you subscribe to and we’ll help you out.
lead_paragraph: Many of this year’s best TV shows and movies are available to stream right now. Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site, can show you where. Tell us what mood you’re in or what services you subscribe to and we’ll help you out.

headline: A Tuscan Village Bares Its Soul on Stage, Again and Again
abstract: For 50 years, residents have acted out the story of their lives, in a kind of collective self-analysis. This year, they pondered whether their village can survive.
lead_paragraph: MONTICCHIELLO, Italy — This walled village of just 200 residents perched in the hills south of Siena has always been a little isolated and, perhaps, a little conflicted about it.

headline: ‘War Paint’ to Close on Broadway in December
abstract: The musical starring Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole will have its final show on Dec. 30 after 300 performances.
lead_paragraph: “War Paint,” a double-barreled musical starring Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole, will close on Broadway on Dec. 30 after 300 performances.

headline: Trump Moves to Widen U.S. Sanctions on North Korea
abstract: An executive order that the president announced suggested that for now at least he was still committed to economic pressure, rather than military action.
lead_paragraph: President Trump ordered a widening of American sanctions on North Korea on Thursday to further choke off its trade with the outside world, in what some experts described as perhaps the most sweeping set of punitive economic measures enacted by the United States in many years.

headline: KB Home to Cut C.E.O.’s Bonus After His Rant Against Kathy Griffin
abstract: Jeffrey Mezger’s 2017 bonus will be cut by 25 percent, the company said, after he used sexist and homophobic language against Kathy Griffin, his neighbor.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Mezger, chief executive of the homebuilder KB Home, will take a 25 percent cut to his year-end bonus as a result of his sexist and homophobic outburst against his neighbor, the comedian Kathy Griffin, the company said Thursday.

headline: Clues to Africa’s Mysterious Past Found in Ancient Skeletons
abstract: An analysis of DNA recovered from fossils thousands of years old hints at enormous migrations that shaped the continent.
lead_paragraph: It was only two years ago that researchers found the first ancient human genome in Africa: a skeleton in a cave in Ethiopia yielded DNA that turned out to be 4,500 years old.

headline: How Three Friends Proved That Jellyfish Can Sleep
abstract: What started as a midnight excursion of curious graduate students turned into a study with implications for basic questions about sleep.
lead_paragraph: Worms and fish do it. Birds and bees do it. But do jellyfish fall asleep?

headline: ‘The Politics of Nondiscrimination Have Gone Too Far’: Readers Debate Free Speech
abstract: In a case that pits a gay couple against a Colorado baker, Times readers grappled over the protections of free speech.
lead_paragraph: The case of a  baker in Colorado who refused to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple has been added to the Supreme Court’s docket for this fall, but thousands of New York Times readers have already weighed in on the debate, which centered on the protections of free speech.

headline: Like ‘Car Talk,’ but With Dead People
abstract: The Gardino brothers find wonder in cemeteries, and they hope to translate it into a PBS show.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny September morning in the Bronx, Vincent and Robert Gardino were out searching for the dead. Strolling among the tombstones in Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, the brothers were not the least bit morbid, excitedly trading stories and barbs.

headline: Wu’s Wonton King
abstract: Some of the best dishes at this restaurant, where Chinatown meets the Lower East Side, are the simplest, along with the whole suckling pig.
lead_paragraph: Some of the best dishes at this restaurant, where Chinatown meets the Lower East Side, are the simplest, along with the whole suckling pig.

headline: Where Dumplings and Ducks Rule
abstract: Some of the best dishes at Wu’s Wonton King on the Lower East Side are the simplest, along with the whole suckling pig.
lead_paragraph: Two Dungeness crabs face off on the plate, ready to duel. One is battered gold, deep-fried and propped on a rubble of garlic shards; the other has been steamed to a dying-sunset hue and shimmers from a frisk in the wok with ginger, scallions and Shaoxing wine. Only a border of half-moon cucumbers separates them, keeping the peace.

headline: Review: An Anime New York in Netflix’s ‘Neo Yokio’
abstract: An affectionate satire of life among the city’s elite is the brainchild of Ezra Koenig, the Vampire Weekend singer and guitarist.
lead_paragraph: Among the notable attributes of “Neo Yokio,” a new fantasy-comedy anime sendup on Netflix:

headline: Tax Reform for the Rich: Reduce the Rates but Lose the Breaks
abstract: Curbing special treatment for state and local taxes, mortgage interest and capital gains could pay for meaningful changes across the board.
lead_paragraph: When the Trump administration unveils new details of its tax plan, promised for next week, one group of taxpayers will be under the microscope: the rich.

headline: New Trailer: In ‘Isle of Dogs,’ Wes Anderson Returns to Animation
abstract: Using the stop-motion technique, the movie features a starry voice cast that includes Bill Murray, Tilda Swinton and Scarlett Johansson.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after making his first foray into animation with “The Fantastic Mr. Fox,” the writer-director Wes Anderson returns to the stop-motion technique and focuses on another type of animal in “Isle of Dogs.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Battle of the Sexes’
abstract: Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris discuss a sequence from their film featuring Emma Stone and Andrea Riseborough.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris discuss a sequence from their film featuring Emma Stone and Andrea Riseborough.

headline: Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris Narrate a Scene From ‘Battle of the Sexes’
abstract: The directors discuss a sequence from their film featuring Emma Stone and Andrea Riseborough.
lead_paragraph: While the movie “Battle of the Sexes” does lead up to the  1973 tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobbie Riggs, it takes some time to explore close moments between its characters off the court.

headline: A Late-Night Radio Drama, With Hints of the Internet to Come
abstract: Stanley Elkin’s “The Dick Gibson Show,” about a talk-radio host, is a landslide of language, offering gags, wordplay and flights of fancy, sexual and otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Elkin’s third novel, “The Dick Gibson Show” (1971), is not improving to read. Its heart is not in the right place. It squeezes the blackheads behind the ears of your imagination; it’s a Diane Arbus walk on the unreconciled side. It’s among the most powerful and funny American novels I know.

headline: Should I Track Down the Girl I Bullied in Middle School?
abstract: And: offering to help a stepdaughter freeze her eggs, a hostess balks at accepting a gift, and a housekeeper helps herself to the makeup stash.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, when I was 14 (and starting to freak out that I might be a lesbian), I spread some mean rumors about a girl in my class. I said that she’d come on to me and that I’d seen her making out with another girl. Neither story was true. And they caused her a lot of trouble. I’ve felt terrible about this for years. But I haven’t seen her since we graduated. Should I track her down and apologize?

headline: Four Modern Masters of Color Reinvigorating Design
abstract: They're using vibrant shades in jewelry, interiors, lingerie and flowers. Get to know them.
lead_paragraph: The Color Field painters of the late 1940s and 1950s exploded many ideas about what art should and shouldn’t be, but one of their greatest and most enduring influences was the assertion that color has its own power, one apart from and even surpassing that of figurative representation. Mark Rothko, for example, wanted viewers to stand close to his paintings, to be enveloped by their hues, to have a mythic, transcendent experience with his work. In the words of critic Calvin Tomkins, the painter sought to depict ‘‘color itself, color liberated and breathing within the alternative world of the picture.’’

headline: A Composer’s Debut, at 82
abstract: Richard Alan White always worked nonmusical jobs for a living. Over 40 years, in his spare time, he wrote the opera, “Hester,” which will finally be staged.
lead_paragraph: Some people are late bloomers. Then there is Richard Alan White, 82, who was a composer-in-hiding for the first eight decades of his life.

headline: And Now a Fifth ‘Game of Thrones’ Prequel Is in the Works
abstract: Bryan Cogman, a co-executive producer for “Game of Thrones,” is developing a prequel with George R. R. Martin.
lead_paragraph: The pool of potential “Game of Thrones” prequels has expanded, and the latest concept will come from core members of the Westeros braintrust.

headline: Review: Advantage, Bobby, but Game, Set, Match, Billie Jean in ‘Battle of the Sexes’
abstract: Emma Stone plays Billie Jean King and Steve Carell plays Bobby Riggs in a movie about the 1973 tennis match that became a referendum on equality.
lead_paragraph: Every so often an exceptionally capable woman has to prove her worth by competing against a clown. That’s one of the durable truisms of “Battle of the Sexes,” a glib, enjoyable fictionalization of the 1973 exhibition tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs. She was 29 and one of the top female tennis players in the world. He was 55 and had been a world champion before she was born. She was a feminist symbol and the first female athlete to win more than $100,000 in a single year; he was a self-avowed male chauvinist pig who liked to gamble big. It was a man vs. woman match made for maximum public-relations gimmickry but also a deadly serious referendum on equality on and off the court.

headline: 20 Under $20
abstract: Twenty exciting value wines to drink right now.
lead_paragraph: Twenty exciting value wines to drink right now.

headline: 20 Wines for Under $20: Weeknight Pleasures for Relaxed Evenings
abstract: These easygoing bottles will not challenge or demand. They are all refreshing pleasures and great values. But they will also reward attention.
lead_paragraph: The requirements for weeknight cooking are easy to understand, but weeknight wine? It’s a bit more conceptual.

headline: A French Theater Impresario, Dressed for Excess
abstract: In a visit to BAM, the stage director Olivier Py introduces his drag alter-ego and talks about plans for the Avignon Festival he runs.
lead_paragraph: One of the most powerful men in European theater was flat on his back, merrily pedaling in the air. The floor-length dress, platinum wig and tiara were a nice touch, and the pendulous rhinestone earring caught the light of BAM’s Fishman Space.

headline: Liliane Bettencourt, L’Oréal Heiress Vexed by Swindling Case, Is Dead at 94
abstract: Mrs. Bettencourt, ranked as the world’s richest woman, tried to live down her family’s fascist associations, and her final years were overtaken by scandal.
lead_paragraph: Liliane Bettencourt, the French heiress to the L’Oréal cosmetics fortune and a family legacy of fascist associations, whose final years were vexed by allegations that she had fallen under the sway of a younger man and given him $1.4 billion, died on Wednesday at her home in the Paris suburb Neuilly-sur-Seine. She was 94.

headline: Skadden, Big New York Law Firm, Faces Questions on Work With Manafort
abstract: The Justice Department wants information about Skadden’s work on behalf of a Russia-aligned former president of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five years ago, Paul Manafort arranged for a prominent New York-based law firm to draft a report that was used by allies of his client, Viktor Yanukovych, the Russia-aligned president of Ukraine, to justify the jailing of a political rival. And now the report is coming back to haunt it.

headline: The Remarkable Patience of the Staten Island Bat Watchers
abstract: Little research has been done on bats in New York. But a team of researchers in Staten Island are starting to better understand their subjects.
lead_paragraph: On the deserted edge of Freshkills on Staten Island, winged shadows swooped through night sky. Wearing a headlamp, Danielle Fibikar, a wildlife biologist and an educator at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center and Botanical Garden, adjusted the nets she had set out to catch bats.

headline: Citizens Mobilize After Mexico Quake
abstract: Volunteers are banding together to help rescue workers clear rubble and distribute resources after the 7.1 magnitude earthquake shook Mexico City on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Volunteers are banding together to help rescue workers clear rubble and distribute resources after the 7.1 magnitude earthquake shook Mexico City on Tuesday.

headline: 3 Police Chiefs Are Killed in a Month in a Volatile Afghan District
abstract: The killings in Jaghatu District underscore the high casualties Afghan forces are suffering in defending against a resurgent Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The police chief of a volatile Afghanistan district was killed by a roadside bomb on Thursday, officials said, just two weeks after taking over for his predecessor, who was killed in the same manner.

headline: Still Processing: Outrage Over ‘Bodega’ and Horror at the Movies
abstract: We talk about a new startup and why it caused an internet firestorm, and how horror at the movies and on TV reflect our times, in hilarious ways.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a Silicon Valley startup called Bodega instigated an internet meltdown after a Fast Company profile made the company’s intentions clear. “Eventually, centralized shopping locations won’t be necessary, because there will be 100,000 Bodegas spread out, with one always 100 feet away from you,” said Paul McDonald, a co-founder, who used to work at Google. The outrage made moral sense. “Bodega” is name that’s asking for trouble, especially with people who frequent them. The outrage is also easy. Where’s the upset over the effect other, bigger companies – like Amazon, whose latest major acquisition, Whole Foods, has slashed prices – might actually have on bodegas? Being mad at Amazon is harder when it’s mixed up in so much of your life. We discuss the dilemma.

headline: Confirm or Deny: Judi Dench
abstract: The dame shares her greatest fears and one of her biggest crushes.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Dowd: You’re bored with playing queens?

headline: Queen! Bow Down to Tattoo-Flashing Octogenarian Dame Dench
abstract: She’s done with Bond but back in play for “Victoria & Abdul,” dating a jolly nice chap and giving Iago higher marks than Trump.
lead_paragraph: I watch as Dame Judi Dench eats her chilled corn soup with saffron and sips Champagne. At 82, she is just as elegant as you would imagine, with silver hair, ice-blue eyes and crisp diction. She’s 5-foot-1, but her reputation is towering.

headline: N.F.L. Week 3 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The N.F.L.’s hierarchy might get some clarity when Atlanta and Detroit square off, and Oakland looks to move to 3-0. Here’s who we think will win.
lead_paragraph: Expectations have to be adjusted throughout the league as teams like Denver and New England looked far better in Week 2 than they had in Week 1, while Dallas and Green Bay fell off a cliff. There is still too much noise in any of the results to draw too many conclusions, but the N.F.L.’s hierarchy might get some clarity this week. Here is who we pick.

headline: Far-Right German Party Is Poised to Break Postwar Taboo
abstract: The Alternative for Germany may win seats in the federal Parliament, the first far-right party to do so since World War II.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In an unpredictable political year across Europe, the German election on Sunday has been considered the boring final act. Angela Merkel, the Continent’s most powerful figure, is expected to win a fourth term as chancellor after a colorless campaign. Yet if many Germans seem satisfied enough with their leader, others are unhappy with the wishy-washy consensus of the main political parties.

headline: Is This the Least-Loved Highway in America?
abstract: When you’re on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the only question is, will you ever get off it?
lead_paragraph: You look up from underneath the elevated Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, or its extension, the Gowanus Expressway, and if it happens to be one of those rare moments when traffic is actually moving, you could fill a bookcase with the stories going on overhead, all endeavoring furiously to be elsewhere. On the B.Q.E., even more than on most highways, success means getting off it. It is a non-place, measured in units of time, not distance. Its existence expresses a builder’s preference — in this case, Robert Moses’s — for automobiles over the communities of people living below.

headline: Ryanair Apologizes Over Mass Cancellations Caused by Pilot Vacations
abstract: The budget airline has faced a wave of customer anger over the cancellation of 2,100 flights over a six-week period in September and October.
lead_paragraph: Ryanair’s chief executive apologized to shareholders and customers on Thursday, looking to stanch criticism over the cancellation of more than 2,100 flights after it scheduled too many pilots for vacation.

headline: Pressure Mounts on Iraqi Kurds to Cancel Independence Vote
abstract: In a region where few people agree on anything, neighbors and allies are pressing the Kurds to delay a vote they say could unleash violence.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — In a region where few people concur on anything, adversaries and enemies in the Middle East find themselves agreeing on one goal: to stop Iraq’s Kurds from forging ahead with a vote for independence on Monday.

headline: For Neanderthals, Growing Big Brains Took More Time
abstract: New research suggests that the brain of a juvenile Neanderthal developed more slowly than that of a similarly aged Homo sapiens child, but scientists don’t yet know why.
lead_paragraph: We modern humans like to boast about our big brains, but the Neanderthals seem to have had even larger ones.

headline: Peabody Essex Museum Gets Set of Native American Artifacts
abstract: Some of the items are claimed by tribes and will likely be returned by the museum as part of its compliance with federal repatriation laws.
lead_paragraph: A noted collection of more than 150 Native American artifacts, including wampum belts and finely beaded ceremonial garb, will stay – for now — where it has been housed for almost 70 years, at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., officials announced Thursday.

headline: Trump and AIDS
abstract: The Center for Health and Gender Equity criticizes a Trump administration proposal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Behind the Scenes with Gigi Hadid
abstract: The model finishes her third collection for Tommy x Gigi — and then walks in the show.
lead_paragraph: The model finishes her third collection for Tommy x Gigi — and then walks in the show.

headline: 48 Hours in London with Gigi Hadid
abstract: The model’s collaboration with Tommy Hilfiger, now in its third season, debuted at the Roundhouse this week. T followed along in the moments before the show.
lead_paragraph: It’s early Monday afternoon at the Tommy Hilfiger showroom in Knightsbridge, West London — a four-story monument to preppy American style in bright primary colors — and Gigi Hadid, the 22-year-old half-Dutch half-Palestinian model is showing me the collection she codesigned with Hilfiger, titled Tommy X Gigi, that will be shown at the historic music venue The Roundhouse the following night. “This is my favorite piece,” she coos, picking out a vintage-looking oversize leather jacket with her name emblazoned in red lettering on the back. “I get very excited when things turn out the way you envision it.”

headline: Only Fools Pay Estate Tax?
abstract: A reader is shocked by a comment by Gary Cohn, the top economic adviser.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Allure of Black-Colored Food
abstract: Why is it so hard to resist the taste of darkness?
lead_paragraph: WE KNOW ONLY a few grim details of the Hell Banquet, which took place in the first century A.D. The host: the glowering, paranoid Roman emperor Domitian, never happier than when executing opponents in the senate. The setting: a room black from floor to ceiling, lit by low-burning lamps, with each guest’s name engraved on a ­tombstone-like stela. The food: of the kind normally offered to the dead, and entirely black.

headline: Documenta’s Athens Venue Was a Costly Success, Officials Say
abstract: The decision to stage a part of the German contemporary art exhibition in the Greek capital helped create an $8 million shortfall
lead_paragraph: Berlin — The budget of Documenta, the pace-setting quinquennial exhibition of contemporary art traditionally hosted in Kassel, Germany, ran $8 million over budget primarily due to costs incurred at a second venue this year in Athens, officials said Thursday.

headline: Syrian Refugee Held in London Tube Bombing Is Released
abstract: Five other men remain in custody over the Parsons Green subway explosion, which injured 30 people.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Syrian refugee arrested in connection with the recent London subway attack was released without charge on Thursday, the British police said.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Wasn’t the First Host to Get Serious About Politics
abstract: When Jimmy Kimmel talked seriously about health care, it was an uncommon moment for him, but other late-night hosts have substituted politics for punch lines.
lead_paragraph: When Jimmy Kimmel dropped the humor and began a relentless campaign against the latest effort from Senate Republicans to repeal the Affordable Care Act, it was — at the very least — an uncommon moment for him.

headline: It’s the U.N.’s Week, but Executives Make It a High-Minded Mingle
abstract: On the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly, business leaders schmooze with diplomats — and one another — at private dinners and opulent events.
lead_paragraph: What do you get when you combine more than 100 heads of state, a few hundred chief executives and several thousand hangers-on in Midtown Manhattan?

headline: Facebook to Turn Over Russian-Linked Ads to Congress
abstract: The company said it would turn over 3,000 ads linked to Russia to Congress after growing scrutiny about its role in last November’s presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under growing pressure from Congress and the public to reveal more about the spread of covert Russian propaganda on Facebook, the company said on Thursday that it was turning over more than 3,000 Russia-linked ads to congressional committees investigating the Kremlin’s influence operation during the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Katherine M. Bonniwell, Life Magazine Publisher, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Bonniwell held a number of top positions at Time Inc. at a heady time for magazine publishing, paving the way for future female managers.
lead_paragraph: Katherine M. Bonniwell, a former publisher of Life magazine who was widely considered a role model for female magazine managers, died on Aug. 31 at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

abstract: Researchers called it “the most severe case they had ever seen in someone of Aaron’s age.”
lead_paragraph: The brain scan came as a surprise even to researchers who for years have been studying the relationship between brain disease and deaths of professional football players.

headline: When the Subway Fails, Riders Scream Into the Twitter Abyss
abstract: The morning commute for L train riders was a mess. So they vented the only way they could — on social media.
lead_paragraph: The cries of misery from the underground began to bubble up into the world above just as the Thursday morning rush was getting underway on the New York City subway.

headline: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to new art shows.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows.

headline: My Struggle to Take Anti-H.I.V. Medicine
abstract: PrEP is effective and it should be available to people who want it. But when I took the pills, I felt guilt and a sense of isolation.
lead_paragraph: I am a 30-something African-American gay man in New York. H.I.V. is constantly on my mind. Not so much my H.I.V.-negative status. Rather, even though I watched my parents die of AIDS when I was young, I still struggle with whether I should take the drug Truvada, a pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) that can protect almost completely against H.I.V.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: Facebook’s Frankenstein Moment
abstract: A series of scandals have opened up the possibility that the company may have created something it can’t fully control.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, in response to a ProPublica report that Facebook enabled advertisers to target users with offensive terms like “Jew hater,” Sheryl Sandberg, the company’s chief operating officer, apologized and vowed that the company would adjust its ad-buying tools to prevent similar problems in the future.

headline: New York Police Sergeant Arrested After Confrontation With Cyclist
abstract: The police said Sgt. Bradley Beamer, 40, threatened the cyclist with a gun, then, after briefly leaving the scene, knocked him to the ground.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer pulled a gun on a bicyclist and later pushed the man to the ground in a fit of road rage in southwestern Queens, the police said on Thursday.

abstract: Our guide to dance performances.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Accused a Senator of Lying About His Health Care Bill. Who’s Right?
abstract: Mr. Kimmel has emerged as a vocal critic of a bill co-sponsored by Senator Bill Cassidy. A review of his statements suggests he has a strong grasp of the measure.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Kimmel, the talk show host who has become the unlikely face of opposition to Senate Republicans’ latest health care push, insisted he had done his homework.

headline: Nine Elephants in Botswana Are Electrocuted by Power Line
abstract: The elephants died after they knocked into the line and the power came into contact with water from a broken pipe, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Nine elephants were electrocuted near a village in eastern Botswana this week after they came into contact with a fallen power line near a water source, officials said.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: Has New York Fashion Week Finally Gotten the Memo on Diversity?
abstract: At least two nonwhite models appeared in 94 shows and presentations, and plus-size models were cast 90 times, an all-time high.
lead_paragraph: For several seasons now, fashion observers have gingerly expressed enthusiasm for the increasing diversity on the runways, often concerned that what seemed like a real change could be nothing more than a trend. But in New York, at least, the slow but steady transformation may have staying power.

headline: Air Pollution Tied to Kidney Disease
abstract: Add a new potential ill to the list of problems linked to air pollution: kidney disease.
lead_paragraph: Add a new potential ill to the list of problems linked to air pollution: kidney disease.

headline: Albert Speer Jr., Architect and Son of Hitler Confidant, Dies at 83
abstract: The younger Mr. Speer ultimately had more influence on urban landscapes than his notorious father, from whom he sought to distance himself.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Albert Speer Jr., an internationally prominent architect who sought throughout his life to distance himself from the dark legacy of his father, a member of Adolf Hitler’s inner circle, died on Sept. 15 at his home in Frankfurt. He was 83.

headline: Sounds of Autumn
abstract: Galas were held last week for the New York Philharmonic, New Yorkers For Children, the American Theater Wing and the Museum at F.I.T.
lead_paragraph: Galas were held last week for the New York Philharmonic, New Yorkers For Children, the American Theater Wing and the Museum at F.I.T.

headline: How to Avoid Buying a Car Flooded by Hurricanes
abstract: With some basic due diligence, as well as a discerning eye, you can usually avoid buying a water-damaged car.
lead_paragraph: It has become predictable. First come the hurricane and flooding. Then come the dire warnings about waterlogged cars being put up for sale without any notice about flood damage.

headline: Amid Quake Rubble in Mexico, ‘We Will Get Through It’
abstract: Hundreds of volunteers, military personnel and city workers came together to try to find survivors after a textile factory collapsed during Tuesday’s earthquake, burying several people in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of volunteers, military personnel and city workers came together to try to find survivors after a textile factory collapsed during Tuesday’s earthquake, burying several people in Mexico City.

headline: Writing Rupert, Playing Murdoch, Making ‘Ink’
abstract: How the playwright James Graham and the actor Bertie Carvel give the media mogul a fair hearing in a play that takes a hard look at populism and the press.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Brash headlines. Hyper-opinionated columnists. Celebrity mania. Unabashed appeals to those who feel excluded.

headline: Saudi Textbook Withdrawn Over Image of Yoda With King
abstract: A Saudi artist says he has no idea how his image of the Jedi master and a Saudi monarch ended up in textbooks. The government was investigating.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — High school students in Saudi Arabia opened their social studies textbooks this week to find that the Force was with them.

headline: New Effort to Kill Obamacare Is Called ‘the Most Radical’
abstract: The Graham-Cassidy bill would turn federal funding for a law Republicans loathe into block grants to states, realizing a long-held goal of the party.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Republicans have dreamed of taking some of the vast sums the federal government spends on health care entitlements and handing the money over to states to use as they saw best.

headline: Essex College Administrator Is Placed on Leave Amid Investigation
abstract: The New Jersey county college, which is in danger of losing its accreditation, is investigating allegations of financial abuse by a vice president.
lead_paragraph: The Essex County College administrator accused of causing problems at the troubled two-year school was placed on paid administrative leave on Tuesday by the trustees while an investigation is conducted into allegations of financial abuse.

headline: Acclaimed French Chef to Michelin: Take My Stars, Please
abstract: Sébastien Bras, who runs Le Suquet restaurant in Laguiole, France, doesn’t want the stress. He’s not the first to seek to surrender the accolade.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sébastien Bras, at 46, one of France’s most celebrated chefs, has stunned the French culinary world with an unlikely plea: Take my three Michelin stars away.

headline: The Doorman Makes a Match
abstract: Two years of friendly exchanges pay off in a big way.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Iran Foreign Minister: If U.S. Wants New Nuclear Concessions, We Do, Too
abstract: The 2015 agreement cannot be selectively “revisited” to address American complaints, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif told The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s foreign minister rejected on Thursday any new negotiation with the United States over extending the length or conditions of the 2015 nuclear accord, saying that Iran would talk about changing the accord only if every concession it made — including giving up nuclear fuel — were reconsidered.

headline: A Little Italy Tradition, Hanging by a String
abstract: For the Feast of San Gennaro, a tradition of Sicilian puppetry is revived.
lead_paragraph: The evening on Mulberry Street was already thickening with the aroma of fried dough and grilled sausage when a knight in faded armor coursed through the crowd in a shopping cart.

headline: North Korea, Puerto Rico, Mexico: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: iPhones, Jemele Hill, Food Memories and Teenage Tattoos: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week
abstract: The Times articles students read last week, and an invitation to join the conversation this week.
lead_paragraph: Each week on our site, we post nine new writing prompts inspired by Times articles or images, and we hear from teenagers all over the world in response. Below, we’ve called out some of the best comments that have come in over the last seven days.

headline: Detectives' Complaint Alleges Discrimination at N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Three black detectives with the New York Police Department filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that they were discriminated against and denied promotions.
lead_paragraph: Three black detectives with the New York Police Department filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that they were discriminated against and denied promotions.

headline: A Glowing Cotton Study That Might Have Deserved Less Glowing Reviews
abstract: Cotton experts were not impressed with a recent study published by scientists who claimed they created naturally glowing and magnetic cotton.
lead_paragraph: The enticing claim in a study released last week was that researchers had created naturally glowing and magnetic cotton. Journalists enthusiastically covered the paper, published in Science. “It could be the biggest advance in cotton technology since Eli Whitney’s gin,” an article in Forbes reported.

headline: Panel Finds N.Y.P.D. Discriminated Against Black Detectives
abstract: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission found the promotion process at the Police Department’s Intelligence Division discriminated against black detectives.
lead_paragraph: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission found the promotion process at the Police Department’s Intelligence Division discriminated against black detectives.

headline: Justice Dept. Declines to Sue N.Y.P.D. Over Discrimination
abstract: The Department of Justice declined to sue the New York Police Department based on a commission’s findings of discrimination against black detectives.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice declined to sue the New York Police Department based on a commission’s findings of discrimination against black detectives.

headline: New Turf Fight Has U.S. Soccer and Women’s Team at Odds Again
abstract: The players are angry that they will close their 2017 schedule with several matches on artificial turf. But the disagreement also suggests a persistent disconnect between the team and the federation.
lead_paragraph: Five months after U.S. Soccer and the women’s national team completed often contentious negotiations on a new collective bargaining agreement, the players and the federation have fallen out again over an old grievance: artificial turf.

headline: Most Seen on Stage? Shakespeare the Character, Not the Playwright
abstract: The 2014 play “Shakespeare in Love” will be the most produced play in the country this season.
lead_paragraph: Works by Shakespeare aren’t counted. But works about Shakespeare are. A survey by American Theater magazine shows that “Shakespeare in Love,” the 2014 play about young Will’s formative years, adapted by Lee Hall from the wildly successful 1998 film version, will be the most produced play in the United States during the 2017-18 theatrical season.

headline: President Trump Inside and Outside the Lines at the U.N.
abstract: Sticking to a speech or veering off script, the president often seemed like a fish out of water at the General Assembly gathering.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It was hardly a surprise that Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate impresario-turned-leader of the free world, would mix awkwardly with the highly scripted, scrupulously diplomatic crowd that converges here for the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Baseball Needs More Netting, and Fewer Excuses
abstract: The sight of a bloodied young fan at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday should serve as the impetus for the sport to extend netting at every ballpark.
lead_paragraph: A little girl, a strawberry blonde, was hit in the face with a 105-mile-per-hour line drive Wednesday afternoon at Yankee Stadium. A fan sitting near her said, “There was so much blood.” In the arms of her grandfather, her small body was limp as he carried her out of the stands.

headline: Fighting Breaks Out at Turkish President’s Speech in New York
abstract: In the middle of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s speech at a Times Square hotel, a protester screamed: “You’re a terrorist. Get out of my country!”
lead_paragraph: Violence broke out at a New York hotel Thursday afternoon when protesters disrupted a speech by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Tradition in Little Italy, Hanging by a String
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 22, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “We got the feast, a Mass and a puppet show — it’s just like it was 70 years ago.”

headline: Trump Poised to Drop Some Limits on Drone Strikes and Commando Raids
abstract: The president’s national security advisers have advised relaxing certain Obama-era rules outside war zones, laying the groundwork for counterterrorism missions in more countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is preparing to dismantle key Obama-era limits on drone strikes and commando raids outside conventional battlefields, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations. The changes would lay the groundwork for possible counterterrorism missions in countries where Islamic militants are active but the United States has not previously tried to kill or capture them.

headline: For Puerto Ricans Off the Island, a Struggle to Make Contact After Maria
abstract: With all power out and most cell towers down, many Puerto Ricans found themselves unable to communicate with loved ones on the storm-ravaged island.
lead_paragraph: For the more than five million Puerto Ricans living on the United States mainland, it was bad enough to watch news reports on Wednesday of Hurricane Maria ripping through an island where relatives and friends lived. What made it worse was not knowing how their loved ones had fared.

headline: Black Detectives in New York Were Bypassed for Promotions, Panel Finds
abstract: A federal panel’s findings, made public for the first time, said that the promotions process systematically stymied black detectives in the elite Intelligence Division.
lead_paragraph: In one of New York City’s most powerful police divisions, there was an obscure unit filled almost exclusively by black detectives.

headline: In Rape Case at Rikers: Did Guards Turn a Blind Eye?
abstract: Two female inmates claimed in court papers that several guards, in some cases, provided a prisoner with access to the victims and materials used in the assaults.
lead_paragraph: The sexual assaults went on for two days in April. A female inmate raped her cellmate on Rikers Island with a makeshift sexual device, according to prosecutors. The whole time the cell was under video surveillance.

headline: World Leaders Urge Big Tech to Police Terrorist Content
abstract: Meeting at the U.N., the officials challenged Silicon Valley to keep terrorists from recruiting on the internet. The companies said they were trying.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The establishment was challenging the disrupters: Get your algorithms to stop terrorists from using the internet.

headline: Kim’s Rejoinder to Trump’s Rocket Man: ‘Mentally Deranged U.S. Dotard’
abstract: After President Trump threatened to “totally destroy” his country, Kim Jong-un vowed countermeasures and called the American leader a “frightened dog” and a “dotard.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Responding directly for the first time to President Trump’s threat at the United Nations to destroy nuclear-armed North Korea, its leader called Mr. Trump a “mentally deranged U.S. dotard” on Friday and vowed the “highest level of hard-line countermeasure in history.”

headline: Puerto Rico Faces Mountain of Obstacles on the Road to Recovery
abstract: For an island long crippled by enormous debt and an essentially bankrupt financial system, Puerto Rico’s road back has gone from long to seemingly endless.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Read the latest on Hurricane Maria with Friday’s live updates.

headline: The Home Run Explosion Is Not Exactly Beyond Suspicion
abstract: Drug testing in baseball is tougher these days, as are the penalties, but it is naïve to think doping might not be a factor in the power surge.
lead_paragraph: The record-setting 5,694th home run of the 2017 season soared over the right-center-field fence in Toronto earlier this week. And the talk afterward among coaches and players centered on launch angles and physics and miraculous epiphanies about the virtue of pulling the baseball.

headline: Scott Perry, New Knicks G.M., Likes Things ‘Clean and Neat’
abstract: Known as a meticulous organizer, he has stepped into a wayward franchise that has never been described as “clean and neat.” His family is along for the ride.
lead_paragraph: Scott Perry, the Knicks’ new general manager, has been in New York for more than a month, but the walls of his office at the team’s practice center in Tarrytown remain bare. A copy of ESPN The Magazine with Aaron Rodgers on the cover was on the wooden coffee table. Perry said he hadn’t had a chance to read it yet.

headline: Stunned by Quake, Mexican Town Fears It ‘Will Never Be the Same’
abstract: Jojutla, a town south of Mexico City that is unaccustomed to earthquakes, was heavily damaged by Tuesday’s quake and is struggling to cope with a scarcity of resources.
lead_paragraph: JOJUTLA, Mexico — The remnants of their life lay before them like some crude exhibit in a gallery of loss: a pink Bible, a Mickey Mouse T-shirt, earthenware plates and enamel pots.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Fall fiction is here and ready to entertain you, as new novels by Nicole Krauss, Salman Rushdie and Nathan Englander can attest. In nonfiction, enhance your viewing of Ken Burns’s “Vietnam War” with James Reston Jr.’s “A Rift in the Earth,” the story of the controversy over Maya Lin’s Vietnam memorial. Two illuminating memoirs — one by a candidate, one by a journalist — will plunge you back into the thick of the 2016 election, but if that history is still a little too close for comfort, you can always take refuge in Scaachi Koul’s irreverent essay collection, “One Day We’ll All Be Dead and None of This Will Matter.”

headline: Guggenheim Exhibit With Video of Dogs Trying to Fight Stirs Criticism
abstract: Facing a backlash, the museum put out a statement defending an exhibition by Chinese conceptual artists that is to open on Oct. 6.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks before a much-anticipated exhibition featuring Chinese conceptual artists opens at the Guggenheim, the museum is facing intense pressure to exclude one piece of art: a video of dogs trying to fight one another.

headline: Western Grouse
abstract: David Steinberg mixes it up.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — “Stacks” (long adjacent entries) are a themeless crossword format that comes in and out of vogue periodically. They do have good things going for them, but some weaknesses as well.

headline: Megyn Kelly Is Ready for Her Morning Closeup
abstract: The former Fox News host says her daily NBC morning show, which starts Monday, is one she was “born to do.” Others aren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: Though Megyn Kelly has offered few specifics about what her NBC morning show will be like, she is happy to try a few analogies.

headline: Mother and Children Rescued From a Boat Caught in Hurricane Maria
abstract: A full day passed before the Coast Guard could rescue a family of four that was at sea during the storm. One passenger, a British man, died.
lead_paragraph: The distress call came at 2:30 a.m. Wednesday. Two adults and two children were on a disabled vessel adrift in 20-foot waves and extreme winds.

headline: Trump, Though Not on Stage, Looms Large in Alabama G.O.P. Senate Debate
abstract: The sitting senator, Luther Strange, took every opportunity to mention the president’s endorsement, and the candidate he trails, Roy Moore, needled him for it.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Senator Luther Strange used every opportunity he had at a Republican candidate forum here on Thursday to invoke his support from President Trump as he defended his seat against former state Supreme Court Justice Roy Moore, who unfurled a litany of accusations against Mr. Strange and ridiculed his reliance on the president’s endorsement just days before they face off in Alabama’s special Senate election.

headline: In Laver Cup’s Debut, Europe Towers Over the World
abstract: There is no question as to which multinational squad will be the underdog in the inaugural three-day competition: Team World, which features four Americans.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — The first draw in the history of the Laver Cup was over, and Team World decided to have the first on-court huddle in the history of the Laver Cup.

headline: Stepping Out After a Day and Night of Fear, Puerto Ricans Find an Island in Tatters
abstract: With power gone and most communication out, residents surveyed the extensive damage they could see and wondered about the devastation elsewhere that they could not.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Power was knocked out across Puerto Rico on Wednesday and communications were scarce, but all residents had to do to witness the state of their island was step outside and survey their homes, barrios and towns.

headline: German Election Mystery: Why No Russian Meddling?
abstract: After witnessing Moscow’s meddling in the American and French elections, Germany had its guard up. But the Kremlin seems to be sitting this one out.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s summons to Germany’s top cabinet ministers and senior military and intelligence officials for a meeting of the Federal Security Council signaled trouble. Such gatherings are rare, typically occurring only when the country faces a grave threat like a terrorist attack.

headline: Seeking Asylum in Germany, and Finding Hatred
abstract: Escaping violence in Libya, Abode struggles to belong in a German town that has become a flashpoint of anti-immigrant anger.
lead_paragraph: Escaping violence in Libya, Abode struggles to belong in a German town that has become a flashpoint of anti-immigrant anger.

headline: In Germany, Blue-Collar Jobs Provide Bulwark to Populism
abstract: Dortmund survived the collapse of its coal and steel industries, which helped the city avoid the working-class alienation that has fed right-wing parties elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: DORTMUND, Germany — This city in the heart of what was once German coal and steel country could easily be a breeding ground for populism.

headline: The Twins Point the Way on Protective Screens
abstract: Target Field in Minneapolis was the first to have protective netting to the far end of the dugouts. Other teams have joined in, including three more on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The line drive that stuck a young girl in the face at Yankee Stadium Wednesday afternoon created a painful reverberation across the world of baseball. And it was particularly felt in Minneapolis, since the Minnesota Twins were the team on the field when the incident occurred and their players were closest to the girl.

headline: Discovering Manhood in Soapy Bubbles
abstract: He thought he had left his father’s machismo behind. But when it came time to propose, he didn’t think he was man enough to be anyone’s husband.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until I started doing dishes that I realized men in my family don’t do dishes.

headline: Corrections: September 22, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, September 22, 2017.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Tony Abbott Claims Head-Butt by Australian Gay-Marriage Supporter
abstract: The former prime minister, a same-sex marriage opponent, said a man in Tasmania wearing a “Vote Yes” badge had left him with a swollen lip.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The police in Tasmania have charged a man with assault after former Prime Minister Tony Abbott said in an interview that a same-sex-marriage supporter had head-butted him Thursday in Hobart.

abstract: Lady Gaga sheds the glamour but retains her chart-topping talent in a new documentary. And the final season of the Canadian cop drama “19-2” arrives on Acorn TV.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga sheds the glamour but retains her chart-topping talent in a new documentary. And the final season of the Canadian cop drama “19-2” arrives on Acorn TV.

headline: Full Text of Kim Jong-un’s Response to President Trump
abstract: The statement by Mr. Kim was the first time that a North Korean leader has issued a statement to the world under his name, South Korea said.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has responded to President Trump’s vow at the United Nations to “totally destroy” North Korea if it threatened the United States or its allies. His remarks, released on Friday by KCNA, the North Korean state news agency, were believed to be the first time a North Korean leader directly issued a statement to the world under his name.
