headline: Word + Quiz: soporific
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Rejection
abstract: What message does this image communicate?
lead_paragraph: This is an illustration that went with an Op-Ed published by The Times in 2015.

headline: Right and Left React to the Graham-Cassidy Bill
abstract: Writers from across the political spectrum discuss the Republican health care bill proposed by Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: I Wanted to Play Football. Mom Wouldn’t Let Me.
abstract: As a boy in the 1970s, the idea that a contact sport could be dangerous seemed ridiculous. It wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: After reading the Times story this week about new evidence that playing tackle football, especially before the age of 12, may lead to diminished cognitive function later in life, my first thought was, “Thanks, Mom.”

headline: World Hunger Haunts the U.N. Festivities
abstract: After a decade of decline, global malnutrition rose last year, as global warming and civil conflicts posed a greater threat.
lead_paragraph: As the leaders of the world posture and sermonize for the United Nations General Assembly this week, a growing global specter should spur common concern among them: World hunger, after a decade-long decline, spiked last year, because of scourges like global warming and civil conflicts that show little sign of abating.

headline: In Rome, a Visit With the Anti-Trump
abstract: As the president went low, the pope went high.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Walking to the Eternal City, over stones worn down by the sandals of centurions, on a pilgrim’s path nearly forgotten in all the layers of Italian time, the mind focuses as the muscles stiffen.

headline: Jake LaMotta and the Art of Taking a Punch
abstract: The boxer, like his sport, hung in there, with a little help from “Raging Bull.”
lead_paragraph: Ad Francis’ face was misshapen from having absorbed too many blows in the boxing ring but, he proudly said, “I could take it.”

headline: Russia’s Olympic Cheating, Unpunished
abstract: World sports officials appear poised to give the Kremlin a pass on doping.
lead_paragraph: In November 2015, I escaped Russia determined to tell the world about my country’s doping program for Olympic athletes. As the former director of Russia’s antidoping center, I disclosed indisputable evidence of widespread, state-sanctioned cheating by my country, hoping this would lead to change.

headline: Merkelism vs. Trumpism
abstract: Angela Merkel finally seems to understand that she is not just the leader of Germany, she’s the defender of internationalism.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — When I suggested in a 2015 article for this paper that Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany might become the leader of the free world, I knew it was a pretty far-fetched idea. After all, despite her leading role in the euro and refugee crises, she didn’t actually seem to want the job.

headline: Cruelty, Incompetence and Lies
abstract: Graham-Cassidy says a lot about the Republican Party, none of it good.
lead_paragraph: Graham-Cassidy, the health bill the Senate may vote on next week, is stunningly cruel. It’s also incompetently drafted: The bill’s sponsors clearly had no idea what they were doing when they put it together. Furthermore, their efforts to sell the bill involve obvious, blatant lies.

headline: The Coming War on Business
abstract: A quarter century ago, Sam Francis was championing the things that got Donald Trump elected last year.
lead_paragraph: The only time I saw Sam Francis face-to-face — in the Washington Times cafeteria sometime in the late 1980s or early 1990s — I thought he was a crank, but it’s clear now that he was at that moment becoming one of the most prescient writers of the past 50 years. There’s very little Donald Trump has done or said that Francis didn’t champion a quarter century ago.

headline: California’s Sexual Assault Law Will Hurt Black Kids
abstract: Harsh school discipline policies fall hardest on students of color.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is poised to sign a worrisome bill that will codify the Obama-era sexual assault guidelines. Those rules told colleges to toughen up on sexual assault allegations or risk losing federal dollars.

headline: How to Win a War on Drugs
abstract: Portugal treats addiction as a disease, not a crime.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — On a broken-down set of steps, a 37-year-old fisherman named Mario mixed heroin and cocaine and carefully prepared a hypodermic needle. “It’s hard to find a vein,” he said, but he finally found one in his forearm and injected himself with the brown liquid. Blood trickled from his arm and pooled on the step, but he was oblivious.

headline: An Obituary Written From Beyond the Grave? Not Quite
abstract: Because The Times prepares some obituaries for notable people in advance, in rare instances an obituary will appear by a writer who is already deceased.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Taylor holds the distinction.

headline: Bowie, Bach and Bebop: How Music Powered Basquiat
abstract: What was on the turntable in Jean-Michel Basquiat’s studio? The answer is crucial to understanding his work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 1979, at 19, the artist Jean-Michel Basquiat moved into an abandoned apartment on East 12th Street in Manhattan with his girlfriend at the time, Alexis Adler. The home, a sixth-floor walk-up, was run-down and sparsely furnished. Basquiat, broke and unable to afford canvases, painted with abandon on the walls and floor, even on Ms. Adler’s clothes.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Maria Strikes, and Puerto Rico Goes Dark’
abstract: How will Puerto Rico recover from the latest devastating hurricane?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to Greek myths, a cover illustration and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Would You Spend Your Ideal Family Vacation?
abstract: How does your family typically spend vacations?
lead_paragraph: What is your favorite family vacation you have ever taken? What did you love about it?

headline: Dogs Recognize Themselves in Test Based on Smell, Not Sight
abstract: Canines don’t seem to perceive their reflections in mirrors. But they do better with a ‘‘smell mirror.’’
lead_paragraph: Imagine a species that lived in a world of smells and didn’t pay a lot of attention to what things look like. What would members of that species use for a mirror?

headline: Leading the Legal War Against Fox
abstract: So far this year, the lawyer Douglas Wigdor, a conservative Republican, has filed 11 suits against Fox News for defamation, sexual harassment and racial discrimination.
lead_paragraph: It was late in April, not long after he had filed his first three lawsuits against Fox News and was gearing up to file three more that the lawyer Douglas Wigdor decided he needed a flow chart. His legal barrage against the network was getting confusing. Litigation was flying everywhere. It was leaping off his desk.

headline: Mexico City Was Built on an Ancient Lake Bed. That Makes Earthquakes Much Worse.
abstract: The devastating earthquake on Tuesday was all the more destructive because of Mexico City’s unusual position atop an ancient lake bed.
lead_paragraph: The devastating earthquake on Tuesday was all the more destructive because of Mexico City’s unusual position atop an ancient lake bed.

headline: Marilynne Robinson on Finding the Right Word
abstract: The author of “Gilead” and “Housekeeping” reflects on Emily Dickinson, expanding the mind and writing into the unknown.
lead_paragraph: One of the things I love about Emily Dickinson is the way that, every time I read her poetry, I feel as though I’m encountering it for the first time. It has a reserve of meaning that seems to open very slowly over a long series of readings. Part of that is due to the extreme compression of her poems, which strip away everything inessential, greatly magnifying the potency of each individual word. She puts an extraordinary pressure on language by her parsimoniousness. But she restricted not only her language very narrowly — apparently, she restricted her life very narrowly, too. Out of this came a body of poetry that really has no equivalent in American literature.

headline: Writing Lines for Obama, Mixing Comedy and Hope
abstract: In his memoir “Thanks, Obama,” the speechwriter David Litt recalls coming of age at the White House.
lead_paragraph: THANKS, OBAMA My Hopey, Changey White House Years By David Litt 310 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99

headline: How Dogs Recognize Their Scents — And Selves
abstract: Dogs appear to know their own scent in a test involving samples of urine. Is that the same as recognizing oneself in a mirror?
lead_paragraph: Dogs appear to know their own scent in a test involving samples of urine. Is that the same as recognizing oneself in a mirror?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: How We Make Up Our Minds
abstract: Four books about the mechanics of decision making.
lead_paragraph: SCIENCEBLIND Why Our Intuitive Theories About the World Are So Often Wrong By Andrew Shtulman 311 pp. Basic Books. $30.

headline: Reviews in Pictures: Harry Bliss on Norman Douglas’s ‘South Wind’
abstract: The 1917 novel from the British travel writer uses landscape as character.

headline: ‘The Snowy Day’ Captured in New Stamp Series
abstract: A new run of “Forever” stamps will feature scenes from Ezra Jack Keats’s classic children’s tale.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 4, the United States Postal Service will issue four stamps, part of the “Forever” series, featuring Peter, the little boy from Ezra Jack Keats’s “The Snowy Day.” The book was published in 1962. The next year, Martin Luther King delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech, and “The Snowy Day” won the Caldecott Medal. It’s a simple story: Peter wakes up, puts on a red snowsuit and plays in the snow, making tracks and snow angels and sliding down a “mountain” of snow. He puts a snowball in his pocket and is sad when, after his bath, it’s gone. But the next day he’s delighted that it has snowed again. Simple, but world-shifting: Peter was black, and no black child had ever been the protagonist of a full-color American picture book.

headline: In ‘Sing, Unburied, Sing,’ a Haunted Road Trip to Prison
abstract: A follow-up to “Salvage the Bones” tells the story of a woman intent on making her fractured family whole again.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: A True Tale of Drug Cartels, Money Laundering and Horse Racing
abstract: In “Bones,” by Joe Tone, the divergent lives of two brothers — a bricklayer in Texas and a cartel boss in Mexico — converge on the racetrack.
lead_paragraph: BONES Brothers, Horses, Cartels, and the Borderland Dream By Joe Tone 329 pp. One World. $28.

headline: The Shipping Container as Home
abstract: Building with shipping containers is becoming more popular as they are seen as an eco-friendly and affordable alternative to traditional homes.
lead_paragraph: Building with shipping containers is becoming more popular as they are seen as an eco-friendly and affordable alternative to traditional homes.

headline: Coming Home to a Shipping Container
abstract: Eco-friendly and affordable, shipping containers are gaining popularity as an alternative to traditional houses.
lead_paragraph: Tim Steele stood outside a pair of orange shipping containers on a hillside about two hours northwest of New York City. The large metal cargo door swung wide to reveal a small mudroom inside the corrugated walls, and beyond that an expansive living room, kitchen and small bathroom. Several tall windows looked out on the Catskill Mountains, a vista that stretched for miles.

headline: Trevor Noah Thinks Paul Manafort Got Mixed Up With the Wrong Crowd
abstract: Mr. Noah said, “Ask yourself this: When has the phrase ‘Russian oligarch’ ever been a good thing?”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Who Will Be Trump’s Pick to Lead the Fed? We Asked Experts to Rate the Odds
abstract: The president has dropped no hints of what he might do, leaving the field wide open for expert guesswork.
lead_paragraph: The most important job in global economics is up for grabs in a mere four months. And it looks to be a wide-open race to fill the job.

headline: Teaching With: ‘Over 60 and Dancing at W.N.B.A. Center Court’
abstract: The Timeless Torches, a dance squad for the W.N.B.A.’s Liberty, lets those over 40 — many in their 60s — shake their booty on center court, breaking the tradition of the typical halftime act.
lead_paragraph: The Timeless Torches, a dance squad for the W.N.B.A.’s Liberty, lets those over 40 — many in their 60s — shake their booty on center court, breaking the tradition of the typical halftime act. Watch the short documentary “Over 60 and Dancing at W.N.B.A. Center Court,” and share what you think in the comments section.

headline: Kim Jong-un Called Trump a ‘Dotard.’ What Does That Even Mean?
abstract: An obscure insult from North Korea’s leader inspires dictionary searches and online jokes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When President Trump threatened to “totally destroy” North Korea and mocked its leader, Kim Jong-un, as “Rocket Man” in a speech on Tuesday at the United Nations General Assembly, the rhetorical retaliation from Pyongyang was inevitable.

headline: North Korea, Puerto Rico, Aaron Hernandez: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Finding My Father, Preserved on Canvas
abstract: His art collection, with its movement and irreverence for boundaries, took him places he could no longer travel.
lead_paragraph: My father was an art collector, but he was anything but pretentious.

headline: New York Today: Keeping Your Apple-Picking Plans
abstract: Friday: How to keep leisure plans, weekend events, and free entrance to dozens of museums.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this nebulous Friday.

headline: Can You Prevent Picking Up Germs on the Subway?
abstract: Someone needs to invent a “subway condom,” one expert says.
lead_paragraph: Q. I take mass transit every day. Would wearing a glove (or holding something) to create a barrier between me and the stainless steel I grab onto every day be effective at reducing the potential for picking up germs?

headline: A Chorus of Mazel Tovs in Uganda
abstract: About 1,500 people, including politicians, family and friends, traveled from throughout Uganda to attend the celebration of five Jewish couples.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Shadrach Mugoya Levi drove three hours from his rural village of Magada in the Namutumba District of Uganda to find a woman named Naomi. His friends had insisted he meet her. When he arrived at her house, her mother answered the door and said: “No, my daughter is too young.”

headline: Theresa May Seeks to Unlock Brexit Talks in Florence Speech
abstract: More conciliatory than in the past, the prime minister offered some specifics aimed at soothing anxieties about a damaging “cliff-edge” withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seeking to end a stalemate in negotiations over her country’s withdrawal from the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain offered Friday substantial payments to the bloc during a two-year transition period immediately after the country’s exit.

headline: Uber Loses License to Operate in London
abstract: London’s transportation agency criticized Uber’s corporate culture, the latest setback for a company that has faced an array of controversies this year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Uber’s history of scandals and disregard for local rules finally caught up with it on Friday, when London declined to renew the ride-hailing company’s license to operate in the city, its largest European market.

headline: Baseball Diamonds Aren’t Forever: Bygone Ballparks of New York
abstract: Much of the game’s history can be traced through these five ballparks, which have all been torn down.
lead_paragraph: When shortstop Don Zimmer’s throw settled into first baseman Gil Hodges’s glove to seal a 2-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates 60 years ago this month, the Dodgers had played their final game in Brooklyn. With the Dodgers gone from Brooklyn, so was professional baseball at their longtime ballpark, Ebbets Field.

headline: Some People Learn to Code in Their 60s, 70s or 80s
abstract: Not all coders are from the millennial generation — older people, some of them retired or semiretired, are also learning technical languages.
lead_paragraph: For some older people, just downloading an app or successfully navigating certain websites might seem like cause for quiet celebration.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Hurricanes, Humans and Climate Change
abstract: As Maria tears apart the Caribbean, leaders in the region say that recent storms have created a humanitarian crisis — and that humans are to blame.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Tod’s: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: How Shan-Lyn Ma, Wedding Registry Founder, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Ma, the chief executive of Zola and a resident of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, writes in her journal, listens to podcasts and shops in Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: When many of her friends were getting married, Shan-Lyn Ma grew frustrated at the online wedding shopping process, so she decided to start Zola in an attempt to reinvent the traditional china-and-silverware registry process. She is the chief executive of the company, which was most recently valued at $220 million and has been used by more than 300,000 couples. There are over 50,000 items available on Zola, but the registry also offers experiences, like wine tastings, as well as a way to earmark cash gifts for honeymoon expenses or a home renovation. Ms. Ma, 40, lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, with her Cavalier King Charles spaniel, Noe.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Migraines, Drinking and Belly Fat
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: ‘The Principles of Uncertainty,’ Staged With Joy and Anguish
abstract: The performance version of Maira Kalman’s book arrives at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: On the jacket flap of her 2007 book “The Principles of Uncertainty,” the author and illustrator Maira Kalman briefly explains what the reader will find within — a fragmented personal diary “abounding with anguish, confusion, bits of wisdom, musings, meanderings, buckets of joie de vivre.” Now brought to the stage in collaboration with choreographer John Heginbotham, the performance version of “The Principles of Uncertainty,” arriving Wednesday, Sept. 27, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, can be described pretty much the same way.

headline: Amy Herzog’s New Play Mines the Personal and Political
abstract: “Mary Jane” is a portrait of a mother’s relationship with her chronically ill young son. Carrie Coon of “The Leftovers” stars.
lead_paragraph: The director Anne Kauffman has described the playwright Amy Herzog as “an inexhaustible excavator.” Anyone familiar with Ms. Herzog’s work is likely to agree. In plays like “After the Revolution” and “4000 Miles,” Ms. Herzog has dug deep into the terrain where generations intersect, in ways political as well as personal, with a perspective as cleareyed as it is compassionate. Expect the same traits to be in evidence in her latest offering, “Mary Jane,” which opens on Monday, Sept. 25, at the New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Richelieu Dennis of Sundial Brands on Building a Business vs. a Career
abstract: The chief executive of a beauty products company says an organization can’t be constructed by focusing on titles and promotions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Richelieu Dennis,  chief executive of Sundial Brands, a beauty products company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Giorgio Armani: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: English National Opera C.E.O. to Step Down
abstract: Cressida Pollock, who clashed with many of the company’s artists and management, will leave her position at the end of the current season.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Cressida Pollock, chief executive of the English National Opera, will leave her position at the end of the current season, four months before her contract expires. Her departure is the latest in a long series of departures from the beleaguered organization, which has had major funding cuts and management upheaval over the last two years.

headline: Morning Agenda: London to Ban Uber
abstract: The move by the British capital’s transportation regulator is a significant setback, as the ride-hailing service deals with trouble on multiple fronts.
lead_paragraph: Transport for London, the city’s transportation regulator, said on Friday that it would not renew the ride-hailing service’s operating license when it expires on Sept. 30.

headline: North Korea Hits New Level of Brinkmanship in Reacting to Trump
abstract: Kim Jong-un turns the standoff with Washington into a personal duel, while warning of more dangerous weapons tests.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has long cultivated an image of defiant belligerence, punctuating its propaganda and diplomacy with colorful threats, insults and bluster. But by addressing President Trump in a personal statement on Friday, the nation’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has pushed his government’s brinkmanship to a new, potentially more perilous level.

headline: Rouhani Lashes Back at Trump, as Iran Unveils New Missile
abstract: At a military parade, the Iranian president vowed to “strengthen our missile capabilities,” a point the American president has cited as a reason to scrap the nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: Escalating a war of words with the United States, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared on Friday that his country would continue to develop new missiles and “would not seek anyone’s permission to defend our land.”

headline: Harry Dean Stanton, and the Movies That Broke Him Free
abstract: The Quad Cinema salutes the actor, who died this month, with a retrospective.
lead_paragraph: With “Lucky,” opening Friday, Sept. 29, Harry Dean Stanton, who died this month, landed the role of a lifetime as a 90-year-old, desert-town atheist seeking spiritual enlightenment as he confronts the void beyond. (This directorial debut from John Carroll Lynch was written by Logan Sparks and Drago Sumonja with Mr. Stanton in mind.) In “Also Starring Harry Dean Stanton,” Sept. 22-Oct. 1, the Quad Cinema in Manhattan rolls out 21 movies that propelled the laconic character actor and his soulfully furrowed countenance to cult stardom. The lineup includes B. L. Norton’s “Cisco Pike,” Monte Hellman’s “Cockfighter,” Ridley Scott’s “Alien” and Howard Deutch’s “Pretty in Pink,” as well as Mr. Stanton’s first real lead, in Alex Cox’s “Repo Man” (1984), and his breakthrough months later as a mostly silent drifter yearning to reconnect with his estranged family in Wim Wenders’s “Paris, Texas.” Mr. Stanton won the part after he confessed to its writer Sam Shepard, who died in July, in a Santa Fe bar that he longed “to play something of some beauty or sensitivity.” (quadcinema.com)

headline: How Did That Date Go? In ‘Liar,’ It Depends on Who’s Telling
abstract: Joanne Froggatt (“Downton Abbey”) and Ioan Gruffudd (“Fantastic Four”) play a couple whose date leads to a vicious she-said, he-said war.
lead_paragraph: Joanne Froggatt, who twisted hearts as Anna Bates, the put-upon lady’s maid in “Downton Abbey,” subjects herself to yet another round of hardship in “Liar,” starting Wednesday, Sept. 27, on SundanceTV. Written by the brothers Harry and Jack Williams (“The Missing”), this six-part psychological thriller, which debuted in Britain this month, stars Ms. Froggatt as Laura Nielson, a teacher recently split from her long-term boyfriend, and Ioan Gruffudd (“Fantastic Four”) as Andrew Earlham, a widowed surgeon and father of one of her students, who asks her out on a date.

headline: Nate Wooley Puts Together a Mini-Festival
abstract: The trumpeter and composer organized “For/With,” a two-night event at Issue Project Room that focuses on four composers.
lead_paragraph: The trumpeter and composer Nate Wooley favors subtlety over bombast and slowly winding structures over obvious drama. His enigmatic sound world can seem to echo the unpredictability of the rest of the world. An artist of rare integrity and artistic ambition, he is also a keen collaborator, and has organized “For/With,” a two-night mini-festival at Issue Project Room in Brooklyn that focuses on four composers — Christian Wolff, Ashley Fure, Michael Pisaro and Annea Lockwood — from whom he has commissioned works. “For,” on Friday, Sept. 29, includes Mr. Wolff’s solo “For Trumpet Player” and Ms. Lockwood’s tribute to Pauline Oliveros alongside Ms. Fure’s percussion solo “Shiver Lung 2” and an improvised duo for Mr. Wolff (on percussion) and Mr. Pisaro (electric guitar). “With,” on Saturday, Sept. 30, features Mr. Pisaro’s piece for Mr. Wooley, “Stem-Flower-Root,” works by Ms. Lockwood and Mr. Wolff, and a discussion with the composers. (8 p.m., Downtown Brooklyn, issueprojectroom.org.)

headline: At a Los Angeles Art Show, Mickey Mouse as an Imperialist Icon
abstract: As part of the art extravaganza “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA,” an exhibition focuses on Walt Disney’s trip to South America.
lead_paragraph: “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA,” the art extravaganza that fills some 70 Southern California art institutions to celebrate the foundational presence of Latin American art in the region, is now under full sail. And probably none of its exhibitions more accessibly capture the hemispheric dynamic than “How to Read El Pato Pascual: Disney’s Latin America and Latin America’s Disney.” In 1941, Walt Disney traveled to South America with a small army of artists and screenwriters as part of the United States government’s postwar “Good Neighbor” policy. The trip produced Latinized versions of Donald Duck and Mickey Mouse in Disney films and accusations of cultural imperialism by Latin American artists. The tale unfolds in this ingeniously thought-out Los Angeles show (through Jan. 14) divided between the MAK Center for Art and Architecture at the Schindler House and the Luckman Fine Arts Complex at the California State University, Los Angeles.

headline: The Saxophonist Darius Jones Works Up to a Jazz Septet
abstract: At the Stone in Manhattan, Mr. Jones will be adding a new instrument each night to his collaborative performances.
lead_paragraph: There are a couple major ways an alto saxophonist can handle the instrument. You can clench and bridle, in the manner of an avant-gardist like Oliver Lake, using the horn to signify something like refusal. Or you can tease the listener, dilate your sound, give it the vibrato of a body overcome. That’s what Johnny Hodges did in Duke Ellington’s orchestra.

headline: Trump Dismisses ‘Russia Hoax’ as Facebook Turns Over Ads Tied to Campaign
abstract: The president asserts that the “Fake News Media” had the most sway in the 2016 election, and he again denies any Russian role in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday deflected concerns that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election in his favor and said the “Fake News Media” wielded the greatest influence with its support of the Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton.

headline: Take That, Jimmy Kimmel
abstract: Enough with the health care analysis from comedians. Let’s listen to the experts.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Do You Cycle in London? Share Your Story
abstract: We want to hear from cyclists and other road users in London. Share your experiences, photos and videos.
lead_paragraph: We want to hear from cyclists and other road users in London. Share your experiences, photos and videos.

headline: California Today: Suing the Trump Administration, Again and Again and Again
abstract: Friday: Taking stock of Xavier Becerra’s lawsuits, Duncan Hunter calls for an attack on North Korea, and a review of “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Very Bad Week for Digital Giants
abstract: Apple’s Watch has a bug, Facebook might be undermining democracy, and Amazon is telling us how to make bombs. Tech news is weird right now.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Jared Goff and the Rams Are a Thursday Night Surprise
abstract: Expectations were rock bottom for a game between the Rams and the 49ers. But it turned out to be an entertaining shootout.
lead_paragraph: Expectations were rock bottom for a Thursday night game between the Rams and the 49ers. But the game turned out to be an entertaining shootout, and maybe a breakout performance by Jared Goff.

headline: How to Help Puerto Rico and Other Islands After Hurricane Maria
abstract: A guide to helping victims of a storm that devastated the Caribbean, leaving millions without power and limited access to water.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico is on the brink of a humanitarian crisis, economies across the Caribbean are on life support, and dozens of people are dead.

headline: Birds Beware: The Praying Mantis Wants Your Brain
abstract: Scientists have developed a healthy respect for mantises, acrobatic hunters with 3-D vision and voracious appetites.
lead_paragraph: Tom Vaughan, a photographer then living in Colorado’s Mancos Valley, kept a hummingbird feeder outside his house. One morning, he stepped through the portico door and noticed a black-chinned hummingbird dangling from the side of the red plastic feeder like a stray Christmas ornament.

headline: A Silent ‘Macbeth’ in Manhattan, a Vodka-Charged One in Brooklyn
abstract: “Macbeth Muet” is a frolic through tragedy with puppetry, while “Makbet” is a darkly gregarious production (shots included).
lead_paragraph: The basement cabaret space at the SoHo Playhouse is not a large room, so it isn’t possible to be very far from the action. Still, at “Macbeth Muet,” a 50-minute frolic through tragedy from the Montreal-based company La Fille du Laitier, you wouldn’t want to be at a front-row table. Too much risk of getting spattered with flying blood (fake) or the innards of eggs (real).

headline: Bobby Moynihan on His New Life After ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: Mr. Moynihan, who was an “S.N.L.” cast member for nine seasons, stars in the CBS sitcom “Me, Myself & I,” which explores a man’s life at three ages.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the spring, Bobby Moynihan was a world-weary New Yorker, appearing weekly on “Saturday Night Live,” where, for nine seasons, he played such endearingly oblivious characters as Drunk Uncle and Anthony Crispino, and impersonated the “Fox & Friends” morning host Brian Kilmeade.

headline: Washington’s Opera Taps a Champion of New Work From St. Louis
abstract: Timothy O’Leary, who is known for staging premieres, has been named general director of the Washington National Opera.
lead_paragraph: Timothy O’Leary, a young American impresario who made new works and community engagement central to his success at the helm of Opera Theater of Saint Louis, will become the next general director of the Washington National Opera, the company announced Friday.

headline: Megan Fairchild, the Swan With the Screwball Spark
abstract: After a stint on Broadway and a divorce, City Ballet’s Megan Fairchild has arrived at a new level of artistry and her first Odette-Odile.
lead_paragraph: You would think that it’s every budding ballerina’s dream to dance “Swan Lake.” But it wasn’t Megan Fairchild’s.

headline: Tennis Onstage: Game, Set and Watch
abstract: Five plays that transported the drama and comedy of the game from the court to the theater.
lead_paragraph: Some tennis matches are tragedies. Some are comedies. Some are farces. And the outfits are pretty nifty, too. With the sport’s mix of grace and ferocity, brains and brute force, tennis has thwacked its way into plenty of plays, from Shakespeare’s “Henry V” to Amanda Peet’s forthcoming “Our Very Own Carlin McCullough.” Here’s a sampling of recent stage upsets and smashes.

headline: They Can Act. But Can They Serve?
abstract: Getting in character for “The Last Match,” the cast gets a tennis lesson from a former pro before taking the stage.
lead_paragraph: On a practice court at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens, two men were playing some pretty ugly tennis. It was the Monday morning after the United States Open and as the subway rumbled by and workers unstrung banners and logos, Wilson Bethel and Alex Mickiewicz faced each other across the sunstruck acrylic turf.

headline: Alternative Movie Posters: Fan Art We Love
abstract: Artists’ odes to favorite films are increasingly valuable. It’s “like a Keith Haring knockoff becoming more popular than the original,” an expert says.
lead_paragraph: A lot of fan art can be pretty lackluster. Consider your typical “Game of Thrones”-inspired noodlings, or the fiction that wistfully imagines romantic interludes between Harry Potter and Hermione Granger. Sure, there are occasional gems, but most are more ode than art.

headline: Anger Management at Prada and Moschino
abstract: Finally, the broader conversation around women made it to Milan.
lead_paragraph: It’s about time someone got mad on the runway.

headline: Expecting a Hero’s Welcome, Lebanese Director Was Accused of Treason
abstract: When Ziad Doueiri was detained at the airport in Beirut over having filmed in Israel, it provoked debates over law, politics and artistic freedom.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — It was supposed to be a glorious homecoming.

headline: What’s New on Netflix and Amazon Prime This Weekend
abstract: Drama, comedy and the search for meaning: This weekend brings the goods.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

headline: Learning to Live With a Changing World Map
abstract: From Kurdistan to Catalonia, the United States seems to reflexively oppose the creation of new countries. It should learn to go with the flow.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 8, 1918, less than a year after the United States entered World War I, President Woodrow Wilson spoke before a joint session of Congress to present a vision of a radically new international system that he believed would prevent the outbreak of another war. Wilson called for an “impartial adjustment of all colonial claims,” respecting the sovereignty of the people living under colonialism, and a redrawing of borders “along clearly recognizable lines of nationality.”

headline: VIDEO: Why an Airport Can Affect Your Mood
abstract: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.
lead_paragraph: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.

headline: Young Man Charged With Attempted Murder in London Subway Attack
abstract: The suspect, identified as Ahmed Hassan, 18, was also accused of using a banned explosive, the British police said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An 18-year-old man was charged with attempted murder on Friday related to the bombing last week on the London subway system that prompted a stampede and left more than 30 people wounded, the British police said.

headline: Why Texas Is No Longer Feeling Miraculous
abstract: The state’s Republicans have somehow become anti-business, and businesses are staying away.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Call it the season of Texas’ discontent. Of course there was Hurricane Harvey, which blasted the coastline, leaving cities flooded and an estimated $180 billion in damage. But Harvey is just the headline.

headline: Trump’s Travel Ban to Be Replaced by Restrictions Tailored to Certain Countries
abstract: The new restrictions could go into effect on Sunday and would prevent people in those nations from traveling to the United States or prompt increased scrutiny if they seek visas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is replacing his ban on travelers from six majority-Muslim countries with severe restrictions on visitors from nations he has determined do too little to protect against terrorists and criminals coming into the United States, officials said on Friday.

headline: Kyle Busch Knows He’s a Villain. The Black Hat Fits Just Fine.
abstract: Busch, one of 16 drivers in contention for the Nascar championship, does not care if he is liked, by fans or his fellow drivers.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Busch, the cantankerous and profane stock-car driver whose fan base calls itself Rowdy Nation, wears his Nascar championship ring from 2015 on his middle finger. He laughed when he was asked if the ring placement was a statement.

headline: Eggplant Parmesan
abstract: A better way to make this Italian, end-of-summer classic.
lead_paragraph: A better way to make this Italian, end-of-summer classic.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Treat yourself to some fried chicken, paired with whatever you’d like, whether cream gravy and mashed potatoes, or braised greens.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: A Weeknight Meal That Needs No Introduction
abstract: Ready in 30 minutes, sausage and peppers, paired with sunny-side-up eggs, can be just the thing for those nights when you just want something simple.
lead_paragraph: In a hurry for dinner? Last-minute guests, perhaps, or just no time to dither? You’ve worked all day, and you want something simple and relatively quick to prepare. You’re not above ordering in, but, given the cost of takeout and the inevitable soggy-steamy contents of the delivered goods, you would prefer to cook something.

headline: Etro: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: When Paddling Is Just the Start
abstract: The techniques needed to keep a small boat moving forward are important, but an outrigger canoe instructor on Maui also teaches the ways of the waves.
lead_paragraph: Solomon Pali, 55, is the outrigger canoe instructor at the Fairmont Kea Lani Hotel on the island of Maui, Hawaii.

headline: Betsy DeVos Reverses Obama-era Policy on Campus Sexual Assault Investigations
abstract: The Education Department said colleges no longer had to use the lowest standard of proof, potentially giving accused students more protection while worrying some women’s advocates.
lead_paragraph: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos on Friday scrapped a key part of government policy on campus sexual assault, saying she was giving colleges more freedom to balance the rights of accused students with the need to crack down on serious misconduct.

headline: Catalonia Showdown Tests Spanish Leader’s Instinct for Survival
abstract: Critics of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy say he has overreached in dealing with Catalan separatists.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy is the great survivor of Spanish politics. He has withstood electoral defeats, a banking bailout and party corruption scandals, not by demonstrating political boldness but rather by being cautious and often waiting for others to fail.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Best Investment Since 1926? Apple
abstract: Apple has generated more wealth for shareholders than any other of the top 50 companies, which account for 40 percent of stock market wealth.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone helped to catapult Apple into its position as the world’s most valuable publicly traded company. But now Apple has another and, arguably, more exalted stock market distinction.

headline: Role Models for Women
abstract: A reader writes, “Today’s women need to get a grip and start finding their own inner resources.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Shattering Ugly Roma Stereotypes
abstract: There are places in Europe, like Slovakia and France, where people are finding ways to end historical discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Historically shunned and disparaged, targeted for liquidation by the Nazis during World War II, Europe’s 12 million Roma, sometimes called Gypsies, still suffer from social exclusion, poor education, high unemployment and poverty. The ugly stereotypes used to stigmatize them as socially backward have proved tenacious, yet there are places in Europe where people are finding ways to end this historical ugliness.

headline: We Charted Arctic Sea Ice for Nearly Every Day Since 1979. You’ll See a Trend.
abstract: Arctic sea ice has been in a steep decline since scientists started using satellites to measure it 40 years ago. And the 10 lowest ice extents have all been recorded since 2007.
lead_paragraph: Arctic sea ice has been in a steep decline since scientists started using satellites to measure it 40 years ago. And the 10 lowest ice extents have all been recorded since 2007.

headline: Thanks, Trump! Katy Tur Sees a Renaissance in Journalism
abstract: The NBC reporter, who has a best-selling campaign book with “Unbelievable,” says that the president’s scorn has “revitalized the fourth estate.”
lead_paragraph: THE TRUMP BEAT: Journalists, even on TV, tend to favor a sort of invisibility cloak, protected by the traditional veneer of impartiality and remove. They — or we, if book columnists count here — would probably agree with Karl Ove Knausgaard, who writes in Book 1 of “My Struggle” that “understanding the world requires you to take a certain distance from it.” But that’s not always possible, as the NBC reporter Katy Tur learned when she covered Donald Trump’s run for the presidency. In “Unbelievable,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 2, Tur looks back on the highs and lows of that campaign and describes how Trump frequently singled her out for attacks.

headline: Of God and War
abstract: Sarah Sentilles’s “Draw Your Weapons” ranges widely through issues of photographic representation, theology, empathy, activism and pacifism.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Sentilles was a doctoral student in theology at Harvard when the photos of prisoners being tortured at Abu Ghraib surfaced in 2004. As a religious scholar, Sentilles was fascinated by the way some of the images were compared to Crucifixion scenes. Her thoughts about the “theological strains” that run through “the intersection of religion and violence,” she told me, was the start of a long process that led to her unclassifiable new book, “Draw Your Weapons.”

headline: Bill Clinton’s Novel With James Patterson to Be Adapted for Showtime
abstract: Showtime has acquired the rights to “The President Is Missing,” the novel that the former president and the best-selling author are writing together.
lead_paragraph: Soon President Trump won’t be the only American president with TV ties. Showtime announced that it had acquired the rights to develop the novel being written by former President Bill Clinton and James Patterson, the best-selling author, into a series.

headline: The Design Companies Conquering New Ground
abstract: Three companies — two established, one emerging — move in new directions.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, Antonio Facco, a young graduate student studying design in Milan, had just presented his final project before a jury of professionals. One of them, the architect and furniture designer Giulio Cappellini, approached him. ‘‘We were waiting outside, and a door opened, and Giulio came out,’’ Facco recalled. ‘‘I saw that he was walking toward me, and in the moment I thought, ‘maybe he needs a lighter for a cigarette.’ ’’ Facco readied one. But Cappellini wasn’t looking for fire; he was looking for Facco, to whom he offered a job on the spot. And thus began a new collaboration, the latest in a long line for Cappellini, who has supported young talent since he joined his family’s forward-thinking Milan-based brand in 1979. Though Facco, who is now 25, started his own studio soon after graduating, he happily agreed to work with Cappellini, designing several of the brand’s most exciting pieces over the past few years, including a deceptively simple modular wooden coffee table, which cleverly contains four retractable cushioned seats.

headline: How To | Activate an Artwork
abstract: Per the artist's instructions, a french horn by the sculptor Darren Bader is used as a serving vessel for sauces – in this case, guacamole.
lead_paragraph: Per the artist's instructions, a french horn by the sculptor Darren Bader is used as a serving vessel for sauces – in this case, guacamole.

headline: S.E.C. Rules to Protect Investors From Cyberthreats Fall Short
abstract: Requiring exchanges to strengthen security systems was wise. In light of recent breaches, excluding big trading firms from the rule looks risky.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the hacking disclosed by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday didn’t seem too much of a concern to investors.

headline: What It’s Like to Live With Art That Doesn’t Love You Back
abstract: At a time when art is as commodified as oil, a few collectors have chosen to buy works that are messy, perishable and threaten to take over their lives.
lead_paragraph: PAUL LEONG, A YOUNG banker who lives in downtown Manhattan, spends an unusual amount of time thinking about square watermelons. He wonders where to get them, how long they’ll last, when they’ll next be in season. This is because two years ago, Leong bought a work by the Los Angeles-based artist Max Hooper Schneider called ‘‘Genus Watermeloncholia’’: a bioengineered square watermelon in a glass case filled with water. The watermelon is connected to an LED sign that is positioned so that it appears to be transmitting the watermelon’s depressive thoughts: ‘‘This is all a mistake,’’ for instance. Leong doesn’t quite know why he bought it, only that he was curious how the work might look in his apartment, with its sculpture of a miniature tank by Lutz Bacher mounted to seem as if it’s driving up the wall over the entrance to his bedroom, or Stefan Tcherepnin’s life-size Cookie Monster statue, which dominates the guest room.

headline: Technology Used to Track Players’ Steps Now Charts Their Sleep, Too
abstract: The wearable technologies that colleges use to track players’ performance on the field now can follow them everywhere, collecting even more data for programs to study.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — For a preseason scrimmage in August, the University of California football team tried to replicate the game day experience as best it could. It stayed in a hotel the night before. It scheduled the kickoff earlier than usual to acclimate to the time zone in which it would play its season opener at North Carolina. And it spent the whole week of practices tapering down.

headline: For Everyday Vegetable Dishes, Meera Sodha Is the Master
abstract: The British author is skilled in simplifying and modernizing the vibrancy of Indian home cooking, and in explaining just how to do it.
lead_paragraph: Maybe my mother and grandmother should have been the ones to teach me their repertory of satisfying vegetarian dishes from Gujarat, in western India. But they never measure or write anything down.

headline: A Third of the Three Tenors, José Carreras Exits on His Terms
abstract: Not just “the other guy,” Mr. Carreras reflects on Pavarotti, Domingo, his career and his brush with death as his final tour arrives at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: To many people whose knowledge of opera began and ended with the Three Tenors juggernaut, he was known, in the words of a memorable “Seinfeld” episode, as “the other guy”: the tenor who wasn’t Luciano Pavarotti or Plácido Domingo.

headline: The U.S. Still Leans on the Military-Industrial Complex
abstract: Weapons manufacturing is a big source of economic growth in the United States, where new factories are so automated that they create fewer jobs.
lead_paragraph: If you want to see what President Trump can do to expand manufacturing in America, look past his criticism of free trade and the few jobs he may have saved at Carrier. Instead, look at his plans for the military.

headline: ‘Lives Were Saved’ When Teacher Subdued Gunman at Illinois School
abstract: “It was the school employee who took this on,” the police said of Angela McQueen, who physically overwhelmed the suspect in a high school cafeteria.
lead_paragraph: When a student opened fire in the cafeteria of Mattoon High School in Illinois on Wednesday, the outcome could have been a lot worse had it not been for a teacher who physically subdued the gunman shortly after he began shooting, the police said.

headline: Quake Threatens to Cause Flight From Mexico City’s Hip Neighborhoods
abstract: Roma and Condesa were hit hard by the big 1985 quake and took years to rebound. Then came the devastation from the Tuesday earthquake.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When Fernando Bustos moved to Mexico City years ago, he had no doubt about where to live. The Roma and Condesa neighborhoods – sidewalk cafes, hip restaurants, thriving art and music, storied architecture – had captured his imagination.

headline: Hurricane Maria Live Updates: Structural Damage at Guajataca Dam Prompts Evacuations in Puerto Rico
abstract: A dam in northwestern Puerto Rico suffered structural damage on Friday, the governor said at a news conference, prompting evacuations of areas nearby in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: A dam in northwestern Puerto Rico suffered structural damage on Friday, the governor said at a news conference, prompting evacuations of areas nearby in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.

headline: ‘Please Offer Me a Seat,’ the Buttons Say. Subway Riders Aren’t Listening.
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is extending a pilot program encouraging riders to give their seats to the pregnant, older or disabled. Riders say it isn’t working.
lead_paragraph: The friendly woman who noticed Mary Alice Dadras’s rounded belly on the No. 2 train in Manhattan recently had lots of questions. When was the baby due? Oh, twins? Were they boys or girls?

headline: T’s Design & Luxury Issue: Editor’s Letter
abstract: Good design — like a good idea — is always relevant, and that context, while important, isn’t everything.
lead_paragraph: Of all the surprises that greet an American on her first trip abroad, the most transformative may be an understanding of how differently we conceive of time. ‘‘Old’’ in American terms is not old anywhere else. (‘‘This sketch was done in the 1800s,’’ I remember telling a Chinese college friend, awe-struck by the work’s provenance. ‘‘Oh,’’ she said, ‘‘so not too long ago.’’) We are a young country, and like most young entities — be they people or states — our internal metronome ticks a little faster; the land we inhabit may in fact be home to ancient civilizations, but America itself is new, with a sense of impatience, adventure, excitability and a cheerful lack of perspective (either charming or dangerous, depending on your point of view and the circumstances) that only the young possess. When you are immature, every bad thing can feel like a crisis, and every good thing like ecstasy; the rest of the world watches us with a sense of weariness and unflappability that is earned only after many centuries of witnessing governments and empires and civilizations and self-styled saviors rise, crescendo and tumble. The accretion of history is relentless, and endless.

headline: The U.S. and the Refugee Crisis
abstract: A human rights advocate says our allies are looking to us for solutions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Announcing Our Fall 2017 Webinar Calendar: Teaching With The Times Across the Curriculum
abstract: Four opportunities to hear from Times journalists, Learning Network staff and classroom teachers on ways to weave The Times into your curriculum.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Nov. 9, 2017

headline: Resolutions for the Big (and Small) Screens
abstract: Many online services now offer three levels of picture quality for videos, but be sure to choose the best one for your device.
lead_paragraph: Q. When it comes to streaming and downloading movies, do you really notice that much of a difference between standard definition and the high-definition version?

headline: After Maria and Irma: Caribbean Tourism, Island by Island
abstract: In the wake of two powerful hurricanes, a look at the damage, bright spots and the uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: After two major hurricanes tore through the Caribbean in less than two weeks, some of the most idyllic — and tourism-dependent — destinations have been devastated.

headline: The Inside Story of Donatella Versace’s Homage to Gianni: Classic Prints and Your Favorite ’90s Supermodels
abstract: Twenty years after her brother’s murder, the designer produces a tribute show including Cindy Crawford, Claudia Schiffer, Helena Christensen, Naomi Campbell and Carla Bruni. Plus, a tease about what’s next.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — When she began creating her Tribute collection, an ode to the work of her brother, Gianni Versace, that would become her spring women’s wear show, Donatella Versace knew what people were going to think. Not of the clothes; of the rationale behind the clothes.

headline: Review: 3-D Enhances an Enigmatic New Opera
abstract: Michel van der Aa’s “Blank Out” mingles stage action and video projection, live music-making and recorded performance, poetry and original text.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch composer Michel van der Aa proves a master of allusion in his chamber opera “Blank Out,” which received its North American premiere at the Park Avenue Armory on Thursday evening.

headline: Creating Test for Trump, Panel Says Imported Solar Gear Hurts U.S. Firms
abstract: The decision may give President Trump a chance to use protectionist measures against imported solar equipment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A flood of imported solar equipment has seriously hurt American companies, the International Trade Commission ruled on Friday, setting up a major test of President Trump’s willingness to use the protectionist measures he endorsed during the campaign.

headline: Israel Endorsed Kurdish Independence. Saladin Would Have Been Proud.
abstract: Present-day politics may have been less important than a long shared history between the Kurds and the Jews.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With a two-sentence statement supporting the Iraqi Kurds’ plan to hold a referendum on independence this Monday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu put Israel at odds with nearly every other major player in the Middle East.

headline: Can Prep Schools Fight the Class War?
abstract: Trinity School’s headmaster sends shock waves through the city’s private-school world calling out insidious parental entitlement and self-interest.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month Princeton University Press published a book called “Uneasy Street: The Anxieties of Affluence,” by a sociologist, Rachel Sherman, who researched the spending habits of 50 well-to-do parents in New York City, and diagnosed a pervasive problem of reticence around wealth. Ms. Sherman uses her encounters with people who agreed to speak with her, in many cases about their fears of seeming showy, to conclude that there is too much silence around money and that all of this alleged hush and professed shame ultimately slow our efforts to mitigate inequality.

headline: Behind New Obamacare Repeal Vote: ‘Furious’ G.O.P. Donors
abstract: Donations to the party are down, and Senator Cory Gardner warned his colleagues that they have to show some results.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As more than 40 subdued Republican senators lunched on Chick-fil-A at a closed-door session last week, Senator Cory Gardner of Colorado painted a dire picture for his colleagues. Campaign fund-raising was drying up, he said, because of widespread disappointment among donors over the inability of the Republican Senate to repeal the Affordable Care Act or do much of anything else.

headline: A Big College Sports Business Is About to Get Bigger
abstract: If Learfield merges with IMG College, it will command near total control over the niche but lucrative market of college sports multimedia rights.
lead_paragraph: Learfield Communications was a farm radio network that stumbled into college sports when it began distributing radio rights for the University of Missouri in 1975. In a role largely invisible to fans, it proceeded to all but invent the industry of selling radio broadcasts, corporate sponsorships and in-stadium signage.

headline: Under Mayor de Blasio, City Vehicles Rack Up Miles
abstract: New York City employees are driving more on the job, an increase that critics say contradicts environmental and safety goals of Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: If it seems like traffic in New York City might be a bit worse than before, there may be an unexpected factor: city workers.

headline: Spain and Catalonia Wrestle Over .Cat Internet Domain
abstract: Secessionists. A government raid. Censorship. Cats. The internet. Naturally we were curious.
lead_paragraph: On the same day this week that the Spanish authorities stormed the offices of the Catalan regional government, detaining at least 14 people, a less-noticed raid took place.

headline: Review: Making Eloquent Theater From Bleak Facts
abstract: Dorothée Munyaneza’s “Unwanted” takes testimony of political rape victims as the basis for a multilayered drama of music, speech and dance.
lead_paragraph: How to convert acts of mass horror into live performance? In spoken theater, the oral testimony of victims, witnesses, even perpetrators, has been adapted into memorable docudramas about war crimes, genocide and other forms of social and political violence. The appalling nature of the events described has often been all the more effective when the actors speak the words in a contrastingly low-key manner.

headline: Do You Live in London? Share Your Views on Uber
abstract: What would London without Uber look like? We want to hear from those in London about their experience, including those who work, or have worked, for Uber.
lead_paragraph: What would London without Uber look like? We want to hear from those in London about their experience, including those who work, or have worked, for Uber.

headline: Expecting a Baby? What to Cook and Freeze Now So You Won’t Go Hungry Later
abstract: With a little advance planning, you can stock your freezer with a couple weeks’ worth of meals.
lead_paragraph: When you’re the exhausted parent of a newborn, you may find yourself relying on takeout and trail mix for sustenance. That gets old fast.

headline: Why the Equifax Breach Stings So Bad
abstract: The credit reporting agency and its counterparts, Experian and TransUnion, deploy withering judgment, trap us in systems we can’t escape and scare us. It’s time for a radical reboot.
lead_paragraph: Among the 2,000 or so enraged messages that I received after the most recent Equifax data breach, the wish that came up most often was that Richard F. Smith, the company’s chief executive, be pushed out the door.

headline: Marco De Vincenzo: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Let Right-Wing Speakers Come to Berkeley? Faculty Is Divided
abstract: Students looking to the faculty and administration for guidance on how to interpret the free speech issue are seeing deep divisions among their leaders.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The class is called symplectic geometry, a high-level course in mathematics that provides elite graduate students at the University of California, Berkeley, a better understanding of, among other things, planetary motion.

headline: McCain Announces Opposition to Republican Health Bill, Likely Dooming It
abstract: Senator John McCain released a statement saying he would oppose the latest proposal, by Senators Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Bill Cassidy of Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain of Arizona announced on Friday that he would oppose the latest proposal to repeal the Affordable Care Act, leaving Republican leaders with little hope of succeeding in their last-ditch attempt to dismantle the health law and fulfill their longstanding promise to conservative voters.

headline: Immigration Officers Won’t Get Guest Lists Anymore, Motel 6 Says
abstract: After the detention and deportation of guests, the company has made it policy to not give information out to law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Motel 6, one of the largest hotel chains in the United States, has introduced a policy forbidding its locations from sharing information on its guests with law enforcement unless they are compelled to.

headline: Minnesota Videographers Said They Don’t Have to Film Gay Weddings. A Judge Disagreed.
abstract: A judge dismissed the lawsuit, ruling that a media production company’s plan to refuse service would be akin to posting a sign that said “White Applicants Only.”
lead_paragraph: Angel and Carl Larsen, a Minnesota couple, had plans to expand their media production business into the lucrative wedding market. But not all weddings. The couple wanted to post a statement on their website saying they would not make films celebrating same-sex marriages, court documents said.

headline: Racial Incidents at Cornell: A Mother’s Outrage
abstract: A Cornell parent calls for change in the Greek system.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Playlist: A Farewell From Leonard Cohen and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear the week's most notable tracks from Noah Cyrus, Angel Olsen, Weaves and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Noah Cyrus teams up with a rapper embroiled in controversy, Angel Olsen reveals a song from an upcoming album of rarities and Sweet Pea Atkinson gives us a taste of his first solo album in 35 years.

headline: Taunts by Trump and Kim Jong-un
abstract: A reader warns against the bellicose talk.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 3: Watched It All? Let’s Talk
abstract: From the season’s first episode, the obvious question has been: Could the series lose Pablo Escobar and still be the same show?
lead_paragraph: Setting aside the “Goodfellas” narration, the earliest episodes of “Narcos” were distinguished by a meat-and-potatoes approach to the crime genre that rebuffed the slickness that usually comes with the territory.

headline: Daniel Yankelovich, Master of Public Opinion Research, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Yankelovich demonstrated that psychology, sociology and statistical analysis could be harnessed in the service of business, government and the masses.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Yankelovich, the pollster, author and public opinion analyst who for a half-century mirrored the perceptions of generations of Americans about politics, consumer products, social changes and, not least, themselves, died on Friday morning at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 92.

headline: The HPV Vaccine Gains Ground Among U.S. Teenagers
abstract: Sixty percent of adolescents received the vaccine in 2016. A decade ago, less than 30 percent did.
lead_paragraph: More than half of all American teenagers are getting vaccinated against human papillomavirus, and the rate is rising over time, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Attempts to Repeal Obamacare
abstract: An Alabama pediatrician calls the bill “heinous”; another writer says giving states more power over health care is misguided.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Protesters Interrupt Comey Speech at Howard
abstract: James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, was interrupted by demonstrators at Howard University on Friday.
lead_paragraph: James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, was interrupted by demonstrators at Howard University on Friday.

headline: Versace: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Do Women Get to Write With Authority?
abstract: Working from a man’s perspective allowed me to wriggle free of certain expectations.
lead_paragraph: On forms to be filled out in waiting rooms, I always hesitate over the question of occupation: writer or author? For years it was only writer; now it’s a question of mood. Writer forever has her work ahead of her. Author has already done it. Writer bears no great claim: Like anyone else, she is just scrabbling away at it, unsure, experimenting. Author comes with distinction, and the right to expect that she will be read. Now, though, I think the perceived honor of the word is wrapped up in “author” sounding like a chip off the granite block of authority.

headline: James Comey Is Interrupted by Protesters During Speech at Howard
abstract: James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, exhorted his audience to “listen with an attitude that they might actually be convinced of something.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James. B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, was met with raised fists and chants of “no justice, no peace” by protesters on Friday as he delivered the keynote address at Howard University’s convocation, marking a rocky re-emergence into public life since he was fired by President Trump in May.

headline: Ciudad de México fue construida sobre un antiguo sedimento lacustre. Eso hace que los terremotos sean peores.
abstract: El sismo del 19 de septiembre fue tan destructivo debido a la inusual ubicación de Ciudad de México sobre el lecho del que antes fuera un lago.
lead_paragraph: El sismo del 19 de septiembre fue tan destructivo debido a la inusual ubicación de Ciudad de México sobre el lecho del que antes fuera un lago.

headline: Four Rules for the Coming Tax Reform Debate
abstract: What must happen so that poor and middle-class families don’t end up paying for tax cuts for the rich.
lead_paragraph: Next week, Trump administration officials and leading Republicans in Congress are expected to unveil a new framework on tax reform. At the same time, Republicans are coming to the end of a last-ditch, likely doomed, effort to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Back-and-Forth on DACA Leaves Young Immigrants ‘Just Dangling’
abstract: The whiplash of emotions surrounding the future of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program has many young immigrants saying they feel helpless.
lead_paragraph: Violeta Gomez-Uribe, 32, goes to kickboxing classes in Brooklyn. Eduardo Garcia, 22, lifts weights at the gym, in between classes and two jobs. Apolinar Islas, 34, who came to New York from Mexico when he was 15, said he walks around in “zombie mode” and tries to stay off social media to avoid “the tsunami of confusion.”

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.

headline: Canada Letter: Health Care Comparisons and an NYT Offer
abstract: Our weekly look for and about Canadians, Canada Letter, explores medical wait times, visits the Yukon and remembers a political mastermind.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Canada Letter includes observations from the Yukon and a ticket offer for Times subscribers. But first we have an exclusive item for readers of this newsletter from our colleagues at The Upshot, the group at The Times that examines the world through data.

headline: Pete Turner, Whose Color Photography Could Alter Reality, Dies at 83
abstract: With saturated colors, often on global assignments, Mr. Turner created spectacular images, some for the covers of record albums.
lead_paragraph: When the photographer Pete Turner was on assignment in Amboseli National Park in Kenya in 1964, a lone giraffe galloped across the empty plain before him, and he captured it in all its solitude, its neck rising above the horizon.

headline: Rutgers Failed to Monitor Football Program, N.C.A.A. Finds
abstract: The N.C.A.A. faulted the university and the former coach Kyle Flood for violations related to recruiting and drug testing.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. punished Rutgers for what it characterized in a ruling Friday as a failure to monitor its football program over a five-year period during which the former head coach and the program flouted N.C.A.A. and university rules related to recruiting and drug-testing.

headline: Rare Necklaces and Rings Are Items to Appreciate. Just Ask Investors.
abstract: Jewelry with the most investment potential has a level of craftsmanship plus scarcity that makes it stand out from other baubles.
lead_paragraph: Diamonds, as the song says, are a girl’s best friend. But certain diamond jewelry — like rings, bracelets and earrings — can be a great investment.

headline: In Battle Over Tax Cuts, It’s Republicans vs. Economists
abstract: Republican leaders reject criticism that their tax plan will add to the deficit. And they are determined to secure economic assessments proving their optimistic assumptions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican lawmakers are gearing up to battle a powerful force in the coming skirmish over a $1.5 trillion tax cut: Economists.

headline: Bye, Bro. In Country Music, It’s the Year of the Gentleman.
abstract: Nashville has been undergoing a gender crisis for most of the 2010s. Is the latest development — kinder men — a solution? A discussion, on Popcast.
lead_paragraph: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Solving Staten Island’s Deer Problem With a Snip and a Stitch
abstract: An experiment to control the borough’s booming deer population through vasectomies is said to be the first of its kind in the nation.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet patch of thorny wineberry bushes on Staten Island, a white-tailed deer snored loudly, oblivious to the team of humans gathered around him.

headline: World Health Officials Describe Progress Against Tetanus, H.I.V. and Malaria
abstract: Tetanus in babies has been eliminated from the Americas, experts said. Malaria treatment will be expanded in Africa; new HIV drugs will be available there, too.
lead_paragraph: Infant and maternal tetanus was officially eliminated from the Americas this year, the Pan American Health Organization announced on Thursday.

headline: Bolshoi Sets ‘Nureyev’ Ballet for December Despite Director’s Arrest
abstract: A production based on the life of Rudolf Nureyev, who died in 1993 from AIDS-related illnesses, will go forward after being postponed in July.
lead_paragraph: The Bolshoi Theater is going ahead with a ballet based on the life of legendary dancer Rudolf Nureyev this December, its general director said on Friday. The ballet, originally scheduled to premiere in July, was postponed three days before its opening, while its director, Kirill S. Serebrennikov, was charged with embezzling government funds and placed under house arrest.

headline: Make Your Makeup Routine Easier, Better and Faster
abstract: Bee Shapiro, Skin Deep columnist, is answering your questions about everyday makeup.
lead_paragraph: Bee Shapiro, Skin Deep columnist, is answering your questions about everyday makeup.

headline: Solving the Puzzle of Eggplant Parmesan
abstract: The answer: Slice the eggplant tempura-style, fan it out and then fry it whole.
lead_paragraph: “No dish has ever been devised that tastes more satisfyingly of summer,” Marcella Hazan wrote of eggplant Parmesan in her definitive (and assertive) cookbook, “Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking.” (I might argue that if she’d never been to a clambake or a crab boil, just this once she might have been wrong.)

headline: How to Have a Better Relationship
abstract: Tara Parker-Pope answered your questions about love and relationships.
lead_paragraph: Tara Parker-Pope answered your questions about love and relationships.

headline: How to Jump-Start Your Career
abstract: Adam Bryant, the Corner Office columnist, took questions about how to get your career moving in the right direction.
lead_paragraph: Adam Bryant, the Corner Office columnist, took questions about how to get your career moving in the right direction.

headline: Knicks Get Ready for Training Camp, Carmelo Anthony Included
abstract: Although Anthony would like to be traded, and the Knicks would be happy to oblige, no trade seems close. For now, he is still here.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Steve Mills, Scott Perry and Jeff Hornacek sat next to one another at a news conference on Friday morning, presenting a united front of top decision-makers as the Knicks prepared for the start of training camp next week.

headline: So Many People Want to See the Tommies and the Johnnies
abstract: A record crowd of more than 35,000 is expected for Saturday’s football game between the Minnesota rivals St. John’s and St. Thomas at the Twins’ ballpark.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Three thousand miles apart on opposite coasts, a former White House chief of staff and the co-owner of the San Diego Padres will be keeping tabs Saturday on an important football game in their home state of Minnesota. It does not involve the University of Minnesota’s Golden Gophers, who are off, or the N.F.L.’s Minnesota Vikings, who don’t play until Sunday.

headline: Johnny Sandlin, 72, Allman Brothers Band Producer, Is Dead
abstract: A onetime band mate of Duane and Gregg Allman, Mr. Sandlin worked with their band and many other artists in a career that began at Capricorn Records.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Sandlin, a record producer, engineer and session musician best known for his work with  the Allman Brothers Band, died on Tuesday in Decatur, Ala. He was 72.

headline: Rising Star: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
abstract: Verdi, a young American composer and Bach on marimba were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what’s delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: A Walk Through Dominica, Hours After Hurricane Maria
abstract: On the morning after Hurricane Maria hit Dominica, a resident surveyed the devastation in the island’s capital, Roseau.
lead_paragraph: On the morning after Hurricane Maria hit Dominica, a resident surveyed the devastation in the island’s capital, Roseau.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Anna Dubenko, Max Fisher and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Sputnik for Sale, if You’ll Settle for a Beeping Replica
abstract: Just ahead of the 60th anniversary of the first Earth launch of a satellite, an auction house will take bids on a replica of the shiny Soviet spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: This could be your chance to make Sputnik beep again.

headline: Holocaust Denier’s Sentence: Visit 5 Ex-Nazi Camps, and Write About It
abstract: A judge ordered Laurent Louis, a far-right former lawmaker in Belgium, to visit a concentration camp every year for five years and write about his experience.
lead_paragraph: A former lawmaker in Belgium convicted of Holocaust denial in 2015 was handed an unusual sentence this week: The Brussels Court of Appeal ordered him to visit one Nazi concentration camp a year for the next five years and write about his experiences, according to the former lawmaker and local news reports.

headline: Russia Says ‘Small-Hearted’ Obama Administration Spoiled Ties
abstract: Speaking at the United Nations, Russia’s foreign minister said Obama administration policies hurt relations between Washington and Moscow, with effects still felt worldwide.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Russia’s top diplomat said Friday that the Obama administration had been “small-hearted” and vindictive toward his country, spoiling relations and jeopardizing cooperation on critical issues including the Syria conflict.

headline: Earthquake Warning System
abstract: An early warning could give advanced warning to people living several miles from the epicenter of an earthquake along the San Andreas fault line.
lead_paragraph: An early warning could give advanced warning to people living several miles from the epicenter of an earthquake along the San Andreas fault line.

headline: Mexico Has Some Earthquake Lessons for the United States
abstract: Several countries, including Mexico and Japan, have far better warning systems than the United States.
lead_paragraph: People cannot prevent earthquakes, but they can take steps to minimize the deaths and damage. Many more might have died in Mexico City this week had the country not invested in an early warning system that rang alarms just before the catastrophic earthquake struck. The United States, which has been slow to finish a similar system on the West Coast, can learn from Mexico’s example.

headline: Syrian Activist and Her Daughter Are Fatally Stabbed in Turkey
abstract: Orouba Barakat and her daughter, Halla, were attacked in their apartment, and relatives blame the Syrian government for their deaths.
