lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A Syrian activist and her daughter, a journalist, have been found murdered in their apartment in Istanbul, family and friends reported on social media Friday.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
abstract: Milan Fashion Week kicks off, the man who dresses Melania Trump — and more.
lead_paragraph: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Marian Horosko, Dancer and Advocate for the Art, Dies at 92
abstract: After a performing career that included eight years with New York City Ballet, Ms. Horosko wrote books and championed the health and other needs of dancers.
lead_paragraph: Marian Horosko, a ballet dancer who became both an advocate for the art form and a historian of it, writing books on Martha Graham and May O’Donnell as well as practical guides, died on Sept. 11 in the Bronx. She was 92.

headline: Riccardo Tisci on the Joys of Time Off — and How to Throw a Great Party
abstract: The former Givenchy designer sat down with T on the eve of a party he is throwing for Italian Vogue, inspired by Dante’s “Divine Comedy.”
lead_paragraph: Perched on the top rail of a church pew, Riccardo Tisci surveys his domain. The designer, who left Givenchy in January on friendly terms after a successful 12-year run at the house, is surrounded by row after row of wooden pews, which sit below carnivalesque luminaria lights — the kind you usually see in the street festivals in southern Italy.

headline: Republican Party, North Korea, Hurricane Maria: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In a Playoff Hunt, the Angels Owe a Debt to the Yankees’ Gene Michael
abstract: Billy Eppler, the general manager of the Angels, worked 11 seasons with the Yankees and learned a lot from Michael, who died this month.
lead_paragraph: In the heat of his first pennant race as a general manager, Billy Eppler flew across the country to attend the funeral of Gene Michael in Florida on Wednesday. Eppler, who has run the baseball operations of the Los Angeles Angels since October 2015, spent 11 seasons in the Yankees’ front office learning from Michael, a top scout and adviser to General Manager Brian Cashman. He has tried to bring some of Michael’s core principles to the Angels.

headline: On Russian Meddling, Mark Zuckerberg Follows a Familiar Playbook
abstract: Mr. Zuckerberg’s modus operandi as a leader is to fix things long after they have broken, rather than to prevent problems in the first place.
lead_paragraph: I knew the big Mark Zuckerberg speech was coming. It always does.

headline: 5 Styling Tips From London Fashion Week
abstract: Here, styling tips inspired by the runways with new ways to wear things — some of which you probably already own.
lead_paragraph: Cardigans are surprisingly versatile: They can be worn buttoned or open, slung over the shoulders or tied around the waist. While they have connotations of being prim and proper, this season they were anything but. At Erdem, cardigans were styled like capes, with the top button fastened and draped over the shoulders. Just twist it off-center and voilà, you have a chic new way to wear sweaters over dresses, T-shirts or button-downs.

headline: PwC, the Accounting Giant, Will Open a Law Firm in the U.S.
abstract: The company formerly known as PricewaterhouseCoopers sees one-stop access to its services as a way to attract multinational businesses based in America.
lead_paragraph: Law firms already elbowing one another for multinational clients will soon have a new competitor: The Big Four accounting firm PwC, formerly known as PricewaterhouseCoopers, plans to open a law firm in Washington, D.C., next week.

headline: An Exhibition? Yes. Of Talent, and Tension, and Tiebreakers.
abstract: “People were questioning if this is going to be an exhibition,” Marin Cilic said after Europe swept to a 3-0 lead at the Laver Cup, “but for none of us this is exhibition.”
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — After a clean sweep of the first-day singles matches by Team Europe on Friday, “exhibition” was still a dirty word at the Laver Cup.

headline: Manslaughter Charge Dismissed Against Son of Ex-City Hall Aide
abstract: Lawyers for Khari Noerdlinger, the son of Chirlane McCray’s former chief of staff, accused a prosecutor and detective of lying to a grand jury and withholding evidence.
lead_paragraph: HACKENSACK, N.J. — A string of damaging personal revelations forced Rachel Noerdlinger to step aside in 2014 as the chief of staff to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray. But as she tried to reestablish herself in the private sector, she was hit with another personal crisis early last year when, her son was arrested in New Jersey and accused of fatally stabbing a teenager.

headline: Three Ways the New Republican Health Bill Differs From Past Repeal Efforts
abstract: A comparison of the Cassidy-Graham measure with four other bills that failed in Congress.
lead_paragraph: A comparison of the Cassidy-Graham measure with four other bills that failed in Congress.

headline: Nafta Negotiators Wading Into Tougher Territory in Third Round of Trade Talks
abstract: The United States, Canada and Mexico are wading into murkier waters this weekend as they push ahead with renegotiating Nafta.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has spent months pummeling the North American Free Trade Agreement, calling the trade pact a “disaster” and insisting that it cost American jobs. Now, United States trade negotiators will have to decide how tough to get on their Nafta counterparts.

headline: Tom Price’s Entitlement Spending
abstract: Taxpayers have spent $300,000 to treat the health secretary’s apparent allergy to flying commercial.
lead_paragraph: Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, is a longtime proponent of slashing entitlements. He might consider starting with his own.

headline: The Real Story Behind Roald Dahl’s ‘Black Charlie’
abstract: The author’s early draft of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” featured a black protagonist who gets trapped inside a chocolate mold. Was it racial stereotyping, or something more complicated?
lead_paragraph: Last week, Roald Dahl’s widow, Felicity Dahl, told the BBC that the children’s author had written an early draft of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” in which Charlie Bucket was black. Mrs. Dahl called it “a shame” that his agent persuaded her husband to make Charlie white. But what was in the draft, called “Charlie’s Chocolate Boy”? Catherine Keyser, an associate professor of English at the University of South Carolina who has written about “Charlie’s Chocolate Boy,” spoke with Maria Russo about that discarded version of the classic story.

headline: Engaged Tennis Players Prefer to Be on the Same Side of the Net
abstract: Tara Moore and Conny Perrin are believed to be the first players on the WTA tour to be engaged to one another. They have had to play against each other only once.
lead_paragraph: The first time Tara Moore and Conny Perrin attempted a relationship, it ended in a split.

headline: Legal Hurdles Could Hamper Suit Against N.F.L. in Aaron Hernandez Case
abstract: The league has resisted settlements and considers the player, who was found to have severe C.T.E., an unsympathetic case.
lead_paragraph: When Aaron Hernandez, the former New England Patriots tight end, was convicted in 2015 of murdering a friend of his, questions arose: Did his years of butting heads on the football field contribute to his violent behavior off the field? And when he killed himself, in April, new questions were asked: Did football play a role in his suicide?

headline: Yes, Aaron Hernandez Suffered Brain Injury. But That May Not Explain His Violence.
abstract: The links between biology and behavior are complex, and a number of factors contribute to violence. Yet evidence is mounting that C.T.E. may be involved.
lead_paragraph: The brain damage was so severe that scientists all but gasped.

headline: Malliotakis Qualifies for Debate and Matching Funds in Mayoral Race
abstract: Nicole Malliotakis, the Republican candidate for mayor of New York City, met critical fund-raising thresholds in the latest reporting period.
lead_paragraph: Republican mayoral candidate Nicole Malliotakis hit a pair of important fund-raising milestones this week, as her campaign reported that it has raised enough money to qualify for the first general election debate against Mayor Bill de Blasio, and that it has also taken in enough qualifying contributions to begin receiving public financing through the city’s generous matching funds program.

headline: Myrna Lamb, Feminist Playwright in an Unwelcoming Era, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Lamb’s works, staged at the Public Theater and elsewhere, often came under attack from male critics.
lead_paragraph: Myrna Lamb, a playwright who put the tenets of second-wave feminism in front of theatergoers in provocative works that were staged at the Public Theater in Manhattan and elsewhere, died on Sept. 15 in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J. She was 87.

headline: Ritha Devi, Indian Classical Dancer and Teacher, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. Devi was a specialist in the Odissi form of dance, a once-neglected style that she helped popularize in America in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Ritha Devi, a performer and teacher who presented Indian classical dance to American audiences with poetic beauty, died on Sept. 12 in Pune, India. She was 92.

headline: Scaramucci and Spicer Extend Their White House 15 Minutes of Fame
abstract: In the Trump era, tradition of post-White House exposure and opportunities appears to be alive and well.
lead_paragraph: As former White House officials continue to haunt Washington, Anthony Scaramucci is enjoying his political afterlife far beyond the capital.

headline: Prospect of Atmospheric Nuclear Test by North Korea Raises Specter of Danger
abstract: Stopping Kim Jong-un from conducting a nuclear test over the Pacific may be as dangerous as letting him go ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If North Korea follows through on its threat to conduct an atmospheric nuclear test, it would be a far more dangerous step than anything Kim Jong-un, its leader, has attempted — and poses a host of hard decisions for the Trump administration because attempting to stop the test could be as dangerous as letting it go ahead.

headline: Berkeley Students Speak Out About Free Speech
abstract: We asked students what free speech means to them, and about the mood on campus ahead of a series of speeches planned for next week.
lead_paragraph: The University of California, Berkeley, has been at the center of the debate over free speech taking place on campuses across the country in recent months. The faculty is divided about how to interpret the First Amendment. Many students, too, feel conflicted.

headline: In Beijing and Abu Dhabi, Signs of Bannon’s Continued Influence
abstract: Meetings with powerful foreigners — including the crown prince of the United Arab Emirates — signal that President Trump’s former strategist still holds global interest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon met privately with a top Chinese government official and a key leader in the Persian Gulf during a recent trip to Asia and the Middle East, demonstrating that President Trump’s former chief strategist is still viewed as an influential figure abroad.

headline: The Great and Immortal French ‘Bof’
abstract: It is useful to look at Trump’s apocalyptic leanings through this different lens.
lead_paragraph: Oh, the eternal consolations of France, how satisfying they are. I am always happy when I am reminded of them.

headline: Jesmyn Ward on ‘Sing, Unburied, Sing’
abstract: Ward discusses her new novel; David Dobbs on five new books about Darwin; and Kristin Cashore talks about “Jane, Unlimited.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Todd Frazier Talks With Father of the Girl Hit by His Foul Ball
abstract: The Yankees third baseman said he had been told that the girl was doing well in a hospital. He also said he hoped to meet her soon.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Yankees third baseman Todd Frazier, who hit the foul ball that struck a young girl in the face at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday afternoon, said he spoke to the girl’s father on Thursday and had been told that she was recovering well in a hospital.

headline: Are Physical Limits All in Our Heads?
abstract: The Berlin marathon will test the primacy of mind over body in sports.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning in Berlin, three of the greatest marathoners in history will face off under highly intriguing and unusual conditions. It will be a race for the ages, pitting the reigning Olympic champion against a former world-record holder and perhaps the best all-around long-distance runner ever. Bookmakers are putting the odds of a new world marathon record at greater than 60 percent.

headline: Morgan Freeman Angers Russians Over Video About 2016 Election
abstract: A Russian news outlet called the actor an “American propaganda loudspeaker” after he appeared in a video accusing Russia of undermining last year’s election.
lead_paragraph: The investigation into Russian meddling during the 2016 presidential election features a cast of what by now are household names: Donald J. Trump, Vladimir V. Putin, Paul J. Manafort and Robert S. Mueller III.

headline: Sandy Alderson Is Eager to Return and Solve the Mets’ Injury Riddle
abstract: The Mets have not announced a new contract for the general manager, but it is widely believed that he will return.
lead_paragraph: We know the end date for the long-running medical drama known as the Mets’ 2017 season. On Oct. 1 — just a week from Sunday! — it will finally, mercifully, be over. Expect the show’s creator to be the one who tweaks the next script.

headline: Fans Expect Access to Players, but Do They Really Want to Listen?
abstract: The benefit of time and patience often rewards us with the true significance of an athlete’s activism.
lead_paragraph: I have had a direct view of the changing way we digest sports and its news over the past 25 years. After nearly a decade in Major League Baseball as a player, I wrote extensively about life in and around the game, culminating with seven years on air at ESPN. One theme that was stressed as critical to my role as a sports analyst was the importance of access.

headline: In a Puerto Rican Town, ‘Water Came Out of Nowhere’
abstract: In the hard-hit town of Toa Baja, Hurricane Maria’s wrath swept some residents to their deaths.
lead_paragraph: TOA BAJA, P.R. — Everywhere they looked there was water. It swept in from the ocean to the north. And it surged toward them from overflowing rivers to the south. Hurricane Maria’s wrath left residents in this coastal town trapped by water.

headline: Facebook’s Belated Awakening
abstract: As social media companies wield greater power in the political system, more safeguards are needed.
lead_paragraph: Chastened by criticism that Facebook had turned a blind eye to Russia’s manipulation of the social network to interfere in the 2016 election, the company’s executives now acknowledge a need to do better and have promised to be more transparent about who is paying for political ads. That’s a good start, but more is required — of Facebook, of social media giants generally and of Congress.

headline: Give Cancer Patients a Break on Student Loans
abstract: Making payments while sick is overwhelming. A piece of bipartisan legislation could change that.
lead_paragraph: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has recently drawn criticism for proposing a long list of cuts to higher education programs. Congress must mull those potentially traumatic trims while reauthorizing standard financing for students and colleges, but there’s one positive change that might sneak by in the process: the bipartisan Deferment for Active Cancer Treatment Act, which would let borrowers defer their student loan payments when they get a cancer diagnosis — and for six more months after their active treatment is completed. It’s a courtesy Congress extends now to borrowers who are unemployed, deployed in the military or volunteering with the Peace Corps.

headline: How Vietnam Killed the Great Society
abstract: By the fall of 1967, Lyndon Johnson had finally realized that he could not fund guns and butter.
lead_paragraph: President Lyndon Johnson surely felt a bitter sense of recognition when he opened The Washington Post on Aug. 1, 1967. There, on Page A12, appeared a political cartoon — the latest by the brilliant cartoonist Herbert Block, better known as Herblock. The sketch showed a beleaguered Johnson flanked by two female suitors. To his right stood a voluptuous seductress bedecked with jewels and a mink stole bearing the words “Vietnam War.” To his left was a scrawny, disheveled waif labeled “U.S. Urban Needs.” The Johnson figure reassured them, “There’s money enough to support both of you,” but readers could hardly fail to grasp the president’s hesitation. The cartoon left no doubt that the flow of resources toward Vietnam might starve Johnson’s domestic agenda.

headline: How Parks Lose Their Playfulness
abstract: When cities rely on private donors, we end up with sterile, controlled environments.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the Hudson River Park Trust floated an idea for a new island. Called Pier 55, it was to be a two-and-a-half-acre wavy rectangle 200 feet off Manhattan reached by two narrow bridges, replacing the remains of Pier 54 near West 14th Street, where the Lusitania used to dock.

headline: Is C.T.E. a Defense for Murder?
abstract: Had his lawyers known of his brain disease, the football star Aaron Hernandez might have been able to use it as a defense for killing a friend.
lead_paragraph: This week, we learned that Aaron Hernandez, a former star tight end for the New England Patriots and convicted murderer, had a severe form of the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy. His mood swings, violent tendencies and memory loss almost certainly resulted from thousands of hits on the football field. Mr. Hernandez’s disease was the worst case doctors had seen in someone so young, his lawyer said.

headline: Facing Months in the Dark, Ordinary Life in Puerto Rico Is ‘Beyond Reach’
abstract: In the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, Puerto Ricans were contemplating empty refrigerators, campfire cooking and perhaps wrangling for fresh water.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Two days after Hurricane Maria flattened this island of 3.5 million people, knocking out all its power and much of its water, the rebuilding of the services and structures needed for people to resume some semblance of ordinary life was looking more complicated by the day.

headline: White House Weighs Response to North Korea’s Threats
abstract: The war of words between President Trump and Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, raised concerns on Friday that it could escalate into a new and more volatile phase.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The war of words between President Trump and Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, raised concerns on Friday that it could escalate into a new and more volatile phase as the White House weighed its next steps in response to a threat by Pyongyang to conduct the world’s first atmospheric nuclear test in 37 years.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Dictator’s Reply Turns Personal
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 23, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “The way North Korea’s supreme leadership works, Kim Jong-un has to respond moreassertively as its enemy gets more confrontational, like Trump has. There is no backing down in the North Korean rule book.”

headline: Facebook Drops Stock Move That Would Have Solidified Zuckerberg’s Control
abstract: The social network’s board withdrew a stock reclassification proposal after a shareholder suit that would have put Mr. Zuckerberg in a courtroom.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said Friday that it would drop a proposed reclassification of its stock that would have solidified Mark Zuckerberg’s control over the social network, in a victory for shareholders in a class-action lawsuit against the social giant.

headline: That Queasy Feeling Down Under
abstract: An erratic U.S. president can do a lot of damage in four or eight years.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Donald Trump long ago named his ambassadors to the Bahamas (the political donor Doug Manchester) and the Vatican (the political spouse Callista Gingrich). So on a trip the other day to Canberra, I asked whether the American president had nominated an emissary to this important if sleepy capital.

headline: Mexico City’s People Power
abstract: A grass-roots political reaction to the devastating earthquake is already underway.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When the earthquake rattled this mountain capital on Tuesday, a five-story office and apartment block round the corner from my home collapsed into a mountain of rubble, burying computer programmers, salesmen, secretaries. Right away, a handful of neighbors approached the wreckage, calling to see if anyone was alive and removing debris. Within hours, the group had swelled into the hundreds, joined by volunteers from across the city arriving by foot, truck and bicycle.

headline: Redhead of Hogwarts
abstract: Robyn Weintraub moves to Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The differences between Friday and Saturday puzzles are not always obvious. Because they’re normally themeless, knowing one or two answers may make a huge difference in any one solver’s experience.

headline: Review: ‘KPOP’ Sings and Dances Its Way Through a Divided Culture
abstract: A new immersive musical set in a Korean hit factory moves to the beats of satire, soap opera and everything in between.
lead_paragraph: So just how do you define the phenomenon known as K-pop — or, for that matter, the new multistranded, multichambered immersive performance piece called “KPOP,” which occupies two floors of a building in Hell’s Kitchen?

headline: Alabama Man Who Waited 10 Years for Trial Is Found Guilty
abstract: In Dothan, Ala., a jury convicted Kharon Davis of a 2007 murder after a four-day trial. Two key witnesses against him changed their stories on the stand.
lead_paragraph: DOTHAN, Ala. — Kharon Davis spent a decade in jail awaiting trial. On Friday, a jury in this southern Alabama town deliberated less than three hours before finding him guilty in the fatal shooting of Peter Dwayne Reaves.

headline: Yankees’ Hopes for an Early Clinching Go Down in a Hail of Homers
abstract: On a night when starter Masahiro Tanaka gave up three home runs to the Blue Jays, his teammates also made some serious mistakes.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The Yankees began their final road trip of the season with a small chance of clinching a wild-card playoff berth by the end of their first night here in Toronto. It would have required a Yankees victory and the right outcomes in two other games, but the Blue Jays and Ryan Goins thwarted any possibility of a celebration with a combination of power and guile.

headline: At Alabama Rally, Trump Toggles Between Republican Loyalists
abstract: The president lent his support to Alabama’s incumbent senator in a Republican runoff campaign, but risked alienating core anti-establishment voters.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — President Trump on Friday implored Alabama voters to support Senator Luther Strange in a close Republican primary, putting his personal political clout on the line in a break with his anti-establishment supporters to aid a lawmaker he portrayed as a loyal soldier for his agenda.

headline: Disney Plays Hardball in Cable Talks With Altice
abstract: Millions of viewers on Long Island and in Connecticut and New Jersey could see ESPN and ABC go dark if an agreement with a cable distributor is not reached.
lead_paragraph: A festering contract dispute between Disney and the nation’s fourth-largest cable distributor broke into public view on Friday night, with Disney warning ESPN and ABC viewers in New York City’s suburbs that those channels could go dark as soon as Oct. 1 if no deal is reached.

headline: A City of Secrets
abstract: On a Vespa tour of his Milan, Andrea Incontri, the creative director of Tod’s, threads the maze of his mysterious city.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — “Milan is a labyrinth,” Andrea Incontri said, as the two of us raced along the cobblestone streets of this ancient city aboard his white Vespa.

headline: Tumult After AIDS Fund-Raiser Supports Harvey Weinstein Production
abstract: A charity’s corporate governance is in question after it allowed proceeds from an auction to be used for a staging of “Finding Neverland.”
lead_paragraph: In May 2015, the entertainment producer Harvey Weinstein arranged for two items to be auctioned off at a fund-raiser for amfAR, a New York-based charity that works to cure AIDS.

headline: 42 Minutes, £2,600 Lost: The U.K.’s Growing Gambling Problem
abstract: The number of problem gamblers has risen by 50 percent in recent years, and campaigners blame a machine that is unique to British betting shops.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tony Franklin entered a betting shop in northwest London one morning last week and paid 300 pounds, or around $400, into a gambling machine — and lost that money within 16 minutes.

headline: Corrections: September 23, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 23, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ and ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
abstract: The hip-hop group N.W.A battles to make a name in “Straight Outta Compton.” And Season 13 of Grey’s Anatomy has its premiere on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: The core members of the hip-hop group N.W.A battle a host of challenges to make a name for themselves in “Straight Outta Compton.” And Season 13 of Grey’s Anatomy has its premiere on Hulu.

headline: 5 Things to Cook While Watching ‘30 Rock’ Before It Leaves Netflix
abstract: “30 Rock” will leave Netflix in October. Here are some dishes to make as you binge it while you still can.
lead_paragraph: Liz Lemon, Tina Fey’s exasperated head writer on the Emmy-winning “30 Rock,” is my personal food hero. She is unapologetic about staying home to enjoy a meatball sub with extra bread. She can shotgun a pizza. She flips a table when she realizes that someone took her mac and cheese.

headline: Trying to Save the Corals of the Great Barrier Reef
abstract: Faced with dying coral reefs, a team of researchers are breeding heat-resistant corals in an effort to restore the population.
lead_paragraph: Faced with dying coral reefs, a team of researchers are breeding heat-resistant corals in an effort to restore the population.

headline: ‘Politics and Foreign Policy Are Not Reality TV’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discussed Trump’s threats to North Korea, the earthquake in Mexico, and a recipe for Baked Stuffed Acorn Squash.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: New Yoga Trips, From Cambodia to Colorado
abstract: Sessions will feature hiking, horsemanship and meditation.
lead_paragraph: Yoga has left the studio as traveling yogis hit the road, guiding practice before more exotic backdrops on rivers, at full moon celebrations and in the great outdoors.

headline: Deals in Code, Arrests in Raids: The Risky Stakes of Oil Middlemen
abstract: A go-to agent in a lucrative industry that depends on global connections speaks up about allegations that it earned millions through graft.
lead_paragraph: MONACO — The worst day of Saman Ahsani’s life began with a 9:30 a.m. knock on the door of the Monaco apartment where he lived with his wife and children. A scrum of law enforcement officials stood in the hallway, flashing a warrant to search the premises and seize property.

headline: A Love Match, Orchestrated by the Moms
abstract: The bride lived in Tokyo, the groom in Cincinnati. They married after a whirlwind romance, thanks to an introduction from their mothers.
lead_paragraph: Yuri Kurashima and Keitaro Harada were married Sept. 19 at St. Andrew’s Cathedral in Tokyo. The Rev. Shintaro D. Ichihara, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: How to Survive the Apocalypse
abstract: Amid natural disasters, terrorist attacks and the North Korea nuclear crisis, it is not just camouflage-clad cave dwellers who are prepping for doomsday.
lead_paragraph: President Trump threatens to “totally destroy North Korea.” Another hurricane lashes out. A second monster earthquake jolts Mexico. Terrorists strike in London. And that’s just this past week or so.

headline: Bringing Quality Food to a Paris Train Station
abstract: L’Étoile du Nord is a brasserie that opened in November inside the Gare du Nord’s bustling entrance hall. The food may be worth missing a train over.
lead_paragraph: For the 700,000 or so people who surge daily through the Gare du Nord in Paris, one of Europe’s busiest train stations has offered little respite from noise and crowds, let alone somewhere to get a decent meal. But the Parisian chef Thierry Marx aims to change that with L’Étoile du Nord, a brasserie with an upstairs wine bar that opened in November in a two-story pavilion of concrete, polished metal and glass inside the station’s bustling entrance hall.

headline: A Mix of Tradition and Trend in Kabul
abstract: In Afghanistan, the photographer Loulou d’Aki made appointments to photograph stylish residents of the capital city. And when the air cooled down, she captured more natural moments in public spaces.
lead_paragraph: “I wasn’t really sure what to expect,” Loulou d’Aki said. The Swedish photographer, who is based in Athens, has worked extensively in the Middle East. Before this summer, however, she had never been to Afghanistan.

headline: Mexico City, Before and After the Earthquake
abstract: Dozens of buildings in Mexico City were destroyed by the earthquake and now pose a risk to rescue workers and residents.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of buildings in Mexico City were destroyed by the earthquake and now pose a risk to rescue workers and residents.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: London and Uber? It’s Complicated
abstract: There is a general feeling in the air that regulators should stand up to businesses that just ignore any rules they don’t like.
lead_paragraph: When Sadiq Khan, the Labour mayor of London, stands in front of the annual gathering of his party’s activists next week, he can be confident that his speech will have at least one applause line: He is the politician who took on Uber.

headline: Small Earthquake Rattles North Korea, and the World’s Nerves
abstract: A tremor was recorded near the North’s underground nuclear test site, but it appears to have been caused by a natural quake.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A small earthquake was detected on Saturday afternoon near North Korea’s underground nuclear test site, reviving fears that the country had set off another bomb.

headline: One Way for G.O.P. to Achieve Some Repeal Goals? It’s Already Part of Obamacare
abstract: The latest Republican repeal effort looks imperiled. But that doesn’t mean the dream of state health care innovation is dead.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Senator John McCain of Arizona announced that he would not support the latest Republican push to overhaul the health care system. He didn’t disapprove of the objectives of the bill, but to its process, which was too rushed and partisan, he said in a statement: “A bill of this impact requires a bipartisan approach.”

headline: Trump Laces Into McCain Over His Opposition to Health Care Bill
abstract: President Trump said Senator John McCain had let his state down and been deceived by Democrats into abandoning a promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: SOMERSET, N.J. — President Trump on Saturday morning lashed out at Senator John McCain of Arizona for breaking with him and opposing Republicans’ latest plan to roll back the Affordable Care Act, saying the senator had let his state down and been deceived by Democrats into abandoning a promise.

headline: When Disaster Hits and Landlines Fail, Social Media Is a Lifeline
abstract: As more people turn to their smartphones in large-scale emergencies, traditional dispatchers are racing to keep up.
lead_paragraph: Since Hurricane Maria lashed Puerto Rico this week, Carol Mitchell has not heard a word from her mother.

headline: At U.N. and in the Air, North Korea and U.S. Trade Tough Messages
abstract: American warplanes flew close to North Korea’s coast, the country’s foreign minister said President Trump was on a “suicide mission” and Mr. Trump replied with a threat on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — American warplanes flew close to North Korea’s coast on Saturday, the same day that the North’s foreign minister told the United Nations General Assembly that President Trump’s threats against the country were “making our rocket’s visit to the entire U.S. mainland inevitable all the more.”

headline: The Storms Moved On. The Caribbean Islands Fear the Tourists Might, Too.
abstract: In a region that relies on visitors, hurricanes left tourism on some islands ‘in a coma.’ The threat of a long-term slump looms, complicating efforts to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: First the hurricanes came, bringing rain, winds and ruin to St. Martin, a tiny island in the Caribbean. Then, said Corby George, a 41-year-old taxi driver there, there was a rush of residents leaving the island, possibly never to return.

headline: Center-Right Party Hangs On in New Zealand Election
abstract: The National Party of Prime Minister Bill English beat back a challenge from the Labour Party and its new leader, Jacinda Ardern.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — After a tumultuous campaign, the center-right governing party in New Zealand placed first in the country’s general election on Saturday, but failed to capture a parliamentary majority, meaning it will have to assemble a coalition if it wants to extend its nine-year hold on power.

headline: Antonio Marras: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Renting a Second Apartment for a Spouse Under Care
abstract: Exploring options for a couple who live in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Q. For 47 years, my wife and I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper East Side. My wife now has dementia and needs constant care. I would like to rent a studio apartment in our building where she could live with her aides. I would be only an elevator ride away. Given my wife’s dementia, we cannot rent in her name and I am concerned I would not be allowed to rent a second apartment. Could a relative sign the lease in his or her name, but not live in the apartment? What options do we have?

headline: Trump Attacks Warriors’ Curry. LeBron James’s Retort: ‘U Bum.’
abstract: The president directly inserted himself into a fiery debate about race, social justice and the role athletes play in highlighting those issues.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of N.F.L. protests and reactions here.

headline: The Not-So-Glossy Future of Magazines
abstract: A spate of departures by celebrity editors suggests that the romance of the industry has faded, as magazines grasp for new revenue streams.
lead_paragraph: One evening in mid-September, a gaggle of writers and bon vivant editors gathered by the outdoor fireplace and ivy-covered trellis of a West Village tavern. Steak was served, and the toasts lasted late into the night, the revelry trickling out to the nearby sidewalk.

headline: As Equifax Amassed Ever More Data, Safety Was a Sales Pitch
abstract: The data breach highlighted just how entrenched the credit bureau is in the lives of Americans, and consumers’ lack of control over their personal information.
lead_paragraph: Equifax’s chief executive had a simple strategy when he joined more than a decade ago: Gather as much personal data as possible and find new ways to sell it.

headline: Luck, Not Tougher Building Standards, Spared Mexico in Quake
abstract: The seismic activity of Tuesday’s earthquake differed from a far more devastating quake in 1985. Enforcement of stronger building codes is lax.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The devastation caused by Tuesday’s earthquake in Mexico City was far less than it might have been, and a fraction of what the city suffered in the quake of 1985.

headline: Michael Phelps, and His Friends
abstract: Alongside an article about Michael Phelps’s mutually therapeutic friendship with Grant Hackett, a Times journalist recounts reporting on him since 2002.
lead_paragraph: My story this weekend about Michael Phelps’s postcompetitive life as an informal counselor to some of sport’s biggest stars, including his close friend Grant Hackett, the Australian distance swimming ace, and the golfer Tiger Woods, took the better part of two days to report — and 15 years to make happen.

headline: Push for Gender Equality in Tech? Some Men Say It’s Gone Too Far
abstract: After revelations of harassment and bias in Silicon Valley, a backlash is growing against the women in tech movement.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Their complaints flow on Reddit forums, on video game message boards, on private Facebook pages and across Twitter. They argue for everything from male separatism to an end to gender diversity efforts.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Crossword
abstract: Sam Ezersky knows how to pick ’em.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Whenever I take a crack at solving a diagramless, which you really should when you see them, I’m always so impressed by the knack it takes to construct something that’s free-form and creative, yet follows crossword puzzling’s many rules. This efflorescent example by the effervescent Sam Ezersky doesn’t disappoint.

headline: Pentagon Tests Lasers and Nets to Combat a Vexing Foe: ISIS Drones
abstract: As deadly drone attacks by the Islamic State increase, American officials are experimenting with technologies that can destroy the weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the vast, windswept White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico earlier this year, nearly a dozen military contractors armed with laser guns, high-tech nets and other experimental systems met to tackle one of the Pentagon’s most vexing counterterrorism conundrums: how to destroy the Islamic State’s increasingly lethal fleet of drones.

headline: Why the Latest Health Bill Is Teetering: It Might Not Work
abstract: For reasons more practical than ideological, the health care world has united to stop the effort by Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Health insurers, who had been strangely quiet for much of the year, came off the sidelines to criticize it. Many state Medicaid directors could not stomach it, either.

headline: Yellen and Cohn Said to Be on Shortlist to Lead Federal Reserve
abstract: Less than five months before Janet Yellen’s term as Fed chairwoman expires, she’s being considered for a second term. But so are several others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House has created a list of about a half-dozen candidates to be the next leader of the Federal Reserve, including its current chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, and the president’s chief economic adviser, Gary D. Cohn, according to two administration officials and a third person with knowledge of the process.

headline: Trump’s Big Gamble: Can He Pull Alabama Senator to Victory?
abstract: The contest between Senator Luther Strange and Roy Moore, an evangelical firebrand, is the most significant test yet of President Trump’s power to sway the party’s conservative base.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — When President Trump took the stage here just days before Alabama’s pivotal Republican Senate runoff, he all but revealed his Oval Office deliberations about whether to stand with Senator Luther Strange and risk attaching himself to a potential loser.

headline: Lessons From Rolling Stone
abstract: I worked at the magazine in the 1990s, and I couldn’t have picked a better place to soak up American culture.
lead_paragraph: Jann Wenner, the founder of Rolling Stone magazine, announced a few days ago that he was putting his company’s controlling stake in the longtime music publication up for sale. For many, it feels like the end of an era, but especially for me. I worked there in the early 1990s, as an intern and then as an editorial assistant. It’s where I learned how to be a journalist — and, to a greater extent than I realized at the time, it’s where I learned how to be an American.

headline: At Florida Nursing Home, Many Calls for Help, but None That Made a Difference
abstract: After the home lost power to its air-conditioning, 11 of its residents died. Records and interviews show a preventable descent into chaos.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The emergency room workers at Memorial Regional Hospital rushed the first patient to Room 9, which was devoted to the hope and practice of arresting death. They threaded fluid lines into her veins and readied a breathing tube. Even through gloves, they could feel the heat corseting the 84-year-old woman’s body.

headline: Missoni: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Traded to Thunder, Ending Turbulent Era With Knicks
abstract: Anthony is leaving New York in exchange for Enes Kanter, Doug McDermott and a second-round draft pick, according to an N.B.A. official briefed on the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: After scoring more than 10,000 points for five coaches over seven seasons without all that much to show for it, Carmelo Anthony is finally leaving New York.

headline: ‘Sisterhood’ Felt Meaningless. So My Sisters and I Got in the Car.
abstract: I didn’t know what sisterhood meant anymore. So I went on a feminist history road trip.
lead_paragraph: I do not know how to drive. My middle sister, Kerri, learned to drive a few years ago. We are both well into adulthood, but I still rely on her and our oldest sister, Kirsten, for any sort of transportation outside of New York City. So this summer, when we took a road trip, with our mother and Kirsten’s husband and two children, to women’s history sites, I found myself in the slightly disempowering back seat while on a search for empowerment.

headline: Facebook’s Ad Scandal Isn’t a ‘Fail,’ It’s a Feature
abstract: The fact that “Jew haters” can be targeted isn’t surprising if you understand how the business model works.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to advertise on Facebook to people who openly call themselves “Jew haters” and want to know “how to burn Jews”? About $10 and 15 minutes, according to what the investigative nonprofit ProPublica recently uncovered.

headline: Rocket Man Knows Better
abstract: Kim family history should keep us from war. Unless a tweet goes too far.
lead_paragraph: A semi-vanquished enemy is rising zombielike from the crypt of America’s dimly remembered wars. North Korea is gleefully shooting missiles over Japan and splashing them into the Pacific Ocean. With astounding technical felicity, it is building a weapons system that may soon be able to hoist hydrogen bombs into Los Angeles, Chicago or even Manhattan. Meanwhile, two neophyte leaders with strange hair and thin skins are insulting each other in bizarre ways. President Trump called Kim Jong-un “Rocket Man” and threatens to “totally destroy North Korea.” Mr. Kim called Mr. Trump “a mentally deranged U.S. dotard” and threatens to “definitely tame” him with “fire.”

headline: Afghan Province, Squeezed by Taliban, Loses Access to Medical Care
abstract: Officials in Oruzgan Province say pressure by the Taliban has closed the region’s health facilities and postponed a vital polio vaccination campaign.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Muhammad Anwar, 8, was vomiting all night and had severe diarrhea. His father, Hajji Aslam, did not know what to do.

headline: One Surprise Standout for Uber: Food Delivery
abstract: Despite a late start, the company’s foray into delivering food, a cutthroat $100 billion-plus service industry, eclipses ride hailing in some markets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, Bob Gordon, the owner of Footprints Cafe in Brooklyn, handled the delivery of his restaurant’s meals, like his Caribbean-inspired “Rasta Pasta,” to customers. So when he decided to work for the first time with an outside delivery service — UberEats, the delivery arm of the ride-hailing giant Uber — he was nervous.

headline: Will Mark Zuckerberg ‘Like’ This Column?
abstract: Oops! Facebook admits it created a democracy-crushing Frankenstein monster that it can’t control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The idea of Mark Zuckerberg running for president was always sort of scary.

headline: The Health Care Cul-de-Sac
abstract: Repeal and replace? Single-payer? Let’s call the whole thing off.
lead_paragraph: Before John McCain put yet another Republican health care plan on life support on Friday, I was going to do with the Graham-Cassidy legislation what I’ve done with previous Republican bills, and weigh the plausible ideas that it contains against its hastily rigged-up architecture and predictable G.O.P. stinginess.

headline: Jil Sander: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Want Geniuses? Welcome Immigrants
abstract: New arrivals to America win many of our top prizes, because they hatch many of our best ideas.
lead_paragraph: Maybe “some are rapists,” in Donald Trump’s nasty words. But many are geniuses. Just ask the MacArthur Foundation, which responded to our president’s frequent demonization of immigrants, including that infamous phrase, by doing a little math.

headline: ‘The New Washington’: Lobbying in the Trump Era
abstract: Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for The Times, spoke with Robert Stryk about how he has leveraged relationships in the Trump administration for political and business success.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode:

headline: On Eve of Kurdish Independence Vote, a Warning From Turkey
abstract: The president of the autonomous Kurdish enclave in Iraq says it is too late to delay a referendum opposed by much of the international community.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Kurds seeking independence from Iraq came under intense pressure on Saturday from their powerful neighbor, Turkey, which demanded that Iraqi Kurdistan cancel an independence vote scheduled for Monday.

headline: Mr. Trump Squanders the World’s Trust
abstract: His indifference to past American commitments undermines the country’s credibility in negotiations and weakens its ability to lead.
lead_paragraph: At a crucial moment, Donald Trump is forcing the world to confront core questions it really shouldn’t have to ask: Can he be trusted? And, more saliently, can America be trusted? His threats to jettison the Iran nuclear deal are undermining America’s credibility as a negotiating partner and weakening America’s ability to lead the free world as it has for 70 years.

headline: How World Leaders Reacted to Trump at the U.N.
abstract: From deriding the American leader as a “giant gold Goliath” to applauding his calls for sovereignty, leaders gave widely varying responses to President Trump’s General Assembly speech.
lead_paragraph: He was called a “giant gold Goliath” and a “rogue newcomer.” But in a few corners the remarks made by President Trump at the United Nations were described as “courageous” and “gratifying.”

headline: Everyone Wants to Reduce Drug Prices. So Why Can’t We Do It?
abstract: The pharmaceutical industry seems an easy target for reform. But thanks to lobbying and campaign contributions, Congress just won’t act.
lead_paragraph: Of all the promises President Trump made for the early part of his term, controlling stinging drug prices might have seemed the easiest to achieve.

headline: A Starry Night Crowded With Selfies
abstract: Van Gogh’s masterpiece has an undisputed magnetism. But has all the photo-snapping eclipsed a deeper kind of looking?
lead_paragraph: The city’s summer tourist season is ending, but visitors still crowd four and five deep in neck-craning hubbubs, brandishing phones to take close-ups and grinning selfies and somehow partake of “Starry Night,” the van Gogh masterpiece at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: The Last Stand of the Amazon’s Arrow People
abstract: Brazil is backpedaling on its protections of uncontacted tribes.
lead_paragraph: Brazil is home to the largest number of uncontacted indigenous communities of any country in the world. Hidden deep in primeval Amazon forests, these groups represent the final frontier of a seemingly inexorable conquest that began with the landing of Portuguese and Spanish navigators on South America’s shores at the start of the 16th century.

headline: The Vietnam War, Revisited
abstract: The Ken Burns-Lynn Novick documentary series has sparked a national conversation about the war.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: DeVos Should Want to Educate Men About Rape
abstract: The education secretary has rescinded Obama’s campus sexual assault guidance. A former college rape crisis counselor explains what she’s missing.
lead_paragraph: During my senior year of college, I spent many evenings in fraternity houses. I didn’t show up, like most did, to drink too much and dance badly. Instead, I was the ultimate buzz kill: As a rape crisis counselor, I was there to talk to fellow young men about how to end sexual assault on campus.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Trump’s Comments on N.F.L. and Stephen Curry Draw Intense Reaction
abstract: After the president took aim at N.F.L. players and the N.B.A. star Stephen Curry, athletes and celebrities reacted on Twitter with strong words.
lead_paragraph: The days of superstar athletes being unwilling to speak their minds for fear of damaging their earnings or reputation appear to be at an end.

headline: As Trump Takes On Athletes, Watch Them Rise
abstract: The president’s inflammatory comments might not be as significant as the players’ responses.
lead_paragraph: Here is our not-so-happy sports and politics recap, and all who complain about the mixture of the two are advised to register their complaints with the White House switchboard.

headline: State Lines
abstract: In a big country, stay with Alan Arbesfeld.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s been too long, puzzlers! I send fond greetings to the regulars and would like to briefly introduce myself to any and all new Wordplay devotees. I work with Deb at The Times, mainly in technology, which happens to be relevant to my approach to the crossword in the 21st century. My job includes troubleshooting and maintaining all of our apps and internal systems, and I do my best to keep up with our tech and do the daily puzzle on my phone, where features like a timer and a streak counter are offered. All well and good, maybe even addictive for some, but when I fill in on this column and really get to ruminate over these grids, I solve them on paper, at my kitchen table, with talk radio on and a cup of either coffee or wine. (Yes I have stems, I’m not a savage; they come out when there’s company.) Often a dog or two loll at my feet. I know I made good time if my coffee’s still hot when I’m done, and I know I’m in trouble when the cup is empty and the dogs get restless.

headline: Free Speech Week at Berkeley Is Canceled, but Milo Yiannopoulos Still Plans to Talk
abstract: A student group that was organizing a series of speeches by right-wing activists canceled the event on Saturday. Mr. Yiannopoulos said he was “blindsided.”
lead_paragraph: A student group at the University of California, Berkeley, that was organizing a series of speeches by right-wing figures canceled the planned four-day event on Saturday but one of its featured speakers, the conservative provocateur Milo Yiannopoulos, said he would show up anyway.

headline: Six Are Burned in Acid Attack as Groups Clash in East London
abstract: A group of men sprayed a caustic substance in the faces of at least six others, the latest in a series of similar crimes in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British police are investigating a series of attacks on Saturday by a group of men in East London who apparently sprayed acid on a group of people, injuring six. It was the latest in a series of similar episodes that the police have linked to gang activities in the area.

headline: Yankees Clinch a Wild-Card Playoff Berth, Exceeding Expectations
abstract: For a team that had emphasized rebuilding, securing a playoff spot was a remarkable achievement by a mostly precocious group of players.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Champagne and beer overflowed in the Yankees’ clubhouse, and soaked players chanted and danced on a puddle-strewn carpet in the first of what they hope will be several such celebrations.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn’s Rise From Political Dinosaur to Potential Leader
abstract: The leader of the Labour Party, written off a year ago, can expect a rapturous reception at this year’s party conference. But can he win a broader audience?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is always satisfying to prove your doubters wrong and, in the case of Jeremy Corbyn, the left-wing leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, there were an awful lot of them.

headline: The President Demands Silence From Colin Kaepernick
abstract: For Mr. Trump, the privilege of breaking your body to be in the N.F.L. doesn’t come with the privilege of protesting for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: President Trump showed an awkward sense of timing in denouncing Colin Kaepernick, the former Super Bowl quarterback who last season began kneeling during the national anthem to protest police injustice against minorities. He tweeted on Saturday:

headline: Cracks in a Puerto Rican Dam Send Neighbors a Message: Leave Now
abstract: Officials of Isabela, in northwest Puerto Rico, are trying to evacuate residents after Hurricane Maria damaged the nearby Guajataca Dam.
lead_paragraph: ISABELA, P.R. — The police came to this coastal city, nicknamed the Garden of the Northwest, in trucks, jeeps and medical evacuation vans. The city’s public safety director wore a life jacket.

headline: Stephen Curry, on a ‘Surreal’ Day, Confronts a Presidential Snub
abstract: The Warriors star woke up on Saturday to learn that he was no longer welcome at the White House, after he had already said he didn’t want to go.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors said he awoke Saturday morning to “about 20 text messages” from friends who were expressing their support for him.

headline: Tom Price Says He’ll Stop Use of Private Jets Until After Review
abstract: Mr. Price, the health and human services secretary, has come under fire for his use of private jets when traveling on government business.
lead_paragraph: Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, said on Saturday that he did not plan to travel on private jets until the department’s inspector general completes a formal review of the use of taxpayer funds for his chartered flights.

headline: Millennials Rule Golf, but Pat Perez Works to Be an Exception
abstract: At 41, Perez is the oldest player in the Tour Championship, whose 30-man field includes nine players under the age of 26.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — If the rapper and actor Ludacris knew who Pat Perez was, he didn’t act like it. When Perez and his wife, Ashley, ventured backstage after Ludacris performed for 45 minutes at a show before the Tour Championship, the entertainer posed with Ashley Perez and ignored her husband.

headline: Inside a Rohingya Refugee Camp
abstract: Our correspondent reports from a sprawling makeshift city that houses hundreds of thousands of Rohingya people, driven from their homes by Myanmar's military.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent reports from a sprawling makeshift city that houses hundreds of thousands of Rohingya people, driven from their homes by Myanmar's military.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Preventable Descent Into Suffocating Chaos
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 24, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “I just imagined her wanting me there with her, looking at the door, wondering when I was going to get her out of the heat.”

headline: Abigail Clark, Christine Hwang
abstract: The couple are lawyers. Ms. Clark represents management in labor issues; Ms. Hwang represents unions and employees.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Wells Clark and Christine Sue Hwang were married Sept. 23 at the Hyatt Regency in Incline Village, Nev. Meredith I. Richmond, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

Gravitz, a friend of the couple, led the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Diana Siu and Charles Chen were married Sept. 23 at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y. Carl Lee, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Anne Gocke and Nolan Ganguli Shenai were married Sept. 23. The Rev. Richard R. Wohlschlaeger, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the James A. Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa.

lead_paragraph: Vanessa Silverton-Peel and Raphael David Rose were married Sept. 23 in Encino, Calif. Robert Abele, a friend of the bride who became a minister through American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated at the home of Gail Silverton, an aunt of the bride.

lead_paragraph: Céline Thérèse Geiger and Brett Adam Weiner were married Sept. 23 at Rancho del Cielo in Malibu, Calif. Emily Evitt, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Noah Syndergaard, Back at Last, Pitches a Quick Inning in a Mets Loss
abstract: Syndergaard’s first appearance for the Mets since April 30 lasted just one inning, as planned, and he needed only five pitches to get through it.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since April 30, the Mets’ ace, Noah Syndergaard, took the mound in a major league game on Saturday. As planned, he pitched just the first inning before giving way to Matt Harvey in a 4-3 loss to the Washington Nationals in 10 innings.

headline: Allison Zelman, Max Lesko
abstract: The couple met in Portland, Ore., in 2008 while working on the Obama presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Allison Lee Zelman and Max Schaetzel Lesko were married Sept. 23 at Fairfield Farm in Lakeville, Conn. Noland Chambliss, a friend of the couple who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Andrea Patricia Desy and Daniel Edrei are to be married Sept. 24 at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, R.I. Edward Cisneros, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate.

lead_paragraph: Casey Van de Walle and Blake Timothy Berman were married Sept. 23 at Gurney's Montauk Resort in Montauk, N.Y. The Rev. Amy Post, an interfaith minister, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Jane Hsu Wong and Nicholas Stephen Smith were married Sept. 23 at the Fernbank Museum of Natural History in Atlanta. James Peter Hodge, a friend of the groom who became a minister of the First Nation Church for the event, officiated.

abstract: Shari Albert and Craig De Lorenzo, both actors, were married.
lead_paragraph: Shari Albert and Craig De Lorenzo were married Sept. 23 at 632 on Hudson, an events space in New York. Sally Clayton, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Emily Sieck Baldwin and Frederico Gilson Padilha were married Sept. 23 at the bride’s family home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The Rev. David A. Davis, a Presbyterian minister, officiate.

lead_paragraph: Bryant Christopher Ross and Scott Michael Curcio were married Sept. 23 at the Big House, a historic private residence in Kennebunk, Me. Matthew R. Kerns, Mr. Curcio’s best friend and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ and ‘Ballers’
abstract: “Star Trek: Discovery” introduces new faces in a different era, but retains the same overarching themes. And Spencer and Joe land promising deals in the Season 3 finale of “Ballers.”
lead_paragraph: “Star Trek: Discovery” introduces new faces in a different era, but retains the same overarching themes. And Spencer and Joe land promising deals in the Season 3 finale of “Ballers.”

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: 1 Station Square, No. 315, Forest Hills Gardens

headline: Spelunking in Search of Antibiotics
abstract: It can take decades of research and more than a billion dollars to create a new antibiotic drug. Sometimes, the first step of the process starts underground, deep inside a mountain.
lead_paragraph: It can take decades of research and more than a billion dollars to create a new antibiotic drug. Sometimes, the first step of the process starts underground, deep inside a mountain.

headline: The N.F.L. and N.B.A., Puerto Rico, North Korea: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Angela Merkel Makes History in German Vote, but So Does Far Right
abstract: Ms. Merkel becomes only the third postwar chancellor to win four national elections, but her victory is diminished by the showing of Alternative for Germany.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Angela Merkel won a fourth term as chancellor in elections on Sunday, placing her in the front ranks of Germany’s postwar leaders, even as her victory was dimmed by the entry of a far-right party into Parliament for the first time in more than 60 years, according to preliminary results.

headline: Marni: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Iraqi Kurds Will Vote on Independence, Recalling Tortured Past
abstract: Almost every Kurd in northern Iraq has a family history stained by treachery and dispossession. A vote for independence would be a step toward realizing a national dream.
lead_paragraph: MALA OMER, Iraq — The Kurdish soldier, wounded in battle last year, rose in pain from his wheelchair. As his reedy legs wobbled, his 13-year-old brother thrust a cane into his hand.

headline: Trump Calls for Boycott if N.F.L. Doesn’t Crack Down on Anthem Protests
abstract: “If NFL fans refuse to go to games until players stop disrespecting our country, you will see change take place fast,” President Trump wrote on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: SOMERSET, N.J. — President Trump on Sunday called for football fans to boycott N.F.L. games unless the league fires or suspends players who refuse to stand for the national anthem, saying that players must “stop disrespecting our flag and country.”

headline: After Trump Blasts N.F.L., Players Kneel and Lock Arms in Solidarity
abstract: After President Trump doubled down on his criticism of players who take a knee during the national anthem, owners and players responded.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of N.F.L. scores here.

headline: Billionaires, Bruised Egos and the Death of a Grand Project
abstract: Barry Diller was about to win the battle for his $250 million arts pier, but then came the “petty questions” from his opponents and he decided to pull the plug.
lead_paragraph: For Barry Diller, the turning point came at a Sept. 5 settlement meeting with the small band of opponents who had tied up his plans for a $250 million park and cultural center in the Hudson River for more than two years.

headline: Senators Revise Health Bill in Last-Ditch Effort to Win Votes
abstract: Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy adjusted the bill to send money toward Alaska and Maine, states with senators who had indicated they weren’t ready to support the latest attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running short, the authors of the latest plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act shifted money in the bill to Alaska and Maine, which are represented by Republican senators who appear reluctant to support it.

headline: Review: The Small Bang Theory of ‘Young Sheldon’
abstract: This prequel to “The Big Bang Theory” tracks the “Muppet Babies” version of Jim Parsons’s character, Sheldon Cooper.
lead_paragraph: CBS’s big-swing comedy this fall is “Young Sheldon.” It’s about an alienated child with severe social limitations and the parents either unable or not particularly eager to understand him, or help him navigate the cruel world that is 1989 Texas.

headline: Imagining Murder at a Cold War Command Post With Harlan Coben
abstract: The novelist Harlan Coben visits a 1950s nuclear-missile command-and-control center in Livingston, N.J., that figures in his latest thriller.
lead_paragraph: LIVINGSTON, N.J. — The road up the hill was narrow, the pavement old and a little cracked, the feeling was vaguely sinister — and the tall man in the T-shirt knew it. “You can almost sense the secretive nature already,” he said as the sport-utility vehicle edged along. “How does this not spark your imagination?”

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Start with Julia Moskin’s incredible new recipe for eggplant parm, then try out some baked chicken tenders or some spaghetti with cauliflower and chickpeas.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: The Dying Art of Disagreement
abstract: Today’s clashes may hoarsen our voices, but they rarely sharpen our thinking, much less change our minds.
lead_paragraph: This is the text of  a lecture delivered at the Lowy Institute Media Award dinner in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday, Sept. 23. The award recognizes excellence in Australian foreign affairs journalism.

headline: 3 United Nations Soldiers Are Killed in Northern Mali
abstract: The West African country has become one of the United Nations’ deadliest peacekeeping missions, with more than 130 fatalities in four years.
lead_paragraph: Three United Nations troops were killed and five others were seriously injured on Sunday by an explosion in Mali, underscoring the dangers facing the four-year-old peacekeeping mission in the country.

headline: Immigration Officials Taking New Steps to Discourage Smuggling of Children
abstract: Officials said the sweep was intended to deter parents in the United States illegally from paying smugglers to bring their children into the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is stepping up its pursuit of parents who paid to have their children illegally brought into the United States, according to people familiar with the matter. The effort, part of a widening crackdown on illegal immigration, is aimed at discouraging families from paying human smuggling organizations.

headline: Street-Style Photographers Unite to Proclaim #NoFreePhotos
abstract: An online campaign hopes to raise awareness about the indiscriminate use of images by influencers and fashion brands.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — They roam in packs. Milling expectantly, cameras in hand, dozens of street-style photographers hover on the sidewalks of fashion week cities in the hope that stylish pedestrians will cross their paths on the way to the front row. When they do — and they always do — pandemonium follows; like a stampede of thirsty wildebeests to the watering hole, the photographers will charge into oncoming traffic or even other guests in their quest for the perfect shots.

headline: Review: Philip Glass Comes, Finally, to the New York Philharmonic
abstract: Jaap van Zweden, the orchestra’s next music director, takes over next year. But he made a statement with a pairing of Mr. Glass and Mahler.
lead_paragraph: Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s incoming music director, doesn’t officially start until next year. But he seized the occasion of his first opening night with his new orchestra to make a statement.

headline: How a Gang of Droogs Get Fit (Ultrafit) Off Broadway
abstract: The physical training required for the theatrical version of “A Clockwork Orange” rivals that of professional athletes.
lead_paragraph: Nine droogs (and one alternate droog) gathered an hour and a half before showtime at New World Stages on a recent Friday night. To a chorus of syncopated grunts, oohs and aahs, they began to warm up.

headline: Review: CBS’s ‘Me, Myself & I’ Doesn’t Know Itself Yet
abstract: The new comedy, which stars Bobby Moynihan and John Larroquette as the same character at different ages, rings false.
lead_paragraph: CBS would love to have another “How I Met Your Mother,” a jovial and nostalgia-tinged sitcom with a built-in sense of both youthful folly and warm wisdom. The existence of “Me, Myself & I,” a comedy that aims for that same sensibility, this time showing a character at the ages of 14, 40 and 65, is not therefore a mystery. But the execution is confounding.

headline: Review: After Flood, Houston Ballet Returns With a Romantic Masterpiece
abstract: Moved from its damaged theater, “Mayerling,” Kenneth MacMillan’s flawed, important 1978 work, receives its first North American production.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Houston Ballet, recovering from the flooding caused by Hurricane Harvey, has lost performances and had to move to a different theater. Yet when it opened its season on Friday, it did so in a big way — as the first North American ballet company to perform Kenneth MacMillan’s three-act “Mayerling.”

headline: Activists Occupy Volksbühne Theater in Berlin as Conflict Widens
abstract: A left-wing group said its aim was to turn the Volksbühne into a collectively run theater. It has been a flash point since Chris Dercon was named its new director.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The drama surrounding Berlin’s iconic Volksbühne theater took another surprising turn on Friday afternoon when a group of left-wing activists moved into the building and proclaimed they were occupying the institution with the aim of turning it into a collectively run theater. The Volksbühne had become a flash point for a tense debate about the city’s future, fueled by concerns about gentrification and globalization, ever since the announcement two years ago that the theater’s longtime director, Frank Castorf, was to be ousted and replaced with Chris Dercon, the former director of the Tate Modern in London.

headline: How Angela Merkel’s Longevity Compares to 3 Decades of European Leadership
abstract: Angela Merkel won a fourth term on Sunday as German chancellor. Her longevity in power has helped her cement her formidable position in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Angela Merkel won a fourth term on Sunday as German chancellor. Her longevity in power has helped her cement her formidable position in Europe.

headline: ‘Lego Ninjago’ Fizzles, Leaving ‘Kingsman’ Sequel a Soft No. 1
abstract: “Kingsman: The Golden Circle” collected $39 million in North America, a bit less than expected. “Ninjago” marked a new low for the Lego movie series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Kingsman: The Golden Circle” and “The Lego Ninjago Movie” underwhelmed critics. The masses seemed to agree.

headline: Shooting at Tennessee Church Leaves One Dead and Seven Wounded
abstract: A gunman who opened fire at a church in Antioch, Tenn., on Sunday shot himself and was in custody, the police said.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and seven others were wounded after a gunman opened fire on Sunday at a church in Antioch, Tenn., near Nashville, officials said. The police said the gunman, who shot himself, was in custody.

headline: 17 ISIS Fighters Reported Killed as U.S. Ends Lull in Libya Airstrikes
abstract: A half-dozen “precision strikes” hit a training camp about 150 miles southeast of Surt, from which militants were plotting and conducting attacks, the military said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military said on Sunday that it had conducted drone strikes on an Islamic State training camp in Libya, killing 17 militants in the first American airstrikes in the strife-torn North African nation since January.

headline: Carmelo Anthony: How Much Was He to Blame for Trouble With the Knicks?
abstract: Anthony is hardly alone in failing as a supposed savior for the franchise, but he set himself up for some of the drama that enveloped him in New York.
lead_paragraph: It would be an unfair assessment to say that Carmelo Anthony failed to achieve some of what he set out to do when he strong-armed his way to New York in February 2011, six and a half seasons ago.

headline: Edgar Smith, Killer Who Duped William F. Buckley, Dies at 83
abstract: Sentenced to the electric chair for killing a 15-year-old girl in New Jersey, Mr. Smith won his freedom with help from the conservative commentator.
lead_paragraph: The final journey of Edgar H. Smith Jr., a killer who duped the conservative commentator William F. Buckley Jr. into helping him win his freedom from death row, most likely took him from a California prison hospital to the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Review: A Cast of 87 Sounds a Climate Change Alarm
abstract: Bringing together wrestlers, a food cart, a cellist and a bandstand, Pig Iron Theater Company takes on catastrophe in “A Period of Animate Existence.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Saturday afternoon was sparkling here: one of those early autumn days with not a whiff of fall in the air. The temperature was close to 90, and when a taxi drove past with an ad on its roof for a production of “The Nutcracker,” the incongruity was jarring. Aren’t the holidays too far off for that?

headline: America’s Roles in Vietnam and Afghanistan
abstract: An official in the Afghan Foreign Ministry takes issue with the comparison, while a former U.S. official agrees with it.

abstract: A reader writes that those who criticize the Rev. James Martin need to reflect on Christian values.

abstract: A foreign policy expert writes that we need a new paradigm.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Student Trapped in Indiana Cave for 58 Hours Licked Water Off the Walls
abstract: What was supposed to be a fun adventure turned into a hellish ordeal for a college student after other cave explorers mistakenly left him behind.
lead_paragraph: Lukas Cavar screamed for hours, hoping to get someone’s attention. Bats, salamanders, crayfish and beetles were his only company.

headline: Make Cities Greener, Not Suburbs
abstract: An architect rejects a lifestyle for young people as not environmentally sustainable.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Big Food and Rising Obesity in Brazil
abstract: Readers talk about reversing and understanding a trend in the developing world.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Movie’s Ads Protest Rules Restricting Gay Men From Donating Blood
abstract: To promote “Jigsaw,” Lionsgate is introducing a fan blood drive and taking aim at contentious federal regulations that add restrictions for gay men.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The last “Saw” movie, released by Lionsgate in 2010, was advertised as “the final chapter.” But you didn’t think a franchise with roughly $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales was going to die that easily, did you?

headline: Politics Has Always Had a Place in Football
abstract: The sport was not incidental to the doctrine of segregation. It was one of the pillars on which it rested.
lead_paragraph: “Wouldn’t you love to see one of these N.F.L. owners, when somebody disrespects our flag, to say, ‘Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, out, he’s fired.’” With those disparaging words, spoken Friday night at a campaign speech for a Senate candidate in Alabama, the president of the United States ignited a firestorm, which he continued to stoke on Twitter over the weekend.

headline: North Korea, Angela Merkel, N.F.L.: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: At Her Own Pace, Melania Trump Tiptoes Into the Limelight
abstract: The first lady is as cautious as her husband is impulsive, but eight months on she is hinting at an emerging policy platform.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Melania Trump took a quick break from Washington.

headline: Charles Bradley, a Late-in-Life Soul Music Star, Dies at 68
abstract: The singer, once a small-time James Brown impersonator called Black Velvet, was known for his beleaguered rasp and passionate live performances.
lead_paragraph: Charles Bradley, the journeyman soul singer whose beleaguered rasp and passionate live performances turned him from an itinerant worker and small-time James Brown impersonator into a late-in-life headliner, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 68.

headline: Heng on Trump and ‘Rocket Man’
abstract: Will Kim Jong-un call President Donald Trump’s bluff?
lead_paragraph: In his first address to the United Nations General Assembly, President Trump called the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un “Rocket Man” and warned that if necessary the United States “will have no choice but to totally destroy North Korea.”

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Maria Sharapova on ‘Unstoppable’
abstract: The tennis star discusses why she wrote her new memoir, the struggles her father faced during her childhood and more.
lead_paragraph: Since shocking the tennis world with her win over Serena Williams in the 2004 Wimbledon finals, Maria Sharapova has spent time as the No. 1 player in the world, a glamorous pitchwoman whose endorsement deals run in the tens of millions of dollars and a figure of controversy. Last year, the Russian-American star tested positive for meldonium, a drug that had been recently banned by the International Tennis Federation. She returned to the court earlier this year after serving a 15-month suspension. Sharapova has now also written a memoir, “Unstoppable,” looking back at her life and career. It arrives a few months after she turned 30 — not exactly old age in tennis but getting there. In the book, Sharapova writes about Serena Williams, who turns 36 this month and continues to dominate the sport: “Serena and I should be friends: we love the same thing, we have the same passion. … But we are not friends — not at all.” Below, in an email interview, Sharapova talks about her unlikely beginnings, how her book transformed into a rallying cry for overachievers, the way art and fashion inspire her and more.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 25
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: 68 Things You Cannot Say on China’s Internet
