abstract: China’s censorship system is expanding forbidden topics far beyond politics, in line with President Xi Jinping’s prim, paternalistic vision for the “China dream.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Song Jie, a writer in central China, knows what she can and cannot write in the romance novels she publishes online. Words that describe explicit sexual acts are out, of course. So are those for sexual organs. Even euphemisms like “behind” or “bottom” can trigger censorship by automatic software filters or a website’s employees.

headline: Angela Merkel, Reluctant Leader of the West, ‘Has Gotten the Taste for It’
abstract: Elected to a fourth term as German chancellor, she wants to put the European Union, post-Brexit and in the age of Trump, on a stable, vigorous path.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany recoils from the idea that she is now, almost de facto, the leader of the Western world, the defender of trans-Atlantic alliances and multilateralism. But like it or not, she and the country she will lead for a fourth term have become global actors.

headline: New York Expands Relief Efforts for Puerto Rico After Hurricane Maria
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a statewide partnership to provide aid to the island territory days after viewing the damage wrought by Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a statewide partnership on Sunday to provide aid to Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, as he called on the federal government to step up efforts to help its Caribbean territories.

headline: Good Deed at the Tow Pound
abstract: Coming up with $10 at a critical moment.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Puerto Rico Is American. We Can’t Ignore It Now.
abstract: Economically ruined before the storm, without power, electrically or electorally, it, and the Virgin Islands, need full federal aid.
lead_paragraph: A century after the United States extended qualified citizenship to the residents of Puerto Rico, that link has never been more vital to the island commonwealth, as it reels from the devastation of Hurricane Maria.

headline: Conveying Sounds Through Words: The Classical Music Critic’s Challenge
abstract: I once compared part of a Sibelius symphony to “a fractured dance in which the broken parts have been reassembled, but in the wrong way.”
lead_paragraph: Some big issues — with implications for the prosperity of the performing arts in New York City and the overall health of classical music — hovered over the programs that the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden led recently to open the season of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Budget Bus Lines Flout the Rules With Little Consequence
abstract: Even after deadly crashes like the one in Queens last week, discount bus companies are often able to stay in business and evade serious penalties.
lead_paragraph: Every time a charter bus is involved in a grisly crash like the one that left three people dead in Queens last week, elected officials demand more scrutiny of the thousands of American companies that privately operate buses. But they do not need to look any farther than Chinatown in Manhattan to see how challenging it can be to stop even a serial violator of the rules of the roads.

headline: A Rabbi, an Imam and a Message of Inclusion at a Muslim Parade
abstract: After white supremacists marched in Charlottesville, Va., earlier this year, organizers decided that this year’s Muslim Day parade must also be a platform.
lead_paragraph: At about 1 p.m. on Sunday, Diakita Amadou burst out the doors of the hotel he works at on 38th Street in Manhattan and took off. He had heard the adhan, the Muslim call to prayer, echoing through the lobby, and followed its song.

headline: Is Trump All Talk on North Korea? The Uncertainty Sends a Shiver
abstract: The president’s willingness to casually threaten to annihilate a nuclear-armed foe was yet another reminder of the steep risks inherent in his brute-force approach to diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump gave a fiery campaign speech in Huntsville, Ala., on Friday evening, he drew a rapturous roar by ridiculing Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, as “Little Rocket Man.”

headline: Here’s What N.F.L. Fans Think of Trump’s Comments and Anthem Protests
abstract: We interviewed fans at several games on Sunday. Suffice to say opinions were wildly divergent.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — In the expansive Gillette Stadium parking lot, with sausages sizzling on the grill and beers icing in the cooler, football fans here resented the intrusion of politics into their Sunday afternoon tailgating traditions.

headline: Fueled by Trump’s Tweets, Anthem Protests Grow to a Nationwide Rebuke
abstract: The wave of demonstrations at N.F.L. games on Sunday even included some of Trump’s supporters in the league, but it drew a mixed reception from fans.
lead_paragraph: On three N.F.L. teams, nearly all the football players skipped the national anthem altogether. Dozens of others, from London to Los Angeles, knelt or locked arms on the sidelines, joined by several team owners in a league normally friendly to President Trump. Some of the sport’s biggest stars joined the kind of demonstration they have steadfastly avoided.

headline: Greetings From a Parade Float
abstract: An easy-peasy Monday by Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, all! Sam Ezersky here again. You may remember me from my “big break” two weeks ago or my diagramless in yesterday’s Magazine. Either way, I’ll be sticking around through Friday, and I promise I don’t bite. [Can confirm. — D.A.]

headline: Colbert, Kimmel and the Politics of Late Night
abstract: Once a refuge from the worries of the workday, late night TV shows and other avenues of entertainment, like sports, are forcing Americans to take sides.
lead_paragraph: The job of a late-night comedian was once so straightforward: Give Americans something to laugh about so they can forget about their workday worries. Presidents always made for comedic fodder, as did the daily headlines. But it was all in good fun. And it generally hovered on the edge of the partisan divide.

headline: Defying Trump, Athletes Intensify Debate on Race and Protest
abstract: President Trump’s scolding of prominent black athletes has touched off a furious national debate on race and patriotism, rattling the world of sports.
lead_paragraph: It began as a crowd-pleasing tirade from President Trump to an overwhelmingly white, conservative crowd in Alabama. But even before dozens of N.F.L. players knelt in silent protest on Sunday, Mr. Trump’s remarks had spiraled into a national uproar over race, patriotism and free speech, with an unpredictable political trajectory.

headline: New Order Indefinitely Bars Almost All Travel From Seven Countries
abstract: Starting next month, most citizens of Iran, Libya, Syria, Yemen, Somalia, Chad and North Korea will be indefinitely barred from entering the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Sunday issued a new order indefinitely banning almost all travel to the United States from seven countries, including most of the nations covered by his original travel ban, citing threats to national security posed by letting their citizens into the country.

headline: A Divider, Not a Uniter, Trump Widens the Breach
abstract: While past presidents at least talked about bringing the country together, this president has made a point of attacking everyone from sports stars to the pope.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the course of just 17 hours this weekend, President Trump assailed John McCain, Chuck Schumer, Stephen Curry, the National Football League, Roger Goodell, Iran and Kim Jong-un — the “Little Rocket Man.” And that was on his day off.

headline: Regulator Wants Financial Industry to Self-Report Wrongdoing
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, an aggressive Wall Street watchdog under President Obama, hopes companies will be lured with smaller penalties.
lead_paragraph: After years as a sleepy federal backwater, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission became one of Wall Street’s most aggressive watchdogs during the Barack Obama administration.

headline: Former Hostage Held by Al Qaeda Describes 6-Year Ordeal in the Sahara
abstract: Johan Gustafsson, a Swede kidnapped at gunpoint in Timbuktu, Mali, by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb in 2011 and recently freed, tells of his captivity and his conversion to Islam.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — It was supposed to be an adventurous motorcycle journey through Africa. Johan Gustafsson, then a 36-year-old engineer, set off with a friend to see the continent, “not just read about it in books,” he later said. His biggest concern was traffic accidents.

headline: For Isolated Philippine Town, a Planned Road Is a Lifeline and a Worry
abstract: A new road to a previously unconnected coastal town is promising prosperity for its indigenous residents, but it may also endanger their culture.
lead_paragraph: PALANAN, Philippines — There is no road to Palanan.

headline: Nigel Farage to Campaign for Roy Moore in Alabama Senate Race
abstract: Mr. Farage, a right-wing British politician, is defying President Trump by endorsing Mr. Moore in a pivotal Republican Senate runoff.
lead_paragraph: Nigel Farage, the right-wing British politician and outspoken supporter of President Trump, plans to campaign in Alabama on Monday against the president’s preferred candidate in a crucial Republican Senate runoff.

headline: Aaron Judge Reaches 48 Homers as the Yankees Lose Ground to Boston
abstract: A day after clinching a wild-card playoff spot, the sluggish Yankees lost and fell to five games behind the Red Sox in the A.L. East.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Based on the Yankees’ level of jubilation and the volume of alcohol poured into and over them after they clinched a playoff berth Saturday night, perhaps it was not surprising what happened the next day.

headline: Rookie Claims a Title, but Justin Thomas Clinches the FedEx Cup
abstract: Xander Schauffele closed with a 68 on Sunday to win the Tour Championship at East Lake, but Thomas did enough for a victory in the season-long competition.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — By the time Xander Schauffele hit his final drive on Sunday, the Tour Championship was a wet blanket that had been wrung dry.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Agriculture and Farmers Decimated by Maria
abstract: Hurricane Maria’s barrage took out entire plantations and destroyed crops and livestock across the island. The storm knocked out about 80 percent of its crops.
lead_paragraph: YABUCOA, P.R. — José A. Rivera, a farmer on the southeast coast of Puerto Rico, stood in the middle of his flattened plantain farm on Sunday and tried to tally how much Hurricane Maria had cost him.

headline: In Germany, a Victory for Angela Merkel and Populism
abstract: The chancellor faces a challenge in forming a government after the loss suffered by her coalition partner, the Social Democrats.
lead_paragraph: As anticipated, Angela Merkel’s party came in first in the German national election on Sunday, assuring her of a fourth term as chancellor. That much was foreordained, even if Ms. Merkel’s center-right Christian Democrats and their Bavarian allies came in slightly below expectations, with roughly a third of the vote.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 3, Episode 3: Green Ain’t Your Color
abstract: The episode gives us one last round of Claire and Frank, as satisfying as it is painful.
lead_paragraph: When we last left Claire and Jamie, they were in limbo: Claire in a stalled marriage, Jamie on the way to prison for his family’s sake. This week’s episode is here to move them past these hard times and start a new act of their epic.

headline: Industry Under Pressure Gathers for Ad Week and a Deadline for Google
abstract: Advertising Week sends marketing professionals to Manhattan and Google’s shopping service must provide a level playing field in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: The Day the Real Patriots Took a Knee
abstract: President Trump’s Twitter clash with N.F.L. owners, players and at least two basketball stars shows again his lack of commitment to social justice.
lead_paragraph: At a political rally in Alabama on Friday, President Trump had clear advice for N.F.L. owners if one of their players followed the lead of Colin Kaepernick, the former Super Bowl quarterback who last season began kneeling during the national anthem to protest police injustice against minorities. “Get that son of a bitch off the field right now,” he suggested.

headline: What is Your Reaction to President Trump’s Tweets About Professional Sports Leagues and Athletes?
abstract: What do you think of how players, owners, teams and leagues have responded?
lead_paragraph: By now you may have heard about, or even seen for yourself, the various demonstrations of protest made by N.F.L. players on Sunday, as well as by a Major League baseball player on Saturday.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Season 1, Episode 3: Making It and Faking It
abstract: No one can stay mad at James Franco, least of all James Franco.
lead_paragraph: In my recap of the pilot episode of “The Deuce,” I likened the relationship between Vinnie and Frankie to the one between Harvey Keitel and Robert De Niro in “Mean Streets,” Martin Scorsese’s 1973 film about low-level hoods mixed up with the local mob in Little Italy. Vinnie is Keitel, the responsible one, and Frankie is De Niro, the charismatic screw-up who constantly makes his friend pay for his sins. A shot in this week’s episode bears out the comparison: Frankie’s stroll into his brother’s new bar with a waitress under each arm recalls De Niro’s entrance to “Jumpin’ Jack Flash.”

headline: Kushner Used Personal Email Account for Government Business
abstract: A lawyer said that Jared Kushner had received or sent “fewer than a hundred emails” involving his White House colleagues, and that all were forwarded to an official account, creating a record.
lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law and a White House senior adviser, has used his personal email account to conduct official government business, his lawyer acknowledged on Sunday.

headline: What Stunts Like Milo Yiannopoulos’s ‘Free Speech Week’ Cost
abstract: Despite budget cuts, Berkeley has already spent almost $1.5 million on security this year.
lead_paragraph: In a typical year, the University of California, Berkeley, allocates around $200,000 to pay for security at campus protests. But since this past February, the school has spent some $1.5 million. That enormous sum excludes the $1 million the administration expected to spend this week on Milo Yiannopoulos’s chaotic and disorganized “Free Speech Week.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘No More Agriculture in Puerto Rico,’ a Farmer Laments
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 25, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes when there are shortages, the price of plantain goes up from $1 to $1.25. This time, there won’t be any price increase: There won’t be any product.”

headline: A Promising Debut for the Laver Cup, Buoyed by Two Timeless Stars
abstract: The competition produced plenty of camaraderie and emotion, but whether it has legs beyond the careers of Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Against the percentages and their biological clocks, it has been one of the dreamiest of seasons for Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal. And despite how much of a disrupter Nick Kyrgios can be when he is truly in the mood for tennis, he could not quite provide the buzzkill this weekend.

headline: What Every N.F.L. Team Did During the National Anthem on Sunday
abstract: Across the country, players, coaches and owners staged protests during performances of the national anthem, reacting to comments from President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Widespread calls for demonstrations at Sunday's games erupted after President Trump's comments this weekend criticizing players for kneeling during the national anthem and owners for tolerating the displays. Starting with Jacksonville’s game against Baltimore in London, players, coaches and several owners protested across the league.

headline: When Athletes Share Infections
abstract: The close contact and casual sharing that are components of team bonding can also be a breeding ground for infectious disease.
lead_paragraph: When parents of young athletes reel off their kids’ sports-related health issues, they usually think of sprains, broken bones and concussions. Infectious diseases may not even make the list.

headline: As China Piles on Debt, Consumers Seek a Piece of the Action
abstract: Mortgage and credit card balances are surging, helping Chinese households reach the middle class but adding to the country’s borrowing binge.
lead_paragraph: QIQIHAR, China — Over the past eight years, to the world’s growing alarm, China’s big state-owned companies and powerful local governments have borrowed trillions of dollars to get what they want.

headline: Angela Merkel, N.F.L., Catalonia: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: No Corrections: September 25, 2017
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, September 25, 2017.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Violent Crime in U.S. Rises for Second Consecutive Year
abstract: Experts were divided over why violence rose in consecutive years for the first time since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Violent crime, including homicides, rose for the second consecutive year in 2016, driven by increases in a few urban centers including Baltimore, Chicago and Las Vegas, according to F.B.I. data released Monday.

headline: How’s Your Retirement Saving Coming Along?
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Young Sheldon’ and ‘The Opposition w/ Jordan Klepper’
abstract: A nitpicky 9-year-old Sheldon Cooper navigates high school in a much-anticipated CBS comedy. And Jordan Klepper leaves “The Daily Show” for his new satirical news program.
lead_paragraph: A nitpicky 9-year-old Sheldon Cooper navigates high school in a much-anticipated CBS comedy. And Jordan Klepper leaves “The Daily Show” for his new satirical news program.

headline: Word + Quiz: superimpose
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: After Mexico Earthquake, Tremors of Anxiety
abstract: Even as Mexico City begins to recover and normal rhythms return to its streets, the psychic damage lingers.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Phantom earthquakes strike in the middle of the night, forcing the dreamers out of bed and into a state of panic. Others, their bodies running on five days of adrenaline, find sleeping and even eating impossible. False news reports ricochet through social media, fueled by fear.

headline: Italy Between Past and Future
abstract: Gianni Berengo Gardin photographed Italy as it hovered between agrarian provincialism and an internationally-touted cosmopolitanism.
lead_paragraph: Gianni Berengo Gardin photographed Italy as it hovered between agrarian provincialism and an internationally-touted cosmopolitanism.

headline: Trapped by Their Own Lies
abstract: Why Republicans can win, but can’t govern.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday pretty much the entire medical sector — groups representing doctors, hospitals, and insurers — released an extraordinary open letter condemning the Graham-Cassidy health bill. The letter was written in the style of Emile Zola’s “J’accuse”: a series of paragraphs, each beginning with the bolded words “We agree,” pointing out the bill’s many awful features, from the harm it would do to people with pre-existing conditions to the chaos it would cause in insurance markets.

headline: The Only Way to Defend Against Russia’s Information War
abstract: Americans need to think seriously about why RT, Sputnik and “fake news” resonate with so many people in the first place.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the American presidential election, RT and Sputnik, Russia’s state-funded foreign media networks, have dominated the discussion about the United States’ response to Russian disinformation. This month, the American government debated whether those outlets should be categorized as foreign agents; a recent article in The New York Times Magazine labeled RT “the most effective propaganda operation of the 21st century so far.”

headline: A Rebel, a Warrior and a Race Fiend
abstract: Donald Trump’s insults are about a lot more than football and flags.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is operating the White House as a terror cell of racial grievance in America’s broader culture wars.

headline: How Did Women Fare in China’s Communist Revolution?
abstract: The story of an across-the-board elevation of women’s status under Mao contains crucial caveats.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — My grandmother likes to tell stories from her career as a journalist in the early decades of the People’s Republic of China. She recalls scrawling down Chairman Mao’s latest pronouncements as they came through loudspeakers and talking with joyous peasants from the newly collectivized countryside. In what was her career highlight, she turned an anonymous candy salesman into a national labor hero with glowing praises for his service to the people.

headline: Becoming a Columnist in the Age of Trump
abstract: Gail Collins welcomes Michelle Goldberg to The Times.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Michelle, welcome aboard. I’m sure people are telling you that being a Times columnist is the best job in the world. It’s actually true, except for the deadline thing. When’s your first column?

headline: Descartes Is Not Our Father
abstract: History tells us he invented modern philosophy. That history is wrong.
lead_paragraph: René Descartes has long been credited with the near-single-handed creation of modern philosophy. Generations of students have read, and continue to read, his famous “Meditations” as the rejection of medieval ways of thinking and the invention of the modern self. They learned that he doubted all traditional ways of knowing before pivoting to the modern subjective individual. Tumbling into a “deep whirlpool,” the doubter of the “Meditations” has no secure footing until he hits upon a single firm and indubitable truth: He is most essentially “a thinking thing.” The modern individual is born, with the rejection of the past as its midwife.

headline: Why Do You Care How Much Other People Work? Revisited
abstract: Basically, you shouldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Greg Leiserson has an interesting post on assessing tax reform, in which he argues that distribution tables — showing the direct gains and losses from a tax change — properly measure welfare gains, and don’t need to be revised to consider the induced effects on labor supply, effort etc.

headline: Italy Between Past and Future
abstract: Gianni Berengo Gardin photographed Italy as it hovered between agrarian provincialism and an internationally-touted cosmopolitanism
lead_paragraph: There they are again, the perpetual Italian migrants. They wait on a platform at the Milan train station in 1970, their many suitcases secured with rope, their bags filled to the brim. A box of panettone, a Milanese holiday specialty, accompanies this family of travelers, suggesting Christmastime. Dressed for the cold, the family of five — parents, children, and an older woman wearing black from head to toe — gaze to the right, pondering perhaps their unknown destinies. We see them in Gianni Berengo Gardin’s photograph, shot at mid-distance from above, a portrait of Italy as a migrant nation.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Immigration Officials Taking New Steps to Discourage Smuggling of Children’
abstract: Who are the people being targeted by immigration officials seeking to reduce the number of young people being smuggled into the United States?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Swiss Firm ABB to Buy G.E.’s Industrial Solutions Business for $2.6 Billion
abstract: The deal comes as new General Electric chief executive John L. Flannery conducts a review of each of its businesses.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss engineering firm ABB Group said on Monday that it would buy General Electric’s business that provides circuit breakers and other electrical equipment for industry for $2.6 billion, as the American giant looks for ways to shake up its operations.

headline: Clues to Prehistoric Cave Painters Remain Scant
abstract: Little is known about the cave paintings in France and Spain made tens of thousands of years ago.
lead_paragraph: Q. Who were the artists who made prehistoric cave paintings in France and Spain?

headline: Special Ops Forces: How Elite Forces Became Military Muscle
abstract: United States Special Operations forces, deployed across the globe, have grown in power and numbers over four decades. But are they stretched too thin?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to just about every policy set by Barack Obama, President Trump has proved to be a dedicated Marxist. As in Groucho Marx. In the 1932 film “Horse Feathers,” Marx sang, “Whatever it is, I’m against it.” The same holds for Mr. Trump, who has made dismantling the Obama legacy his goal, one program at a time.

headline: Keeping Indian Folk Painting Alive
abstract: An award-winning Madhubani painter explains the historic art form and how she plans to help keep it alive.
lead_paragraph: An award-winning Madhubani painter explains the historic art form and how she plans to help keep it alive.

headline: ‘Lonely Scholar With Unusual Ideas’ Defends Trump, Igniting Legal Storm
abstract: A scholar’s fight, invoking Alexander Hamilton, to show that the Constitution does not bar foreign payments to the president yielded a barrage of attacks, and then an apology.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seth Barrett Tillman is a lecturer in the law department of Maynooth University in Ireland. He is, he said in a recent court filing, a “lonely scholar with unusual ideas, who is unaffiliated with the popular, the organized and the wealthy.”

headline: Syrian War Drags On, but Assad’s Future Looks as Secure as Ever
abstract: Bashar al-Assad has not declared victory, but no one is left who could oust him, and regional powers increasingly operate as though he is here to stay.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Although Syria’s bloody six-year war is far from over, one result is already becoming clear: President Bashar al-Assad looks as though he is here to stay.

headline: For Cities Wooing Amazon’s New Headquarters, Nothing Is Too Strange
abstract: Officials and business leaders across North America are going to extreme lengths to court Amazon to put its second headquarters in their city.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Business leaders in Tucson have tried to mail Amazon’s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, a 21-foot cactus. The largest conference room in the Tulsa, Okla., mayor’s office has been converted to a war room, with 50 volunteers poring over videos of Mr. Bezos.

headline: In a Quiet Ohio Town, Who Started the Fire, and Why?
abstract: Celeste Ng’s “Little Fires Everywhere” witnesses the mysteries of arson, kinship and community in late-’90s suburban America.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Celeste Ng’s second novel, “Little Fires Everywhere,” will recognize a few elements from her acclaimed debut, “Everything I Never Told You.” There are the simmering racial tensions and incendiary family dynamics beneath the surface of a quiet Ohio town. There are the appeal and impossibility of assimilation, the all-consuming force of motherhood and the secret lives of teenagers and their parents, each unknowable to the other.

headline: How Special Ops Became Central to the War on Terror
abstract: The allure of elite commandos parachuting in to tackle "mission impossible" began with two operations -- one a huge success and the other a massive failure.
lead_paragraph: The allure of elite commandos parachuting in to tackle "mission impossible" began with two operations -- one a huge success and the other a massive failure.

headline: Shopping for Sectional Sofas
abstract: Unlike conventional sofas, sectionals offer a multitude of design possibilities. Just make sure the one you choose isn’t so big it swallows the room.
lead_paragraph: Unlike stiff, formal sofas, sectionals come with the promise of fun. Not only are they made from modular elements that can be rearranged, but “they are usually the flop-down, fall-into pieces in a room,” said David Mann, the founding partner of MR Architecture + Decor, in New York.

headline: A Battle to Save the World’s Favorite Treat: Chocolate
abstract: In Costa Rica, researchers are cloning cacao hybrids resistant to frosty pod rot, a blight that has spread throughout Latin America.
lead_paragraph: TURRIALBA, Costa Rica — The trees of the International Cacao Collection grow here in an astonishing diversity of forms, bearing skinny cacao pods with scorpion-stinger protrusions, spherical green pods that could be mistaken for tomatillos, oblong pods with bumpy skin resembling that of the horned lizard — all in colors ranging from deep purple to bright yellow.

headline: On the Market in Toronto
abstract: This week’s properties include a two-bedroom in the Distillery District and a four-bedroom in the Beach area.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a two-bedroom in the Distillery District and a four-bedroom in the Beach area.

headline: Homes for Sale in Toronto
abstract: This week’s properties include a two-bedroom in the Distillery District and a four-bedroom in the Beach area.
lead_paragraph: The market for Toronto homes has picked up in recent weeks, with some houses being scooped up after just a few days on the market, brokers say. Buyers who waited to see how effective the Ontario government’s recent measures would be at bursting the real estate bubble, are now entering the market to cautiously make purchases. As the market rebounds, brokers also say they are seeing a slight uptick in bidding wars, but nowhere near as much competition as there was in the first half of the year.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 25, 2017
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 28, 2017

headline: When a Drug Coupon Helps You but Hurts Fellow Citizens
abstract: Sometimes a course of action that makes perfect sense for individuals hurts the collective.
lead_paragraph: It’s completely rational for you to use coupons to reduce the cost of your brand-name drug purchase.

headline: Shinzo Abe of Japan Calls Early Election, as a Rival Party Forms
abstract: The prime minister’s announcement comes as his approval ratings have been rising during the North Korea crisis and the economy has been growing.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Seizing on anxiety over tensions about North Korea and the opposition’s weakness, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan called Monday for an early election next month.

headline: N.F.L., Angela Merkel, Iraqi Kurdistan: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Philippines Promises Vietnam a Full Investigation Into Fishermen’s Deaths
abstract: The two Vietnamese fishermen were shot as a navy patrol boat pursued them in Philippine waters, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine government said on Monday that it had promised Vietnam a “fair and thorough” investigation into the deaths of two Vietnamese fishermen as they were being pursued by the Philippine Navy over the weekend.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Protest on the N.F.L. Sidelines
abstract: We discuss how President Trump has forced professional athletes to become more political.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: A Plague and a Blessing in My Empty Nest
abstract: By the time I dropped my daughter off at college, we were both bejeweled with the raised itchy bumps of flea bites.
lead_paragraph: A week before I took my only daughter to college in another state this fall, our house became infested with fleas. Combined with the impending sense of child loss, it felt like a biblical plague. Bites accumulated around our ankles and feet, and on me at least, seemed to work their way up further every night toward my neck. By the time I dropped her off, we were both riddled with the raised itchy bumps that we have a shared penchant for scratching raw.

headline: New York Today: Why Do We Yawn?
abstract: Monday: Doctors explain the phenomenon, where to donate to hurricane relief efforts, and the Library HotSpot Program.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this, yawn, Monday.

headline: Can You Find Rwanda on a Map?
abstract: A weekly interactive quiz to celebrate the world’s diverse geography.
lead_paragraph: A weekly interactive quiz to celebrate the world’s diverse geography.

headline: Vision and Hearing Loss Are Tied to Cognitive Decline
abstract: When the brain struggles to make sense of the world it may be less able to perform other important tasks.
lead_paragraph: Now and then I hear someone (myself included) proclaim “my brain is on overload.” This is not surprising given the myriad complex tasks the brain performs, among them enabling you to learn, plan, remember, communicate, see, hear and smell.

headline: A Visit to Italian Villages That Inspired the Term ‘Riviera’
abstract: Liguria is a place of unvarnished beauty, where the draw is the simplicity of its timeless way of life.
lead_paragraph: Finale Ligure, a sun-baked town at the edge of the Ligurian Sea, has no symphony orchestra or opera house. But it has a maestro of its own: Franco Morasca, the manager of Bagni Est Finale, a no-frills, private club on the beach that pulls in generations of Italians each summer for a reminder of what it means to be Italian.

headline: Touching on History, a Chinese Film May Have Been Burned by It
abstract: The premiere of “Youth,” set against the Cultural Revolution, has been abruptly delayed, and some blame official jitters as a Communist Party congress approaches.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One of China’s most popular directors, Feng Xiaogang, was determined to triumph at the box office with the release of his new film “Youth” during the weeklong National Day holiday.

headline: Pain for N.F.L. Partners; German Elections: DealBook Briefing
abstract: While many players and owners rebuked President Trump’s comments on protests, ratings declines could mean trouble for broadcasters and sponsors.
lead_paragraph: The biggest clash in the N.F.L. over the weekend was off the field — but the battle over protests may soon draw in the broadcasters, deep-pocketed sponsors who partner with the league as well.

headline: Uber C.E.O., Reacting to London Ban, Apologizes for ‘Mistakes’
abstract: Dara Khosrowshahi said in an open letter that the ride-hailing service had “got things wrong.” The company will appeal a decision over its right to operate in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Uber’s chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, apologized in an open letter on Monday for the company’s “mistakes,” after the transport authority for London said last week that it would not renew the ride-hailing service’s license to operate in the city.

headline: Carmelo Anthony: No N.B.A. Title, but Lots of Olympic Gold
abstract: In Rio de Janeiro last year, Anthony, a cornerstone of the American team, earned his third Olympic championship.
lead_paragraph: At 33, Carmelo Anthony is a lot closer to the end of his career than the beginning. His trade from the Knicks to Oklahoma City on Saturday had the feel of a last chance to go for a championship.

headline: As Kurds Celebrate Independence Vote, Neighbors Threaten Military Action
abstract: The vote, a milestone in Kurdish aspirations for their own state, was opposed by Iraq, Turkey and Iran, which held military exercises on the border.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — As jubilant Iraqi Kurds celebrated their vote Monday on independence from Iraq, shooting off fireworks and parading in cars festooned with Kurdish flags late into the night, their neighbors conducted military exercises on the region’s borders, raising the threat of military intervention if it secedes.

headline: National Anthem Protests by Black Athletes Have a Long History
abstract: The protests by African-American athletes date back decades, often angering mostly white fans and officials.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s outbursts against professional athletes protesting racial injustice and the defiant response of N.F.L. teams on Sunday brought a renewed focus on political demonstrations during the national anthem at sports events.

headline: Trump’s N.F.L. Critique a Calculated Attempt to Shore Up His Base
abstract: White House officials said President Trump is deeply worried that his recent show of bipartisanship endangers his standing with conservatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was restless on the flight home from his rally on Friday night in Alabama, griping about the size of the crowd, wondering how his pink tie played with his audience and fretting about the low energy of the Senate candidate he was there to bolster.

headline: Airbnb Offers Tours With New Yorkers (No Vacation Rental Required)
abstract: The vacation rental company adds a city to its list of places where you can buy a tour.
lead_paragraph: In the grand debate over whether New Yorkers are inherently charming or churlish, Airbnb seems to be placing its bets on the former.

headline: California Today: Bay Area Athletes Clash With Trump
abstract: Monday: Bay Area athletes take on President Trump, generous pensions at the University of California, and a new state symbol: a duck-billed dinosaur.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: How to Eat Healthy on a Trip
abstract: Tips for maintaining a healthy diet, even when your only option is fast food.
lead_paragraph: When you’re on vacation, the temptations to overdo the eating and drinking are everywhere, said the New York-based nutritionist Joy Bauer.

headline: Pharrell Williams ‘Takes a Knee’ as Artists Join Anthem Protest
abstract: Mr. Williams knelt during a concert in Charlottesville, Va., on Sunday to show solidarity with N.F.L. players. Stevie Wonder, Eddie Vedder and others have joined in.
lead_paragraph: The singer and producer Pharrell Williams is the latest entertainer to show solidarity with N.F.L. players protesting President Trump’s call to fire players who refuse to stand during the national anthem.

headline: Read Both Sides of the Trump-N.F.L. Fight
abstract: How much have you thought about why so many of your fellow Americans disagree with those athletes’ protests?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Tom Brady: ‘I Certainly Disagree’ With What Trump Said
abstract: A day after locking one arm with a teammate during the anthem, Brady shared his thoughts about the issue in a radio interview.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, every N.F.L. player and team had to make a decision about what to do during the national anthem: whether to stand, kneel, sit, lock arms or just remain in the locker room.

headline: In Dire Straits, Connecticut Nears 90 Days Without Budget
abstract: Months of wrangling in the State Legislature over cuts has not led to a resolution. Many have grown frustrated. Some are working without pay.
lead_paragraph: Every day, Brent Peterkin still puts on a suit and tie and drives to his job in New Haven as statewide coordinator for Project Longevity, a program to thwart gun violence and redirect potential gang members in some of Connecticut’s most crime-ridden neighborhoods. It is also one of many social services nonprofit organizations that has lost its funding as the state approaches three months of operating without a budget.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ Season 1, Episode 1: Engaging the Klingon
abstract: The first episode of “Star Trek: Discovery” was promising and worrisome at the same time, with great performances to boot.
lead_paragraph: After multiple stops and starts the highly anticipated “Star Trek: Discovery” finally hit impulse speed on Sunday and this recapper set his phasers on disbelief.

headline: In Germany, the Center Holds
abstract: Yes, the far-right Alternative for Germany party did well. But the overwhelming majority rejected its appeal.
lead_paragraph: Sunday was a dark day for Germany. For the first time in its postwar history, a far-right party won enough votes to enter the Bundestag. And not by a hair, either — the Alternative for Germany, or AfD, won 12.6 percent, ahead of stalwart parties like the Greens and the pro-business Free Democrats, making it the third-largest caucus among the seven represented in the Parliament. It’s shocking. It’s a catastrophe.

headline: Russia Committed ‘Grave’ Rights Abuses in Crimea, U.N. Says
abstract: Investigators have documented evidence of arbitrary detentions, torture and abductions since Russian troops annexed the former Ukrainian region.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Russia has committed “multiple and grave” human rights abuses in Crimea since reclaiming the territory three years ago, the United Nations said on Monday, including arbitrary arrests, torture and the imposition of Russian citizenship on residents of the former Ukrainian region.

headline: Steelers’ Villanueva Takes a Stand, but Might Agree With Kaepernick’s Mission
abstract: The 6-8, 320-pound lineman, a former Army Ranger, was the only member of the Steelers to stand outside the tunnel on Sunday during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: When Alejandro Villanueva, the Pittsburgh Steelers’ starting left tackle, arrived at West Point for cadet basic training in the summer of 2006, he already stood out — and not just because he was bigger than anyone else.

headline: Anthony Weiner Gets 21 Months in Prison for Sexting With Teenager
abstract: The sentencing may finally signal an end to the long and tortuous downfall of the former New York congressman.
lead_paragraph: He lost his seat in Congress, his audacious bid to resurrect his career as mayor of New York City, and his high-profile marriage. And he undermined Hillary Clinton’s shot at the presidency in the closing days of the tumultuous 2016 campaign.

headline: How Did Marriage Become a Mark of Privilege?
abstract: Liberals fault the economy for the drop in marriage among the less educated, while conservatives blame changing values. Both may be on to something.
lead_paragraph: Marriage, which used to be the default way to form a family in the United States, regardless of income or education, has become yet another part of American life reserved for those who are most privileged.

headline: Pandas Are No Longer Endangered. But Their Habitat Is in Trouble.
abstract: Logging, human encroachment and activities have fragmented the natural range of pandas in China, which could make recent population gains short-lived.
lead_paragraph: One year after giant pandas graduated from endangered to “vulnerable,” a welcome designation after 28 years, Chinese scientists have sobering news: The animal’s natural habitat in China is in serious danger.

headline: Cooking With Meera Sodha
abstract: Make the British cookbook writer’s terrific (and terrifically simple) recipes for roasted broccoli with cardamom or Sri Lankan dal with coconut and lime.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Ball Gowns, Lace Ruffs and Fairy Wings: Theater History for Sale
abstract: The Royal Shakespeare Company sold a third of its costumes to finance the renovation of its workshop and specialist apprenticeships.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — Have you ever wanted to step into the shoes of a great Shakespearean actor? Over the weekend, shoppers here in Shakespeare’s birthplace, which is also the home of the Royal Shakespeare Company, had a chance to walk away with a piece of theatrical history, as the legendary company held a sale of 15,000 costumes and other items.

headline: North Korea Says It Has the Right to Shoot Down U.S. Warplanes
abstract: The country’s foreign minister also said the North considered President Trump’s threatening comments about the country and its leadership “a declaration of war.”
lead_paragraph: North Korea threatened on Monday to shoot down American warplanes even if they were not in the country’s airspace, stating that President Trump’s comments suggesting he would eradicate North Korea and its leaders were “a declaration of war.”

headline: China Blocks WhatsApp, Broadening Online Censorship
abstract: With a crucial Communist Party meeting just weeks away, Beijing is further tightening its already formidable internet controls.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China has largely blocked the WhatsApp messaging app, the latest move by Beijing to step up surveillance ahead of a big Communist Party gathering next month.

headline: Alternative for Germany: Who Are They, and What Do They Want?
abstract: The party that placed third in Sunday’s German elections is a young right-wing movement with divided leadership and a nationalist message.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As Chancellor Angela Merkel won her fourth term in power on Sunday, nearly 6 million Germans — 12.6 percent of those who voted — cast their ballots for an upstart, populist party that has denounced her: Alternative for Germany. Here’s a guide to the far-right party that could reshape German politics.

headline: Wheelchair Racer Aron Anderson Has Another Mountain to Climb
abstract: The triathlete has done Kilimanjaro, and would like to conquer Aconcagua in Argentina. The North Pole is on his list too.
lead_paragraph: At age 7, Aron Anderson was diagnosed with cancer. Two years later, doctors removed a tumor from his lower back and the boy who once loved to play soccer lost the use of his legs. But his wheelchair “changed my life,” said Mr. Anderson, 29, a native of Sweden. He began wheelchair racing competitively and has participated in four Paralympic Games. To challenge himself and raise money for the Swedish Childhood Cancer Foundation, he began making expeditions, including climbing Mount Kilimanjaro, biking from Malmö, Sweden to Paris and, last year, skiing across Antarctica, a monthlong journey that raised roughly $800,000. As a triathlete, he plans to compete in the handcycle division of the Ironman World Championship race in Hawaii in October. As an inspirational speaker, he travels frequently and his autobiography, “Opportunities,” was recently published in Sweden. The following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Anderson.

headline: The Kurds of County Leitrim: Refugees Call an Irish Town Home
abstract: About 100 Kurdish refugees were resettled in a small town in Ireland. Time, tragedy and hurling eventually made them feel part of the community.
lead_paragraph: CARRICK-ON-SHANNON, Ireland — A bold black-and-red sign announces Jamshid Ghafur’s business — “Kurdish Barber” — up a narrow flight of stairs just off the main street of Carrick-on-Shannon in western Ireland.

headline: Engrave Your Own Stationery Template
abstract: Microsoft Word comes with many sample document templates, but you can also create your own custom letterhead.
lead_paragraph: Q. Microsoft Word 2016 comes with plenty of templates, but none of them are quite what I want. Is there a way to modify one of the stock business letters into a multipage document with my own letterhead?

headline: Jennifer Lopez Donates $1 Million to Puerto Rico Relief Effort
abstract: The singer, who is of Puerto Rican descent, is leading a New York-state-wide donation drive in the wake of Hurricanes Irma and Maria.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez has announced that she will donate $1 million to the relief effort in Puerto Rico following the devastation caused by Hurricanes Irma and Maria.

headline: Actor Tobias Menzies on the ‘Outlander’ Death We All Knew Was Coming
abstract: Just because we knew it had to happen, didn’t mean it felt good.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “Outlander” through Season 3, Episode 3.

headline: Cardi B’s ‘Bodak Yellow’ Makes Its Move to No. 1
abstract: The rapper’s song displaced Taylor Swift from the top of the Hot 100 while Foo Fighters’ “Concrete and Gold” debuted at No. 1 on the album chart.
lead_paragraph: It is not just any woman who can knock Taylor Swift from No. 1.

headline: Unilever to Buy Carver, Korean Cosmetics Company, in Bid for Asian Growth
abstract: The $2.7 billion deal highlights the conglomerate’s efforts to expand into fast-growing products like skin care.
lead_paragraph: In its pursuit of growth, Unilever is moving away from mayonnaise and toward makeup.

headline: Want to Get Smarter Fast? Get In Over Your Head
abstract: The quickest way to self-improvement may well be to jump into the deep end of the pool and paddle furiously.
lead_paragraph: Being in over your head may be the best way to learn what you’re capable of. Consider the following example of someone we’ll call David.

headline: In a Lost Essay, a Glimpse of an Elusive Poet and Slave
abstract: A previously unknown manuscript by George Moses Horton, a poet and slave, opens a window onto eerily familiar debates about race, power and free speech on campus.
lead_paragraph: Around 1817, George Moses Horton, an enslaved young man from Chatham County, N.C., began walking to the town of Chapel Hill on weekends to sell his owner’s fruit. Horton, who had taught himself to read but could not yet write, also offered more unusual goods: poems.

headline: Trump and Arctic Drilling
abstract: An environmental advocate calls on Congress and Americans to defend this fragile place.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eric Reid: Why Colin Kaepernick and I Decided to Take a Knee
abstract: We chose the gesture purposefully. Our bodies were like flags flown at half-mast to mark a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In early 2016, I began paying attention to reports about the incredible number of unarmed black people being killed by the police. The posts on social media deeply disturbed me, but one in particular brought me to tears: the killing of Alton Sterling in my hometown Baton Rouge, La. This could have happened to any of my family members who still live in the area. I felt furious, hurt and hopeless. I wanted to do something, but didn’t know what or how to do it. All I knew for sure is that I wanted it to be as respectful as possible.

headline: Review: Faustin Linyekula’s Twin Peaks of Mourning and Joy
abstract: Displacement and obscured histories, but also joyful fluidity: Two projects by the Congolese choreographer.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through Faustin Linyekula’s “In Search of Dinozord” on Saturday, amid fragments of Mozart’s “Requiem” and organ music by Arvo Pärt, a lighter melody drifted through the theater: the refrain of an incoming Skype call.

headline: Review: A ‘Law and Order’ Where ‘Whodunit’ Meets ‘Who Cares’
abstract: The NBC crime franchise extends its brand to true crime, but there’s not enough life in “The Menendez Murders.”
lead_paragraph: In the criminal-entertainment system, ripped-from-the-headlines dramas are represented by two separate groups.

headline: How South Koreans Cope With Kim Jong-un
abstract: A reader says the South Koreans carry on with life, ignoring Kim’s antics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: American Oil Worker Is Kidnapped in Yemen
abstract: No one has claimed responsibility for the kidnapping. The American had lived in Yemen for years, married a Yemeni woman and worked for a local oil company.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — An American oil worker was abducted from his car by unidentified gunmen on a busy street in the Yemeni capital, his wife and colleagues said on Monday.

headline: Supreme Court Cancels Hearing on Previous Trump Travel Ban
abstract: But questions remain about how the new travel ban will be implemented, who will be affected, how the countries were picked and whether it will prevent terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday abruptly canceled oral arguments on President Trump’s travel ban, signaling the beginning of the end for a politically charged legal case that could have produced a blockbuster ruling on the clash between presidential power and claims of religious discrimination.

headline: Was It a One-Day Revolt in the N.F.L., or Something More?
abstract: This movement could force real change, unless the owners and players get back to business as usual.
lead_paragraph: LANDOVER, Md. — It was undeniably a monumental Sunday for the National Football League. There were teams that were no-shows for the national anthem, and others that linked arms with owners. Players knelt and sat during the anthem, and some raised their fists.

headline: It’s Canned Tomato Season. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: For everyday cooking, canned often outperform fresh. Julia Moskin tastes and investigates 10 top brands.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — At last: Canned tomatoes are back in season.

headline: Stephen King and Son Team Up for a Novel About Women Whose Sleep Should Not Be Disturbed
abstract: In “Sleeping Beauties,” by Stephen King and his son Owen, women who fall asleep don’t wake up, and grow tendrils that are best left alone.
lead_paragraph: Stephen King’s enthralling “Under the Dome” (2009) dreamed up a small Maine town thrown into a surreal situation: The place was suddenly covered by an invisible, impermeable dome. It’s a sprawling book with a big cast of characters, but the drama of this crisis brings every one of them into sharp focus. It’s one of his best books, drawing its terror from human nature, not from a voyage into fearsome fantasyland.

headline: ‘Mother!’: What You Should Read After Watching Darren Aronofsky’s Polarizing Film
abstract: Love it or hate it, it’s got people talking.
lead_paragraph: Darren Aronofsky, the maximalist auteur behind “Black Swan,” “The Wrestler” and “Requiem for a Dream,” has always attracted his share of devoted fans and vocal detractors. But his home-invasion thriller “Mother!,” which hit theaters earlier this month, has quickly become his most controversial work.

headline: Las Vegas Police Officer Fatally Shoots Man at a Hospital
abstract: The man, who was taken to the hospital because he was extremely intoxicated, was shot after taking a Taser from a bag left in a room and pointing it at the officer.
lead_paragraph: A Las Vegas police officer fatally shot a man who was in custody at a hospital early Monday morning after the man took a Taser that had been left in a room and pointed it at the officer, the police said.

headline: G.O.P. Points to Welfare Overhaul as a Model for Health Care. The Comparison Has Limits.
abstract: Republicans praise the latest Affordable Care Act repeal as the successor to the 1996 welfare overhaul, but few would cheer a plunge in insurance coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As they propose to give each state a wad of federal cash to replace the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance, Senate Republicans have a ready comparison to press their case: the overhaul of welfare adopted two decades ago.

headline: Moths, Alive and in Color, in All Their Diversity
abstract: A new collection from the photographer Emmet Gowin delivers an appreciation for the hidden ties between humans and moths as well as art and science.
lead_paragraph: Moths belong to the night. We often only see them when light sends them spiraling down to surfaces, where they land and sit still, beaming out messages like antennaed aliens: Greetings from the World of Darkness.

headline: Review: A Flock of Shylocks Transforms ‘Merchant of Venice’
abstract: Karin Coonrod’s inventive production of Shakespeare’s notorious comedy has five actors playing the moneylender. It sounds gimmicky but it works.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The first gathering of the Shylocks is a sobering sight, instantly pushing comedy into the borders of tragedy. This chilling vision occurs halfway through what has thus far been an unusually blithe production of Shakespeare’s “The Merchant of Venice,” directed by Karin Coonrod at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University.

headline: Street Style: Milan
abstract: As Milan Fashion Week winds down, we take a look at what the stylish set photographer Acielle Tanbetova saw between shows.
lead_paragraph: As Milan Fashion Week winds down, we take a look at what the stylish set photographer Acielle Tanbetova saw between shows.

headline: Trump vs. N.F.L. Players Who Kneel
abstract: Readers discuss the players’ protest during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alternate Site for Conferences: Movie Theaters
abstract: They’ve come a long way from the days of sticky floors and uncomfortable seats. Many offer extensive food offerings and the technology used for 3-D films.
lead_paragraph: Before the lights dimmed at a summer showing of “Wonder Woman” in Bridgeport, Conn., an advertisement flashed on the screen for the movie theater itself — as a venue for meetings, events and small conferences.

headline: Report Finds Gaps in Access to Opioid Addiction Help on Staten Island
abstract: Prosecutors and public health experts team up to help find ways to curb the opioid epidemic in the New York City borough.
lead_paragraph: New York City was in the throes of an alarming increase in opioid-related overdoses last summer when the city’s special narcotics prosecutor, Bridget G. Brennan, decided to follow up on a tip — not about a drug crime but about a potential academic collaboration. The approach revealed a severe treatment gap for addicts on Staten Island.

headline: Reddit Limits Noxious Content by Giving Trolls Fewer Places to Gather
abstract: A new study shows that the website reduced hate speech by shutting down two particularly poisonous forums. The findings could have implications for social networks like Twitter and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: There are — and always have been, and probably always will be — trolls, scoundrels and reprobates on the internet.

headline: Poland’s President Offers New Path to End Court Crisis
abstract: When he vetoed laws to alter Poland’s courts, President Andrzej Duda promised his own plan. On Monday, he unveiled it. Nearly everyone found fault.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Two months after vetoing laws to restructure the Polish court system that had drawn sharp rebukes from the European Union and brought thousands of protesters into the summer streets, President Andrzej Duda on Monday offered his own draft versions of the legislation.

headline: When Black Children Are Targeted for Punishment
abstract: Harsher discipline for black students is not just a Southern or state-level problem.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years ago today, Minnijean Brown and eight other black students walked into all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., as angry white protesters shouted obscenities, spat on them and threatened violence in full view of television cameras.

headline: Why Kaepernick Takes the Knee
abstract: And why it’s not enough to link arms instead.
lead_paragraph: Given the fiery responses to Colin Kaepernick’s protest during the national anthem — taking a knee, a gesture now being adopted by a wave of professional athletes — you would think that it was a militant motion, full of anger and menace, akin to the Black Power salutes raised by Tommie Smith and John Carlos at the 1968 Olympics. But kneeling during the national anthem is a gesture of humility, not ominous ire.

headline: FloFab’s Top 10: Special Ingredients to Elevate Your Pantry
abstract: They aren’t often cheap, but these items are worthwhile investments, a safe-deposit collection for flavor.
lead_paragraph: My husband sometimes complains that there’s never anything to eat in the house. If you examine my pantry, the only option might be eggs — and those take a bit of effort. I can remember desperation crackers, smeared with mustard, during late-night cram sessions in my college dorm, but that’s not the point. This is not a list of what to eat, but what you must have to be primed to prepare something good.

headline: Germany’s Far Right Complicates Life for Merkel, and the E.U.
abstract: Political fragmentation and populism in Germany will make it harder for Angela Merkel to pair with President Emmanuel Macron of France to revitalize Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Angela Merkel’s re-election as chancellor of Germany was supposed to be the ceremonial capstone of a year in which Europe did better than anticipated in holding off a populist surge, especially after the new French president, Emmanuel Macron, won so decisively over the National Front of Marine Le Pen.

headline: Aaron Judge Hits 2 More Homers, Breaking Mark McGwire’s Rookie Record
abstract: Home run No. 49 came in the third inning Monday at Yankee Stadium against Kansas City. Home run No. 50, the record-breaker, came in the seventh.
lead_paragraph: Ned Yost is not the kind of manager who dwells on statistics. Two years ago, his Kansas City Royals had the fewest strikeouts in the majors and won the World Series. Hitting for contact was in.

headline: At Tales of the Cocktail, the Founder Steps Down
abstract: Ann R. Tuennerman, the founder of the annual cocktail convention in New Orleans, has resigned following a controversy that began with a Mardi Gras costume.
lead_paragraph: The founder of Tales of the Cocktail, the New Orleans convention that has become a must-attend annual town hall for the drinks business, announced Saturday that she would step down, months after a controversial costumed ride in a Mardi Gras parade.

headline: Behind the Scenes of Angela Missoni’s 20th Anniversary Show
abstract: The designer prepares for her spring/summer 2018 collection – followed by a big party.
lead_paragraph: The designer prepares for her spring/summer 2018 collection – followed by a big party.

headline: 48 Hours in Milan With Angela Missoni
abstract: T follows along as the designer readies for her spring/summer 2018 show — which marks her 20th anniversary at the helm of her parents’ luxury brand.
lead_paragraph: At high noon on Friday, a day before showtime, Angela Missoni is everywhere. The glass-roofed former warehouse that holds Missoni’s Milan showroom is abuzz with comings and goings, but the fastest moving target is the designer herself, pursued by stylists, producers, assistants, PR, camera people and me.

headline: In Trump Era, Boeing Trade Case Boils Over Into ‘Multicountry Feud’
abstract: World leaders have urged President Trump to intervene in a trade case that could reshape the aerospace industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Boeing is no stranger to disputes with foreign competitors, but a rising tide of protectionism has turned its most recent trade disagreement into an international throw down.

headline: North Korea, Japan, Myanmar: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Republicans Are Remarkably Good At Uniting Opposition Against Themselves
abstract: The Republican health care bill achieved a stunning feat: it united most of the health care industry against it.
lead_paragraph: The Republican health care bill achieved a stunning feat: it united most of the health care industry against it.

headline: From a Master Chef, Grandfatherly Advice
abstract: Jacques Pépin and his granddaughter talk cooking and table manners in “A Grandfather’s Lessons.”
lead_paragraph: In his many decades at the stove, the chef Jacques Pépin has accumulated a priceless depth of knowledge, and he communicates it freely, with wit and self-effacing charm. Any novice cook, not just a teenager, has much to gain as Mr. Pépin describes cooking with his 13-year-old granddaughter in his new book, “A Grandfather’s Lessons.” The first? Cook as a family. Second and third (and these are from his granddaughter) are to set a table properly and practice good manners. Mr. Pépin gives lessons in sourcing ingredients like fish, then provides an easy microwave horseradish cream sauce for fillets. Experienced cooks should note a mayonnaise-based dressing called “mayogrette,” and how buttered, sugared bread fingers become emergency cookies. Mr. Pépin also delivers an excellent caramel tutorial. Yet for all his Gallic expertise, he does not ignore ribs and hot dogs: “A Grandfather’s Lessons: In the Kitchen with Shorey,” by Jacques Pépin (Rux Martin/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $30).

headline: Wildfires, Earthquakes and Hurricanes: Is All This Normal?
abstract: A climate reporter for The Times explains what you should know about recent disasters that have struck in quick succession.
lead_paragraph: A climate reporter for The Times explains what you should know about recent disasters that have struck in quick succession.

headline: How Much Time Was Spent on Subway? M.T.A. Can Now Tell You
abstract: A digital dashboard will provide subway riders with detailed information about commutes, from time spent waiting on the platform to the ride itself.
lead_paragraph: Was the commute on New York City’s subway this month worse than last month? Did it feel like the trains were running slower because it was a hot and sticky morning? Exactly how many minutes of the day were spent on delayed trains or crowded platforms?

headline: No-Fuss Aprons for the Home Cook
abstract: This cover-up from the designer Mariana Velasquez is easy to slip over your clothes.
lead_paragraph: This apron is easy to slip on over your clothes, has no ties to fuss with and comes in an array of attractive colors and patterns — details that set these loose and effective smocks apart. They are the work of Mariana Velasquez, a Colombian chef and designer, and are made of cotton or linen: Buenlimón aprons, $80 to $120, marianavelasquez.com.

headline: A Crisp Refresher Course in Home-Brewing
abstract: Learn beer fundamentals and tour the historic Ballantine House at the Newark Museum.
lead_paragraph: The ultimate homemade weeknight dinner should include a home brew. Ballantine House, now a wing of the Newark Museum, was built for the brewing family in 1885, and it will provide the inspiration for a hands-on course in brewing. The classes will be held in the MakerSPACE of the museum, led by Thomas Jambor, a founder of the Morris Area Society of Homebrewers. It runs for four sessions, and participants will take home know-how and two six-packs of beer: Ballantine House Beer-Making Course, 6 to 8 p.m., Oct. 25 and Nov. 1, 8 and 15, $120 for museum members, $140 for nonmembers, Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street (Washington Place), Newark, 973-596-6690, newarkmuseum.org.

headline: Olive Wood Utensils Make an Attractive Addition to the Table
abstract: An assortment of spatulas and spoons from Italy are now available.
lead_paragraph: Handmade olive-wood utensils are a practical addition on the kitchen counter and handsome on the table. Marcelli Formaggi, a cheese company, imports quite an assortment from Abruzzo, Italy. I especially like the sturdy container for the spatulas, spoons and such because it is heavy enough so as not to topple over. That the utensils cannot go in the dishwasher may be a drawback, but then, I never put anything wood in the dishwasher: Olive wood utensils, $8 to $125; tool holder, $45 (tools sold separately), marcelliformaggi.com.

headline: ‘Saul Leiter’ by François Halard
abstract: Photos of the East Village apartment that the New York School photographer left behind.
lead_paragraph: Photos of the East Village apartment that the New York School photographer left behind.

headline: Where an Iconic East Village Photographer Lived
abstract: A new photo book documents Saul Leiter’s apartment two years after his death, for a close look at what he left behind.
lead_paragraph: Two years after the New York School photographer Saul Leiter died, François Halard had the good fortune to come across the East Village apartment where Leiter lived for more than half a century. Leiter had created some of his best-known work there: gritty scenes of Manhattan streets in the ’50s and ’60s. There was almost nothing left but the barest traces of Leiter’s life — boxes of photographs, a paper lantern, an unfinished sketchbook, a lonely chair — which Halard documents in a new book. In the photographs, taken in 2015, the walls are stained and peeling, the floors spattered with paint. One can clearly see the ravages of time. Yet the soft winter light imbues the rooms with a ghostly beauty and Halard’s haunting images convey the presence of the artist and a lost time.

headline: Right and Left React to the N.F.L. Protests and Trump Statements
abstract: Read about how the other side thinks about President Trump’s statements on free speech, the national anthem, the flag as well as responses from football players and owners.
lead_paragraph: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

headline: A New York Cheddar Aged to Perfection
abstract: Murray’s Clothbound Cheddar is made from ingredients from New York State and aged for a year.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Murray’s Cheese began working with Cornell University to develop an English-style clothbound Cheddar made solely with ingredients from New York State. The classic pale ivory cheese with fruity, citric flavors is now available. Some commercial Cheddars are coated in wax to prevent mold, but using cheesecloth instead allows this Cheddar to develop complex flavors as it ages. The cheese, made in very small batches at the Cornell Food Processing and Development Laboratory in Ithaca, N.Y., is aged for 12 months in Murray’s ripening caves in Queens. The resulting Cheddar has a creamy, yet firm and slightly crumbly texture. The cow milk comes from the Old Chatham Sheepherding Company in the Hudson Valley and, vegetarians should note, the wheels are rubbed with lard from New York State pigs before the cheesecloth is applied, something that is frequently done when making Cheddar: Murray’s Clothbound Cheddar, $29.99 a pound, murrayscheese.com.

headline: At N.B.A. Media Days, Players and Coaches Take Aim at President Trump
abstract: LeBron James weighed in again, as he did on Saturday, when he referred to Trump as a “bum.” Toronto’s DeMar DeRozan compared Trump to a “12-year-old.”
lead_paragraph: Some of the N.B.A.’s most influential figures took aim at President Trump on Monday, as several teams around the league turned their versions of media day — which tend to be subdued occasions marking the start of training camp — into politically charged events.

headline: The Thickest Glass Ceiling in the Marine Corps Breaks
abstract: The graduation of the first woman from the Marine Corps’ grueling Infantry Officer Course is momentous. Soon, I hope, it will be no big deal.
lead_paragraph: It is a rite of passage that I have experienced: brand-new lieutenants introducing themselves to their platoons of a few dozen enlisted Marines. It is a powerful experience for any new officer. Now consider the stakes when that lieutenant is a woman — and the platoon is a front-line infantry unit. The Marine Corps is the most male-dominated of the armed services, and the infantry is the most male-dominated bastion of the corps. The moment will be electric, and historic.

headline: Around the World and the U.S., New Travel Ban Draws Anger, Applause and Shrugs
abstract: Foreign leaders and immigrant groups here reacted strongly to new restrictions being imposed by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump announced the latest and most far-reaching version of his travel ban on Sunday, citing threats to national security posed by letting citizens of specific countries into the country, the White House said it had come after exhaustive planning. It was meant to prevent the confusion and chaos that his first travel ban created at airports, colleges and technology companies in the United States and at refugee camps around the world back in January.

headline: An Upbeat Mood May Boost Your Flu Shot’s Effectiveness
abstract: Older people who are in a good mood when they get a flu shot have a better immune response.
lead_paragraph: Don’t worry, be happy — it might make your flu shot more effective.

headline: A Condiment That Brings the Heat
abstract: Chinese chile oil from Blank Slate Kitchen adds numbing fire to recipes.
lead_paragraph: For me, ruddy Chinese chile oil is a must-have staple to unleash fire on many dishes. Blank Slate Kitchen in Brooklyn has just introduced an uncommon version made with Sichuan peppercorns, which contribute the intriguingly numbing heat of that spice. Drizzle it on noodles, rub it on shrimp or fish, or brush it on sliders: Blank Slate Kitchen Szechuan Chili Oil, $12.50 for eight ounces, blankslatekitchen.com.

headline: David Shepherd, Who Both Painted and Preserved Wildlife, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Shepherd, enraged by poaching and other abuses he witnessed while painting wild animals, formed his own conservation foundation.
lead_paragraph: David Shepherd, a British artist whose love of painting wildlife led him to become a leading conservationist as well, died on Sept. 19 in Sussex, England. He was 86.

headline: Before Trump Brought Politics Into Football, He Made Politics Into Football
abstract: The president and the league he is criticizing have a lot in common.
lead_paragraph: When all else fails, the National Football League has always been able to market its product as an escape — from all that. Football provides fans “a chance to really celebrate and come together and get away from our everyday troubles,” Commissioner Roger Goodell said in an interview with CBS’s Bob Schieffer before the Super Bowl in 2010. Yes, life is hard, full of “troubles,” but Sundays offer the solace of a beginning-to-end emotional experience. Games are confined to about three hours and yield unambiguous, stick-to-sports results. “We offer a respite,” the Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones told me in 2016. “We are a respite that moves you away from your trials and missteps, or my trials and missteps.”

headline: Exxon Aims to Cut Methane Leaks, a Culprit in Global Warming
abstract: The move by the nation’s biggest natural gas producer was hailed by an environmental activist as a welcome step in mitigating climate change.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil announced a program on Monday to reduce emissions of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, from its oil and natural gas production and pipeline operations across the United States.

headline: Nothing Is Free
abstract: An overheard snippet of conversation between a woman and her mother.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Republicans Present Conservative Vision for ‘Dreamer’ Protection
abstract: Republican senators unveiled an alternative to the Dream Act, offering immigrants brought illegally to the country as children a slow path to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three Republican senators introduced a bill on Monday that would offer young undocumented immigrants a path to citizenship, signaling a possible bipartisan consensus on legislation to protect immigrants brought to the United States as children.

headline: After the German Election
abstract: Angela Merkel made history on Sunday. So did the far-right.
lead_paragraph: Angela Merkel won a fourth term as chancellor in Sunday’s election, but her victory was overhsadowed by the entry of the far-right party, Alternative for Germany, into Parliament for the first time in more than 60 years.

headline: North Korea, N.F.L., Puerto Rico: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Health Bill Appears Dead as Pivotal G.O.P. Senator Declares Opposition
abstract: Senator Susan Collins of Maine announced her opposition to the latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, leaving party leaders short of the votes they need.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A last-ditch attempt by President Trump and Senate Republicans to dismantle the Affordable Care Act appeared to collapse on Monday as a pivotal senator announced her firm opposition to the latest repeal plan, virtually ensuring that Republicans would not have the votes they need for passage.

headline: Read the C.B.O. Report on the Graham-Cassidy Health Care Bill
abstract: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office on Monday released its findings on the latest Republican health care bill.
lead_paragraph: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office on Monday released its findings on the latest Republican health care bill.

headline: Tyranny of the Minority
abstract: Most people didn’t vote to be governed like this.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald Trump’s cataclysmic election, the unthinkable has become ordinary. We’ve grown used to naked profiteering off the presidency, an administration that calls for the firing of private citizens for political dissent and nuclear diplomacy conducted via Twitter taunts. Here, in my debut as a New York Times columnist, I want to discuss a structural problem that both underlies and transcends our current political nightmare: We have entered a period of minority rule.

headline: Target Raises Base Pay to $11 an Hour Heading Into Holidays
abstract: Target, which plans to raise base pay to $15 an hour by 2020, aims to hire 100,000 seasonal workers during a tight labor market for retailers.
lead_paragraph: Target fired the first salvo of this year’s holiday hiring wars on Monday, saying that it would raise its minimum hourly wage to $11 next month and then to $15 an hour by the end of 2020.

headline: The Wreckage of Anthony Weiner
abstract: The former congressman’s imprisonment for sexting with a teenager is his final disgrace. But the damage he caused lives on.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Weiner arrived at the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan nearly an hour early on Monday to receive his final humiliation. When he got it — a sentence of 21 months in prison and an order to register as a sex offender — he stayed late, frozen at the defense table as the courtroom emptied. He was a broken man, sobbing with his face buried in his hands.

headline: Menendez Co-Defendant Pressured Government for Help, Official Testifies
abstract: A Commerce Department official recalled receiving threats of political retribution during a meeting with a lawyer for Dr. Salomon Melgen, a friend and donor to Senator Robert Menendez.
