lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A lawyer representing Dr. Salomon Melgen, who is on trial on federal corruption charges here alongside Senator Robert Menendez, threatened officials from the Department of Commerce if they failed to help him resolve a contract dispute in the Dominican Republic, a federal official testified on Monday.

headline: The Republican Senators Who Have Opposed the Many Bills to Repeal Obamacare
abstract: Thirteen lawmakers from 12 states have opposed at least one of the Senate’s five major repeal efforts in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen lawmakers from 12 states have opposed at least one of the Senate’s five major repeal efforts in recent months.

headline: Why I Admire Anthony Weiner
abstract: The former congressman stood before a judge and offered no excuse for the behavior that sprang from his addiction.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, former New York Congressman Anthony Weiner was sentenced to 21 months in prison for having lewd exchanges with a 15-year-old girl on Skype and Snapchat. The sentencing was just the latest act in Mr. Weiner’s nightmarish downfall fueled by his compulsive sexting habit.

headline: Barbara Blaine, Who Championed Victims of Priests’ Abuse, Dies at 61
abstract: Ms. Blaine, who had been molested by a priest as a teenager, founded a national network of abuse survivors and became a voice for them.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Blaine, who was sexually abused by a Roman Catholic priest as a teenager and went on to found the nation’s most potent advocacy group for abuse survivors, died on Sunday in St. George, Utah. She was 61.

headline: Puerto Rico: What Other Americans Should Know
abstract: Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, home to 3.4 million Americans. Here are answers to questions you may have about the commonwealth.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico. The island has no electricity, and may not for months to come. Much of the water is undrinkable. About 80 percent of crop value is gone, a loss of $780 million.

headline: Reading Something in the N.F.L. Ratings? You’re Probably Wrong
abstract: Amid protests against police brutality and in the wake of the president’s tweets, the war over television ratings has become explicitly political.
lead_paragraph: Nielsen’s television ratings are traditionally an industry metric, used by networks and advertisers to buy and sell commercial time. But on this Monday, and every Monday for the next four months, the N.F.L. ratings will be dissected far and wide in search of broader meaning.

headline: Reaction to Steelers’ Anthem Decision: How’d We Lose to the Bears?
abstract: In Pittsburgh, most people want their football without a dash of politics, thank you very much.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The tradition for a fall Monday here is to engage in the true national — or at least regional — pastime: celebrating a Steelers’ win on Sunday or complaining about what in the world has gotten into the offense.

headline: Entrepreneur, Charged in U.S., Recounts Abuse in Colombia Prison
abstract: Kaleil Isaza Tuzman, whose securities fraud trial is to start in federal court in Manhattan next month, says he has already undergone a harrowing ordeal.
lead_paragraph: “I was ordered down from the slab where I slept. I was wearing a T-shirt and sweatpants. They pushed me down to the floor by my head and shoulders. One of them had a knife at my Adam’s apple. I tried to leave my body, pretend that I wasn’t living it. I wanted to die. I’ve regretted at times since then that I didn’t jerk my head away and let my throat be cut.”

headline: Rough Waters Darken a Sunny Weekend at the Shore
abstract: Unseasonably warm temperatures brought crowds to New York and New Jersey beaches over the weekend, but the surf became deadly in some areas.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures in the 90s over the weekend sent hordes of beachgoers to the shoreline in the New York area, and a hurricane hundreds of miles out to sea sent unusually large waves to those same beaches.

headline: At Least 6 White House Advisers Used Private Email Accounts
abstract: While it is not necessarily illegal for White House officials to use private email accounts, President Trump had made Hillary Clinton’s mishandling of emails as secretary of state a centerpiece of his 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At least six of President Trump’s closest advisers occasionally used private email addresses to discuss White House matters, current and former officials said on Monday.

headline: Wisconsin Strict ID Law Discouraged Voters, Study Finds
abstract: Nearly 17,000 registered Wisconsin voters were deterred from casting ballots in November, according to a new survey of nonvoters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 17,000 registered Wisconsin voters — potentially more — were kept from the polls in November by the state’s strict voter ID law, according to a new survey of nonvoters by two University of Wisconsin political scientists.

headline: The Jones Act: The Law Strangling Puerto Rico
abstract: The Jones Act has outlived its original World War I intent and is devastating the island’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Maria was the most powerful storm to hit Puerto Rico in more than 80 years. It left the entire island without electricity, which may take six months to restore. It toppled trees, shattered windows, tore off roofs and turned streets into rivers throughout the island.

headline: After Mexico Earthquake, Villagers Are ‘Left With Nothing’
abstract: With hundreds of houses destroyed and President Trump vowing to limit Mexican immigration, a rural village whose workers flocked to the U.S. wonders how it will rebuild.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO XOCHITEOPAN, Mexico — Saúl Nicolas Pérez stood in front of his house — or what was left of it — and surveyed the damage the earthquake had inflicted. Deep, diagonal gashes scored the adobe facade. Interior walls were rubble. A collapse seemed likely.

headline: In Tax Code Rewrite, Republicans Ask How Low Can They Go
abstract: Discussions between the Trump administration and Republican leaders in Congress continue over how deep to slash tax rates for businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans are unifying behind an aggressive tax code rewrite with a single, overarching goal: How low can they go?

headline: A Piece of Obama’s Post-Presidential Life: Sandwiches and Speeches
abstract: A spate of paid addresses, with fees that have hit $400,000, provide an indication of how Mr. Obama is navigating moneymaking opportunities.
lead_paragraph: An hour inside Barack Obama’s post-presidential life included boxed sandwiches, scores of money managers and a treatise on health care reform.

headline: Knicks Officially Begin Life Without Carmelo Anthony
abstract: The trade that sent Anthony to Oklahoma City became official just before the start of the Knicks’ media day, where Kristaps Porzingis was suddenly the centerpiece.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — At 10:45 on Monday morning, it became official: The Carmelo Anthony era was over for the Knicks, marked with a news release. A tenure that had lasted six-plus seasons took one weekend to finally disassemble.

headline: European Diplomats Speak Out Against Trump’s Opposition to Iran Deal
abstract: For months, they had helped paper over their countries’ differences with the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After months of quietly urging the Trump administration to preserve the Iran nuclear deal, European diplomats have begun an aggressive defense of it, warning of serious consequences if the United States ignores their concerns.

headline: In Battered Puerto Rico, Governor Warns of a Humanitarian Crisis
abstract: Stressing that Puerto Rico deserved the same treatment as hurricane-hit Florida and Texas, Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló urged Congress to move swiftly to send more aid.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló of Puerto Rico said on Monday that the island was on the brink of a “humanitarian crisis” nearly a week after Hurricane Maria knocked out its power and most of its water, and left residents waiting in excruciating lines for fuel. He called on Congress to prevent a deepening disaster.

headline: N.F.L. Owners’ Unity With Players Might Be Short-Lived
abstract: Despite a show of sideline support, a group consisting largely of white billionaires has reluctantly addressed social injustice and head injuries.
lead_paragraph: The image was striking — several owners of N.F.L. teams locking arms with their players on the sidelines Sunday in a dramatic statement of defiance to a president who ridiculed their sport and condemned players for refusing to stand during the national anthem as a protest against racism.

headline: Trump Calls Dallas Cowboys’ Anthem Demonstration ‘Progress’
abstract: The Cowboys and the Arizona Cardinals continued an N.F.L. trend by demonstrating during the playing of the national anthem before their game Monday night. Dallas beat Arizona, 28-17.
lead_paragraph: A day after most of the N.F.L. engaged in at least some form of demonstration during the national anthem, the Dallas Cowboys, along with the team’s owner, Jerry Jones, linked arms on the University of Phoenix Stadium field Monday night and collectively took a knee before the anthem was played.

headline: A Trump Travel Ban We’ve Seen Before
abstract: The new ban may look more modulated, but it’s a direct descendant of the Muslim ban President Trump called for from the start.
lead_paragraph: The central question to ask about President Trump’s latest travel ban, which he issued on Sunday, is: Will it make Americans safer?

headline: Yankees Ignore Growing Questions About Whether They’ll Extend Netting
abstract: Since a young girl was hit by a line drive at Yankee Stadium last week, several other teams have announced that they will extend their protective screens.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, the Yankees played their first game at home since last Wednesday, when a line drive off the bat of Todd Frazier struck a young girl in the face as she was sitting a few rows behind the third-base dugout.

headline: New Jersey Man Who Won Millions in Powerball Lottery Is Accused of Molesting Girl
abstract: Pedro Quezada, who won $338 million in 2013, was charged with sexual assault. His lawyer said his accuser had fabricated the charges to get his money.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man who won $338 million in the Powerball lottery four years ago was released from jail on Monday while he awaits trial on charges of sexually abusing a young girl.

headline: Quotation of the Day: North Koreans Issue a Threat to U.S. Planes
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 26, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Since the United States declared war on our country, we will have every right to make countermeasures, including the right to shoot down United States strategic bombers even when they are not inside the airspace border of our country.”

headline: Trumpcare Is Dead. Long Live the Trumpcare Opposition.
abstract: Republicans won’t just give up, so it’s too early to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: It’s over. And it’s not over.

headline: Lion Observed at Night
abstract: Comedian and television personality Joy Behar teams up with Lynn Lempel for a humorous offering.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s been over a month since we saw the stellar celebrity crossword collaboration between Neil Patrick Harris and David Steinberg, so it was only a matter of time before another one appeared. Today, we are presented with a puzzle from Joy Behar and Lynn Lempel.

headline: Review: Beckett’s Absurdist House of Horrors, in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: “Beckett in the City: The Women Speak” powerfully articulates a theme of powerlessness in four short plays staged at a secret location near the Irish Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Cross a courtyard, slip into a building, climb a flight of stairs, slink down a corridor and you’ll find yourself in a high-modernist haunted house. Lips scream here, hands clench, a woman in a gray peignoir walks up and down, a restive ghost. These refined frights are yours courtesy of “Beckett in the City: The Women Speak,” a strikingly acted and indifferently site-specific presentation of four Samuel Beckett shorts, presented by Ireland’s Company SJ and the Irish Arts Center.

headline: Bringing My Own Kind of ‘Madness’ to the Office
abstract: I’ve been fired more times than I care to admit. Work and paranoid schizophrenia aren’t exactly a recipe for success.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been fired more times than I care to admit. I have even more resignation letters to my name.

headline: Review: In ‘Mary Jane,’ a Young Mother Faces Her Worst Fears
abstract: A child’s illness raises existential questions in Amy Herzog’s heartbreaking new play, starring Carrie Coon, at New York Theater Workshop.
lead_paragraph: Plays don’t usually come with content advisories, but “Mary Jane,” by Amy Herzog, should: Parents strongly cautioned.

headline: Roger Stone to Tell House Panel He Pulled No Treasonous ‘Trick’
abstract: Roger J. Stone Jr., an informal adviser to President Trump, is to be interviewed on Tuesday by the House Intelligence Committee, one of several bodies investigating Russian election interference.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., a self-proclaimed political “dirty trickster” and an informal adviser to the president, will strongly deny to congressional investigators on Tuesday that he worked with Russians to aid President Trump’s campaign.

headline: Reinventing Balmain (With Help From His Instagram Friends)
abstract: Olivier Rousteing, the creative director of Balmain, wants to make the French fashion house relevant to a new generation — and his 4.6 million Instagram followers are paying attention. We take you inside his Paris studio.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Rousteing, the creative director of Balmain, wants to make the French fashion house relevant to a new generation — and his 4.6 million Instagram followers are paying attention. We take you inside his Paris studio.

headline: Guggenheim, Bowing to Animal-Rights Activists, Pulls Works From Show
abstract: The museum made the decision after it had come under unrelenting pressure from critics over three works that involve animals.
lead_paragraph: Facing an avalanche of criticism, the Guggenheim surrendered late Monday and said it would remove three major works from a highly anticipated exhibition of art by Chinese conceptual artists, including the signature piece of the show, which opens next month.

headline: Corrections: September 26, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 26, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Terrorized British City Turns to an All-American Play for Healing
abstract: In the wake of a concert bombing, the Royal Exchange Theater in Manchester added “Our Town” to its fall schedule.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — In the wake of the May terrorist attack at Manchester Arena, which killed 23 people, including the attacker, the space outside the nearby Royal Exchange Theater became a site of public mourning. St. Ann’s Square slowly filled with flowers and other tributes – soft toys, football jerseys, balloons — covering an area the size of a swimming pool. Every day for three weeks, the theater’s staff walked past on their way to work.

headline: In Alabama Senate Runoff, Pence and Bannon Take Opposing Sides
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence appeared with Senator Luther Strange while Stephen K. Bannon joined Roy Moore, pitting the Republican establishment against the party’s populist wing.
lead_paragraph: FAIRHOPE, Ala. — Just hours before the polls opened in a special United States Senate runoff in Alabama that will echo through the national Republican Party, two of the best-known figures in President Trump’s orbit raced to the state Monday night on behalf of opposing candidates.

headline: Reinventing Givenchy
abstract: Clare Waight Keller, the house’s first female artistic director, has a lot riding on her debut show Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One day in July, not long after Clare Waight Keller had begun work as the first female artistic director of Givenchy — succeeding its longtime designer, Riccardo Tisci, and helping further reset the gender imbalance that has long existed at the top of famous French fashion brands — she was sitting at a long table in the vast white design studio of the brand’s headquarters on Avenue George V.

headline: Five Places to Go in Athens
abstract: In recent years, Kifissia, an upscale Athens suburb, has attracted an appealing mix of stores and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Travelers looking for a sense of where locals in Athens hang out should head to Kifissia, a leafy, upscale suburb north of the city center. While homegrown stores have long been a trademark here, eateries have been scarce. In recent years, that’s changed as it’s become easier to obtain restaurant licenses. Now, the neighborhood includes an enticing mix of stores and restaurants —  both of which appeal to Athenians with good taste in fashion and food.

headline: Meet Decibel Bellini, the Booming Soundtrack to Napoli Goals
abstract: A radio D.J.’s thunderous stadium announcements have won over fans and players alike, and made him a global social media sensation.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — When Dries Mertens scores Napoli’s first goal, Stadio San Paolo’s creaking stands rattle and shudder with the noise. It is not a cheer: a cheer is something joyful and merry and high-pitched. This is different: deeper, more guttural, rooted as much in release and euphoria, caught somewhere between a roar and a howl. It hits you like a wave.

headline: The Top 10 Moments of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Including: Cindy Crawford, Claudia Schiffer and Naomi Campbell recreating a Richard Avedon tableau from 1994, and Gigi Hadid as a walking bouquet at Moschino.
lead_paragraph: The fashion editors and reporters of Styles and T round up the highlights of the week.

headline: ‘Pretty Woman’ as a Broadway Musical? Get Ready
abstract: With Samantha Barks in the role that made Julia Roberts famous, the stage musical aims to open in New York next fall.
lead_paragraph: “Pretty Woman,” the film that made a star of Julia Roberts, is being adapted into a stage musical, with songs co-written by Bryan Adams, and is aiming to open on Broadway next fall after a spring run in Chicago.

headline: Angela Merkel, North Korea, Iraq: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Word + Quiz: dais
abstract: This word has appeared in 64 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Collapsed School in Mexico Earthquake Is Checked for ‘Hidden Defects’
abstract: The building, constructed before 1985, may never have been upgraded to meet strict new building codes enacted in the wake of that year’s horrific quake.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexican officials have begun an investigation to determine whether a school that collapsed in last week’s quake, killing 19 children and six adults, may have violated construction codes.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Law & Order True Crime’ and ‘Difficult People’
abstract: “Law & Order” spins off a new true crime series about the Menendez murders. And Julie and Billy part ways in the Season 3 finale of “Difficult People.”
lead_paragraph: “Law & Order” follows the successes of “Making a Murderer” and “American Crime Story” with a new true crime series. And Julie and Billy part ways in the Season 3 finale of “Difficult People.”

headline: Van Gogh Selfies
abstract: What do you think this photo is saying about our society?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this photo is saying about our society? How does it relate to your own life or experiences?

headline: Curious About Eyelash Extensions? Here’s What You Should Know
abstract: These semi-permanent eyelashes work their fluttery magic with no daily effort.
lead_paragraph: Can I let you in on a secret, just between you and me? I’ve worn eyelash extensions continuously for about two years now. They make me feel like a Disney princess whose pure and gentle spirit has enticed delicate, mascara-free butterflies to live on my face.

headline: The Studio Museum Has a Vision for Its Home. And a Power Player at the Helm.
abstract: Thelma Golden, the museum’s formidable steward, is focused on a big building project and many initiatives at an important time for the institution.
lead_paragraph: It was evening in Harlem.

headline: Disney Reimagines Its Stores to Be More Like a Vacation
abstract: With light-up Mickey ears, cotton candy and live-streamed theme park parades, Disney remakes its stores and offers a new web store, ShopDisney.com.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Quietly, like a mouse on tiptoe, Disney overhauled its retail store at the Northridge Fashion Center mall in late July. Out went the twisty Pixie Path aisles, the ornate displays, the green walls and the color-changing fiberglass trees. In came a movie-theater-size screen, a simplified floor plan, white walls and more items for fashion-conscious adults.

headline: The Evolution of Fashion Photography
abstract: The various movements and turning points in fashion throughout the decades are chronicled in a new volume by Aperture.
lead_paragraph: The various movements and turning points in fashion throughout the decades are chronicled in a new volume by Aperture.

headline: The Tiger Force Atrocities
abstract: In 1967, a single Army platoon killed hundreds of Vietnamese civilians, and no one was held responsible.
lead_paragraph: The memory haunts Bill Carpenter even 50 years after his tour in Vietnam ended. An elderly villager dressed in white had just carted geese over the dark Song Ve River when he crossed paths with Mr. Carpenter’s platoon — a unit known as Tiger Force. The villager sputtered in fear. The angry troops told him to be quiet. He couldn’t.

headline: It’s Donald Trump’s World. You and I Just Live Here.
abstract: “American visitors to Antarctica are probably greeted by penguins flapping their wings in alarm.”
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: So I’m just back from Down Under, Gail. It was my first visit there, and all of my expectations were upended. “On the Beach” and the “Mad Max” series gave me a sense of Australia as the land of the apocalypse. Actually, it’s lovely and people there seem quite relaxed.

headline: The Abbie Hoffman of the Right: Donald Trump
abstract: Trump is winning at shredding the dominant American culture.
lead_paragraph: It has to be admitted that Donald Trump is doing exactly what he was elected to do.

headline: Taking the Battle Against Malaria to the Mekong
abstract: Drug-resistant malaria strains often develop in the region, then spread elsewhere. Eliminating it there will require all the weapons we have.
lead_paragraph: Malaria infected more than 200 million people in 2015, and killed more than 400,000, most of them children in Africa. As devastating as those numbers are, they were a major improvement: Deaths  fell by  48 percent since 2000. This impressive drop was the result of billions in funding and decades of effort by thousands of people across the globe.

headline: Do Republicans Really Care About the Deficit?
abstract: Yes, but only when it’s an excuse to cut social spending. Tax cuts — now that’s a different story.
lead_paragraph: Though America really doesn’t need a tax cut — demographic pressures alone suggest the need for more, not less, future revenues — President Trump and the Republican majority want one. But they don’t want to pay for it, which means the budget deficit is going to rise. Based on what we’ve seen so far, the increase in the deficit could be at least $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

headline: Get the Keg Out of the Frat House
abstract: Fraternities are growing in popularity, and are in desperate need of reform.
lead_paragraph: Fraternity initiation season has just begun and already an 18-year-old freshman is dead. An investigation into the death of the student, who had been drinking at Louisiana State University’s Phi Delta Theta house, will most likely point to a familiar culprit: the toxic brew of alcohol and hazing.

headline: Courts That Save Opioid Victims’ Family Life
abstract: A new kind of family court tailors substance abuse treatment programs to the individual needs of a recovering parent’s household.
lead_paragraph: One spring afternoon, Samantha Coleman’s two daughters ran across the family’s yard, chasing dozens of newly hatched chicks. Coleman, 28, ran after them. “Whoa! Child down,” she called, reaching to pick up her 2-year-old, who had managed to fall into a bush.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Angela Merkel, Reluctant Leader of the West, ‘Has Gotten the Taste for It’’
abstract: What examples does the article give to demonstrate Angela Merkel’s change from a leader who recoils from new responsibilities to one who embraces them?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Palestinian Gunman Kills 3 Israelis at West Bank Crossing
abstract: The killings shattered the routine at an ordinarily peaceful crossing point. The assailant, a Palestinian father of four, was fatally shot.
lead_paragraph: HAR ADAR, West Bank — Each weekday scores of Palestinians from the surrounding West Bank villages line up at a yellow metal barrier on the edge of Har Adar, an affluent Israeli border community, awaiting entry for work. That quiet routine was disrupted on Tuesday when one worker opened fire, killing three Israeli security personnel and wounding a fourth.

headline: The Evolution of Fashion Photography
abstract: The various movements and turning points in fashion throughout the decades are featured in a new volume by Aperture.
lead_paragraph: With so many exhibits and monographs devoted to fashion photography and its leading practitioners, it’s hard to imagine that it wasn’t that long ago that the genre was seldom the focus of highbrow studies. Yet, that’s what Eugénie Shinkle discovered when she began researching it almost a decade ago.

headline: Would You Like to Be Famous?
abstract: What does a meaningful life look like to you?
lead_paragraph: Would you like to be famous? Why or why not?

headline: Snapshots Along the River Where China Meets North Korea
abstract: As tensions grow over North Korea’s nuclear tests and China’s sanctions, tourists and residents in the region seemed divided over where to cast blame.
lead_paragraph: As tensions grow over North Korea’s nuclear tests and China’s sanctions, tourists and residents in the region seemed divided over where to cast blame.

headline: Where It’s Made: Visit a Lego Factory
abstract: Step inside a factory that makes the bricks for your favorite Lego toys in this 360° tour.
lead_paragraph: Step inside a factory that makes the bricks for your favorite Lego toys in this 360° tour.

headline: All Signs Pointed to a Stroke. Then the Tests Come Back Negative.
abstract: When, at 94, she suddenly found it difficult to speak and swallow, the doctors had to explore more unusual possibilities.
lead_paragraph: “Mom?” the middle-aged man asked. He recognized the voice, but the words were muffled and strange. I’ll be right over, he said into the phone. The 15-minute drive from his small Connecticut town to his mother’s seemed to last forever. Had she had a stroke? She was 94, and though she’d always been healthy, at her age, anything could happen.

headline: What I Care About Is Important. What You Care About Is a ‘Distraction.’
abstract: It’s a clever way to write off other points of view: Just suggest they’re getting in the way of what truly matters.
lead_paragraph: I recently stumbled across a quote, rendered in friendly block lettering and posted, naturally, on the internet: “Perhaps figuring out what matters most matters most.” I couldn’t tell if it was meant to be inspirational or a joke. Funny as it sounds, it is a widespread, fervid belief that we are failing to concentrate on the things that actually matter. If only we could pay attention where attention must be paid! Instead, we fritter away our energy on frivolous distractions! Our inability to focus is framed as weakness, moral failure, neuropathology; as the byproduct of sugar, artificial colors, video games, loopy brain chemistry, social media. Distraction, we say, will be the death of us. This is the way the world ends — not with a bang but a ding. From your iPhone.

headline: In Mexico, Earthquake Survivors Plan on Rebuilding Their Lives
abstract: Jojutla, in Morelos State, is near the epicenter of the earthquake that hit Mexico on Sept. 19. Residents are planning to rebuild their lives in the city, which was one of the hardest hit parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: Jojutla, in Morelos State, is near the epicenter of the earthquake that hit Mexico on Sept. 19. Residents are planning to rebuild their lives in the city, which was one of the hardest hit parts of the country.

headline: How Fake News Turned a Small Town Upside Down
abstract: At the height of the 2016 election, exaggerated reports of a juvenile sex crime brought a media maelstrom to Twin Falls — one the Idaho city still hasn’t recovered from.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday morning in June 2016, Nathan Brown, a reporter for The Times-News, the local paper in Twin Falls, Idaho, strolled into the office and cleared off a spot for his coffee cup amid the documents and notebooks piled on his desk. Brown, 32, started his career at a paper in upstate New York, where he grew up, and looks the part of a local reporter, clad in a fresh oxford and khakis that tend to become disheveled over the course of his long days. His first order of business was an article about a City Council meeting from the night before, which he hadn’t attended. Brown pulled up a recording of the proceedings and began punching out notes for his weekly article. Because most governing in Twin Falls is done by a city manager, these meetings tend to deal with trivial subjects like lawn-watering and potholes, but Brown could tell immediately that this one was different.

headline: Dear Match Book: I’m Seeking Satirical, Semifantastical and Standout Literary Fiction
abstract: High-minded novels and stories that favor fairy tales, unsolved crimes and dystopian drama over the ubiquitous run-of-the-mill plots in today’s fiction.
lead_paragraph: Dear Match Book,

headline: Is Climate-Themed Fiction All Too Real? We Asked the Experts
abstract: Some works of apocalyptic fiction are starting to feel too close for comfort. We chose seven of them and asked: How likely are they to come true?
lead_paragraph: Some works of apocalyptic fiction are starting to feel too close for comfort. We chose seven of them and asked: How likely are they to come true?

headline: The 21st-Century Fantasy Trilogy That Changed the Game
abstract: The first two novels in N.K. Jemisin’s Broken Earth trilogy both won Hugo awards. In the final volume, “The Stone Sky,” the fate of the world is at stake.
lead_paragraph: THE STONE SKYThe Broken Earth: Book Three By N.K. Jemisin445 pp. Orbit. Paper, $16.99.

headline: In ‘One Nation After Trump,’ a Study of the Trends Behind His Rise
abstract: If someone hibernated through 2016 and then turned on cable news and wondered what the hell happened, this would be the book to read.
lead_paragraph: ONE NATION AFTER TRUMP A Guide for the Perplexed, the Disillusioned, the Desperate, and the Not-Yet Deported By E. J. Dionne Jr., Norman J. Ornstein and Thomas E. Mann 344 pp. St. Martin’s Press. $25.99.

headline: De Blasio Pledged Progress for Schools. For $582 Million, Change Is Slow.
abstract: As Renewal, the mayor’s signature education program, enters its fourth school year, results are mixed at best and the city must decide the fate of schools taking part.
lead_paragraph: Even as New York City’s schools opened their doors for the new year this month, the clock was ticking on the future of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s boldest education initiative.

headline: A Place to Unplug
abstract: When Daniel Caudill, the creative director of Shinola, and Tyler Rink, an interior designer, built a weekend house, they started with a prefabricated unit and made it their own.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Caudill, the creative director of Shinola, and Tyler Rink, an interior designer, built a weekend house, they started with a prefabricated unit and made it their own.

headline: For the Creative Director of Shinola, a Place to Unplug
abstract: When Daniel Caudill and interior designer Tyler Rink built a weekend house, they started with a modern box in the woods and then made it their own.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Caudill and Tyler Rink were visiting friends in Northport, Mich., when their hosts took them to see a piece of land they planned to sell. The group meandered past cherry and apple orchards before arriving at a windswept, forested cliff, from which they could see the crashing azure waters of Lake Michigan some 200 feet below.

headline: Corporations Have Rights. Why Shouldn’t Rivers?
abstract: The lawsuit could upend environmental law, possibly allowing the Rocky Mountains or the deserts of Nevada to sue individuals, corporations and governments over pollution or depletion.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Does a river — or a plant, or a forest — have rights?

headline: Health Care, N.F.L., Puerto Rico: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Trump’s New Travel Ban
abstract: We discuss why Chad is now included on the list of countries facing restrictions, and how the revisions will affect a politically charged legal case.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Trevor Noah Sticks Up for N.F.L. Players in War of Words with Trump
abstract: Mr. Noah responded with frustration after President Trump condemned players who protest during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Star Singers Lift a Muddled ‘Norma’ at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: The greatness of a Bellini classic shines through a dimly lit new production.
lead_paragraph: Bellini’s 1831 opera “Norma,” which opened the Metropolitan Opera’s season on Monday, is rich in themes that resonate in today’s political and social climate.

headline: New York Today: Return of the (Giant) Pumpkins
abstract: Tuesday: Weigh-off contests across New York, how to eat like a samurai, and a taste of pumpkin history.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this toasty Tuesday.

headline: Houston Convention Center Shelters One More Harvey Survivor: An Opera Company
abstract: Driven from its home by Hurricane Harvey, Houston Grand Opera will use the city’s George R. Brown Convention Center to stage “La Traviata” and “Julius Caesar.”
lead_paragraph: Houston Grand Opera, which was driven from its opera house by the flooding unleashed by Hurricane Harvey, said on Monday that it had found a temporary home for the first three productions of the season: Exhibit Hall A3 of the city’s George R. Brown Convention Center, which sheltered hundreds of Texans during the storm.

headline: The Overmonitored Nursery
abstract: As a new mom, it finally dawned on me that all this technology meant to calm agitated parents actually agitates us more.
lead_paragraph: One evening a few days after we brought baby Ella home from the hospital, my husband, Dave, walked into the bedroom carrying what looked to be a tiny neon Grecian sandal.

headline: Weekly News Quiz: N.F.L. Protests, Travel Ban, Hurricane Maria
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the headlines this week? Take our 10-question quiz and see.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the headlines this week? Take our 10-question quiz and see.

headline: CAA Talent Agency Gets a Big New Investor: DealBook Briefing
abstract: Temasek of Singapore is set to take a minority stake in CAA, as it competes to expand globally and into the digital realm.
lead_paragraph: The Singaporean sovereign wealth fund Temasek will take a minority stake in the talent agency CAA, in a deal expected to be announced today, DealBook is the first to report. TPG Capital will remain the agency’s biggest shareholder.

headline: Review: In ‘Clive Davis,’ the Evolution of a Music Mogul
abstract: The documentary “The Soundtrack of Our Lives” is a valedictory for Mr. Davis, the record executive whose radio acumen is industry legend.
lead_paragraph: Chris Perkel’s reverent documentary “Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives” is a valedictory for Mr. Davis, the music executive whose Midas touch with radio hits across genres — especially at Arista Records, from 1975-2000 — is industry legend. The career of Mr. Davis, now 85, covering the 1960s to the present, is remarkable when you consider his longevity and resilience given pop music’s core audience of young listeners. Entertainment luminaries — Aretha Franklin, Puff Daddy, Bruce Springsteen, Patti Smith, Alicia Keys and many others — attest to his golden ear and marketplace savvy.

headline: Might Athlete Protests Reach Podiums at the Winter Olympics?
abstract: “As athletes, we have a very unique opportunity to speak up about things that we believe in,” the American figure skater Adam Rippon said.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — The protesting of racism and police brutality by American athletes started with W.N.B.A. players at a news conference in July 2016 and soon spread to the playing fields of the N.F.L. and the hardwood courts of the N.B.A. In less than five months, the Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, will present a far larger stage for demonstration: an Olympic podium.

headline: North Carolina Looking to Slip Through Hole in N.C.A.A. Rules
abstract: University lawyers have argued that the N.C.A.A. has no right to punish the university for a scandal centered on academics.
lead_paragraph: In the 1840s, the most bitter rivalry in American sports might have been between the crew teams from Harvard and Yale, and it boiled over when, for one race, Harvard enlisted a nonstudent to be its coxswain. The unsporting ringer led the universities to put rowing under faculty control, and eventually, according to Rodney K. Smith, a law professor who directs Utah Valley University’s Center for Constitutional Studies, helped lead to a national regulatory body for intercollegiate athletics.

headline: Exhibition Highlights Diversity of Turner Prize Shortlist
abstract: Works from the four nominees for the British contemporary art award can be seen at the Ferens Art Gallery in Hull.
lead_paragraph: The Turner Prize exhibition, which showcases the nominees for the British contemporary art award, opened Tuesday at the Ferens Art Gallery in Hull, northern England.

headline: California Today: Autumn’s First Blush
abstract: Tuesday: A look at the fall foliage, a fast-moving fire in Corona, and ranking happiness in the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Muslim American’s Homecoming: Cowboys, Country Music, Chapatis
abstract: Would I be an outsider in a country that had banned travelers from Muslim nations and was shutting its doors to immigrants? I hit the road to find out.
lead_paragraph: The conversion took place on Honky-Tonk Row, my baptism a glaze of midsummer Tennessee sweat anointing my forehead. Nashville’s Wildhorse Saloon is a tabernacle for line-dancing disciples, and I was in communion with the gyrating congregation.

headline: Yahoo Co-Founder Gives $25 Million to San Francisco’s Asian Art Museum
abstract: Jerry Yang’s gift, made with his wife, Akiko Yamazaki, is the largest in the history of the museum.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a rare example of high-level cultural philanthropy from Silicon Valley’s entrepreneurial elite, Jerry Yang, a Yahoo co-founder, and his wife, Akiko Yamazaki, have pledged $25 million toward a $90-million transformation project of the Asian Art Museum here. It marks the largest financial gift in the history of the museum, which is owned by the city but privately operated.

headline: Coming Soon to AMC Theaters: Virtual Reality Experiences
abstract: The theater chain has invested $20 million in the start-up Dreamscape Immersive and will open six locations offering V.R. experiences in the next 18 months.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — It is easily Hollywood’s hottest start-up.

headline: Trying to Stem Fallout From Breach, Equifax Replaces C.E.O.
abstract: After the attack, the list of possible internal candidates for the chief executive, Richard Smith, was depleted.
lead_paragraph: When the board of Equifax convened last week to discuss the company’s response to an enormous data breach, the 10 outside directors concluded that it was time for their hard-driving chief executive to step down.

headline: Review: A ‘Downton Abbey’ Star in Peril Again in SundanceTV’s ‘Liar’
abstract: Joanne Froggatt plays a woman who levels an accusation of rape in a she said, he said, who knows story
lead_paragraph: As the lady’s maid Anna Bates on “Downton Abbey,” Joanne Froggatt negotiated a series of increasingly horrific situations, from surreptitiously moving  a dead houseguest to campaigning for her imprisoned husband to being raped by another lord’s valet.

headline: What the Far Right’s Rise May Mean for Germany’s Future
abstract: Lessons from a year of covering right-wing populism.
lead_paragraph: It has become a new ritual of Western politics: hold an election, watch a far-right populist party do better than ever before, then debate the significance of its rise.

headline: Nearly Half of Americans Don’t Know Puerto Ricans Are Fellow Citizens
abstract: A new poll suggests many Americans don’t realize that what happened in Puerto Rico is a domestic disaster, not a foreign one.
lead_paragraph: More than three million Americans in Puerto Rico are struggling to meet basic needs after a devastating strike from Hurricane Maria, but their plight seems to be attracting far less public or political attention than the woes caused by the recent hurricanes in Texas and Florida.

headline: Young Vic Theater Names New Artistic Director
abstract: Kwame Kwei-Armah will leave his post at Center Stage in Baltimore to take up the position at the theater in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The playwright and director Kwame Kwei-Armah, known for his outspoken views on racial inequality in British theater, has been announced as the new artistic director of the Young Vic theater here.

headline: N.C.A.A. Coaches, Adidas Executive Face Charges; Pitino’s Program Implicated
abstract: A criminal complaint filed in Manhattan charged that several coaches used their positions to solicit and obtain bribes from a financial adviser and business manager to steer athletes to them.
lead_paragraph: At one major university, a sports agent arranged for a quid pro quo among Adidas, the college’s men’s basketball program and a top high school prospect in which the player’s family would receive $100,000 if he committed to the school and signed with the apparel giant once he turned pro.

headline: How Not to Respond to the Rising Murder Rate
abstract: We need solutions to violent crime, but all we hear are slogans.
lead_paragraph: This week the F.B.I. released its annual tally of crime in the United States, and the picture it paints is troubling. In 2016, there were 17,250 homicides, an increase of more than 8.5 percent from the previous year. This comes on the heels of a 12 percent rise in 2015, bringing the total increase over two years to nearly 22 percent — the largest two-year increase in homicide in 25 years.

headline: Dean Skelos’s 2015 Corruption Conviction Is Overturned
abstract: A federal appeals panel cited the same Supreme Court decision used to vacate the conviction of Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel on Tuesday overturned the 2015 corruption convictions of Dean G. Skelos, once the powerful majority leader of the New York State Senate, and his son, Adam B. Skelos, toppling the final bookend of what had been historic, back-to-back convictions of two of Albany’s most entrenched leaders.

headline: Coltrane by De Keersmaeker, Freewheeling but Structure Intact
abstract: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker became intrigued by a new improvisatory way of working. One outcome: “A Love Supreme.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cerebral. Formal. Rigorously patterned and structured.

headline: Behind North Korea’s Bluster, Some See Caution
abstract: Pyongyang is anxious to avoid a war it can’t win, according to some analysts, and is careful to leave itself a rhetorical way out when it makes threats.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In the dead of night on Saturday, American B-1B long-range bombers, escorted by F-15 fighter jets, prowled along North Korea’s east coast, in one of the United States military’s most daring maneuvers on the peninsula in decades.

headline: After the Chase, the Long Goodbye
abstract: “It’s a very emotional feeling, it’s a very intense feeling,” Ellen Stern said about preparing to part with works she collected with her husband.
lead_paragraph: Losing her husband, Jerome, in March was devastating for Ellen Stern. And preparing to part with much of their extensive art collection this fall is its own kind of grief.

headline: Jacquemus: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Pat Tillman Becomes Partisan Symbol in N.F.L. Conflict
abstract: The widow of Corporal Tillman, a football star killed in Afghanistan, said he should be remembered as a symbol of unity and that his memory “should never be politicized.”
lead_paragraph: For the many people who believe that N.F.L. players who kneel during the national anthem are disrespecting American armed forces, Pat Tillman was a perfect symbol.

headline: Belgian ‘Indiana Jones’ Tries to Solve Mystery of a WWI Submarine
abstract: A Flemish marine archaeologist has discovered a German U-boat from the war that he believes holds the remains of 23 people.
lead_paragraph: When Tomas Termote, a marine archaeologist, plunged 100 feet into the sea near Belgium this summer, he could barely believe his eyes: In front of him was a German submarine from World War I, with two of its hatches closed and, he suspected, 23 bodies inside.

headline: Classic Men’s Trench Coats for the Season
abstract: 6 versions of the staple — upgraded for fall.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing quite as timeless as a trench coat — find a good one and you’re set for years. Here, six versions of the wardrobe staple, in varying styles and silhouettes, which will work easily on your daily commute.

headline: Review: In ‘I Am Another You,’ Eating From a Garbage Can for Her Art
abstract: Nanfu Wang’s documentary asks if homelessness can be a form of freedom.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “I Am Another You” poses tricky questions about the relationship between filmmaker and subject, and maybe between filmmaker and audience. It begins when the director, Nanfu Wang (“Hooligan Sparrow”), meets a young, itinerant homeless man named Dylan in Florida and decides to tag along with him.

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Cervo’s
abstract: Simple Portuguese cooking and wines are the focus at this seafood restaurant on Canal Street.
lead_paragraph: Simple Portuguese cooking and wines are the focus at this seafood restaurant on Canal Street.

headline: Without Calling Itself a Wine Bar, Cervo’s Acts Like One
abstract: A new restaurant on the Lower East Side pours Spanish and Portuguese drinks that leave the familiar behind. And it keeps the food simple.
lead_paragraph: Cervo’s, a two-month-old restaurant on the east end of Canal Street, is divided in two. In front is a long bar where bartenders stir sherry with lemon-lime soda and three cooks make all the food. In the rear is a squarish dining room that can fit about 16 people if they all hold their breath.

headline: Crisis in Catalonia: The Independence Vote and Its Fallout
abstract: The Spanish region declared independence after a referendum that the courts called illegal. What are the origins of the secessionist movement, and what has happened since?
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Separatist lawmakers declared Catalonia’s independence from Spain on Oct. 27, prompting the central government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to take administrative control of the region, oust Catalan leaders and schedule elections on Dec. 21.

headline: Wooing Amazon: Your Turn
abstract: We invite you to make a pitch to Amazon for its second headquarters, giving your choice of location, and your reasons.
lead_paragraph: Cities across North America are engaged in a competition to sell themselves as a place for Amazon to build a second headquarters, with the infusion of tens of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars (“To Woo Amazon, Nothing’s Too Weird,” Business Day, Sept. 26).

headline: Trump Rates His Hurricane Relief: ‘Great.’ ‘Amazing.’ ‘Tremendous.’
abstract: The hurricanes are yet another reminder of the president’s rare capacity for self-congratulation, even in the aftermath of deadly disasters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has a ready answer for anyone who questions his administration’s response to the hurricanes that laid waste to Texas, Florida, the United States Virgin Islands and now Puerto Rico.

headline: Bouchra Ouizguen, Finding the Difference in Sameness
abstract: Ms. Ouizguen’s piece was inspired by the abrupt movement of the head, throat and neck that she had seen in rituals in Morocco and Senegal.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the women facing each other in the photograph above seem like reflections of each other. But a longer look reveals tiny differences: in the bend of a neck, the tie of a head scarf, the level and angle of hands.

headline: These Perfumes Are Anything but Demure
abstract: Lustiness is all over the new fall fragrances.
lead_paragraph: This fall, the new class of perfumes are mostly floral, mostly strong and not at all dainty. Tuberose, an intoxicating white flower that had its heyday in the 1940s in Robert Piguet’s Fracas, is back in a big way. Boozy and giddy, it smells like being drunk underneath a disco ball. While some perfumers chose a more delicate sensuality, lustiness is all over the season’s new bottles. These scents are baroque and voluptuous. Perfume as ornament has returned.

headline: Yayoi Kusama, Queen of Polka Dots, Opens Museum in Tokyo
abstract: “Since I was 10 years old I have been painting every day,” she said in an interview. “I still see polka dots everywhere.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Even the restrooms are covered in polka dots.

headline: Call a Lynching By Its Name
abstract: As parents of biracial kids, we shudder to say the word. But we have to.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, we have read gut-wrenching accounts of an alleged attack on an 8-year-old biracial boy in Claremont, New Hampshire. Like the local police, who did not issue any public statements until more than a week after the incident, under pressure from the boy’s family, state media have also been circumspect in their coverage. Nowhere in the reporting by top state media outlets on this tragic event does the word “lynching” occur.

headline: Bond 45 Reopens in a New Theater District Location
abstract: The latest from John Fraser, a collaboration between Nom Wah and Fung Tu and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The centerpiece of Shelly Fireman’s relocated theater district restaurant is the appetite-whetting cornucopia of antipasto platters arranged around the bar, just steps from the entrance. Beyond this are booths and tables. There’s a lower-level dining room as well, done in deep coppery tones and lit with Edison bulbs. “We’re more in the heart of the theater district in the new location,” Mr. Fireman said of the two-block move. It’s surrounded by theaters, including the Richard Rodgers. The menu, by the executive chef Brando De Oliveira, is as vast as the restaurant, which seats 268. All-day breakfast items, like gooey cheese omelets, beckon, as do salads big and small, more than a dozen antipasto choices, pastas, pizzas, burgers, chicken, fish and Italian specialties like veal Milanese. And there are overflowing family-style servings of Caesar salad, chicken wings Calabrese and manicotti, each enough for three to five people: 221 West 46th Street, 212-869-4545, bond45.com.

headline: Everything Is Fair Game in Football Coverage
abstract: From Deflategate to President Trump, Ken Belson, an N.F.L. reporter for The Times, reports from where sports and society intersect.
lead_paragraph: When I was first asked to cover the National Football League in 2013, I paused. As a longtime business writer, not a career sportswriter, I was not terribly excited about the prospect of spending my weekends in press boxes and locker rooms. I have followed the N.F.L. since I was a child, but I hadn’t aspired to cover it week in and week out. No, no, I was told. We want you to cover the league as a business and one of the powerful institutions, warts and all, in our country. That’s when I signed up.

headline: A Roundup of the Season’s Romance Novels
abstract: Robert Gottlieb on what the genre has to offer nowadays, and what it always had to offer.
lead_paragraph: He: Simon Arthur Henry Fitzranulph Basset, Earl Clyvedon, Duke of Hastings, whose face “put all of Michelangelo’s statues to shame” — “the perfect specimen of English manhood,” whose “opinion on any number of topics” is sought after by men and at whose feet “women swooned,” yet whose tragic childhood has left him determined never to marry and, above all, never to father a child who might suffer as he had.

headline: With a Friend Like Him, They Didn’t Need Enemies
abstract: In “Difficult Women,” David Plante writes about his friendships with the novelist Jean Rhys, the feminist writer Germaine Greer and Sonia Orwell, George’s widow.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of literary treachery, there is a special place reserved for David Plante and his memoir “Difficult Women,” a portrait of three of his friends (or so they believed): the novelist Jean Rhys; the feminist writer Germaine Greer; and Sonia Orwell, George’s widow, who presided, in her depressive fashion, over London’s bookish set in the 1970s.

headline: Janet Yellen Says Fed Plans to Keep Raising Rates
abstract: The Federal Reserve is struggling to understand a recent slowdown in inflation, and Ms. Yellen did raise the possibility of a slower increase in rate if low inflation persisted.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Tuesday that the Fed plans to keep raising its benchmark interest rate despite the mysterious weakness of inflation.

headline: N.F.L. Owners Who Donated to Trump Push Back
abstract: Several N.F.L. team owners contributed a million dollars or more to President Trump’s inauguration. Here’s how they reacted after he took a shot at N.F.L. players who protest during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: Several N.F.L. team owners contributed a million dollars or more to President Trump’s inauguration. Here’s how they reacted after he took a shot at N.F.L. players who protest during the national anthem.

headline: Tech Firms Add $300 Million to Trump Administration’s Computer Science Push
abstract: Many of the country’s largest technology companies pledged Tuesday to help finance an initiative meant to prepare American students for careers in so-called STEM fields.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many of the country’s largest tech companies, including Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Salesforce, on Tuesday pledged a total of $300 million for computer science education, part of a partnership with the Trump administration meant to prepare students for careers in technology.

headline: Iraq Orders Kurdistan to Surrender Its Airports
abstract: A day after Iraqi Kurds voted on independence, the Iraqi prime minister threatened to shut down flights to the region.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Iraq’s prime minister, angered by a vote on independence by his nation’s Kurdish minority, has given the country’s Kurdish region until Friday to surrender control of its two international airports or face a shutdown of international flights.

headline: Review: ‘Bugs’ Is a Culinary Adventure. Insects Never Looked so Yummy.
abstract: Ben Reade and Josh Evans travel the world to visit cultures where insects are prepared as food.
lead_paragraph: If an enterprising restaurateur is eager to grill up some insects and make a mint in the West Village, the time has never been riper. “Bugs,” an entertaining and eye-opening documentary from Andreas Johnsen, will send moviegoers out with a feeling of culinary adventurousness, eager to sample well-prepared escamoles (ant larvae) or termite queen with mango. (The maggot mousse might be pushing it.)

headline: To Transform Your Weeknight Cooking, Turn On the Instant Pot
abstract: There’s no other single gadget that makes it as easy to get a delicious meal on the table.
lead_paragraph: (Need more instruction on using your multicooker? Our “How to Use an Instant Pot” guide can help you master the device.)

headline: 5 Islands in and Around the Caribbean That You Can Still Visit
abstract: Nearly 70 percent of the Caribbean was not damaged by the hurricanes. Here are the islands where you can have an unspoiled beach getaway and help tourism.
lead_paragraph: Hurricanes Irma and Maria upended life in the Caribbean and beyond, wreaking havoc on islands stretching from Barbuda to Puerto Rico.

headline: Want Some Beatbox With That Zip-Boom-Aaah? A Cappella’s Best Face Off
abstract: Ten acts harmonized at Carnegie Hall as a cappella, an insular community, reached for new voices.
lead_paragraph: A three-hour immersion in the world of a cappella music at the first International Championship of A Cappella Open Finals left a layman listener with a few perhaps unanswerable questions. Is Meghan Trainor one of the great comic performers of our time? Did Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon secretly copy his spooky space harmonies from extreme a cappella arrangements? What is the aftermarket like for white collegiate beatboxers?

headline: How Dinosaurs Swapped Terrifying Teeth for Bird Beaks
abstract: A look at the dinosaur species that began the transition from teeth to the beaks we see in birds today.
lead_paragraph: The world once trembled before the theropods.

headline: Senate Republicans Say They Will Not Vote on Health Bill
abstract: Senate Republicans said they would not move ahead with a vote on the latest plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act, which lacked the support to pass.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Tuesday officially abandoned the latest plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act, shelving a showdown vote on the measure and effectively admitting defeat in their last-gasp drive to fulfill a core promise of President Trump and Republican lawmakers.

headline: North Korean Banks and Citizens Added to U.S. Sanctions List
abstract: The Treasury Department blacklisted eight North Korean banks and 26 individuals, most operating in China, to choke North Korea’s access to global finance.
lead_paragraph: The United States added eight North Korean banks and 26 individuals operating in four countries to its sanctions blacklist on Tuesday, part of an intensified effort to starve North Korea financially in response to the country’s nuclear weapons and missile testing.

headline: Van Gogh on Five, Wonderbra on Six: A Tour of MoMA’s New Fashion Exhibit
abstract: For the second time in seven decades, the Museum of Modern Art has mounted a show about fashion. Its curator takes a reporter on a “carwash” tour.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know whether you ever made a list of all the people you kissed in your life,” said Paola Antonelli, senior curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art one recent Monday. (Answer: Yes, and no regrets, though I wouldn’t like them all to walk into this room right now.)

headline: Will a Corporate Tax Holiday Give Workers Anything to Cheer?
abstract: Investment and jobs from the repatriation of profits held abroad have been promised in the past. But the incentives to executives will need to change.
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 2004, and to the glee of multinational corporations across the United States, a bipartisan majority in Congress offered them a gift they had long sought: an opportunity to repatriate billions of dollars stashed overseas and pay just 5.25 percent in taxes, instead of the statutory corporate rate of 35 percent.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from James Poniewozik, Mark Scheffler and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Egyptian Concertgoers Wave a Flag, and Land in Jail
abstract: Egyptian police arrested seven people for promoting homosexuality after they raised rainbow-colored flags at a concert by a popular Lebanese band.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Seven Egyptians were arrested on charges of promoting homosexuality after concertgoers waved rainbow-colored flags at a rock concert in Cairo last week, Egyptian officials said.

headline: Uber’s Contrite Stance in London May Hint at a Fruitful New Path
abstract: The ride-hailing company has been infamous for defiantly breaking rules. Its conciliatory response to having its license to operate in the British capital not renewed is a better approach.
lead_paragraph: “Move fast and break things” may have been Facebook’s mantra, but few companies have taken the slogan to heart like Uber Technologies. The ride-hailing company, which not long ago was valued at nearly $70 billion, has pushed aggressively into one market after another.

headline: Saudi Arabia Agrees to Let Women Drive
abstract: The monarchy abandoned its driving ban for women, long criticized as an infringement on women’s rights and a drag on the economy and society.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia announced on Tuesday that it would allow women to drive, ending a longstanding policy that has become a global symbol of the oppression of women in the ultraconservative kingdom.

headline: Joseph M. McDade, 18-Term Pennsylvania Congressman, Dies at 85
abstract: A Republican champion of the coal industry, he delivered for his Scranton-area constituents and survived ethics charges, of which he was acquitted.
lead_paragraph: Joseph M. McDade, an 18-term Republican congressman from northeastern Pennsylvania who helped revive the local coal-driven economy, and who late in his career was accused and acquitted of helping himself to $100,000 in illegal gifts, died on Sunday at his home in Fairfax, Va. He was 85.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in October
abstract: Every month, the streaming service adds new movies and shows to its library. These are our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site. Sign up for our three-times weekly newsletter here.

headline: Review: Sam Shepard’s ‘Simpatico,’ Cut Loose and Roaming Wild
abstract: In this production from Chicago, starring Michael Shannon, goofball farce and existential despair are by no means incompatible.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — It’s hard to imagine a more exuberant wake for Sam Shepard than the party being thrown — and I mean thrown, like a beer bottle in a bar fight — at the McCarter Theater Center here. That’s where A Red Orchid Theater’s revival of his strange “Simpatico” is running — and jumping, stumbling, falling down drunk, writhing on the floor and gleefully reminding us of the fierce and anarchic humor of Shepard, who died in July.

headline: Are N.F.L. Ratings ‘Way Down,’ as Trump Says? Not Exactly
abstract: President Trump claimed that ratings for football games had declined precipitously, but the data doesn’t support his charge.
lead_paragraph: During his recent social media fusillade against the N.F.L. and its players, President Trump claimed that ratings for football games were “way down,” except during pregame shows “when people tune in to see whether or not our country will be disrespected!”

headline: Standing Up for New York Subway Riders
abstract: A reader defends New Yorkers as more than willing to give their seat to a pregnant woman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Olivier Theyskens: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Memories of an Anti-Semitic State Department
abstract: An offensive tweet from last week brings back memories of earlier days in my career in the national security establishment.
lead_paragraph: The former C.I.A. officer Valerie Plame Wilson made news with her Twitter account last week when, on the first day of Rosh Hashana, she shared an article that said, “America’s Jews are driving America’s wars: Shouldn’t they recuse themselves when dealing with the Middle East?”

headline: Rezoning a Block in Harlem, Respecting an African Burial Ground
abstract: The City Council is to vote on a zoning framework for a big development in Harlem with a memorial to a long-ago African burial ground.
lead_paragraph: For not quite two centuries starting in the mid-1660s, when a Dutch village was established under the name Nieuw Haarlem, a church in Upper Manhattan had separate cemeteries, one for white parishioners, the other for descendants of Africans.

headline: End of the Line for the Latest Republican Health Bill
abstract: One reader praises the G.O.P. senators who refuse to back the health care bill, while another predicts that the Republicans won’t give up.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guggenheim Museum Is Criticized for Pulling Animal Artworks
abstract: Art leaders are concerned that museums are setting a worrisome precedent after protests led to the removal of three works featuring animals from a coming show.
lead_paragraph: Artists and museums are often in the thick of free speech debates — think of Rudolph W. Giuliani’s battle with the Brooklyn Museum over a Virgin Mary artwork with elephant dung and more recently a fight over an exhibit that evoked Emmett Till’s mutilated corpse. Typically the art world holds its ground, emerging bruised but resolute.

headline: Trading Insults and Threats With North Korea
abstract: Readers are fearful of the consequences when the leaders of two nuclear powers taunt each other.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: S.E.C. Hacking Response Provides Road Map for Compromised Companies
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission, which has chastised companies over digital security before, may have its words come back to haunt it.
lead_paragraph: Guess whose database was hacked, exposing sensitive information that could be used for illegal profit, but who failed to disclose that information to the public in a timely manner?

headline: How to Tell if Someone Is Lying and 8 More Conversation Tips
abstract: Amanda de Cadenet, the celebrity interviewer and author of the new book “It’s Messy,” explains how to have hard conversations.
lead_paragraph: The staring contest lasted 14 seconds before Amanda de Cadenet, best known for interviewing bold women with boldfaced names, broke the silence with “I can’t take it anymore!” She was delivering instruction in an interview technique: It is sometimes important to keep quiet, and even to stare down one’s interview subject, in the hope that the stare-ee will try to fill the silence with her truth.

headline: The Lecture That Donald Trump Needs
abstract: Jeff Sessions schooled college students on free speech. His most important pupil is the president.
lead_paragraph: I’m thrilled that Jeff Sessions is such an evangelist for free speech.

headline: Debra Messing, Sean Hayes and Eric McCormack at a Party for ‘Will & Grace’
abstract: Stars and friends of the beloved 1990s sitcom celebrate the show’s return.
lead_paragraph: Stars and friends of the beloved 1990s sitcom celebrate the show’s return.

headline: Cast and Fans of ‘Will & Grace’ Toast the Show’s Return
abstract: Eric McCormack, Debra Messing and Sean Hayes celebrate the new season of the trailblazing sitcom.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 11 years since we last saw them together, so when Will and Grace fell into a hug halfway through a party on Saturday night, you could practically hear the theme song’s rousing piano-pounded first chords.

headline: North Korea, Puerto Rico, Iraqi Kurdistan: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The 25 Best Photos of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Highlights from Versace, Prada and more shows at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from Versace, Prada and more shows at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Our Favorite Photos of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Donatella and Versace’s icons, an anniversary at Missoni — and many more visual highlights from the shows.
lead_paragraph: Milan Fashion Week was filled with highlights. Donatella Versace reunited the brand’s most iconic models in tribute to her late brother — and Angela Missoni celebrated her 20th anniversary at her family house. To cover the week, T’s photographers fanned out across the city to capture the spectacle. Click through the slide show to see the best images they took.

headline: Saudi Arabia Resists Independent Inquiry on Yemen Atrocities
abstract: Renewed efforts to set up a U.N.-backed commission of inquiry on Yemen rights abuses is called “premature” by Saudi Arabia, a party to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Saudi Arabia and its allies are pushing back on a renewed effort to establish a United Nations-backed independent international panel to investigate human rights abuses in Yemen.

headline: Linda Lavin: The First Time I Sang in New York. (It Was a Bar Mitzvah.)
abstract: Linda Lavin’s mother gave up a dream. Her daughter lived it.
lead_paragraph: So here’s the story. My mother, Lucille Potter Lavin, was a singer, an opera singer, with a very beautiful lyric coloratura and a brief but dazzling career in New York. She sang on the radio and early TV with George Gershwin, Risë Stevens and Paul Whiteman, until she and my father moved back to Portland, Me., to give birth to me.

headline: Fitting Your Photos on Instagram
abstract: The image-sharing social network goes beyond the traditional picture squares, but it does have standards for shape and size.
lead_paragraph: Q. I thought Instagram now lets you post photos that aren’t in the standard square format, but it’s still cropping my pictures. Also, is it changing the resolution of my original image when I upload it?

headline: How Smart a Traveler Are You?
abstract: Here are a few questions, culled from recent articles from our Travel Tips collection, to test your travel savvy.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few questions, culled from recent articles from our Travel Tips collection, to test your travel savvy.

headline: When the Streets Were Mean (but Far Less Crowded)
abstract: The photographer Edward Grazda captured a city before our Gilded Age, when you could fix your car on the curb but you could never win at three-card monte.
lead_paragraph: These are photographs of affordable housing. Not literally, of course. But they are artifacts from a city in which apartments were plentiful and relatively cheap, and from this, much followed. “You could go to New York and become whatever you wanted,” said the photographer Edward Grazda, 70, who moved to the city in 1970. “Rent a place for a couple hundred dollars a month, and invent yourself. Which a lot of people did.”

headline: Uber Says It Will Leave Quebec Rather Than Face New Rules
abstract: The ride-hailing service said it would leave Montreal and the rest of Quebec province next month rather than abide by a new set of government regulations.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Uber said on Tuesday that it would stop service in Montreal and the Quebec province next month rather than accept new government rules, the second setback in a week for the ride-hailing service’s international operations.

headline: Tennessee’s Bob Corker Announces Retirement from Senate
abstract: Senator Bob Corker, the Tennessee Republican who leads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, announced on Tuesday that he will not seek re-election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, announced on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election next year, a move that is likely to set off a scramble pitting mainstream Republicans against President Trump’s populist wing.

headline: A Luxury Building Boom Hits Montreal
abstract: The largest of the developments is the new Four Seasons Hotel and Private Residences Montreal, a more than $200 million hotel and condo project.
lead_paragraph: Along the main shopping street in the area of downtown Montreal known as the Golden Square Mile, Sonya Szczygiel and her husband, John Guinto, have sold beaded bracelets made of semiprecious stones for the last five years.

headline: Parents of Otto Warmbier, North Korea Captive, Say He Was Tortured
abstract: In their first interview since their son died in June, they called North Korea a terrorist state for what they said his captors had done.
lead_paragraph: The parents of Otto F. Warmbier, the American student detained by North Korea who died shortly after he had been flown home comatose in June, said Tuesday that he had been tortured, describing his captors as “terrorists.”

headline: Puerto Ricans on Mainland Rely on Strangers to Reach Relatives
abstract: Nearly a week after Hurricane Maria, people are resorting to extreme measures — and the kindness of others — to reach loved ones in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s governor, Ricardo Rosselló, has asked people abroad worrying about their families to remain calm and be patient as the island continues to confront the crisis left in the wake of Hurricane Maria.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: A Queen Anne-style townhouse on East 82nd Street, which sold for $10.7 million, is among the recent transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $10.7 MILLION

headline: Twitter to Test Doubling Tweet Length to 280 Characters
abstract: Twitter is trying out a version of its service that extends the allotted text limit of a post to 280 characters, double the current amount.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter’s defining attribute has long been its brevity: 140 characters in a post and no more.

headline: Dismayed by Trump, Head of Drug Enforcement Administration to Leave
abstract: The administrator, Chuck Rosenberg, is close to James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director who was fired by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The acting head of the Drug Enforcement Administration will resign at the end of the week, according to law enforcement officials, who said he had become convinced that President Trump had little respect for the law.

headline: Our Favorite Milan Fashion Week Photos
abstract: Highlights from the shows we covered this season.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the shows we covered this season.

headline: High Tea on the Lower East Side
abstract: By night Garfunkel’s is a hard-to-find speakeasy, Victorian in décor. By day, it is the home of Janam Tea, which offers a proper tea service.
lead_paragraph: Above a burger place, brassy swing tunes filled a private room located behind a vault door and up an old staircase, left over from when the building was a bank.

headline: In Hamilton, N.J., Art, Nature and Trinidadian Delights
abstract: Grounds For Sculpture, a 42-acre arboretum and museum, is a quick bus ride from the train station and within walking distance of a Trinidadian roti shop.
lead_paragraph: Part Giverny, part “Gulliver’s Travels,” Grounds for Sculpture is an indoor-outdoor museum and arboretum sprinkled with surrealism, bawdiness and eerie surprises. The 42-acre property in Hamilton, N.J., about 60 miles southwest of New York City, is a place to get lost, both literally and figuratively.

headline: Pot Farmer to Neighbors: Chill Out. Neighbors: No.
abstract: In the Willamette Valley of Oregon, longtime residents clash with the new cannabis farmer next door.
lead_paragraph: McMinnville, Ore. — “This is hostile territory. Everyone hates us.”

headline: Trump Plans 45,000 Limit on Refugees Admitted to U.S.
abstract: The proposed number is the lowest any White House has sought since 1980.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to cap refugee admissions at 45,000 over the next year, according to current and former government officials briefed on the decision, setting a historically low limit on the number of people who can resettle in the United States after fleeing persecution in their own countries

headline: Saint Laurent: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Basil Gogos, Who Painted Monsters With Love, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Gogos made penetrating portraits of Dracula, the Wolf Man and the Phantom of the Opera, and imbued Frankenstein’s monster with notable compassion.
lead_paragraph: Basil Gogos, who painted penetrating and chilling color portraits of movie monsters like Dracula, the Wolf Man and the Phantom of the Opera, and imbued Frankenstein’s monster with notable compassion, died on Sept. 13 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: A Helping Hand, but Whose?
abstract: Confusion over crossing Lexington Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: As Google Fights Fake News, Voices on the Margins Raise Alarm
abstract: The editorial head of a socialist website complained that Google is censoring the internet by curbing search traffic to his publication.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When David North, the editorial chairman of the World Socialist Web Site, noticed a drop in the site’s traffic in April, he initially chalked it up to news fatigue over President Trump or a shift in political consciousness.

headline: Trump Headlines Big-Dollar Fund-Raiser for National G.O.P.
abstract: Donors willing to pay $250,000 participated in a private round-table at Le Cirque, a New York restaurant.
lead_paragraph: For a cool quarter-million dollars per couple, wealthy Republican donors participated in a “private round-table” with President Trump on Tuesday night.

headline: Bills to Protect Mueller Are Bipartisan, but the Path Forward Is Uncertain
abstract: Most Senate Judiciary Committee members appear to support legislation to shield the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, from being fired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee appeared on Tuesday to back legislation that would provide an added layer of job protection for Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russian interference in last year’s election.

headline: Republican Party, Puerto Rico, North Korea: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
