abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Mayor Visits the High Line and Becomes One in Seven Million, Finally
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio toured parts of Manhattan, including the High Line, the popular park he had pointedly avoided. He kept his opinion to himself.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio strode north between the grasses and the sumac, his sleeves rolled up, his head visible above the crowds streaming along the High Line, the popular park on a former rail line in Chelsea.

headline: E.P.A. to Spend Nearly $25,000 on a Soundproof Booth for Pruitt
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency has signed a contract for a secure communications booth for the office its administrator, Scott Pruitt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency has signed a contract for nearly $25,000 to build a soundproof communications booth for the office of the administrator, Scott Pruitt.

headline: Trump to Propose Sweeping Tax Cut for Corporations and Individuals
abstract: The proposal is an attempt to answer wealthy donors’ demands for lower taxes without being seen by the president’s working-class base as a windfall for the rich.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump will propose a sweeping rewrite of the federal tax code on Wednesday, outlining a plan to reduce rates for corporations and individuals and eliminate some popular deductions, in a move that will set off a scramble among powerful groups eager to protect their tax breaks.

headline: Prison Term for Weiner Is Set, but Where Will He Go?
abstract: Multiple factors may affect where Anthony Weiner will serve his 21-month sentence, including his notoriety, his record and his status as a sex offender.
lead_paragraph: He pleaded guilty to exchanging lewd messages with a 15-year-old girl. He learned his sentence: 21 months. And now the big question for Anthony D. Weiner is: Where will he serve?

headline: How Failure of the Obamacare Repeal Affects Consumers
abstract: People with Medicaid and employer plans need not worry about big policy changes. But the individual insurance market will be marked by high prices and limited choices next year.
lead_paragraph: Obamacare repeal is dead, again. But the months of Republican attacks on the health law will still have consequences for some consumers.

headline: Prosecutor Recommends Loss of Vacation for Officer in James Blake Case
abstract: The officer, James Frascatore, was charged with using excessive force against the former tennis player when he took him down in 2015, mistaking him for a fraud suspect.
lead_paragraph: Four days of public disciplinary hearings for a police officer accused of using excessive force to take down James Blake, the retired professional tennis player, boiled down to a single question, a prosecutor said: “Was there cause for force to be used?”

headline: A Corruption Case Worth Repeating
abstract: Cleaning up Albany was never going to be easy, and now prosecutors will need to retry Dean Skelos.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court decision to overturn the 2015 corruption convictions of the former Albany powerhouse Dean Skelos and his son has us channeling “I’m Henery the Eighth, I Am,” an old British music hall song. In the 1960s hit version by Herman’s Hermits, a singer calls out, “Second verse, same as the first.”

headline: Paul Manafort Expects to Be Indicted, Longtime Trump Adviser Says
abstract: The adviser, Roger J. Stone Jr., also said he told the House Intelligence Committee that he had not colluded with Russians or seen any collusion by Trump associates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roger J. Stone Jr., an informal adviser to President Trump, said on Tuesday that Mr. Trump’s former campaign chairman is expecting to be indicted by federal prosecutors investigating Russia’s attempts to disrupt last year’s election.

headline: Y/Project: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Chad’s Inclusion in Travel Ban Could Jeopardize American Interests, Officials Say
abstract: Experts on Africa in the Trump administration said they were mystified by the ban on travel from Chad, an American counterterrorism partner in Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to impose his updated travel ban on Chad came over the objections of Pentagon and State Department officials, who argued that alienating the nation, one of America’s more reliable counterterrorism allies in Africa, risked harming long-term national security interests, administration officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Says N.F.L. Is Getting Soft. Players Hit Back.
abstract: Some players grumble about a lot of rules to curb dangerous tackles but insist they are still hitting very, very hard.
lead_paragraph: President Trump says the N.F.L. has gone soft.

headline: Ireland to Hold Abortion Referendum Next Year
abstract: Voters will be asked to lift or ease the bitterly contested constitutional prohibition.
lead_paragraph: Ireland will vote in a referendum next year on whether to lift or ease the country’s constitutional ban on abortion, one of the most restrictive such laws in the Western world.

headline: Discrimination Based on Sex Is Debated in Case of Gay Sky Diver
abstract: Donald Zarda was fired from his job as an instructor after telling a female student he was gay. Lawyers for the federal government have opposing positions on the federal discrimination law.
lead_paragraph: About seven years ago, Donald Zarda, a Long Island sky-diving instructor, shared a bit of personal information with a female student as they prepared for a jump. He was, he told the woman, “100 percent gay.”

headline: Chuck Person, With N.C.A.A. and N.B.A. Pedigree, Runs Afoul of F.B.I.
abstract: Federal investigators say Person, who spent 13 seasons in the N.B.A., participated in a bribery scheme as a coach at Auburn.
lead_paragraph: As the associate head coach at Auburn University, Chuck Person knew he had plenty to sell to the elite high school basketball players he recruited. He was the N.B.A. rookie of the year in 1987 and a deadly shooter with a colorful nickname, the Rifleman, who spent  13 seasons in the league. He also earned a championship ring as an assistant coach with the 2010 Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: U.S. Slaps Duties on Canadian Jet, Raising Trade Tensions
abstract: The new duties on Bombardier, which will more than triple the price, come as Canadian and American negotiators clash at the Nafta table.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The United States announced Tuesday that it would impose duties on imports of a new jet made by the Canadian jet maker Bombardier, a decision likely to fuel trade tensions between the United States and Canada just as the two countries face off over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Sessions Calls for ‘Recommitment’ to Free Speech on Campus, Diving Into Debate
abstract: Speaking at Georgetown University’s law school, Attorney General Jeff Sessions backed unrestricted speech on campuses as he faced scores of protesters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions dived into the debate over free speech on college campuses on Tuesday, inserting the Justice Department into a little-known lawsuit against a Georgia college and, in a speech that embraced First Amendment protections, comparing the tactics of one student group to the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Black Lives or Bottom Line? Activists Ask What N.F.L. Protests Are All About
abstract: As the nation debates football players’ kneeling during the national anthem, activists wonder whether issues of racism and police misconduct will be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: While a debate over professional football players kneeling during the national anthem consumed much of the country over the weekend, a scene was playing out around St. Louis that drew far less notice. There, demonstrators protested the acquittal of a white former police officer in the fatal 2011 shooting of a black man, marching inside a mall and through the streets in daily protests over the case for more than a week.

headline: White House Considers Tougher Rules as Part of Immigration Overhaul
abstract: The newest blueprint includes hiring 10,000 more immigration agents and eliminating protections for some migrant children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials are circulating a set of hard-line immigration proposals — including the hiring of 10,000 new immigration enforcement agents — to House Republicans alarmed by President Trump’s pledge to protect around 800,000 so-called Dreamers.

headline: ‘This Is Like in War’: A Scramble to Care for Puerto Rico’s Sick and Injured
abstract: The situation on Puerto Rico was becoming increasingly critical as residents struggled to find medical care amid a shortage of power, water and gasoline.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — As Hurricane Maria pummeled Puerto Rico, María Martínez Espada, 86, slipped because of a water leak in her apartment and broke her hip. Almost a week later, doctors at Hospital del Maestro have not been able to operate because of a shortage of medical supplies.

headline: At Puerto Rico’s Main Airport, Heavy Hearts and Long Waits
abstract: Commercial air traffic has increased, but many were stuck waiting at the gates and some wondered if they would ever come back.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport is normally a bustling and happy place, full of vacationers and warm family reunions.

headline: Roy Moore Wins Senate G.O.P. Runoff in Alabama
abstract: Mr. Moore, a firebrand former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, overcame efforts by top Republicans to rescue his rival, Senator Luther Strange.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Roy S. Moore, a firebrand former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, overcame efforts by top Republicans to rescue his rival, Senator Luther Strange, soundly defeating him on Tuesday in a special primary runoff.

headline: Corrections: September 27, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 27, 2017.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day: Prison Term for Weiner is Set, But Where Will He Go?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 27, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “Martha Stewart, she’s like an icon. Anthony Weiner is just another politician who is being sent to jail, of whom there are many from New York as well as from all over the country.”

headline: Where Caribou Roam
abstract: Jacob Stulberg puts on a show for us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I’m not sure whether it stems from a solving, constructing, or editing mind-set, but I’m always fascinated by the variety of “circled letter” themes in puzzles. Circles can highlight letters within a single entry that spell a word, whether they’re adjacent or spread out. At times, they can be arranged to form images the solver must identify. There have even been puzzles where the circles were used to bring attention to noncircled letters.

headline: Review: In ‘The Treasurer,’ a Son Remembers Mama, as She Forgets Everything
abstract: Max Posner’s tender yet unforgiving new play considers a son’s inability to love a mother who has dementia.
lead_paragraph: The man standing before us, a middle-aged geologist with festering mother issues, doesn’t like sharing his feelings with others. Yet because he is the center of a drama, and a memory play at that, he finds himself baring the unmentionables of his soul to an abyss of unseen listeners.

headline: How Couples Are Coping With Trump’s Travel Ban
abstract: President Trump issued a new order indefinitely barring almost all travel to the United States from seven countries, citing national security threats. We spoke with Iranian and American fiancés separated by the ban.
lead_paragraph: President Trump issued a new order indefinitely barring almost all travel to the United States from seven countries, citing national security threats. We spoke with Iranian and American fiancés separated by the ban.

headline: Siemens and Alstom Will Merge Rail Operations Into Global Giant
abstract: The deal will create a company with revenue of about $18 billion, rivaling Chinese state-backed competitors.
lead_paragraph: The German industrial giant Siemens plans to merge its rail business with the French train equipment maker Alstom, the companies said Tuesday, creating a behemoth that can compete with the Chinese-state backed China Railway Rolling Stock Corporation.

headline: Microsoft C.E.O. Says Tech’s Progress on Gender Equality Is ‘Not Sufficient’
abstract: Satya Nadella said Silicon Valley had “a significant distance to cover” in offering equal opportunities for female workers.
lead_paragraph: More women are working in Silicon Valley, showing the tech industry has made progress that is “good, but not sufficient,” Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, said Tuesday.

headline: ‘Law & Order True Crime: The Menendez Murders’ Episode 1: The Limits of Nostalgia
abstract: Can a show whose essence is its formulism tackle the anthology crime series?
lead_paragraph: Murder, it seems, just ain’t what it used to be. American nostalgia reliably follows a two-decade cycle — today we miss the ’90s; in the ’90s it was the ’70s; and I’m told that in the ’70s sock hops made a comeback. If the recent flood of ’90s-based true-crime TV is any indication, we clearly feel some similar nostalgia toward even violent crime. It’s a little bit twisted (guilty), and the reason is anybody’s guess (Dr. Freud?), but it’s no less true for its strangeness: ’90s crime is as much a part of the zeitgeist as chokers and emo-band reunions.

headline: Now Hosting the Presidents Cup: A Former Polluted Dump
abstract: Tom Kite transformed a Superfund site into Liberty National Golf Club, with views of Manhattan and other New York landmarks.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Two months after Tom Kite won the 1992 United States Open, the crowning achievement of his Hall of Fame golf career, he was playing in a law firm’s company outing near Baltimore. A lawyer at the event asked Kite if he had ever designed a golf course. Kite just so happened to have a fledgling course design firm, partnering with the veteran architect Bob Cupp on several projects.

headline: Yankees, With Leaping Save by Hicks, Stay Alive in A.L. East Race
abstract: A victory over Tampa Bay, coupled with a loss by Boston, gave the Yankees home-field advantage for a wild-card playoff, and tightened the division race.
lead_paragraph: It was the former Yankees catcher Yogi Berra who supposedly said, “It ain’t over till it’s over” while he was managing the Mets to their improbable 1973 pennant run.

headline: Lyft Adds Ford to Its List of Self-Driving Car Partners
abstract: Lyft was already working with Waymo, a sister company of Google, and General Motors on self-driving partnerships. Now add Ford to that list.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Lyft, winning the race to create the first fully self-driving vehicles on the road is a far from lonely pursuit. The company’s ethos is the more partners, the merrier.

headline: U.S. Climate Change Policy: Made in California
abstract: A peculiar confluence of history, legal precedent and defiance has set the stage for a regulatory mutiny in California that would reverberate throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The Trump administration may appear to control climate policy in Washington, but the nation’s most dynamic environmental regulator is here in California.

headline: Is Germany Still a Haven for Israelis? After Election, Some Wonder
abstract: Some Jews read the worst into gains made by the far-right Alternative for Germany party. Others said Germany was still more progressive than Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Some freaked out.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Liar’ and ‘The Blacklist’
abstract: In “Liar,” a first date between strangers goes smoothly until it unravels the next morning. And it’s a busy night for returns, with “Empire,” “The Blacklist” and more.
lead_paragraph: In “Liar,” a first date between strangers goes smoothly until it unravels the next morning. And it’s a busy night for returns: “Empire,” “The Blacklist” and “Modern Family” are just some of the offerings.

headline: Wilbur Ross, Fresh From China Visit, Warns of ‘Lopsided’ Trade Relationship
abstract: The United States commerce secretary said China’s government needed to do more to allow foreign companies to operate freely and close the trade deficit.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — During his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump talked tough on China, accusing the world’s second-largest economy of stealing jobs from Americans. On Wednesday, Wilbur Ross, his commerce secretary, echoed that sentiment, calling for a dramatic shift in the countries’ trade relationship.

headline: Puerto Rico After Hurricane Maria
abstract: What do you know about what is happening in Puerto Rico right now?
lead_paragraph: This photo was taken after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, a United States commonwealth, in September. A recent Times article reported that:

headline: 鸭绿江畔，中朝边境掠影
abstract: 中国是朝鲜唯一的盟友，两国之间只有鸭绿江一江之隔；但在政治上，这对盟友正渐行渐远。随着半岛局势日趋紧张，鸭绿江畔的居民和游客对朝鲜也有着不同的看法。
lead_paragraph: 中国是朝鲜唯一的盟友，两国之间只有鸭绿江一江之隔；但在政治上，这对盟友正渐行渐远。随着半岛局势日趋紧张，鸭绿江畔的居民和游客对朝鲜也有着不同的看法。

headline: In Her Own Words, Photographing the Vietnam War
abstract: While covering the Vietnam War, Catherine Leroy wrote over 100 letters home, detailing her professional and personal experiences.
lead_paragraph: While covering the Vietnam War, Catherine Leroy wrote over 100 letters home, detailing her professional and personal experiences.

headline: How Big Banks Became Our Masters
abstract: Lending to consumers or small companies is no longer a core business for large banks. Mainly they are trading assets that enrich the rich.
lead_paragraph: Ten years on from the financial crisis, it’s hard not to have a sense of déjà vu.

headline: How Gun Controls Work Beyond Washington
abstract: California legislators bucked the N.R.A. Now condors soar freely. Congress should show that courage, too.
lead_paragraph: The majestic, though vulturous, California condor is once again soaring above the wilds. It was on the brink of extinction 30 years ago when the last 22 giant birds were captured in a desperate effort to breed them in captivity. There are now an estimated 450 condors, with 270 freely swooping and scavenging in California, Arizona, Utah and Mexico.

headline: Folks, We’re Home Alone
abstract: We need to adapt to succeed, and this president isn’t helping.
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson wrote a famous memoir, “Present at the Creation,” about the birth of the post-World War II order — an order whose institutions produced six decades of security and growth for a lot of people. We’re now at a similar moment of rapid change — abroad and at home. Many institutions have to be rethought. But any book about Washington today would have to be called “Absent at the Creation.”

headline: Trump’s Empty Culture Wars
abstract: Many cultural controversies are well worth fighting over. The president is a virtuoso of the other kind.
lead_paragraph: The secret of culture war is that it is often a good and necessary thing. People don’t like culture wars when they’re on the losing side, and while they’re losing they often complain about how cultural concerns are distractions from the “real” issues, usually meaning something to do with the deficit or education or where to peg the Medicare growth rate or which terrorist haven the United States should be bombing next.

headline: Playing the Online Dating Game, in a Wheelchair
abstract: Being upfront about my disability on Tinder and other dating sites has liberated me.
lead_paragraph: The first time I forayed into online dating, I let my wheelchair show just a little in my photos. The good guys, I hoped, would be so taken by my clever profile and witty banter that they’d be able to look beyond my disability, if they even noticed it at all.

headline: How a Critic Opens a Book: A Q&A With Parul Sehgal
abstract: “I don’t like when book reviews feel hermetic. I always want to open things up — to say that this is a book, but it’s also just a stage for certain ideas.”
lead_paragraph: Parul Sehgal joined The New York Times’s team of daily book critics in late July.  She was previously a senior editor for The New York Times Book Review; she also wrote a column, “Roving Eye,” focused on international literature. Her latest review is on “Difficult Women,” by David Plante. What follows is a lightly edited Q. and A.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Student Trapped in Indiana Cave for 58 Hours Licked Water Off the Walls’
abstract: How did a student become trapped in a cave?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: When a Star Architect Wants You Not to See His Work
abstract: In restoring Mies van der Rohe’s New National Gallery in Berlin, David Chipperfield is aiming to meet modern standards while making himself invisible.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “We’re like surgeons around a body,” said David Chipperfield as he looked at Berlin’s New National Gallery. The building, designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, one of the 20th century’s greatest architects, was almost as bare as it had been at its topping-out ceremony, in April 1967. The British architect and his lieutenant, Martin Reichert, a partner in his sizable Berlin office, surveyed the dirty steel frame and exposed concrete walls atop weed-strewn sand. “We’ve opened him up and now we’re looking at him.’”

headline: In Her Own Words, Photographing the Vietnam War
abstract: While covering the Vietnam War, Catherine Leroy wrote over 100 letters home, detailing her professional and personal experiences as the only female photojournalist in Vietnam at the time.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Leroy was 21 when she arrived in Vietnam in 1966 with only a hundred dollars, a Leica M2 and a limited professional portfolio. Over the next three years covering the war, she built an exceptional body of work: surviving and documenting a capture by the North Vietnamese Army, parachuting in combat operations with the 173rd Airborne, and being published on the covers of major magazines, including Life and Paris Match.

headline: 鴨綠江畔，中朝邊境掠影
abstract: 中國是朝鮮唯一的盟友，兩國之間只有鴨綠江一江之隔；但在政治上，這對盟友正漸行漸遠。隨著半島局勢日趨緊張，鴨綠江畔的居民和遊客對朝鮮也有著不同的看法。
lead_paragraph: 中國是朝鮮唯一的盟友，兩國之間只有鴨綠江一江之隔；但在政治上，這對盟友正漸行漸遠。隨著半島局勢日趨緊張，鴨綠江畔的居民和遊客對朝鮮也有著不同的看法。

headline: What We Learn When Two Ruthless Killers, Heart Disease and Cancer, Reveal a Common Root
abstract: Understanding the link will involve unraveling the mysteries of inflammation.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I met a very unlucky man. A financial adviser in his mid-60s, he seemed chronically short of breath, and he had an odd habit of widening his eyes and raising his brows every time he finished a sentence.

headline: Franklin Leonard Wants to Diversify the Box Office
abstract: The film executive on foreign crossover appeal and passing on “Slumdog Millionaire.”
lead_paragraph: You graduated from Harvard and worked in politics, then management consulting, then Hollywood. What is the through line with those jobs? It has probably been advocacy for people whose stories have historically been excluded or overlooked. I had pretty much every advantage growing up — my father’s a doctor, my mom was a teacher — but when you grow up a black nerd in the Deep South while Steve Urkel is on television, you learn to identify with those on the outside.

headline: When ‘Not Guilty’ Is a Life Sentence
abstract: What happens after a defendant is found not guilty by reason of insanity? Often the answer is involuntary confinement in a state psychiatric hospital — with no end in sight.
lead_paragraph: Despite Ann’s determination to betray no emotion, a drop of sweat rolled down her temple as a guard painstakingly examined her lunch items. That Sunday morning, she had taken two buses, two trains and a shuttle to get from her home to the New York state psychiatric facility where her son is confined. Frustrated, she pushed back a little, but just a little, when the guard took away two sealed bottles of fruit-flavored water, a special treat that Ann had made an extra stop to buy. She watched as he held them up to examine them and concluded that they must contain caffeine — which is not allowed — because they did not read, “Does not contain caffeine.”

headline: Bruce Springsteen on Broadway: The Boss on His ‘First Real Job’
abstract: It’s not a small rock show or a theatrical event. Inspired by a White House concert, one of rock’s celebrated storytellers is bringing his tales to a new stage.
lead_paragraph: “Springsteen on Broadway.” For the songwriter who rose from bar gigs on the Jersey Shore to become a symbol of empathy for working-class America, who has been playing arenas for nearly four decades, the simple juxtaposition seems like a clash of scale and style. Is this an intimate concert, or a theatrical event? Mr. Springsteen says it’s something else, and that an extended Broadway residency is the statement he wants to make now.

headline: The Golfer Lydia Ko Loves Beaches (and Legos)
abstract: Her favorite destinations include Jeju Island in South Korea, Queenstown in New Zealand and Disney Springs in Orlando.
lead_paragraph: The golfer Lydia Ko, 20, who is currently ranked eighth globally, calls three places home: South Korea, where she was born, New Zealand’s North Island, where she grew up, and Orlando, Fla., where she lives. “They’re different and all equally dear to my heart,” she said.

headline: Alabama Republicans Bet on Roy Moore, a Familiar Rebel, for Senate
abstract: Roy S. Moore, a former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, was repeatedly cast aside, even by his fellow Republicans, as a bigot and a hatemonger. Now he may win Jeff Sessions’ Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: PIEDMONT, Ala. — Roy S. Moore, a former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, seems to keep score on everything.

headline: Tracking the Hyper-Gentrification of New York, One Lost Knish Place at a Time
abstract: In “Vanishing New York,” Jeremiah Moss laments the transformation of a city into a place that no longer accommodates failure.
lead_paragraph: VANISHING NEW YORK How a Great City Lost Its Soul By Jeremiah Moss Illustrated. 465 pp. Dey St./William Morrow. $28.99.

headline: As China’s Economy Slows, ‘Business Cults’ Prey on Young Job Seekers
abstract: Swindlers are seizing on the anxieties of a generation of young Chinese willing to go to great lengths to avoid the shame of unemployment.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Some look like high-tech firms, promising young college graduates a fast track to riches. Others pose as charitable groups on a membership drive, or companies building a sales network for a new product. Tens of millions across China are signing up — and learning that all is not as advertised.

headline: Sustainable Travel Can Be Budget-Friendly
abstract: Not only should traveling sustainably not break the bank — it’s frequently a more enjoyable product than its nonsustainable counterpart. Some tips on how to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: When you think of sustainable travel, what comes to mind? Gorilla trekking in Uganda, perhaps, or a sojourn in a remote yet well-appointed eco-lodge in the forests of Costa Rica, or even a luxurious stay at a Galápagos safari camp with an infinity pool and locally made teak furniture. If these high-cost trips are what pop into your head, your picture of what qualifies as sustainable tourism is not necessarily wrong — it’s just incomplete.

headline: Can I Spread the Word About an Unvaccinated Child?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to reveal another parent is an anti-vaxxer and more.
lead_paragraph: I’m pregnant with my first child, and concern for my unborn baby has prompted me to ask my friends if their children are vaccinated. One close friend, Y, has two young (vaccinated) children, and lives near another friend, X. Both Y and I have suspected for some time that X chose not to vaccinate her child, and we have been trying to work up the courage to ask her. With the new pregnancy as an excuse, the task fell to me.

headline: The Devastation in Puerto Rico, as Seen From Above
abstract: Aerial imagery shows the destruction that Hurricane Maria brought to the United States commonwealth.
lead_paragraph: Aerial imagery shows the destruction that Hurricane Maria brought to the United States commonwealth.

headline: Should the Middle Class Invest in Risky Tech Start-Ups?
abstract: With the tech industry’s increasing dominance, Jason Calacanis, a tech investor, offers a radical guide for prospering: betting on more of it.
lead_paragraph: Jason Calacanis cuts an unusual figure for a financial savior in Silicon Valley, where it’s fashionable for the world’s richest men to feign embarrassed modesty about their wealth and power.

headline: Living in ... Glen Cove, N.Y.
abstract: Where the wealthy once summered on the North Shore of Long Island, development is again booming.
lead_paragraph: Where the wealthy once summered on the North Shore of Long Island, development is again booming.

headline: Glen Cove, N.Y.: An Old Gem Poised for a Comeback
abstract: Where the wealthy once summered on the North Shore of Long Island, development is again booming.
lead_paragraph: For 43 years, Lorraine Wendt, 79, loved her five-bedroom house on more than two acres in Lloyd Neck, N.Y. But as a widow, she wanted to downsize, though she couldn’t decide whether she preferred to be on the water or in a town.

headline: National Parks Struggle With a Mounting Crisis: Too Many Visitors
abstract: Overcrowding has put a strain on a park system already grappling with climate change and funding problems, leading to proposals to limit access.

abstract: More than 153,000 homes were damaged in two earthquakes this month, and the future for many who can’t return to them is highly uncertain.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — They are a population adrift, cast loose by a disaster.

headline: Leaving a Condemned Mexico City Building
abstract: Since the Sept. 19 earthquake in Mexico, about 500 buildings across Mexico City have been found to be structurally unsafe. At this building on Iturbide street, residents are packing up and leaving.
lead_paragraph: Since the Sept. 19 earthquake in Mexico, about 500 buildings across Mexico City have been found to be structurally unsafe. At this building on Iturbide street, residents are packing up and leaving.

abstract: After he enthusiastically endorsed Senator Luther Strange on Twitter, President Trump deleted those tweets after Mr. Strange lost.
lead_paragraph: After enthusiastically endorsing an Alabama senator’s campaign for re-election, President Trump distanced himself on Tuesday night from the candidate’s loss in the most Trumpian way possible: He deleted his supportive tweets.

headline: Seth Meyers Criticizes Trump’s Response to Crisis in Puerto Rico
abstract: Mr. Meyers was frustrated that President Trump chose to remind his Twitter followers on Monday that the island is in debt to Wall Street lenders.

headline: How Exercise Might Increase Your Self-Control

lead_paragraph: For most of us, temptations are everywhere, from the dessert buffet to the online shoe boutique. But a new study suggests that exercise might be a simple if unexpected way to increase our willpower and perhaps help us to avoid making impulsive choices that we will later regret.

headline: Yingluck Shinawatra, Ex-Leader Who Fled Thailand, Gets 5-Year Sentence

lead_paragraph: This is a guest lesson from Jinnie Spiegler, the director of curriculum at the Anti-Defamation League. She has written for us previously on 10 Ways to Talk to Students About Sensitive Issues in the News.

headline: Pentagon and NATO Leaders, Visiting Kabul, Are Met by Insurgent Rocket Barrage
abstract: The attack at the international airport and near the American Embassy underscored the fragile security in Afghanistan and the insurgency’s broad reach.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents fired dozens of rockets at the international airport in Kabul and near the American Embassy on Wednesday as the top leaders of the Pentagon and NATO met with the Afghan president.

headline: Review: NBC’s ‘Will & Grace’ Hasn’t Changed. But the World Has.
abstract: After a clunky, Trump-y premiere episode, this throwback comedy stays in its comfort zone, for better and worse.
lead_paragraph: TV’s numerous series revivals usually make at least a gesture toward rationalizing why they need to tell one more story. “Twin Peaks: The Return” had Agent Cooper emerge from the Black Lodge after 25 years. “Gilmore Girls” brought Rory home to Stars Hollow after her grandfather’s death.

abstract: They will receive $50,000 each for the award, which is given to rising American playwrights.
lead_paragraph: Ayad Akhtar and Lucas Hnath, two highly decorated playwrights, can each add another feather to their caps: They have been named winners of the 2017 Steinberg Playwright Awards, given to rising American playwrights. The award comes with $50,000.

headline: N.F.L. Protests Draw Attention – and Comparisons – in Australia
abstract: President Trump’s criticisms of N.F.L. and N.B.A. players are fueling Australia’s own debate about sport, race and protests.
