headline: Confederate Flags With Cotton Found on American University Campus
abstract: It was at least the second time this year that racist symbols were discovered on the school’s Washington campus.
lead_paragraph: Ten Confederate flag posters with cotton attached to them were discovered on the campus of American University on Tuesday evening, according to a statement posted by the school.

headline: Maye Musk, 69, Is Now a CoverGirl
abstract: Ms. Musk has modeled for five decades, holds master’s degrees in dietetics and nutritional sciences and has no intention of retiring. Ever.
lead_paragraph: In the past year or so, the beauty company CoverGirl has shown it is determined to corner the market on diversity. Today, months after signing James Charles, its first cover boy, and Nura Afia, its first CoverGirl in a hijab, CoverGirl debuted its newest ambassador: Maye Musk, 69, who has been modeling for five decades. She is also a dietitian and nutritionist with two master’s degrees.

headline: Review: Robert Redford and Jane Fonda Are Neighbors With Benefits in ‘Our Souls at Night’
abstract: This small-town romance was adapted from the novel by Kent Haruf.
lead_paragraph: As gentle as a moth’s wing, as soft and sweet as the flesh of a marshmallow, “Our Souls at Night” chronicles the blossoming of a December-December romance between two neighbors in the fictional prairie town of Holt, Colo. It begins not with a spark of passion but with a sensible, if unusual, proposal. Addie Moore shows up at Louis Waters’s house and asks if he will sleep with her. Addie doesn’t mean she wants to have sex with Louis. She wants to slide under the covers next to him, turn off the bedside lamp and chat quietly until slumber arrives, simulating the easy marital intimacy that the two of them, both long widowed, have learned to live without. Louis, startled by the idea, agrees to think about it.

headline: How a Quirky Art Prize Tied to the DeVos Family Went Political
abstract: This year’s $500,000 ArtPrize contest in Grand Rapids, Mich., created by the education secretary Betsy DeVos’s son Rick, is the first in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Patricia Constantine thought hard about whether to use an image of the education secretary, Betsy DeVos, in her entry to this year’s ArtPrize contest. The mixed-media painting depicts Ms. Constantine as a carnival freak suffering for the perceived misdeeds of Ms. DeVos and President Trump. But Ms. DeVos isn’t just your everyday target in Michigan: She and her family provide major financial support to the ArtPrize awards that might honor the very works that skewer her.

headline: Nintendo’s Super NES Classic Edition Is Nostalgia, Revisited
abstract: Following last year’s NES Classic Edition console, the $80 Super NES version is a flashback to Nintendo’s early-90s glory days, but it lacks many modern features.
lead_paragraph: Nintendo tapped into the retro gaming trend last year with the release of the NES Classic Edition game console, a $60 gadget that came loaded with 30 vintage games, which became an unexpected hit. Now, the Japanese video game giant is again nodding to the past with the Super NES Classic Edition console.

headline: What Does a ‘Woke Woman’ Wear?
abstract: Designers at Dior and Saint Laurent have come up with two very different proposals.
lead_paragraph: The final round of the ready-to-wear collections began here with a quote, and a call to arms.

headline: How to Decide Where to Donate Your Money After Disasters
abstract: In a time of hurricanes, floods, earthquakes and wildfires, choosing a charity can be overwhelming. Here’s some help.
lead_paragraph: First, there was Hurricane Harvey. Then came Irma, Jose and Maria. In between, there were floods, earthquakes and wildfires, too.

headline: How to Wreck a Brand in 3 Years
abstract: Lanvin’s third creative director in as many years, Olivier Lapidus, sent out logo-printed dresses and playsuits. Not exactly a return to elegance.
lead_paragraph: For his debut as Lanvin’s third creative director in three years, Olivier Lapidus (son of Ted, the couturier famed for his unisex fashion) resurrected the raised runway. Eyeing it before the show, Stefano Tonchi, editor of W magazine, said, “I haven’t seen a runway like that in 15 years.” Turned out the runway was not the only thing Mr. Lapidus brought back.

headline: ‘Frida Sofia’: The Mexico Earthquake Victim Who Never Was
abstract: News coverage of a girl supposedly trapped in a collapsed elementary school captured the public’s attention. How did everyone get it so wrong?
lead_paragraph: Her plight captured the attention of the Mexican public: a 12-year-old girl, trapped in the rubble of a collapsed elementary school as rescuers rushed to save her.

headline: Trump Proposes the Most Sweeping Tax Overhaul in Decades
abstract: In Indiana, President Trump began an intense push to slash taxes and salvage what is left of his foundering legislative agenda in Congress.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — President Trump on Wednesday began an ambitious push to slash taxes and salvage what remains of his embattled legislative agenda in Congress this year, proposing a politically challenging array of tax cuts for individuals and businesses that would constitute the most sweeping changes to the federal tax code in decades.

headline: My Father Died in Afghanistan, and I Support Colin Kaepernick
abstract: Americans have been disrespecting “The Star-Spangled Banner” for years. Why is the president now attacking athletes who protest for a good cause?
lead_paragraph: I went to my first Kansas City Chiefs football game in December 2010, six months after my father, Army Col. John McHugh, had been killed by a suicide bomber in Kabul, Afghanistan. The team sent my newly minted Gold Star family pregame field passes and seats only a few rows behind the team’s bench.

headline: Wolfgang Schäuble, Architect of Austerity, Is Out as Germany’s Finance Minister
abstract: He will become the speaker of Parliament, effectively capping a decades-long career at the height of German politics.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Wolfgang Schäuble, a dominant figure in the European Union for more than a decade, will leave his post as Germany’s finance minister, effectively ending a career in international politics that has been marked by his insistence on budgetary penitence for suffering eurozone countries.

headline: McConnell Gambled on Health Care and the Alabama Senate Race. He Lost.
abstract: A majority leader celebrated for years as a brilliant tactician suddenly looks vulnerable to dissent in his caucus, and insurgent Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, is not a man who leaves things to chance. But this week, in both policy and politics, Mr. McConnell gambled — and lost big.

headline: A Four-Bedroom Contemporary in a Johannesburg Suburb
abstract: Built in 2014, the house has treetop views and limited vistas of the downtown skyline of Sandton, a business hub nearby, from its second floor.
lead_paragraph: Built in 2014, the house has treetop views and limited vistas of the downtown skyline of Sandton, a business hub nearby, from its second floor.

headline: House Hunting in ... Johannesburg
abstract: Difficult economic conditions have adversely affected South African real estate in recent years, but the market finally seems to be rallying.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE IN A SUBURB OF JOHANNESBURG

headline: Satya Nadella on Women in Tech, A.I. and E-Sports
abstract: During an interview with The New York Times at a TimesTalks event, Microsoft C.E.O. Satya Nadella said that women in the technology industry have “a lot of distance” to make up.
lead_paragraph: During an interview with The New York Times at a TimesTalks event, Microsoft C.E.O. Satya Nadella said that women in the technology industry have “a lot of distance” to make up.

headline: The Dress: Honoring Tradition
abstract: How a bride’s culture or religion may influence her wedding gown.
lead_paragraph: For some, a white wedding gown is traditional. But Western wedding customs are not global and many brides choose a dress style and color — white, red, sleeveless or more modest — according to their cultural, or religious, traditions.

headline: In Ukraine, a Huge Ammunition Depot Catches Fire
abstract: One of the army’s largest storage sites caught fire, setting off tons of explosives. The authorities have blamed a drone for the attack.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — One of the Ukrainian Army’s largest ammunition depots caught fire overnight after what was probably an act of sabotage using a drone, an official said on Wednesday, setting off gigantic explosions and forcing the evacuation of about 30,000 people.

headline: My Time Undercover With the Alt-Right
abstract: What I learned from infiltrating extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: Patrik Hermansson spent nearly a year infiltrating the extreme right for the British anti-racist watchdog group Hope Not Hate. His findings were shared in an Op-Ed article by Jesse Singal, “Undercover with the Alt-Right,” as well as a report by the group.

headline: A Designer With a Low Profile Is Ready to Raise It Up
abstract: Before the LVMH Prize crowned her the next big thing, few had heard of Marine Serre. That’s about to change.
lead_paragraph: When Karl Lagerfeld, Phoebe Philo, Nicolas Ghesquière and the family Arnault agree, it is at least worth paying attention. This June they made their latest pronouncement: Marine Serre may be the next great designer.

headline: Southeast Asia Stakes Its Claim in the Art World
abstract: Works by artists from Indonesia, Myanmar and Vietnam plumb the roiling past and fractured present of places we have no excuse to be clueless about.
lead_paragraph: Until recently — the 1990s, let’s say — an American critic keeping tabs on new art would concentrate on New York’s museums and galleries; cast an occasional, often dismissive eye on Western Europe; and perhaps try to visit Los Angeles now and again. No longer. By the ’90s the idea of a single avant-garde was dead and buried, and in its place arose a pluralist art ecosystem that spans the planet. It makes larger intellectual demands than ever, and requires us to accept that we’ll never see everything or understand it completely. In the new global art world, even we New Yorkers are provincials.

headline: Why It’s Time to Kill Jack on ‘This Is Us’
abstract: NBC’s family dramedy has been beating a dead character for too long, and the contrived mystery is getting distracting.
lead_paragraph: On the season premiere of NBC’s “This Is Us,” we finally got clarity on a nagging question. In a flashback to just after the death of Jack (Milo Ventimiglia), his distraught wife, Rebecca (Mandy Moore), pulled up, crying, in front of the flame-gutted shell of their house. So this was the answer: Jack died in a fire.

headline: Read President Trump's Tax Proposal
abstract: The New York Times on Wednesday obtained the Trump administration's proposed tax framework that includes what would be the most sweeping changes to the tax code in decades.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times on Wednesday obtained the Trump administration's proposed tax framework that includes what would be the most sweeping changes to the tax code in decades.

headline: The Best Weeknight Recipes
abstract: With the right tools and ingredients, you can cook a simple, delicious dinner in under an hour.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: Iraq Escalates Dispute With Kurds, Threatening Military Action
abstract: Iraq threatened to send troops and seize oil fields and moved to shut down international flights in the Kurdish region after an independence referendum.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The Iraqi government escalated its confrontation with its northern Kurdish region on Wednesday, threatening to send troops and seize oil fields there and taking steps to shut down international flights to and from the region.

headline: A Deep Blue Vision of Earth From an Asteroid Hunter
abstract: As it slingshotted past Earth at 19,000 miles per hour on Friday, NASA’s Osiris-Rex spacecraft made a composite portrait of the planet.
lead_paragraph: As it slingshotted past Earth at 19,000 miles per hour on its journey to an asteroid, NASA’s Osiris-Rex spacecraft took a moment to admire the view — from 106,000 miles away.

headline: 215 Million Americans Watched the Solar Eclipse, Study Finds
abstract: It was bigger than the Super Bowl. Many more watched it in person or electronically than voted last year.
lead_paragraph: We hear it all the time: Americans are more divided than ever, or at least since the Civil War.

headline: New Director Named for Museum of African Art
abstract: Gus Casely-Hayford, a British author, curator and broadcaster, will take up the role at the Smithsonian Institution in February 2018.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution announced Wednesday that Gus Casely-Hayford, an author, curator and broadcaster on African history and culture, will be the new director of the National Museum of African Art.

headline: For Paper Trails in Voting
abstract: A tech company executive writes that auditing mechanisms like paper-based ballots go beyond directly securing elections, and ultimately build trust.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Remote Textile Plant May Secretly Fuel North Korea’s Weapons
abstract: A new assessment suggests that the fuel, which some had thought might be imported from Russia or China, is made within North Korea.
lead_paragraph: In the remote North Korean city of Hamhung, separated from the capital by vast, jagged mountains, an inconspicuous chemical plant may be secretly fueling the growing missile array that threatens the United States.

headline: Protomartyr Turns Dread Into Post-Post-Punk on ‘Relatives in Descent’
abstract: The Detroit band expands its jagged, dissonant vocabulary on a new album filled with songs that carve their own paths and bristle with tension.
lead_paragraph: “Dread 2017-18,” Joe Casey of Protomartyr declaims to start “Here Is the Thing,” tersely specifying the mood and theme of Protomartyr’s new album, “Relatives in Descent.” Political, environmental, epistemological, social, familial and individual anxieties fuel the latest songs by Protomartyr, a band from Detroit that has been reclaiming the jagged, muscular dissonances of post-punk for 21st-century America.

headline: Google Offers Concessions to Europe After Record Antitrust Fine
abstract: The search giant is changing how it operates its online shopping service, signaling a new willingness to bow to tightening regulatory pressure around the world.
lead_paragraph: Google announced concessions on Wednesday to European regulators over its online shopping service, signaling a new willingness by the Silicon Valley company to bow to tightening pressures from governments around the world.

headline: Stray Dogs Started Turning Blue. Then the Street Mobilized.
abstract: When a community in Mumbai turned out to help the canines, it was in a long tradition of caring for “community dogs,” protected by Indian law.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Mumbai turns out to be a pretty good place to be a dog.

headline: North Korea Skaters Seek Olympic Bid, and Diplomats Cheer
abstract: A pair of figure skaters — performing to a Beatles song — represent the best chance for the country to have athletes at the 2018 Winter Games in South Korea, and possibly, at defusing nuclear tension.
lead_paragraph: OBERSTDORF, Germany — The next effort to defuse the nuclear brinksmanship over North Korea’s missile and bomb testing may come, not from diplomats, but from a pair of North Korean figure skaters who perform to music by the Beatles.

headline: Preventing Nuclear War
abstract: A reader from the Union of Concerned Scientists discusses how to limit the president’s authority to launch a nuclear attack.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jeremy Corbyn Says U.K. Labour Party Is Ready to Govern
abstract: A party conference underscored the left-wing shift in Britain’s opposition party, and Mr. Corbyn’s control of it.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, England — Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, told supporters on Wednesday that their brand of left-wing politics had brought them to “the threshold of power,” as he ended an annual conference that consolidated his grip over the party and marked another stage in his journey from fringe politician to potential prime minister.

headline: Saudis Wonder What’s Next After the King Allows Women to Drive
abstract: While the change does not take effect until next June, the announcement was so abrupt it stunned the country, and the world.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Rights groups attacked it. Conservatives defended it. Comedians sang about it. A king had vowed to end it, but died without doing so.

headline: Ryanair Cancels More Flights, Affecting 400,000 More Passengers
abstract: Staffing issues have prompted the budget airline to cancel 18,000 flights from mid-November to mid-March, after already having cut 2,100.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ryanair, the low-cost Irish airline struggling to deal with staff shortages that prompted the cancellation this month of 2,100 flights, said on Wednesday that it would cut 18,000 more.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ Season 1, Episode 2: Battles Begin
abstract: The second episode leaves a lot of questions unanswered but keeps the dazzling visual effects coming.
lead_paragraph: Early in the run of “Star Trek: Discovery,” it is clear that character development will be a slow burn. In the franchise’s first serialized television show, everything else takes a back seat to action. For now, fans will have to be patient and just enjoy the dazzling special effects.

headline: Rick Pitino Is Out at Louisville Amid F.B.I. Investigation
abstract: Louisville’s Hall of Fame basketball coach, Rick Pitino, formerly of Kentucky, was removed Wednesday amid a mounting recruiting scandal.
lead_paragraph: One of college basketball’s most illustrious coaching careers seemed to come to an ignominious close on Wednesday as Rick Pitino was ousted by the University of Louisville.

headline: How to Be Mindful When Making Art
abstract: You don’t need any previous training to meditate through art, just a willingness to draw like a child, with freedom and a sense of curiosity.
lead_paragraph: “Art is a natural way to practice mindfulness. The colors, textures and sounds of creating pull us into the moment. You don’t need any previous training to meditate through art, just a willingness to draw like a child, with freedom and a sense of curiosity.” — Amy Maricle, an artist, art therapist and founder of Mindful Art Studio

headline: Louise Bourgeois: Imagination Unfolds in All Dimensions
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s superb survey links paintings, sculptures and spiders — and gives the artist’s printmaking new prominence.
lead_paragraph: As an artist and a brand, Louise Bourgeois was a force of nature. She was a prolific if not obsessive maker of art — sculpture, drawings and especially prints. There was — and probably still is — plenty of product.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Leaving Netflix by Oct. 1
abstract: Catch these 10 titles before they disappear.
lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Subscribe to our three-times weekly newsletter here.

headline: Sign-Stealing 101 Gets a Fan Ejected From Yankee Stadium
abstract: The espionage did not involve any of the shenanigans for which the Red Sox were recently fined. Instead, the fan just yelled out what he saw from the stands.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of baseball espionage, this was about as low-tech as it gets: A fan with a good view of the catcher and a strong set of lungs.

headline: New York Film Festival Is a Feast for True Believers
abstract: The festival, at 55, retains a near-holy belief in cinema as art. Highlights: new work by Agnès Varda, Agnieszka Holland and Valeska Grisebach.
lead_paragraph: “All things are possible in cinema,” Agnès Varda said back in 1966. This was at the New York Film Festival, during a conversation about form and content with Pier Paolo Pasolini and other cine luminaries. Over the decades — even as directors like Ms. Varda traded in their film cameras for digital ones and moviegoers turned into homebody binge-watchers — she and many of the world’s other greats continued to present work at this festival. Now, the New York Film Festival is 55, Ms. Varda is 89 and she’s back with “Faces Places,” a movie that — like this event — retains a near-holy belief in cinema as art.

headline: New Gravitational Wave Detection From Colliding Black Holes
abstract: Virgo, a new detector for gravitational waves, joined the L-shaped antennas seeking space-time reverberations from colliding black holes.
lead_paragraph: In another step forward for the rapidly expanding universe of invisible astronomy, scientists said on Wednesday that on Aug. 14 they had recorded the space-time reverberations known as gravitational waves from the collision of a pair of black holes 1.8 billion light years away from here.

headline: Bronx School Stabbing Leaves One Student Dead and Another Wounded
abstract: It was the first killing inside a New York City school building in more than two decades, the mayor said. An 18-year-old student was charged.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old was fatally stabbed and a 16-year-old was critically wounded in their Bronx high school on Wednesday morning in what the police say was apparently the culmination of weeks of conflict.

headline: Aid-in-Dying and Dementia
abstract: A reader objects that in an opinion article her views were likened to those of the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Abbie Hoffman Was No Donald Trump
abstract: A reader objects to David Brooks’s comparison of the 1960s activist to the current president.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why the BBC’s Star Political Reporter Now Needs a Bodyguard
abstract: Laura Kuenssberg, one of the public broadcaster’s top correspondents, was assigned protection during a Labour Party gathering after a series of threats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This week’s Labour Party conference, an annual gathering and one of the landmark events of the British political calendar, had an unexpected attendee: a bodyguard.

headline: Paul Horner, Fake News Writer Who Took Credit for Trump Victory, Dies at 38
abstract: The cause was an apparent drug overdose. His hoaxes included articles about paid protesters and claims that President Obama was gay and a Muslim.
lead_paragraph: Paul Horner, a writer who trolled the nation with his fabricated news stories and claimed that he was responsible for Donald J. Trump’s election victory, died last week. The cause was a suspected drug overdose, the authorities in Arizona said Wednesday.

headline: To Saudi Women: Drive On!
abstract: A reader hails the momentous change.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Virgil Abloh Isn’t SHOUTING (He Just LIKES Capital Letters)
abstract: A visit to Em Pty Gallery in SoHo, the new retail home of the design star’s label Off-White.
lead_paragraph: The floor of Em Pty Gallery in SoHo, the first outpost of Off-White in the United States, crunches underfoot. Mulch and leaves are scattered around the perimeter, and birch trees touch tips above the racks. A sign on the wall clarifies that the space “is a new conceptual platform merging art and programmed experiences.”

headline: How N.F.L. Sponsors Have Reacted to ‘Take a Knee’ Protests
abstract: Few companies commented on the protests at all, and those that did stuck to bland statements of support for American values.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has been loud lately. Its sponsors, not so much.

headline: Black Detectives’ Case: The New York Police Dept. Responds
abstract: The New York City Police Department takes issue with a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rochas: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: After Outcry, Irish Government Buys Yeats’s Artifacts
abstract: The department of culture provided funds to buy a number of the poet and his family’s personal effects, which were set to be auctioned.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amid fears that culturally significant items that belonged to the Nobel Prize-winning Irish poet W.B. Yeats would be sold to foreign buyers, the Irish government today announced it had secured the purchase of a portion of the collection ahead of an auction in London.

headline: What Keeps Puerto Rico’s Governor Awake at Night
abstract: In an interview, Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló talks about what the island needs to get through the enormous disaster of Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Gov. Ricardo A. Rosselló of Puerto Rico discussed the aftermath of Hurricane Maria and the needs of island residents with a reporter from The New York Times on Tuesday. Here are his remarks, edited for length and clarity.

headline: Russia Destroys Chemical Weapons, and Faults U.S. for Not Doing So
abstract: Presiding over the weapons’ destruction, President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that Washington was playing a devious double game.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia presided over the destruction of his country’s last declared chemical weapons on Wednesday, describing the elimination as a “historic event” and complaining that the United States has failed to purge its own chemical arsenal.

headline: The Fall of Rick Pitino: One Scandal Too Many
abstract: From Hawaii to Kentucky and Louisville, the college basketball coach has frequently run afoul of the rules.
lead_paragraph: Rick Pitino has achieved tremendous success as a college basketball coach. But he has also run afoul of N.C.A.A. rules at various points in his career. That caught up with him on Wednesday, when he was ousted as Louisville’s head coach.

headline: Siemens and Alstom Form European Train Giant to Beat Chinese Competition
abstract: Germany’s Siemens will combine its train unit with Alstom of France, showing how the threat from China is pushing the Continent together even as populist politics try to pull it apart.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Once, the merger of two iconic European companies might well have been derailed by regional political rivalries. But in the case of a deal between Siemens and Alstom, those concerns have receded in the face of a larger threat: China.

headline: Why Aren’t Paychecks Growing? A Burger-Joint Clause Offers a Clue
abstract: Some fast-food workers are blocked from changing jobs by obscure language in franchise contracts, and economists are taking note.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The American fast food industry is built on two pillars: cheap hamburgers, and cheap labor.

headline: Roy Moore, in His Own Words
abstract: Mr. Moore, who won a primary runoff for an Alabama Senate seat, is known for inflammatory statements, like calling homosexuality “an inherent evil.”
lead_paragraph: Roy S. Moore, who won a special Republican primary runoff for an Alabama Senate seat on Tuesday, is a staunch evangelical Christian, and his often-inflammatory political beliefs are informed by his strongly held religious views.

headline: Jennifer Egan Updates the Old-Fashioned Page-Turner in ‘Manhattan Beach’
abstract: Egan’s fifth novel is about a young woman working at the Brooklyn Naval Yard during World War II, and about the mystery of why her father disappeared.
lead_paragraph: One definition of a great novel, William Styron said, is that it should “leave you with many experiences, and slightly exhausted at the end. You live several lives while reading it.”

headline: Lemaire: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Delta to Offer Free In-Flight Text Messaging
abstract: Starting Sunday, Delta will allow free testing on three messaging apps, giving it an advantage with travelers who would otherwise have to pay for Wi-Fi service.
lead_paragraph: Wi-Fi rarely comes cheap for airline passengers. But Delta Air Lines is about to offer one form of connection at no charge: text messages.

headline: Minority Rule in America Today
abstract: Readers discuss the debut column by Michelle Goldberg.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tom Price’s Spending Habits Catch Trump’s Attention: ‘I’m Not Happy About It’
abstract: The president said he would look into his secretary of health and human services, who has chartered at least $400,000 in private jet travel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Price’s fondness for taxpayer-funded private jet trips drew the ire on Wednesday of President Trump, who said he was disappointed in his secretary of health and human services, and would personally examine any financial malfeasance.

headline: Can You Run Android on an iPad?
abstract: If you like Android software and Apple hardware, you can usually find iPad versions of all your favorite Google apps to install.
lead_paragraph: Q. I prefer Android and PC applications, but want to run Android on an iPad. I have a Kindle Fire, but I want the true Android environment, and the 10-inch Samsung Galaxy Tab S3 model is too expensive. However, I keep seeing reports that Google Drive, Photos, Docs and other Android apps work fine on iPads. Is that true? Or would I just be miserable?

headline: 7 Fall Foliage Destinations Offering More Than Just Pretty Leaves
abstract: Eight destinations spanning the continental United States that offer pretty trees — and a lot more to fill up a perfect autumn weekend trip.
lead_paragraph: There are too many idyllic fall foliage locations across the United States to list in one place, and while most people think of the Northeast as the best viewing region, it is certainly not the only one. Here are eight destinations spanning the continental United States that offer pretty trees  — and a lot more to fill up a perfect autumn weekend trip.

headline: Why Isn’t Your Toddler Paying the Mortgage?
abstract: There’s a new class of social-media celebrities, and they’re not old enough for kindergarten. Welcome to the weird, lucrative world of viral toddler videos.
lead_paragraph: Mila and Emma Stauffer, 2-year-old twin sisters who live with their parents and three older siblings near Phoenix, were sitting on the floor, having a discussion about what they might be when they grow up. “Maybe a teacher?” Emma said.

headline: Daniel Johnston, Back on the Road, Hopes This Isn’t the End
abstract: The enigmatic singer-songwriter is about to start a tour that’s been billed as his last. But at 56, he isn’t ready to give up his dream yet.
lead_paragraph: WALLER, Tex. — In late July, when dates were announced for a series of concerts featuring the enigmatic singer-songwriter Daniel Johnston performing with members of bands including Wilco, Built to Spill and Fugazi as part of his rotating cast of backing musicians, the shows were billed as Mr. Johnston’s final tour. But sitting in his home on a rural cul-de-sac in this farming community 45 miles from Houston on Monday, Mr. Johnston seemed surprised at this news.

headline: Street Style: Paris
abstract: After a long month of shows, the fashion crowds save the best for last in Paris.
lead_paragraph: After a long month of shows, the fashion crowds save the best for last in Paris.

headline: Long-Lost Letter to Jack Kerouac Reaches Its Final Destination
abstract: The rambling letter by Neal Cassady that inspired “On the Road,” lost for more than 60 years, has been acquired by Emory University, which is putting it on view
lead_paragraph: The letter that inspired Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road” before being (allegedly) dropped off a houseboat, misfiled at a small Bay Area publisher, nearly tossed out with the trash, and then fought over by two literary estates has now reached its seemingly final destination.

headline: Methamphetamine Abuse Afflicts Western Australia Amid Mining Boom
abstract: The runaway growth of the mining industry provided a combustible mix for drug addiction: an influx of young, mostly single workers with money to spend.
lead_paragraph: PERTH, Australia — “My beautiful little family was destroyed because of my drug use.”

headline: High Blood Pressure During Pregnancy Tied to Obesity in Children
abstract: Even maternal blood pressure levels not generally considered dangerous can raise the obesity risk in offspring.
lead_paragraph: High blood pressure during pregnancy poses serious risks to mothers and babies. It may also increase the risk for childhood obesity, a new study reports.

headline: Puerto Rico May Get Help from Unlikely Source: Its Lenders
abstract: Investors who hold some of Puerto Rico’s bonds are offering the beleaguered island $1 billion to finance urgent repairs to its ruined electrical grid.
lead_paragraph: After wondering for seven sweltering days who would pay to rebuild their ruined electrical grid, Puerto Ricans got a possible answer from an unexpected source on Wednesday: investors holding the island power company’s defaulted bonds.

headline: The One Piece You Need This Fall
abstract: A men’s wear blazer is the season’s must-have. Here, the best bang for your big and small buck — and how to wear it.
lead_paragraph: Forget furry mules and ludicrously oversize hoodies. This season’s must-have item is refreshingly untrendy. In fact, it’s downright mundane. The men’s wear blazer — in every stripe, check and flannel — could be spotted all over town at New York Fashion Week, on the runway as well as on stylish showgoers. Even the typically streetwise Alexander Wang endorsed a buttoned-up version for fall. Versatile and practical, it’s the ideal foundation for a wardrobe. Most important, the jackets are available in a wide range of prices. Here, a look at the best bang for your big or small buck — and ways to dress them up or down.

headline: Watch: President Trump Reveals Tax Cut Plan
abstract: President Trump unveiled details of his plan to overhaul the tax code in a speech in Indiana. He has promised that it will be the biggest tax cut in history.
lead_paragraph: President Trump unveiled details of his plan to overhaul the tax code in a speech in Indiana. He has promised that it will be the biggest tax cut in history.

headline: In ‘The Mayor,’ Brandon Micheal Hall Raps His Way to City Hall
abstract: Mr. Hall plays a young, struggling rapper who unexpectedly finds himself in charge of a small California town in the ABC comedy.
lead_paragraph: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — In “The Mayor,” a new ABC comedy series that premieres on Oct. 3, Brandon Micheal Hall plays Courtney Rose, a struggling rapper who runs for mayor of a small Northern California town in an ill-considered scheme to get the word out about his mixtape.

headline: Read the Memo on the Implications of the Alabama Race for Republicans
abstract: The New York Times obtained a confidential memo on Wednesday about the Alabama Senate race, circulated to Republican donors by allies of Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader. In it, an adviser to Mr. McConnell warns that conservative voters have turned against congressional Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times obtained a confidential memo on Wednesday about the Alabama Senate race, circulated to Republican donors by allies of Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader. In it, an adviser to Mr. McConnell warns that conservative voters have turned against congressional Republicans.

headline: Roy Moore’s Alabama Victory Sets Off Talk of a G.O.P. Insurrection
abstract: Republicans are facing rebellions from Mississippi to Arizona that could imperil their grip on Congress, as Mr. Moore’s win emboldens populist challengers.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Republicans are confronting an insurrection on the right that is angry enough to imperil their grip on Congress, and senior party strategists have concluded that the conservative base now loathes its leaders in Washington the same way it detested President Barack Obama.

headline: Catalan Officials Are Squeezed as Madrid Tries to Stop Independence Vote
abstract: As Sunday’s independence referendum nears, mayors risk suspension from office for violating Spain’s Constitution — or the wrath of frustrated voters.
lead_paragraph: ARENYS DE MUNT, Spain — As Spain’s government tries almost everything it can to stop an independence referendum Sunday in the restive northeastern region of Catalonia, the standoff is escalating into a constitutional crisis emblematic of the larger forces tearing at European unity.

headline: Sex, Politics and the Banned Books of 2016
abstract: The American Library Association revealed its annual Top Ten Most Challenged Book List, revealing a glimpse of some of the issues that concern Americans.
lead_paragraph: One way to discover what Americans are concerned about is to delve into the books they read. Or more tellingly, the ones they reject.

headline: Bryce Harper Is Back, Just in Time to Take On the October Demons
abstract: The Nationals star missed six weeks. Now he has a few days to sharpen his game as Washington tries to finally make a deep postseason run.
lead_paragraph: To get Bryce Harper back on the field in time for the postseason, the Washington Nationals and their manager, Dusty Baker, took some extraordinary measures.

headline: Harvey, Irma, Maria: Trump Administration’s Response Compared
abstract: President Trump has been accused of giving the crisis in Puerto Rico short shrift, compared with his response to major storms in Texas and Florida. But the picture is more complex.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Has the Trump administration’s response to Hurricane Maria’s devastation in Puerto Rico been slower and stingier than for earlier storms in Florida and Texas? As hundreds of thousands of people on the island continue to struggle, critics have barraged the administration with complaints, and the administration has pushed back.

headline: Obama Says Leaving Malia at College Was ‘Like Open-Heart Surgery’
abstract: Former President Barack Obama cried after he dropped his older daughter, Malia, off at Harvard last month — but not in front of her, he said.
lead_paragraph: After Malia Obama went off to Harvard University last month, her father couldn’t hold back the tears.

headline: Alabama Disses the Establishment
abstract: Voters in my home state, like their predecessors elsewhere, told the Washington bully-boys to stuff it.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Senator Mitch McConnell and his minions wasted some $10 million — and President Trump squandered more of his shrinking political capital — trying to tell Alabama Republicans whom to choose as their nominee for the Senate.

headline: Be Patient. Really Look.
abstract: In Beth Gill's “Brand New Sidewalk,” the dancer Danielle Goldman painstakingly removes layers of clothing: “It’s like a striptease,” Ms. Gill says.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Ali Fazal Reads ‘When Your Greatest Romance Is a Friendship’
abstract: On this week’s podcast, the “Victoria and Abdul” actor reads an essay about a relationship that transcends age.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode, the actor Ali Fazal reads “When Your Greatest Romance Is a Friendship,” Victor Lodato’s story of falling into a more-than-neighborly relationship with the woman across the street.

headline: Yang Li: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: In Her Verses, It’s Sammus Versus the World
abstract: Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo, a rapper whose alter ego is a video game character, weaves nerdy references and personal strife into her lyrics.
lead_paragraph: Name: Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo

headline: A Week of Openings, Collaborations and Don’t-Miss Shopping Events
abstract: A reversible bomber jacket from Schott, slick new Cutler and Gross eyewear, cat-eye tutorials from MAC and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the online vintage retailer Spark Pretty will open a shop in the East Village filled with colorful fashion finds like a neon Lisa Frank jacket ($450) and 1960s patchwork bell-bottoms ($400). At 333 East Ninth Street.

headline: How Technology Has Changed News Photography Over 40 Years
abstract: Jim Wilson, a photographer who started at The Times in 1980, discussed how technology has altered news photography — for good and ill.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Jim Wilson, a photographer for The Times based in San Francisco, discussed the tech he is using.

headline: North Korea, Kurds, Bombardier: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: In College Basketball Scandal, Follow the Money … and the Shoes
abstract: Louisville ousted Rick Pitino on Wednesday after a federal criminal complaint said money from Adidas was steered to high school prospects.
lead_paragraph: In the sneaker business, the feet of professional athletes are the most valuable billboards in the world. The company that gets its shoes on the best basketball players, football players and soccer players wins, because those athletes’ footwear choices have outsize influence over everyone else’s purchasing decisions.

headline: A Golfer Aiming to Save More Than Strokes on a Scorecard
abstract: Marc Leishman, who will lead the International team at the Presidents Cup this week, helps those with sepsis, the blood infection that nearly killed his wife.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — At the 2015 Presidents Cup, the Australian Marc Leishman beat Jordan Spieth, then the world No. 1, in the singles competition. Leishman’s 1-up victory came three months after he lost in a British Open playoff, but his hot streak didn’t do much for his public profile.

headline: Norman Dyhrenfurth, 99, Dies; Led First U.S. Team to Reach Top of Everest
abstract: Though he did not reach the summit himself, he made it possible for others to plant the flag in 1963 and be honored by President Kennedy
lead_paragraph: Norman G. Dyhrenfurth, an explorer and filmmaker who in 1963 led the first expedition of Americans to reach the summit of Mount Everest, a feat that inspired generations of mountaineers, died on Sunday in Salzburg, Austria. He was 99.

headline: La devastación en Puerto Rico vista desde arriba
abstract: Imágenes aéreas muestran la destrucción causada por el huracán María.
lead_paragraph: Imágenes aéreas muestran la destrucción causada por el huracán María.

headline: Viva: A Warhol-Era Superstar Wants the Last Word
abstract: The artist’s onetime muse and sidekick takes aim at her mentor, fake news and the F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: Janet Susan Mary Hoffmann turned up for a screening at the Roxy Cinema in TriBeCa last week draped in a pair of woolly shawls. With her honey-and-silver hair loosely coiled in a chignon, bifocals slung from her neck, she was the picture of a granny straight out of central casting.

headline: When White Supremacists Ruled Washington
abstract: The National Cathedral just this month removed stained-glass windows depicting Confederate generals. What does that say about our capital’s past?
lead_paragraph: Southerners who rose to federal office after the Civil War achieved something the Confederate Army had not: They seized control of Washington and bent it to their will. The Washington National Cathedral illuminated the era of white supremacist domination this month when it dismantled ornate stained-glass windows that portrayed the Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson as saintly figures.

headline: T Fashion Editors’ Guide to Paris
abstract: A shortlist of places to relax, enjoy a meal, shop a bit — and find some peace between the shows during fashion week (and always).
lead_paragraph: French-Japanese Mashups

headline: As California Wildfires Rage, ‘People Don’t Know What’s Happened in Their Homes’
abstract: Evacuation orders were lifted for about 1,000 people in Southern California counties who escaped the flames that ranged over three square miles.
lead_paragraph: Several wildfires are burning in California. Among the largest near a populated area is the Canyon Fire, which covers 2,000 acres — or about three square miles — and affects communities in Orange and Riverside Counties in the southern part of the state.

headline: The Record Bid for ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ Script Is From Tiffany’s
abstract: Audrey Hepburn’s 140-page typed script to the classic film brought the highest price for any film script at auction, Christie’s said.
lead_paragraph: Audrey Hepburn’s original working script for the 1961 movie “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” sold Wednesday night at Christie’s in London for £632,750, or about $847,000, appropriately enough to Tiffany & Co. The price was a high for any film script offered at auction, according the London-based auction house.

headline: For a Preview of the Border Wall, Look to California
abstract: A barrier between the United States and Mexico, and a history of what it can and cannot accomplish, has existed near San Diego for nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — On a dusty patch of land surrounded by a chain-link fence near the border here, workers this week began shoveling ground for a large-scale prototype for a border wall with Mexico.

headline: Hack at S.E.C. Provides Warning for Other Regulators
abstract: The breach at the agency’s corporate filing system highlighted the risks that poor security at the country’s watchdogs poses for investors.
lead_paragraph: A botched investigation into a hack at the Securities and Exchange Commission is a warning for other regulatory agencies.

headline: The Mystery of the Dead Bumblebees and the Linden Trees
abstract: Large numbers of bees were turning up sick or dead beneath fragrant trees in botanic garden in London. Two scientists set out to crack the case.
lead_paragraph: The scene: Visitors in the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens near London have reported hundreds, if not thousands of bees, especially bumblebees, sick or dead, beneath fragrant, flowering Tilia trees. Similar reports have been made in other parts of Britain and Europe, as well as the United States — as long ago as the 16th century.

headline: ‘I Served for What This Country Stood For’: Readers React to N.F.L. Protests
abstract: How some New York Times readers reacted to N.F.L. players who demonstrated during the national anthem on Sunday in a show of solidarity against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Across the country N.F.L. players knelt or linked arms during the national anthem in a widespread demonstration against President Trump, who criticized athletes on Twitter and in a speech last weekend.

headline: In the Virgin Islands, Hurricane Maria Drowned What Irma Didn’t Destroy
abstract: As islanders wait for doctors, medicine, fuel and manpower to rebuild, the economic toll from the storms is only starting to come to light.
lead_paragraph: CRUZ BAY, V.I. — Even before two Category 5 hurricanes struck the United States Virgin Islands with punishing fury this month, the notion of paradise here was already about as brittle as a sand dollar.

headline: Dwyane Wade Joins LeBron James for Act II With Cavs
abstract: Seven years after joining forces in Miami, they’re staging a reunion with the Cavaliers. And Wade’s arrival will give Cleveland some needed depth.
lead_paragraph: It is worth remembering, as Dwyane Wade and LeBron James embark on their reunion in Cleveland, that Wade recruited James to join him in Miami seven years ago.

headline: Trump Tax Plan Benefits Wealthy, Including Trump
abstract: The Trump administration’s tax plan provides large benefits for the wealthy, modest benefits for the middle class — and no direct benefit to the poor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tax plan that the Trump administration outlined on Wednesday is a potentially huge windfall for the wealthiest Americans. It would not directly benefit the bottom third of the population. As for the middle class, the benefits appear to be modest.

headline: After Disasters, New York Goes Into Overdrive in Gathering Aid
abstract: Volunteers united to send relief supplies to Puerto Rico and Mexico, the homelands of two of city’s largest Spanish-speaking populations.
lead_paragraph: The sidewalks of Sunset Park, in Brooklyn, were overflowing with bottled water and boxes of donations on Tuesday, most bound for Puerto Rico, others to Mexico. At an East Harlem fund-raiser, Puerto Rican poets shouted their verses above the thunderous roar of the Metro-North Railroad trains.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C.’s Stadium Search Includes Belmont Park Proposal
abstract: The Major League Soccer team will meet a Thursday deadline to present plans for the property, which may not be its first-choice option — or its only one.
lead_paragraph: New York City F.C. and a major New York City real estate developer will submit a proposal to build a soccer stadium on property at Belmont Park ahead of a Thursday afternoon deadline. But the site might not be their first choice — and it is not their only one.

headline: Tax Plan Punts on a Loophole for the Wealthy
abstract: There’s no easy way to keep the “pass-through” provision from being used for tax avoidance.
lead_paragraph: In devising any complicated plan, there will be some knotty issues when it is tempting to offer vague promises of fixes that come later. The new Republican tax plan includes just such language, about a provision that wealthier Americans might find tempting to abuse.

headline: Overturned Convictions Loom Over Menendez’s Corruption Trial
abstract: The turn of events in the cases against two former New York legislative leaders is almost certain to reverberate in the case of the New Jersey senator.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — They were two of the most notable corruption convictions in recent political history, two entrenched New York power brokers seemingly brought to justice, their cases reverberating well beyond the wood-paneled walls of the Statehouse in Albany.

headline: With Construction Worker Deaths Up, City Council Tightens Regulations
abstract: Council members unanimously approved a contentious bill to require increased safety training for those employed on building sites in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For months, lawmakers, real estate groups and construction workers have agreed on the need to tighten safety regulations at construction sites in New York City, after an alarming surge in worker deaths. But for months, a seemingly straightforward effort to do so has languished, amid concerns that a proposal to increase safety training requirements would put minority and nonunion laborers out of work.

headline: Why No Comments? It’s a Matter of Resources
abstract: Times readers questioned our decision not to allow comments on a recent article. Our community editor explains our policy.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center is a newsroom initiative that is helping The Times build deeper ties with our audience.

headline: Trump’s Inaugural Committee to Donate $3 Million to Hurricane Relief
abstract: Inaugural committee officials said the money will be divided equally among the American Red Cross, the Salvation Army and Samaritan’s Purse, an evangelical group.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s inaugural committee, under fire for a delay in donating its remaining funds to charity, plans to give $3 million to three organizations involved in hurricane rescue efforts, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Tom Harkin Recalls Meeting With Menendez and Melgen, and Not Much Else
abstract: Mr. Harkin, a former senator from Iowa, was one of the more high-profile witnesses to take the stand in the corruption trial, though he did not offer many revelations.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The juxtaposition was stark: a former Democratic senator on the stand as a witness for the prosecution, while a current senator from the same party sat in the defendant’s chair.

headline: Six Charts That Help Explain the Republican Tax Plan
abstract: The bill makes major changes to the tax code by lowering rates for individuals and corporations.
lead_paragraph: The bill makes major changes to the tax code by lowering rates for individuals and corporations.

headline: Chat With the Waiter
abstract: Taking a server aside when he is less than gracious.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Donald Trump Jr.’s Great Escape
abstract: What really happened when the president’s son ditched his security detail.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Sept. 14, a man who looked an awful lot like Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of the president of the United States, boarded Air Canada Jazz Flight AC 8889 in Vancouver, British Columbia. He made his way down the aisle of the Bombardier CRJ 900, found his seat, 17A, in the economy cabin, then settled in for the 923-mile flight to his final destination, Whitehorse, in Canada’s Yukon Territory. He was carrying a camouflage backpack, but he checked some other luggage at the beginning of his journey, two cities earlier, at New York’s LaGuardia Airport. That luggage consisted of a high-end hunting bow and a duffel bag. Hunting bows are dangerous weapons, and when you travel from the United States to Canada with a bow, you are supposed to retrieve it and whatever other luggage you are traveling with at your initial port of entry, then escort it through customs for inspection before continuing your journey. He had entered Canada in Toronto but failed to retrieve his bow and duffel bag there, which is why, a half-hour after his flight arrived in Whitehorse, when most of the other passengers had long since gotten their things and gone on their way, he was still milling around the baggage carousel, looking increasingly forlorn, as it appeared his luggage was not going to show up.

headline: Kathy Halbreich of MoMA to Lead Rauschenberg Foundation
abstract: “The more I learned, the more perfect the match felt as my next chapter,” Ms. Halbreich said of moving to the foundation.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Halbreich’s name has often surfaced over the years as a possible successor to the director of the Museum of Modern Art, Glenn D. Lowry. But Ms. Halbreich points out that she is, in fact, older than Mr. Lowry, that MoMA has a mandatory retirement age and that she has long considered her current job at MoMA — associate director — the best in the business.

headline: Tax Plan, Roy Moore, Puerto Rico: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Albert Tomei, Judge Who Doomed New York Executions, Dies at 77
abstract: He ruled in 1997 that a law reinstating the capital punishment had prodded defendants to plead guilty rather than risk a death sentence by going to trial.
lead_paragraph: Albert Tomei, a Brooklyn judge whose rejection in 1997 of a murder defendant’s plea bargain crippled New York State’s recently revived death penalty, died on Sept. 22in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: How to Move as a Couple Without Driving Each Other Crazy
abstract: Moving with a partner — either for the first or the 10th time — has unique challenges. Here’s how to do it right, without risking your relationship.
lead_paragraph: “I’m never moving with you again.” Nick, my then-boyfriend, stood over the shattered remains of his favorite mug, coconut oil pooling at his feet. I gripped the remains of the box that, until the bottom fell out, I swore I’d packed perfectly. We’d spent weeks before the big day bickering over everything, from how to pack our cocktail coupes to whether his Lego collection needed downsizing. By moving day, we were barely speaking.

headline: Brazil Offshore Oil Drilling Rights Draw Interest at Auction
abstract: The bidding, the first of nine rounds, was considered a test of confidence in government policy as well as the industry’s appetite for exploration.
lead_paragraph: Brazil offered the world’s oil companies a chance to bid for drilling rights in its waters on Wednesday, and it declared the results encouraging.

headline: E.P.A. Threatens to Stop Funding Justice Dept. Environmental Work
abstract: Scott Pruitt, the E.P.A. head, wants to end reimbursements for Superfund litigation that seeks to force polluters to pay for cleaning up sites they left contaminated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Pruitt, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator who has aggressively pushed to dismantle regulations and downsize the organization, is threatening to reach outside his agency and undermine the Justice Department’s work enforcing antipollution laws, documents and interviews show.

headline: In a Puerto Rican Village: ‘The Wind Came and Took Everything’
abstract: In a village fifteen minutes from the capital of Puerto Rico, residents sit amid the rubble that was once their homes.
lead_paragraph: In a village fifteen minutes from the capital of Puerto Rico, residents sit amid the rubble that was once their homes.

headline: Don’t Expect ‘Wild Man Bo’ at Mayoral Debate, Bo Dietl Says
abstract: Mr. Dietl could help Mayor Bill de Blasio and add to the challenges facing his Republican opponent, Nicole Malliotakis.
lead_paragraph: The first general election debate in the race for New York City mayor just got more crowded, if not more colorful, as organizers announced on Wednesday that Bo Dietl, the bombastic and frequently profane former police detective running on his own political line, will join Mayor Bill de Blasio and his Republican challenger, Nicole Malliotakis.

headline: Not Giving Up, Trump Insists He Has Votes to Repeal Obamacare
abstract: In an exchange with reporters, President Trump said on Wednesday that he has the votes to repeal the Affordable Care Act but that he will first negotiate a deal with Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unwilling to accept defeat, President Trump insisted on Wednesday that Republicans “have the votes” to dismantle much of the Affordable Care Act, and he predicted that the Senate would vote on legislation to do that in the first three months of next year.

headline: Facebook Responds to Trump and Positions Itself as Election-Ready
abstract: Facebook, under fire after the American presidential election, responded to criticism from President Trump and touted its efforts for the German elections on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — President Trump took aim at Facebook on Wednesday, calling the social network “anti-Trump.” But the social network insists it is pro-democracy and pro-truth — and the German election shows it.

headline: A Guide to Graveside Tourism
abstract: “199 Cemeteries to See Before You Die” is a guide to checking out the hereafter before you check out.
lead_paragraph: There are books that list records you should listen to, movies you should watch and books you should read before you die. There’s “101 Asian Dishes You Need to Cook Before You Die” and “Fifty Places to Fly Fish Before You Die.” So perhaps it was inevitable — and especially fitting — that we would get “199 Cemeteries to See Before You Die,” Loren Rhoads’s new guide to checking out the hereafter before you check out.

headline: Amazon Wants You to Wake Up With Alexa, and That’s Just the Start
abstract: The company introduced a wide collection of new Echo devices that are smaller, cheaper and, in some cases, built for specific areas of the home.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon released the first Echo smart speaker three years ago, not long after the company’s attempt at a smartphone proved to be a humiliating failure.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hurricanes’ Rage Leaves Faded Paradise in Shock
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 28, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “The economy evaporated pretty much overnight.”

headline: Navy Returns to Compasses and Pencils to Help Avoid Collisions at Sea
abstract: A top officer issued new orders to sailors worldwide as the Navy scrambled to make priorities of safety and maintenance after two deadly collisions in recent months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Urgent new orders went out earlier this month for United States Navy warships that have been plagued by deadly mishaps this year.

headline: Heaps of Stuff We Like
abstract: This week’s newsletter, highlighting journalism from around the web that the Australia bureau can’t stop talking about.
lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Albert Innaurato, Playwright Who Lit Up Broadway in ’70s, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Innaurato had a long stretch of success with “Gemini” and “The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie” and made a comeback in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Albert Innaurato, a playwright who enjoyed spectacular success for a time in the late 1970s, including having a play run on Broadway for more than four years, has died in Philadelphia. He was 70.

headline: North Korea’s Athletic Ambassadors
abstract: When athletes from the world’s most isolated nation participate in global competitions, casual meetings can reveal more similarities than differences.
lead_paragraph: OBERSTDORF, Germany — Over the past 24 years, while covering international sports for The Times, I’ve encountered North Korean athletes and officials on a number of occasions. Though the country is extremely isolated, its sportsmen and sportswomen compete around the world in Olympic sports and in soccer.

headline: I Can’t Wait to Drive in Saudi Arabia Again
abstract: The last time I was arrested. Next time, I will be on the road to equality with my fellow Saudi women.
lead_paragraph: In May 2011, I drove a car in the city of Khobar, Saudi Arabia, to protest the kingdom’s ban on women driving. As a result, I was arrested, taken from my home in the dark of night and jailed for nine days, during which time I was interrogated, strip-searched and accused of being a traitor and a spy. I was released only after my father begged King Abdullah, the ruler at the time, to pardon me.

headline: Lindsey Vonn May Get Her Chance to Race Against Men in 2018
abstract: Vonn has long wanted to compete against male skiers, but she may get her best, and last, chance with a request that will be considered by F.I.S. next week.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Lindsey Vonn has wanted to race against men, and her requests have been bluntly denied by international ski racing officials. But next week, Vonn may get her best, and likely last, chance to enter a men’s World Cup Alpine race.

headline: Feel That Post-Recession Bounce? The Rich Feel It the Most
abstract: Low-wage workers and other groups largely left out early in the recovery did better from 2013 to 2016, a study shows, but the richest gained the most.
lead_paragraph: Eight years after the Great Recession officially ended, the fruits of economic growth are finally spreading to low-wage workers, racial and ethnic minorities and other groups that were largely left out of the early stages of the recovery.

headline: After School Stabbing, Parents Ask: Where Were Metal Detectors?
abstract: Whether metal detectors are the answer to keeping schools safe has been debated. Regardless, the city plans to add them at the Bronx school where two students were stabbed.
lead_paragraph: When word came that two students had been  stabbed inside a Bronx high school on Wednesday, the parents of several students in the elementary school housed in the same building voiced anger at a lack of metal detectors there and demanded action from Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: New York Village’s Seal, Widely Criticized as Racist, Has Been Changed
abstract: The updated Whitesboro seal depicts a more evenly matched tussle between the village’s founder and a Native American than a previous version did.
lead_paragraph: It endured national scrutiny and was derided by many as racist. Now, the official seal of Whitesboro, a village of about 3,700 in central New York, has been changed.

headline: 3 Weeks Later, Equifax Makes a Peace Offering
abstract: The interim chief executive apologized to victims of the company’s data breach and offered a credit lock instead of an old-fashioned credit freeze.
lead_paragraph: For some time, the credit reporting industry has been quietly attempting to change the behavior of consumers who wish to protect their own data: They want you to “lock” your files, not “freeze” them.

headline: Twitter, With Accounts Linked to Russia, to Face Congress Over Role in Election
abstract: Facebook has faced the most scrutiny over social media’s role in the 2016 election. But Twitter may have been used even more extensively by Russians.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a weekend when Americans took to social media to debate President Trump’s admonishment of N.F.L. players who do not stand for the national anthem, a network of Twitter accounts suspected of links to Russia seized on both sides of the issue with hashtags such as #boycottnfl, #standforouranthem and #takeaknee.

headline: Trump Talks Tough on China and Mexico, but Trade Actions Hit Canada
abstract: In the latest move, the administration imposed a huge tariff on a new aircraft made by Montreal’s Bombardier.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — While President Trump has reserved his harshest words on trade for Mexico and China, Canada, one of America’s closest allies, has emerged as a major pressure point on trade, with the countries’ leaders trading barbs over lumber, dairy products, airplanes, and even magazine paper.

headline: KIPP NYC Charter School Network Is Investigating Claims of Past Sex Abuse
abstract: The network hired an outside law firm to investigate, a precedent set by several prominent private schools including St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: A prominent New York City charter school network announced on Wednesday that it was opening an investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct that occurred more than 10 years ago.

headline: Trump Misleads on Who Benefits From Tax Plan
abstract: President Trump claimed his tax plan will help small business owners and farmers, but not himself or the wealthy. That’s not quite right.
lead_paragraph: President Trump and Republican leaders released their long-awaited tax plan on Wednesday, offering several misleading and false claims to bolster their framework for the overhaul. Here’s an assessment.

headline: A Boondoggle Masquerading as Tax Reform
abstract: The proposals outlined by President Trump and congressional leaders depend on the discredited notion that tax cuts for the rich will help everyone.
lead_paragraph: After months of secret negotiations, the Trump administration and congressional leaders have come up with a tax plan — sort of. What they have really come up with is a wish list of tax cuts for the wealthy, with lots of “we’ll get back to you on that” promises where the details are supposed to be.

headline: El Capitan Rockfall Kills One and Injures Another in Yosemite
abstract: Emergency workers were trying to transport the injured person out of the park, about 150 miles east of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: A chunk of rock broke off El Capitan, the towering granite wall in Yosemite National Park, on Wednesday afternoon, killing one person and injuring another, park officials said.

headline: No Triple Crown Winner Ever
abstract: Joe Krozel’s puzzle should be a big hit at parties.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Do you ever feel your jaw immediately hit the ground the moment you look at a grid for the first time? Well, that was certainly the case for me today. Joe Krozel has been known to create some inventive puzzles in the past, and this one was no exception.

headline: Corrections: September 28, 2017
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, September 28, 2017.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Yankees Keep Pace With Red Sox, Preserving a Host of Season-Ending Scenarios
abstract: While the Yankees did not gain any ground on Boston, they still could win the division or force a one-game tiebreaker, complicating their schedule for the next week.
lead_paragraph: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi is a man who seeks out certainty. He does not like hypotheticals, waving away what-ifs as though they were a child with too many questions.

headline: Hugh Hefner, Who Built the Playboy Empire and Embodied It, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Hefner, the magazine’s very public avatar, styled himself as an emblem of the sexual revolution.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hefner, who created Playboy magazine and spun it into a media and entertainment-industry giant — all the while, as its very public avatar, squiring attractive young women (and sometimes marrying them) well into his 80s — died on Wednesday at his home, the Playboy Mansion, in the Holmby Hills area of Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: The Last Word: Hugh Hefner
abstract: In 2008, the founder of the Playboy empire sat down with The New York Times to talk about his influences, his well-publicized lifestyle and his labor of love.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, the founder of the Playboy empire sat down with The New York Times to talk about his influences, his well-publicized lifestyle and his labor of love.

headline: Can a $300 Cooler Unite America?
abstract: Whether you’re in either of the Portlands or in Mobile, Ala., Yeti is how America keeps luxuriously cool.
lead_paragraph: In a country where we can’t seem to agree on anything, one opinion has lately reached a broad consensus across diverse groups of people: Yeti is pretty awesome.
