abstract: The carefree bunch from “Will & Grace” return in a new revival. And Viola Davis pieces her life back together in “How to Get Away With Murder.”
lead_paragraph: The carefree bunch from “Will & Grace” return in a new revival. And Viola Davis pieces her life back together in “How to Get Away With Murder.”

headline: IBM Now Has More Employees in India Than in the U.S.
abstract: IBM has shifted its center of gravity halfway around the world to India, making it a high-tech example of the globalization trends that the Trump administration has railed against.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — IBM dominated the early decades of computing with inventions like the mainframe and the floppy disk. Its offices and factories, stretching from upstate New York to Silicon Valley, were hubs of American innovation long before Microsoft or Google came along.

headline: Do You Think You Can Tell When Something Is ‘Fake News’?
abstract: What are the challenges of trying to disprove false information?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been in a situation, either in person or online, where someone presented you with information you knew or suspected was not true?

headline: Carbohydrates
abstract: Cakes, cookies, pasta, bread: do you crave these things and, often, eat too much of them?
lead_paragraph: Cakes, cookies, pasta, bread: do you crave these things and, often, eat too much of them? Would you consider yourself a “carboholic”?

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things I Wish I Had Bought Before I Moved (or Just After)
abstract: Welcome to the latest edition of the Smarter Living newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The Smarter Living team emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: Weegee: King of the Nighttime Streets
abstract: Weegee’s images, of swells and speakeasies, crime and crowds, or perps and play, are a singular record of New York City in the 1930s and 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Weegee’s images, of swells and speakeasies, crime and crowds, or perps and play, are a singular record of New York City in the 1930s and 1940s.

headline: ‘The Flag Is Drenched With Our Blood’
abstract: For black Americans, patriotism is a paradox.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Donald Trump has once again used racial hostility to rouse his base and is reveling in the achievement.

headline: Lessons From a Travel Ban Clash That Wasn’t
abstract: Now that the White House has issued new curbs, the Supreme Court won’t consider earlier restrictions. But questions remain.
lead_paragraph: While the Supreme Court has taken the Trump administration’s travel ban appeal off its calendar, there is something important to remember: Just because a case is moot, as this one appears to be, doesn’t mean that nothing happened.

headline: Saudi Women Behind the Wheel
abstract: The lifting of a ban on female drivers is an important symbolic and practical step in a society where women still have many barriers to overcome.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult not to be a bit sardonic about women in Saudi Arabia getting the right to drive. It is the 21st century in most of the world, after all, and there’s not a single other country with so nonsensical a restriction. But precisely because the ban was so out of step with the world, the royal decree overturning it carries major symbolic importance.

headline: Trump’s Worst: An Update
abstract: His cabinet’s behavior has us wondering again who should be the first to go.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has just voted in the Worst Cabinet Member contest.

headline: The Corruption at the Heart of March Madness
abstract: A federal inquiry lays out unscrupulous competition for star players.
lead_paragraph: College basketball has long made much of its money by sleazy recruitment and exploitation of teenage stars. With a series of federal bribery and fraud  charges announced this week, prosecutors are now treating these shady dealings as what they are: corruption, not a rules violation.

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Saudi Arabia Agrees to Let Women Drive’
abstract: Why did Saudi leaders change the longstanding policy that prohibited women from driving?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: The Trump Voter Paradox
abstract: How can people be so friendly and so angry at the same time?
lead_paragraph: Roy Moore’s decisive victory over Luther Strange in the Republican Senate primary runoff on Tuesday in Alabama confirms — as I have reported before — that many Republican voters have a strong sense of white identity, that they harbor high levels of racial resentment and that they sometimes exhibit authoritarian leanings.

headline: I Believe Some of Your Best Friends Are Jewish
abstract: Valerie Plame and others have said things that some people might just take as anti-Semitic.
lead_paragraph: I believe Valerie Plame, the former C.I.A. operative and fading liberal celebrity, when she says she missed the anti-Semitic “undercurrents” in an article she called “provocative, but thoughtful.” I believe her when she says she “zeroed in on the neocon criticism” but missed the article’s more prejudicial elements.

headline: Weegee: King of the Nighttime Streets
abstract: Weegee’s images of swells and speakeasies, crime and crowds, or perps and play are a singular record of New York City in the 1930s and 1940s.
lead_paragraph: To those among us fortunate enough to have known old-timers who regaled us with tales of tabloid derring-do, New York was once a place of outrageous characters both in front of and behind the camera. Like players in “The Front Page,” hordes of cigar-chomping, fedora-wearing men plied their trade as a contact sport that was not above recreating scenes or putting a prop or two — like a lonesome looking doll — into everyday moments of tragedy.

headline: Hugh Hefner Created an Image, and Lived It
abstract: The founder of the Playboy empire was not just the promoter of a certain bachelor lifestyle, he was its avatar.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the Playboy empire was not just the promoter of a certain bachelor lifestyle, he was its avatar.

headline: Here Comes the Closer . . . In the Seventh Inning?
abstract: Dominant relief pitchers usually just get the last few outs of the game. Baseball managers may be ready to change their roles
lead_paragraph: On they came, one after another, making the walk from the bullpen to the pitcher’s mound. It was the first night of the American League playoffs, one year ago this week, and the Baltimore Orioles’ starting pitcher hadn’t lasted through the fifth inning. Six relief pitchers followed as a 2-2 stalemate with the Toronto Blue Jays stretched toward midnight. By the end, Buck Showalter, the Orioles’ manager, had put every available pitcher into the game except his best one: Zach Britton, the league’s leader in saves that season.

headline: Prison Through Art, Rap and VR
abstract: “State Property” is a Bronx-based art exhibition that looks at the American consumerism of prison labor.
lead_paragraph: “State Property” is a Bronx-based art exhibition that looks at the American consumerism of prison labor.

headline: Have Your Date and Your Garlic Too
abstract: How you should — and should not — cook with garlic.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, at the end of a lovely long afternoon spent browsing used bookstores, my date and I unexpectedly ended up in my kitchen, famished. There wasn’t much food around, but I managed to dig up some leftovers and the makings for garlic bread. I’d been dreading this occasion, our first time cooking together. Friends have warned me that I can be a bully in the kitchen. With every fledgling relationship, I’m anxiously aware that the simple act of cooking alongside my new paramour can unleash havoc.

headline: 36 Hours in Sonoma County, Calif.
abstract: Sipping wine only scratches the surface of what California’s big-sky country has to offer.
lead_paragraph: Sipping wine only scratches the surface of what California’s big-sky country has to offer.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Shark Tank’
abstract: Trickle-down economics that works, at least on TV.
lead_paragraph: When I was 10 or so, my mom took me to a Fourth of July barbecue so we could celebrate America in our traditional family way — at her Howard Zinn-reading grad-student friend’s apartment, where most of the other guests were aspiring screenwriters. The America we celebrated was one that encouraged protest and strived for justice, peace and equality. My lasting memory of the party came after dark, after the fireworks, after the hot dogs, when the host brought out a tiny American flag and set fire to it. He handed it to me. I was mesmerized, enchanted. I held the small wooden pole and watched the sacred symbol of America burn. It was the mid-’80s, and Ronald Reagan was a hated capitalist pig in our household.

headline: The Mind of John McPhee
abstract: A deeply private writer reveals his obsessive process.
lead_paragraph: When you call John McPhee on the phone, he is instantly John McPhee. McPhee is now 86 years old, and each of those years seems to be filed away inside of him, loaded with information, ready to access. I was calling to arrange a visit to Princeton, N.J., where McPhee lives and teaches writing. He was going to give me driving directions. He asked where I was coming from. I told him the name of my town, about 100 miles away.

headline: Virgil Abloh Is Saving Luxury With T-Shirts
abstract: Virgil Abloh is creative director of Off-White and consultant to Kanye West. Take a tour of his studio, where graphic tees and wedding dresses are part of the same outfit.
lead_paragraph: Virgil Abloh is creative director of Off-White and consultant to Kanye West. Take a tour of his studio, where graphic tees and wedding dresses are part of the same outfit.

headline: Some Worry About Judicial Nominee’s Ties to a Religious Group
abstract: Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s choice for an appeals-court seat, belongs to People of Praise, a tight-knit, oath-bound group with considerable sway over its members.
lead_paragraph: One of President Trump’s judicial nominees became something of a hero to religious conservatives after she was grilled at a Senate hearing this month over whether her Roman Catholic faith would influence her decisions on the bench.

headline: Two Memoirs Celebrate Muses With Four Legs
abstract: Eileen Myles and Nicole J. Georges write about the dogs that helped them become better artists.
lead_paragraph: AFTERGLOW (a dog memoir) By Eileen Myles 207 pp. Grove Press. $24.

headline: Jennifer Egan: By the Book
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “A Visit From the Goon Squad” and the forthcoming “Manhattan Beach” reads only what she craves: “If I try to read a book I’m not hungry for, I won’t enjoy it.”
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “A Visit From the Goon Squad” and the forthcoming “Manhattan Beach” reads only what she craves: “If I try to read a book I’m not hungry for, I won’t enjoy it.”

headline: With Tax Cuts on the Table, Once-Mighty Deficit Hawks Hardly Chirp
abstract: Senate Republicans are pressing ahead with a plan to cut taxes by up to $1.5 trillion, and those worried about the deficit have little company.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2001, when surging budget surpluses fueled hopes of extinguishing the national debt, a pitched battle broke out over President George W. Bush’s proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut. Never mind that the tax cut’s 10-year tab was supposed to leave behind more than $3 trillion in surpluses — Democrats and some Republicans said that the tax cut was just too large.

headline: Trump Wants to Repeal Obama’s Climate Plan. The Next Fight: Its Replacement.
abstract: Mr. Trump is intent on repealing the Clean Power Plan, the centerpiece of Mr. Obama’s environmental legacy. Failure to replace it could invite lawsuits and, eventually, tougher rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump failed again this week to fulfill his promise to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, President Barack Obama’s signature health plan. Now he is taking aim at Mr. Obama’s central environmental legacy, the Clean Power Plan.

headline: Roy Moore’s Win and Bob Corker’s Retirement Deliver Blows to Bipartisanship
abstract: The big victory by an uncompromising candidate and the threat of a primary race challenge could force incumbent Republicans to the right.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bipartisanship took a beating this week.

headline: On the Cocktail Trail in Brazil, a Favorite Spirit Gets Frisky
abstract: In São Paulo, bartenders are using a variety of cachaças (some of them vintage) to make inventive drinks — and to perfect the caipirinha.
lead_paragraph: As in many large countries, most of the popular stereotypes about Brazil unravel with the slightest tug. A nation of sunny beaches and exquisite tans on svelte bods? Sure, and chilly mountain towns and linebackers in the German enclaves in the south, as well. Dysfunctional politics? In the extreme, but what is functional politics nowadays, anyway?

headline: In Search of a Studio With Counter Space
abstract: Finding a place in the city with a decent-size kitchen can be a challenge — but for a buyer who loves to bake, it was essential.
lead_paragraph: For Catherine Bazerghi, a Texas native, life in New York City began in 2011, with a roommate on the Lower East Side. “It was such a rude awakening,” she said. “It was less than 500 square feet for a two-bedroom, and I came from a 950-square-foot one-bedroom in Dallas.”

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Is Surprised Trump Went ‘All In’ on a Loser That Wasn’t a Casino
abstract: Late-night TV hosts pounced on the loss of Senator Luther Strange, a candidate President Trump had endorsed for an Alabama Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Trump’s Apprentice Plan Seems to Need a Mentor
abstract: President Trump is seeking to increase the number of apprenticeships, which seems like a great idea — unless doing so leads to watered-down standards.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Destina Garcia found herself outside a locked front door in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. Somewhere on the other side was an older man who needed her help.

abstract: The agreement, under which the former symbol of Japanese industrial might will keep a minority stake, values the operations at about $18 billion.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toshiba, the huge but struggling Japanese conglomerate, traded some of its size for financial security on Thursday by selling off most of its profitable microchip business.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: Lobbying in Trump’s Washington
abstract: The Trump presidency has changed the rules of influence in the nation’s capital — and spawned a new breed of lobbyist.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Learning to Breathe
abstract: My baby had an extra branch stemming from his heart, constricting his trachea. The surgery that saved him brought another crisis.
lead_paragraph: When my third child was born, I felt extraordinary joy watching him turn from blue to pink in my arms — me holding my breath as he took his first. Unlike our twins, who came surgically six weeks early, my youngest son Jack arrived naturally at nearly 41 weeks. He bypassed the breathing treatments, feeding tubes and incubators that marred our other sons’ debuts and even nursed within an hour of birth.

headline: New York Today: Our First Responders in Puerto Rico
abstract: Thursday: New Yorkers helping hurricane victims, events around the city, and a World War I centennial.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this crystal clear Thursday.

headline: South Korea Says It’s Speeding Up Arms Buildup to Counter the North
abstract: President Moon Jae-in also renewed his call for the South’s military to become more independent of America’s, though he said deterring the North was the top priority.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The president of South Korea vowed on Thursday to accelerate efforts to strengthen its pre-emptive strike, missile defense and retaliatory capabilities against North Korea, and he renewed his call for the armed forces to become more independent from the United States.

headline: Chloé: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Trump Tax Plan, Russia and Tech: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The proposed tax overhaul brings benefits for corporate America, but the outline presented on Wednesday still has plenty for critics to attack.
lead_paragraph: Where does President Trump’s big tax push, unveiled yesterday in Indiana, go from here?

headline: The High Price of Failing America’s Costliest Patients
abstract: A moral and financial challenge: Only 5 percent of patients account for nearly half of the nation’s health care spending.
lead_paragraph: Even patients with whom I have the best rapport would probably rather not see me so often.

headline: Review: A Cranky Loner Faces Mortality in ‘Lucky’
abstract: In one of his last roles, Harry Dean Stanton shines as a cantankerous old man.
lead_paragraph: Nothing much happens in “Lucky,” and then everything does. That doesn’t mean this leisurely portrait of its title character, a cantankerous old coot (Harry Dean Stanton, in one of his last roles), is any more eventful at the end than at the beginning. Rather, the accumulation of spot-on performances and long-familiar faces, small-town routines and dusty-worn locations, finally coalesces into a picture that’s greater than the sum of its oft-clichéd parts.

headline: Review: An Inheritance Is Threatened in ‘Abundant Acreage Available’
abstract: Amy Ryan and Terry Kinney are siblings at the center of a land dispute in this film from Angus MacLachlan.
lead_paragraph: The title is quite the mouthful, but it’s not the only thing about “Abundant Acreage Available” that’s hard to swallow.

headline: Review: ‘Let’s Play Two’ Takes Pearl Jam Out to the Ball Game
abstract: Blending concert film and sports diary, Danny Clinch chronicles Pearl Jam’s pair of shows at Wrigley Field during the Cubs’ championship season.
lead_paragraph: After a 108-year drought, the Chicago Cubs finally won the World Series last year. Maybe you heard.

headline: Review: ‘Blood Stripe’ Finds a Woman Back From War, and Still Fighting
abstract: A former Marine returns home and battles with post-traumatic stress in this film.
lead_paragraph: “A hundred twenty-nine days.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin,’ a Portrait of a Gifted Writer
abstract: The film, directed by Jennifer M. Kroot, illustrates how the novelist’s gay experience informed his art.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a writer who is gay,” the novelist Armistead Maupin says in “The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin.” “I’m not a gay writer. I write about heterosexuals as well.” This fond documentary portrait, directed by Jennifer M. Kroot, makes it clear that Mr. Maupin’s mastery of assorted perspectives is his gift, evident in his masterpiece, “Tales of the City,” a love letter to San Francisco comprising multiple characters. And yet the film offers an enlightening glimpse into how the gay experience informed Mr. Maupin’s art.

headline: Review: Seeking Connection in a Busy Town in ‘Autumn, Autumn’
abstract: This South Korean film follows lonely characters in a resort town.
lead_paragraph: “Autumn, Autumn,” the moving new film from the South Korean writer and director Jang Woo-jin, contains two rather remarkable scenes. In the first, a young man (Woo Ji-hyeon), a little drunk, calls an old friend on the phone and asks him to sing for him. The friend complies with a mournful love song, and the movie seems to hold its breath until the final notes rise into the night air.

headline: Review: Winning Her Back on Deadline in ‘Literally, Right Before Aaron’
abstract: In this disjointed rom-com, Justin Long plays a man invited to the wedding of his former paramour. He’s not going easily.
lead_paragraph: Justin Long is no stranger to the rom-com trenches: In “A Case of You,” he wooed Evan Rachel Wood, and in “Going the Distance,” he courted Drew Barrymore. Now in the disjointed “Literally, Right Before Aaron,” Mr. Long romances, or tries to re-romance, Cobie Smulders. Ms. Smulders plays Allison, who went out with Adam (Mr. Long) for years before they broke up. Now she has invited him to her wedding to Aaron (Ryan Hansen), and Adam is ambivalent about it at best, unhinged at worst. He decides to attend and win her back.

headline: Review: In ‘Realive,’ a Man Is Reanimated in 2084
abstract: This above-average science-fiction film, written and directed by Mateo Gil, plays like a “Black Mirror” episode combined with a solemn love story.
lead_paragraph: Like a “Black Mirror” episode combined with a philosophy seminar, “Realive” has plenty of brains. Yet it has a heart, too, and that adds a surprising amount of emotion to this above-average science-fiction film.

headline: Review: A Violent Accident Rocks a Friendship in ‘Super Dark Times’
abstract: Kevin Phillips’s direction and fine acting from the cast elevate this tale centered on two high schoolers coping with tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers looking for ways to distinguish their first feature film could learn from Kevin Phillips’s direction of “Super Dark Times.” His thoughtful investments in blocking and sound design communicate the interior conflict of his teenage leads, and elevate what could have been a generic slasher movie.

headline: Review: In ‘Different Flowers,’ a Runaway Bride Gets Help From Her Sister
abstract: The two siblings get on each other’s nerves and in each other’s business.
lead_paragraph: As with many siblings, the sisters at the center of Morgan Dameron’s “Different Flowers” fit together like a pair of mismatched socks. Millie (Emma Bell) is the seemingly put-together grown-up about to marry her longtime sweetheart (Sterling Knight). Her sister, Emma (Hope Lauren), is more of a wild child. But when Millie decides to become a runaway bride on her wedding day, Emma is the perfect match to sneak her out of the church.

headline: Celebrities Remember Hugh Hefner for More Than Just the Articles
abstract: Tributes on Twitter came from Jesse Jackson, Jenny McCarthy and others who remembered Mr. Hefner for his business acumen and activism.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hefner’s death at  91 on Wednesday inspired reactions from stars who got their starts on the pages of Playboy, celebrities who appeared at his famous parties and commenters who recognized his outsize role in American life.

headline: California Today: Should California Ban Non-Electric Cars?
abstract: Thursday: Jerry Brown asks about phasing out gas vehicles, an obituary for Hugh Hefner, and the Rams’ precipitously falling stadium attendance.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Hugh Hefner’s Memorable Interview Moments
abstract: Highlights from more than 40 years of his conversations with William F. Buckley Jr., David Letterman, Piers Morgan, and more.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy magazine, died on Wednesday at  91. Known for his hedonistic parties at the Playboy Mansion, and for his many romantic involvements, he became a symbol of sexual liberation — if at times a contentious one.

headline: ‘Flesh-Eating Bacteria’ From Harvey’s Floodwaters Kill a Woman
abstract: Necrotizing fasciitis, a deadly infection that destroys tissue, can be caused by a wide range of bacteria, many of which were present after Hurricane Harvey.
lead_paragraph: From the moment the waters began rising in Texas last month, disease was on health officials’ minds. Floodwaters, after all, are filthy.

abstract: Also: Dr. Enrichment gets a checkup.

abstract: “The Cher Show,” a musical that uses her songs to tell her life story, will open first in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Here comes Cher. And Cher. And Cher.

lead_paragraph: Through Oct. 21. Tyler Rollins Fine Art, 529 West 20th Street, Manhattan; 212-229-4100, trfineart.com.

headline: Airports Worldwide Are Hit by Delays After Software Outage
abstract: A “network issue” affected programs used by several major carriers, delaying flights and causing other problems for travelers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Flights were delayed and travelers struggled to check in at airports around the world on Thursday after a software program used by several major airlines went down.

headline: Instead of Changing the Woman, Change the Standard
abstract: Optimizing individuality at Chloé and Dries Van Noten.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The day before her Chloé debut the designer Natacha Ramsay-Levi was discussing the model she had chosen to open her show: a relative unknown whose face, she said, was full of character, but whose body did not conform to the traditional runway mold — which is to say, it did not fit easily into the standard sample size.

headline: Yankees Get Some Zest, Courtesy of Frazier and Frazier
abstract: The two players share the same last name and some of the same sensibilities. Both have a little swagger and sass, and both have livened up the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: When Todd Frazier arrived at the visitor’s clubhouse in Minnesota this summer after his trade to the Yankees, he settled in among a room full of new teammates and introduced himself to the freckle-faced rookie at the adjacent cubicle.

headline: Word + Quiz: astigmatism
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on nytimes.com in the past four years.

headline: Trump Waives Jones Act for Puerto Rico, Easing Hurricane Aid Shipments
abstract: Puerto Rican officials and their allies had argued that the law was making it harder to get needed supplies to the island after Hurricane Maria.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration said on Thursday that it would temporarily waive a century-old shipping law for Puerto Rico that officials there said was hindering disaster relief efforts after Hurricane Maria.

headline: Meet the Fraziers
abstract: The New York Yankees have two Fraziers — Clint and Todd. Here's a guide to help tell them apart.
lead_paragraph: The New York Yankees have two Fraziers — Clint and Todd. Here's a guide to help tell them apart.

headline: Students Look to Vending Machines for Better Access to Morning-After Pill
abstract: Stanford is the latest university to install a vending machine that sells emergency contraception after students spoke of difficulty obtaining the pill.
lead_paragraph: It has been four years since the federal government lifted the age limit for the morning-after pill, but college students across the country say gaining access to it remains fraught with confusion and difficulty.

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include an eight-bedroom in Stamford, Conn., and a seven-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

headline: Most Unmarried Homeowners Are Women
abstract: Unmarried women have long been more likely than their male counterparts to own a home.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you missed it, but Unmarried and Single Americans Week was observed from Sept. 17 to 23. Based on 2016 demographics, there were 110.6 million unmarried people in the country to be celebrated. That’s 45.2 percent of all United States residents ages 18 and older, a number that includes the never married, widowed, divorced and cohabiting.

headline: Sparks’ Alana Beard Finds a Home on the Waves
abstract: Beard, the W.N.B.A. defensive player of the year at age 35, says the “best feeling in the world” comes not on the hardwood, but on a surfboard.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When the Los Angeles Sparks are at home during the W.N.B.A. season, guard Alana Beard starts almost every morning with coffee at The Cow’s End Café, a Bohemian spot a few steps from Venice Beach, sipping cortados and mingling with surfers who have become like family to her.

headline: Supreme Court Will Hear Case on Mandatory Fees to Unions
abstract: A year after a short-handed Supreme Court deadlocked on whether government workers must pay fees to unions, the justices will revisit the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday agreed to hear a case that could deal a crushing blow to organized labor.

headline: A Ghostly Father Sets Off a Cascade of Memories
abstract: Seeing Sarah Ruhl’s “For Peter Pan” reminds a critic of her own father and why she turns to theater to “confront the hard stuff,” like grieving his death.
lead_paragraph: The grown-up kids have gathered at their childhood home, where a white-haired man is puttering around behind them. His name is George, and he is their dad. Just a little bit ago, in the first scene of Sarah Ruhl’s play “For Peter Pan on her 70th birthday,” we watched him die in a hospital bed. Then he sat up, swung his legs over the side and walked away unnoticed, a freshly minted ghost.

headline: Edward St. Aubyn on the Challenge of Reimagining Shakespeare
abstract: In his bold modern adaptation of King Lear, Mr. St. Aubyn envisions Lear as an aging media mogul whose empire and legacy are under threat from his daughters.
lead_paragraph: “We’re off our meds,” Henry Dunbar, the protagonist of Edward St. Aubyn’s modern retelling of Shakespeare’s “King Lear,” whispers in the novel’s arresting opening sentence.

headline: The ‘Blade Runner 2049’ Look: Sci-Fi Brought Back Down to Earth
abstract: The costume designer Renée April explains the thinking that went into the sequel — masks and collars that hide faces and sleeves that hide hands.
lead_paragraph: Living up to the looks of “Blade Runner,” Ridley Scott’s 1982 science-fiction classic, was stressful for Renée April. She began designing costumes for “Blade Runner 2049,” the sequel starring Ryan Gosling, with the bar already set pretty high, she said. Over-the-top zoot suits, slashed stockings and other fashions that mixed punk and noir had made Mr. Scott’s hyperfuturistic world unmistakable.

headline: Hugh Hefner, the Pajama Man
abstract: Hugh Hefner’s long life in sleepwear.
lead_paragraph: In the daytime, Hugh Hefner wore custom-made silk — not satin, satin made him slip off the bedsheets, he said — in a shade he liked to call “gunfighter black.” At night he would transition into rich colors. Of an evening, he would add a bathrobe. For company, he’d put on a smoking jacket.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Return Would Be Good for Golf. But What About for Him?
abstract: Woods, who had a fourth back surgery in April and was arrested in May, is serving as an assistant captain at the Presidents Cup this week.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Tiger Woods staked out a spot off to the side of the 14th green and cast a long, cold shadow on Si Woo Kim, the Presidents Cup rookie who was bent over a three-foot putt to extend Thursday’s third foursomes match.

headline: Review: In ‘Mark Felt,’ Liam Neeson Is the Man Known as Deep Throat
abstract: Peter Landesman’s accidentally timely Watergate procedural has men in suits fighting for the independence of the F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: True story: As the executive branch of the American government is revealed to be a sinkhole of corruption and deceit, a career F.B.I. man with silver hair and a reputation for righteousness takes up the thankless task of investigating the suspected wrongdoing and attendant cover-up. Just so we’re clear: I’m describing the premise of a new movie starring Liam Neeson. What did you think?

headline: Review: When It Comes to New Marvel Shows, Skip ‘Inhumans’ and Try ‘The Gifted’
abstract: Two new network series bring the tally of Marvel shows to nine, with four more due in the near future.
lead_paragraph: Marvel series have become their own genre, and it’s one of the larger ones in the television-and-streaming universe: 13 live-action shows by next spring, if plans hold.

headline: Playboy in Popular Culture
abstract: Hugh Hefner, the creator and curator of the Playboy empire, died Wednesday. Here’s a look back at what made Playboy magazine and the media and entertainment empire it spawned so prominent.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hefner, the creator and curator of the Playboy empire, died Wednesday. Here’s a look back at what made Playboy magazine and the media and entertainment empire it spawned so prominent.

headline: Bayern Munich Fires Carlo Ancelotti, Sensing Team Had Lost Its Edge
abstract: Bayern, winner of the last five German Bundesliga titles, is sitting in third place, 3 points behind Dortmund.
lead_paragraph: There is only the finest of lines between what Bayern Munich not so long ago found so appealing about Carlo Ancelotti that it made him its manager and what convinced the club, on Thursday, to relieve him of those duties a few weeks into his second season. Ancelotti had not changed, far from it, but the context in which he found himself had.

headline: Ann Demeulemeester: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Paco Rabanne: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: How the Trump Administration Is Doing Renegotiating Nafta
abstract: Just how much progress has the Trump administration has made in renegotiating the North American trade pact? Here’s where it stands on five major goals.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Six weeks into the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the thorniest issues surrounding the pact remain unresolved.

headline: Fantasy Football: The Best Players to Start in Week 4
abstract: Russell Wilson is a good bet at quarterback, and LeSean McCoy is a smart start at running back.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: In Paris, Worn-Out Notre-Dame Needs a Makeover, and Hopes You Can Help
abstract: Rain, wind and pollution have battered the cathedral, which is seeking funds in France and in the United States to help pay for extensive renovations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Broken gargoyles and fallen balustrades replaced by plastic pipes and wooden planks. Flying buttresses darkened by pollution and eroded by rainwater. Pinnacles propped up by beams and held together with straps.

headline: Interior Department to Overhaul Obama’s Sage Grouse Protection Plan
abstract: The agency will consider allowing grazing and mineral leasing within the protected Western habitat of the greater sage grouse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will seek to reconsider an Obama-era blueprint for protecting the greater sage grouse, a move that could lead to new mineral leasing, grazing and other commercial activities across the quirky bird’s Western habitat.

headline: Facebook’s Ad-Targeting Problem, Captured in a Literal Shade of Gray
abstract: Many of the social network’s ad-targeting terms are legitimate in principle but can be problematic in practice. Consider, for instance, the word “confederate.”
lead_paragraph: For a sense of the dilemma confronting Facebook over its ad-targeting system, consider the following word: confederate.

headline: When It Comes to Gender, Let Confusion Reign
abstract: The New Museum shouldn’t mind some puzzled faces at the show “Trigger: Gender as a Tool and a Weapon.” Thinking hard is the point.
lead_paragraph: The New Museum isn’t new any more. It hit 40 this year, by some reckonings early middle age, though it’s still thinking young, or youngish, and living in the now. One thing that made it feel fresh early on was that it did shows on themes no other museums were tackling, like the 1982 “Extended Sensibilities: Homosexual Presence in Contemporary Art,” the first major American institutional survey of work by gay and lesbian artists. Now comes another such venture, “Trigger: Gender as a Tool and a Weapon,” a look at concepts of “trans” and “queer” as embodied in new art.

headline: Using Backup Codes Without a Cellphone
abstract: If you don’t have a smartphone around all the time for getting two-step verification codes, you can get those digits by voice or paper.
lead_paragraph: Q. I know we are all supposed to use the extra security and get a code sent when we log in, but what if a person doesn’t have a cellphone or doesn’t always keep it handy for instant access?

headline: Kopi Kopi
abstract: In Greenwich Village, this coffeehouse and wine bar has a dining room tucked in the back.
lead_paragraph: In Greenwich Village, this coffeehouse and wine bar has a dining room tucked in the back.

headline: Warung Selasa
abstract: Want to visit one of the smallest restaurants in New York? Then show up on Tuesdays at Indo Java, a grocery in Elmhurst, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Want to visit one of the smallest restaurants in New York? Then show up on Tuesdays at Indo Java, a grocery in Elmhurst, Queens.

headline: Spreading the Flavors of Indonesia, One Table at a Time
abstract: Warung Selasa, a pop-up in Queens, is one of New York’s smallest restaurants. And Kopi Kopi in the Village keeps the Indonesian cuisine ‘light.’
lead_paragraph: Yours is the best table in the house, and the only one: bright yellow between two black metal folding chairs, pressed against a freezer stacked with tempeh packets and a wall of instant curry noodles.

headline: Hey Kids! How Young Is Too Young to Get Married?
abstract: And: brawling toddlers, too-small parking spaces, and is it O.K. to try and meet women in the supermarket?
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I are in college. We’ve dated for two years. We talked about getting married after the first year. My parents supported it; it’s common (even considered lucky) in my family to be married before 25. But his mother thought we were too young and asked us to date for another year. We did. Now she’s added a new condition: that we be financially secure before marrying (even though I come from a wealthy family). I sense this pattern will continue, but her approval is essential to my boyfriend. Any advice?

headline: ‘I Don’t Need to Walk to Live’
abstract: Johnny Quinn, a 40-year-old insurance broker from Pennsylvania, is one of about two dozen professional wheelchair bodybuilders in the world.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Quinn was alone onstage, in total darkness. When the lights flicked on, he immediately turned sideways and flexed, his massive biceps swelling like inner tubes. Thousands respond with applause, giving Quinn a sense of accomplishment.

headline: China’s Abuse of Uighurs
abstract: The Uyghur Human Rights Project says the United States should not cooperate with China’s security campaign in the region.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Home for a Fabled Ship
abstract: The S.S. United States Conservancy suggests Pier 54 in New York as a suitable site.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: N.F.L. Week 4 Picks: Our Predictions Against the Spread
abstract: The Vikings should be fine regardless of who is at quarterback, the Patriots hope to continue rolling, and the Chiefs have become a must-see team.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of N.F.L. Week 4 anthem protests and game action here.

headline: Older Siblings a Risk Factor for Serious Flu Infections in Infants
abstract: Having older brothers and sisters puts young children at higher risk for being hospitalized with the flu.
lead_paragraph: Having older brothers and sisters puts infants at higher risk for being hospitalized with the flu.

headline: Rovio, Angry Birds Maker, Valued at $1 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The offering was aimed at helping Rovio carry out a growth strategy, with shares being used for possible acquisitions and rewards to its employees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It turns out Angry Birds is a billion-dollar idea.

headline: Chevron Names New Chief, Signaling Steady Path
abstract: Michael K. Wirth, with experience in pipelines and refineries, will succeed John S. Watson at a time when the company’s shares have bounced back.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Chevron, the nation’s No. 2 oil company, announced a new leader on Thursday in a move signaling confidence in its ability to thrive in an era of lower oil prices.

headline: Three Months After Shooting, Steve Scalise Makes Emotional Return to House
abstract: Steve Scalise, the No. 3 Republican who nearly lost his life to a gunman on a baseball field, returned to the House on Thursday to bipartisan applause.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Walking gingerly and on two canes, Representative Steve Scalise, the Republican whip, made an emotional return to the Capitol on Thursday, more than three months after a gunman nearly took his life during practice for a charity baseball game.

headline: Hugh Hefner, Between the Headlines
abstract: Newspapers, including The Times, could not help but follow Mr. Hefner’s exploits. His story was the story of changing attitudes toward sex.
lead_paragraph: The story of Hugh Hefner, who died Wednesday at 91, was in many ways the story of the sexual revolution. At least, that is how he would probably want us to tell it.

headline: A Legal Industry Built on Private School Sex Abuse
abstract: At some law firms, investigating sexual misconduct at prep schools has become a lucrative practice area, at a cost of as much as $2 million to schools.
lead_paragraph: It has become almost routine in recent months: An elite prep school announces the result of an outside investigation revealing how faculty members sexually abused their students, while administrators did little, if anything, to protect the children in their care.

headline: Pitino, Who Demanded Total Control, Can’t Avoid Accountability Now
abstract: Pitino always believed he was at his best as the underdog, but he let down people who expected better.
lead_paragraph: Rick Pitino always had a story to tell, an audience to charm. The campus folks — players, administrators, reporters — were his easiest marks.

headline: Review: In ‘Principles of Uncertainty,’ Talking and Dancing About the Weather
abstract: The artist Maira Kalman and the choreographer John Heginbotham have made a diffuse, agreeable, evasive study. (But a study in what?)
lead_paragraph: John Cage liked to say “I have nothing to say – and I’m saying it.” In that positive sense, “The Principles of Uncertainty” feels nothingy. A dance-theater collaboration between the choreographer John Heginbotham and the writer-designer Maira Kalman, this is an inconsequential collage of history, travel, memory, objects. It passes the time, which, as Vladimir and Estragon observe in “Waiting for Godot,” would have passed anyway. But to what end?

headline: Anti-Semitism in Germany
abstract: A reader writes that anti-Jewish attitudes are more extensive and pronounced than expected.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Long Island Town Opens Arms to All Unwanted Columbus Statues
abstract: Leaders says Massapequa will be a refuge for monuments to the historical figure they say is being maligned by revisionist history and “political correctness gone awry.”
lead_paragraph: MASSAPEQUA, N.Y. — The elders of Columbus Lodge 2143 of the Order Sons of Italy in America here on the South Shore of Long Island had settled into their daily poker game on Wednesday when Joseph Saladino, the supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay, came in to say hello.

headline: How Hugh Hefner Invented the Modern Man
abstract: People really did read Playboy for the articles — and those articles changed the country.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex. — In December 1953, the inaugural issue of Playboy magazine hit newsstands without a date. Hugh Hefner, its creator, was unsure whether it would be a success and have a future, so by withholding the date he hoped he could continue to sell that issue until he sold out of that first run.

headline: The Giveaway Artist
abstract: For more than a decade, the photographer Fred Cray has been hiding his “Unique Photographs” — more than 30,000 so far — all over New York City.
lead_paragraph: Security guards at Bergdorf Goodman kept an eye on Fred Cray. A 60-year-old man wearing cheap cherry-red reading glasses and a floral shirt, Mr. Cray adjusted his battered leather messenger bag, peered around his shoulder and pushed his glasses back up his nose as he browsed the racks in men’s wear. Eventually, the guards lost interest in him. That was when he struck.

headline: ISIS Releases Recording Said to Be of Its Leader
abstract: The recording suggests that the Islamic State’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, is still alive. It is his first public communication in nearly a year.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State issued on Thursday what appears to be the first recording in nearly a year of its reclusive leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, a move that seems intended to silence rumors of his death and to galvanize his pummeled troops.

headline: Review: Spinning and Toiling, but Not Finding Coltrane’s Sacred Love
abstract: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and Salva Sanchis’s dance, set to John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme,” is frantic and urgent, yet strangely unfeeling.
lead_paragraph: It probably doesn’t make sense to call a work of art perfect, but for “A Love Supreme,” John Coltrane’s four-part musical masterpiece recorded in 1964, the word sacred feels true and right. It’s an offering, one that seems more invincible and raw with each hearing.

headline: Balmain: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Relief Efforts in a Battered Puerto Rico
abstract: Readers both praise and criticize the U.S. response and suggest ways to hasten aid and to rebuild based on renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: What better season than autumn to savor two books about culinary icons — a memoir by Alice Waters, founder of Chez Panisse, and a biography of Patience Gray, a locavore long before the word became popular. Other nonfiction recommendations this week will set you off on a journey, whether retracing the steps of the “Odyssey” with the memoirist and translator Daniel Mendelsohn and his father, or crisscrossing America with the senior-citizen “workampers” of “Nomadland,” for whom retirement isn’t an option. And a book about an unsung theory of Darwin’s seeks to explain beauty as an evolutionary function.

headline: Review: ‘American Made’ Has Tom Cruise. And Lies, Spies and Coke.
abstract: Mr. Cruise plays a real-life pilot turned smuggler who worked for the C.I.A., in Doug Liman’s new movie.
lead_paragraph: The tagline for “American Made,” a breezily, at times woozily rollicking Tom Cruise vehicle, announces that it is “based on a true lie” — though the movie also asserts that it is based on a true story. But who’s quibbling? This is, after all, a Hollywood fantasy starring Mr. Cruise as Barry Seal, a real-life smuggler. An enigma with multiple chins, Mr. Seal was apparently known as El Gordo (the Fat Man), a name he may have picked up while working for a drug cartel, the C.I.A. or the Drug Enforcement Administration.

headline: In Trump Tax Plan, a Windfall for Businesses Large and Small
abstract: The administration’s proposed tax cuts give companies most everything they wanted, while skeptics question whether businesses would use the savings to hire and invest.
lead_paragraph: A lower tax rate for corporations. Reduced taxes for partnerships like law firms. An easy way to bring overseas profits back to the United States without being taxed.

headline: Two North Korean Spies, a Ukrainian Jail and a Murky Tale
abstract: Imprisoned for trying to steal missile technology, the two mostly keep to themselves but closely follow news about their nation’s nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: ZHYTOMYR, Ukraine — The North Korean spy, posing as a member of his country’s trade delegation in Belarus, thought he was photographing a secret scientific report on missile technology as he snapped away with a small camera in a dingy garage in the Ukrainian city of Dnipro, the home of Ukraine’s Soviet-era rocket industry.

headline: The Bronx Airport That Never Was
abstract: In the 1920s, plans were underway to build a major airport in the marshland of the eastern Bronx. But the Great Depression put a stop to that.
lead_paragraph: Q. I grew up in the northeast Bronx, and I remember my father and neighbors mentioning that back in the 1920s an airport was planned in the marsh. According to legend, a biplane came in for a landing and ended up in a cherry tree, destroying any chance of further developing the project. Is there any truth to this?

headline: Read the Letter a Democrat on an Oversight Subcommittee Sent to Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: Representative Robin L. Kelly, Democrat of Illinois, sent a letter on Tuesday to Mark Zuckerberg, the C.E.O. of Facebook, expressing concern about the advertising practices of the social media company.
lead_paragraph: Representative Robin L. Kelly, Democrat of Illinois, sent a letter on Tuesday to Mark Zuckerberg, the C.E.O. of Facebook, expressing concern about the advertising practices of the social media company.

headline: Black Lawmakers Pressure Facebook Over Racially Divisive Russian Ads
abstract: In a letter to Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, Representative Robin Kelly demanded that he take seriously Russian efforts to exploit racial division.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the Congressional Black Caucus pressured Facebook this week to seriously examine how the site allowed Russian operatives to use advertising to target Black Lives Matter and sow racial divisions ahead of last year’s election.

headline: Carven: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Voodoo Gets Even Voodooier
abstract: Even less likely to work now than then.
lead_paragraph: I liked Binyamin Appelbaum’s historical comparison of the Trump tax cut with Reagan and Bush, although such a comparison risks suggesting that the previous rounds made sense. They didn’t. The Reagan tax cut caused a sharp reversal in the long-run trend toward a declining debt-GDP ratio, the Bush tax cuts undid the fiscal progress of the Clinton years. And conversely, the Clinton tax hike helped produce surpluses even as the economy experienced a large boom, totally the opposite of what the usual suspects on the right predicted.

headline: How an Alabama Senator Got His Job May Have Led to His Losing It
abstract: Senator Luther Strange, who lost a primary runoff this week, was shadowed by the suspicion that his appointment was part of a deal with the governor.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — The first public whiff of the drama came two years ago, with a surprise divorce filing by the governor’s wife of more than 50 years. A surreptitious, salacious recording surfaced months later. Then, this past April, Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama, a Republican, resigned under the threat of impeachment over his relationship with a close aide.

headline: Australia’s Big Media Set to Get Bigger, With Help From Lawmakers
abstract: New legislation would ease ownership limits to help local owners compete with Google and Facebook. Critics say it would largely benefit Rupert Murdoch.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Most of Australia’s newspapers, radio stations and television broadcasters are controlled by only a handful of owners, like Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, making it one of the most concentrated media markets in the developed world.

headline: After the Tsunami, Japan’s Sea Creatures Crossed an Ocean
abstract: Hundreds of species — mussels, crabs and others — traveled thousands of miles on plastic debris to American shores.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The towering tsunami that devastated Japan six years ago also unleashed a very different sort of threat onto the distant coastline of North America: a massive invasion of marine life from across the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Lock ’Em Up, Then Dim Sum
abstract: Why waste time on a trial? You can tell by his face he’s guilty.
lead_paragraph: I have been summoned to jury duty or, as New Yorkers think of it, lunch in Chinatown, and I am torn: On one hand, I want to avoid it because sitting in a room for five hours is simply not that interesting, no matter how recently the room has been painted; on the other hand, I cling to the hope of being able to put someone behind bars for life.

headline: The Zika Virus Grew Deadlier With a Small Mutation, Study Suggests
abstract: A single variation in its DNA may have helped equip the virus to attack fetal cells, contributing to a surge of birth defects in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: It remains one of the great mysteries of the Zika epidemic: Why did a virus that existed for decades elsewhere in the world suddenly seem to become more destructive when it landed in Latin America?

headline: Review: Kronos Quartet Revisits Vietnam Horror in ‘My Lai’
abstract: The story of a soldier who took a heroic stand against evil is evoked in a monodrama for tenor, string quartet and Vietnamese instruments.
lead_paragraph: You would like to think that a soldier who took a heroic stand against evil and managed to save at least a few lives amid a massacre could find peace of mind in his dying days. The creators of “My Lai,” a musical theater work given its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday evening, suggest otherwise in the case of Hugh Thompson.

headline: Swans With Glittering Technique
abstract: Megan Fairchild and Tiler Peck, making their Odette-Odile debuts, are still figuring out how to make “Swan Lake” full-blooded drama.
lead_paragraph: Megan Fairchild has been a principal dancer at New York City Ballet since 2005. Tiler Peck advanced to that rank in 2009. Yet it was not until this week that these ballerinas got their first chance to star in “Swan Lake.”

headline: The Evolutionary Event That Gave You Pumpkins and Squash
abstract: About 100 million years ago, the genome of a melon-like fruit copied itself, leading to fruits now associated with autumn, scientists have found.
lead_paragraph: Dear Watermelon,

headline: Rick Owens: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: ‘Springsteen on Broadway’ to Hold Digital Ticket Lottery
abstract: For every performance of Bruce Springsteen’s solo Broadway show, 26 tickets will be available for $75 each.
lead_paragraph: To get into “Springsteen on Broadway,” you can either pay over a thousand dollars, or hope to steal some good fortune from “Lucky Town.”

headline: Still Processing: Take a Knee if You Agree
abstract: We talk about the protests that swept the N.F.L. last weekend, and what they mean for Trump and the country at large.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another rant from Donald Trump. This time, the president took aim at Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback who spent the majority of last season sitting or kneeling during the national anthem to draw attention to police brutality and racial injustice. Trump’s remarks — that the owners of football teams should fire anyone who followed suit — prompted a nationwide demonstration the following Sunday from players and team owners who knelt or linked arms. We talk about the language used by the president and his supporters and their expectations of black entertainers and athletes. We also investigate the history of the national anthem. What all did Francis Scott Key really invoke in the “Star-Spangled Banner”? Oh, and we also manage to work in a reference to “Get Out.” All kinds of people, including Stevie Wonder and celebrity chef Carla Hall, are joining the #TakeAKnee movement. Will it retain its integrity as it evolves away from Kaepernick?

headline: N.F.L. Protests, Family Vacations, Rejection and Selfies: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week
abstract: Our favorite student comments from the last several days, and an invitation to join the conversation yourself.
lead_paragraph: Each week on our site, we post nine new writing prompts inspired by Times articles or images, and we hear from teenagers all over the world in response. Below, we feature some of the best comments that have come in over the last seven days.

headline: In Taiwan, Modest Test of Driverless Bus May Hint at Big Things to Come
abstract: The small vehicles are being tested on a university campus and central Taipei. The city’s mayor hopes they will reshape transportation.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Rolling with a barely audible hum beneath banyan trees, a brightly painted shuttle bus cruised through a university campus here.

headline: The Met Has the Voices. But Will It Need More to Survive?
abstract: This is repertory-wise one of the dullest Met seasons in memory, but the singing in the first week of performances was often superb.
lead_paragraph: “I am very aware of all the elements in opera,” the playwright Albert Innaurato, who died this week, once wrote in The New York Times, “but I love voices.”

headline: In Trade Actions, Trump Embraces Unpredictability
abstract: In imposing punitive tariffs on Canadian jets, the Trump administration has intensified confusion about the principles guiding its trade policy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Trump has rarely been accused of running a surplus in predictability. As his administration this week imposed punitive tariffs on a Canadian airplane manufacturer, it exacerbated confusion over where Mr. Trump might venture next in his zeal to redraw the terms of American commerce with the world.

headline: Blaufränkisch From Austria: The Rewards of Exploration
abstract: Wines like this red from the Burgenland are often unfamiliar, but an openness to trying what is new can bring unexpected pleasure and great values.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people who love wine and are curious enough about it to participate in our Wine School enterprise have never heard of blaufränkisch.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Crozes-Hermitage
abstract: In the northern Rhône Valley of France, Crozes-Hermitage can often be an afterthought. But the wines are rapidly improving.
lead_paragraph: Next up will be Crozes-Hermitage from the northern Rhône Valley of France. It was not my first choice or even my second, which I guess is fitting for a wine that is often an afterthought.

headline: Google Acts to End One Fight in Europe as Bigger Antitrust Battle Looms
abstract: The search giant agreed to changes in its online shopping unit to focus its resources for a fight with European regulators over Android smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Google’s parent company, Alphabet, has cleared the deck for a huge antitrust fight. The technology giant is separating its European shopping unit and allowing rivals to bid for ads. That frees Google up to battle European regulators over claims that the company uses its Android operating system to dominate online search.

headline: How Trump’s Proposed Tax Plan Affects Rich and Poor
abstract: Readers criticize the proposal as a gift to the wealthy and based on the “fable of supply-side economics.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lobbyists Rally to Save Tax Breaks Under Threat in Trump Plan
abstract: Less than 24 hours after Republicans unveiled a sweeping plan to rewrite the tax code, Washington lobbyists are already jockeying to protect valuable tax preferences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans’ release of a sweeping plan to rewrite the tax code has set off a scramble among Washington lobbyists and trade groups to protect valuable tax breaks and other long-ingrained provisions.

headline: For Uber in London, a New Route: Diplomacy
abstract: The ride-hailing service’s chief, Dara Khosrowshahi, has moved away from the combative tone of his predecessor, Travis Kalanick, in an initial test.
lead_paragraph: As a global disrupter, Uber is no stranger to conflict, and its instinct has always been pugilistic. But on Monday, three days after Transport for London said it wouldn’t renew the ride-hailing service’s license to operate, Uber all but prostrated itself to show its humility.

headline: The Case for Shunning the White House
abstract: As long as bigotry dominates the Trump administration, there’s no common ground to be found with my nonprofit — even if money is on the table.
lead_paragraph: On a gray day in late January — four days after President Trump’s inauguration and three days after the Women’s March — I received a call from the newly constituted office of Ivanka Trump. I was invited to the White House to discuss a computer-science education initiative she was spearheading. She wanted the organization I founded, Girls Who Code, to join. Despite my deep personal opposition to many of the positions President Trump had already expressed, I was prepared, in the interest of furthering our mission, to collaborate with his new administration the way we had with the Obama administration.

headline: Kit Reed, Author of Darkly Humorous Fiction, Dies at 85
abstract: In novels and stories that hopscotched across genres, happy endings were no more likely than they are in life.
lead_paragraph: Kit Reed, a prolific novelist and short-story writer who was celebrated for her science fiction but also hopscotched to the fantasy, Southern Gothic, paranormal and mystery genres, died on Sept. 24 in Los Angeles. She was 85.

headline: The Met Opera Offers Buyouts to Its Staff as Its Season Opens
abstract: Citing “economic challenges,” the Metropolitan Opera, the nation’s largest performing arts organization, offered early retirement to some employees.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, which has continued to struggle at the box office and face what it calls “economic challenges,” has offered voluntary buyouts to 21 of its 243 administrative employees, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Brevity Is the Soul of Twit
abstract: Say it in 140 characters or don’t say it at all.
lead_paragraph: Back in Twitter’s early days, there was a lot of parodying what would come next. My favorite was Flutter, 26 characters — one for each letter of the alphabet — marking the brave, new world of nanoblogging.

headline: U.S. to Collect Social Media Data on All Immigrants Entering Country
abstract: The new policy, which officials called an effort to more effectively screen those coming to the country, drew alarm from privacy advocates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security will soon begin collecting social media data from all immigrants entering the United States, part of what agency officials call an effort to more effectively screen those coming to the country but privacy advocates see as an unnecessary intrusion that would do little to protect national security.

headline: In Catalonia, an ‘Accidental’ Leader of Unwavering Conviction
abstract: A compromise choice as Catalan leader, Carles Puigdemont is fully committed to an independence referendum in defiance of Spain’s central government
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — A mayor from the Spanish hinterland, Carles Puigdemont was a relative unknown until thrust into the leadership of Catalonia last year. He was a compromise choice to break a deadlock among separatist parties.

headline: Russian Court Orders Arrest of Doping Whistle-Blower Who Fled
abstract: A Russian court seeks the arrest of the former sports official who alleged that government officials organized a doping scheme at the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian court has ruled that a former top sports official who blew the whistle on doping violations will be arrested if he ever sets foot back in his native land.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Shares Breast Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: The actress learned she had the disease one day after winning her sixth consecutive Emmy Award for her role on “Veep.”
lead_paragraph: Julia Louis-Dreyfus has breast cancer, she announced on Thursday, less than two weeks after her record-setting Emmy win for “Veep.”

headline: Emmanuel Macron’s Lofty Vision for Europe Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: French president’s speech on European reform gives political weight to some mainstream ideas and pushes more integration as the answer to populism.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — No one has ever accused Emmanuel Macron of lacking in audacity. He broke a lot of rules and expectations of deference to become, at 39, the president of France, the closest thing a Western democracy has to a civilian monarch.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Stronger’
abstract: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from the film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal as Jeff Bauman.
lead_paragraph: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from the film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal as Jeff Bauman.

headline: David Gordon Green Narrates a Scene From ‘Stronger’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence featuring Jake Gyllenhaal and Tatiana Maslany.
lead_paragraph: In the drama “Stronger,” Jake Gyllenhaal portrays Jeff Bauman, who lost both legs after the Boston Marathon bombing in 2013. In this scene, he’s in the hospital getting his bandages removed, with his on-again, off-again girlfriend, Erin (Tatiana Maslany), by his side. In an interview, the director David Gordon Green discussed casting the actual surgeon who worked with Mr. Bauman. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: The Wrong Way to Fight Gangs
abstract: The administration thinks law enforcement is the answer, but education works better.
lead_paragraph: Oakland, Calif. — Young migrants from Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador come to this country fleeing violence and lives that are often dictated by savage gangs. It’s expensive to get here. They often arrive with thousands of dollars of high-interest debt and little or no English skills. And they face an administration that insists that they are gangsters bringing bloodshed and gang warfare to American cities.

headline: Dance in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to dance performances.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances.

headline: Anne Jeffreys, Glamorous Ghost of ’50s TV, Is Dead at 94
abstract: Ms. Jeffreys, who had a long career in film, on television and on Broadway, was best known for playing the otherworldly Marion Kerby on “Topper.”
lead_paragraph: Anne Jeffreys, the sophisticated blond actress and singer who played a glamorous ghost in the 1950s television series  “Topper,” died on Wednesday at her home in the Brentwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: Comedy in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety sHOWS.

headline: Too Young to Vote, but Asking for Yours
abstract: Motivated by President Trump’s election, teenagers and young adults are seeking political office, from village halls to state capitals.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, Tahseen Chowdhury is no ordinary 17-year-old. He is president of the student government at Stuyvesant High School, among New York City’s most selective public schools, and leads the student advisory council for the borough of Manhattan. He even helped found two companies: an event photography business and a firm that teaches students computer programming and engineering.

headline: Events for Children in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

headline: Once Trapped in Korea, Puerto Rican Vets Now Face Battle at Home
abstract: Puerto Rican veterans who survived the horrors of Korea wonder when their commander in chief will address their island’s humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: Luis Rivera-Pérez was a baby-faced 18-year-old recruit when he left his home in San Juan in 1951 to fight in Korea with the 65th Infantry Regiment, a storied Puerto Rican unit known as the Borinqueneers. He aged quickly in combat, venturing out on night patrols where they used flamethrowers to incinerate enemy troops hidden in caves. In one battle, they slogged up a hillside for a bayonet assault, only to be pinned down by relentless gunfire.

headline: North Korea, Hugh Hefner, Shinzo Abe: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows — and some that will be closing soon.

headline: Risk on All Sides as 4,800 Women Sue Over Johnson’s Baby Powder and Cancer
abstract: Johnson & Johnson has been accused of causing thousands of cases of ovarian cancer by plaintiffs who are mostly taking the company to court individually, not as a team.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of women across the country are suing the consumer goods giant Johnson & Johnson over its baby powder, claiming that talcum particles in the popular product caused their ovarian cancer.

headline: Isabel Marant: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Amid Protests at Trump Hotel, Neil Gorsuch Calls for Civility
abstract: Critics said the Supreme Court justice showed poor judgment by speaking at the Trump International Hotel, which is the subject of several lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Neil M. Gorsuch addressed a conservative group at the Trump International Hotel on Thursday, drawing protests and criticism for speaking at a venue that is the subject of several lawsuits against the president.

headline: Film Series in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: Red Miller Dies at 89; Coached Broncos to Their First Super Bowl
abstract: Perennial losers since 1960, Denver found glory under Miller, powered by its defensive unit, the Orange Crush.
lead_paragraph: Red Miller, who turned the hapless Denver Broncos into a defensive powerhouse and guided the team to its first Super Bowl, in 1978, in his first season as a head coach, died on Wednesday in Denver. He was 89.

headline: Classical Music in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.

headline: Finn Wolfhard, the Young Star of ‘Stranger Things,’ Shops for Vinyl
abstract: The 14-year-old actor, who also stars in Stephen King’s “It,” plays in a garage rock band and has a growing record collection.
lead_paragraph: Finn Wolfhard, a 14-year-old actor with a shaggy haircut and a baby face, was perusing the aisles of Rough Trade NYC, a far-from-extinct music store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Flipping through stacks of vinyl, he stopped every so often to comment on a record.

headline: Von Miller of the Broncos Took a Knee, Then a Sponsor Drew Scrutiny
abstract: A car dealership in Denver faced an internet backlash after a retracted TV news report saying it had fired him. The facts were more complicated.
lead_paragraph: Von Miller, a star linebacker for the Denver Broncos, was one of many N.F.L. players who knelt on Sunday during the playing of the national anthem in what became a sweeping and stark show of solidarity against police brutality and a silent admonition of President Trump.

headline: Chastened, Tom Price Tries to Deflect Anger Over Chartered Flights
abstract: President Trump let it be known that paying back his travel costs as repentance was no guarantee that Mr. Price would keep his job.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After being rebuked by President Trump for racking up at least $400,000 in travel on chartered flights, Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price said on Thursday that he would pay back taxpayers for his part of the bill and stop flying on private jets.

headline: Ikea Enters ‘Gig Economy’ by Acquiring TaskRabbit
abstract: The Swedish retailer known for build-it-yourself furniture, did not disclose how much it paid for the San Francisco-based start-up, which provides on-demand services.
lead_paragraph: Ikea, the Swedish home goods retailer, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire TaskRabbit, a company known for, among other things, sending tool-wielding workers to rescue customers befuddled by build-it-yourself furniture kits.

headline: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

headline: Hefner’s Mansion Embodied Hedonistic Fun and Darker Impulses
abstract: Seemingly everyone in Hollywood has a story about the Playboy Mansion. Some of them are ugly.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Everyone in Hollywood has a Playboy Mansion story. Many are unprintable.

headline: Last Chance to Watch Big Brother as He Watches You
abstract: “1984” nears the end of its run at the Hudson Theater.
lead_paragraph: ‘1984’ at the Hudson Theater (closes Oct. 8). Doublethink, Newspeak and thoughtcrime leave Broadway as Robert Icke and Duncan Macmillan’s version of George Orwell’s 1949 novel — which stars Tom Sturridge as Winston Smith and Olivia Wilde as his clandestine lover, Julia — finishes its run.

headline: What’s New in NYC Theater
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages — and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’: What to Remember Before Watching Season 9
abstract: It’s been more than six years since we last saw Larry David. Where did we leave off?
lead_paragraph: TV’s funniest misanthrope is back. After an extended hiatus that had fans wondering whether “Curb Your Enthusiasm” was gone for good, that beloved sitcom, starring the “Seinfeld” co-creator Larry David as an exaggerated version of himself, is finally returning to HBO.

headline: Off/White: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Three Things to Watch This Weekend
abstract: However much you have, surely it’s enough for fat pets, Hollywood sleaze or the return of Larry David.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

headline: Otto Warmbier: The Coroner’s Report
abstract: In the full text of the pathology report, the coroner's office in Hamilton County, Ohio, described the cause of death for Mr. Warmbier, a university student who was detained in North Korea.
lead_paragraph: In the full text of the pathology report, the coroner's office in Hamilton County, Ohio, described the cause of death for Mr. Warmbier, a university student who was detained in North Korea.

headline: Otto Warmbier Suffered Extensive Brain Damage, Coroner Confirms
abstract: The college student, imprisoned for more than a year in North Korea, fell into a vegetative state after blood flow to his brain was cut off, according to a coroner’s report.
lead_paragraph: Otto F. Warmbier, the college student imprisoned in North Korea and returned to the United States in a vegetative state, suffered extensive brain damage following interrupted blood flow and a lack of oxygen, according to the coroner who examined his body.

headline: Saudi Women Can Finally Drive
abstract: Just in time ...
lead_paragraph: Just in time ...

headline: Senator Berates Twitter Over ‘Inadequate’ Inquiry Into Russian Meddling
abstract: Twitter told lawmakers investigating Russian election interference that it identified about 200 accounts linked to Kremlin disinformation, far fewer than others have found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A key senator investigating Russia’s interference in the 2016 election sharply criticized Twitter on Thursday for failing to aggressively investigate the Russian misuse of its platform after the company said it had largely limited its own inquiry to accounts linked to fraudulent profiles already identified by Facebook.

headline: 7 Habits for a Healthy Heart
abstract: It pumps your blood throughout your body, but how much do you know about your heart? Learn about the most important steps you can take to keep it beating strong.
lead_paragraph: It pumps your blood throughout your body, but how much do you know about your heart? Learn about the most important steps you can take to keep it beating strong.

headline: Former VW Engine Chief Arrested, Signaling Widening Emissions Case
abstract: Wolfgang Hatz, former head of engine development, is being held without bail in Munich and will be under intense pressure to testify against others.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — An investigation into Volkswagen’s diesel emissions scandal expanded significantly on Thursday after German authorities arrested a former high-ranking executive of the carmaker, two people with knowledge of the arrest said.

headline: Trump Administration Is Pressed to Step Up Hurricane Recovery in Puerto Rico
abstract: White House aides insisted that the administration’s response was adequate, but residents in Puerto Rico complained of a lack of basic supplies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved on Thursday to step up its assistance to Puerto Rico more than a week after Hurricane Maria, appointing a three-star general to coordinate with agencies and vowing to give the island all it needed as aides tried to stave off comparisons to the response to Hurricane Katrina more than a decade ago.

headline: Vann Molyvann, Architect Who Shaped Cambodia’s Capital, Dies at 90
abstract: He returned from years in exile only to watch as his buildings and urban planning were dismantled by unbridled capitalism, corruption and urban sprawl.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Vann Molyvann, an architect and urban planner whose pioneering mixing of modernism with indigenous elements transformed the landscape of Phnom Penh, Cambodia’s capital, died on Thursday at his home in the northern Siem Reap Province. He was 90.

headline: Gala Season Kicks Off
abstract: Events were held for the Metropolitan Opera, the Drawing Center, Royal Academy America and Save the Chimps.
lead_paragraph: Events were held for the Metropolitan Opera, the Drawing Center, Royal Academy America and Save the Chimps.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
