abstract: Two new friends get a little help retrieving a runaway vessel on the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Alabama Victory Provides Blueprint for New Bannon Alliance
abstract: A new coalition could put Steve Bannon and Robert and Rebekah Mercer on a collision course with not just the Republican establishment, but with the Koch brothers and ultimately with President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen K. Bannon and two of his longtime benefactors are putting together a political coalition designed to ensure that the victory of a Republican insurgent in the Alabama Senate primary this week was just the beginning of the surprises that await the party establishment.

headline: Elon Musk’s Mars Vision: A One-Size-Fits-All Rocket. A Very Big One.
abstract: Mr. Musk’s booster, scaled back from last year’s plan but still the largest ever, could take travelers to Mars, the moon — or around the world in minutes.
lead_paragraph: ADELAIDE, Australia — Elon Musk is revising his ambitions for sending people to Mars, and he says he now has a clearer picture of how his company, SpaceX, can make money along the way.

headline: Menendez’s Actions on a Donor’s Behalf Were ‘Unusual,’ Witnesses Say
abstract: Witnesses in the corruption trial of Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, said he used his seats on two powerful senate committees to help a wealthy donor.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — “Unusual.” “Odd.” “Just different.”

headline: Trump Could Save More Than $1 Billion Under His New Tax Plan
abstract: Mr. Trump and his family would benefit from his proposed repeal of the estate tax and a reduction in other tax rates.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump and his family would benefit from his proposed repeal of the estate tax and a reduction in other tax rates.

headline: They Swallowed Live Typhoid Bacteria — On Purpose
abstract: A clinical trial enlisted some of England’s brightest minds, tempted by curiosity and cash. They proved a new typhoid vaccine works and could save children’s lives.
lead_paragraph: “I was curious.” That’s how James M. Duggan, an Oxford University medical student, explains why he agreed to swallow a big dose of live typhoid bacteria.

headline: Amid Facebook’s Troubles, Message to Advertisers Stays Consistent
abstract: At Advertising Week, the social network extolled its size and reach to marketers, even while facing criticism over the misuse of its ad-targeting tools.
lead_paragraph: “I want to start off with our mission,” Carolyn Everson, the vice president of global marketing solutions at Facebook, said this week as she faced a crowd of marketers from the stage of a theater in Times Square. Ms. Everson was there to extol the potential of video advertising on Facebook site and its apps during the annual industry confab known as Advertising Week New York.

headline: After Kristaps Porzingis Leaves Practice, Knicks Play Down Durability Concerns
abstract: The Knicks have put their faith in Porzingis, but nagging injuries, including a sore knee that forced him to leave practice on Thursday, continue to hound him.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks’ hopes of a smooth training camp after trading away Carmelo Anthony took a hit Thursday afternoon when Kristaps Porzingis, the team’s burgeoning star, left practice early with a sore right knee.

headline: Hugh Hefner, a Force for Good? Discuss.
abstract: Mr. Hefner was keen to promote himself as a progressive, but what did he really do for women? Our writers discuss.
lead_paragraph: Since the news that Hugh Hefner died on Wednesday night, at 91, the obituaries and tributes have been pouring in. While many have focused on the pajama-clad avatar of sybaritic male pleasure, others have paid tribute to a less familiar figure: Hef the progressive.

headline: Teaching About Charlottesville With Resources from The New York Times
abstract: A list of articles, essays, multimedia, lesson plans and more.
lead_paragraph: While the violence that took place in Charlottesville happened more than a month ago, the questions it raises are as relevant as ever.

headline: How Teachers Are Bringing Charlottesville to the Classroom
abstract: Educators across the country reflect on how they‘ll tackle the topic in the context of what and who they teach.
lead_paragraph: In late August, we asked teachers if they would be adding this summer’s events in Charlottesville, Va., to their curriculum. We heard from many, and, with help from Talya Minsberg, a New York Times social strategy editor, we feature some of their voices below.

headline: Catalonia’s Drive to Vote on Independence
abstract: The problem with the movement for a referendum is that the Catalan leaders are disregarding democratic procedures.
lead_paragraph: The referendum on independence planned for Sunday in Catalonia, Spain, is about more than a people’s wish for self-government. It threatens the very democracy and rule of law that Spain insisted upon after the decades-long dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco came to an end in 1975.

headline: Student Charged in Bronx School Stabbing Felt Bullied, Police Say
abstract: Investigators are trying to piece together the life of an 18-year-old before his classmate was killed and another injured during a fight at a Bronx high school.
lead_paragraph: A week into his senior year, the 18-year-old student logged onto Amazon and bought a knife: a spring-loaded switchblade, slim enough to stay hidden in his pocket but sturdy enough, at a price of $30, that it could be lethal.

headline: Pressure Rises at U.N. on Myanmar Over Rohingya Crisis
abstract: The leader of the United Nations called the Rohingya crisis “a human rights nightmare” as Myanmar canceled a U.N. visit to the affected area.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s authorities came under intensifying pressure on Thursday over the Rohingya refugee crisis, with the United Nations secretary general calling it a “human rights nightmare” that has driven more than a half-million civilians into Bangladesh in the past month.

headline: Private Emails, Private Jets and Mr. Trump’s Idea of Public Service
abstract: His promises to fight corruption look emptier by the day.
lead_paragraph: Electing him, Donald Trump promised on the campaign trail, would “make every dream you ever dreamed for your country come true.” Among those reveries, he suggested, would be a government free of self-dealing and one devoted to public service. “If we want to make America great again,” he wrote in an op-ed for USA Today days before the election, “we must clean up this corruption.”

headline: Second Yosemite Rockfall in Two Days Injures One at El Capitan
abstract: For the second consecutive day, a chunk of rock broke off the granite monolith at the California park. Crashing rock on Wednesday killed a tourist from Wales.
lead_paragraph: A chunk of rock broke off the face of El Capitan in Yosemite National Park on Thursday afternoon, injuring one person a day after a massive slab fell from the towering monolith and killed a tourist, park officials said.

headline: How to Protect Yourself After the Equifax Breach
abstract: For weeks, we have been asking Equifax dozens of questions about credit freezes, credit locks and the trouble readers have been having with its various systems. The company has responded — to some of them.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, we have been asking Equifax dozens of questions about credit freezes, credit locks and the trouble readers have been having with its various systems. The company has responded — to some of them.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Few Objections by Deficit Hawks on Tax Cuts’ Cost
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 29, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “I think the greatest threat to our nation is us. The way we handle our finances, we as a nation are the greatest threat to our nation. It’s not ISIS. It’s not North Korea. It’s not ascendant China. It’s not Russia. We are the greatest threat.”

headline: Packers Continue Anthem Demonstrations, and Recent Mastery of Bears
abstract: National anthem demonstrations at N.F.L. games stretched into a second week when the Green Bay Packers, and some of the team’s fans, linked arms before the team’s game against the Chicago Bears.
lead_paragraph: In a twist on last week’s N.F.L. national anthem demonstrations, the Green Bay Packers locked arms during the playing of the song, and asked that the team’s fans lock arms as well, before their home game against the Chicago Bears on Thursday night.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Julie Taymor to Direct Gloria Steinem Biopic
abstract: Ms. Taymor will direct a film about the feminist icon Gloria Steinem’s formative years, written by Sarah Ruhl.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Steinem’s story will be coming to the big screen.

headline: Puerto Rico Deserves Better
abstract: The island won’t recover unless it gets more, and speedier, federal help.
lead_paragraph: It has been a week since Puerto Rico emerged from a double battering by hurricanes, and it is caught in a painful, torpid recovery. Far more and far faster help is needed as the island struggles with vast devastation that only the federal government has the resources to repair.

headline: Review: An ‘As You Like It’ That Is More Prose Than Poetry
abstract: The director John Doyle brings to Shakespeare the same techniques that helped him refresh many a musical. So why doesn’t it work?
lead_paragraph: The maximalism of musical theater is often a good match for John Doyle’s knife. In pared-back stagings of “Sweeney Todd” and “The Color Purple,” to name just two, he has shown us what is essential by removing everything that isn’t.

headline: Brain Power Like You Can’t Believe
abstract: Damon Gulczynski shows off his themeless skills yet again.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — TGIF, everyone! What a way to kick off the weekend; Damon Gulczynski has returned for his seventh themeless puzzle this year, and like all the rest of his work, it’s chock-full of pizazz.

headline: Illinois Governor Signs Abortion Bill, Angering Fellow Republicans
abstract: One Republican called Gov. Bruce Rauner’s signing of the bill, which expands abortion coverage for women on Medicaid, “an absolute betrayal.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Bruce Rauner, the Republican governor of left-leaning Illinois, won praise on Thursday from some unlikely corners. The American Civil Liberties Union and the Chicago Abortion Fund stood behind Mr. Rauner as he announced that he would sign a bill expanding abortion coverage for women on Medicaid.

headline: Commissioner Still Expects N.B.A. Players to Stand for Anthem
abstract: The N.B.A. is known for being socially progressive, but Commissioner Adam Silver said the league’s policy requiring players to stand for the national anthem has not changed.
lead_paragraph: Commissioner Adam Silver said Thursday that the N.B.A. would continue to require players to stand for the national anthem before games this season.

headline: After Anthem Protests, N.F.L. Plots a Careful Path Forward
abstract: The league is trying to balance its players’ desire to raise awareness of social issues while accommodating fans who would prefer football to be just about football.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the prospect of another wave of sideline demonstrations at N.F.L. games this weekend, the league’s owners and players are wrestling with how to plot a path forward from one of the most divisive weekends it has seen.

headline: Immigration Agents Arrest Hundreds in Sweep of Sanctuary Cities
abstract: Operation Safe City focused on jurisdictions that prevent cooperation between local law enforcement and immigration officials.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Federal agents arrested 498 people from 42 countries in a four-day nationwide operation targeting cities that United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement said give sanctuary to undocumented immigrants who have committed crimes.

headline: Poised to Build Pressure on the Red Sox, the Yankees Stumble Instead
abstract: The Yankees had a promising start to their night but several costly errors allowed an opportunity to gain ground on Boston to slip away.
lead_paragraph: On a night in which the Yankees could have applied some real pressure on the Boston Red Sox, they succeeded only in turning up the heat on themselves.

headline: Taking My Ex Back In (for His Own Good)
abstract: They loved each other and had a child together, but couldn’t make it work. Twenty years later, could their bond save his life?
lead_paragraph: Tim was on the other side of the kitchen counter looking at a list I had written of what he should check on in the house while my husband, Din, and I were on vacation.

headline: Brigitte Macron’s Stylist: Man of Mystery
abstract: Mathieu Barthelat Colin has been helping to shape the French first lady’s wardrobe but few in the fashion industry say they‘ve even met him.
lead_paragraph: As the final, frenzied week of spring ready-to-wear shows began in the French capital, the country’s most influential stylist was nowhere to be found.

headline: Word + Quiz: debutante
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: Catalans and Kurds Discover the Hard Truth About Secession
abstract: Independence referendums in Spain and Iraq reveal the deep contradiction between the norms and rules of secession.
lead_paragraph: When does an independence movement get to form its own nation? For decades, a set of unstated but well-known rules has supposedly decided that.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Big Mouth’ and ‘The Future Perfect’
abstract: The new series “Big Mouth” ruthlessly captures teenage embarrassment. And a new language opens an immigrant’s eyes to life in “The Future Perfect.”
lead_paragraph: The new series “Big Mouth” ruthlessly captures the embarrassment of the transformative teenage years. And a new language opens an immigrant’s eyes to life’s possibilities in “The Future Perfect.”

headline: China’s Harsh Words Mask a Trade Boom With South Korea
abstract: Even as China scolds Seoul for housing a U.S. missile defense system, its businesses and consumers buy up more Korean semiconductors and cosmetics.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Forget geopolitics: Leo Li, a 33-year-old language teacher in China, wants his essence of South Korean snail slime.

headline: A Town’s New Seal
abstract: Why do you think Whitesboro, N.Y., decided to change its seal?
lead_paragraph: Early in 2016, a small town in central New York received national criticism for its town seal (left). Recently, town officials decided to redesign it (right).

headline: Right and Left React to Trump’s Tax Cut Proposal
abstract: Read about how the other side thinks: Writers from across the political spectrum discuss the president’s tax plan.
lead_paragraph: President Trump proposed a sweeping plan to cut taxes on Wednesday that included the elimination of the estate tax and big cuts to corporate tax rates.

headline: Cuban Doctors Revolt: ‘You Get Tired of Being a Slave’
abstract: In a rare act of defiance, some 150 Cuban doctors serving in Brazil have sued to work as independent contractors, cutting out the Havana government.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — In a rare act of collective defiance, scores of Cuban doctors working overseas to make money for their families and their country are suing to break ranks with the Cuban government, demanding to be released from what one judge called a “form of slave labor.”

headline: Teaching Activities for: ‘Birds Beware: The Praying Mantis Wants Your Brain’
abstract: What distinguishes mantises from other insects?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: How Donald Trump Opened the Door to Roy Moore
abstract: A defeat for Trump and a win for Trumpism.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, the Alabama Supreme Court issued a ruling in a child custody battle between a lesbian mother and an allegedly abusive father. The parents had originally lived in Los Angeles, and when they divorced in 1992, the mother received primary physical custody. But she was an alcoholic, and in 1996, she sent her three children to live with her ex-husband, who’d since moved to Alabama, while she went to rehab. Her lawyer, Wendy Brooks Crew, told me they had an understanding that the kids would stay with their dad for a year, but he refused to return them to their mother because she was living with a woman.

headline: We Are All Jew-ish Now
abstract: “Jewishness” can be the sensibility of whoever feels unsure of who they are — a bit peculiar, a bit funny.
lead_paragraph: Asked what makes them “Jewish,” many Jews are, naturally, likely to point to religion — to rituals and prayers like the ones associated with the High Holy Days.

headline: What Sincerity Looks Like
abstract: Chance the Rapper’s cultural revolution.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes pop culture seems completely prepackaged and professionalized, so when somebody steps out and puts on a display of vulnerability, trust and humility, it takes your breath away.

headline: The Trump Fog Machine
abstract: His legislative agenda is in tatters, but his master strategy — throwing out distraction bombs — is working.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember what monstrous, contemptible or demonstrably false thing Donald Trump said one year ago? Six months ago? O.K., last week? Probably not. The effect of this presidency-by-horrors is to induce amnesia in the public, as if we’d all been given a memory-loss drug.

headline: The Wrong Time to Cut Back on Refugees
abstract: President Trump needs to realize that resettling refugees is good for our economy and our foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Amid the world’s worst migrant crisis on record, the Trump administration is cutting back on refugee resettlement. As part of his travel ban, President Trump capped the number of refugees to be admitted in 2017 at 50,000, the lowest number in decades. Now the administration has proposed lowering the goal even further, to 45,000, next year.

headline: Trump’s Deadly Narcissism
abstract: The president strokes his ego while Americans suffer and die.
lead_paragraph: According to a new Quinnipiac poll, a majority of Americans believe that Donald Trump is unfit to be president. That’s pretty remarkable. But you have to wonder how much higher the number would be if people really knew what’s going on.

headline: Are There Books That Should Be Banned From Your School Library?
abstract: What do you think of the books on the American Library Association’s most-challenged list?
lead_paragraph: Do you think there are books that you and your friends are not mature enough to read?

headline: Fear of Volcano Eruption on Bali Drives 145,000 From Homes
abstract: Mount Agung, which killed hundreds on the Indonesian island in the 1960s, has shown signs it will explode again soon. But no one can say exactly when.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — About 145,000 people on the Indonesian island of Bali have left their homes around Mount Agung, a volcano that is showing signs it could erupt, officials said on Friday.

headline: Behind the Cover: 10.01.17
abstract: For this issue, a look at life after an insanity acquittal.
lead_paragraph: Gail Bichler, design director: “This week’s cover story looks at what happens when someone is found ‘not guilty by reason of insanity.’ The mentally ill who are acquitted of a crime may spend more time involuntarily confined than those convicted. Hugo Alonso’s image of the closed door to a psychiatric ward evokes the weight of realizing you may walk through the hospital doors and never come out.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Geoffrey C. Ward, Viet Thanh Nguyen and Vanessa Grigoriadis respond to reviews.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Decluttering Your Mother’s Love
abstract: When it comes to converting to minimalism, parents just don’t understand.
lead_paragraph: Kristen writes: I have recently embarked on a journey toward minimalism. As part of my new way of life, I asked my mother to stop buying me birthday gifts, holiday gifts or anything else. I would also like to stop buying her as many gifts. I would prefer to give and receive experiences (e.g., a mani-pedi). She is very unhappy and says I’m ruining everything.

headline: Helping the Rohingya
abstract: A partial list of aid groups working to ease the humanitarian crisis in Myanmar and Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the organizations responding to the Rohingya refugee crisis. Some are trying to gain access to restricted areas of the western state of Rakhine in Myanmar, where many ethnic Rohingya Muslims remain. Most of the aid has been focused on camps in Bangladesh where hundreds of thousands have fled over the past month.

headline: Man of ‘Gotham’ Returns
abstract: “Gotham” — a 1,400-page radical history of New York — was an unlikely hit. Now, 20 years later, Mike Wallace has finished Volume II. And he’s still not done.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, an unlikely tome by two academics became the most popular narrative of New York. The 4.7-pound, 1,424-page doorstop that focused on the city’s first three centuries won the Pulitzer Prize and was instantly hailed as a definitive history.

headline: The Transcontinental Life of an 18th-Century Woman of Letters
abstract: Based on volumes of Lady Anne Barnard’s private and published writing, “Defiance,” by Stephen Taylor, reveals the inner world of a quiet revolutionary.
lead_paragraph: DEFIANCEThe Extraordinary Life of Lady Anne BarnardBy Stephen Taylor388 pp. W.W. Norton. $28.95.

headline: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Visions for His Daughter
abstract: In “Autumn,” addressed to his unborn child, the Norwegian writer focuses on the household preoccupations of middle age, shorn of novelistic glamour.
lead_paragraph: AUTUMN By Karl Ove Knausgaard Translated by Ingvild Burkey Illustrated. 224 pp. Penguin Press. $27.

headline: A Writer’s Onward and Upward Path in 1980s New York
abstract: Vivian Gornick reviews Adam Gopnik’s memoir, “At the Strangers’ Gate,” which intertwines his early professional life with the city’s cultural history.
lead_paragraph: AT THE STRANGERS’ GATE Arrivals in New York By Adam Gopnik 253 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.

headline: An ‘Antigone’ for a Time of Terror
abstract: In Kamila Shamsie’s novel “Home Fire,” British Muslims contend with identity, terrorism and divided loyalties.
lead_paragraph: HOME FIRE By Kamila Shamsie 276 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.

headline: Gucci Mane’s Inspirational Guide to Self-Improvement (in Prison)
abstract: In “The Autobiography of Gucci Mane,” the Atlanta rapper details how exercise and books helped him improve himself behind bars.
lead_paragraph: RAP SHEET: The idea of “desert island books” always makes me smile. For one thing, has anyone outside of Robinson Crusoe and the cast of the S.S. Minnow ever spent significant time on an uncharted desert isle? But O.K., fine, let’s say it happened to me: Would I really tackle the complete works of Shakespeare (as I once proclaimed), or would I just refresh my Twitter feed and scroll through the latest intimations of doom until either my battery died or I did?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: The Latest and Greatest in Crime Fiction
abstract: New mysteries include Anne Perry’s “An Echo of Murder” and Attica Locke’s “Bluebird, Bluebird.”
lead_paragraph: To the East Texas natives in Attica Locke’s BLUEBIRD, BLUEBIRD (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26), Highway 59 is the lifeline that both links their towns and provides an escape route from them. Darren Mathews, a righteous Texas Ranger who comes from a deep-rooted family of black professional men, “men of stature and purpose,” knows every truck-stop hamlet from Laredo to Texarkana. But he is currently on suspension, and “without the badge, he was just a black man traveling the highway alone.”

headline: For Homeless Advocates, a Discouraging Lesson in Los Angeles: Money Is Not Enough
abstract: Last year, Los Angeles voted to spend $1.2 billion to build housing for the homeless. A battle over one small project shows how tough this will be.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Finding $1.2 billion to build housing for the homeless — as voters here did last year by overwhelmingly approving an increase in their own property taxes — may turn out to have been the easy part.

headline: The Story of Louisa Alcott’s Baby Sister, and Other Characters From Literature’s Sidelines
abstract: Three recent books revisit the works of literary forebears to revive characters and contexts from centuries past.
lead_paragraph: CAROLINE Little House, Revisited By Sarah Miller 384 pp. William Morrow. $25.99.

headline: Who’s Eating Jellyfish? Penguins, That’s Who
abstract: Researchers attached miniature video cameras to four penguin species and found that each was a jellyvore, even when other food was available.
lead_paragraph: There are not many jellyvores in the world, or so scientists have long thought.

headline: The 9.17 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: RT

headline: Preparing Your Home for a Disaster
abstract: The past few weeks of rolling natural disasters are a reminder to homeowners across the country to do what they can to prepare for the unknown.
lead_paragraph: Disaster, even one experienced through a television screen, has a way of sharpening the mind. And the recent cascade of hurricanes, forest fires and earthquakes has reminded many Americans, including those thousands of miles from danger, that there is no time like the present to think about all the things that could go wrong.

headline: After New Travel Warning, Questions About Safety in Mexico
abstract: Tourist areas like Cancún and Los Cabos have seen an increased police presence following shooting incidents. The United States issued an updated warning last month.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 22, the U.S. Department of State issued an updated travel warning on Mexico, advising caution in several popular beach destinations, including Cancún, the Riviera Maya and Los Cabos, for the first time.

headline: In Grim Camps, Rohingya Suffer on ‘Scale That We Couldn’t Imagine’
abstract: Half of Myanmar’s Rohingya Muslims are now packed into tarp huts in Bangladesh, and aid workers are just starting to reach some of the most desperate.
lead_paragraph: BALUKHALI, Bangladesh — Up to their ankles in mud, hundreds of Rohingya refugees fought to the front of the crowd outside of their makeshift camp. An open-bed truck full of Bangladeshi volunteers was passing by, tossing out donated goods at random: small bags of rice, a faded SpongeBob SquarePants T-shirt, a cluster of dirty forks.

headline: Hotels Rake in Record Fees, and Travelers Foot the Bill
abstract: These days you may be charged for even basic amenities, like storing luggage, parking, housekeeping or simply having a room with a safe.
lead_paragraph: The next time you look at your hotel bill, don’t be surprised if you see a fee for your in-room safe or a mandatory gratuity for the housekeeping staff.

headline: Taking a Walk Through the History of Opera
abstract: The Victoria and Albert Museum’s vast new exhibition seeks to sum up the art form’s long history — and plead for its future relevance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The soprano Danielle de Niese arrived at the Victoria and Albert Museum here on a recent afternoon for an early glimpse of the new exhibition “Opera: Passion, Power and Politics.”

headline: Poem: Last Photograph of My Mother Laughing
abstract: Selected by Terrance Hayes.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Terrance Hayes

headline: How to Eat Spicy Food
abstract: Practice a benign masochism. Keep a dairy product nearby.
lead_paragraph: “It’s helpful to think of spiciness as something other than painful,” says Pamela Dalton, an olfactory researcher at Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia. The burn of spicy food is not a taste; it’s a result of chemical compounds triggering an innate averse reaction in the central nervous system. At Monell, researchers use the word “mouthfeel” to describe that post-chile tongue-on-fire sensation.

headline: Visiting R.L. Stine: an Apartment Meant to Give You ‘Goosebumps’
abstract: R.L. Stine, the author of the “Goosebumps” children’s horror book series, takes us on a 360-degree tour of his apartment, where a skeleton, a three-foot-long cockroach and two ventriloquist dummies reside.
lead_paragraph: R.L. Stine, the author of the “Goosebumps” children’s horror book series, takes us on a 360-degree tour of his apartment, where a skeleton, a three-foot-long cockroach and two ventriloquist dummies reside.

headline: Trevor Noah Says the Republican Tax Plan Is ‘a Cash Cow for Trump’
abstract: On “The Daily Show,” Mr. Noah joked that President Trump could have become president just to lower his own taxes.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline: Why Retirements May Hold the Key in Whether Republicans Can Keep the House
abstract: Incumbency is a powerful edge for the G.O.P. right now, in addition to its advantages in gerrymandering and geography.
lead_paragraph: Democrats often lament that the House electoral playing field is stacked against them, but that’s not their only problem.

headline: Puerto Rico, Elon Musk, Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An Unorthodox Sunday Tradition
abstract: After discussing for years whether to take us kids to church or temple, my parents made the great outdoors our place of worship.
lead_paragraph: It was a Sunday when my boyfriend met my parents, so as the church bells in town chimed, we got in the car and drove — past the chapels of various denominations — and into the woods. On his first time hiking a trail that my family has trekked down too many times to count, mud got all over his green Vans sneakers.

headline: Is Microvascular Heart Disease a Serious Condition?
abstract: Microvascular heart disease affects about four times as many women as men, and the condition can be very serious.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have been diagnosed with microvascular heart disease, which I was told mostly affects women and is not considered “serious” in and of itself. How long can it exist before it turns into serious heart disease?

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Herpes, Flu Shots and Self-Control
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: They Have No Reservations (About Each Other)
abstract: When the chef Melissa Perello hired Robert Wright as general manager of her San Francisco restaurant, she didn’t expect he’d also be Mr. Right.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Perello, a renowned chef in San Francisco, was in search of a general manager to help run her restaurant, Frances, about five years ago. She found Robert Wright, with years of experience in the city’s fine-dining scene, to be the perfect candidate.

headline: Teaching With: ‘How Junk Food Is Transforming Brazil’
abstract: Why are Brazilians turning from traditional fresh food diets to ultra-processed food?
lead_paragraph: This short Times documentary, How Junk Food Is Transforming Brazil, shows how big business and a changing economy are driving Brazilians to eat ultraprocessed foods, even in small country villages.

headline: Listen to ‘The Daily’: When ‘Not Guilty’ is a Life Sentence
abstract: When defendants are found not guilty by reason of insanity, they could be confined to a psychiatric institution for life.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: ‘Star Wars’ on Stage
abstract: Friday: A local trip to a galaxy far, far away, your weekend lineup, and Raccoon Appreciation Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this flawless fall Friday.

headline: Elon Musk’s New Rocket Plan, Tax Overhaul Pushback: DealBook Briefing
abstract: The SpaceX founder insists that he can ferry cargo into space and fly people anywhere in the world in less than an hour, and make money doing it.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has finally explained how SpaceX could make money: through a rocket that can both deliver goods to space and fly people from New York to Shanghai in 39 minutes.

headline: What Happened to Police Accountability? The Mayor’s Not Saying
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio pledged to bring more openness to how police officers are disciplined, but, unable to get action in Albany, he has largely disappeared on the issue.
lead_paragraph: This past week Mayor Bill de Blasio conducted two excursions in downtown Manhattan, one of them to visit his junior-year dorm room at New York University and another to walk the High Line, a park he had famously ignored, with a group of third-graders. It was a good thing they didn’t come at him with a barrage of questions about congestion pricing and why it would take 10 years to close Rikers Island, because Mr. de Blasio did not appear to be in the mood for inquiry.

headline: Review: A Riveting Piano Recital in a Harlem Crypt
abstract: The adventurous pianist David Greilsammer weaves together music old and new in a 60-minute program titled “Labyrinth.”
lead_paragraph: Before playing an unusual — some would say radical — recital in an underground crypt in Harlem, the pianist David Greilsammer explained his thinking to the audience. “Labyrinth,” this 60-minute program, played without a break, was intended to evoke a state of mind common to us all: the feeling of being lost, disoriented, in search of a safe route.

headline: Jody Gerson of Universal Music Publishing Group on Trusting Teams
abstract: The chairman and chief executive of a music publisher says she learned she didn’t have to solve every problem, and to rely instead on her managers.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jody Gerson, chairman and chief executive of Universal Music Publishing Group, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Lasting Influence in Golf Descends From a Boxing Legend
abstract: Joe Louis Barrow Jr., a son of the boxing champion Joe Louis, will retire this year from the First Tee, a golf program for disadvantaged children that has grown exponentially under him.
lead_paragraph: Next week, the Detroit Red Wings will begin the N.H.L. season in new Little Caesars Arena. Joe Louis Arena, their longtime home, will sit idle nearby, awaiting demolition.

headline: How to Discourage a Well-Intentioned, but Pesky, Co-Worker
abstract: What to do when a co-worker is just trying to be nice – and it’s driving you crazy.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Volkswagen Issues Profit Warning Over Cost of Diesel Repairs
abstract: Technical problems have added to the astronomical cost of the carmaker’s emissions scandal, as it tries to cope with slipping market share in Europe.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen warned on Friday that its profit in the third quarter would be hit by unexpectedly high costs for repairing diesel cars in the United States equipped with emissions cheating software, part of its efforts to resolve the scandal.

headline: Indonesia Takes a Step Back From Reckoning With a Past Atrocity
abstract: The killing of hundreds of thousands of Indonesians was justified as a purge of communist enemies. Half a century later, anti-communist hysteria is seeing a resurgence.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The armed mob set out after nightfall, looking to break up — or worse — an illegal gathering of communist sympathizers in an upscale neighborhood of Jakarta, the Indonesian capital.

headline: Review: In ‘Clockwork Orange,’ the Future is Dark and Very Fit
abstract: This adaptation of Anthony Burgess’s word-drunk fantasy is notable less for its violent themes than for its often-shirtless cast.

headline: A Game to Help Students Pay the Right Price for College
abstract: Payback walks students through picking a college and paying for it, from choosing majors to finding work. Will it help them or scare them?
lead_paragraph: In the last big economic downturn, back when Tim Ranzetta was in the student loan analysis and consulting business and working with colleges, borrowers often found their way to him, too.

headline: Your Week in Culture: Katy Perry, Agnès Varda, the Guggenheim’s Chinese Art (Minus the Animals)
abstract: Also the week of Oct. 1: Dave Malloy returns downtown, and “The Gifted” debuts on Fox.
lead_paragraph: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts — it’s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Oct. 1, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:

headline: Now You See Him, Now You Don’t: Duchamp From Beyond the Grave
abstract: Is the face of the Dadaist a mirage? A model of Duchamp’s final artwork produces a “where’s Waldo,” eye-of-the-beholder game.
lead_paragraph: Asked whether he cared what his contemporaries thought of him, Marcel Duchamp once said, “I would rather wait for a public that will come fifty years – a hundred years – after my death.”

headline: When an Interviewee Runs Away
abstract: Afraid of retaliation, North Korean spies imprisoned in Ukraine did not want to talk to an American journalist. To get details, I turned to their cellmates.
lead_paragraph: Reporters seeking interviews in parts of the former Soviet Union quickly get used to the brushoff. But, in a combined 10 years of living and working in the region after the 1991 collapse of communism, I have never seen anyone respond to my request with the sheer terror displayed by Ryu Song-cho, a convicted North Korean spy now nearing the end of an eight-year jail term for espionage in the central Ukrainian town of Zhytomyr.

headline: Stampede at Mumbai Railway Station Kills at Least 22
abstract: Commuters were crushed at an overpass in the Indian city, and news reports showed some jumping from the narrow bridge and others hanging desperately from the railing.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Commuters stampeded on a narrow, crowded railway station overpass in India’s financial capital, Mumbai, during the morning rush hour on Friday, leaving at least 22 suffocated or crushed to death and 36 injured.

headline: Doom Is So Last Season
abstract: Hope is a good look at Rick Owens and Loewe; Balmain comes full circle.
lead_paragraph: Rick Owens may be the only designer who could get his front row — not to mention Courtney Love and Fergie — to wear garbage bags. Or, O.K.: ponchos that looked like garbage bags.

headline: Loewe: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Skin Care’s Backlash Against Essential Oils
abstract: Sometimes, the organic ingredients can also be the most irritating. Natural beauty experts are dedicated to providing safer alternatives.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, the San Francisco skin-care specialist Kristina Holey noticed a dramatic spike in patients all suffering from red, inflamed skin. Sensing a pattern, Holey — who studied cosmetic chemistry and plant science — delved into their beauty routines and found that many reactions could be traced back to one type of ingredient: essential oils. While these potent, highly active oils — found in an array of farm-to-bottle, natural lines — are often touted as being pure and beneficial for one’s complexion, Holey found the opposite to be true.

headline: California Today: Why Move Up the 2020 Presidential Primary?
abstract: Friday: A move to get off the primary sidelines; immigration agents arrested 498 people and a look at the Grove of Titans
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: How Savannah Guthrie, of the ‘Today’ Show, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The television host and children’s book author “sleeps in” until 6 a.m., enjoys a hearty breakfast, and then hits the town with her family.
lead_paragraph: A little more than five years ago, Savannah Guthrie became a host of the “Today” show on NBC. Since then, she has married, given birth twice, and most recently, co-written her first children’s book, “Princesses Wear Pants,” with Allison Oppenheim. During the week, Ms. Guthrie, 45, puts in nine-to-16-hour days on set. Having recently covered Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria, when she gets a free Sunday, she relishes it, spending time with her husband, Michael Feldman, 48, a consultant, their daughter, Vale, 3, and their son, Charley, 9 months. The family lives in TriBeCa.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Twitter’s Eventful Few Days
abstract: From the continuing saga of the Equifax hack to Twitter’s Russia links to Uber’s international travails, it was another busy week in tech.
lead_paragraph: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: This (Server) Space for Rent
abstract: If you’re being nagged about reaching your online storage limit, you can add on to your room in the cloud for as little as a dollar a month.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m getting warnings about my iCloud drive’s being full, and Apple wants to sell me more space. Are there other options that are easier and cheaper? I don’t need to back up my whole computer, just random stuff.

headline: Cost of Contact in Sports Is Estimated at Over 600,000 Injuries a Year
abstract: Yale researchers calculated that, if contact sports could be made noncontact, there would be 49,600 fewer injuries among male college athletes per year and 601,900 among those in high school.
lead_paragraph: It seems obvious that there would be more injuries, and more serious ones, among high school and college athletes in football or soccer or lacrosse than, say, in running or tennis. But, how many more, and at what economic cost?

headline: Estée Lauder Chairman Buys $23.5 Million Co-op
abstract: William P. Lauder, chairman of the Estée Lauder Companies, closed on a palatial apartment at the exclusive 998 Fifth Avenue co-op.
lead_paragraph: The imposing limestone apartment house at 998 Fifth Avenue has been home to some of the world’s most recognizable names since its opening in 1912 — from luminaries of the Gilded Age, like the Guggenheims and Vanderbilts, to modern-day billionaires, like the Ukrainian-born businessman Leonard Blavatnik.

headline: Danny Trevathan’s Hit Sends Packers’ Davante Adams to Hospital
abstract: Trevathan hit Adams helmet-to-helmet. Adams was removed on a stretcher and taken from the stadium in an ambulance.
lead_paragraph: Any intrigue in the Packers-Bears game on Thursday night around Chicago’s quarterback situation or national anthem protests was surpassed by a brutal hit by Bears linebacker Danny Trevathan on Packers wide receiver Davante Adams.

headline: Air Force General Addresses Racial Slurs on Campus: ‘You Should Be Outraged’
abstract: Show respect or “get out,” the head of the Air Force Academy told cadets after slurs were directed at black students.
lead_paragraph: The head of the Air Force Academy delivered a resounding message on Thursday in response to racial slurs that were found on the academy’s campus, saying that if students could not treat their peers of different races with respect, “then you need to get out.”

headline: What Scares R. L. Stine?
abstract: The bestselling children’s book author isn’t afraid of skeletons or cockroaches or even houseguests. But don’t ask him to play pool.
lead_paragraph: The bestselling children’s book author isn’t afraid of skeletons or cockroaches or even houseguests. But don’t ask him to play pool.

headline: What Frightens the ‘Goosebumps’ Writer R. L. Stine?
abstract: The author of the children’s horror book series isn’t afraid of skeletons or cockroaches or even houseguests. But don’t ask him to play pool.
lead_paragraph: R. L. Stine, the author of the best-selling children’s horror book series “Goosebumps” — 400 million copies and counting — is amazingly cheerful for a writer.

headline: Trump Plans Trip to Asia Amid North Korea Crisis
abstract: The White House announced that the president will travel to five nations in November: Japan, South Korea, China, Vietnam and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to travel to Asia in November for the longest overseas journey of his presidency to date as he seeks to build a common front against North Korea’s development of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, the White House announced on Friday.

headline: FandangoNow Bridges the Theatrical Experience and Streaming
abstract: Going to the movies with Fandango and getting the movies at home with FandangoNow.
lead_paragraph: There are a good number of big-name providers of streaming video-on-demand out there, including iTunes Google Play and Amazon Video, but I’ve had the most fruitful time with FandangoNow in part because the site, in tandem with its sister app, Fandango, provides a direct bridge between the theatrical and home experiences.

headline: Adam Scott Does Not Believe in Ghosts
abstract: The actor talks about playing a paranormal investigator in Fox’s “Ghosted,” his role in “Big Little Lies,” and what he and his co-star Craig Robinson really believe.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take Adam Scott long to see the comic potential in partnering with Craig Robinson on “Ghosted,” the new Fox series about a pair of reluctant paranormal investigators.

headline: Director Behind ‘American Masters’ Tries Something New With ‘Spielberg’
abstract: Susan Lacy, who pioneered the biographical documentary at PBS with “American Masters,’’ is rolling out a film about Steven Spielberg for HBO.
lead_paragraph: When you make a movie called “Spielberg,” and its subject agrees to sit for what turns out to be 30 hours of interviews — and his sisters sit down with you, as do his parents, and half the Hollywood mavericks including Francis Ford Coppola, Brian De Palma, George Lucas and Martin Scorsese — you’d better get it right. No one wants to be the director who screwed up the Steven Spielberg documentary.

headline: Illnesses at U.S. Embassy in Havana Prompt Evacuation of More Diplomats
abstract: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson repeated the American assertion that embassy personnel were deliberately targeted. But he did not blame Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It started as a medical mystery. It then was determined to have been the result of a mysterious attack. And on Friday, the illness that has affected 21 diplomats at the American Embassy in Havana, with symptoms including hearing loss and cognitive difficulties, threatened the future of Cuban-American relations.

headline: How Opera Inspired Walt Whitman’s ‘Leaves of Grass’
abstract: One of America’s greatest writers spent his formative years idolizing divas and listening to Italian operas.
lead_paragraph: Walt Whitman wasn’t always an opera fan. As a budding young journalist in New York, he was known to take potshots at the etiquette and artifice of what he saw as an aristocratic pastime. Whitman cultivated a more democratic persona and preferred popular songs, which he called “heart” — as opposed to “art” — music.

headline: Germaine Acogny on Choosing to Be the Chosen One
abstract: Ms. Acogny, a driving force in contemporary African dance, will be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in “Mon Élue Noire” (“My Black Chosen One”).
lead_paragraph: Germaine Acogny was first chosen some 40 years ago. She was then the director of Mudra Afrique, the most prestigious school of dance in her country, Senegal. One day, Maurice Béjart, the prominent French choreographer who had founded the school, announced that he wanted her African students to perform his erotic version of Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring.” And who would play the woman selected for the climactic mating ritual? “You will be my black chosen one,” Béjart told her.

headline: In Tillerson’s China Stop, Questions on North Korea but Slim Chance of Clarity
abstract: The secretary of state is to arrive in Beijing to discuss North Korea. Chinese officials are likely to see if he can clarify inconsistent statements made by U.S. officials.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson is scheduled to arrive in Beijing early Saturday for a brief visit, amid confusing signals about President Trump’s position on two questions looming over the confrontation with North Korea: Is America’s long-term goal to overthrow its leader, Kim Jong-un, or just try to change his behavior? And what would it take to get negotiations with Pyongyang started?

headline: Nina Ricci: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Catalans, Elated but Fearful, Brace for Independence Vote
abstract: Spain has ordered security forces to stop Sunday’s referendum, but many Catalans plan to defy them, after “waiting for this moment for 300 years.”
lead_paragraph: TERRASSA, Spain — Jordi Juanico Sabaté, a 6-foot-8 giant of a man, folded himself into a cafe chair in this Catalan city and fixed his eyes at a point on the horizon.

headline: The Secret to Atlanta's Growth? Just Look Up
abstract: Atlanta is home to the world’s busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where it’s going and how it took to the skies.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta is home to the world’s busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where it’s going and how it took to the skies.

headline: As Kurdish Borders Close, War of Words Heats Up
abstract: Kurds insist on independence talks, and warn of retaliation as Iraq increases its crackdown, shutting off flights and closing borders.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — The president of Iraq’s Kurdish region warned on Friday that the Kurds might be forced to retaliate if the central government persists with what his spokesman called a “very aggressive” stance toward the pro-independence referendum.

headline: Why an Airport Can Affect Your Mood
abstract: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.
lead_paragraph: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.

headline: Despite Challenges, Holding Down a Job at McDonald’s
abstract: He had a brain injury when he was 8 but has come a long way. He works happily, walks to his job by himself and lives in an apartment with a co-worker.
lead_paragraph: Peter Barrett, 47, is a crew member at a McDonald's in Lynn, Mass.

headline: Advice to College Students on Bank Promotions: Read the Fine Print
abstract: Many colleges have agreements with banks to offer accounts to students. Experts urge students to check the fees and compare their banking options.
lead_paragraph: Students settling into college life for the first time also may be new to managing their finances on their own. So it’s important to compare banking options on campus to minimize hassles as well as costly fees.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: After a long week, there’s nothing better than a roast chicken with carrots, a simple salad and fresh bread.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘A Little Bit Like Fun,’ by Sparks
abstract: A sad question, repeated a saddening number of times.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, the brothers Ron and Russell Mael, recording as Sparks, have crafted songs that scan almost like light verse. None of the impressionistic muddle of rock lyrics for them; their subjects, scenarios and verbal conceits are as clear and legible as limericks.

headline: New Skirmish in an Old Battle: Wall Street vs. the Customer
abstract: Investors in Europe will soon enjoy a fairer market under new rules. American investors won’t, if regulators side with big brokerage firms.
lead_paragraph: A corrosive custom forced on investors is finally getting the ax under new regulations in Europe. Too bad some on Wall Street are working overtime to ensure that United States investors don’t get the same deal.

headline: The Secret to Atlanta's Growth? Just Look Up
abstract: Atlanta is home to the world’s busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where it’s going and how it took to the skies.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta is home to the world’s busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where it’s going and how it took to the skies.

headline: Why an Airport Can Affect Your Mood
abstract: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.
lead_paragraph: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport is the busiest airport in the world. Every day, there are more than 2,500 arrivals and departures, carrying 275,000 passengers to destinations around the globe. The scale is vast and technically complex, but airlines know their core objective: to get passengers safely from point A to B as quickly and comfortably as possible. And Atlanta’s is just a tiny fraction of the massive global network that is modern aviation.

headline: Why Public Health Insurance Could Help, Even if You Don’t Want It
abstract: A public option could put competitive pressure on private health insurers. Markets in India and Mexico show how that might work in the United States.
lead_paragraph: It is anyone’s guess whether Democrats will unite around the goal of creating a single-payer health care system or even take a less ambitious approach — introducing a public health insurance option.

headline: San Juan Mayor on Hurricane Response: ‘This Is Not a Good News Story’
abstract: Carmen Yulín Cruz, the mayor, had a blistering response to comments by an administration official about the situation in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: A White House official’s praise of the government response to Hurricane Maria drew a sharp rebuke from the mayor of San Juan, as Puerto Ricans grew desperate in the aftermath of the storm, struggling to obtain basic life-sustaining supplies.

headline: North Korean Figure Skaters Qualify for Olympics, Possibly Easing Tensions
abstract: Two figure skaters at a competition in Germany earned places for the Games in South Korea, calming fears North Korea might interrupt the event.
lead_paragraph: OBERSTDORF, Germany — The North Korean coach stood just off the ice and exhorted her figure skaters: “Keep going! Keep going!”

headline: A Teacher Vanishes Again. This Time, in the Virgin Islands.
abstract: Nine years ago, Hannah Upp disappeared in New York and was found weeks later in a fugue state. Now she is missing in the hurricane-devastated Virgin Islands.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 14, one week after Hurricane Irma swept through the Caribbean, a 32-year-old teacher named Hannah Upp left her apartment on St. Thomas, in the Virgin Islands, to go for a morning swim at a nearby beach. According to a note she left for her friends, she then planned to go to the Virgin Islands Montessori School, where she worked as a teacher. It seemed as if she’d be home before the curfew the government had imposed in the wake of the storm.

headline: Two Confessions and Claims of Misconduct in Murder Case
abstract: The Staten Island district attorney convicted a man of murder 23 years ago. A lawyer who has investigated the case for five years says he wasn’t the killer.
lead_paragraph: In the rainy early morning of July 4, 1992, two armed men pushed their way into a drug stash house in a third-floor apartment of a Staten Island housing project, not far from the ferry terminal. It was a robbery: hardly the first in the crime-ridden neighborhood of New Brighton in those crime-ridden times.

headline: A Child’s Death Brings ‘Trauma That Doesn’t Go Away’
abstract: Even more than other parents, the elderly struggle to recover from the death of a child.
lead_paragraph: Anne McBrearty Giotta doesn’t remember much of what happened on that August morning in 2013.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in October
abstract: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here’s what we like for October.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site.

headline: What It’s Like to Hear the Same Piece of Music for 19 Hours
abstract: Our reporter was left agitated, delirious and maybe even enlightened by a marathon performance of Satie’s “Vexations” at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: The hallucinations began around 4 a.m. — nine hours and not even halfway through Erik Satie’s “Vexations,” the devilishly beguiling piece that, depending on whom you ask, is either a step toward Zen enlightenment or the longest joke in music history.

headline: Jamaica Puts a Different Face on the Runways
abstract: Ten years ago, a Jamaican modeling industry barely existed. Then fashion got the diversity memo, and now island talent is blossoming everywhere.
lead_paragraph: PORT ANTONIO, Jamaica — His machete blade a blur, Tevin Steele whacks the top off a fresh green coconut. Deftly knifing a window through the tender pith, he inserts a straw and hands the fruit across the counter at Dinga-Fling, his roadside stall outside this drowsy coastal town. Selling coconuts is his livelihood, and Mr. Steele, 21, says it is a good one, though neither as promising, lucrative or downright implausible as his other.

headline: Ch-ch-ch-ch-changes (In Column Days)
abstract: One small step for a columnist, one, er, small step for mankind.
lead_paragraph: For issue portfolio reasons, my column in the physical paper will move from Monday-Friday to Tuesday-Friday, effective immediately. Which means that I have Sundays again! I don’t expect any changes in content, although more chance to respond to start-of-the-week disasters news.

headline: Kurds Voted for Independence. Here’s Who Else Has a Say.
abstract: After years of autonomy in Iraq, Kurds overwhelmingly supported a referendum on independence, creating another destabilizing crisis in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Several million Kurds in Iraq have taken a symbolic step toward achieving a dream deferred since the end of World War I: establishing a homeland of their own.

headline: ‘Othello’: Shakespeare’s Tragedy Was Orson Welles’s Triumph
abstract: The director pieced together his masterpiece “Othello” over several years and continents, and then revisited it two decades later in a documentary about its making.
lead_paragraph: Something odder than a masterpiece, Orson Welles’s “Othello” is at once a credible abridgment of Shakespeare and a jigsaw puzzle that nearly defies comprehension.

headline: Recent Romances
abstract: Robert Gottlieb talks about new romance novels, and Celeste Ng discusses her new novel, “Little Fires Everywhere.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates and the Making of a Public Intellectual
abstract: “Between the World and Me,” Coates’s treatise on black male life in America, catapulted him to prominence. Coates spoke to The Times about his new book, “We Were Eight Years in Power,” his year in Paris and what he’s up to next.
lead_paragraph: When Ta-Nehisi Coates’s first book, “The Beautiful Struggle,” was published in 2008, it landed with barely a ripple. At the time, Mr. Coates was a struggling writer. He had lost three jobs, and he and his family relied on unemployment checks, his wife’s income and occasional support from his father to stay afloat. By the time the book came out in paperback, his fortune had shifted slightly; he’d become a regular contributor to The Atlantic magazine, writing a blog that attracted a moderate but engaged audience.

headline: Restoring Those Old Liner Notes in Music’s Digital Era
abstract: TunesMap, which offers a feed of videos, photographs and links to related material when songs are streamed, will make its debut as an Apple TV app in November.
lead_paragraph: Two decades into the era of online music, streaming has been hailed as the industry’s savior, but a complaint from the earliest days of digital services persists: What happened to the liner notes?

headline: Unpopular Delusions and the Madness of Elites
abstract: What keeps the tax-cut zombie alive?
lead_paragraph: Who rules the American right? I fairly often find myself talking with people who see either the nation as a whole or at least the right side of the political spectrum as a pure oligarchy, where the big money controls everything. And money definitely plays an outsized and generally malign role in policy. Usually, however, it’s only the root of some evil, not all evil: the vileness of a Roy Moore or Joe Arpaio comes from very different sources,

headline: Canada Letter: The Land Where Trade Talks Make Headlines
abstract: Our weekly look for and about Canadians reviews the latest trade tussle between Canada and the United States and previews a Broadway show with Canadian input.
lead_paragraph: This week the roadshow to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement made its way to Ottawa. Although the city was suffering through an exceptional September heat wave, the Canadian government offered school buses that lacked air conditioning to shuttle government officials and reporters to and from the site hosting the talks.

headline: Hugh Hefner Was My Enemy
abstract: I was fighting for women’s liberation. The Playboy creator only pretended to.
lead_paragraph: On March 26, 1970, I accepted an invitation to appear on “The Dick Cavett Show” to talk about a new movement I was involved with called Women’s Liberation. I knew that our young movement was suspicious of activists who sought media attention, so I roped my friend Sally Kempton, a talented writer, into coming with me. I don’t recall if we knew ahead of time who the principal guest that evening would be. He turned out to be Hugh Hefner.

headline: An Internet-Famous Cookie Worthy of Baking in Real Life
abstract: A chocolate chip cookie, thin with crisp ripples that run to the edges, finds Instagram fame.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, an aberrant chocolate chip cookie turned up in my Instagram feed. As wide as a salad plate and flat as a flounder, it appeared thin, but it was somehow layered with slabs of chocolate. Oddest of all, it was ringed, like a tree trunk — as if a chunk of chocolate had been dropped in the center and somehow made waves out to the edges. I assumed it was a mutant, posted by a troubled baker as a cry for help, and I kept scrolling.

headline: Trump Pitches Tax Cuts as ‘Rocket Fuel’ for the Economy
abstract: Speaking to the National Association of Manufacturers, the president said that under his leadership “the era of economic surrender is over.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump took his push for deep tax cuts to a supportive audience of manufacturers on Friday, arguing that reducing levies on businesses will be “rocket fuel” to propel economic growth and ultimately translate to more jobs and better wages for American workers, as well.

headline: Arming China’s Terracotta Warriors — With Your Phone
abstract: At an exhibit at the Franklin Institute, visitors will be able to use an app on their phones to see digital images of spears and arrows for the statues.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Imagine pointing your phone at China’s ancient terracotta warriors to arm them with spears and bows, weapons that disintegrated long ago.

headline: ‘Wisdom of the Crowd’ is the Latest in the ‘Yay, Rich Jerks’ Genre
abstract: The new CBS show is the latest drama to suggest the answer to the world’s problems are wealthy and off-putting tech titans who have suddenly decided to care.
lead_paragraph: If you follow the tech business, you may have heard the formulation, “It’s Uber, but for ...” The idea is that there’s no human endeavor that can’t be transformed by a little coding, as Uber did for taxis. Uber, but for pizza. Uber, but for classical music. Uber, but for marijuana.

headline: Undercover: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Senate Unveils Budget Blueprint Allowing $1.5 Trillion in Tax Cuts
abstract: The release of the Senate’s budget resolution is a critical step toward passing a tax overhaul that is protected from a Democratic filibuster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate Budget Committee unveiled a 2018 budget blueprint on Friday that would open the door for a $1.5 trillion tax cut, even as an independent analysis concluded that the plan as offered would far exceed that price tag and overwhelmingly benefit corporations and the rich.

headline: Live Event: The Evolution of Women’s Fashion in Washington
abstract: Join us on Thursday, Oct. 19, for a discussion with Betsy Fisher, Theresa Watts, Hilton Hollis and Helene Cooper.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests. Times Insider offers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: The Playlist: Hear Beyoncé Join ‘Mi Gente,’ Plus 9 More New Songs
abstract: Listen to the songs that caught our critics' attention this week, from a track Chance the Rapper debuted on "Colbert" to the finale of Torres' new album.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Chance the Rapper debuts a song on “Colbert,” Torres ends her new album with transcendence and Yeah Yeah Yeahs dig up a track from the “Fever to Tell” era.

headline: New Book About Woody Allen Alleges Abusive Parenting by Mia Farrow
abstract: In the book, Moses Farrow asserts that Ms. Farrow coached her daughter, Dylan Farrow, in accusing Mr. Allen of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: A new book about Woody Allen’s film career includes allegations that Mia Farrow, his former partner, was abusive toward their children and coached their daughter, Dylan, to accuse Mr. Allen of sexual abuse. An excerpt from the book, which will be published Tuesday, was provided by its publisher, Knopf.

headline: New York’s Response to Puerto Rico Devastation: ‘It’s Personal for Us’
abstract: An outpouring of relief efforts in New York after Hurricane Maria reflects a bond to the island that has stretched over decades.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Torres had no hope of boarding a flight out of Puerto Rico, or even talking to an airline employee in person. Still, he returned to the airport in San Juan, as sweltering and packed as it was: The terminal there was one of the few places his cellphone could pick up a signal, connecting him to the life he needed to get back to in New York City.

headline: Trump and the Racial Pay Gap
abstract: Lawyers say those most affected by pay bias deserve to know why the Trump administration is siding with companies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Marriott Won’t Cancel Event by Group Criticized as Anti-Muslim
abstract: The president and chief executive of Marriott defended the decision, saying that the hotel should not decide whose views are acceptable.
lead_paragraph: ACT for America, a group that the Southern Poverty Law Center says is anti-Muslim, and the Council on American-Islamic Relations, whose mission is to enhance the understanding of Islam, have at least one thing in common: they’re each holding an event at the same Marriott hotel in Arlington, Va., just a few weeks apart.

headline: North Korea Says U.N. Sanctions Are Causing ‘Colossal’ Damage
abstract: North Korea says it would be foolish for the United States to expect it to abandon its nuclear weapons, despite the harm of sanctions.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Friday that American-led international sanctions were causing “colossal” damage in the impoverished country, but added that it would be foolish for Washington to think the sanctions would stop the country’s nuclear weapons programs.

headline: Republican Tax Cut Would Benefit Wealthy and Corporations Most, Report Finds
abstract: The first detailed assessment of the tax plan found that the average tax bill would fall by $1,600, or 2.1 percent, in 2018. But the biggest drop would go to those with incomes above $730,000.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican tax plan promoted by President Trump this week as a middle-class tax cut would overwhelmingly benefit the wealthiest Americans and businesses, according to an analysis released on Friday by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center.

headline: Trump’s Insults for Foreign Leaders and Athletes
abstract: A reader turns to Alexis de Tocqueville for political wisdom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Atrocities in Myanmar
abstract: Members of the Steering Group of the International Panel of Parliamentarians for Freedom of Religion or Belief condemn the violence in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Free Speech on Campus
abstract: A civil rights lawyer writes that when colleges bar controversial speakers, free speech will be substantially eroded.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Weiner’s Sentencing, Abedin Opts for ‘Divorce Jeans’
abstract: During a dark period, the brightly flowered dungarees by Alice & Olivia say: “Let the sunshine in!” And such perky post-breakup makeovers are common.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night at Watchung Booksellers in Montclair, N.J., Hillary Rodham Clinton held a book signing for “What Happened,” her new book recounting the events leading up to the 2016 presidential election. But there was something competing for the attention of her eager fans: Huma Abedin’s dungarees.

headline: Trump’s Tax Proposal: Who Wins, Who Loses?
abstract: Readers discuss the proposed lowering of corporate tax rates and the elimination of most itemized deductions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Better Beet, Fresh From the Market
abstract: Canned beets just don’t compare to the sweet and earthy ones just pulled from the garden.
lead_paragraph: I know I’m not the only one who grew up on waterlogged canned beets, which definitely predisposes a person to dislike the vegetable. The vacuum-packed, shelf-stable cooked beets are not much better.

headline: Watch the Evolution of Cringe Comedy in 9 Clips
abstract: Here’s how a grimace-filled genre, exemplified by “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” grew into a television comedy staple.
lead_paragraph: Has a more significant television subgenre been born this century than cringe comedy?

headline: Did Leonardo da Vinci Sketch the ‘Nude Mona Lisa’?
abstract: A drawing at the Condé Museum, similar in composition to that of the Louvre’s painting, has long been attributed to the master’s studio.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Behind closed doors in the Louvre’s basements, experts have been scrutinizing a drawing for weeks with one question on their minds: Could this semi-naked, mysteriously smiling lady that looks strikingly like the Mona Lisa be a sketch by Leonardo da Vinci?

headline: Review: Why the New ‘Flatliners’ Is Just ‘Meh’
abstract: The original starred Julia Roberts, Kiefer Sutherland and Kevin Bacon, among others. The new one has Ellen Page and some horror movie tricks.
lead_paragraph: Remakes — especially of beloved classics — run the risk of alienating sentimental moviegoers. With “Flatliners,” Columbia Pictures takes a bold, innovative step to address this issue.

headline: Black Lives Matter Can’t Be Sued, Judge Tells Police Officer
abstract: A judge on Thursday dismissed a police officer’s lawsuit against Black Lives Matter, saying that he cannot sue a social movement.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Louisiana on Thursday said that Black Lives Matter is a social movement and therefore can’t be sued, dismissing a lawsuit brought by an anonymous police officer.

headline: New Black Boxes Will Be Easier to Track in Plane Crashes at Sea
abstract: Instead of going down with the plane, the recorders will be released and bob back to the surface. They will then send a signal to satellites.
lead_paragraph: Since the dawn of the jet age, flying has gotten significantly safer. In fact, you are thousands of times more likely to die while driving to the airport than you are flying in a plane.

headline: Rosetta’s Lost Picture From Moments Before It Struck a Comet
abstract: One year after the spacecraft dived into Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, it gave scientists a gift from beyond the grave.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after it crashed into a comet, the Rosetta spacecraft has given scientists a gift from beyond the grave: the final image of its resting place on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

headline: In the U.S., 110 Million S.T.D. Infections
abstract: Chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis are all on the rise, federal researchers found.
lead_paragraph: The incidence of chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis is increasing, according to a new report from the Centers for Disease  Control and Prevention. At any given time, there are an estimated 110 million sexually transmitted infections in the United States.

headline: Far-Right Gains Leave Germans Wondering, What Now?
abstract: Dismay, confusion, fear and a search for answers for Germans who did not vote for far-right AfD, but must come to terms with it shaping their future.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As the results of Germany’s election last Sunday flashed on her television screen in the western city of Cologne, Kirsten Schindler, watched with a mixture of confusion and dismay.

headline: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.

headline: Isabel Marant Wants to Dress You and Your Boyfriend
abstract: After the success of men’s clothes made for an H&M collaboration in 2013, the designer is adding men’s wear to her main collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ever since Isabel Marant backed into men’s wear in 2013, designing a few men’s piece for her H&M collaboration, her fans have been asking for more. “I’m inundated by guys asking me, ‘When are you going to do men’s?’” Ms. Marant said before her show in the Palais Royal on Thursday night.

headline: Zuckerberg’s Preposterous Defense of Facebook
abstract: If everyone is upset with you, as the platform’s chief says, are you really doing something right?
lead_paragraph: Responding to President Trump’s tweet this week that “Facebook was always anti-Trump,” Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, defended the company by noting that Mr. Trump’s opponents also criticize it — as having aided Mr. Trump. If everyone is upset with you, Mr. Zuckerberg suggested, you must be doing something right.

headline: Review: The Unstuffy Gala: City Ballet Delivers Youth and Style
abstract: Four premieres (and four sets of new couture costumes) showcased youthfulness and a liberal view of life and dance.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, New York City Ballet’s fall gala became an event for fashion onstage: an annual rendezvous in which new choreography joined new couture. Since 2014, the formula has been four creations, made by four different choreographers, each with a design team from the fashion world.

headline: High Schools Threaten to Punish Students Who Kneel During Anthem
abstract: Schools on Long Island and in Louisiana have cautioned students against protesting. And in public schools, such directives run up against students’ First Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: The controversy over kneeling in protest of racial injustice moved beyond the world of professional sports this week, when a number of schools told students they were expected to stand during the national anthem.

headline: Jared Kushner’s Entitlement Is New Jersey Born and Bred
abstract: There are many reasons he doesn’t think the rules apply. The Garden State is one of them.
lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner, first son-in-law and White House senior adviser, used a personal email account to communicate about government business, it was recently revealed. In his initial application for a security clearance, Mr. Kushner failed to list a single meeting with a foreign government official during the campaign and transition. (Amended forms now reportedly list over a hundred contacts.) He is also, according to official sources, a person of interest in the investigation into the Trump campaign’s dealings with Russia, although when he was recently hauled up to Capitol Hill to testify about a meeting he attended at Trump Tower in June 2016 with a Kremlin-linked lawyer who was promising dirt on Hillary Clinton, he insisted he was entirely blameless.

headline: Mad Virtuosity: The Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
abstract: Alternative versions of the national anthem, "Norma" and "West Side Story" were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of what’s moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

headline: The Elusive Giant Coconut-Cracking Rat of the Solomon Islands
abstract: A chance encounter with a falling tree let scientists finally confirm the existence of a legendary rodent species in the South Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Locals living on the island of Vangunu in the Solomon Islands sing songs about vika, a giant, tree-dwelling rat that can crack open coconuts with its teeth. But scientists had never seen it.

headline: A Collector’s Dream: Creating Your Own Museum as a Legacy
