abstract: Collectors who want their life’s work to live on after they die sometimes do this, but like many things, there is more to it than meets the eye.
lead_paragraph: Paintings, sculptures, gems, cars, items made perfectly by a single craftsman — if you have the collector’s gene, these are the kinds of things you must own. Add wealth to fuel that desire, and your collection is likely to grow. But then what do you do with it?

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Strikes Out 15 on an Unusual Day for the Yankees
abstract: The pitcher retired the first 14 batters he faced to keep the playoff-bound Yankees mathematically alive for the A.L. East title.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ 4-0 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Friday performed the function of keeping their faint American League East title hopes alive, at least for another day.

headline: New Trailer: ‘Annihilation’ Puts Natalie Portman in Danger
abstract: The creepy sci-fi drama, based on a best-selling novel, is from Alex Garland, the director of “Ex Machina.”
lead_paragraph: Alex Garland follows up his 2015 directorial debut, “Ex Machina,” with another creepy sci-fi drama featuring Oscar Isaac. Only in “Annihilation,” Mr. Isaac’s character vanishes early on, during a mission into an environmental danger zone, and his wife, played by Natalie Portman, leads an expedition to save him.

headline: The Activist Judge Conservatives Love
abstract: Conservatives who hate judicial activism should be alarmed by Roy Moore, the Republican Senate nominee in Alabama. But many love his kind of activism.
lead_paragraph: For some time now conservative Republicans have been screaming about activist judges who put their own political opinions above the law. And they’ve been right to complain. But now, thanks to socially conservative voters in Alabama, we learn that they didn’t really mean it. What bothered them weren’t activist judges in general — but liberal activist judges in particular. Conservative activism by a judge who gets his marching orders from the Bible is apparently fine.

headline: In Atlanta With Guo Pei, Who Spins Stories in Couture
abstract: The in-demand Chinese designer brings her fantastical high-fashion to the Peach State.
lead_paragraph: When the designer Guo Pei turned 100 days old, her family dressed her in a special outfit made from one of her grandmother’s old silk qipaos in accordance with Chinese tradition. Guo was born during the Cultural Revolution, when citizens were forced to give up all traces of finery and individuality. Girls didn’t wear dresses, clothing was devoid of color and silk was something that Guo rarely saw in her younger years. Her baby outfit was the first beautiful garment that she remembers.

headline: Study Finds More Diversity Among First-Time TV Directors
abstract: The Directors Guild of America says that the pool of new directors is growing more diverse, but some industry officials are not so sure.
lead_paragraph: The pool of first-time television directors has grown more diverse, according to a new industry report, but not everyone is convinced of the findings.

headline: Health Secretary Tom Price Resigns After Drawing Ire for Chartered Flights
abstract: The health and human services secretary stepped down soon after President Trump said that he was “not happy” about Mr. Price’s travel bills.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, resigned under pressure on Friday after racking up at least $400,000 in travel bills for chartered flights and undermining President Trump’s promise to drain the swamp of a corrupt and entitled capital.

headline: I Want My 2.3 Bonus Years
abstract: Where do 50-year-old men get the strange impression that they can date 23-year-olds?
lead_paragraph: If I could prolong my time as a young adult by, say, 2.3 years, here is a list of things I would like to do:

headline: National Anthem Protests, From ‘Jazzing the Banner’ to Taking a Knee
abstract: “The Star-Spangled Banner” has long been a site of dissent and disagreement. A conversation about the history of the anthem, and those who have protested it, on Popcast.
lead_paragraph: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

headline: Veterans Agency Seeks to Scrap Ethics Law on For-Profit Colleges
abstract: The department says the conflict-of-interest statute, passed after scandals in for-profit education, is outdated, but others call it a safeguard.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Veterans Affairs is pushing to suspend a 50-year-old ethics law that prevents employees from receiving money or owning a stake in for-profit colleges that pocket hundreds of millions of dollars in tuition paid through the G.I. Bill of Rights.

headline: New Trailer: Gary Oldman Takes on Churchill in ‘Darkest Hour’
abstract: The actor has set off Oscar talk with his portrayal of the British leader in the film due in November.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to playing Winston Churchill, actors will never, never, never give up. John Lithgow recently won an Emmy as the British bulldog in Netflix’s “The Crown,” and Brian Cox embodied the title role in this year’s biopic “Churchill.” Now Gary Oldman throws his homburg into the ring with “Darkest Hour,” and it’s already earning him best actor Oscar talk.

headline: Don’t Let Puerto Rico Fall Into an Economic Abyss
abstract: Decades of economic progress were undone in 12 hours by Hurricane Maria. Now the island needs substantial and sustained help.
lead_paragraph: Almost nothing on the planet, short of nuclear weaponry, destroys economic value as rapidly as a mega-hurricane. In Puerto Rico, decades of economic progress were undone in 12 hours by Hurricane Maria.

headline: The Latest Populist Craze in Britain: An Unabashed Elitist
abstract: In a country hungry for “authenticity,” activists have seized on the Tory lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg, whose upper-crust persona seems drawn from another era.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent afternoon, when the very tall, very thin British lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg rose from the bench where he had been reclining, his fellow members of Parliament perked up, confident that what followed would be amusing.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Great reads around the web, from Sheri Fink, Amanda Taub, Damien Cave and others.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: Azerbaijan Detains Dozens of Gay and Transgender People
abstract: Homosexuality was decriminalized in Azerbaijan in 2000, but discrimination and even violence remain.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — More than 50 gay and transgender people in Azerbaijan’s capital, Baku, were detained and abused in a series of raids over the past week, lawyers and rights activists said.

headline: The Perils of Peanut Butter
abstract: How clean does a jar for your sandwich spread need to be for recycling efforts?
lead_paragraph: Q. In trying to recycle responsibly, is it worth the hot water needed to clean a jar of peanut butter, or should it not be recycled?

headline: In Puerto Rico, Loved Ones Send Video Messages: ‘We Are Alive’
abstract: In Utuado, one of the hardest hit towns in Puerto Rico, locals sent video messages to relatives abroad. The community has been without phone or internet connections since Hurricane Maria hit the island.
lead_paragraph: In Utuado, one of the hardest hit towns in Puerto Rico, locals sent video messages to relatives abroad. The community has been without phone or internet connections since Hurricane Maria hit the island.

headline: Transit Workers Tasked With Improving Subway Name a New Leader
abstract: The powerful New York chapter of the Transport Workers Union named a lifelong track worker to replace John Samuelsen, who will lead the national union.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of nearly four decades, Tony Utano has seen the New York City subway system at its worst and best and worst again.

headline: Threatened by Madrid, Catalonia Referendum Is Game of Cat and Mouse
abstract: Far from the orderly vote that separatists wanted to stage, it has turned into a covert operation to avoid a Madrid-ordered shutdown.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Catalonia’s independence referendum is no longer about whether Catalans want statehood but whether they will be able to vote on Sunday at all.

headline: What the State Department Warning on Cuba Means for Travelers
abstract: The Trump administration has again imposed new restrictions on going to Cuba. Here’s what it means for travelers.
lead_paragraph: [UPDATED NOV. 8, 2017]

headline: Tom Price Resigns Under Pressure
abstract: Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, resigned on Friday. Mr. Price drew criticism for his use of expensive chartered flights, which undermined President Trump’s promise to “drain the swamp” of an entitled capital.
lead_paragraph: Tom Price, the health and human services secretary, resigned on Friday. Mr. Price drew criticism for his use of expensive chartered flights, which undermined President Trump’s promise to “drain the swamp” of an entitled capital.

headline: Lady Lucan, Last Witness to a Murder Most Lurid, Dies at 80
abstract: Lord Lucan, the first peer indicted in a killing since 1760, disappeared after the 1974 slaying of his children’s nanny. Did he mistake her for his wife?
lead_paragraph: In November 1974, John Bingham, the seventh Earl of Lucan, a dashing but dissolute gambler, supposedly mistook his children’s nanny for his estranged wife in the dimly lit basement of their London home and bludgeoned her to death. Then he vanished, never to be seen again.

headline: ‘Another Fantastic Week’: Tom Price’s Celebratory Travelogues
abstract: The health and human services secretary sent dispatches from his globe-trotting to agency staff members, including many who faced budget-related travel restrictions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he traversed the world on taxpayer-funded flights, Tom Price made it a habit to write home, repeatedly sending celebratory letters back to staff members at the Department of Health and Human Services detailing his time on the road, and complimenting agency employees who “ensure the good stewardship of taxpayer dollars.”

headline: Kabul Reels After Attack on Another Shiite Mosque
abstract: Suicide bombers posing as shepherds killed six, including an attacker, and wounded at least 20 people ahead of an annual religious commemoration.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Militants disguised as shepherds who were tending a flock of sheep attacked a Shiite mosque in Kabul on Friday as worshipers were leaving, killing five people and wounding at least 20 others, officials said.

headline: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
abstract: Reinventing Givenchy, a city guide to Paris — and much more.
lead_paragraph: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Read the Resignation Letter Tom Price Sent to President Trump
abstract: Tom Price sent a letter on Friday to President Trump resigning as health secretary. Mr. Price had been under pressure after racking up at least $400,000 in travel bills, footed by the taxpayers, for chartered flights.
lead_paragraph: Tom Price sent a letter on Friday to President Trump resigning as health secretary. Mr. Price had been under pressure after racking up at least $400,000 in travel bills, footed by the taxpayers, for chartered flights.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Jeff Flake, in Feud with Trump, Now Faces Challenge from the Left
abstract: Representative Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat, has announced she will seek the Senate seat held by Jeff Flake of Arizona, who was already facing a primary challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Jeff Flake, the Arizona Republican whose public feud with President Trump had already fueled a primary challenge from the right, now has reason to worry about his left flank: Representative Kyrsten Sinema, a centrist Democrat with a powerful biography, announced she will seek Mr. Flake’s Senate seat in 2018.

headline: In Ad, Malliotakis Takes Swing at de Blasio Over Subway Woes
abstract: Nicole Malliotakis, the Republican mayoral candidate, released a “Subway Nightmare” ad that links Mayor Bill de Blasio to a deterioration in train service.
lead_paragraph: The Republican candidate for mayor in New York, Nicole Malliotakis, an assemblywoman from Staten Island, is struggling to get the attention of voters in a heavily Democratic city, with a little more than five weeks before the Nov. 7 election. Ms. Malliotakis just received a payment of $1.5 million in public matching funds from the Campaign Finance Board, giving her campaign a needed boost and making a large advertising purchase possible.

headline: Herbert Kalmbach, Who Figured in Watergate Payoffs, Dies at 95
abstract: Nixon’s personal lawyer was the conduit for hush money to the defendants who bungled the break-in. He pleaded guilty in an illegal fund-raising scheme and served time in jail.
lead_paragraph: Herbert W. Kalmbach, Richard M. Nixon’s personal lawyer and a conduit for hush money from the 1972 presidential campaign to the Watergate burglars, died on Sept. 15 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Digital Currencies Are Growing on Faltering Foundations
abstract: Bitcoin, Ether and their rivals are gaining popularity. But the exchanges where they trade have serious weaknesses that need to be fixed.
lead_paragraph: One of the chief strengths of digital currencies is becoming their weakness.

headline: Where Students Were Stabbed, a School on a Downward Slide
abstract: The Wildlife Conservation school had three principals over five years and the confidence of teachers and students had plummeted amid reports of bullying.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, on annual school surveys, 94 percent of teachers at the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation in the Bronx said they would recommend the school to parents, and 80 percent of students said they felt safe in the halls.

headline: Tom Price’s Travels Around the Globe
abstract: Here are several of the "Week in Review" updates that Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, sent out to staff at the agency, prior to his resignation. The updates frequently detailed his trips around the United States and the world.
lead_paragraph: Here are several of the "Week in Review" updates that Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, sent out to staff at the agency, prior to his resignation. The updates frequently detailed his trips around the United States and the world.

headline: Tom Price, Rohingya People, Elon Musk: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In a Compromise, U.N. Rights Experts Will Examine Abuses in Yemen’s War
abstract: A decision by the Human Rights Council spared Saudi Arabia from the embarrassment of a formal panel of inquiry like the one investigating Syria’s war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In a surprise compromise, the top United Nations human rights body decided on Friday to establish an international team of experts to examine abuses in the Yemen war and seek to identify those responsible.

headline: Reggie Lavong, Smooth-Voiced D.J., Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lavong helped bring rhythm and blues to New York radio listeners in the 1960s and promoted the genre as a vice president of Capitol Records.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Lavong, a velvet-voiced radio personality who played rhythm and blues and more in the 1960s on WWRL-AM in New York, died on Sept. 19 in Philadelphia. He was 84.

headline: U.S. Says A.I.G. Is No Longer ‘Too Big to Fail’ 9 Years After Bailout
abstract: Federal regulators voted Friday to no longer classify American International Group as “systemically important,” meaning it will face less oversight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of federal regulators voted Friday to no longer classify the American International Group as “too big to fail,” freeing the giant insurer from years of tough government oversight.

headline: Complaint Against CUNY Lecturer
abstract: A biology instructor at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn is accused of setting up an unauthorized side teaching business that offered students fraudulent certificates in the health care field.
lead_paragraph: A biology instructor at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn is accused of setting up an unauthorized side teaching business that offered students fraudulent certificates in the health care field.

headline: Do Americans Want Everything Vegan?
abstract: Learning to cook for different tastebuds.
lead_paragraph: Learning to cook for different tastebuds.

headline: Haki Madhubuti, the Book Publisher on the South Side
abstract: Third World Press, a beloved cultural institution in Chicago, is turning 50.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In 1956, when Haki R. Madhubuti was 14 years old and living in Detroit, his mother gave him a firm order: Go down to the public library and check out “Black Boy” by Richard Wright, the seminal memoir on growing up African-American in the segregated South.

headline: Hemingway’s First Short Story Found in Key West
abstract: The untitled, previously unknown work was written by the famous author when he was 10 years old.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Irma smashed into Key West, Fla., author Shel Silverstein’s historic home was nearly leveled. But it was another home in his neighborhood that had Brewster Chamberlin, a writer and historian, worried.

headline: With Widespread Power Failures, Puerto Rico Is Cash Only
abstract: With power failures and communications outages still widespread nine days after Hurricane Maria, much of Puerto Rico has become a cash-only island.
lead_paragraph: FAJARDO, P.R. — Juan Jimenez squinted into the dark lobby of his bank early Friday, thinking about the paycheck sitting in his account, just behind the locked doors. If only he could get to it.

headline: CUNY Lecturer Charged With Running Fake Health Certificate Program
abstract: A biology instructor at Medgar Evers College was accused of teaching unauthorized health care classes and selling fake certificates of completion.
lead_paragraph: A biology lecturer at the City University of New York was arrested Friday on fraud and corruption charges, federal and state investigators said, for teaching unauthorized health care classes and selling students fake certificates of completion.

headline: Cubans Alarmed at U.S. Embassy Withdrawals and Travel Warning
abstract: The actions, triggered by unexplained health problems among diplomats, dealt a harsh blow to the island’s plans for economic growth.
lead_paragraph: It was grim, unsettling news: the United States warned Americans on Friday not to travel to Cuba and ordered the withdrawal of more than half its diplomats in Havana.

headline: Texas Man Convicted of Helping Attack U.S. Army Base in Afghanistan
abstract: Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh was found guilty on charges of providing material aid to terrorists. He faces up to life in prison.
lead_paragraph: In January 2009, two trucks packed with explosives careened toward the front gate of a remote United States Army base in the Khost Province of Afghanistan. The first truck exploded near the gate, injuring a pregnant Afghan woman and several others. But the terrorist plot to kill American soldiers was foiled when the second truck crashed into the blast crater left by the initial explosion.

headline: ‘Botched Plastic Surgery’ Leads to Manslaughter Charge
abstract: Law enforcement officials have seen a surge in the number of back-alley clinics offering buttocks injections.
lead_paragraph: A Queens woman who the authorities say set up appointments for an unlicensed plastic surgery clinic in Manhattan was charged with manslaughter on Friday in the death of a woman who received silicone injections in her buttocks.

headline: At Presidents Cup, the International Team’s Best Pair Falters
abstract: The United States squad built an 8-2 lead after two days of competition, defeating even the previously unbeaten Louis Oosthuizen and Branden Grace.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Louis Oosthuizen had sung the song, and now Nick Price was asking him to live the lyrics.

headline: San Juan Mayor Rebukes Trump Administration for Rosy Comments on Relief Effort
abstract: “Damn it, this is not a good news story,” Mayor Carmen Yulín Cruz said. Later, President Trump said the operation was going “really well, considering.”
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — In the storm-battered neighborhood of Barriada Figueroa on Friday, neighbors greeted visitors with a now-familiar question, one that was inevitably followed by a disappointing answer: “Are you FEMA?”

headline: New Virtual Currencies Hit Barriers in U.S. and 2 Other Nations
abstract: The authorities in the United States, South Korea and Switzerland all took steps to cool down the market for so-called initial coin offerings.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Regulators in the United States, South Korea and Switzerland all took independent steps on Friday to crack down on so-called initial coin offerings, a hot but risky new method of raising money for start-ups.

headline: For Trump, a Different Kind of ‘Locker Room Talk’
abstract: Professional athletes are being driven crazy by the president, which makes them no different than half of America.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a nearly all-white suburb outside of Philadelphia, and no more than 10 percent of my classmates in school were African-American. They lived in a separate, all-black neighborhood of row homes called Bloomsdale. At our high school basketball games, the black students sat together in one corner of the gym. When the national anthem was played, most stayed seated on the wooden bleachers.

headline: As Mets Stagger to Finish Line, Collins Gets Splattered
abstract: The 2017 season has fallen apart in Queens, in large part because of too many injuries. But on Friday, Terry Collins found himself defending his managing.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In what is likely to be his final weekend as the manager of the Mets, Terry Collins had to deal on Friday with the agitation that often accompanies a disappointing season and, in this instance, made him the target.

headline: Under the House G.O.P. Plan, Tax Cuts Shrink Over Time for Everyone but the Richest
abstract: The major findings in a preliminary analysis of the House Republican tax plan.
lead_paragraph: The major findings in a preliminary analysis of the House Republican tax plan.

headline: Suspect in Tennessee Church Shooting Cited Revenge for Charleston Massacre
abstract: A note found in the gunman’s car made reference to retaliation for the nine church members killed by Dylann Roof in 2015, The Associated Press said.
lead_paragraph: The 25-year-old black man accused of a deadly shooting at a church near Nashville had a note in his car that made reference to revenge for the church massacre carried out by a white supremacist in Charleston, S.C., according to a report by The Associated Press.

headline: Amid Feud With Mayor, Texas Governor Gives $50 Million to Houston
abstract: Mayor Sylvester Turner and Gov. Greg Abbott put aside their dispute over Hurricane Harvey to announce an influx of $50 million to aid the city’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Democratic mayor of Texas’ largest city and the Republican governor have been publicly clashing over Hurricane Harvey for more than a month, at times turning one of the worst natural disasters to strike the state into a politically tinged feud.

headline: The ‘Hustler’ vs. the Feminist Champion: Inside the ‘Battle of the Sexes’
abstract: The hype leading up to the tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs on Sept. 20, 1973, was over the top. Here’s a look at the coverage.
lead_paragraph: Forty-four years ago this month, Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs faced off in what may be the most famous tennis match ever televised.

headline: What Not to Learn From Vietnam
abstract: As the Burns-Novick documentary wraps up, viewers need to avoid drawing simple conclusions.
lead_paragraph: As the dust settles on the 18-hour documentary “The Vietnam War,” it seems unlikely that the longstanding debates engendered by the conflict will abate much in the film’s aftermath. As is so often the case, most reviews, some written even before the first episode of Ken Burns and Lynn Novick’s epic aired, reveal more about the reviewer than the film itself. When it comes to the war in Vietnam, there are plenty of hobbyhorses to mount.

headline: America’s Cup Will Return to Monohulls in 2021
abstract: Boat designs and citizenship requirements are the focus of rules changes for the next edition of sailing’s biggest event, which will likely be in New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Trust has hardly been the byword for the America’s Cup. For far more than a century, sailing teams have been trying to conceal their cards and design breakthroughs and secure the sport’s most prestigious prize.

headline: Stamped Out
abstract: In the internet age, philately has lost its once-worldly charms.
lead_paragraph: Silver Spring, Md. — I got rid of my stamp collection the other day. It was no great loss from a monetary standpoint. The emotional loss, though, was enormous.

headline: Quotation of the Day: An Eerie Calm Before Catalans Vote on Liberty
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 30, 2017.
lead_paragraph: “All my life, I had the dream of dying in an independent country. It was a dream that used to seem very remote. But now it is very near.”

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 30, 2017.

headline: In Power Move at Uber, Travis Kalanick Appoints 2 to Board
abstract: Mr. Kalanick, the former Uber chief, who has been embroiled in a fight with other directors at the ride-hailing company, moved to assert his control over its board.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The divisions between Uber and its former chief executive, Travis Kalanick, are widening.

headline: Can the Supreme Court Fix American Politics?
abstract: The practice of partisan gerrymandering corrodes representative democracy. The justices need to stop it.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was right: America’s political system is rigged.

headline: The Strange Impotence of the Republican Party
abstract: Anger is an excellent emotion for pushing ratings and winning elections but terrible for governing.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you’re a Republican. Since you’re reading The Times, suppose hard.

headline: Crack Team’s Initials
abstract: Mary Lou Guizzo and Jeff Chen unite and conquer.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — How are you all doing? I’m taking the weekend over from Sam Ezersky so he can do a rave in augmented reality or machine learn or whatever the youth get up to these days.

headline: A Very Taxing President
abstract: The Trump team is rich, but they want to rewrite the tax code because they care only about you.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is willing to suffer, just for you.

headline: Google Prepares to Brief Congress on Its Role in Election
abstract: Following scrutiny of Facebook and Twitter, the search giant is examining if Russians used its services to meddle in last year’s election.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has become the latest Silicon Valley giant to become entangled in a widening investigation into how online social networks and technology products may have played a role in Russian interference in the 2016 election.

headline: A Polished Victorian Standout in a Sea of Island Inns
abstract: The Christopher’s Victorian roots are just the backdrop. Its owners have rehabbed the 15-room hotel in Edgartown to give it a sleeker, modern look.
lead_paragraph: From $179

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘S.N.L.’ and ‘Kingsman’
abstract: “Saturday Night Live” returns with two superstars. CBS’s “48 Hours” turns 30, and then turns to O.J.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” returns with two superstars. “48 Hours” turns 30, and then turns to O.J.

headline: 3-D Printing for Space Exploration
abstract: Branch Technology is developing a 3-D printing process that can build structures on Mars. Step into their Tennessee workspace in 360 degrees.
lead_paragraph: Branch Technology is developing a 3-D printing process that can build structures on Mars. Step into their Tennessee workspace in 360 degrees.

headline: Can Parents Leave a Co-op to a Grown Child? It Depends
abstract: The co-op board has the final say in whoever takes over the apartment and ultimately lives in it.
lead_paragraph: Q. My husband and I recently updated our will. We want to leave our apartment to our adult daughter. She grew up in the apartment, but now lives on her own. Our lawyer told us to check with the co-op board. To our surprise, it refused our request. What’s the point of having a will if I can’t leave our apartment to our child?

headline: Love Urban Architecture? There Are Maps for That
abstract: A series of two-sided maps from Blue Crow Media celebrates unsung buildings in cities like Berlin, Boston and Moscow. The latest: Concrete New York.
lead_paragraph: The most visibly arresting buildings are, paradoxically, sometimes the most overlooked in the modern cityscape.

headline: The World According to Dan Brown
abstract: A visit with Dan Brown, whose new novel — as with all of his works — doesn’t shy away from the big questions, but rushes pell-mell into them. In “Origin,” the question is: Can science make religion obsolete?
lead_paragraph: RYE BEACH, N.H. — Anyone who has read Dan Brown’s work — and with 200 million copies of his books in print, you know who you are — is familiar with his signature technique of inserting little chunks of expository information into the narrative. Among the topics addressed in his latest thriller, “Origin”: the wide-ranging talents of Winston Churchill, the elusive appeal of abstract art, the exciting peculiarities of Gaudi’s Sagrada Familia cathedral and the latest insane developments in the world of artificial intelligence.

headline: 'A Monumental Moment for Women’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discussed N.F.L. players protesting police brutality, women driving in Saudi Arabia and private moments with Playboy.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: What’s Up in Coal Country: Alternative-Energy Jobs
abstract: Miners may have just the skills for scaling wind towers and putting solar panels on roofs. And that’s no small thing in Wyoming and West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: From the mountain hollows of Appalachia to the vast open plains of Wyoming, the coal industry long offered the promise of a six-figure income without a four-year college degree, transforming sleepy farm towns into thriving commercial centers.

headline: ‘Faux’ Male Feminists Draw Ire in Hollywood
abstract: A scathing essay by Joss Whedon’s ex-wife is the latest example of a male feminist being called a fake.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough time to be a male feminist, especially in Hollywood.

headline: Production of a Lifetime: Whitney Houston and Clive Davis
abstract: The singer and the hit maker were entangled for three decades. He wanted chart-topping songs. But what did she want?
lead_paragraph: Downstairs at the Beverly Hilton hotel on Feb. 11, 2012, black cars delivered celebrities, among them Serena Williams, Britney Spears and Gayle King, to Clive Davis’s annual Grammys party. Upstairs in Room 434, the coroner’s office tended to the body of his biggest star, Whitney Houston, who had been found dead in the bathtub earlier that day. Police investigators removed empty bottles of liquor while the wails of her daughter, Bobbi Kristina Brown, could be heard down the hall.

headline: A Landscape at Peace With Man and Nature
abstract: On the edge of Peconic Bay, a low-key garden offers solace and requires little work.
lead_paragraph: The true test of a garden is how it looks in the rain. Any landscape is lovely garnished with blue skies and butterflies. But in a summer storm?

headline: Designing a Home Without Disrupting the Land’s Healing Energy
abstract: In Washington State, an interior designer and an artist team with an architect to blend light and material to design a house dedicated to the sun.
lead_paragraph: Agnes Bourne, an interior designer based in Jackson, Wyo., always loved to visit her sister’s rustic dwelling near Spokane, Wash. The 1890s log house was on an astonishing site: next to a lake full of trout, deep within a thousand acres of unlogged forests of Douglas firs and Ponderosa pines. It was filled with open skies, eagles, ospreys, wildflowers and giant boulders, some marked with Native American petroglyphs.

headline: In Russia, Refusing to Disappear in a Crowd
abstract: Long gone are the days of party-issued uniforms and uninspired Soviet style. In Moscow and Kazan, the photographer Sasha Arutyunova captured the Russian sartorial ambition to stand out through bold colors, vintage or handmade items and eye-catching patterns.
lead_paragraph: “I feel really connected to Moscow, but I also still feel a little bit like a tourist,” Sasha Arutyunova said. Ms. Arutyunova, who lives in Brooklyn, was born in Moscow in 1988, a few years before the Soviet Union collapsed and during an era when Levi’s were still a coveted item in the country. She moved to Florida with her mother when she was 6 years old.

headline: After the Vote, Does the Kurdish Dream of Independence Have a Chance?
abstract: Iraq’s Kurds voted overwhelmingly for an independent state, but their territory lacks democratic institutions, and their troubled economy is dependent on hostile neighbors.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — After a century of yearning, the Kurds of Iraq have managed, at last, to pull off a vote for independence, but not without antagonizing nearly everyone in perhaps the world’s most volatile region.

headline: In a Warming World, Keeping the Planes Running
abstract: Sea walls, longer runways and lighter plane loads could add major expenses for a global industry that transports billions of passengers a year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Airports are a major global business, part of an industry that by one estimate transports the equivalent of nearly half the world’s population in a single year.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: One Day in the Life of Battered Puerto Rico
abstract: A team of New York Times reporters and photographers spent 24 hours with people trying to survive the catastrophe that Hurricane Maria left behind in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: A team of New York Times reporters and photographers spent 24 hours with people trying to survive the catastrophe that Hurricane Maria left behind in Puerto Rico.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Trump Lashes Out at Puerto Rico Mayor Who Criticized Storm Response
abstract: In a series of tweets, the president accused the mayor of San Juan of “poor leadership” and implied that Puerto Rico should do more to help itself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump lashed out at the mayor of San Juan on Saturday for criticizing his administration’s efforts to help Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria, accusing her of “poor leadership” and implying that the people of the devastated island were not doing enough to help themselves.

headline: A Fight for Catalonia, Whatever That Means
abstract: Spaniards who never thought much about national identity and separatism are being forced to now.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The question of secession that is being put to voters in Spain’s Catalonia region on Sunday is being seen as a political confrontation between Madrid and Barcelona, or Spain versus Catalonia.

headline: U.S. in Direct Communication With North Korea, Says Tillerson
abstract: The confirmation marks the first time the Trump administration has acknowledged it is in contact with Pyongyang without the help of an intermediary.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Trump administration acknowledged on Saturday for the first time that it was in direct communication with the government of North Korea over its missile and nuclear tests, seeking a possible way forward beyond the escalating threats of a military confrontation from both sides.

headline: In Crimea, Russian Land Grab Feeds Cries of ‘Carpetbaggers!’
abstract: In storied Sevastopol, government effort to confiscate land distributed free under Ukraine adds to long list of grievances over Russian rule.
lead_paragraph: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea — More than three years after Russia snatched Crimea from Ukraine, the peninsula is suffering through an extended season of discontent.

headline: As Argentine Elections Approach, Two Disturbing Mysteries Loom
abstract: A report says that a prosecutor investigating a 1994 bombing was murdered, and the disappearance of an activist stirs memories of the dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Only a few weeks ago, Argentina’s midterm election was shaping up to be a duel over economic policy.

headline: A First Date Begins, a Bit Prematurely, at the Bus Stop
abstract: They connected online and decided to meet at a restaurant. What they didn’t know was that they were neighbors and both used mass transit.
lead_paragraph: Staci Rachel-Helén Maiers was married Sept. 28 to Christopher John Woods in Maui, Hawaii. The Rev. Michael Roland Lopez Sr., a minister with House of Bread International Christian Fellowship and Ministries, officiated at the Olowalu Plantation House.

headline: It Happened in Real Life, Unscripted
abstract: Alexis Gregorian, a federal prosecutor, and Jay Lavender, a writer and producer, got straight to the heart of their story.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Danielle Gregorian and Jay Lavender were married Sept. 30 at Castle Hill Cider, an event space in Charlottesville, Va. Capt. William N. Marshall Sr., the chief deputy sheriff of the Charlottesville Sheriff’s Office, received permission from Virginia to officiate, with Meredith Lavender Wilson, the sister of the groom, taking part.

headline: She Had Questions. He Had No Answers. Flirting Began.
abstract: The couple met when he was the media contact for a story she was covering.
lead_paragraph: Sonia Moghe and Eric Douglas Koch were married Sept. 30 in West Dennis, Mass. Pandit Jayant Sane, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Lighthouse Inn, in a ceremony that also included the Greek wedding tradition of placing crowns on the heads of the bride and the groom.

headline: ‘Little Lobbyists’ Help Save the Health Care Law, for Now
abstract: Children with complex medical conditions helped their parents beat back Republican proposals to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anna C. Corbin had not been involved in politics, had not even been to the Capitol before this year. But since March, she has made the two-hour drive here from her home in Hanover, Pa., 15 times so her sons, Jackson and Henry, could lobby against efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.

headline: How Two Sentences in Tax Plan May Help Unleash $1 Billion in Lobbying
abstract: Two sentences in the nine-page Republican framework have K Street salivating over the payday to come.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sweeping tax rewrite unveiled by President Trump and Republican lawmakers this past week leaves many of the details to Congress, but two sentences in the nine-page framework have Washington lobbyists salivating over a payday that some industry experts predict could top $1 billion.

headline: Acne Studios: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: M.L.B. Awards: Who Deserves to Win
abstract: Judge or Altuve? Kluber or Sale? Kershaw or Scherzer? Our columnist names his picks for baseball’s biggest honors.
lead_paragraph: The division races offered little suspense this season. Most of the winners are repeat champions, and the Houston Astros, who missed the playoffs last fall, ran away with the American League West.

headline: How Saudi Women Fought for the Right to Drive
abstract: Women in Saudi Arabia have been fighting for the right to drive for 30 years. Four key milestone moments paved the way for the surprise overturning of the ban by the country's king. Meet the women behind the movement.
lead_paragraph: Women in Saudi Arabia have been fighting for the right to drive for 30 years. Four key milestone moments paved the way for the surprise overturning of the ban by the country's king. Meet the women behind the movement.

headline: Catalonia’s Independence Referendum, in Photographs
abstract: Hundreds were injured in clashes with the police as Catalans tried to vote in a referendum that Madrid considered illegal.
lead_paragraph: Catalonia, the restive northeastern region that is Spain’s economic powerhouse, attempted to hold an independence referendum on Sunday.

headline: Catalans Camp at Voting Sites as Independence Confrontation Looms
abstract: Scores of polling stations were occupied by people intent on keeping them open for Sunday’s independence referendum in defiance of the Spanish government.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — A confrontation in Catalonia drew closer on Saturday, as people camped out in scores of polling stations throughout the region, intent on keeping them open for Sunday’s referendum in defiance of the Spanish government’s orders.

headline: Trump’s Next Move on Health Care? Choice for Secretary May Offer Clue
abstract: The selection of a successor for Tom Price, who resigned as secretary of health and human services, could be a turning point in the debate over health care.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s selection of a secretary of health and human services could be a turning point in a health care debate that has polarized Washington, as he faces a choice of working with Democrats to fix the current system or continuing his so-far failed efforts to dismantle his predecessor’s program.

headline: Shifts Get Real: Understanding the GOP’s Policy Quagmire
abstract: Lies and willful ignorance catch up with them, again.
lead_paragraph: Right now it looks as if tax “reform” — actually it’s just cuts — may go the way of Obamacare repeal. Initial assessments of the plan are brutal, and administration attempts to spin things in a positive direction will suffer from loss of credibility on multiple fronts, from obvious lies about the plan itself, to spreading corruption scandals, to the spectacle of the tweeter-in-chief golfing while Puerto Rico drowns.

headline: Who Can Beat Trump in 2020?
abstract: A field guide for Democrats desperate to paint the White House blue.
lead_paragraph: A field guide for Democrats desperate to paint the White House blue.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon escape in a cloud of ink.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic, by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, is an excerpt from an ode to a beast that has become a bit of a 21st-century folk hero, one of those honey badger types with a natural social media savvy and extensive public relations skills, who can engineer an image makeover from a sinister deep-sea strangler to a winsome oddsmaker. And there’s this:

headline: China Tries to Steer Loans to Small Businesses
abstract: Chinese banks have balance sheets bloated with loans to big state-owned enterprises. The central bank is nudging them to lend more to smaller rivals.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China announced a move on Saturday aimed at addressing a vexing problem: how to steer more bank loans to small businesses while adding little to the country’s huge debt load.

headline: Democrats, Please Get Ready to Lose
abstract: To prevail in 2020, the party can’t put too much faith in 2018.
lead_paragraph: There’s a saying that what matters isn’t winning or losing. It’s whether you beat the spread.

headline: Professors Behaving Badly
abstract: Maybe it’s not left-wing politics. Maybe it’s bleak employment prospects.
lead_paragraph: Is there something about adjunct faculty members that makes them prone to outrageous political outbursts?

headline: America’s 8-Step Program for Opioid Addiction
abstract: The president hasn’t declared an emergency, but one exists. Here are some crucial measures to break its grip.
lead_paragraph: Opioid addiction has developed such a powerful grip on Americans that some scientists have blamed it for lowering our life expectancy.

headline: Vivienne Westwood: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: The Wrong Pill Can Play With Your Mind
abstract: For me, the same medication, in subtly different forms, was like night and day.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was 16, I was admitted to U.C.L.A.’s neuropsychiatric institute. I’d been suffering from increasing paranoia (I thought war was imminent; I thought I would be called into battle) and lack of sleep (I paced our staircase into the early hours of morning). Most profoundly, I thought my parents were actually secret agents, wearing masks, sent to monitor my behavior.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Speaking Ill of Hugh Hefner
abstract: An honest obituary for a wicked American.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hefner, gone to his reward at the age of 91, was a pornographer and chauvinist who got rich on masturbation, consumerism and the exploitation of women, aged into a leering grotesque in a captain’s hat, and died a pack rat in a decaying manse where porn blared during his pathetic orgies.

headline: Dear Amazon: Please Build Here
abstract: Readers make pitches for the city it should pick for its second headquarters. But a Seattle reader cautions, “Be careful what you wish for.”
lead_paragraph: Amazon is often promoting the idea of improving the world. Therefore its second headquarters should do that. Knowing that it is a game changer, Amazon should go to a Rust Belt city and forever alter the economy of the region. Take a good look at Pittsburgh or Cleveland. Both have had a renaissance and offer lovely downtowns, beautiful architecture, great waterfronts, beautiful parks, treelined streets, excellent cultural amenities, great public transportation and pro sports teams. Even better, they have great colleges and medical facilities.

headline: What the Cubs Could Teach the President
abstract: Just about every quality that makes Donald Trump a nightmare in governance could be cured by a few summers at Wrigley Field.
lead_paragraph: We wouldn’t be in this mess if Donald Trump were a Cubs fan.

headline: Catalonia Readies for Volatile and Unpredictable Vote
abstract: A vote on secession is being put to voters in Spain’s Catalonia region on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A vote on secession is being put to voters in Spain’s Catalonia region on Sunday.

headline: Want to Know What Divides This Country? Come to Alabama
abstract: It’s a state proud of how far it’s come, and yet it picked Roy Moore as a Senate nominee.
lead_paragraph: “Just wow,” Peggy and Mark Kennedy said to each other last week in Montgomery, Ala. On the TV, Roy Moore had just pulled a little pistol from a pocket of his cowboy costume to show his love for the Second Amendment. The next night he won the Republican nomination in the race to be their next senator.

headline: The Latin Mass, Thriving in Southeastern Nigeria
abstract: The older service appeals to the poor and links faraway lands to Rome, and Catholic traditions.
lead_paragraph: UMUAKA, Nigeria — In August, under a bright blue sky and in front of 2,500 worshipers, Bishop Gregory Ochiagha performed the first traditional Latin ordination in Nigeria since the vernacular liturgy was introduced after Vatican II. Near the end of the Mass, the 86-year-old bishop nearly fainted. “I am so happy, I am so happy,” he whispered as he was led to a chair.

headline: Erick Erickson: How to Find Common Ground
abstract: In the past year, I have come under fierce attack and my wife has come down with cancer — and I have learned the importance of real friendships.
lead_paragraph: A year ago my life went to hell. After I declared myself unable to support the election of Donald Trump because of my faith and conservative convictions, three protesters showed up on my front porch. They did not threaten physical harm. But they did express feelings of betrayal and declared their intention to ruin my career as a conservative talk radio host and writer. I needed to carefully reconsider, or else.

headline: Altuzarra: Spring 2018 rtw
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: Catalan Police Face Their Own Test of Independence
abstract: The Mossos d’Esquadra, an autonomous force, has been told to confront the very citizens who recently praised their response to terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — Catalonia’s police force faces a crucial test of its autonomy on Sunday, as it comes under orders from the national government in Madrid to prevent Catalans from voting on their independence.

headline: Thousands Rally in Dublin Against Ireland’s Abortion Ban
abstract: This year’s march occurred just days after the government announced that a referendum on the nation’s abortion law would be held next year.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people marched in Dublin on Saturday to demand an end to the country’s constitutional ban on abortion, one of the strictest such laws in the Western world.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda Says Trump Is ‘Going Straight to Hell’
abstract: The “Hamilton” creator, who has family in Puerto Rico, denounced the president for his outburst against San Juan’s mayor with the island still in crisis.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s criticism of the mayor of San Juan, P.R., drew sharp rebukes across social media on Saturday, including from Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator and original star of “Hamilton.”

headline: ‘The Social Contract Is Broken’: Inequality Becomes Deadly in Mexico
abstract: Security, the bedrock of the social order, has become deeply inequitable, fraying Mexican society and politics.
lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Viewed from above, greater Monterrey, with its corporate headquarters and golf resorts, appears as one city stretching between the mountains that surround it.

headline: China Fears India May Be Edging It Out in Culture Battle
abstract: As Beijing and Delhi vie for regional dominance by deploying various forms of soft power, a Bollywood movie becomes a huge hit in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One of the most popular movies in China over the summer ran 161 minutes, so long that it was sometimes shown with an intermission. Unlike Hollywood blockbusters, there were no special effects, speeding cars or epic battle scenes. Nor was the film a Chinese production with a Chinese cast.

headline: Statue’s Stolen Foot Reflects Divisions Over Symbols of Conquest
abstract: A conquistador’s statue in New Mexico that was vandalized 20 years ago remains a divisive symbol, one of a number of monuments drawing protests from Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: ALCALDE, N.M. — The mystery figure appeared at twilight at a rendezvous point in a clearing of piñon trees. He opened his rucksack and revealed plunder hidden for 20 years: the bronze right foot, including spur and stirrup, severed from a statue of Don Juan de Oñate, the despotic conquistador of New Mexico.

headline: Engine Explodes on an Air France Plane, Forcing an Emergency Landing
abstract: The plane bound for Los Angeles from Paris landed safely at a small airport in Labrador, Canada.
lead_paragraph: An Air France flight bound for Los Angeles from Paris made an emergency landing in Canada on Saturday after one of the jumbo jet’s four engines exploded in midair, passengers said.

headline: Wild Card Game Awaits the Hot Yankees as Their A.L. East Hopes End
abstract: Aaron Judge hit his 52nd home run in a win over Toronto, but the Red Sox clinched the division title by beating the Astros.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees’ pursuit of the American League East title officially ended late Saturday afternoon when the Boston Red Sox completed a 6-3 victory over the Houston Astros for their 93rd win of the season, a mark the Yankees cannot match. Unofficially, the chase ended about an hour earlier, when the Red Sox opened a 5-0 lead, rendering the Yankees’ 2-0 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays essentially meaningless.

headline: Sonia Rykiel: Spring 2018
abstract: The label shows its spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The label shows its spring looks.

headline: When Budget Vacations Are Your Job
abstract: The Times’s Frugal Traveler shares his tricks, including his go-to cheap-trip recommendation, and when a splurge is worth it.
lead_paragraph: My tenure as the Frugal Traveler columnist began inauspiciously. My first official frugal assignment, to Las Vegas, went smoothly enough. But during my second, to Hawaii, I blew out two tires driving on a remote, cell-service-free part of the island, had to be towed 140 miles back to the rental car desk, and was slapped with a $1,500 bill. On my third trip, my bus from Chicago to Milwaukee erupted into a ball of flames. “Someone doesn’t want you to have this job,” a friend suggested.

headline: In the Rangers’ Roster Shuffle, a Teenager Emerges
abstract: Filip Chytil, an 18-year-old Czech center, was a first-round draft pick in June, and he is likely to make the lineup when the N.H.L. season opens this week.
lead_paragraph: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault has a favorite phrase when considering roster decisions: “Talent has no age.”

headline: Monty Hall, Co-Creator and Host of ‘Let’s Make a Deal,’ Dies at 96
abstract: A smooth-talking personality and ad-libber, he presided over a rollicking game show that, with some interruptions, would last more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Monty Hall, the genial host and co-creator of “Let’s Make a Deal,” the game show on which contestants in outlandish costumes shriek and leap at the chance to see if they will win the big prize or the booby prize behind door No. 3, died at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Saturday. He was 96.

headline: For Manchester City, Slim Victory at Chelsea Speaks to a Wider Goal
abstract: Kevin De Bruyne’s goal lifted City to a 1-0 victory, but the comprehensive nature of the visitors’ performance may have been even more important.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few days before Manchester City met Chelsea for the first time last season — a game that, in hindsight, would mark out the latter as Premier League champions-in-waiting and the former as a work in progress — Pep Guardiola came to a realization.

headline: That’s One Way to Put It
abstract: Robert Fisher’s glass is tremendously full, of something delicious.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a dense puzzle, even for a Sunday, and puzzlers may note with trepidation that four of the six theme answers span or nearly span the entire grid, despite having the briefest of clues.

headline: Inside the Latest Power Struggle at Uber
abstract: A proposal to the board by Uber’s new chief, Dara Khosrowshahi, and Goldman Sachs would reduce the voting clout of the ex-C.E.O., Travis Kalanick.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The phone calls began late Friday among Uber’s new chief executive, Dara Khosrowshahi, and the ride-hailing company’s executives, as well as board members and a raft of lawyers. They were facing an emergency.

headline: Who Is Carmen Yulín Cruz, the Puerto Rican Mayor Criticized by Trump?
abstract: On the island, the outspokenness of the liberal mayor, who tends to speak in blunt and emotional terms, has come as little surprise.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — When Carmen Yulín Cruz was a long-shot candidate for mayor here in 2012, she cast herself as a “pitirre,” a small bird known for fearlessly attacking larger ones.

headline: Phil Mickelson, With Family in Tow, Breaks a Presidents Cup Record
abstract: Mickelson’s wife, Amy, and two of their children looked on as he took the record for the most career wins in the event and as the United States nearly finished off the International team.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Spectators ringed the 17th green at Liberty National on Saturday, many of them yelling terms of endearment at Phil Mickelson. “Hoboken loves you, Phil,” one said. But Mickelson played his Presidents Cup foursomes match, a record breaker, primarily for an audience of three.
